column2: Retail trade lacked a pattern last week. Sales pursued an irregular trend, showing a modest gain one week followed by small decreases for several weeks, as compared with 1960. One major department store in downtown Kansas City has converted to a discount store and operators of traditional sporting goods, drug and jewelry stores are entering the leased field in a big way.
Mayor Wagner accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of "a grandstand play" in deciding to convene a special session of the Legislature to deal with city school problems.

STUDENTS of Marion Palfi's class in "Social Research With Photography," which starts Sept. 28 at the New School, 66 West Twelfth Street, will be assigned a term-long project to document life in Greenwich Village.
HOLLYWOOD. WHENEVER an English play is imported to Broadway there are discussions of what changes will be necessary to make the drama palatable for American audiences.

While Geoffrey Gorer's explanation of the reason for many Americans' boastful attitude about being in analysis is amusing, it seems a bit far-fetched. The reason is more likely that they are proud of being able to make the often painful alterations in their modes of thought and behavior which enable them to live more useful and happier lives.

Marya Mannes, in "They're Cultural, But Are They Cultured?" (July 9), when referring to artistic talents, asserts that the Soviets "provide enormous incentives to develop them." Sidney Harth, in the report on his trip to the Soviet Union, "Fifty Rubles a Week," states that the average salary in a Soviet orchestra is between forty and fifty rubles per week (the equivalent of about fifty dollars a week).
NEWARK, Aug. 12 -- Opponents of the state Highway Department's alignment of the proposed Route 78 through Newark have won the support of their representatives in Washington and county officials.

A BOOK written by a dying man about the final months of his life might seem forbidding at first glance. Thomas Bell, however, was a sensitive and perceptive novelist, and his random thoughts during the trying period often contain a rare beauty of understanding, plus at wry touch that makes them delightful.

THE first novel about John Wilkes Booth was published anonymously in Paris in 1865, the year Booth shot Lincoln. Since then, novels about Lincoln (juveniles discounted) have outnumbered novels about Booth eleven to one.
America, the Jesuit weekly, has editorially assailed William F. Suckley Jr., editor of the conservative National Review, for criticizing Mater et Magistra, the Papal encyclical on social issues.

Premier Khrushchev has said many strange things this past week -- some so strange that his own press has thought it better not to print them. He has threatened the world with a bomb equivalent to 100,000,000 tons of TNT, as though the bombs already in existence were not far more than enough to bring catastrophe upon all life on this planet.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Beau Prince scored his second straight stakes triumph in two Saturdays when he won the $83,400 Travers Stakes today.
American business men and many large hotels are making a generally ignored activity -- breakfast -- pay dividends.

HAVANA, Aug. 12 -- Three musicians in extravagant, B-movie dress still wait under large billboards painted with revolutionary slogans and sing to visitors arriving at the airport here. A young militiaman still taps his feet to the music as he sits guard with a submachine gun.

The new 60,000-ton attack aircraft carrier Constellation started to take aboard her crew at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn yesterday. The first complement, 970 enlisted men and fifty officers, moved into quarters on the $200,000,000 ship, which was seriously damaged by fire last Dec. 19.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 12 -- Four years ago this week this tropical capital was teeming with diplomatic delegations, here for the Presidential inauguration of a mild-mannered brother of Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, the late dictator.

Business conditions in the Chicago area were good in July from almost every angle excepting profits, according to the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago. Earnings, which had shown a steady improvement since early in the year, slipped from June levels.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 12 -- Texas reluctantly joined this week the retail sales tax states. A desperate need for added revenue to meet rising governmental costs forced adoption of "the last resort levy."
Four Federal agencies are helping American ships make a safe landfall anywhere in the world through reliable marine maps.

Following is the text of a statement by Governor Rockefeller on the city school situation, issued yesterday by his office here. It includes a report made to him by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., Commissioner of Education.

EASTHAM, Mass. -- The United States has another National Park, and this one is in the East. When President Kennedy signed the bill last week authorizing the Cape Cod National Seashore Park, he made it possible to open up and preserve for the people an unusual historical, biological and geological treasure house.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 -- Susan Doerr, a 16-year-old Philadelphia schoolgirl, cracked a five-hour-old world record today in winning the national 100-meter butterfly title. She was timed in 1 minute 8.2 seconds in the Amateur Athletic Union women's national outdoor swimming championships.

David Frisch's article on disarmament ("Between Futile Strength and Surrender," July 30) expresses a civilized attitude of calm reasonableness altogether too rare in the contemporary public forum. His premises, however, require examination.

SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 12 -- The Santa Fe Opera presented one of its regular productions last night. That is, it gave "The Marriage of Figaro," a standard work that is now in the company's repertory for the second summer.
THIS being the time of season when everyone seems to be taking pot shots at records, there is no reason why one more bystander shouldn't get into the act.
LIME ROCK, Conn., Aug. 12 (AP) -- C.R. Hagy of New Hope, Pa., took first today in the Formula III event, and Tim Mayer of Daton, Pa., captured the Formula Junior race at Lime Rock Park.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 12 -- The American weather satellite Tiros III is giving valuable assistance to meteorologists in New Zealand.

The annual New Hope (Pa.) antique and classic auto show, with its attendant sports car rallies, gymkhanas, flea market for auto sales and other events, will be held on Saturday and Sunday, Aug. 26 and 27.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Huntington-Northport of Long Island defeated the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today in a Luders-16 Class interfleet team match, a new event on the calendar, on Long Island Sound off Indian Harbor Y.C. The score was 32-28 1/4.
When William Schifrin walks through the crowded streets of New York he rarely notices people's faces, but he always sees if their limbs are bedecked with baubles, bangles or beads.

The situation in the stores around the country last week was much like the weather -- wilted. One merchant in this city commented that the air-conditioning in his store was the most attractive feature, luring customers who had had about as much of the searing heat as they could take.
The adult who is immune to measles because of a childhood attack of the disease may actually be harboring a mild lifelong infection, a specialist has suggested.

This is now the overriding question: Will Premier Khrushchev negotiate in good faith? Spelled out, this means: How sincere is he about moderating the cold war and what concessions is he prepared to make?
THE largest group of expert bridge players to gather in any one place anywhere in the world is that which assembles for the summer national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League.

When the Department of Commerce appointed four advertising agencies last week to do the initial research and planning for the newly-established United States Travel Service, it started Madison Avenue on a formidable venture.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- Premier Khrushchev said in Moscow yesterday that it was a fairy tale that the West would fight for West Berlin. But the Berlin command -- the 5,000-man force of the United States Army here -- has a different idea.

PANAMA, Aug. 12 -- As its first year is nearing a close, President Roberto F. Chiari's Administration is making considerable advances over previous regimes in its social program, but economic progress is not keeping pace.

Dr. Albert Szent-Gyorgyi's "Secret of Creative Impulse" (July 30) should be read and read again by all long-range strategist in the field of education and research. The average young American admires the heroes at the ball games or young stars of the entertainment world.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell pitched a five-hitter today as the Pirates handed the Philadelphia Phillies their fifteenth straight defeat -- the longest losing streak in the club's history. The score was 4-0.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Kennedy Administration showed signs this week that it was finally resigned to prolonged and bitter cold war with the Communist world in which propaganda will have to be fused with policy.
The old and forgotten man sat in an East Side nursing home last week and talked of the past he loved so much.

THERE is a cruel irony in the fact that the only unqualified success achieved by the late Marquis de Cuevas in the more than fifteen years of his International Ballet was his last Production, "The Sleeping Beauty," to the Paris premiere of which last October he was literally carried on his deathbed.

It is really no good looking at the word "negotiation" as an incantation that can be repeated and will solve everything. If from the start there is no hope of getting an agreement, it is worse than no negotiation at all. Therefore the problem wants looking at extremely carefully to see whether it is profitable to get into a negotiation and if so when.
Maj. Yuri Gagarin's space flight last April has caused some changes in the curriculum of Soviet middle schools, according to a recent speech by Professor N. Suvorov, a Russian educator.
United States-flag tankers trading from the Gulf of Mexico to the East Coast accounted for the bulk of domestic petroleum traffic on oceangoing vessels in the first four months of the year.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Thinking Man, owned by Theodore D. Buhl of Lexington, Ky., defeated Bushel-n-Peck in a photo finish of the $21,800 Olympia Handicap at Arlington Park today.
WHEN in doubt or panic, says the rule-book, proceed slowly, exactly, methodically. Let us so proceed with Michael Hastings' new novel, beginning by listing some of its main characters.

The annual display of celestial fireworks, known as the Perseid meteors, lighted the skies last week. They began on Wednesday and reached a climax early yesterday, streaking across the sky every minute by the hundreds of thousands.

The big aircraft, missile and electronic companies are not the only ones that stand to benefit from the space age. Many small and medium-size concerns are also in a position to reap financial gains from the nation's accelerating space program.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, proposed today that the status of Berlin be submitted to the United Nations for a decision on Western and Soviet treaty rights.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Republicans will seek to drive home to the party faithful at four regional meetings the lessons of defeat in the 1960 Presidential election.
The fifty millionth passenger to use New York International Airport since it opened July 1, 1948, was expected to arrive or depart there tomorrow morning, the Port of New York Authority said.

A pedestrian was killed yesterday by an out-of-control stolen car as he walked on a sidewalk. A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth, identified by the police as the driver, was held on charges of automobile theft and leaving the scene of an accident.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Lou Monge of Las Cruces, N.M., birdied the second extra hole today to win a sudden-death play-off for the National Amputees golf championship. He defeated Burgess Windsor of Stockton, Calif.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 12 -- Detroit unleashed a seventeen-hit attack today to smash the Minnesota Twins, 17 -- 3. Chico Fernandez drove in five runs and Norm Cash brought in four as the Tigers cut loose for six runs in the fourth, five more in the eighth and four in the ninth.

FOR a society which takes for granted the concept of human evolution and uses "Neanderthal man" as a household word, we have given strangely little thought to mankind's evolution in the future. It is almost as if we conceived that evolution, having produced Homo sapiens, could go no further and, having dusted off its hands, had called it a day.

ATHENS, Aug. 12 -- A large pagan temple and parts of life-size cult statues dating from the twelfth century B.C. have been discovered by an American archaeological expedition on Kea Island, forty-two miles southeast of Athens.

The letter which you published on July 30 from William P. Yohe, Assistant Professor of Economics at Duke University, coupled the name of Veritas Foundation with the John Birch Society and Operation Alert as fugitives from reality. As a trustee of the Veritas Foundation (which has no connection with the two other organizations).
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday he would call a special session of the Legislature to consider the replacement of the New York City Board of Education.

ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers broke a 10-10 tie with two touchdowns in the first two minutes 38 seconds of the second half tonight and whipped the Baltimore Colts, 24 -- 20. It was the opening exhibition for both National Football League clubs.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 12 -- A forty-three-mile, star-shaped course marked the eleventh annual Shrewsbury River Yacht Club contest, held today for the national express cruiser championship. John Gans, in his Miaha, was the winner of this thirty-boat competition. His accuracy score was 99.647 per cent.
BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- The stream of refugees into West Berlin became larger this week than in any post-war year except 1953, when discontent caused open rebellion.
HAVANA, Aug. 12 -- The Cuban Government charged today that a large stock of arms had been transferred from the United States naval base at Guantanamo to the anti-Castro underground in Santiago.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Aug. 12 -- Maj. Ernesto Guevara of Cuba shared a picnic table with a Roman Catholic Bishop today at a brief pause in the Inter-American Economic and Social Conference.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- John Brophy, one of the leaders in the drive to organize mass production industries in the Nineteen-Thirties, was hailed today by President Kennedy and union leaders as a "labor pioneer."

MONTICELLO, N.Y. -- Sullivan County, which has been sports-minded ever since the days when croquet was the popular pastime more than fifty years ago, is bidding to become one of the golf capitals of the world. The modest croquet lawn has made way or a collection of golf courses that is said to make the southern Catskills one of the busiest rural links areas in the world.

THE British Crown Colony of Fiji, encompassing more than 300 islands in the Southwest Pacific Ocean, desirous of giving a new look to its previously announced definitive series of stamps, turned to a prize-winning artist for the design of the first of the group, an 8-pence released last Tuesday.
The Port of New York Authority last week voted to award, then changed its mind and withdrew a contract to expand the central heating and refrigeration plant at New York International Airport.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 10 -- President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes, who has faced a balky Legislature and repeated revolutionary attempts for the greater part of his time in office, now appears to be in the strongest position since becoming President in 1958.

ROME, -- An American tourist in Rome cannot do as the Romans do because it takes a quality peculiar to the Italians to live their way. The next best thing is for the visitor to experience Italy in the catalytic company of, and through the eyes of, an Italian friend.

THE title of this first novel by David Madden, an English teacher at Centre College in Kentucky, is taken from Conrad's "Lord Jim." This suggests at the start that the author intends to recapitulate the Conrad theme -- and, to some degree, this proves to be the ease.
WITH a Swiss father, a French mother, Spain as a birthplace, an Austrian wife and twenty-five years' residence in England, Roberto Gerhard considers himself an international person.

RICHARD LLEWELLYN certainly gets around. He began his "bestselling" career with the famous "How Green Was My Valley," about his native Wales. His last book was laid in Patagonia. Now he has written a long work about a native tribe of Kenya.

THE introduction in New York of a sight-seeing bus equipped with a multi-lingual sound track was reported here last week. Now comes more good news for foreign visitors. The Museum of Modern Art has published a folder, printed in French, Spanish and English, describing the purpose of the museum and the nature of its exhibitions.

THIS volume, the editors say, "is a description of the seas and crust of our planet Earth, and the story of how they came to be what they are; and it is a description of the plants and animals of the earth, and the story of how they evolved; and it is a description of the web of life, and the story of how man arose, to become part of it, finally to dominate it."

THERE was a Berlin crisis, a Tunisian crisis and a space shot that was always in the offing the first week that John Chancellor became a television fixture. Ordinarily none of these events would ruffle the surface of an "I Love Lucy," a "Gunsmoke" or a "Dinah Shore Show."
TRENTON, Aug. 12 -- When New Jersey's public schools reopen next month they will face far greater problems than they did a decade ago, an analysis showed today.

A new kind of "ultimate weapon" that is infinitely less terrible than any such nuclear device conceived so far has been invented by a young theoretical physicist at one of the nation's leading weapons laboratories.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- More than 31,000,000 persons now live in the East Coast belt of cities and suburbs that stretches without interruption from New Hampshire to Virginia. Similar belts are developing in the South, Midwest and West.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 -- Johnny Podres registered his fifteenth victory of the season with a five-hitter tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 5 -- 1.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 12 -- With elections only three days away, Israeli politicians turned to the main cities today for their final campaigning.
SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican candidate for Mayor, came up into the Catskills today and beat the bushes for votes.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 12 -- Merry Ruler won the $32,050 Ventnor Turf Handicap by a neck today at the Atlantic City track in a driving finish.
PARIS, Aug. 12, -- This year's longest week-end emptied Paris of Parisians today and filled it with policemen.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Mike Belkin, a sturdy 16-year-old from Miami Beach, rallied today to edge Dave Reed, 18, in five sets in the boys' division of the junior tennis tournament.
TRENTON, Aug. 12 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today called the Legislature into a special session on Aug. 28.

A newly incorporated company has approached maritime unions to determine manning scales for reestablishing a pas-scales for re-establishing a pas-official publication of the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union reports.
The Maryland Cup Corporation offers proof that a family-run business can become a big business -- if the family is big enough.

The domestic cotton industry has entered the new crop year in a favorable position. The surplus of former years has been reduced to manageable proportions and the Federal Government has relaxed its strict control over the marketing of the fiber.
If a Nassau County resident files suit in an accident case tomorrow and asks for a jury trial he may expect to have his case heard in January, 1967.
Contemporary racial and medical problems were considered here last week as the National Medical Association held its sixty-sixth convention at the Commodore Hotel.
VIENNA, Aug. 11 -- Communist Rumania has reported that her collectivized agriculture is showing large production increases.
Harold W. Smith has been appointed an assistant vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company. He had been assistant treasurer and deputy Far East representative.
An $18,000,000-a-year program for distribution of Federal surplus food to home-relief and low-income families here will get under way next Tuesday.

DETROIT -- Automobile assembly lines and the pennant-contending Tigers may have to give ground in September as leading attractions for visitors to Detroit. The annual Michigan State Fair gets under way here on Sept. 1 and, before it ends ten days later, it will not be surprising if a young lady named Annie Oakley is voted the most popular girl at the event, posthumously or otherwise.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- The chimes reverberated precisely at noon and the chief propaganda voice of communism said: "Moscow Speaks!"
Of all types of disabling conditions, hearing loss, the nation's leading cause of disability, is one of the least understood.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Aug. 12 (AP) -- More men, machines and equipment were thrown into battle today at a furious rate as the 101st Airborne Division, acting the part of an aggressor, strove to make headway against other United States troops in war games in North Carolina and South Carolina.
WASHINGTON, Aug., 12 -- (UPI) -- Congress will soon take its first look at organized gambling since 1951, when Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, headed an investigation.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 12 -- The Government appeared today to have firmly shut the door on the possibility of collaborating with private United States interests in oil exporation in western India near the Pakistani frontier.
More than 4,000 Brooklyn dock workers plan to seek Governor Rockefeller's aid this week in their protest against "discriminatory tactics" by the State Division of Employment.
The White House several days ago made public the contents of a score of letters President Kennedy received in reply to his request for ideas on how to handle foreign policy.
AN impeccably dressed gentleman with a reassuring voice looked down gravely at his audience one afternoon this week and said: "Let's play bingo!"
A sympathy demonstration for Freedom Riders in the form of a twenty-four-hour "fast and vigil" began at 9 A.M. yesterday in Battery Park.
FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 12 -- Champion Pixietown Serenade of Hadleigh, a tiny Pomeranian, went best in show at the thirteenth annual Cape Cod Kennel Club fixture today.
PARIS, Aug. 11 -- The United States has changed its approach in inducing the more prosperous nations of Europe to assume fair shares of aid to under-developed nations.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles defeated the Boston Red Sox tonight, 8-3, for their seventh victory in eight games against Boston at Baltimore.

When Dr. Alvin M. Weinberg, in "Big Science -- Marvel or Menace?" (July 23), denounced science's preoccupation with space flight, he ignored a psychological factor. Russia's desire to explore space reflects her national confidence, while the reluctance of the United States shows the lack of confidence of the people.

For a man who shuns publicity, Howard Hughes probably has had more than most business men in the last year. He was in the financial news head-lines for months last year while negotiating the three-man trusteeship that now runs Trans World Airlines.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- William Simpson's white-hulled yawl Elda from the Greenwich Yacht Club was the scratch boat today as the fourteenth annual Port Washington Y.C. two-day race to Huntington Bay and back opened.
A team of New York University archeologists has received permission from Turkey to excavate an ancient city in Turkey.

FOR children, there is a poetry in sounds that makes them shake, rattle and tumble. "What can be explained is not poetry," and what makes a child laugh the poet Carl Sandburg said is an elusive secret.
International trade is gaining increased prominence as a part in the Kennedy Administration's strategy related both directly and indirectly to rising East-West tensions.

The katydid is a green grasshopper with a built-in fiddle that can play only one monotonous three-note tune. But nature so managed matters that the katydid has a reputation as a weather prophet, a reputation actually about as dubious as that of the woodchuck or the woolly bear caterpillar. In fact, whoever wrote the lyrics for the katydid's tune missed a bet by not using the words, "Frost is near," or "Six more weeks."

One of the basic tasks in building up underdeveloped countries is the stamping out of illiteracy. Last week UNESCO published a new manual on Literacy Primers (113 pp., $1.25). Familiarity of subject and pictorial simplicity are the keys to successful self-instruction or teaching by inexperienced instructors.
The appointment of Dr. Robert K. Merton as chairman of the Columbia University Department of Sociology was announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 10 -- Last March, Georg Mueller decided the time had come to leave East Germany.
AN odd and disturbing vacuum has come into existence since Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, upbraided television programing as "a vast waste land."
CINCINNATI, Aug. 12 -- The City of Cincinnati ordered full speed ahead this week on its first neighborhood rehabilitation and conservation program.

THE problem of a novelist in a dictatorship, hampered by a watchful censor in his desire to comment on his times, is solved these days in a number of ways. Thumbing the nose at the censor and going to jail may be the moist satisfying, but it is also the most expensive.
SEAN O'CASEY, whose singing prose and plays have enchanted readers and the-atregoers, now may do as much for movie audiences.

FOR millions of Americans, summertime is iced-tea time. Ironically, but perhaps suitably, this typically American beverage was invented by an Englishman. He had been trying unsuccessfully to sell hot tea at the St. Louis World's Fair in 1904.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 12 -- Desegregation will come for the first time this fall to at least eighteen Southern school districts, among them Atlanta and Dallas.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Capping Saratoga's sales week, fifty-seven horses of racing age, most of them in training, were disposed of today for a total $232,100. The average price was $4,072.

Consider a nuclear test ban treaty with a number of fixed monitoring stations inside the U.S.S.R., but with no "on-site" inspections at all. A treaty could be made under which suspicious seismic, acoustic, electromagnetic or radiological signals received by these monitoring stations would be reported to the countries participating in the treaty by even a small minority of the inspectors.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Ryne Duren, who won fame as a relief pitcher for the New York Yankees, hurled the first complete game of his big-league career today as the Los Angeles Angels shut out the Cleveland Indians, 3 -- 0. Duren gave three hits.

LONGBOAT KEY, Fla. -- Among the many sub-tropical islands that fringe Florida's west coast, one of the loveliest and most unusual is Longboat Key, which lies off the mainland between Sarasota and Bradenton and faces the setting sun as it disappears into the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico.
FORT ERIE, Ont., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Anita's son raced home an eight-length winner today in the $10,000 Auspicious Stakes at the Fort Erie Jockey Club, missing the track record by one fifth of a second.

MANDAN, N.D. -- This state is suffering from drought, but the vagaries of nature have not materially altered the vacation pattern for tourists driving through it. U.S. 10, which runs across the lower half of North Dakota, connects this city with Medora and Dickinson, west of here, and Bismarck, the state capital, six miles to the east.

TO Sidney Hook's excellent review of Prof. Wallace Mendelson's perceptive study of "Justices Black and Frankfurter: Conflict in the Court," I would add a brief footnote. Unanimity is hard to achieve but one would wish for greater amity among the justices.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Francis T. Hunter and Vincent Richards, two modern-era tennis stars, and three old-timers, Harold H. Hackett, Fred B. Alexander and Malcolm G. Chace, were elected to the national lawn tennis hall of fame today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Communist China is suffering from "widespread" livestock diseases, a United Nations report indicated today.
MOREHEAD CITY, N.C., Aug. 12 -- An eighty-five-foot patrol boat will start changing here soon from Navy gray to hospital white before going to Haiti to help fight a war against tuberculosis.
This year the English office of Justice of the Peace is six hundred years old. In 1361 under Edward III these officers were set up in every shire to help the central power to govern.

When Princeton University announced last week that it had received an anonymous gift of $35,000,000 for the establishment of a professional school for Government service, it stressed that special provisions would be made for the advanced training of public servants "in mid-career."

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 12 -- A study of proposals for a national park in southern Utah was failed to eliminate conflicts between park advocates and state officials who wish to foster industry in the canyon lands.
SOON regiments of first-time hunters will be considering taking to the fields during the hunting season. And for the first time they will be thinking seriously of buying a weapon.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 12 -- Residential users of Tennessee Valley Authority electricity bought more than 16,600 major appliances, valued above $3,500,000, during an appliance jamboree sponsored by ninety-five distributors of T.V.A. power during May.

The collapse of recent efforts to pass a public school aid bill must not be permitted to lead to desertion of this most important measure. The issue has not changed. The need is as critical as before. The Congress is still in session, and nothing should prevent it from passing a sound public school aid bill before it adjourns.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- The large-scale feeding of troops with food preserved by radiation is expected to begin within a few years, Maj. Gen. Webster Anderson, the Army's new Quartermaster General, said here this week.
Mayor Wagner campaigned in Queens yesterday with his wife, his running mates, their wives and the Wagnerettes -- cheerleaders who made the letters of his name resound at every corner.
ALBANY, Aug. 12 -- The state's campaign to keep billboards from blighting its expanding expressway system has run into a serious roadblock.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 12 -- If 20-year-old Hartmut Auer had his choice, he would be spending his nights playing the drums in a Frankfurt night club.

LA FERTE-GAUCHER, France, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The United States took a lead over the Soviet Union and France in the 1961 world sky-diving championship that opened today.

Marya Mannes contends that the millions who listen to concerts in the United States are receiving no cultural benefit from the experience. Her belief is echoed by Robert D. Levine in "Letters" (July 30). How do they know?
MODERN zinnias have a new look which is making them more popular than ever. There now are varieties compact in form, fine for cutting, or disease resistant.

It has been eight years this month (the Korean armistice went into effect July 27, 1953) since this Presidential greeting stirred much of the male population. Now it is again going to be a more familiar salutation.

IN the Washington office of the president of the Inter-American Development Bank -- one of the main instruments for lifting Latin America by her bootstraps out of her persistent backwardness -- hangs a small sign telling the visitor, "Be Brief: We Have Ten Years to Recoup."

HARTFORD, Aug. 12 -- Connecticut Democrats are still squabbling over Federal patronage.

PORTLAND, Me. SINCE today's column has to do with what might be called the ethics of historical fiction, and since I write from my favorite Eastern state, may I remind you of one or two factual fictions in our history which are not acceptable in the State of Maine?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Cuban Government will release Tuesday the Eastern Air Lines Electra airplane hijacked on July 24, the State Department announced tonight.

The recent speech of President Kennedy has been favorably received by much of the press in this country and in Western Europe, as well as by many individuals of importance in public life. We, as citizens and as scientists, regret to state that we are not able to share this enthusiasm.
DETROIT, Aug. 12 -- Contract negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the Big Three auto companies will move into a more critical phase next week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- In the eyes of the world, the two great powers seem to be playing a space-age counterpart of that childhood game of "take one giant step." And as with children different national interpretations are being made of how big a "giant step" really is and how many "baby steps" go to make up one "giant step."

BERLIN, Sunday, Aug. 13 -- More than 2,500 East Germans, fearing the closing the borders, had slipped through tight police controls into West Berlin yesterday. This brought the total to more than 150,000 this year.

The Soviet Cosmonaut, Gherman S. Titov, who orbited the earth in a space satellite seventeen times, experienced weightlessness about twenty-five hours. This compared with eighty-nine minutes of weightlessness experienced by the first Soviet cosmonaut and of about five minutes each experienced by the two American astronauts in their suborbital space flights.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 15 -- The General Assembly of the International Astronomical Union opened here today. It heard pleas from President Kennedy and Adlai E. Stevenson that the exploration of space be an international enterprise that could develop greater trust among nations of divergent ideologies.

BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Wednesday, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- The African nationalist Malawi Congress party, which is pledged to take Nyasaland out of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, surged toward a sweeping victory today in this British protectorate's first elections.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Harmon Killebrew, Bob Allison and Billy Martin smashed home runs tonight as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 9 -- 4.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The New York Titans of the American Football League today acquired Dick Christy, a halfback, from the Oakland Raiders in exchange for an end, Dave Ross. Christy is expected to arrive in camp in time for tomorrow's workout.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Juan Marichal of the San Francisco Giants gained his fifth triumph in a row tonight, beating the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 -- 2.

Gold was in demand yesterday, as it always is in a time of crisis. Worries over Berlin undoubtedly were behind the rise in the price of gold in London, where it sold at $35.16 1/8 an ounce, or about three-eighths of a cent above the preceding day's level.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- A Congressional inquiry into alleged racial discrimination by two major seamen's unions here was sought today by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
The market for prime debt securities was firm and inactive yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Kennedy Administration set out today to portray East Germany's closing of the border between East and West Berlin as a dramatic confession of Communist failure.

The United Accumulative Fund of Kansas City, Mo., reported yesterday that net assets on June 30 were $496,492,831, equal to $14.40 a share. This compared with assets of $411,051,835, or $21.57 a share on fewer shares outstanding, six months earlier.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15. (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 15 (UPI) -- A patrol boat brought here by defectors from Premier Fidel Castro's regime was handed back to Cuba today. The boat left Key West about the same time that an Eastern Air Lines crew landed at Havana to pick up a hijacked airliner.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points off to 6 up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

SEATTLE, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Ann Baker and Mary Lou Daniel, the co-medalists in the 1961 national girls' junior golf championship, won close matches today in the first round of match play on the Broadmoor course.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 15 -- New Jersey won the Metropolitan Golf Association junior triangular matches today by a wide margin.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- This city's controversial wel fare program was criticized today by an official of the merged labor movement as a system contributing to "misery, disease, crime and juvenile delinquency."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 -- In a major rift in the ranks of California's dominant Democrats, the state's Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, Robert I. McCarthy, resigned today. He said that the administration of Gov. Edmund G. Brown, who appointed him, was "spineless" and "sick."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Senate Elections subcommittee unanimously approved a resolution today in favor of shorter Presidential campaigns.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The first contract in the Government's new helium conservation program was signed today with the Helex Company, a subsidiary of the Northern Natural Gas Company, Omaha, Neb.

Kwame Nkrumah, President of Ghana, will have his political testament published Nov. 3 by Praeger under the title "I Speak of Freedom." The volume contains a selection from President Nkrumah's speeches linked by a narrative that presents his views on Ghana's independence -- political freedom followed by economical development and social regeneration.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Michael Burke of Cedar Hill led the advance in the first round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association match-play championship today at the Somerset Hills Country Club.
Acting to strengthen their shaky quarterback position, the New York Giants of the National Football League yesterday obtained Y.A. Tittle from the San Francisco Forty-Niners.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 15 -- The New Haven Railroads trustees today petitioned a Federal court for permission to continue pension payments of $28,000 a month to 310 persons.

Cornell Mills, Inc., a textile company, has leased space for a sales office in the W.T. Grant Building at 1441 Broadway, corner of Forty-first Street. The Cross Brown Company is the agent for the building.

Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, yesterday challenged the Waterfront Commission to prove its contention that 30 per cent of the union's officers had criminal records.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Stuart Brayshaw of Babylon Yacht Club, second to Bobby Locke in the qualifying round, won the first race today in the round-robin competition for the midget sailing championship of Great South Bay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Justice Department pressed the Interstate Commerce Commission today to adopt Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy's recommendations for ending segregation in interstate bus travel.

This year marks the hundredth anniversary of the Government Printing Office. In a field mostly reserved to private initiative, public ownership and operation, it has created in Washington perhaps the largest and most complex printing establishment in the world.

The name of Jacob T. Zuckerman, an attorney, of 815 Avenue J. Brooklyn, was substituted yesterday with the Board of Elections as the Kings County Liberal party candidate for Borough President. Le Roy Bowman earlier had declined the nomination.
Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, Pennsylvania Power Company, reported yesterday increased operating revenues and net income for the twelve months ended on July 31.

YONKERS, Aug. 15 -- One day this week Adios Butler, the world's fastest harness horse, will be taken from the grounds of Yonkers Raceway. Unless either the raceway or the $600,000 syndicate that owns The Butler undergoes a change of heart, it will be forever.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Wednesday, Aug. 16 -- The Mapai party of Premier David Ben-Gurion led in the early returns this morning from the general election in Israel. But there were indications that the new Liberal party would gain a firm place in the Israeli political scene.

HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Hanover state attorney announced today that he was investigating to see whether Dr. Erhard Wetzel is the man who was accused of being co-author, with Adolf Eichmann of a program recommending the gassing of Jews.

SLIGHTLY more than a decade ago, Ralph Kiner wrote a magazine article, "The Home Run I'd Hate to Hit." The homer that was so distasteful to him then was the one that would break Babe Ruth's record of sixty. At that time the big Pittsburgh slugger had slammed fifty-four in the 1949 season and looked as if he might improve on that total.

BIZERTE, Tunisia, Aug. 15 -- French paratroops had virtually disappeared from the city of Bizerte today. French gendarmes, sailors and marines had repeaced the paratroops in the sandbag posts that control most of the European sector.
Bronx County Judge Abraham D. Levy said yesterday that he would impose "maximum penalties" on persons convicted of assaulting policemen.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- At the age of 86, the French-born American conductor, Pierre Monteux, was appointed tonight as principal conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra.
The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation showed a further improvement in earnings for the second quarter, following profitable operations in the first three months of 1961.

A MARRIAGE counselor who went to work immediately after she was graduated from elementary school (but later completed her education) warned recently that girls who fail to finish high school are unlikely to be mature enough to cope with the problems of marriage and motherhood.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- Robert Byrne of Valparaiso, Ind., defender, defeated Dr. Theodore Bullockus of Palo Alto, Calif., in the first round of the United States open chess championship tonight.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Henry Linxweiler, who is 75 years old, is giving up his blacksmith business here soon.
BERLIN, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a note sent today by the United States, British and French commandants in Berlin to the Soviet commandant:
Twenty bandits -- one-armed bandits, that is -- sailed into New York yesterday aboard the Queen Mary. They were locked and bore customs seals.
TOKYO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Japan and the United States will start discussions in Tokyo next Tuesday on Japan's voluntary cotton textile quota for 1962, the Foreign Office said today.

A MAN careened into this corner yesterday, eyes alight with the burning fervor of dedication, hands trembling with fingers crooked as if holding a fishing rod. Sometimes he would cock his head, lapsing into silence, for he was hearing sounds beyond the normal range, such as the sibilance of moving fish.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 15 (AP) -- The United States tonight apparently succeeded in firing into orbit a "windmill" satellite to study the relation between magnetic fields and space radiation.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Aug. 15 -- An attempt to have a strong anti-Cuban political declaration adopted at the conference on the Alliance for Progress charter apparently failed today.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., has arranged for the private placement of $147,000,000 of equipment mortgage notes to finance its purchase of twenty-six new jet airplanes.

A JOURNEY to the moon will be simulated in the Space Medicine Exhibit at the 1961 New York Health Exposition, which opens on Friday at the New York Coliseum. Other features will include free medical tests for visitors and exercise demonstrations for physical fitness.
DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers rallied for three runs with two out in the ninth inning tonight and defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 3 -- 2, in the second game of a double-header.

THE name "aubergine" seems, somehow, more fitted to the splendidly purple vegetable that bears it than does "eggplant." Even in England the vegetable -- if it is known at all -- is known as an auborgine. The fact that the French name is so close to the word for inn (auberge) seems to be purely coincidental, but it makes about as much sense as likening the vegetable to an egg.

SEATTLE, Aug. 15 (AP) -- St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia was stripped today of its third-place standing in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament as an aftermath of the recent gambling scandals.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 15 -- Indonesia's youth has been mobolized in one organization to advance this under-developed country's progress through President Sukarno's concept of nationalistic socialism.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Government gave tentative approval today to economic development plans submitted by seven depressed areas seeking Federal aid.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -A successful New York tax lawyer was conferring with an important client a few months ago when the telephone rang and the client passed the instrument saying, "It's for you."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The appointment of Adolphe W. Schmidt, a Pittsburgh financier and philanthropist, to head the United States delegation to the international preparatory committee for the convention of North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations, was announced today.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 15 -- The Humble Oil and Refining Company has appealed a $35,000,000 tax assessment on its Bayonne plant. The appeal heads a list of 932 appeals filed by Hudson County property owners.

We refer to your editorial of July 31, "Controlling the Pesticides." It contains a number of misleading and unsubstantiated statements which reflect unfavorably on the mount of research which has been done by the pesticide chemical industry, Federal and state agencies, and private research organizations.

Plans of Food Fair Stores, Inc., to expand its supermarket chain and the distribution of goods and services in the non-food field were outlined to stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Philadelphia.

Frank Leo, a realty investor and builder of Bloomfield, has bought a half-acre of land at 157 South Munn Avenue, southwest corner of Rhode Island Ave., East Orange. He acquired the tract from Sinclair Chigar and will improve it with a twenty-five-family garden apartment building.

BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- At 4 a.m. Sunday when RIAS, the United States radio station in West Berlin, gave itsfirst bulletin on the closing of the border by East German forces, an editor removed the recorded song that was to follow the news. It was "Let's Do Like the Swallows Do."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Under Secretary of State Chester Bowles said today that he had found under-developed nations "profoundly skeptical" of the United States' capacity to live up to its own revolutionary traditions.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Two-run homers by Ernie Banks, Ron Santo and Billy Williams carried the Chicago Cubs to a 6-5 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.
DETROIT, Aug. 15 -- The United Automobile Workers struck back at the Chrysler Corporation today for turning down a union proposal to put hourly workers on salary.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa reported yesterday that the city would be able to borrow $385,000,000 within the debt limit for its capital budget for the calendar year 1962.
Plans are progressing for the annual fashion show and tea of the Brick Presbyterian Church to be held Oct. 17 in the Watson Hall of the church at Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.
The removal of Dr. John J. Theobald as Superintendent of Schools was demanded yesterday by Mayor Wagner's two chief rivals in the municipal election.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Braves recorded their fifth consecutive victory tonight, as home runs by Hank Aaron and Frank Thomas sent the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-1 loss. The Braves collected nine hits off three pitchers.

Arrangements are being made for Franco Zeffirelli to direct "The Queen and the Rebels," in which Beatrice Straight is to be starred. Mr. Zeffirelli has achieved a reputation in London not only as an imaginative director of plays and operas but also as a scenic designer.

COHASSET, Mass., Aug. 15 John J. (Don) McNamara, the Massachusetts Bay senior sailing champion, guided the Corinthian Yacht Club's challenging Sea Star to victory today in the opening race of the thirty-seventh Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewkski and Albie Pearson rapped doubles that provided two runs in the ninth inning tonight for an 8 -- 7 victory by the Los Angeles Angels over the Washington Senators. Ken Hunt, with three hits including his twentieth home run, led the Angels' eleven-hit attack.

PESCARA, Italy, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Lorenzo Bandini and Giorgio Scarlatti of Italy drove a Ferrari to victory today in the Pescara Grand Prix auto race. They covered 355.2 miles and averaged 88.8 miles an hour for the four-hour race.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- France opened her month-long national exhibition here today, showing the best she has to offer -- from fashions and tapestries to the most advanced medical equipment and machine tools.
COBLENZ, Germany, Aug. 15 -- The West German infantry is feeling the effects of the short service periods for conscripts more than any other branch of the armed forces.
Mayor Wagner campaigned for votes in a big West Side housing project last evening and reaped a harvest of complaints.
BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- The United States, Britain and France formally protested to the Soviet Union today against Communist East Germany's closing of the border between East and West Berlin.

WILTON, Conn., Aug. 15 -- To reassure a local mail carrier accused of murder that "all of society is not against him," seven Community leaders today started to raise a defense fund of several thousand dollars.
A fifth new motion-picture theatre is scheduled to be constructed in Manhattan this fall, for opening in the spring.
A stay-in-school campaign described as the most intensive civic drive ever attempted in the city was opened yesterday by Mayor Wagner at City Hall.

GLADSTONE, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Crowding into two weeks a training program he believes should take two years, Gordon Wright has been teaching eight young riders to maneuver their ponies as they never have before.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The country's industries set a production record in July, when the pre-recession peak was surpassed, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Controls Company of America, Schiller Park, Ill., is broadening its position in the gas controls industry through the acquisition of the Thermac Company, Corona, Calif.
The thirteenth game of the sixteen-game chess series between Samuel Reshevsky and Bobby Fischer was postponed last night until tomorrow evening. The match is scheduled for the Hotel Empire.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 15 -- Primer Minister Jawaharlal Nehru appealed fervently today for Indian unity as a leader of the Sikh religious faith began a fast that could lead to widespread strife.

JOHN MASTERS' eleventh book, "The Road Past Mandalay,"* is the second volume of his autobiography. Like its predecessor, "Bugles and a Tiger," which was published five years ago, it is better than any of Mr. Masters' nine novels.

Carmine G. De Sapio accused Mayor Wagner yesterday of allowing Washington Square Park to become an open-air garage for Fift Avenue buses, "a disgraceful shambles" and a dust bowl filled with toxic fumes.
STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, Aug. 15 -- The Royal Shakespeare Theatre opened a new production of "Romeo and Juliet" tonight with a 23-year-old novice playing the part of Romeo on a week's notice.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- President Kennedy ordered today the immediate release of more than $818,000,000 in Federal-aid highway funds that would normally not have been released to the states until Oct. 1.

The master and crew of the freighter Yaque received a citation yesterday for the rescue last March of four men who had drifted in the Caribbean Sea for eighteen days in a twenty-foot motor launch without food or water.

Pittsburgh Steel Company announced yesterday that it planned to raise about $10,000,000 through the sale of additional common shares and called a special meeting of stockholders for Sept. 28 to vote on a proposal to increase authorized common shares from 2,500,000 to 4,000,000.
Your July 31 editorial "A Strike Mired in Concrete" is an object lesson in the power and responsibility of the press.

A GREENWICH VILLAGE shop has invaded fashionable Fifth Avenue. The Et Cetera at 29 West Eighth Street has opened a second branch opposite Lord Taylor and, much to the amusement of its two young owners, the wilder clothes are selling faster than they ever did downtown.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 973 persons were hurt here last week in traffic accidents. This is a decrease of eighty compared with last year.

SANTA MARIA DEL MAR, Aug. 13 -- Small pine trees grow almost to the water's edge on this dazzling white beach fifteen miles outside of Havana. Houses, some elaborately expensive, others of an even more expensive simplicity, look over the trees to the ocean.
TRENTON, Aug. 15 -- State Attorney General David D. Furman questioned today the validity of the three major television networks' participation in the proposed sale of WNTA-TV (Channel 13).

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Aug. 15 (AP) -A United States spokesman disclosed tonight that a Leftist mob stole secret American Embassy documents from the burning car of the United States Ambasador in Caracas, Venezuela, last June.
PASSAIC, N.J., Wednesday, Aug. 16 -- More than 1,800 United States Rubber Company workers struck the company plant here at midnight last night.
Another kind of lively ball showed up at the Stadium last night -- a fugitive, elusive thing thrown by Juan Pizarro of the Chicago White Sox as he beat the New York Yankees, 2 -- 1.
TOKYO, Aug. 15 -- The Japanese people found two photographs in their newspapers today that illustrated the dramatic changes in the fortunes of Japan since World War II.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Leon H. Keyserling, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under former President Truman, said today that President Kennedy's programs and policies did not offer "any large likelihood" of appreciable improvements in the nation's economic performance during the next few years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has assured Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo that the United Nations recognizes his Government as the only legitimate one in the Congo and will give it all possible aid.
Some subtle changes have been taking place in what some experts regard as the nation's largest advertising medium -the classified telephone directory.

In a first reply to the Soviet challenge in Berlin, the Western military commanders have delivered a sharp protest note to the Soviet commander denouncing the lowering of the Iron Curtain in the center of that beleaguered city as "the most flagrant violation" of international agreements since the Berlin blockade eleven years ago.
ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- Governor Rockefeller plans to abolish any New York City Board of Education that may be named by Mayor Wagner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Impressive Republican support continued today to line up behind President Kennedy's proposal for a high-level disarmament agency as a permanent fixture in the executive branch of the Government.
The bound and gagged bodies of two boys, both covered with stab wounds, were found last night in the marshlands of the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -Alternate flurries of profit taking and liquidation held the grain futures market today on an unsteady course within a fairly moderate range on the Board of Trade.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., narrowly escaped defeat today in the eightieth annual Newport invitation tennis tournament at the Casino.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 15 -- The continuing Communist charges of the presence of large numbers of Chinese Nationalist guerrillas in the forces of the Right-Wing Laotian Government appear to be completely false.

The election of William Zeckendorf Jr. as president of the International Recreation Corporation, operator of Freedomland, was announced yesterday. Mr. Zeckendorf is executive vice president of Webb Knapp, Inc., which owns the land leased to Freedomland and holds a 40 per cent interest in International Recreation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today reversed itself and guaranteed a $1,000,000 loan to the Boston and Maine Railroad.
The Government is planning to put pressure on maritime unions and shipping operators to settle their contract differences within a few weeks.

ATHENS, Aug. 15 -- The Harvard Glee Club was cheered tonight in the eigthteen-century-old theatre of Herod Atticus at the foot of the Acropolis here when it gave the first of two performances for this year's Athens Festival. It shared honors with Italy's Opera da Camera di Milano.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Senate approved today an amendment to the foreign aid bill that would give Congress potentially far-reaching control over the President's long-term Development Loan Fund.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The House Science Committee approved legislation today setting a maximum of five years imprisonment and a $10,000 fine for any member of a Communist organization convicted of applying for a National Science Foundation fellowship.

Mayor Wagner's three-man board of inquiry, in asking the Board of Education to tender its resignation, reaffirmed the recommendations that the Mayor ask for the aid of civic and educational organizations and a panel of distinguished, nonpartisan citizens in assembling a new board of the highest quality. This is the procedure on which all responsible earlier reports, both at city and state level, have been in complete agreement.

A pre-election clash between the Republican leaders in Queens and their candidate for Borough President appeared to be in the making yesterday. It involves the choice of a successor to Frank Kenna as the Queens Republican leader.

It is now mid-August and the strike of 1,200 concrete mix drivers, which began July 1, is still on. Almost everyone of any consequence, it seems, has made an effort of some kind to end it, Mayor Wagner appealed for intensive bargaining; the bargaining took place, and then the members of Local 282 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters turned down the bargain.
PARIS, Aug. 15 -- A rumored political deadline for France came and passed today without any startling events.

Stockholders of Giannini Controls Corporation, at a special meeting, approved a proposed two-for-one split which increases authorized common stock from 1,000,000 shares of $1 par value to 2,000,000 of 50 cents par value.
A three-year agreement, retroactive to Aug. 1, with the stagehands, members of Theatrical Protective Union, Local 1, was ratified yesterday by the League of New York Theatres.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Jaipur, the colt that repressed local observers by winning the Flash Stakes on the opening day of the current meeting, will be in action again tomorrow.

ATHENS, Aug. 15 -- When General MacArthur saw President Kennedy last spring he said to him: "Mr. President, all the chickens are now coming home to roost and you are living in the henhouse." A union proposal for ending the six-week-old concrete mix strike was rejected last night by employer representatives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The House Armed Services Committee raised no objection today to a Navy plan for continuing oil production from its Buena Vista Hills petroleum reserve in Kern County, Calif.
GUATEMALA, Aug. 15 -- The Guatemalan Government threatened today to break off commercial relations with Britain in the continuing dispute over neighboring British Honduras, which Guatemala claims.

The board of directors of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation again deferred dividend action yesterday on the 6 per cent preferred stock. The arrearages on the stock amounted to $90 a share on July 1. The most recent dividend on the preferred was paid in 1958.

GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- The Soviet Union joined Communist China today in warning that the outlook for the conference on Laos here was dimmed by a stalemate over the withdrawal of foreign troops from the Southeast Asian kingdom.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Republican Congressional leaders said today they had received information to indicate that the Soviet Union was conducting secret nuclear tests.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 15 -- The Bundestag, West Germany's lower house of Parliament, will meet in special session Friday to hear a Government statement on the Berlin crisis, officials announced here tonight.
Sales of Texas Instruments, Inc., rose slightly for the three and six months ended on June 30, but earnings declined from the 1960 levels, the company reported yesterday.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Lester Abberley of the Noroton Yacht Club, representing the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, won the Area B semi-final of the North American junior sailing championship here today.
BUFFALO, Aug. 15 -- Federal Judge John O. Henderson ruled today that the Eastman Kodak Company need not divest itself of any of its nine film processing plants in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The State Department said today modified martial law had been decreed in Santa Cruz, Bolivia, where four United States citizens and a Brazilian aboard a cargo plane were forced down last month by Bolivian fighter planes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A United States District Court judge upheld the Controller of the Currency yesterday in a case contested by the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance and the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

Stocks were drifting along yesterday in quiet trading when suddenly "the bottom fell out" in the form of a late sell-off. On average, prices on the New York Stock Exchange showed the biggest decline in two weeks.
PARIS, Aug. 15 -- France rejected today Tunisian charges that French forces had violated the cease-fire in military actions near Bizerte and along the Algerian-Tunisian frontier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced today that agreement had been reached on provisions of legislation to create a Delaware River Basin Compact Commission.
Artists' representatives and top city officials met yesterday at City Hall to find a solution to the problems of artists occupying loft studios.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- The City Manager of Newburgh, N.Y., said today that he expected the city to lose the first court test of its strict new welfare code.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A struggle between two major carriers in the Puerto Rican trade for two C-4 ships in the Navy's reserve fleet generated considerable heat at a hearing today of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Trading contracted sharply in the stock market here today and was barely at a level to test prices. Among the industrials, movements were irregular and generally small.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- President Kennedy announced today the appointment of a special assistant to prepare an international trade program to replace the reciprocal trade program next June 30.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A bill to require disclosure of more information on the financing of campaigns for Federal offices was worked out today by the Senate Elections Subcommittee.
A hardy little year-old Shetland pony has been donated to the nearly finished Lehman Zoo for Children in Central Park to augment gifts of chickens, ducks and rabbits.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 (AP) -- John Romano's homer helped the Cleveland Indians defeat the Boston Red Sox, 6 -- 4, tonight. Romano belted his sixteenth of the season over the left-field fence in the sixth inning.

DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The International Union of Electrical Workers, which represents 25,000 of General Motors' 325,000 production workers, proposed anew today that the company establish a profit-sharing plan for hourly paid workers.

Production of electric power dipped to 16,080,000,000 kilowatt-hours last week from the record 16,137,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The latest figure compared with 15,037,000,000 kilowatt-hours a year ago.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 16 -- The Laotian neutralists and pro-Communists refused to budge today from their position that the name of Prince Souvanna Phouma, and no other, should be presented to King Savang Vathana for approval as the next Premier of Laos.

Four police sergeants and a retired sergeant were indicted and arraigned yesterday in Queens County Court on charges of conspiracy and extortion arising from a grand jury investigation of a tow-car racket.

Fifteen evening courses in filmmaking will be offered during the fall semester by City College's Institute of Film Techniques. Classes in photography, screen writing, sound and film editing, directing and production will be held at night, with Saturday workshop production classes for advanced students and professional filmmakers.

The American Electric Power Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday an increase in net income for the twelve months ended on July 31. However, share earnings fell, as the number of shares outstanding rose to 21,903,299 from 21,698,291 on July 31, 1960.

YONKERS, Aug. 16 -- Apmat of Australia, who got rich winning two early international paces here, then got tired of chasing home the great Adios Butler in races in Long Island, Canada and Delaware, is favored to win the $25,000 Widower Creed Pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reorganized its top management yesterday but left Frederick R. Kappel in charge of over-all operations.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- The American Federation of Teachers was told today that the United States could not afford to continue squandering the talent of young people.

Despite the new armament race precipitated by the Moscow-made Berlin crisis, the Kennedy Administration urges Congress, with wide bipartisan support, to create a new Disarmament Agency for World Peace and Security. Nationwide Homes, Inc. Cruttenden, Podesta Co. and McDaniel Lewis Co. and associates are offering today securities of Nationwide Homes, Inc., totaling $3,300,000. The securities are being offered in units consisting of one $10 debenture and two common shares, priced at $22 a unit.
Magistrate Edward J. Chapman ruled in Housing Court yesterday that John E. Hand, a longtime Democratic political figure, was not guilty of a housing charge brought against him last Dec. 29.

Writing a newspaper column may be a perilous business, but at least one prominent columnist has managed to sustain himself for ten years. His case is unusual, of course, in that he pays for his space. His name is Willard F. Rockwell Jr., and he is president of the Rockwell Manufacturing Company.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Hedge selling and profit taking weakened the grain futures market today against a diminishing demand on the Board of Trade.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 16 (AP) -- A hijacked Eastern Air Lines airliner was returned from Havana today along with a bullet with which its crew had been threatened.

Bobby Fischer, the 18-year-old chess champion of the United States, faces a suit for damages if he fails to continue his sixteen-game series with Samuel Reshevsky, the American Chess Foundation warned yesterday.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 20 cents a bale up yesterday.

The Air Reduction Company, Inc., soon will supply high purity nitrogen in large quantities to plants in the Delaware Valley chemical complex through a twenty-two-mile nitrogen pipeline, the longest in the country.

OTTAWA, Aug. 16 -- A leading Soviet scientist has requested and received political asylum in Canada.

The formal sentence in the frontispiece of many novels announcing that the characters take their resemblance from no one (the author especially) is not always taken to heart by the reader.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- President Kennedy's foreign-aid bill suffered severe setbacks in both houses of Congress today.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 16 -- The Salzburg Festival today took a flier in modern opera, with a world premiere of Rudolf Wagner-Regeny's "Das Bergwerk zu Falun." This can be translated as "The Mine of Falun," and it is set to the play by the same name of Hugo Von Hofmannsthal.

The division in organized labor over the Mayoralty race deepened yesterday when leaders of 70,000 butchers and fur workers announced their support for State Controller Arthur Levitt in the Democratic primary.

IT was a lazy summer afternoon at the Yankee Stadium. The sun heat down with a drowsy warmth and not even the ballplayers seemed in any hurry to engage in violent exercise. The pitchers, who always fancy themselves to he potentially great hitters, didn't even bother to take early batting practice.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Malcolm McLean, president of McLean Industries, Inc., told the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries today that the Vessels Exchange Act that it sponsored and that was passed last year was a "give-away program."

Planning for the annual Lighthouse Gala Ball to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 1 is already under way.

Borough President John Cashmore did not live to see the 1960-61 edition of "Brooklyn Progress," the title of his annual reports year after year. A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth was fatally stabbed in the back last night in what the police believed to be a gang fight near the New York Naval Shipyard.

The Rockefeller Foundation yesterday announced a $300,000 grant to the Russian Institute of Columbia University. The grant will be used to finance research activities for seven years starting in 1962.

The operating companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group had a combined net income of 86,710,000 ($242,788,000) for the first half of this year, the parent companies announced yesterday. This compared with profits of 84,956,000 ($237,876,800) for the 1960 period.
ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- The Democratic state chairman went a long way today toward drawing up the party's state-wide slate for the 1962 election.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies matched the modern National League losing streak of nineteen games today by bowing to the Chicago Cubs, 9 --5.

Nothing activates Roger Maris' home run bat like the sight of a White Sox pitcher 60 feet 6 inches away. In precisely those circumstances yesterday, Maris slammed No. 47 and No. 48 off Billy Pierce in a 5-4 Yankee triumph at the Stadium.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- Whitney Reed yesterday won a match he appeared to be on the verge of losing to Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico in the Newport invitation tennis tournament. Today the big Californian from Alameda apparently was on the way to victory over Jack Frost of Monterey, Calif., only to weaken and yield four successive games and the decision, 6 -- 2, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

TOKYO, Aug. 16 -- The Soviet Union warned the Japanese Government today that the presence of United States military bases in Japan would subject the Japanese to Communist military attack in case of war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Kennedy Administration will go into the United Nations General Assembly next month with new appeals for total disarmament, for the peaceful uses of outer space, for the independence and self-determination of new and old nations alike and for guarantees against aggression by subversion as well as invasion.
Sales of the nation's leading store chains rose for July and the first seven months of 1961 from the levels of the 1960 periods, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The United States had a surplus in its balance of international payments this spring for the first time in four years, but only because of extraordinary developments that are unlikely to be repeated. Without those developments, the payments situation worsened.

TRENTON, Aug. 16 -- The state today asserted for the first time its claim to 254 specific parcels of tideland in eleven Bergen and Hudson County communities. This land is part of more than 100,000 acres of tideland, valued at more than $60,000,000, which the state claims under riparian rights.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Two wild throws on one play after two out in the ninth inning let in two runs tonight and enabled the Washington Senators to score a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Angels.

Simon's Jean de Larsan, can conclude his own separate peace and still live with pride is a question in our brightest and bloodiest of centuries.

Louis Goldfarb, who recently acquired an eighty-four-year leasehold on two four-story buildings at 817-19 Second Avenue, has resold the lease to Jack P. Schleifer, realty investor. Two selections of the late H. L. Mencken's writings will be issued Sept. 12 by Knopf. One will contain Mencken's thoughts on music in general and on composers and performers. It is called "H.L. Mencken on Music: A Selection of His Writings on Music, Together with an Account of H.L. Mencken's Musical Life and a History of The Saturday Night Club."

The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company announced yesterday the election of Zach Toms as president. Mr. Toms, who has been executive vice president since December, 1959, succeeds William A. Blount.

Withdrawals at savings and loan associations in the United States exceeded gross receipts last month for the first time since July, 1957, and only the second time since 1950, the United States Savings and Loan League reported yesterday. Schaeffer, wife of a retired Rear Admiral in the United States Navy, are conducting a preparedness campaign, with the help of their husbands.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- Shareholders of Bishop Oil Company voted today to sell the company's wholly owned subsidiary, Canadian Bishop Oil, Ltd., to Shell Oil Company for $5,626,700.

The Metropolitan Opera said yesterday a 1961-62 season was "no longer a possibility" and broke off negotiations with a union representing its orchestra members.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 17 -- Briggs S. Cunningham of Greens Farms, Conn., won the opening race of the Atlantic Class sailing championship this morning. The afternoon race was called off because of lack of wind with thirty sloops on the course.
Potatoes and domestic sugar futures were the most actively trade commodities on the New York exchanges yesterday.
Ten Army units in New York prepared yesterday to alert individual reservists needed to bring the units up to authorized strength.

That they have reached their conclusions and made their recommendations promptly has helped to clarify a situation in which the confusion of voices had reached destructive proportions.

Three of the nation's largest manufacturers of antibiotics and three of their top executives were indicted yesterday on criminal antitrust charges. The defendants are accused of maintaining unreasonably high and noncompetitive prices and of monopolizing the production and distribution of the drugs since November, 1953.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The railroad and trucking industries reported today a slight rise in week-to-week freight loadings last week.
MADRID, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Three persons were killed and 200 injured today when part of a bullring collapsed at Jimena de la Frontera in Cadiz Province, it was reported here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A late rally lifted soybean futures into a firm range today on the Board of Trade but the grains, under pressure for the second consecutive day, generally lost further ground.

TURKEY traffic to local markets continues in rush-hour proportions. Big or little, the birds cost 4 cents less this week. At supermarkets, however, chicken prices are making the headlines. Some stores price broilers as low as 25 cents a pound; others tag roasters at only 31 cents a pound.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City rose $66,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, compared with a rise of $1,000,000 in the like week a year ago. Petroleum, coal, chemical and rubber companies, food, liquor and tobacco concerns, and textile, apparel and leather merchants added significantly to their borrowings.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 2 to 28 points (10 cents to $1.40 a bale) yesterday.

THE announcement made yesterday of Jacques Lipchitz' bequest to the Jerusalem Museum of Art of 300 original plaster models for his most famous pieces of sculpture is an event of international significance in the world of art.

JUAREZ, Mexico, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Alicia Darr, actress and artist, filed suit for a divorce from Edmund Purdom, British film star, today and said she would be married to Alfred Corning Clark of New York, Singer Sewing Machine heir.

BOONTON, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Assemblyman Joseph J. Maraziti, Republican of Morris County, today declined an invitation to take part, with his family, in the Port of New York Authority's annual "Inspection Tour" of its facilities on Sept. 26.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
GENEVA, Aug. 17 -- The fourteen-nation conference here on Laos split again today over controls to guarantee the kingdom's neutrality and independence.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 17 -- Pinhas Lavon suggested today that the electorate in Israel vindicated him Tuesday in his old quarrel with Premier David Ben-Gurion.
Eight major plumbing contractors who stopped work yesterday and who threatened to hold up the school building program agreed to return to work today on twenty-three major contracts.
United States newsprint consumption in July and the first seven months of this year declined from the records set in the 1960 periods, according to the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
State Controller Arthur Levitt took a one-hour thirteen-block walk yesterday through Washington Heights to meet voters and seek their support in the Democratic primary.
Emile Griffith of New York, the world welterweight champion, yesterday signed to defend his title against the man from whom he won it.

THE reason J.W. Porter, the baseball player, uses only his initials is because he has neither a first nor a middle name. This presented a problem in nomenclature when he finally came to the big leagues. So he was asked what he was called at home.
