CUTTYHUNK, Mass., Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Engineers began setting the long steel legs of a Texas-tower type of structure into the ocean bottom today. Thus they began the first replacement of New England's lightships.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 -- The Cincinnati Reds, leaving the Los Angeles Dodgers dead to all outward signs, headed home today with high hearts and a one-game lead in the National League. The Reds swept the three-game series by demolishing the Dodgers in a double-shutout conquest, 6 -- 0 and 8 -- 0, last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Arthur and Robert Julius of Briar Hall won the Westchester County Golf Association's father-and-son championship today for the third time in five years. They scored 36, 35 -- 71 in alternate-stroke play at Knollwood Country Club.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Chuck McKinley drew the key assignment for the United States in the opening Davis Cup singles match of the American Zone tennis final against Mexico tomorrow.
CAIRO, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Seven Vice Presidents have been appointed to the United Arab Republic's new Cabinet.
We need to rid our homes of numerous decorating cliches, Lawrence Peabody, Boston designer of interiors and home furnishings, told United Press International.

OTTAWA Aug. 17 -- The Canadian Minister of Justice said today that Dr. Mikhail A. Klochko, a Soviet scientist, had defected in Canada because there was no "scientific or intelectual freedom" in the Soviet Union.
DELAND, Fla., Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Applications of two Negro girls for admittance to a white grade school in Daytona Beach were approved by the Volusia County School Board today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Angels gave another game to the Washington Senators today, with two of their three errors contributing to their 4-3 defeat.

Production of lumber totaled 223,339,000 board feet in the week ended Aug. 12. This compared with 221,214,000 board feet the week before and 232,189,000 board feet a year ago, according to reports from regional associations.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Count that day lost whose low descending sun sees no record-breaking performance on the Saratoga thoroughbred track.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Eight convicts held twenty-five persons hostage with a toy gun, pocket knives and icepicks for eight hours at Tennessee State Prison today. They surrendered as an Army tank bore down on their stronghold.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Western Allies protested to Moscow today against the Communists' closing of the frontier between East and West Berlin. They called on the Soviet Union "to put an end to these illegal measures."

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Astronomers from East and West, including those from the two countries that are racing to explore the moon, sat down together today to discuss the problems of mapping that body.
CORDOBA, Argentina, Aug. 17 -- This 388-year-old university center is humming with expanding big industry.
The Houston Corporation announced yesterday that it had reversed the loss it showed for the first half of 1960 and reported a profit of $231,133 for the period this year.

Mercedes-Benz announced yesterday it would introduce a new luxury sedan for the 1962 model year. They also will have a more powerful and roomier version of the established 190 land, 190D (Diesel) medium priced lines.
NEW YORK CITY'S firemen were the subject of an informative half-hour telecast over Channel 4 last night.
A $5,600,000 damage suit was filed yesterday by a naval lieutenant commander, his wife and their five children as a result of exposure to radioactive rays from a wrist watch.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed by voice vote tonight the nomination of George W. Mitchell for a seat on the Federal Reserve Board.
The planning, management, analysis and reporting procedures of the Police Department will be surveyed by City Administrator Charles H. Tenney, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The United States is concerned over next Monday's elections in British, Guiana. Officials wonder whether the almost certain victory of the extreme Leftists there will push the territory into the Cuban sphere of influence.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Elliott Oldak of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club posted his fifth victory today in six Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound junior Blue Jay Class starts. It came as Manhasset Bay Y.C.'s thirteenth annual junior regatta ended.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 17 -- The 700-member Cab Drivers Local 954 joined three other units of the Teamsters International Union here tonight in voting to withdraw from James R. Hoffa's Teamsters Union.

Plans for telecasts here of four baseball games between the Cincinnati Reds and Los Angeles Dodgers, who are in a close race for the National League pennant, have been canceled. The Cincinnati club agreed to sell television rights, but the Dodgers, formerly based in Brooklyn, refused.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Following is the text of a United States note to the Soviet Union today protesting the closing of the East Berlin border: (Parallel notes were sent by Britain and France.)
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- A dramatization of "Lady Chatterely's Lover" opened at the Arts theatre last night to unanimous critical scoffing.
Mayor Wagner sought yesterday to assuage the fears of Greenwich Village residents that the projected West Village urban renewal study would materially change the character of the area.

The Affiliated Young Democrats of New York decided last night after a membership poll to refrain from endorsing any candidates for the three top city-wide nominations being contested in the Democratic primary.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Gov. David L. Lawrence of Pennsylvania and Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson of New York joined today in predicting that a new freeway would bring prosperity to the central sections of both states.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency disclosed today it was trying to levy a $1,000 fine -- heaviest on record -- on a passenger accused of endangering an airliner while drunk.
William P. Buckner, a gambler who was sometimes known as "the king of the Bingo operators," died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 3811 Riverdale Avenue, the Bronx.
DETROIT, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Whitey Herzog drove in all the Baltimore Orioles' runs with a homer and single today and Jack Fisher's pitching stopped the Detroit Tigers, 3 -- 1.

The Electric Autolite Company is entering the factoring business in Canada through a wholly owned subsidiary, the Equilease Corporation, which has purchased a 60 per cent interest in the Aetna Factors Corporation, Ltd., of Montreal and Toronto, for more than $1,000,000 in cash.

The Standard Oil Company (Kentucky) confirmed yesterday reports that it planned to build a refinery at Bayou Casote near Pascagoula, Miss. The plant would cost about $125,000,000 and would have a capacity to process 100,000 barrels of crude oil a day.

Stocks broke loose yesterday from the recent indecisiveness and moved to a major advance. The gain in prices on the New York Stock Exchange was the largest in two weeks. Volume of trading also increased significantly.

The Mountain Fuel Supply Company plans to offer for sale $18,000,000 of twenty-five-year debentures with a five-year protection against call, according to a registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina clashed in the Senate today with two other Democratic Senators over the military's activities to indoctrinate service personnel and the public on the Communist menace.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The growers of California grapes for sweet wines have voted to sweeten their incomes.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $61,000,000 to $62,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $51,000,000 to $609,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- There will be no appointments to Federal judgeships in New York City until after the September primary elections, a source close to Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today.
Dealers in bankers' acceptances raised rates to investors by one-eighth percentage point across the board yesterday on these short-term obligations used to finance goods in shipment or in storage.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Efforts to salvage part of the Administration's aid-to-education program have been renewed at President Kennedy's request.

Net income of the Chicago and North Western Railway Company last month rose to $1,852,947 from $506,496 for the 1960 month, the carrier announced yesterday. However, after special credits of $4,276,259, earnings in July, 1960, amounted to $4,782,755.

A significant step toward a "universal" transistor was reported yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America. The company announced the development of a silicon transistor capable of doing the work of more than 40 per cent of the 2,000 units or more on the market.

Mayor Wagner called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to broaden the scope of next week's special session of the Legislature to include consideration of key items in a city legislative program that was killed in the 1961 session.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will meet in New York City Aug. 30 to make plans for a three-state transportation study.

"MAN that is born of woman hath but a short time to live, and is full of misery," says the First Anthem of The Book of Common Prayer. "In the midst of life we are in death." The beautiful words express a truth that most people prefer not to think about. Neither the teachings of religion nor the consolations of philosophy can reconcile most men to the thought of death.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The Winged Foot Golf Club's team won the Hoffhine memorial tourney again today. Last year, when the Winged Footers triumphed, the result was determined by matching cards after a tie with the Westchester Country Club representatives.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Government announced today that it had licensed the manufacture of one Sabin oral vaccine for protection against one of the three types of poliomyelitis.

Another major United States-flag shipline involved in the nation-wide maritime strike in June and July has signed up with all East Coast unions. All of its Atlantic services are now free to operate, regardless of negotiations elsewhere in the industry.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Chicago and Pittsburgh split a double-header today. The Cubs won the opener, 11 -- 4, for Dick Drott's first victory since June of 1959 and the Pirates took the finale, 4 -- 3, with a two-run rally in the eighth inning.
YONKERS, Aug. 17 -- O'Brien Hanover, a junior free-for-all pacer who was not expected to do well, won the $25,000 Widower Creed Pace before 27,726 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- South Africa's gold and foreign exchange reserves have risen by 28,000,000 rand ($39,200,000) in eight weeks, Finance Minister Eben Donges said here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Explorer XII rode around the earth on its second lap through space today but a separate effort to probe even farther out failed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The amphibious ships to be reactivated include: the Achernar, at Orange, Tex.; Algol, Bremerton, Wash.; Uvalde, Stockton, Calif.; Wyandot, Orange, Tex.; Yancey, Bremerton; Winston, Suisun, Calif.; Sandoval, Stockton; Telfair, Suisun; Mountrail, Stockton; Liddle, Orange; Ruchamkin, Boston; Earl B. Hall, Norfolk, Va.; Viachenko, San Diego.

A total of 1,344 Manhattan properties were sold for prices amounting to $194,574,168 in the first half of this year, compared with 1.466 for a total of $153,723,174 in the first six months of last year. The figures represent a drop of 8 per cent in the number of deals, but an increase of 22 per cent in the dollar volume.

The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, Inc., operator of an oil refinery in Puerto Rico, announced yesterday a refunding operation through which it plans to refinance all of its remaining long-term debt. The plan involves the sale to the New York Trust Company of a $20,000,000 promissory note bearing 5 7/8 per cent interest annually and maturing on Aug. 1, 1976.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday he could see no reason why the Rockefeller administration's plan to put the city school system under a state-appointed board would backfire on his candidacy.
TOKYO, Aug. 17 -- The "goodwill mission" of Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, turned into a political battle between the visitor and his Japanese hosts today.

Dr. Grace L. Hopper, the originator of electronic computer automatic programing, has been appointed director of systems research for the Remington Rand division of the Sperry Rand Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

The three men who used a stolen motorboat to rob the Freedomland amusement park of $28,837 last year were sentenced to prison yesterday. They had pleaded guilty to second-degree robbery in Bronx County Court.
A minor collision on the Great Lakes ten days ago has swept a puzzled Greek ship captain into a legal swirl that included arrest, jailing in the Federal House of Detention and a charge of perjury.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 17 -- The fourteenth annual American Dance Festival presented by Connecticut College began here tonight in Palmer Auditorium.

BINGHAM, Utah, Aug. 17 -- Members of a small electrical workers' local set up picket lines this morning in a contract dispute at Kennecott Copper Corporation's open-pit copper mine in Bingham Canyon.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 17 -- Uruguay for the first time in several years has sold almost its entire wool crop. As a result the country is enjoying a favorable balance of foreign trade, whereas for the last two years there had been trade deficits of about $100,000,000 a year.

Bobby Fischer, the 18-year-old United States chess champion, failed to show up yesterday for the thirteenth game of his series with Samuel Reshevsky. The move not only cost the young Brooklynite the forfeiture of the game but also the sixteen-match series.
BOSTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Irish Bob Murphy, a contender for the light heavyweight boxing championship in the early Nineteen Fifties, was killed in an automobile accident today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- The American Federation of Teachers urged local school systems today to provide special opportunity for culturally underprivileged children.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Navy announced today that it would expand its operating fleet by forty-two ships as part of the nation's defense build-up.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- When the cast of "Tender Is the Night" broke for lunch today at the Twentieth Century-Fox studio, Henry King, the director, verbally slaughtered some cinematic sacred cows.
NEW DELHI India, Aug. 17 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru warned Portugal against any attempt to reach two of her former enclaves that are about to be integrated with India.

Rights for the development of an Australian system for producing improved chromium alloys for high-temperature applications have been obtained from the Australian Government by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

United States imports of steel mill products rose in June to a fourteen-month high of 277,000 tons. The figure represented a rise of 11,000 tons over that of May and 67,000 tons over that of June, 1960.

United Air Lines announced yesterday the purchase of six Viscount turbo-prop planes from Vickers-Armstrongs, Ltd., to meet expanded traffic needs created by United's merger with Capital Airlines last June 1.

THE coordinated house, with continuity from sofa to silverware, is what is known as the Palazzo idea in decorating, now being displayed for the second year at Macy's. Derived from English Regency and Italian Ottocento, the cherrywood furnishings are suitably scaled for today's small homes and apartments.

The Mark Properties Company has sold the building containing 132 apartments and occupying a plot 250 by 165 feet at 789 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn. The buyers were investing clients of Milton Meschel, lawyer.

In a survey late in July, which it announced yesterday, the Federal Reserve Board found that more Americans planned to buy automobiles within the next twelve months than intended to do so in April, or 7.6 per cent now, compared with only 6.8 per cent of families three months earlier.

Two tenement houses occupying a plot 40 by 100 feet at 589-91 Third Avenue, adjoining the southeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street, have been sold by A.E.S. Realty, Inc., to clients of Walter Scott Co. The plot will be improved with a three-story business building, the ground floor of which will be occupied by a restaurant.

The American Ballet Theatre will play a New York engagement at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre from Oct. 2 through Oct. 14. The schedule of ballets will include American premieres by Harald Lander and Birgit Cullberg, as well as three revivals from the company's older repertoire.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Prices of industrial shares turned down-ward in the stock market here today. At 311, the Financial Times industrial shares index lost yesterday's gain of 1.3 points.

Home run watchers spent a fruitless afternoon at the Stadium yesterday, like contrite sinners waiting for Godot. They saw the Yankees down the Chicago White Sox, 5 -- 3, but for the most part, the runs trickled across the plate in a quiet and laborious manner.
OTTAWA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Commissioner C.W. Harvison of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, who took Dr. Klochko under his protection, described him as a chemist of "considerable world importance."
STANLEYVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 17 -- The visit of Premier Cyrille Adoula to Antoine Gizenga, head of the Soviet-backed regime here, has been extended for another day.

The Texas Railroad Commission yesterday set the permissible oil production of Texas for September at 2,699,540 barrels a day, about 50,000 a day more than in August. The commission retained the eight-day producing pattern for the fifth straight month.
COHASSET, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Jonathan Wales, a 21-year-old Boston University junior, today brought the historic Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup back to the Pleon Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- It may not become publicly apparent for a while, but this week's events in Berlin have profoundly changed the Berlin and German problems with which East and the West have been contending for the last decade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Representatives of large United States primary producers of aluminum were in agreement today that expanding markets and increasing consumption was the way to more employment in their industry.
The espresso machine, which often is noisier when making a cup of coffee than any complaining housewife, is also becoming increasingly complicated.
Ten men and two women were arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on indictments charging they assaulted policemen.
The Procter Gamble Company achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 124-year history during its fiscal year ended last June 30, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

At 5 P.M. yesterday at the Equitable Life Building, on Seventh Avenue between Thirty-first and Thirty-second Streets, a punctilious record-keeper, Anna Brennan, got up from her desk and pushed aside her typewriter and a half-used box of Kleenex.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 17 -- Premier Khrushchev seeks to persuade Chancellor Adenauer that all will be well in Soviet-German relations if Bonn will engage in peace negotiations with Moscow and recognize East Germany.

The Justice Department has been trying to get the Interstate Commerce Commission to adopt new rules against segregation in interstate bus travel. The object is to integrate rest rooms, waiting rooms and restaurants in all bus terminals for interstate travelers. The bus companies would also have to put up signs on their interstate buses saying that "Seating on this vehicle is without regard to race, color, creed or national origin."
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 -- After 2 hours 10 minutes of play, Robert Mark of Australia walked off the center court at the Newport Casino today the winner from his countryman, Alan Lane.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod voted today to terminate relations with the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod in a disagreement over the doctrine of fellowship.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Sir Muhammad Zafrulla Khan, Pakistan's new permanent representative of the United Nations, said today that the question of seating Communist China in the United Nations was a "credentials" problem, requiring a simple majority.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 17 -- The Westchester Board of Elections today rejected (on what some observers characterized as technical grounds) a Democratic voter's complaint (characterized by some as technical) that the Republican candidate for Mayor of Rye resides in Port Chester, not Rye.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. Joseph Cralle of Montclair won the New Jersey women's amateur golf championship today, defeating Mrs. Michael Burke of Cedar Hills, 1 up, in the 36-hole final at the Somerset Hills Country Club.
DETROIT, Aug. 18 (UPI) -Early returns from a nationwide poll showed today 95 per cent of the United Auto Workers members voting were backing a strike against car manufacturers.
Norris Houghton said yesterday that the theatre in the Soviet Union, was "at a more interesting condition than at any time since the Nineteen Thirties."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Two world records and one United States mark were smashed today as the men's national Amateur Athletic Association outdoor swimming and diving championships got off to an explosive start.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Federal Judge H.H. Grooms ruled unconstitutional today a Birmingham ordinance prohibiting Negroes and white persons from taking part in sports contests together.

SEATTLE, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Mary Lowell of Hayward, Calif., today won the national girls' junior golf championship by defeating Margaret Martin of St. Clairsville, Ohio, 1 up.

VILLAGERS heading for a tiny Italian grocery store called Echo, a landmark at 138 West Tenth Street, are in for a surprise. The shoebox of a store has been transformed into a showroom called Sculptsmith, which is full of contemporary brass and copper sculpture.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Richard Stockton of Riverdale, the Bronx, defeated Luis Glass of Jackson Heights, Queens, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, today to win the singles title for boys 13 years old and younger in the metropolitan junior and boys tennis championships at the Cherry Valley Club.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- John Osborne, the British playwright who was the original "angry young man," has written an open letter to his fellow countrymen in which he renounces Britain and accuses her people and leaders of being murderers.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The Plaquemines Parish (county) police jury urged voters in the parish today not to talk to two Federal agents investigating allegations of discrimination against Negro voters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Economic advisers to the Kennedy and Eisenhower Administrations sparred with restraint today before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- George H. (Pete) Bostwick's favored Tuscarora rallied today and won the $19,075 Saratoga Steeplechase Handicap by three lengths.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics scored three unearned runs against a former team-mate, Ray Herbert, in the seventh inning tonight and defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3 -- 1. Deron Johnson drove in the last two runs with a double.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A late rally in the grain futures market here today gave most contracts moderate to good gains.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Good N Safe won four blue ribbons at the Monmouth County Horse Show on Wolf Hill Farm today.

Sharp increases in air freight traffic for June in comparison with the same month last year were reported here yesterday by British Overseas Airways Corporation.

General Public Utilities Corporation and domestic subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 5.3 per cent in total kilowatt-hour sales of electricity for the twelve months ended last June 30. WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed tonight the foreign-aid authorization bill:

Recent events chronicled in this newspaper have caused deep concern to many who held high hopes at Bretton Woods in 1944 for the International Monetary Fund and the idea of international cooperation that it embodied.

Three policemen yesterday carried seven Children and a pregnant woman from the third floor of a burning five-story apartment building at 842 Myrtle Avenue in the Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 118.9 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 18 -- A high-speed automatic stamping press normally used to make metal parts for telephone switchboards has been converted into an aid for the blind by the Telephone Pioneers of America.
Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg began working at the request of President Kennedy yesterday to try to save the Metropolitan Opera's 1961-62 season.

STOKE-ON-TRENT, England, Aug. 18 -- If the United States needs the friendly English pub, as some housing experts believe, two young barmaids here want to help provide the genuine article. Sheila Evanson and her sister Barbara read of a New York study urging that low-cost housing projects be humanized by including pubs.
BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- "Panic buying" among West Berlin housewives was reported today as a result of the Communists' sealing off of East Berlin last week-end.

The board of directors of the Lincoln Printing Company proposed yesterday a three-for-one split of the common stock and and an increase in the capital shares to 1,500,000 from 250,000. Shareholders will vote on the proposals at a special meeting to be called in the near future.
Morris J. Kasper, treasurer of the American Chess Federation, said yesterday officials of that organization would meet next week to decide upon the final compensation to be paid to Bobby Fischer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The House and the Senate passed tonight foreign aid bills that were completely at odds on President Kennedy's long-range development loan program and the means of financing it.
BALBOA, C.Z., Aug. 18 -- The damaged ore carrier September Iles passed through the Panama Canal Zone bound north today under special procedures. The ship was floating partially on a mattress of air.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Five railroads are seeking a short cut to increase passenger fares by 14.23 per cent on Oct. 1.

IN these days when almost everything that is purchased costs more -- and often a lot more -- than it did ten years ago, canned tuna fish is a pleasant exception. At the present range of from 30 to 39 cents for a six-and-one-half to seven-ounce tin, tuna is about 7 cents less than it was a decade ago.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- West Coast shipowners are hopeful of reaching an agreement with two unions before the expiration next month of an eighty-day cooling-off period.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 -- Cleveland baseball fans, who soured on the Indians weeks and weeks ago, turned out 37,840 strong tonight -- the largest crowd of the local season -- to see the Yankee bombers, heated by Rogers Maris and Mickey Mantle do their stuff.
NEW YORKERS who are accustomed to ninety burglaries every twenty-four hours may choose to leave all entrances unguarded and trust that the burglars are more impressed with the Joneses.

Thirteen years ago when the Metropolitan Opera announced it had canceled its season, it took twenty-three days before various pressures brought the opera and its unions together in a workable agreement. Only twelve days have elapsed since the Metropolitan announced this year's cancellation, but already the chances of any rescinding of the decision look darker than they were in 1948.

BUFFALO, Aug 18 (UPI) -The Dallas Texans survived three long touchdown runs by the Buffalo Bills tonight and scored their third straight exhibition victory over American Football League rivals, 35 -- 26, before 11,166 fans in War Memorial Staduim.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Kennedy renewed his plea to Congress today for a long-term development loan program for foreign countries, financed by Treasury borrowing over a five-year period.
YONKERS, Aug. 19 -- More proof was provided by harness racing fans tonight that rich, highly ballyhooed events with the sport's top stars aren't necessarily the magnets that draw crowds.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 19 -- A Princeton University sculpture teacher who is equally adept at teaching boxing, said today he had found both skills useful in communicating with the people he met on a four-month goodwill tour of the Far East.
BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- Vice President Johnson pledged to the people of West Berlin today that the United States would never forget its obligations to them.
LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 16 -- The capital of Portuguese Angola has few of the sights and sounds of Africa.

IT has been fifty-five years since Upton Sinclair startled the meat-eaters of America with his exposure of conditions then existing in the Chicago stockyards in a novel called "The Jungle." It has been twenty-odd years since he did the first of his massive Lanny Budd books.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- Tottenham Hotspur, last season's soccer champion, scored a 2-1 victory over Blackpool today to open the 1961-62 season.

BATH, England -- Nearly a thousand American antiques hunters have taken advantage this summer of something most of them never expected to see -- a museum of American antiques lodged in an English country house. The new American Museum, as it is simply named, is at Claverton Manor on the outskirts of Bath.
NORWALK, Conn., August 19 -- The Democratic party faces a primary to determine its candidate for Mayor in the municipal election on Nov. 7.

ASK almost any contemporary composer to name the evils he would most like changed and chances are his list would include performances of difficult new music with insufficient rehearsal, and audiences who don't get the chance to get really acquainted with a score through only one performance.
IN his book "The Three Worlds of Boris Pasternak" [reviewed recently by George Steiner] Robert Payne elaborates many things in great detail, giving the illusion of intimate knowledge of his subject.

This year's Holiday Hop, an annual preparatory-school dance for the benefit of the Brooklyn division of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation, will take place at the St. George Hotel Roof in Brooklyn on Nov. 24.

VIRGINIA CITY, Nev. -- With the climax today to a week-end of saluting this once roystering "capital" of the fabulous Comstock Lode, formerly the richest silver deposit known, the question arises, "What next for the place?" The possible answers seem somewhat dubious.
LAOS, Nigeria, Aug. 19 -- The All-Nigeria People's Conference, called to plan Nigeria's role in African affairs, was opened today by the Prime Minister, Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa.
The time lag between the docketing and hearing of a case in Supreme Court in Brooklyn continues at twenty-four months, the court's annual report showed yesterday.

IN a fighting mood, John O'Hara has sanctioned the publication of five plays. Since Broadway has not seen fit to produce them as he wrote them, he has reached out to the public -- and it is large -- that his books have cultivated.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19 -- John Pflug, sailing under the banner of the New York Athletic Club, today made a clean sweep of the men's division and teamed with his wife, Jane, to take the mixed division honors in the three-day invitation Sunfish Class regatta.

Only three more weeks remain for American tourists to get home free under present customs regulations, for on Saturday, Sept. 9, the new $100 limit becomes effective. This is the schedule pushed through Congress by President Kennedy in the apparent belief that it would help to close the dollar gap between our exports and imports.

THE GREAT MEADOW. Elizabeth Madox Roberts. (New American Library. 50 cents.) A chance to rediscover the work of the gifted but now largely neglected Elizabeth Madox Roberts (1886-1941), whose stories of American frontier life were notable for their poetic style and insight into character.

MANKIND, J.B. Priestley explains, between pulls on his pipe, has lived under the sign of Pisces, the fish, for a couple of thousand years. Now, we are moving out of the reign of Christ, of whom Pisces was the symbol, into the sign of Aquarius, the water, and as we bob about in our fluid world, two planets exercise their tow upon us.

THE sculptor Jacques Lipchitz celebrates his seventieth birthday this year by giving rather than getting. In a single munificent gesture he has bequeathed 300 of the original models for his most famous pieces of sculpture, representing his entire life's work, to the Jerusalem Museum of Art.
A slight downward trend in airline passenger traffic through New York's major airports is evident in figures for the first six months of 1961.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 17 -- Ancient royal Balinese traditions of unsurpassed splendor were observed here today for probably the last time in the increasingly Socialistic republic of Indonesia.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Denmark and Sweden have urged that the General Assembly take up the question of the earth's rapidly increasing population and the depressing effect this "ominous trend" has on the economic development of nations.

HADDON HEIGHTS, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Levittown, Pa., earned a trip to the Little League world series at Williamsport, Pa., and the right to defend its world championship by defeating Darien, Conn., 8 -- 0, before 2,500 fans this afternoon.

SALEM, Mass. -- The birthplace here of Nathaniel Hawthorne, described by Carl Van Doren, the critic, as "the consummate flower" of New England's romancers, now has literally joined Salem's most famous dwelling, "The House of the Seven Gables," to make a double literary shrine.

Clear weather and more normal temperatures over the New York area last week helped turn potential shoppers into actual customers. Retail sales in the area rose during the week from the 1960 level after having dipped in the preceding week.
WASHINGTON, Aug 15 -- Representative Wright Patman has initiated what he calls a "definitive study" of tax-exempt foundations and their effect on the nation's economy.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 -- The Cincinnati Reds surged into a three-game lead in the National League tonight with a 3-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

GREENVILLE, Me. -- Big news for the camper, the boat enthusiast and the fisherman is being made on the eastern shore of Moosehead Lake. Nine miles north of Greenville, the finishing touches are being added to the new Lily Bay State Park. The facilities, it is said, will be among the best in the state, combining ease of access with a location in true wilderness.
CLAYTON, N.Y., Aug. 19 (AP) --Walter Swindeman of Toledo, Ohio, won the North American Dragon Class championship today in perfect sailing weather on the St. Lawrence River.
State Controller Arthur Levitt made a sentimental and political journey to Greenpoint yesterday. He promised that if elected Mayor he would improve the neighborhood he had known as a boy.

CITY rooftop gardeners can have a compost pile just as their country cousins do. One or two ordinary metal garbage cans, with covers, can be used as the containers for leaves, twigs, weeds and certain kitchen wastes.
TOKYO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Warning signals are flashing over Japan's booming economy today. Outracing the world in its rate of growth, Japanese industry has been warned by the Government to slow down.

A fifty-watt electric power plant which taps solar energy to pump water has been built by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. The plant is a prototype of a plant which will be designed to supply irrigating and household water in under-developed areas of the world, according to Dr. S.W. Herwald, vice president in charge of research for Westinghouse.
LITTLE ROCK, Aug. 19 -- The Legislature will come back to Little Rock next week to enact a new construction program for state institutions.

An unkempt girl in pin curls and casual attire sat smoking a cigarette in the personnel office of a major corporation. She had applied for employment as a stenographer at an unusually high salary, considering her modest skills.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Cuban Government formally asked the United States today to return the Bahia de Nipe.

THE new season is about to descend upon us with a double-barreled bang, for two of the great ballet companies of our time will be opening two weeks apart, and since each of them is to remain for three weeks, that gives them an overlapping middle week.

THE gun-slinging, bowlegged, hard-riding cowboy actor in Hollywood occasionally may find it tough making ends meet while waiting for studio bigwigs to cast another Western. But here in the domain of the sophisticated, the cultured, the realistic in cinema, the actor who can make like a cowboy is having himself a field day in popularity and in work.

PLANS are shaping rapidly for the screen version of the highly-lauded television play, "Requiem For a Heavyweight," under the production banner of David Susskind, the energetic head of Talent Associates.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The September Eve Opera Bal Masque will be given on Sept. 8 at Winfield Hall, former mansion here of the late Frank W. Woolworth, which overlooks Long Island Sound. The fete will benefit the Adelphi College Association and Long Island Cultural Center to be built on the campus of Adelphi.

Committees have been announced for the theatre party to a preview of "Kwamina" on Oct. 18 for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society. The musical starring Sally Ann Howes is scheduled to open at the 54th Street Theatre Oct. 23.

TORONTO -- In this golden age of gadgetry and automation, one tends to overlook the fact that the pioneers who settled in the North American wilderness did not lack for ingenuity themselves. For a glimpse of such inventiveness, one needs only to visit the Pioneer Village in the Black Creek Conservation Area here.

The independent oil producers of Texas are stepping up their campaign for a greater share of the domestic market. They contend that the other producing states are not bearing an equitable share of the burden of restricting domestic production to market demand and that oil imports are continuing at too high a level.

WHETHER the season is saved or not, the last weeks have been gloomy and exasperating for lovers of the Metropolitan Opera. So many wanted the cancellation notice to be rescinded; so few stood in the way of that happy eventuality.

THE cadre of the John Birch Society seems to be formed primarily of wealthy business men, retired military officers and little old ladies in tennis shoes. BAYSHORE, L.I., Aug. 19 -- Ralston Hayden's Stinger took Thistle Class honors today in the invitation regatta of the Bay Shore Yacht Club. The fleet got off under a full-sail southwester, which held steady at about fifteen miles an hour.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -Juan Marichal and Stu Miller combined on a five-hitter and Orlando Cepeda supplied the power with his thirty-fourth homer today as the Giants beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5 -- 0. The loss was the Dodgers' sixth straight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The House of Representatives has encountered an embarrassing question in its efforts to strengthen curbs on the activities of former Government officials and employes.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 -Mexico took a 2-1 lead over the United States in the American zone Davis Cup tennis final today as Antonio Palafox and Rafael Osuna defeated Chuck Mc Kinley and Dennis Ralston in the doubles.

ACHILL ISLAND, Ireland -- St. Patrick never got here. Nor have many Irish or other tourists found this holiday haven, which looks out over the blue Atlantic from an awesome shelter of mountains on three sides.

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- As firemen continued today to pour water on ruins of last night's million-dollar pier fire the police searched for the body of a missing pier worker.

FRED B. THOMAS of Oakland, Calif., last week was elected president of the American Philatelic Society, which celebrated its seventy-fifth anniversary at a convention in Chicago that ended yesterday.

TAKING the long view of world affairs has never been our strong point as a nation. We become so wrapped up in the events of the day that we do not look beyond them. KATONAH, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- The trustees of the Katonah Village Library are sponsoring a benefit musicale next Saturday evening in the music room of the Harvey School.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- The California Fair Employment Practice Commission ended its twenty-third month of operation this week with only four complaints of discrimination out of about 1,100 sent to the public hearing stage.

The thirtieth anniversary of the Bled tournament, won by the late Dr. Alexander Alekhine, will be memorialized by an international chess masters congress Sept. 2 to Oct. 4 at the Casino in Bled, Yugoslavia. Twenty will compete.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Premier Cyrille Adoula declared today that he and Antoine Gizenga had agreed on a united Congo and would bring President Moise Tshombe's secessionist Katanga Province back into the fold, by force if necessary.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- The United States swept the two singles matches and one doubles match today for a 3-0 lead against Britain in Wightman Cup tennis competition.

The article in The Times of Aug. 11 referring to the agreement between President Kennedy and Vice President Johnson providing far action in case of the President's incapacity, and Arthur Krock's column of the same date on this subject point up the extraordinary, unwillingness of Congress to deal with the vital question of Presidential inability.

Herbert A. Krumbein has been elected a vice president and placed in charge of the new Richmond, Va., office of B.N. Rubin Co., Inc., New York investment bankers. He had been with Francis I. du Pont Co.
TORQUAY, England, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Jim Wynne of Miami piloted Yo-Yo through the rough English Channel today to second place in The Daily Express international power-boat race.

WILLARD D. Morgan's "Leica Manual" (New York: Morgan Morgan, Inc., 456 pp., $6.95), first published in 1935 and last revised in 1955, has just been published in its fourteenth edition. The six-year lapse since the previous edition is the longest in the book's history.

FEW figures in Africa today are more controversial than Jomo Kenyatta. To Africans he is a symbol of nationalism and a potential leader of his country, Kenya. To many of Africa's resident whites, in contrast, whether they are inside or outside Kenya, Kenyatta symbolizes the Mau Mau.

TARRYTOWN, Aug. 19 -- The Bear Mountain Trophy, the largest cup in predicted-log competition, was won today by Ray S. Leach. In his thirty-flour-foot cruiser Polaris II he ran at eight knots and turned in an accuracy score of 99.57 cent.
HARTFORD, Aug. 19 -- A movie actress and a former New England boxing champion are among candidates for the City Council in a nonpartisan primary to be held on Oct. 17.

Pierre Monteux has accepted the post of principal conductor of the London Symphony, pointing up again the incredible vitality of the French conductor, who celebrated his eighty-sixth birthday last April. Mrs. Owen R. Cheatham recently met at her home with members of her committee to further plans for the eleventh annual luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic. The luncheon, arranged for Nov. 28 at the Waldorf-Astoria, will raise funds for the New York Philharmonic Orchestra.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The annual Atlantic Class championship series went to the defending champion, Briggs U. HAVANA, Aug. 20 -- Almost all embassies here will protest the Castro Government's refusal to return immediately all Cuban currency the embassies deposited during a currency exchange two weeks ago, informed sources said tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- Ray Renfro took a 27-yard scoring pass from Milt Plum with seven seconds left, enabling the Cleveland Browns to post a 27-24 victory over the San Francisco Forty-Niners today in an exhibition between National Football League clubs.

If the rivals in New York's Mayoral campaign appear wall-eyed on their neighborhood walking tours, it is because they so often have one eye on the citizen whose hand they are shaking and the other on news cameras.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 -- Steel demand is building up on schedule. Within the next few weeks it is expected that, aside, from automotive steel orders, regular steel bookings will show a strong improvement. Most steel officials now expect that total business booked this month will come close to the June level and will be about 10 per cent above the July level.

DUBLIN, N.H., Aug. 20 -- More than 275 residents and visitors crowded the community church at vespers here this afternoon to witness a revival of early medieval church drama in a miracle play written and directed by Elizabeth Pool of Dublin.

Bank Leumi le-Israel, Israel's oldest and largest commercial bank, will convert its agency at 60 Wall Street today to a branch. It is the first foreign bank to make such a conversion under a law passed last year by the Legislature at Albany.

It was not uncommon in the Nineteen Twenties or early Nineteen Thirties for Soviet scientists to defect when given the opportunity by a trip outside the country. Many of such defectors then were people who had come to maturity under czarism and were unsympathetic to communism, while to be a Soviet scientist then was a source neither of prestige nor appreciable material reward.

LOWELL, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Ch. Rudel's Solitaire, a 3 1/2 year-old greyhound owned by Dr. Elsie S. Neustadt of Quincy, was named best in show at the third annual dog show and obedience trials of the Greater Lowell Kennel Club, Inc., tonight.
A total of 5,744 tenants situated on the sites of housing and other public works projects were given relocation assistance by city agencies during the first six months of the year.

The Northrop Corporation has appointed William F. Ballhaus executive vice president, it was announced over the week-end. Frederick Stevens has been named a vice president and general manager of its Nortronics division, succeeding Mr. Ballhaus.
Rear-end collisions cause the most accident injury claims, according to the Allstate Insurance Company.

WHEN George Noel Gordon, Lord Byron, died at Missolonghi in 1824 he was only 36 years old. But he was the world's most celebrated writer, a great poet and a sensationally popular and controversial one. He was a lord and an extraordinarily handsome, charming one. And he was notorious for his reckless love affairs, for shocking scandals and for epochal dissipations.

Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner have acted in the best public interest in agreeing on the steps to resolve the city's school problems. They have properly accepted the recommendations of the State Education Commissioner as the competent authority, both for immediate emergency action and for the even more vital long-range reforms.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The biggest world - record binge in swimming history ended today with four more marks in the Amateur Athletic Union men's national outdoor championships.
A spectacular five-alarm fire blazed out of control early today along the Weehawken, N.J., waterfront.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Aug. 20 -- New appeals for calm were made here today in the face of increasing incidents of violence before the elections throughout the colony tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles won their fifth straight game today, defeating the Washington Senators, 9-3, in a steady rain.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has rejected protests by ten major freight forwarders against an air-surface express service to Alaska that not only meets all-surface transportation rates but cuts delivery time by about four days.

A baby raccoon was captured in the wilds of New York City by the police yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The White House expects its one-millionth visitor of the year this week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Kennedy's proposals to revise the law governing national emergency strikes is not likely to go to Congress this year, as originally planned.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 20 -- The Fifteenth International Edinburgh Festival opened here today in much the same atmosphere as its predecessors -- pipers skirling and glittering on the floodlit Edinburgh Castle Esplanade, hotels and lodging houses crammed and shops primed to do business with every conceivable variety of Tartan.
One man went berserk and three escaped mental patients fell to their knees in prayer yesterday morning when four policemen raided the first man's lower East Side flat.

HORNELL, N.Y., Aug 20 -- Cocker spaniels from Connecticut swept the top honors in their breed today as the annual Southern Tier Kennel Club dog show and obedience trial opened at Ample City Park.

Alfred Lunt will return to Broadway this season, but not as an actor. He has agreed to stage "First Love," starring Elisabeth Bergner. Written by Samuel Taylor, the comedy is an adaptation of Romain Gary's autobiographical novel. "The Promise at Dawn," to be published Oct. 10 by Harper's.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- A nightclub on south side of Indianapolis burned today in what the authorities said might be a result of racial tensions in the neighborhood.

Record sales and earnings were achieved by Federated Department Stores, Inc., in its second quarter and half-year ended July 29, the big department store chain reported yesterday. DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The 1962 model automobiles began to trickle off assembly lines last week at General Motors and Studebaker-Packard plants. Chrysler and American Motors will starts work on the new models this week.

Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg won assurance yesterday from the Metropolitan Opera that it would reinstate its canceled 1961-62 season if it could reach an agreement quickly with the musicians' union and if singers were available.
RYE, Aug. 21 -- Twin garden apartment houses with a built-in fall-out shelter will be constructed on Theodore Fremd Avenue near this city's business district, a developer announced today.
SHREVEPORT, La., Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Ben C. Dawkins upheld today most of a Government suit claiming discrimination against Negroes who attempted to vote in Bienville Parish (County).
TOKYO, Aug. 21 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, asserted today that in the future the West would not be allowed to enter West Berlin without the permission of the East Germans.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing (3M) Company of St. Paul has adopted a unified identification system, after nearly sixty years of diversifying its trademarks to keep pace with its growing product line.

Storm clouds have been hovering over Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street these sultry days, as the presentiments grew thicker that one of New York's most respected institutions, the Metropolitan Opera, might have to shut up shop for a while and go off to the Orient to lick its financial wounds.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- Three international grandmasters, Arthur Bisguier and Pal Benko, both of New York, and Zoltan Kovacs of Los Angeles, were tied today at 5 1/2-1/2 after six rounds of play in the United States open chess championship.

Events today: Downtown Manhattan Concert, George F. Seuffert, guest conductor, Bowling Green Park, noon; Municipal Concerts Orchestra, Julius Grossman, conductor, Helen Kwalwasser, violinist, Silver Lake Park, S.I., 8:15 P.M.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- A company formed to build six skyscrapers over the Illinois Central Railroad tracks on Chicago's downtown Lake Front announced plans today to double its construction program at a cost of half a billion dollars.

In your editorial of Aug. 20 entitled "Chaos in Foreign Aid" you stated that the long-range, low-interest lending aspects of the foreign aid bill were killed in the House of Representatives by a vote of 287 to 140. This is inaccurate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Treasury's short-term bill rates moved slightly in opposite directions on today's sale of the regular weekly issues. The average discount on the rate on the ninety-two-day issue declined after a sharp, four-week climb.

METROPOLITAN area gunners soon will be thinking of sighting-in weapons for the hunting season, the first phase of which is a mere six weeks away. If they are not they should be. Attending to this important detail can make the difference between bringing home game and bringing home elaborate alibis.
The manufacturer of a toothpaste formally recognized by the American Dental Association has purchased a one-hour television show and turned over all commercial time to the A.D.A.
VENICE, Italy, Aug. 21 -- The French delegation at the Venice Film Festival caused a stir tonight by refusing to attend the screening of Yugoslavia's official entry, "Thou Shalt Not Kill."

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- An all-day rain forced the postponement of the third annual Maurice Stokes benefit basketball game scheduled tonight at Kutsher's Country Club. The game will be played tomorrow at 9 P.M. on the outdoor court.
Would you ask a bowler to give up his beer frame? Probably no more than you would ask a golfer to give up his drink at the nineteenth hole.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Senator Barry Goldwater said today that the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was muzzling military leaders.
DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 21 -- The Ford Motor Company put ten new models on the line today to strengthen its hand for an expected near-record 1962 automotive year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- An American representative of Japanese makers of iron and steel products contended today that any restrictions on United States imports would mean fewer jobs for Americans.

HONG KONG, Aug. 21 -- Special measures to "safeguard public health" and combat "seasonal diseases" are being taken by Communist authorities in the Chinese province of Kwantung, according to Chinese language broadcasts.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 -- "How does an idea come?" Gertrude Berg asked rhetorically. "It just happens," she answered herself. "God puts an idea in your head."

Catholic Charities has lived and worked with the people of Newburgh for many years. Clearly there are social and economic problems to be faced and solved in Newburgh. Indeed, the issues have more significance for the welfare of all citizens than the problems solely involved in administering public assistance.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Federation of Dominican Students charged the armed forces today with new political killings and appealed to the Organization of American States to intervene.

Stocks of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation had another busy day on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The heavy activity followed last week's performance, when the auto maker's common stock was the most actively traded issue on the Big Board, with 1,509,700 shares changing hands.

The First National City Bank of New York said yesterday that it was prepared to obtain travel reservations, information on medical and visa requirements and advice on where to live and buy for its business-executive customers who may be transferred overseas.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A union official called Newburgh's new welfare program "a hoax and a complete denial of human rights" today.

A 17-year-old confessed slayer sloshed through a rain-drenched Brooklyn marsh before dawn yesterday and showed the police where and how he had stabbed two young boys fifty-five times in a fit of anger a week ago.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 21 -- Thirty-nine debutantes of Darien and New Canaan will be presented at the fourteenth annual Darien-New Canaan Autumn Cotillion Sept. 8 at the Wee Burn Country Club. The young women were guests at a tea recently given by the cotillion committee, of which Mrs. Richard N. Rand is chairmail.

Franco Patane, conductor at the Teatro San Carlo in Naples, Italy, and Walter Susskind, conductor of the Toronto Symphony Orchestra, have been engaged by the New York City Opera for its fall season at the City Center, opening on Oct. 5.

DENVER, Aug. 21 -- The head of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, said today that a "cardinal principle" of her organization was the avoidance of any affiliation or identification with any political party in Israel.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement made by Vice President Johnson today on his return here from West Berlin:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Private American investment abroad increased by a record of $5,500,000,000 last year, raising the total to a new high of $50,300,000,000.
A RESTRAINED and effective telecast about cancer and the means of combating it was shown last night over WNEW-TV (Channel 5).

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 21 (AP) -- This city was agog with its annual excitement tonight as Little League baseball players scurried about in preparation for the opening elimination games of their world series.
A bridge to link Rikers Island and Astoria, Queens, has been under discussion by the Departments of Correction and Public Works.

The price of being black includes being overcharged by bankers, overlooked by Congressmen and being portrayed in Newburgh, N.Y., as "lazy, criminal and immoral," a Negro leader declared here yesterday.

A syndicate headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank submitted the best bid yesterday for $1,650,000 of airport bonds of King County (Seattle), Wash. The bid designated an interest cost of 3.4912 per cent. The obligations are secured by the general taxing power.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- The House approved a bill today that would provide the death penalty for airplane hijackers.
ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- Following is the text of Governor Rockefeller's message on school legislation sent to the Legislature today:
NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Federal Civil Aeronautics Board authorities were investigating today the mystery of a plane that disappeared last week with a pilot and three engineers aboard.
SHREVEPORT, La., Aug. 21 (AP) -- District Judge John A. Dixon Jr. found six Negro Freedom Riders guilty today of having an intent to provoke a breach of the peace.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Stock market activity was at a low ebb here today and prices continued to decline in most sections.

THE "cellophane-wrapped" child, whose parents conspire to insulate him from all of life's harsher realities, lives in a world in which nobody ever dies, illness is virtually unheard of, and tempers are never lost, for nobody ever gets angry.

Cardinal Spellman yesterday urged Senator Wayne Morse "to refrain from fanning the embers of religious discord" in comments about the Roman Catholic clergy's position on Federal aid to public schools.
Three important executive changes were announced yesterday by Trans World Airlines, Inc. The changes will become effective Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today designed to discourage United States shipowners from registering their ships under foreign flags and then returning them to American registry after rebuilding them abroad.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Light but fairly general selling weakened most grain futures contracts today on the Board of Trade.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 21 -- Jomo Kenyatta, African nationalist leader in Kenya, was given complete freedom today. He had spent nine years of imprisonment and house detention for having led the Mau Mau terrorist rebellion.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- An order approving the merger of two large Chicago banks, the City National Bank and Trust Company into the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, was issued in Washington today by Ray M. Gidney, Controller of the Currency.

While a two-year extension of the life of the Civil Rights Commission is arousing some controversy in Congress, two far more ambitious civil rights programs have been in committee until the dust has gathered on them. One was introduced by Democrats, Senator Clark of Pennsylvania and Representative Celler of Brooklyn. Another bears the names of New York Republicans, Senators Javits and Keating.

In an expansion move, the investment concern of Bacon, Stevenson Co. has leased the entire twenty-first floor and part of the twentieth flor of the building at 25 Broad Street, on the corner of Exchange Place. The space includes a penthouse with a private elevator and garden.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- At least fifteen states will be collecting higher taxes by the end of 1961, the result of legislative attempts to finance spiraling state budgets.
The chancellor of the City University of New York charged yesterday that waste and inefficiency in planning and construction procedures for college buildings were hampering higher education here.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- Joe Gibbon, helped by ElRoy Face, registered his first triumph in a month tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates downed Milwaukee, 4 -- 1, and ended the Braves' victory string against the home team at seven games.
The State Board of Regents, acting quickly yesterday under the new school emergency law, scheduled a meeting next Monday of the eleven-member panel that will nominate a new city Board of Education.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 22 (Reuters) -- The Swedish Government has decided not to follow the lead of Britain and Denmark in seeking membership to the European Economic Community, or Common Market, Premier Tage Erlander said today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that an ordinance in suburban Park Ridge that limited solicitation for charitable causes to one organization was unconstitutional.
Fifty years ago today a thin, 14-year-old boy walked into the spacious office of the director of the Bronx Zoo and asked for a job. He was made an assistant keeper in the bird house, at $30 a month.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Errcountess, the useful filly owned by Sidney M. Barton, showed a fine burst of speed to score by a nose over Chicha of El Peco Ranch in the feature race at Saratoga today.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- British European Airways, with a 21 per cent increase in passenger traffic, made a profit of 1,545,321 ($4,326,989) during the last operating year.
The City Council moved yesterday to make repeal of local taxes a central issue in the bitter primary fight between Mayor Wagner and the regular Democratic organization.

The Space Design Group, Inc., headed by Marvin Affrime and Robert Pontabry, designed the remodeling of the Air France Building at 683 Fifth Avenue. J.F.N. Associates were the designers of the modernization of the office building at 90 West Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee was told today that Government subsidies were essential if the nation's increasing elderly population was to be provided with good housing.
PARIS, Aug. 22 -- A common European currency may be the next step after Britain's entry into the Common Market.
Trading on the New York commodity exchanges was relatively quiet yesterday, with price declines predominating.
THIS deal comes from the most recent (August) issue of the magazine "Texas Bridge."

JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Eddie Merrins, the Long Island open champion, led the way with a 70 in the first round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today. His score over the 7,122-yard Meadow Brook Club course was the only round under par 71.

TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 22 (UPI) -- Mary Lowell, a high school senior from Hayward, Calif., beat JoAnne Gunderson, the defender, in the second round of the women's national amateur golf championship today. She won on the nineteenth hole.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall recommended today a stepped-up search for economical ways of changing salt water into fresh water.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse said tonight Cardinal Spellman "couldn't be more wrong" than in his reply to a recent Morse speech on the Roman Catholic position in the Federal aid to education controversy.

ROSLYN, L.I., August 22 -- Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rose of the host Engineers Country Club scored a 42, 36 -- 78 today and won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association husband and wife Class B championship.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- West Berliners are taking their own reprisal against the Communist action sealing off the border between East and West Berlin. They are boycotting the elevated railway, which is run by the East German Communists.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- The Davis Cup doubles teams of the United States and Mexico began play today in the national doubles tennis championships. The competition was resumed at the Longwood Cricket Club after yesterday's rain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The House voted without fanfare or discussion today to make it easier to draw pensions under the Congressional pension system. It sent to the Senate by voice vote a bill to reduce the age and length-of-service requirements.
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP) -- An East German astronomer has apparently found an important link in the evolution of the universe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn apparently is not satisfied with the Administration's compromise school-aid proposal.
Publication of the new Soviet periodical in Yiddish appears to mark a further retreat by Soviet authorities from the policy followed by Stalin in his last years toward Soviet Jews and their culture.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Aug. 22 -- Dr. Cheddi Berret Jagan, described by friends as "a man who always liked to argue a lot," faces a future brimming with his favorite pastime.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- An Air Force colonel went on military trial here today on a charge of dereliction of duty in the collapse of a Texas Tower eighty miles off the New Jersey coast last Jan. 15.

IN the first scrimmage play involving Charlie Conerly, the most precious piece of bric-a-brac in the collection of the New York Giants, the ancient quarterback rolled out to throw a pass. He rolled so far that he was out of his protective pocket and completely exposed to the tidal wave of defensive linemen surging in on him.
Mayor Wagner was charged yesterday with having violated the City Charter by using city-paid Gracie Mansion servants at his Islip, L.I., summer home.

Roger Burlingame, whose biography of Elmer Davis, "Don't Let Them Scare You," was published in April, has signed a contract with Lippincott for a book to be called "The Sixth Column." The author says it was "inspired by hatred of communism" and the difference between hate and fear.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Charley Neal fumbled Julian Javier's ground ball in the ninth inning, permitting Bob Lillis to score the winning run as the St. Louis Cardinals scored a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

A block of 633,400 common shares of the Upjohn Company was offered to the public yesterday at $52.50 a share by Morgan Stanley Co. and associates. The stock is being sold by Kalamazoo College, certain charitable organizations and members of the family of Dr. W.E. Upjohn, founder of the drug manufacturing company in 1866.
DENVER, Aug. 22 -- The Hadassah Medical Organization and Hebrew University will open a complete medical school for African and Asian students in Jerusalem in November.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- The United States appealed today to France and Tunisia to negotiate without delay their differences over the Bizerte naval base in the interest of world peace.

American film audiences, whose acquaintance with Yugoslavia has been limited largely to views of the country's army in dubbed Italian costume spectacles, will soon have the opportunity to sample the Communist satellite's expanding film industry.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Very Rev. George F. O'Dea, superior general of St. Joseph's Society of the Sacred Heart, said today that he had ordered two Roman Catholic priests to stop their plans to participate in the Freedom Rider movement.

Net income of the Carnation Company in the six months ended June 30 rose to $4,865,546 or $2.20 a share, from $4,401,219, or $2.02 a share, in the 1960 period. Sales climbed to $212,943,556 from $204,279,575. The company cans evaporated milk.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 22 -- In a tense finish that would do justice to some of the tight ones in the major leagues, El Cajon, Calif., eliminated Levittown, Pa., the defender, in the Little League world series opener today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A Senate committee was told today that gambling was flourishing as a multibillion-dollar industry partly because of corruption or leniency among judges, sheriffs and policemen.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Fred Harlow of Newark, Ohio, won the Class D national trap shooting championship by cracking 196 of 200 targets today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 22 -- President Janio Quadros today furthered his "independent" policy of closer relations with Cuba and the Communist world as Carlos Lacerda, the anti-Communist Governor of the state of Guanabara, took his protest to the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said today he would ask the Senate Internal Security subcommittee to investigate the visit of Owen Lattimore, the Johns Hopkins University Far Eastern specialist, to Outer Mongolia.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 22 -- The British Governor of Kenya, Sir Patrick Renison, traveled to Kiambu, eighteen miles north of Nairobi, today to meet Jomo Kenyatta, African nationalist leader who was granted full freedom yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- An uneasy calm was restored to Middlesbrough today after three days of clashes between the police and crowds of hoodlums attacking the property of Arab and Pakistani residents.
BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- The East German Communists announced late tonight sharp new restrictions on travel to East Berlin for both West Berliners and "foreigners."
DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- Oldsmobile's F-85 was promoted today to the top of General Motors luxury compact entries for the model year of 1962.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A musical program that ranged from Aaron Copland's "Hoedown" to Brahms' "Lullaby" entertained 345 physically handicapped children today on the south lawn of the White House.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The grain futures market almost stalled today except for September soybeans, which attracted a broad general demand and moved up 3 3/4 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- United States officials shifted their attention today from the drama in Berlin to the job of preparing an Allied bargaining position for negotiations with the Soviet Union on Germany, probably in late October.
ALBANY, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The State Public Works Department reported today that business on the state barge canal system was continuing to drop.

Four major corporations that manufacture carbon dioxide were named in a civil antitrust suit filed in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday by the Justice Department.

ELIZABETH CITY, Va., Aug. 22 -- The Continental Army Command, with its headquarters at near-by Fort Monroe, is convinced it can train new divisions faster than the nation can equip them or transport them overseas.

The National Dairy Products Corporation is going into the fish canning field in Australia in a further move to expand its foreign operations.
The anticipated negotiations on a new contract did not materialize yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera dispute, but they are scheduled for today.

YONKERS, Aug. 22 -- Fifty minutes before the pari-mutuel windows opened at Yonkers Raceway tonight, Kate's Daughter, a young bay filly won the largest purse of the evening -- $3,750. That was the winning share of the $7,500 New York State Sire Stakes for 2-year-old trotters.

A total of 985 persons were injured in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was 160 fewer than in the comparable 1960 period.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 22 -- More than 500 youngsters swam and floated at six town beaches here today to prove they had studied their lessons during a seven-week swimming program conducted by the Department of Beaches.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 22 -- West Germany's political parties continued today to struggle for advantage from the Berlin crisis.

The Cities Service Company announced yesterday the signing of a contract with the Secretary of the Interior for the construction of a plant near Ulysses, Kan., with a capacity to deliver 2,000,000 cubic feet of helium gas a day.
TOKYO, Aug. 22 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan flew home to Moscow today, leaving Western diplomats in Tokyo beaming happily and hoping that he would come back to Japan soon.
Mayor Wagner moved vigorously yesterday to obtain labor votes in his campaign for re-nomination and re-election.

Directors of Stokely-Van Camp., Inc., raised the quarterly dividend yesterday and voted to distribute a stock dividend to common shareholders. On the New York Stock Exchange the stock hit a high for the year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, which was expelled from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in 1957, today challenged George Meany, A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, to a debate in Cincinnati Sunday on the relative advantages of the teamsters union and the A.F.I.-C.I.O.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- President Kennedy confirmed today that he was the informant who touched off protests against a plan at the Pentagon to close the Philadelphia, Boston and San Francisco Navy yards.

Francis Peter Crosby's conviction for stock fraud was upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals. At the same time it reversed the convictions of three stockbrokers on stock fraud charges. The court ordered that the indictment against the brokers be dismissed.

The Empire State Building is being sold to an investment group headed by Lawrence A. Wien for $65,000,000. The price, which does not include the valuable Fifth Avenue land under the structure, is believed to be the highest ever paid for a single building.
The cast and other details about "Sound of the Sixties," the special television program to be written and produced by Dore Schary, were announced yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- France is at odds with the United States and Britain over the timing and method of an approach to the Soviet Union for negotiations on the Berlin and German problems. But there is no basic discord.

Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan and his Leftist People's Progressive party won their expected victory in the British Guiana elections. He will form a Government that will have internal self-rule, and it is indicated that he will press immediately for independence for British Guiana.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, warning of a possible new round of inflation, urged President Kennedy today to seek ways to prevent a steel price increase this fall.

Twenty years of summer performances by the Popular Price Grand Opera Company at the Triborough Stadium have ended, it was learned yesterday, because the city has decided to invoke a licensing requirement.
A cocktail party on Sutton Place added class last night to the New York City political campaign.
Another series of scientific tests, arranged this time by Sports Illustrated, a national sports magazine, indicates that the 1961 major league baseball has more bounce than the 1952 ball.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 -- California is putting up another $100,000,000 of state bonds for sale at public bidding in less than a month. Bert A. Betts, State Treasurer, set the date for Sept. 13.

Glass container manufacturers are making progress in their battle with the can makers for the beer market, according to a spokesman for a leading glass producer.

In the stock market yesterday it was "the mixture as before." Once again, as in recent sessions, stocks backed and filled and failed to set a clear-cut pattern. However, prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed slightly higher on average.

TEEN-AGERS may compete in the twentieth annual Harvest Dance Contest to be held tomorrow evening at the Mall in Central Park. Competition will be in the fox trot, waltz, cha cha and jitterbug. Admission is free.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- The House passed by voice vote today a bill designed, to "expose and attack" identical bids on Government contracts.
Clams were an issue yesterday in a Federal-state-city conference on pollution in Raritan Bay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The United States set a record for wheat and flour exports during the year that ended on June 30. The Department of Agriculture said today that 660,000,000 bushels were shipped in that period, 20 per cent more than the previous record of 550,000,000 bushels exported during the 1956-57 year.

The draft indebtedness of Latin-American importers to United States exporter increased again in July, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday. The debts of Latin-American importers increased in eleven of the twenty-three countries, according to the Reserve Bank's monthly survey of twelve large commercial banks.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Governor Rockefeller's controversial fall-out shelter proposal will probably not be an issue in the election-year legislative session of 1962.
A young Dick Whittington came to town this week but he did it the hard way. Jose Benevides, a 20-year-old lad from Argentina, rode his bicycle 16,000 miles to get here.
L. Judson Morhouse, the Republican state chairman, said yesterday that Frank Kenna had reaffirmed to him during the day his intention of not resuming his office as Republican leader of Queens.

During his recent tour of South America Adlai Stevenson recognized in his report to Secretary Rusk the urgent need for deeds, not words, to bridge the gap between rich and poor if democratic governments are to survive strong pressures from the pro-Communist Left and the ultraconservative Right.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 22 -- Engineers' tests indicate that the introduction of jet flights at Newark Airport will sharply increase the noise level in the surrounding area, Mayor Stephen J. Bercik said tonight.
The committee has been formed for the dinner dance to be held in the Embassy Club of the Sheraton-East on Sept. 11 as a benefit for Jobs for Youth, a free employment agency.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Alick Dick, 45-year-old head of the big auto company of Standard Triumph International, has resigned as managing director after a board room dispute in which six fellow directors were ousted.
Negotiations in the nationwide maritime dispute entered a final phase yesterday under the auspices of the fact-finding board named by President Kennedy in June.
