A CORPSE that mysteriously materializes at the oddest moments and in the most unlikely spots in a regal villa on the French Riviera is the kicker in "Scream of Fear," a British-made melodrama that came to the Forum and the Fine Arts yesterday.

HONOLULU, Aug. 22 -- Scientists from many lands met here today to mark the 100th anniversary of the first proposal for international exploration of Antarctica and to compare notes on the fruits of subsequent efforts.
Jean Dalrymple, the City Center theatrical producer, was awakened in her bedroom early yesterday by a prowler who was rummaging through her handbag.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 22 -- Slogans, placards and banners such as are heard and seen throughout this pennant-starved area may help jam 29,383 frantic fans into Crosley Field, as they did tonight.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22 -- Argentina is undergoing crippling internal disputes at a moment when the Government is trying to exert leadership in hemisphere affairs.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Milt Pappas uncorked a wild pitch in the tenth inning tonight, permitting Jim Rivera to score with the winning run as the Kansas City Athletics beat the Baltimore Orioles, 3-2.
The Transit Authority announced yesterday it had ended its fiscal year on June 30 with a surplus of $2,146,976. This brought the agency's reserves to $25,000,000.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
BERLIN, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- The Communist police detained a United States major and three American soldiers in the heart of Berlin today and questioned them for an hour before they released them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Justice Department disclosed today that it had demanded, and received, stiff guarantees on the major Chicago bank merger that was approved yesterday by the Controller of the Currency the Federal regulator of national banks.
A remarkable change has come over the city's Police Department in the last six months without attracting public attention.

State Controller Arthur Levitt urged Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg yesterday to intervene in the strike of ready-mix concrete truck drivers. The walkout, now in its eighth week, has tied up half of the city's $1,125,000,000-a-year construction industry.
A decision by the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile on the Watkins Glen (N.Y.) request to hold the United States Grand Prix on Oct. 7 is expected before the week-end.
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Natural radio signals have been picked up from Mercury, the closest planet to the sun, astronomers reported today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- A fleet of nineteen cruising yachts manned entirely by crews under 18 years of age headed out from Scotch Caps in mid-afternoon today in quest of the junior distance sailing championship of Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- The Marine Corps said today that volunteers had responded so enthusiastically to its call that it would reach its recently increased manpower level six months ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Senate banking subcommittee approved today legislation increasing from $150,000, to $250,000, the maximum amount of debentures the Small Business Administration (S.B.A.) may purchase from any one small business investment company.

The New York City Housing Authority sold yesterday two issues of short-tern notes totaling $31,212,000 and subsidized by the State Government at interest costs ranging from 1.70418 to 1.77614 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- An avalanche of amendments brought a halt today to an attempt to extend the life of the Civil Rights Commission by a rider on an appropriations bill.

The Decorative Plant Corporation, manufacturer of artificial flowers and plants since 1896, has sold the five-story office and loft building it occupies at 136-38 West Twenty-fourth Street. Nationwide Investors, Inc., the buyer, leased back the building to Decorative, which will contiune to occupy the structure and the space it uses in adjoining buildings at 130-34 and 140 West Twenty-fourth Street.
Rockaway Park in Queens is getting over an attack of Hollywooditis. For three days it has been a movie set, all in the cause of advertising.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- Nellie Fox singled through the pitcher's box with two out in the ninth innning tonight, scoring Minnie Minoso from second base and giving the Chicago White Sox a 4-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

One hundred thousand square feet of space in the Pan Am Building, which is under construction at 200 Park Avenue adjoining Grand Central Terminal, has been leased by six savings banks service organizations and the Savings Banks Trust Company.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 22 -- The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club crew, skippered by Steven Moore, headed the qualifiers for the Long Island Sound midget championship after the three-race preliminary series off Indian Harbor Y.C. today.

Paperboard production in the nation totaled 327,549 tons in the week ended Aug. 19, off from 332,332 tons in the preceding week. This figure compared with 314,607 tons in the 1960 week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 22 -- Religious vigilantes raided a clearance camp for teen-age immigrants near Haifa this afternoon and abducted twenty children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon in effect warned today that Congressional denial of long-term financing authority for the Administration's foreign aid program might undermine the Alliance for Progress program in Latin America.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 22 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru called today for "responsible people from each side" to confer to work out peaceful solutions for the problems of Berlin and the two Germanys.

Peeking at the investment portfolios of the big mutual funds can be an intriguing pastime for the small investor who likes to measure his judgment against that of the professionals. The Capital Gains Research Bureau, Inc., Larchmont, N.Y., investment advisory service, has just issued a report showing the stocks in which eighty-three leading funds had their largest investments on June 30.

PARIS, Wednesday, Aug. 23 -- Jacques Soustelle, a former close associate of President de Gaulle but now his bitter political enemy, disclosed today that he had chosen voluntary exile abroad to escape what he believed to be a threat of arrest.

Your Aug. 21 editorial concerning the Democratic Primary lacked both logic and conviction. I appreciate your generous personal references to me, but your conclusion is labored and rationalized beyond the bounds of fair reason.

The off-again, on-again hassle over the widening of Fulton Street clearly demonstrates the needless waste of human and financial resources that follow in the wake of piecemeal planning, while it vividly highlights the desperate need for a modern master plan for this entire City Hall district.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Administration's tax bill is dead for this year, informed sources reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- Art Mahaffey pitched a one-hitter tonight and eased the Philadelphia Phillies to a 6-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Harry Q.M. Clawson of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club won the first and only race completed today as the tenth annual Hipkins Trophy series to decide the men's sailing champion of Western Long Island Sound began off the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club.
A man who says he is a song writer made a feeble attempt yesterday to rob the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company branch at Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 -- Jim Mertz of the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y., tallied a pair of third places with his Allegra as the International 210 Class championship opened at the South Boston Yacht Club today. This left the Long Island Sound champion only one-quarter point off the pace, with two of five races completed.

GENEVA, Aug. 22 -- The United States demanded today effective international controls to guarantee the independence and sovereignty of Laos. It cited a long record of Communist interference in the Southeast Asian kingdom's affairs.

ROME, Aug. 22 -- The leader of the Liberal party, Giovanni Malagodi, formally requested Premier Amintore Fanfani today to test his parliamentary majority. He asked that Parliament be convened immediately for a vote of confidence in the Fanfani Government, which has been in power a little more than a year.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Aug. 22 -- Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, whose extreme Leftist People's Progressive party won easily in yesterday's election, is expected to be asked tomorrow night to form a Government.

Periodically educational institutions, Federal, State and City, are thoroughly surveyed -- even when no political repercussions are involved. Sometimes the surveys deal with administrative practices, sometimes with pedagogic procedures.

The gates have been snapped shut on two of the Lakes of Killarney as a result of a feud between the owner of the property, a Philadelphia contractor, and the drivers of tourist carriages who congregate outside his estate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The House and Senate completed action today on a compromise bill to speed up the procedure of the Federal Communications Commission and relieve commissioners of burdensome routine.
Prices of high-grade bonds continued to fluctuate within narrow limits yesterday. The trading was just as inactive as during the succession of slow sessions of the past week.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 22 -- The annual convention of the National Student Association was stirred today by controversy over the race issue and African nationalism.
The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, a chain of thirty-three department stores, attained the highest sales and earnings in its history in the quarter and six months ended last July 29.

We humans long ago had to resign ourselves to the fact that electronic computers can add, subtract, multiply and divide millions of times faster than we can. Now comes news much more sobering. A machine has been developed that can learn from its errors, and thus exercise judgment needed to solve problems for which there are no cut-and-dried formulas.
A Canadian real estate broker swung by his hands from a twelfth-floor ledge here last night, just to demonstrate his nerve. His grip failed and he plunged to his death.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 22 -- Frederick S. Baron, 19 years old, of 1018 Kilsyth Road, a supermarket clerk here, pleaded not guilty today in the rifle-killing of 14-year-old John J. McKernan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Vice President Johnson today presented the first invitations to foreign nations to participate in the World Economic Progress Assembly and Exposition to be held in Chicago in November 1962.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- With the "full support and confidence" of President Kennedy behind him, Arthur H. Dean, chief United States negotiator for a ban on nuclear testing, left for Geneva today for another -- and possibly final -- attempt to win a meaningful agreement with the Soviet Union.

The two-story business building at 76-01 to 76-27 Thirty-seventh Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by Texplast, Inc., to the 590 Corporation. The sale was negotiated by Joseph R. Ruffino of the Ruffino Realty Company of Kew Gardens and Leonard, Levites Schiller, Bronx brokers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A Georgia couple who had promised their three children a trip through the White House got more today than they had bargained for. President Kennedy welcomed them in his private office.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Senate approved today President Kennedy's four-year, $655,000,000 program to train more than 100,000 unemployed workers in new skills. The vote was 60 to 31.

The Lytton Financial Corporation announced yesterday that it was canceling a proposed issue of 300,000 common shares, and that the company would meet fund requirements through newly negotiated long-term bank credits.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- The Zenith Radio Corporation made its entry into the color television field official today with the introduction of ten basic model color receivers. The sets were shown at a sales meeting in the Ambassador Hotel.
The high-grade hand market passed another day of quiet equilibrium yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored across two runs in the twelfth inning tonight and beat the Kansas City Athletics 7 -- 5.

There was a taping sound down the hall, and with it slow but firm footsteps. Preceded by a puff of blue-gray smoke from a stubby briar with a silver band, tarnished around the stem, the visitor entered, hooked the cane he was wearing on the arm of his chair, tamped with the tip of an index finger the tobacco in his pipe, and sighed.
Governor Rockefeller has decided to take a hand in efforts to settle the thirty-four-day-old strike of grooms and other stable hands at the state's thoroughbred racing tracks.

GARDEN CITY, L.I, Thursday, Aug. 24 -- A physician was stabbed to death early today in his home and his wife, also a physician, was critically wounded by an intruder. The killing occurred shortly before 1 A.M.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Jon Douglas of Santa Monica, Calif., and Chris Crawford of Piedmont, Calif., were beaten in the national doubles tennis championships today.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- A court-martial board sought today to learn why orders had never been issued to abandon a damaged Texas tower that collapsed into the Atlantic, taking twenty-eight men to their deaths.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Two victories and a second place today enabled Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr. of Larchmont Yacht Club, the defending champion, to take the lead in the men's sailing championship of western Long Island Sound.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 23 -- The prospect improved tonight that a way could be found to end the hunger strike of the 76-year-old Sikh leader Master Tara Singh, before it resulted in his death.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The Foreign Office said today that the new restrictions placed by the East German Government on movements between East and West Berlin represented a further violation of the four-power status of the city.

There was evidently some small-scale confusion in Washington one day recently, but nothing to shake the foundations of civilization, as a House subcommittee heard about pumped storage for Federal reservoir projects.
Harlem is being pounded by the full force of the violent political storm raging within the Democratic party in the city.
The threat of a general resumption of the maritime strike here on Sept. 21 receded yesterday.

GANDER, Nfld., Aug. 23 (UPI) -- Gander Airport was reopened today after a one-day shutdown caused when flames from an out-of-control forest fire licked the edges of one runway and shrouded the area in dense smoke.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The newspaper Soviet Sport today charged that Jay Silvester, the world record-holder in the discus throw, had used an illegal wind-up during the United States-Soviet track meet here more than a month ago.
Mayor Wagner promised yesterday to expand his "shock attack" on the problems of West Eighty-fourth Street into a major anti-slum campaign through the whole section west of Central Park.
A "trade-in" application calling for the exchange of two war-built Liberty ships for two modern C-4 vessels in the Navy's reserve fleet was approved by the Maritime Administration yesterday.

The third and presumably final volume of Van Wyck Brooks' autobiography is planned for publication Sept. 6 by Dutton. The book, "From the Shadow of the Mountain: My Post-Meridian Years," opens in 1931, with the author's emergence from four years of mental illness.

The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday urged a change in the wording of a question on the application for Federal employment that requires disclosure of a police record of investigation or arrest.
Lloyd Hauser, head of an investment syndicate, has repurchased the six-story apartment house at 232-34 East Fortieth Street from Fisher Brothers, builders.
FOR the mature men and women who are learning to peel potatoes, fry eggs, wash dishes and clean house at the Lutheran parsonage in Skelleftea, Sweden, housework offers a way back to an active life.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Nine marksmen broke perfect scores of 200 today to tie for the North American clay target championship at the sixty-second Grand American Trapshoot.
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Astronomers are eager to try some celestial sharp-shooting and hit a comet.
GENEVA, Aug. 23. -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, asserted tonight that the survival of Jews as a people was "more precarious and difficult" than ever before.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Vice President Johnson was reported today to be recommending to President Kennedy a further build-up of United States military forces in West Berlin.
" Contemporary," a furniture style that means something different to many people, is expressed in five distinctive ways in the six model rooms that opened yesterday at Altman's.
Twelve years of controversy and lawsuits over the now-extinct Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights ended yesterday.

Referring to your comments on Aug. 14 on "Staggered Transit Hours," why should employers and employes be expected to cooperate why should $200,000 be spent on a survey, and why should there be any attempt to stagger working hours when at this writing the largest office building yet constructed is being erected in the very heart of the most crowded area in Manhattan, with an anticipated daily office load of some 50,000 workers ?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23 -- A virtual revolution occurred on a movie set here today when flocks of men, women and children ignored both Cary Grant and Doris Day to plead for the signatures of three men who had never acted here before this morning.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 23 -- United States children at the American Elementary School here are now being required to sing what constitutes a pledge of allegiance to the Argentine flag each day. The practice started in the school Monday, as a matter of Argentine law, after having been planned earlier.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Aug. 23 (AP) -- A South African, a British West Indian and six Americans gained the quarter-final round of the world senior golf tournament today.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Dick Stuart's ninth-inning single drove in the winning run tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates topped the Milwaukee Braves, 7 -- 6.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 -- After twenty-seven moves in the Gruenfeld variation of the kings Indian defense, the international grandmasters, Arthur Bisguier and Pal Benko, agreed to a draw yesterday in the eighth round of the United States open chess championship at the Sheraton-Palace Hotel.

Since some people, like Will Rogers, know only what they read in the papers, we should like to comment on the incomplete reporting and one-sided arguments of Arthur Krock in his columns of July 21 and Aug. 18, dealing with the Glidden and Gemmer cases.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals exploded for four runs in the eighth inning tonight to take an 8-7 decision from the second-place Los Angeles Dodgers. It was the Dodgers' ninth straight loss, their longest losing streak since 1944, when they dropped fifteen in a row.
WASHINGTON Aug. 23 (AP) -- President Kennedy's Commission on Labor at Missile Sites recommended today a cut of 31 cents an hour in wage rates for laborers on Forbes Air Force Base near Topeka, Kan.

Investors Diversified Services, Inc., reported yesterday net assets of $3,798,521,000 as of June 30. This figure was a new high for the assets under the company's management and ran $380,396,000 higher than at the end of 1960 and $581,066,000 higher than on June 30, 1960.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 23 -- The Bonn correspondent of Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, was expelled from West Germany today for having "systematically disparaged prominent West German public figures" in his dispatches, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 23 -- Master Tara Singh has been said to thrive on crisis. His seventy-six years have been marked by agitation in support of an assortment of causes, all for what he fervently considers the benefit of his Sikh religious faith.
ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- Governor Rockefeller filled today the two new seats on the State Supreme Court bench created in the Ninth Judicial District by the 1961 Legislature.
YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Two-year-old race horses are exciting and beautiful animals. They may be unpredictable and they certainly are green as they start their careers for money and glory.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The grain futures market finished mostly higher today on a late mild rally in which rye and soybeans generated the most steam. Wheat and oats were the laggards.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Shirley Jones, owned by James O. McCue of New York, carried the top weight of 124 pounds to a one and a half length victory today in the $46,600 Arlington Matron Handicap.
Two men were held in $100,000 bail each yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court in the attempted slaying of a policeman outside a Flatbush restaurant. The policeman had foiled a gangland slaying.
Two East Harlem youths told the police last night that they had wounded five persons in sniping attacks last month.

The New York Stock Exchange has been counting the number of stockholders, women as against men, and has found that there are slightly more women. It has also found that investing usually is a family decision, especially with new investors, and that women often have an intense interest in investing but want sound education and advice.

PARIS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Nearly 70 per cent of the world's population lives out its life without knowing what is going on at home or abroad, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization reported today.

Stocks ran into a roadblock yesterday -- namely, mounting concern over the possibility of an automotive strike. The result was the first setback in the last six trading sessions and the largest loss on average in more than a month.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Dissatisfied with the play of the Davis Cup team in its uphill 3-2 victory over Mexico at Cleveland, Captain David L. Freed expressed the hope today that Hamilton Richardson might be willing to reconsider his retirement from cup competition.

IGNORANCE of English need not deter a foreign visitor from shopping in New York department stores. Braced for an invasion of tourists from Europe, Africa, Asia and elsewhere, several of the large emporiums have tabulated the linguistic capabilities of their staffs.
Newly-designed electric bulbs make it possible for motorists approaching New York from New Jersey by way of the Lincoln and Holland tunnels to find their way easily.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The State Department served notice today that a new Soviet rejection of a treaty prohibiting testing of nuclear weapons "would invite the resumption of nuclear tests."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Treasury experts testified today that the wagering tax law of 1951 had been "amazingly disappointing." It was supposed to raise $400,000,000 a year in Federal revenue. Last year it raised $7,317,000.
Robert Sterling Clark, art collector, sportsman and benefactor of Williams College, who died in 1956, left a gross estate of $84,282,199, it was disclosed yesterday in Surrogates Court.

The Philadelphia Electric Company yesterday joined those few electric utilities that control power supplies and generating stations through an electronic computer. The Philadelphia unit, developed jointly by the utility and the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, can control the power needs of 3,500,000 persons in that area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon was questioned intensively by a Senate committee today on commitments the Administration made at the hemispheric economic conference in Uruguay.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 23 -- Britain joined the United States today in calling for immediate talks between France and Tunisia to settle their dispute over the French-held Bizerte naval base.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Southern Railway Company reported today net income of $1,336,000, equal to 16 cents a common share, for July The figures compared with $1,518,000, or 20 cents a share in July, 1960.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- W. Averell Harriman, the President's Ambassador at Large, insisted today that Laos had not been lost to the Communists.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today that business men were cooperating less and less with Justice Department antitrust investigations.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 23 -- Chancellor Adenauer prepared today to deal with attacks in his own party charging he had erred politically in his reaction to the Berlin crisis.
A national meeting to modify the "rather primitive emotions" involved in the fight over Federal aid to public and parochial schools is being planned by the National Conference of Christians and Jews.
The silver jubilee convention of the National Catholic Theatre Conference opened yesterday. Two thousand persons are attending the five-day meeting at the Statler-Hilton and Sheraton-Atlantic Hotels.

LONDON, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- The head of the state-owned British European Airways Corporation (B.E.A.) said today the airline's future would be jeopardized if it had to compete with private British airlines.

George Vanderbilt dated a will disposing of his multi-million dollar estate the day before he plunged to his death from a hotel window, it was learned yesterday when the will was filed for probate in Surrogates Court.

Geisinger Germain, realty operators, purchased the five-story building containing sixty-one apartments at 1097-99 Walton Avenue, the Bronx. The property, which is 150 by 100 feet, was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $227,500.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 23. -- A Douglas DC-8 jet air liner was flown faster than the speed of sound Monday in an experimental flight, the Douglas Aircraft Company said today.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Selwyn Lloyd discussed with industrial leaders today the possibility of working out a long-term economic planning system for Britain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher, Democrat of New Jersey, likened the Army quartermaster today to a Paris dress designer.
Supporters of the Humane Society of New York are planning a fashion show for dogs at a luncheon arranged for Nov. 1 in the Sheraton-East.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 23 -- The Nassau County Planning Commission, which two months ago recommended a 569-acre county airport at Mitchel Field, reversed itself today and endorsed a county plan that rejected proposals for a civil airport.
DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 23 -- A slightly larger version of Ford's new middle-sized car is being offered by its "rival" Lincoln-Mercury Division.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 23 -- The soft drinks were on the house -- the banking house of Merrill (Dooley) Galloway -- as a slick fielding team from El Campo, Tex., today defeated Terre Haute, Ind., 4 -- 2, on the second day of the Little League world series.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 -- The United Automobile Workers filed an unfair labor practice charge against the General Motors Corporation today on the ground that the company had failed to bargain in good faith.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The House committee on Government Operations approved today a bill to establish an eleventh Cabinet post. A Negro is in line for the job and would be the first member of his race to hold Cabinet rank.
State Controller Arthur Levitt accused Mayor Wagner and Michael J. Quill yesterday of having made a political deal that would force transit fares up next year.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 -- Gregg Bemis, chairman of the Yacht Racing Rules Committee of the North American Yacht Racing Union, sailed his Pesgasus to two handsome victories today in the international 210-Class championship series.

The New York School of Interior Design has leased a floor in the new building at 155 East Fifty-sixth Street. Members of the faculty will design the quarters for the school, which is one of the largest in the country specializing in the interior decorative arts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Members of the House Judiciary Committee wrestled today with the problem of how to replace any or all of the Representatives who might be killed or injured in a nuclear attack.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Indians halted the second-place Detroit Tigers' five-game winning streak tonight, scoring a 4-2 victory with the help of Johnny Temple's two-run homer.
DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Five major Great Lakes ports have joined to promote the export by water of goods manufactured in the Middle West.
TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Fourteen-year-old Roberta Albers of Tampa. Fla., gained the quarter-finals of the United States Golf Association's tournament today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- President Kennedy has asked Congress to rush funds for additional Customs inspectors to police the new $100 ceiling on what tourists may bring from abroad duty free.
BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- The Western powers deployed 1,000 troops of their West Berlin garrison, backed by ten forty-ton United States tanks, along the border with East Berlin today.

A group of eleven investor-owned electric utility companies operating in seven Southwestern and Middle Southern states announced yesterday that they had offered to exchange seasonal surpluses of power with the Government-owned Tennessee Valley Authority.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The United States will shift from European to domestic producers for the coal and coke it needs to supply its forces in West Germany.
Two push-button machines that covert a $5 bill into a desired foreign currency went into operation yesterday at New York International Airport.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 23 -- An electronically controlled five-level parking garage of pre-fabricated parts is rising here for customers of the adjacent Altman's department store.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Woody Millen of Piping Rock and Mrs. J.B. Balding of The Creek scored 39, 37 -- 76 for low gross honors and the title in the Long Island Golf Association mixed foursomes championship at the Piping Rock Club today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- Camilo Pascual pitched a two-hitter tonight to gain' his fifth shutout of the season as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Chicago White Sox, 4 -- 0.
WOMEN apparently take the saying seriously that gentlemen prefer blondes, but marry brunettes.

The rapid development of the electronic computer industry has created a communication problem reminiscent of the one that beset the workers on the Tower of Babel. About 200 computer models are on the market today and they operate in about as many different "languages."

CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 -- Fifteen San Francisco Giants came to bat in the ninth inning at Crosley Field tonight. Eleven of them hit safely, twelve of them scored and you never saw a sadder looking bunch of league-leaders than the Cincinnati Reds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Directors of Consolidated Foods Corporation proposed today a five-for-four split of its common shares and said the dividend rate on the new shares probably would be about 15 per cent higher than the present rate.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 23 (AP) -- President Jorge Alessandri ordered five provinces of strike-troubled Chile placed under military control today as a precautionary measure.

A new tire to be used in the 1962 model cars that is said to incorporate improvements for greater mileage and safer turnpike driving at sustained high speeds was announced yesterday by the United States Rubber Company.
Both sides in the Metropolitan Opera contract dispute took major steps last night toward reconciling their differences and saving the opera's 1961-62 season.
BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Gary Geiger and Jackie Jensen blasted late-inning homers today and propelled the Boston Red Sox to a 9-4 victory over the Washington Senators.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The hunt for the missing Goya painting continued today without success.
MIDDLESBROUGH, England, Aug. 23 -- Cannon Street today was just another tawdry slum area in this drab industrial city in Yorkshire.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Frank A. Bonsal's Nahodah won the first running of the $17,850 Interstate Handicap at Atlantic City before 18,876 fans today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 23 -- Benjamin Dranow, a business acquaintance of James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union was prepared today to leave for Washington to appeal a conviction on eighteen counts of fraud and falsification of records.

MOST of the Edgar Allan Poe films, from Hollywood and England, have been rock-bottom shock shows, little more. While "The Pit and the Pendulum," which arrived yesterday at the Palace, is essentially another old-fashioned fright package, some credit belongs to this free adaptation for its imaginative Gothic wrapping.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- American Airlines today defended the legality of its proposed youth fare.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 23 -- A $9,310,000 plan for redevelopment of a section of this city bordering the projected East-West Freeway was unfolded today by city officials.

The Huntington and Babylon, L.I., Central School District 5 borrowed $4,013,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance new building construction. The obligations were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The price was 100.269 for obligations bearing 3.8 per cent interest, a borrowing cost of 3.77 per cent.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Cicada won the Spinaway Stakes by a neck at Saratoga today, but only after a daring coup by her jockey, Ismael Valenzuela.

Experience gained as a scenarist and playwright will be put to use by Ketti Frings as an independent Broadway producer. Mrs. Frings previously had a hand in the sponsorship of last year's "The Long Dream," which she dramatized from Richard Wright's novel.
Public health authorities in the New York area had reassuring words yesterday for devotees of the clam cocktail.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, long famous as the nation's trading center for egg futures, plans to add bacon to its diet next month.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- House Democratic leaders agreed today to seek passage of a compromise program of aid to education at this session of Congress.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- Oil company leaders expressed "reasonable optimism" today on the eve of the resumption of three-year -old oil negotiations with Iraq tomorrow.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 -- As the Yankees faced the Angels at Wrigley Field tonight, following last night's 4-3 setback despite Roger Maris' fiftieth homer, another interesting question posed itself:

Fundamental issues are raised by the campaign against a steel price increase that has been started by Senator Gore and some of his Senatorial colleagues. These Senators are determined to prevent the steel industry from raising its prices after October 1 although the industry is committed to giving its unionized workers a significant wage increase then.
Following a "bon voyage" address by Mayor Wagner at City Hall, a squad of 135 American athletes prepared to depart yesterday for the Sixth Maccabiah Games in Israel.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Governor Rockefeller today predicted Republican victories in the state and New York City.
MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- The Soviet Union declared tonight that the Western powers must accept the closing off of East Berlin and turn their attention to negotiating an over-all German settlement.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 23 -- The United States put into orbit today its first Ranger satellite, a test version of the craft that is to land the nation's first instrument on the moon early next year.
Mohasco Industries, Inc., plans to expand its big carpet business through a proposed merger with the Firth Carpet Company.
The IRT subway system was hit in yesterday's morning rush hour by a series of delays caused by a fire, signal failure land door trouble. Thousands of Brooklyn and Bronx riders were affected.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The General Council, of the Trades Union Congress, Britain's labor federation, with a total membership of more than 8,000,000, voted today to recommend the expulsion of the Communist-led Electrical Trades Union.

Jerry Zimmerman went in to catch for Cincinnati. Willie McCovey doubled. Willie Mays popped to Don Blasingame near the right-field line, McCovey scoring when Blasingame threw wildly as McCovey broke for third.
THE play of today's deal has an appeal for experts, but it is likely that the casual player will be more impressed by the bidding.
Some men who have served two years of active duty in the Army will be called to fill out alerted Reserve and National Guard units, the Army said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Administration was reported today to be ready to give Dr. Jagan's regime in British Guiana every opportunity to prove the Leftist leader's avowed intention of cooperating with the inter-American system.
HANCOCK, Me., Aug. 23 -- "Maitre, do you approve of the idea of covering up the orchestra underneath the stage as Wagner did at Bayreuth?" asked the pupil.
BERLIN, Aug. 23 (AP) -- United States military police protected two Soviet officers in a reconnaissance car today from a crowd of angry West Berliners, witnesses reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board of Governors reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 16:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Senate leaders began setting the-stage today for what is expected to be the last big struggle of this session -- a proposal to change the rule dealing with filibusters.

Lehman Brothers and Blyth Co. Inc. and associates offered to the public yesterday $20,000,000 of 5 1/4 per cent twenty-year debentures of Clark Equipment Credit Corporation, Buchanan, Mich., financing arm of the Clark Equipment Company.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt was handed a retroactive thirty-day suspensionsion today by the Professional Golfers Association's appeals committee. The action forces him out of the $50,000 American Golf Classic starting here tomorrow.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- Following is the text of a statement issued by the three Western commandants in Berlin today its reply to an East German attempt to establish a 110-yard no-entry zone all along the West Berlin border:
PARIS, Aug. 23 -- A wave of terrorist bombings swept France and Algeria last night and early today, injuring eight persons and causing heavy damage.

THE outstanding feature of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Bloch's attractive dining room is the display of copper molds above the buffet. Yet Mrs. Bloch becomes quite angry if it is suggested that the main function of these molds is to be ornamental.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa sent to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday city records relating to Mayor Wagner's use of three city-paid Gracie Mansion servants at his Islip, L.I., summer home.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- The West Berlin city government indicated tonight that it would try to prevent the East German Communists from opening West Berlin offices for the issuance of passes for West Berliners to travel to East Berlin.
The motion picture "King of Kings" has been given a "separate classification" by the National Legion of Decency for taking "poetic license" with the life of Jesus.

The debate in the United Nations General Assembly over Bizerte is rapidly going beyond the merits of the case and is turning into a new cold-war battle over "colonialism." It was set on that course when the Tunisian delegate denounced the presence of French troops in Bizerte as a symbol of "colonial domination." This assured him support from the Soviets and the African-Asian neutralists but does not help to resolve the issue.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 23 -- Some immigrant children were still missing tonight following a raid yesterday by religious zealots on the children's reception center at Ramat Hadassah Szold.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 23 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and King Hussein of Jordan have replied to President Kennedy's letter of May 11 that proposed a new attempt to solve the Palestine problem.
PARIS, Aug. 23 -- The tightening of the Communist restrictions on travel to East Berlin today has reinforced French reluctance to rush into negotiations on the Berlin issue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The House passed today the most controversial of Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy's series of bills to combat organized crime and racketeering after modifying it.

One of the noteworthy features of the recently announced draft program of the Communist party of the Soviet Union is the similarity between its descriptions of future affluence in the U.S.S.R. and predictions of bounty in Red China made in 1958 by the Chinese Communists.

The Bulova Watch Company has leased the entire thirty-sixth floor of the International Building at 630 Fifth Avenue in Rockefeller Center. The lease, involving 20,000 square feet of space was negotiated by A. Sheldon Jaffe, broker.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Nehru's statement today that the Communists had the right to seal off East Berlin runs completely counter to the United States legal position on Berlin.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Donald M. Elliman Jr. of American Yacht Club won the junior distance sailing championship of Long Island Sound today.

TOKYO, Aug. 23 -- In Tokyo today, Russians and Americans, Japanese Communists and Japanese conservatives could all react with delight to the same political phenomenon: a new demonstration of weakness by the fanatic Japanese Right wing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Action on President Kennedy's interim tax revision program has been put off until 1962, the House Ways and Means Committee reported today.
Mayor Wagner promised yesterday that the Jefferson Market Courthouse, an eighty-five- year-old Greenwich Village landmark, would he preserved and converted into a public library branch.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America will become the owner of the Empire State Building. The company has owned the land under the building for the last ten years.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 23 -- The Right-wing faction at the National Student Association's annual convention suffered a rushing defeat today when it cried to sponsor the appearance of a Cuban refugee student.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- Igor Novikov, a 32-year-old Russian school teacher, finished second in the cross-country run today and won the world modern pentathlon championship for the fourth time. He also became the first pentathlon winner to score more than 5,000 points. The Soviet Union took the team title.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Soviet Union protested to the United States today against what it called "provocative" actions in Germany and abuse of the Western rights of access to Berlin. The note has not been thoroughly studied here, but diplo- mats who were briefed on its contents said it appeared to be a further attempt by Moscow to justify additional restrictions on the Western position in Berlin.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 23 -- There is a photographer here whose telephone has been unusually busy lately. His number is 4600. The business phone of Cyrille Adoula, the new Congolese Premier, is 4800, and there have been some wrong numbers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The Peace Corps Director, R. Sargent Shriver, announced today the appointment of the first seven Peace Corps representatives in foreign countries.
Trading in commodity futures on the New York exchanges was quiet yesterday, with exception of Brazilian coffee.

" You can't teach an old dog new tricks" is an adage to which Dr. Daniel Horn of Frenchtown, N.J., doesn't subscribe. The psychologist, who is engaged in scientific research with the American Cancer Society, said: "As far as the show ring is concerned, most people bring out their dogs entirely too early, particularly in the larger breeds.

The Brooklyn Savings Bank has awarded a contract to the Turner Construction Company for the construction of a main office building at 211 Montague Street, corner of Fulton Street, Brooklyn. The five-story structure will contain about 93,000 square feet of floor space and will be part of the new Brooklyn Civic Center.
City Labor Commissioner Harold A. Felix said yesterday that a "new and improved" contract offer had been made to striking concrete-mix truck drivers.

WELL, it's over, now. While it lasted, though, life in this book-lined cloister was like participating in a perpetual pageant. You'd seem to see Anne Boleyn coming through one door and Christopher Columbus going through another. Readers of this page are entitled to the revelation.
The new Board of Education should resolve the controversy over Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, as one of its first tasks, a civic leader said yesterday.

A cost-price squeeze and other adverse factors were blamed for a $3,662,000 drop in earnings of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in the nine months ended July 31, according to its report issued yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made it clear today that he felt East Germany had a legal right to close the border between East and West Berlin.

The "play with music" that the Columbia Broadcasting System had commissioned Gian Carlo Menotti to write will not be televised because of a "difference of opinion" between the network and the composer.

The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes listed below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of companies the shares of which are listed on those exchanges.
The Board of Estimate approved unanimously yesterday a proposal by Mayor Wagner for a forty-hour week for 40,500 policemen and other uniformed city employes.
The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest carrier, operated in the black last month.

The editorials in The Times on Aug. 10 and 11 "Wayward Girls" are welcome indeed, stressing at they do some urgently needed reforms. So far as we recall, this is the only expression in the mass-media of the need to revise New York's Children's Court laws to the generally accepted standard of "under 18 years of age."

JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 23 -- With mist and rain as a background for the second round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship, Eddie Merrins of Rockaway Hunt retained the lead today with a 72 for 142 on the Meadow Brook Club course.
MOSCOW, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Soviet women gymnasts held a 192.2-to-187.5-point lead at the end of tonight's competition in a two-day meet with the touring United States team.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 23 -- The final returns in Israel's Parliamentary elections showed tonight that Premier David Ben-Gurion's Mapai party and its affiliated Arab lists had dropped six seats in the Knessit (Parliament). But they retained as many as the three next largest parties combined.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Better use of traffic control devices and better training of motorists in how to understand them were today urged as aims for the traffic engineering profession.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- The export of general cargo from the Port of Chicago to overseas destinations is running ahead of a year ago, the Chicago Association of Commerce reported today.

The nation's inventories of gasoline rose 1,523,000 barrels last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. This contraseasonal rise in inventories was in the face of virtually unchanged gasoline production, which was 30,026,000 barrels for the period, compared with 30,061,000 the preceding week.
DENVER, Aug. 23 -- Fifteen hundred women left this "mile-high scenic wonderland" tonight for their homes in hamlet, town and city in virtually every section of the country.

NEWCOMERS tell their friends that New York is a fabulous city and when they write letters to their families in the South, Middle West and on the West Coast, they put exclamation marks at the ends of sentences.
Jet passenger service between Newark and Chicago will be started Sept. 11 or earlier.

It is something of a political anomaly that the two members of the Administration whom the President has been delighted conspicuously to honor in the past few days are converts from the opposition to Mr. Kennedy's ambition to become President.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Aug. 23 -- Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, who will become Prime Minister of this British territory, disavowed today any political interest in Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

Two ballets with choreography by Jerome Robbins, "The Cage" and "Afternoon of a Faun," will be removed from the repertory of the New York City Ballet at the request of Mr. Robbins. Since he has decided to have a New York season with his own company, he wishes to give these works an exclusive place in its repertory.

It is time that the United States stock diplomatic steps to end the current Communist provocations over the status of Berlin. While it is both prudent and imperative that we should increase our military strength so that the Soviets will honor our treaty rights in Berlin, we cannot simultaneously allow the Soviets to maintain their provocative diplomatic initiative over the status of that city.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 25 cents a bale up to 25 cents off yesterday. The July contract showed the only rise.

CHARLES O. FINLEY, a millionaire insurance man, has been an incorrigible baseball buff for years. Repeatedly he had tried to buy a big league franchise. Eight months ago he made it. His new toy was the Kansas City Athletics. Immediately he impressed his fellow owners by hiring the knowledgeable Frank Lane as his general manager at $100,000 per annum for a four-year term.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 2.6 per cent in total operating revenues for the twelve months ended on July 31. Electric operating revenues were up 7 per cent and net income up 11.3 per cent.

People watching for some indication of tighter money have been disappointed by the fact that the Federal Reserve has permitted bank reserves to remain at "easy money" levels. Yesterday they received further evidence that tighter money was still somewhere in the future.

The next order of business in reform of the New York City school system is selection of the best Board of Education that can be had. The task to be performed by the newly created panel of civic leaders is of historic importance. It will influence the quality of the schools for many years to come. The caliber of this first board, appointed under the new ground rules, will set a pattern for the future.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 23 (UPI) -- Alabama law enforcement officers testified today that Freedom Riders caused angry mobs to form in their state a few days before the integrationists were arrested here for breach of the peace.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said last night that he considered it possible to discuss the withdrawal of troops from Central Europe as one means of easing East-West tensions.

Production of electric power dipped to 15,665,000,000 kilowatt-hours last week from 16,080,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This figure compares with 14,866,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the same week a year ago.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- After a brief rally early in today's session, the stock market here resumed its pattern of the last couple of weeks: Not much buying, not much selling and prices declining in pennies.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- New car sales between Aug. 11 and 20 came to 115,749 units, compared with 141,486 in the first ten days of the month, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Dr. Joseph E. Johnson, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, has been appointed a special United Nations envoy to seek a solution to the Palestine refugee problem.
A slum landlord was sentenced to sixty days in jail and fined $500 yesterday for violations of the multiple-dwelling law on a building he owns at 27-29 West 120th Street.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- The United Automobile Workers and the American Motors Corporation were reported today to be making progress toward agreement on a profit-sharing program new to the industry.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Small gains in corn were the exception in a generally lower grain futures market here today.

HAD Eddie Senz turned to a life of crime, he doubtless would have achieved international notoriety. For disguise is his milieu, whether he is beautifying a Kansas housewife, creating character make-up for a Broadway play or enhancing the glamour of a visiting Hollywood star.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- President Kennedy nominated Lincoln Gordon, a Harvard professor with extensive government experience, today to be the United States Ambassador to Brazil.
Mayor Wagner charged last night that financial decisions by state Controller Arthur Levitt had enabled the sponsors of a Queens housing project to realize windfall profits of $2,400,000.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- The Soviet Government in effect rejected tonight a United States appeal to Moscow to reconsider its stand and to agree on a ban on nuclear testing on Western terms. The appeal was contained in a pamphlet made public yesterday by the State Department.
Mayor Wagner was accused yesterday of having been asleep until very recently to the need for givin ga forty-hour work week to 39,900 policemen and other uniformed city employes.

With Hal Holbrook and George Voskovec in the two-character cast, "Do You Know the Milky Way?" will open here the week of Oct. 2 at the Barrymore. This was confirmed yesterday by Paul Feigay, co-sponsor with Dick Button and Ninon Tallon Karlweis.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 24 (UPI) -- The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing (3M) Company has resold Insulation and Wire, Inc., to the Essex Wires Corporation, Fort Wayne, Ind., as a result of a complaint by the Federal Trade Commission charging the company with violating the anti-trust laws.

Capt. Jorge Navarro Custin, captain of the Cuban merchant vessel Bahia de Nipe, told yesterday how he and two mates spent five hours overpowering and locking up most of the ship's crew last week so they could shift course to Norfolk, Va., and defect. The ship was en route to a Soviet port.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Jim Kaat, a 22-year-old lefthander, held the White Sox to five hits today as he pitched the Minnesota Twins to a 3-to-0 victory.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- President Kennedy appealed to representatives of three leading business organizations today to help him find first-rate personnel for the foreign aid program.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 24 -- Prime Minister Sir Edgar Whitehead of Southern Rhodesia told Parliament tonight that "measure after measure" would be introduced by his Government to bring about a spirit of Rhodesian nationalism on a nonracial basis.

The formation of the African American Trade and Development Association was announced yesterday by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America. He will serve as chairman of the new organization.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of a White House statement issued today in answer to a note from the Soviet Union delivered yesterday:
PARIS, Aug. 24 -- President de Gaulle announced today a minor reshuffling of the Government of Premier Michoel Debre.
The Cott Beverage Corporation is going after the cola market, now dominated by Cocoa-Cola and Pepsi-Cola, with a new contender.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- The West Berlin city government rejected today the East German Communist request to open permit offices in West Berlin where West Berliners could apply for permission to enter East Berlin.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 24 -- A 28-year-old porter was charged tonight with the murder of a Garden City, L.I., physician in his home early today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg reported today some success in the drive to cut down on job discrimination against older workers.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The slow price decline continued on the stock market here today in the quietest session of this year.

The Governors of New York and Michigan became involved in a baseball dispute yesterday, but the issue concerned neither the lively ball nor the hopped-up bat -- it concerned apples, eggs and possibly a hefty New York cow.
HAWORTH, N.J., Aug. 24 -- Mary Ann Doctor of White Beeches won the second annual Maureen Orcutt tournament over her home course today. She also won last year.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 24 -- A West German spokesman, commenting on the Soviet notes about air traffic to Berlin, warned today that Moscow risked a heightening of international tension by "one-sided illegal" moves.
The promotion of three vice presidents to senior vice presidents was announced yesterday by the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The United States Government will open an information center for foreign correspondents at 340 East Forty-sixth Street in New York City.
The last major East Coast shipping lines holding out in the nation-wide maritime dispute yielded to union pressure yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 24 -- Dr. Inkongliba Ao, chairman of the interim government of India's troubled state of Nagaland, died today of wounds inflicted Tuesday by an assailant.
Brazilian coffee again was actively traded in otherwise quiet sessions yesterday on New York commodity exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Defense Department urged today that all telephone and telegraph facilities, including future communications satellites, be considered a national resource to be Federally administered in time of emergency.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 24 -- The double bill of stage events set to music by Alessandro Scarlatti, in which Salvador Dali and others had a hand, went its two performances at the Teatro Fenice and tonight passed into history, presumably for eternity.

Su Mac Lad, who has dominated trotting this year, will strive for his eighth straight victory and a money-winning record in the mile-and-a-quarter $25,000 Volo Song Trot Friday, night. He needs a first or second to become the leading money-winning trotter in history.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 24 -- A Federal judge declared invalid today the use of public funds to finance segregated schools in Prince Edward County while public schools are closed.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- F. Ambrose Clark's Amber Diver made it two in a row in jump competition at the Saratoga race meeting when he won the Lovely Night Hurdle Handicap today. Taking the lead approaching the final obstacle, the 7-year-old went on to beat the favored Gallant Tonto by five lengths.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- The Soviet Union accused the Western powers today of flagrant violation of a 1945 four-power accord that guaranteed unrestricted Allied air access to West Berlin.
Edward Vieth Sittler, who renounced his American citizenship to become a Nazi propaganda broadcaster in Germany during World War II, was ruled yesterday "unworthy of regaining his citizenship."
ALGIERS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Twenty-four hours of terrorism by European Right-wingers and Moslem rebels left twenty-six persons killed and about fifty injured throughout Algeria today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Cuba challenged today the right of the United States to retain the naval base at Guantanamo Bay under its treaty with Cuba. The United States countered with a charge of "international lawlessness."
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

On an increasing number of occasions recently, my belief in The Times' infallibility has been severely jolted. It was finally toppled by your endorsement of Mayor Wagner in the Democratic primary. You just have to be joking. To give you due credit, I will admit that you could not have managed a more tentative, faint-hearted, backhanded recommendation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The United States will make a greater effort to project a more favorable image of itself in the world through broadened information activities, Secretary of State Dean Rusk told Congress today.

HAVANA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A student leader, Alberto Muller, and two Roman Catholic priests were sentenced today to twenty years in prison on charges of having plotted against Premier Fidel Castro's regime "under the influence of the Central Intelligence Agency."
Stocks fell sharply again yesterday. Prices firmed in later trading, but only a small portion of the earlier losses was erased.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Elbert Lesley, a 42-year-old real estate salesman from Reading, Ohio, borrowed a shotgun today and won about $6,500 at the sixty-second Grand American trapshoot.

Loans to business at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York declined $55,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $104,000,000 in the 1960 week.
A three-hour bargaining session in the Metropolitan Opera contract dispute produced a new union proposal yesterday.
Three central labor organizations will demonstrate tomorrow morning at Belmont Park in support of grooms and other stable hands striking the state's thoroughbred racing tracks.
Secretary Freeman's suggestion to move grain, particularly wheat, to 191 population centers to be used as emergency food seems so ill-advised that it needs clarification.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Public officials on all levels of government must share the blame when a business leaves a community, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- In this energetic city of automobile makers, Walter P. Reuther and the Detroit Tigers, the mood is one of troubled uncertainty. There is lots of hope, but no one has sure answers to the questions that are bothering Detroit: Will the smartly styled car models for 1962, just begin ning to go into production, sell well and give Detroit an economic lift ?

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Detroit Free Press, the state's only morning newspaper, resumed publication tonight after issuance of a Federal District Court injunction against "secondary boycott" picketing by Miami Herald pressman.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold warned the Soviet Union today that its attacks on the United Nations could cause the world body to collapse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Senate rejected today by a vote of 59 to 32 a Republican attempt to cut from $40,000,000 to $25,000,000 the first year's authorization for the Peace Corps.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Five boys studying weather and air currents have succeeded, to their surprise, in placing a 5-cent toy balloon in London three days after launching.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 24 -- West Germany is worried about the reaction of the noncommitted states to the Berlin crisis, and the Government is making an effort to inform them of its views.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Bills to carry out a new compromise program of aid to education were introduced today in the House of Representatives. But the outlook for favorable action was still uncertain.
RENO, Nev., Aug. 24 (UPI) Miss Spokane and Century 21 today became the third and fourth boats to qualify for the $35,000 Gold Cup hydroplane race at Pyramid Lake Saturday and Sunday.

The Bar Association of the City of New York and the New York County Lawyers' Association have put proposals to each of the candidates for Mayor that should deeply concern the public and also political party leaders.
Prices of Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 20 to 75 cents a bale yesterday.
The American Educational Theatre Association opened its twenty-fifth anniversary convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. Twelve hundred persons are attending the week-long meeting.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirate general manager, Joe L. Brown, making what he called a "routine announcement," said today that Danny Murtaugh would manage the team again in 1962.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of a note to the United States from the Soviet Union as distributed today by Tass, the official Soviet press agency (parallel notes were sent to Britain and France):

The Cities Service Company plans to acquire the Columbian Carbon Company. The transaction, which would involve an exchange of stock valued at an estimated $108,000,000 would represent one of the biggest mergers of the year.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 24 -- An increase in mental health services was announced today by Mrs. Prescott B. Huntington, chairman of the Suffolk County Mental Health Board.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- New York and California, which have been at odds over defense contracts, figuratively bumped into each other today over the birthplace of naval aviation.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 24 -- An eleven-member, bipartisan Nassau County Charter Revision Commission was appointed today by County Executive A. Holly Patterson.
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 24 -- An assembly of 1,000 of the world's leading research astronomers recorded itself today as opposed to a forthcoming United States space project pending further study.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Sen. Frank J. Lausche said today Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker had been "wrongly and unjustly relegated to obscurity in the military organization."
BAHREIN, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- The 20,584-ton oil tanker World Jury signaled today that she was in danger of breaking up after having run aground off Masira Island in the Arabian Sea.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Five former Chicago policemen were sentenced to the penitentiary today as members of a police burglary ring. They received terms of one to five years.
A campaign is in swing to put a man in the mayoral race who has given no indication that he is ready to become a candidate.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 24 -- A victory in the final race of the three-day, nine-race Hipkins Trophy series today helped Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr. of the Larchmont Yacht Club to clinch the men's sailing championship of Western Long Island Sound for the second straight year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Spending by local school districts for school construction dropped during 1959-60 for the first time since World War II, the Office of Education reported today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Frank Lary of Detroit shut out the Cleveland Indians, 6 -- 0, on four hits tonight to gain his nineteenth victory in twenty-five decisions. It was his eighteenth complete game in twenty-nine starts.
Following is the exchange of apple-betting correspondence between the Governors of Michigan ad New York:

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24 -- While their own tailspin had not quite reached the panic stage, the Cincinnati Reds appeared to be getting there until Fred Hutchinson, their manager, made some changes tonight at Crosley Field.
DJIDOUTI, French Somaliland, Friday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Government of Premier Abdi Bashid Shermarke of Somalia has submitted its resignation, reports reaching here said today.
GENEVA, Aug. 24 -- The Soviet Union appeared today to be preparing a surprise to greet the return to the nuclear test ban conference here of Arthur H. Dean, chief United States delegate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The only certain preventive for a nuclear war is for the great powers of the world to disarm John J. McCloy, Presidential disarmament adviser, told Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Acid Congressional comment made it plain today that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru had damaged the cause of Indian-American friendship by his statement yesterday supporting the Soviet stand in the Berlin controversy.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Adios Butler, having exhausted virtually all his competition, has embarked on an exhibition tour. It is expected to take him to many of the nation's leading harness racing tracks.

The New York Brass and Copper Company has leased an entire floor in the office building at 72 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Thirteenth Street, which is owned by M. Robert Steel. The lessee had occupied smaller space on the third floor and made the change in an expansion move.
Jimmie C. White, 29-year-old actor and model, was convicted by a Federal jury last night of stealing a $150,000 Degas pastel and two other art works.

HONOLULU, Aug. 24 -- Archaeologists, using a peculiar type of stone adze as a tracer, are pursuing an ancient migration of the Polynesians. The route may have led through the northwestern United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The lack of progress in the peace talks in Laos on the formation of a national government may force the suspension of the Geneva conference on guaranteeing the kingdom's neutrality, Administration officials said today.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 -- The young wobbled up manfully to the firing line, hoisting 12-gauge shotguns as long as their bodies. The elderly moved to their positions aided by crutches or wheel chairs.

You prefer, in your Aug. 21 editorial, Mayor Wagner whose "second term, especially, has been full of glaring disappointments" and "shot through with an accumulation of defects and scandals," to Controller Levitt, "a man of ability and integrity."

A world of toys, from dolls to plastic missile bases, opened wide yesterday for eighteen children of delegates to the United Nations. They were the first visitors to tour the American Toy Exhibit at 1107 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The White House gave the Soviet Government a "solemn warning" today that any Communist interference with Allied access to West Berlin would be "an aggressive act" for which the Soviet Government would bear full responsibility.
Dean H. Schoelkopf, assistant city editor of The Minneapolis Tribune, is the winner of the new Seymour Berkson Foreign Assignment Grant.
The District Attorney's office cleared Mayor Wagner yesterday of a charge that he had violated the City Charter by using three city-paid Gracie Mansion servants at his Islip, L.I., summer home.

U.N. Secretary General Hammarskjold's public remarks are never inflammatory but often they are cogent. In the introduction to his annual report, made public yesterday, he entered into two highly controversial subjects. One of these was the difference between the Russian concept of the United Nations organization and the Western or, as he by inference called it, the "dynamic."
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Demonstrators and the national police battled on the main street here today shortly before an inter-American team arrived on a mission of inquiry.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 -- Robert M. Sides, sailing under the colors of the Marblehead fleet, became the winner of the 210 Class international yacht championship today when the race committee canceled the fifth race.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The House of Representatives voted today for a two-year study of the nation's stock markets by the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Senate Banking Committee cleared the way for quick approval in the Senate.
GENEVA, Aug. 24 -- The Communist bloc unexpectedly reversed itself today at the fourteen-nation conference on Laos by softening its attack on a United States proposal.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 24 -- Efforts continued tonight to find a solution to the hunger strike by 76-year-old Master Tara Singh of the Sikh religious faith.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Following are excerpts from the introduction to the annual report by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold on the work of the United Nations during the year ended June 15, 1961:
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The original plasters of almost all the great works of sculpture by the late Sir Jacob Epstein were given by his widow today to the new Jerusalem Museum of Art.
Stockholders of the Laboratory for Electronics, Inc., and Tracerlab, Inc., will vote on the proposed merger of Tracerlab into Laboratory for Electronics at separate meetings in Boston on Sept. 19.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 24 -- A Hawaiian team, made up almost entirely of players of Japanese descent, won the hearts of 5,500 spectators but lost its semi-final struggle today in Little League world series play.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- An additional $56,500,000 in loan funds for the Small Business Administration was approved today by the Senate Banking Committee.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Directors of Nuclear-Chicago Corporation today proposed a three-for-two split of the $1 par common stock and an increase in authorized shares to 2,500,000 from the present 1,500,000.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 -- The Yankees bade farewell to Wrigley Field for the last time tonight and for the Bombers it was a sad leave taking, to say the least.

JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 24 -- With a fourth round of 68, Shelley Mayfield tied Eddie Merrins in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today. With both posting 72-hole 286's at the Meadow Brook Club course, an 18-hole play-off was scheduled for 1:30 P.M. tomorrow.

A Brooklyn policeman escaped injury yesterday when a 22-caliber automatic rifle, pointed at his chest, misfired. But his assailant, a Williamsburg building owner who was being served with a warrant for violations of the multiple-dwelling law, escaped.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- The Rev. John F. Cronin urged both clergy and laity of the Roman Catholic faith today to give a higher priority to racial justice.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr., hampered by physical ailments since being named the golfer of the year in 1959, took the first-round lead today in the 72-hole, $50,000 American Golf Classic with a three-under-par 67.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A striking similarity exists in the problems and the future of urban transportation in Europe, South America and the United States, according to experts from five countries.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (UPI). -- World output of industrial fibers in the 1960-61 season will, on balance, move higher again than in the preceding season, the Commonwealth Economic Committee said today.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Aug. 24 -- The Soviet Union has asked Pakistan to explain what Moscow charges are Western plans for nuclear attacks on targets in the Middle East, the Soviet Union and Communist China in the event of war.
MUKWANAGO, Wis., Aug. 24 -- The trend to smaller cars is saving motorists $171,000,000 a year in gasoline, George Romney, president of American Motors Corporation, said today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- The Lake Michigan Region Planning Committee, American Institute of Architects, today urged a comprehensive review of all possible sites for an Indiana deep water port.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- The East German Communists are cracking down on their foes in what was described by West Berlin municipal authorities today as a "widespread campaign of intimidation and oppression."
McCOMB, Miss., Aug. 24 (UPI) -- A New York man who was convicted of attempting to intimidate a policeman will appeal his case in Pike County Court, his attorney said today.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- Communist East Germany broadened its offensive against West Berlin today by challenging the Western powers' right to move their personnel across the border between West and East Berlin without permission.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 241 -- James Crane, representing Noroton Yacht Club, today completed a sweep for the Long Island Sound midget sailing championship off Indian Harbor Y.C.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Shares of the Channel Tunnel Company, Ltd., which proposes to build a railway tunnel under the English Channel, rose sharply on the London stock market today following the French Cabinet's decision yesterday to initiate talks with the British Government on a "fixed work" across the channel.

FOR value in round, red fruits look to grapes this weekend. Both red and seedless grapes shed 6 cents this week and now sell generally for 29 cents a pound. Black Ribier grapes, at 4 cents less, sell for 35 cents a pound.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 -- Pal Benko of New York defeated William G. Addison of San Francisco last night in the United States open chess championship and now leads in the tournament with an 8-1 score.
HAVANA, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Cuban officials at the last minute tonight prevented twenty-seven Americans from leaving Havana on a special repatriation flight arranged by the Swiss Embassy.
PARIS, Aug. 24 -- France regards the implicit Soviet threat to Allied aerial communications with Berlin as "particularly grave" and demanding of the firmest possible resistance the Western Big Three.
ST. JOHN'S, NFLD., Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Premier Joseph Smallwood declared a state of emergency in Newfoundland tonight and appealed to the Federal Government to help fight forest fires in the province.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Pentagon indicated today that the first call-up of reserves, presumably on a modest scale, could be expected in mid-October.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Britain took an extremely serious view today of the implied threat to air communications between West Germany and West Berlin in the latest Soviet notes to the Western Big Three.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Republican Congressional leaders called today for "muzzling" Chester Bowles or dismissing him.
TUNIS, Aug. 24 -- The Government said today that more than 1,300 Tunisians were killed in the Bizerte fighting last month, according to a new count.

As a registered Democrat who intends to vote for Mayor Wagner in the forthcoming primary, I found your endorsement of his candidacy very gratifying. Robert Wagner has conscientiously served the interests of New York ever since his election as Mayor some eight years ago.
Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson announced last night that a "work-training program" involving 300 to 500 relief clients at a time would be started at his department headquarters next month.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The House voted today to subsidize operators of small lead and zinc mines. Payments could total up to $16,500,000 in the next four years.

The Senate subcommittee currently investigating gambling in the United States has produced some majestic arithmetic and some startling assertions. One witness said the total of betting in the United States amounted to $50 billion annually. This is about one-third of the value added by manufacture in all industries in the United States.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Aug. 24 -- Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan said today that he would visit Washington early in November to seek American aid for British Guiana's development program.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Col. William M. Banks was found not guilty today of negligence in the collapse of a radar tower in the Atlantic Ocean that killed twenty-eight men.
The appointment of Haim Sanderson as manager for the Americas for El Al Israel Airlines was announced yesterday.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 24 (UPI) -- An all-white jury that had listened to three days of testimony took forty minutes today to convict Henry J. Thomas, the first Freedom Rider to appeal his conviction for breach of the peace.
The Radio Corporation of America is hearing pleasant sounds from its home instrument business, which includes the development, manufacture and marketing of television sets, radios and phonographs.
