WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The transaction through which the Empire State Building will become the property of the Prudential Insurance Company of America involves offering for sale up to $39,000,000 of securities.

Some unusual models are being used in Glenmore Distilleries' advertising for its Yellowstone bourbon. Among those who speak up for the product are a rancher who owns 273,000 acres in the area around Tombstone, Ariz.; a horseman known as "Mr. Quarter Horse" because his stock has won more than 1,500 trophies, a champion rodeo contestant and breeders of Appaloosa horses and Brangus bulls.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A six-run second inning, highlighted by Don Demeter's three-run homer, paced the Philadelphia Phillies to a 7-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight. It was the third victory in a row for the last-place Phils, matching their longest winning streak of the season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 -- William Inge, who has refused, as a matter of principle, to adapt his own plays for movies, today traced the process that finally persuaded him to do his first adaptation of someone else's work for the screen.
The State Supreme Court yesterday denied a motion by fourteen members of the International Longshoremen's Association for a temporary injunction against the Waterfront Commission.

Sales of Bobbie Brooks, Inc., manufacturer of apparel for young women, increased 20 per cent during the company's fiscal first quarter from a year ago, the annual meeting was told yesterday in Cleveland.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed tonight promotion of Gene Hal Williams, 33-year-old West Virginia National Guard officer, to the rank of brigadier general in the Army Reserve.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Getting horse race information and transmitting it while it's hot is a business that calls for more ingenuity than capital, the Senate Investigations subcommittee showed today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Those who live near airports might as well learn to accept the noise of planes taking off and landing, it seems, or move away.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Deron Johnson smashed a two-run homer over the leftfield fence in the eighth inning tonight that gave the Kansas City Athletics a 5-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

Today's new film is "Ada," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama of politics, co-starring Susan Hayward and Dean Martin, at the Capitol Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-first Street. Daniel Mann directed and Lawrence Weingarten produced, from a screen play by Arthur Sheekman and William Driskill.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24 -- A pair of Juniors, one the champion of the United States and the other the champion of Wimbledon, provided the most exciting moments in the national doubles tennis tournament today.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 24 -- Following are excerpts from Judge Oren R. Lewis's memorandum opinion today in the Prince Edward County School case:
The real secret of successful fishing, according to juvenile experts, is using bread dough or bait.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 24 -- A 20-year-old gasoline station attendant who secretly married the 17-year-old daughter of a Wall Street broker last month won a partial victory today in his attempt to see his young bride.

The principal justification which the Kremlin has put forth for its action in sealing off East Berlin is that this step was necessary to frustrate Western organizations carrying on anti-Soviet activities, to eliminate "a den of adventurists, rogues, paid agents, terrorists and other criminals."
Thomas W. Gleason, 60-year-old organizer and negotiator for the 60,000-member International Longshoremen's Association, was elected executive vice president of the dockworkers' union yesterday.

Hope for an end of the eight-week strike of ready-mix concrete truck drivers against the construction industry rose yesterday as 1,200 strikers prepared to vote today on a new offer for a two-year contract.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A hearing room packed with interested Congressmen today heard representative Frank Chelf, Kentucky Democrat, argue for increasing the house membership by thirty-four.
Illinois is planning to borrow $100,000,000 in the bond market on Sept. 27 to finance construction of university buildings and mental health institutions.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Alex Grammas, a .148 hitter before the game, drove in five runs and led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 10-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall today urged a major change in the Federal-interstate compact for development of Delaware River water resources.

With investing institutions clinging to the sidelines, the bond market yesterday was largely a professional affair dominated by operations of the Federal Reserve System and by the striving of dealers to prepare for another large-scale advance refunding of Treasury war bonds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The recent unseasonably favorable pattern of freight loadings continued last week for the railroad and trucking industries.

LOS ANGELS, Aug. 24 -- Casey Stengel insisted today that he had made no firm decision, but there were new indications that he would become the manager of the New York's club that will start play in the National League next season.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- There was a wedding in Berlin yesterday. The bride and bridegroom and some of their friends and the minister stood in West Berlin, just by the wall that the Communists have built to separate West Berlin from Communist East Berlin.

TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Roberta Albers, a 14-year-old golfer from Temple Terrace, Fla., swept into the semi-finals of the women's National Amateur golf championship today with three seasoned campaigners.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Two Air Force pilots completed a simulated space flight today. They said the seventeen days they spent sealed in a steel tank had gone smoothly.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A group of rebel truck drivers has begun a campaign to oust the Teamsters Union as bargaining agent for Chicago's long-distance truckers.
Two men were indicted yesterday for felonious assault with intent to kill in the shooting of a patrolman outside a Brooklyn restaurant Sunday night.
BOSTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Jackie Jensen hit a home run in the tenth inning today, giving the Boston Red Sox a 5-4 victory over the Washington Senators and a sweep of their three-game series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Administration gave qualified support today to legislation aimed at easing the tax and stock market impact of the court-ordered disposal of $3,000,000,000 in General Motors Corporation stock by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

Bell Intercontinental Corporation announced yesterday its proposed plans for the expansion of its present petroleum interests by entry into the bottled gas industry. The plan is subject to the merger of the Blue Flame Gas Corporation and the Petroleum Securites Corporation, Bluffton, Ind., into the American Hydratane Corporation of Chicago.

If the President and his foreign affairs advisers and administrators had any great hopes of support by neutral India on the basis of our diplomatic protest over the Kremlin's recent moves in Germany, the adverse judgment now expressed by Prime Minister Nehru has removed them.

The president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews will sail today for Europe and Israel to discuss with religious leaders the role of church and synagogue groups in religious liberty and public affairs.
EAST and South both made plays involving upper-level bridge tactics in the deal shown, and East came out victorious because he was one step ahead.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Aug. 24 -- The Cape Canaveral rocket center is to be enlarged to more than five times its present size for manned flights to the moon and comparable missions.
With its remaining days in office numbered, the city Board of Education went about business as usual yesterday.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $25,000,000 to $37,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $18,000,000 to $622,000,000.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, Aug. 24 -- The Pan-Arab Games, a subsidiary of the Olympics, opened here today fraught with the political problems facing the Arab world.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

The Columbia Broadcasting System has found a man to fill a gap in its "Calendar." Harry Reasoner will be the host of the new daytime news and information program, which will be televised from 10 to 10:30 A.M. Mondays through Fridays, beginning Oct. 2.

NEWARK, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A nine-acre portion of the twenty-acre Ruppert Stadium site on Avenue K has been sold for $180,000 to the Hackensack concern of Hanson Hanson Inc., developers of industrial property.
Consolidated Edison has ordered fourteen power transformers at a cost of almost $3,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that where-ever possible a person on relief should work for the money received.
The will of Ernest Hemingway, written by his own hand in stilted legal language, was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogates Court.
Operations of Deere Co. in the nine months ended on July 31 showed a sharp recovery, as sales rose 19 per cent and earnings 159 per cent from the levels of a year earlier.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Warren Spahn coasted to his fifteenth victory of the season and No. 303 of his career tonight as the Milwaukee Braves got thirteen hits in downing the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 -- 1. The 40-year-old southpaw gave ten hits, but he stopped Roberto Clemente's batting streak at eight games. Spahn fanned five batters.

Your editorial in support of Mayor Wagner in the forthcoming primary represents a type of cock-eyed reasoning that besmirches your own paper. You state that his second term has been shot through with an accumulation of defects and scandals.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 24 -- (Reuters) -- A merger of Singapore and neighboring Malaya is almost certain by 1963, Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's Prime Minister, said tonight.

A report by an Anglo-American of his observations during a five-month visit to China in 1960, contrasted with what he saw there in 1957 will be published by Doubleday Sept. 8. Called "Awakened China," it was written by Felix Greene.
State Controller Arthur Levitt and Michael J. Quill disputed by telegram yesterday whether Mayor Wagner had a deal with Mr. Quill to raise transit fares after the election.
WASHINGTON, Friday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department said early today that wheat farmers apparently had given their approval to marketing quotas on the 1962 crop.

Prime Minister Nehru has signaled the start of a new era in Indian economic planning with his announcement that a new long-range program covering the next fifteen years is being prepared. By 1976, the Prime Minister explained, it is hoped that India's national income can be more than doubled, from about $30,000,000,000 a year at present to over $71,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Farmers' cash receipts from marketing for the first seven months of 1961 came to $17,100,000,000, 2 1/2 per cent above those of last year, the Department of Agriculture said today. The volumes of marketing was up 2 per cent.
CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies said today Russia was the greatest colonial power in the world and was "enslaving advanced people."

Production of lumber totaled 229,029,000 board feet in the week ended Aug. 19. This figure compared with 223,339,000 board feet in the preceding week and 228,688,000 board feet in the same 1960 week according to reports received from regional associations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent above the level of a year earlier.
Committees are being formed here to work for the success of the fourth annual Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds Ball planned for Dec. 14 at the Plaza.

An investing client of J.J. Wender, lawyer, has purchased the six-story apartment house on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 210,212 and 214 East 112th Street between Second and Third Avenues. The building contains twenty-eight apartments and was sold for $18,000 in cash over a mortgage.

THE newly appointed United States Ambassador to Brazil is the kind of man who learned to play the 'cello when he was 40 years old. Now he has the chairs in his music room "arranged permanently" for string quartets.

An English and a Nigerian sculptor, working together, have produced a modern version of an ancient African art form that now adorns the entrance to the Chase Manhattan Bank's branch at Lagos, Nigeria.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 25 -- Charles Kamen, a 21-year-old Peace Corps recruit now being trained at Pennsylvania State University, was refused a deferment by the local draft board today.
BERLIN, Aug. 25 -- Walter Ulbricht, the East German Communist leader, took some of the immediate heat out of the Berlin crisis today.
ALBANY, Aug. 25 -- More than one-third of the national supply of Sabin oral poliomyelitis vaccine was allocated to New York State today to meet an "impending epidemic" in three upstate counties.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- In a moderate and fairly general recovery, most grain futures finished with gains running to major fractions here today on the Board of Trade.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The Soviet Union again challenged the right of Nationalist China to sit in the United Nations but voted today for a report approving the Taiwan Government's credentials.
The Air Line Pilots Association declared yesterday that its membership had demanded "immediate and positive action" by the union in its fourteen-month-old-strike against Southern Airways.
Henry Karp, the 11-year-old Bronx boy who started selling homemade plaster plaques on Monday to swell the cancer fund, is almost half way to his goal of $100.

UNION, N.J., Aug. 25 -- An amateur, Frank Maroney, took the play away from the professionals with a five-under par 35, 33-68 to lead the field in the annual Coakley Memorial Tournament today at the 6,808-yard, par-73 at Galloping Hill course.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has promised that if elected Mayor he will consult the bar associations before appointing judges.
MONTREAL, Aug. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Plans for the first deep penetration of the St. Lawrence River in midwinter were announced today by a Danish shipping line.
BURLINGTON, Wis., Aug. 25 -- Engineering and mechanical changes rather than sharp restyling mark the 1962 Ramblers.
Former soldiers will recall that Friday was traditionally the day for "GI-ing" the barracks. Yesterday was no exception at the Army Recruiting and Induction Center, 39 Whitehall Street.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Carry Back returns to the track tomorrow at Atlantic City. His future depends on his showing in a seven-furlong event.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Aug. 25 -- An attempt to orbit a capsule with a mechanical astronaut aboard was postponed today because of electrical troubles.
A pioneer in providing funds for capital-hungry companies in growth industries has issued a dissenting report on Small Business Investment Companies.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru condemned today as "cold-blooded treachery" the fatal shooting of Dr. Inkongliba Ao, chairman of the Interim Council of the State of Nagaland.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- Trustees of the Barnes Foundation filed a court petition today to justify plans to charge a $2 admission fee at its art gallery in near-by Merion.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Aug. 25 -- President Kennedy arrived here at 4:30 P.M. today for his ninth consecutive holiday weekend on Cape Cod.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Senators investigating book-making operations heard today about a "cheese box" that cheats the telephone company out of long-distance tolls.
Dr. Robert A. Soblen, 61-year-old convicted Soviet spy, collapsed in his cell yesterday and was knocked unconscious when he hit his head on the stone floor.

PARIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Paris Bourse held up well today in face of the Berlin crisis, despite reports of a drop in share prices on Wall Street. German stock market prices, which fell sharply two days ago, were showing more resistance although trading was slow. A few share values dropped appreciably and one or two even rose.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 25 -- They never did get to count 11 over the Los Angeles Dodgers, and now the Cincinnati Reds may never get to count them out of the National League pennant race. Weighted down with ten straight setbacks, the runner-up Californians staggered into Crosley Field tonight straightened themselves away and flattened he league-leaders, 7 -- 2.
Montreal will be the location for a new British-American co- production, to be filmed next spring with the young English actress, Susannah York.
HAMPTON, Va., Aug. 22 -- The Tactical Air Command, charged with delivering nuclear weapons, paratroopers or conventional bombs, faces relatively minor problems in preparing for the Berlin crisis.
TRENTON, Aug. 25 -- The Democratic-dominated Assembly is expected to give final legislative approval on Monday to a bill that would give legal status to the Metropolitan Regional Council.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- State Department officials were perplexed tonight by the news of the resignation of President Janio Quadros of Brazil, whose foreign policy had been a source of growing concern to the United States.
The first agreement since 1958 between a major airline and the Flight Engineers' International Association was reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- -A professor of psychology said here today that the "tremendous progress" in race relations in America in the last twenty years had whetted the Negro's appetite for the fruits of full equality as an American citizen.

HAMILTON, Mass., Aug. 25 -- Michael O. Page of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., led today in the dressage phase of the equestrian competition for the Col. John W. Wofford Memorial Perpetual Challenge Trophy at the Myopia Hunt Club.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- The outlook for an early contract settlement between the American Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers improved today as round-the-clock bargaining appeared imminent.

THERE was an interval during World War II when a small Italian fishing harbor ranked seventh among the great ports of the world. It lies between Naples and Rome and the story of those days, when it was a boiling Allied beachhead, is told by Wynford Vaughan-Thomas in "Anzio."*
The state Education Department indicated yesterday that its intervention in the city school crisis might be the forerunner of other actions to assure high scholastic standards throughout the state.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 25 -- President Janio Quadros of Brazil resigned today blaming forces of "reaction" for blocking his "efforts to lead the nation along the road to true political and economic liberation."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Pepper is becoming less and less a spice of life, the Food and Agriculture organization reports. Production and consumption is 20 per cent less than before World War II. World production of black and white pepper fell from 83,630 metric tons in the pre-war years to about 39,000 tons during the war. Production in 1959 was 68,000 tons.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- President Kennedy's special consultant on youth fitness offered a five-point program today.
CHARLES RENDIGS, the man the late Christian Dior called "the best copyist in America, would not think of retiring. A 83, he is still lifting bolt afte bolt of heavy French silk.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- A chunky economist, whose advice Walter P. Reuther once sought on the guaranteed annual wage concept, surprised the auto union leader this year with what he called "a fresh new approach" to collective bargaining.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 25 -- West Germany's two major parties declared themselves today in favor of an early meeting of the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France to prepare the basis for negotiations with the Soviet Union.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Mexico has demanded a "full investigation and report" of the death of Senor Flores Aguirre in Havana, the Foreign Ministry said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Pentagon today ordered to active duty 76,500 members of the reserve military forces -- 46,500 in the Army, 23,600 in the Air Force and 6,400 in the Navy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- Pal Benko of New York de= feated the defending champion, Robert Byrne of Indianapolis, in their tenth-round game in :ie United States open championship last night. Benko is in first place, with a 9 -- 1 record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Drivers have been invited to remind one another of the need for extra caution by keeping their headlights burning -- day as well as night -- over the Labor Day week-end from 4 P.M. Friday, Sept. 1, to 8 A.M. Tuesday, Sept. 5.

New York banking circles seconded the view that the Berlin crisis had resulted in renewed buying of gold. They noted that liquid assets had been placed in the mark in substantial quantities over some time because of the stability of West German currency.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A jet F-100 fighter plane crashed into a suburban residential area today, killing a small child and injuring at least three other persons.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars today chose a new commander in chief, Robert E. Hansen, 35-year-old insurance man from South St. Paul, Minn.
Stirred perhaps by the baseball exploits of Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia has done some musing over the business of spectator sports in its August review.
LINDEN, N.J., Aug. 25 -- A sudden downpour and temperatures in the eighties failed to wilt a demonstration of a new mobile snow-melting device here today.
With a new season approaching, several players were announced yesterday as additions to forthcoming Broadway productions.

In spite of some preliminary scowls from the weather man, the sixth Randall's Island Jazz Festival got under way last night at Downing Stadium. An audience estimated at 4,000 persons attended, and almost that many musicians appeared during the long evening on what is billed as the largest movable stage in the world.
JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Eddie Merrins won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association title today in an 18-hole play-off with Shelley Mayfield.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Bishop Fred Pierce Corson of Philadelphia, inaugurated today as president of the World Methodist Council, said Protestantism was increasing in favor while diminishing in influence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- One of the week's patents discloses that a General Electric Company scientist has succeeded in making radioactive diamonds. Although the only production so far has been experimental, the process has potential commercial use.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The advance party of a West German tank battalion arrived today in Britain.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made it known today that he believed the Western Allies should continue to have access to West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- A Federal judge today froze the millions of dollars in assets held by the United House of All Prayer, the church of the late Charles M. Grace, known as Daddy Grace.

The five-week strike of stable employes at the state's thoroughbred race tracks ended last night. The strikers agreed to the establishment of a commission by Governor Rockefeller to investigate their bid for union recognition.

May I compliment you on your editorial of Aug. 14 on the Farm Labor Bill. As you pointed out, the Administration has proposed that the importation of "bracero" labor, a program begun as an emergency measure during the Korean War, be continued only if improvements are made to safeguard the interests of American farm workers.
DUSTON, England, Aug. 25 -- An American team of eight ponies and teen-age riders defeated a British squad, 13 -- 9, today, in the British Timkin horse show in Northampton County.
MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 20 -- A chambermaid here in Munich, speaking about the Berlin situation, exclaimed: "Poof! What can we do about it?"
A group of fifteen tanker companies reached an accord here last night with the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The United States was offered a Russian-English dictionary last night by a Bulgarian as his "personal contribution to East-West understanding."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Ray Sadecki pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to their filth consecutive victory tonight with a 7 -- 3 triumph over the San Francisco Giants.

COLD SPRING, N.Y., Aug. 25 (UPI) -- State Supreme Court Justice John P. Donohoe signed an injunction today preventing Newburgh, N.Y., from enforcing twelve of the thirteen points in its stringent welfare code.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Jonathan D. Simon's balloon did not sail more than 3,400 miles from here to London. It sailed fifteen miles to East Islip.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Navy announced today the assignment of twenty-eight shipbuilding jobs to Navy yards.
Alaska is the latest state to get a natural gas pipeline. The first consumer service began at 6:35 A.M. on Aug. 14 at Anchorage.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of President Janio Quadros' resignation statement:

NETCONG, N.J., Aug. 25 -- "This is it, so let's get it right. Jay, you pick up Billy from the dirt, stand him up and throw several punches at him. Billy, you reel back against the hitching post and then fall into the trough."

In a year that has seen two other boat-manufacturing companies acquire new ownership, still a third boat-building firm has changed hands. The famous Wheeler Yacht Company, now on Clason Point, Bronx, on Paterson Avenue and formerly with yards on Coney Island Creek and during World War II in Whitestone, has been taken over by the Rimbach family of Flushing, Queens.
NEWARK, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The City Council has asked the Board of Education to postpone the proposed sale of nine acres of land at the old Ruppert Stadium site.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Steve Barringer of Russell, Kan., who had never seen a clay target until three years ago, today won trapshooting's No. 1 prize, the Grand American Handicap.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Prime Minister Macmillan and the Earl of Home, the Foreign Secretary, will interrupt their holidays in Scotland Sunday to discuss the Berlin situation. The two are scheduled to meet at Gleneagles, where the Prime Minister is vacationing.
Price fluctuations in the high-grade bond market were the narrowest of the year yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25 -- President Arturo Frondizi was under strong, pressure by Argentina's military leaders tonight to oust his Foreign Minister and curtail the power of the General Confederation of Labor, Government sources said.
Five two-story and three-story commercial buildings at 150-58 West Fifty-sixth Street, west of the Avenue of Americas (Sixth Avenue), has been sold by the RTR Realty Corporation.
Undefeated Doug Jones of New York will seek his nineteenth victory tonight when he faces Von Clay of Philadelphia in a scheduled ten-round fight in Madison Square Garden.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 25 -- The Chamber of Agriculture announced today that this year's harvest fell short of its goal by 800,000 tons of wheat and 2,500,000 tons of corn.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- A huge wave lashed 150 yards of the waterfront at the United States Military Academy here today. It flooded a warehouse, cut off a rail line, damaged twenty pleasure boats, and sucked heavy construction machinery into the Hudson River.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A political purge affecting high officials in the Cuban regime may result from public sessions of "criticism and self-criticism" that are to open tomorrow in Havana over the worsening food crisis.
HONG KONG, Aug 25 (AP) -- Hong Kong's textile industry decided to continue to impose a voluntary quota on its exports to Britain for another year, reliable sources here said today.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Bob Goalby, the only player to put together successive sub-par rounds, and Jay Hebert, who shot a three-under-par 67, tied for the lead today in the $50,000 American Golf Classic at the half-way mark.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A Senate-House conference committee reached tentative compromise agreements today on amounts to be recommended for several categories of foreign aid.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Robyn Ebbern of Brisbane, Australia defeated ninth-seeded Linda George of Santa Monica, Calif., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, today to advance to the fourth round of the United States girls' grass court tennis championship.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Dr. Frances Behrendt today identified a 28-year-old porter as the man who stabbed her husband to death and seriously wounded her with a knife.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 25 -- A one-day boom in the baby-sitting business took place today with the playing of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's husband and wife championship at the Cherry Valley Club.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Directors of Purex Corporation, Ltd., today declared a 25 per cent stock dividend, proposed a two-for-one stock split and said the company would raise the cash dividend rate on the split shares.
MOSCOW, Aug. 25 -- The Soviet press commented jeeringly today on a new American "phenomenon": moles with machine guns.
Customs inspectors will be increased here early next month to cope with the seasonally high number of returning voyagers and the new limitation of $100 in duty-free goods, effective Sept. 9.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- A French Government spokesman said today that the "lying and provocative" Soviet note implying a threat to Allied air access to Berlin would be answered speedily in the firmest terms.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Scout rocket put a satellite into orbit today. It will study the lethal effect that space dust could have on astronauts.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 cents a bale up on the March contract to 15 to 50 cents off on the others yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Four South Side slum buildings were ordered vacated today by Judge Julian P. Wilamoski in Circuit Court.
TUNIS, Aug. 25 -- President Habib Bourguiba held out today the prospect of eventual reconciliation with France in the conflict over Bizerte.
PARAMUS, N.J., Aug. 25 (AP) -- E.J. Korvette, Inc., of New York will build a shopping center on a twenty-acre tract on Route 4, opposite the Bergen Mall Shoping Center.
MOSCOW, Aug. 25 -- The Soviet Union asserted today that the United States, in reinforcing its military garrison in West Berlin, had simply put more men into a "mousetrap."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Senate passed today three bills designed to improve the lot of migratory farm workers.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 25 -- White residents of Prince Edward County, contemplating the future of their private segregated school system, were discussing two possible courses of action today.
The Times is to be commended on its editorial of Aug. 21 wherein it stated that the solution reached by the Legislature is in the "best public interest."

SARATOGA, SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- It seems that Sir Gaylord will have some opposition in the Hopeful Stakes tomorrow after all. Earlier in the week indications were that only five or six 2-year-olds would dare to oppose the Christopher T. Chenery colt.
Trading in cocoa, coffee and sugar futures on the New York exchanges was active yesterday in an otherwise quiet day.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 25 -- It seems that nothing can make baseball fans around the nation happier than to see the Yankees famed M. and M. boys belt home runs while the home team finishes on top.

A crash of four trucks and a bus in the Lincoln Tunnel combined with heavy weekend traffic late yesterday afternoon to produce one of the worst midtown traffic jams of the year. Temperatures in the eighties and humidity in the mid-seventies added to the irritation of drivers, who blasted their horns, bumped bumpers in frustration and hurled words in anger while trying to escape from the snarled traffic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Jim Bunning pitched a two-hitter to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 6-0 victory over the Washington Senators tonight. The game was shortened to eight innings because of rain.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 25 -- Kenya's two major political parties called for new legislation today to enable Jomo Kenyatta, the African leader, to participate in government.

HAVANA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Jesus Flores Aguirre, 54-year-old Mexican poet and counselor of his country's embassy here, was fatally shot in his automobile last night in the suburb of Marianao. He died in a hospital.
The moon turned coppery red last night during a 99 per cent eclipse visible over much of the earth.

The issue of Federal aid to education has been obscured under a smoke screen of extraneous issues. Under various pressures, ranging from simple hostility toward any form of Government support to advocacy of aid to parochial schools, the simple outline of needs and priorities has become blurred. What remains is a residue of compromises.

THE 41st Street Theatre's summer comedy festival, which has been less than uproarious, presented its fifth and final installment last night, a revival of "The Tender Trap" by Max Shulman and Robert Paul Smith.

CRUSHED red pepper is such a fiery spice that only a teaspoon of it is needed to add zest in the following recipe for one and one-half gallons of Brunswick stew. Described as the peppiest and most pungent of all spices, red pepper comes under various labels.

The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway showed a sharp improvement in its operations during July, but results for the first seven months this year still lagged behind those for the 1960 period, according to the report issued yesterday by Ernest S. Marsh, president.

Richard II of England, in the past, has often been portrayed as a neurotic who attempted tyranny and, failing, almost gladly surrendered his throne. In "The Hollow Crown, A Life of Richard II," Harold F. Hutchinson presents the monarch as neither a tyrant nor a weakling, but an able medieval king.
High temperatures, intermittent fog and light drizzle made yesterday in New York a day to stay inside with air conditioning.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 25 -- United Nations forces started operations today aimed at disarming the 13,000-man army of secessionist Katanga Province.

Columbia University's recent decision to drop its Contemporary Civilization course for sophomores surprised some of us. Colleges, of course, frequently drop courses for one reason and another, but seldom do they do so for the reason given in this instance.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States, Britain and West Germany were reported today to be urging France to join them in a proposal for early East-West contacts to discuss the Berlin crisis.
Drivers of ready-mix-concrete trucks voted yesterday to end their eight-week strike against the construction industry.

GENEVA, Aug. 25 -- Arthur H. Dean, chief United States delegate to the deadlocked nuclear test ban talks here, said today that he hoped that Moscow's recall of its negotiator for consultations presaged a favorable change in Soviet policy.
Stocks made a small gain yesterday in slow trading. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange were generally steady in quiet trading. Volume dwindled to the lowest level since July 25.
TOKYO, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- The Japanese Government, in an official blue book issued today, reaffirmed Japan's alliance with the Western world and ruled out a policy of "defenseless neutrality."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today the United States must press for disarmament and world peace despite the efforts of "one rogue government" -- the Soviet Union -- to block it at every turn.

HONOLULU, Aug. 25 -- An attempt to test the color blindness of sharks has produced a result so disastrous to the shark that it is believed the incident might be a clue to an effective means of repelling the fish.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 25 -- Although Dink Vail's Jollity, the defender from Fishing Bay, Va., won the opening race, boats of the Marblehead fleet dominated the opening competition in the seventh annual Jolly Boat North American sailing championship today.
TACOMA, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Mrs. Anne Quast Decker and Phyllis Preuss, a 22-year-old willowy blonde, today gained the final of the womens' National Amateur golf tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- A substantial majority of the United Nations called tonight upon France to negotiate her withdrawal from the naval base of Bizerte in Tunisia. A special session of the General Assembly thus ended in a victory for Tunisia, whose demands for evacuation produced an armed clash with France last month.
NEW BRUNSWICK N.J., Aug. 25 -- Sixty-one Peace Corps volunteers were graduated tonight in a ceremony at Rutgers University.
PELHHAM MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Four meet records were set tonight in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's outdoor swimming championships at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island pool.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The Senate Finance Committee approved over Treasury objections today a bill granting a tax credit to self-employed persons setting up their own pension plans.

WITH the return of summer vacationers after Labor Day, presumably the fall party season will be on. To some this means a flood of invitations for cocktail and dinner parties. Keeping the various dates straight can pose a problem to those accustomed to casual country living.
The Citizens' Committee for Children wishes to congratulate The Times for its two constructive editorials (Aug. 10 and 11) on wayward girls.
PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 25 -- Dr. Morris A. Jacobs of Port Richmond, S.I., a former New York City Hospital Commissioner, has been chosen superintendent of the merged Passaic County Hospital.
ALBANY, Aug. 25 -- Governor Rockefeller does not support all the long-range financing features of President Kennedy's foreign-aid program after all.
I was dismayed by the narrow picture presented in your Aug. 15 editorial dealing with the situation now existing in Berlin.
"The Sound of Music" received yesterday the professional theatre award of the National Catholic Theatre Conference, which is holding its convention here.
The New York, Brooklyn and Queens Public Libraries yesterday asked the city Planning Commission for $9,276,044 in 1962 capital budget allocations.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox scored nine runs on four homers -- including the first grand-slam drive of Carroll Hardy's major league career -- in beating the Angels, 12-6, today.
Steam is rising these days from slow-moving cars and irate New Yorkers because of traffic tie-ups on the elevated roadway around the Grand Central Terminal.
Negotiations in the Metropolitan Opera contract dispute reached another stalemate yesterday, and Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg summoned both sides to meet with him in Washington Monday.
Armour Co. is offering its common shareholders the right to subscribe for $32,648,000 of 4 1/2 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due Sept. 1, 1983, at 100.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A steady decrease in the accident rate as the volume of highway traffic increases had been found in studies conducted in France, Belgium and England.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- LeRoy Collins, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, assured two inquiring Senators today that the industry generally is adhering to a ban on hard-liquor advertising.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 25 -- All the immigrant children removed from a Zionist clearance camp during a raid by religious zealots Tuesday have returned to camp, it was stated today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Jack Fisher, a right-hander, returned to the mound after an eight-day absence and pitched the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight. Dave Philley of the Orioles set a major league record for pinch-hits, getting his twenty-third of the season in the eighth inning.

BLACKPOOL, England, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Carolyn Wood equaled the pending world record of 1 minute 10 seconds for 110 yards in the butterfly tonight in helping a sickness-stricken United States girls' team to a 47-35 lead over a European team halfway through their two-day swimming meet.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The office of Attorney General Jack Gremillion ordered Louisiana teachers today to resign front the National Education Association because it supports school integration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 per cent in July, the Department of Labor reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Senate approved permanent status far the Peace Corps today.
State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday angrily revoked his pledge to support Mayor Wagner for re-election if the Mayor won the Democratic party nomination.
Buddy Rogers and Bob Orton defeated Antonino Rocca and Johnny Valentine last night in the final wrestling show of the summer session at Madison Square Garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves battered Philadelphia pitching for twenty-one hits and a 9-4 victory in the second game of a double-header tonight after the Phillies had taken the opener, 9 -- 4.
A merger of Hazel Bishop, Inc. and Lanolin Plus, Inc. was agreed upon yesterday by their directors. It is subject to the approval of stockholders at meetings to be announced.
A bakery owner who was found guilty of having failed to pay two employes the state minimum wage was given a heavy sentence yesterday in Municipal Term Court.
The Chain Belt Company's sales and earnings declined in the nine months ended on July 31 from year-earlier levels, O.W. Carpenter, president of the Milwaukee manufacturer, reported yesterday.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 25 -- Little League baseball no longer is little.
Richard Poley, Bergen County builder and realty developer, has bought three-fourths of an acre of land at 249 Prospect Street, East Orange. He will build an apartment house on the site.
THERE are well-defined cases in which one should not take an ace, even when he is sure declarer has a singleton in the suit and the ace will be lost if not taken immediately.
TEN years ago nearly half the ice cream sold in this country went over the counter via the ice cream dipper. Now only 18 per cent is sold this way.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 25 -- Karen Hantze of Chula Vista, Calif., who led the United States Wightman Cup team to victory over the British at Chicago last week, and Janet Hopps of Seattle were beaten today in the women's national doubles tennis championships.

State Controller Arthur Levitt made a point-by-point reply yesterday to a charge by Mayor Wagner that he had jeopardized the State Employes Retirement Fund by approving an investment in a queens housing development.

John C. Bolinger Jr. has been elected president and a director of Tennessee Bank and Trust Company of Houston, Tex., it was announced by Gardiner Symonds, chairman. Mr. Bolinger was formerly president of the East Tennessee Natural Gas Company of Knoxville. Tenn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 118.9 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Men who do the psychological screening of United Lutheran candidates for the ministry will meet here for five days beginning Monday in a workshop to "sharpen skills, techniques and general procedures."
YONKERS, Aug. 25 -- Su Mac Lad, a 7-year-old trotting gelding, set a track record, equaled a world record and eclipsed two other marks tonight while winning the $25,000 Volo Song at Yonkers Raceway.

Your editorial of Aug. 16 "Egyptian Socialism" could hardly have been thought through very clearly. You state that "it is necessary for us in the West to prove that our democratic, free enterprise system is better than any variation of socialism.''
Janio Quadros said not long after taking office as President of Brazil last Jan. 31 that "by August I will not have a friend left in this country."

Jonathan Logan, Inc., a major manufacturer of dresses and sportswear, announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached to acquire the Arthur Imerman Undergarment Corporation, large manufacturer of lingerie for girls.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The free-market price of gold edged up again here today, and there is a feeling in the air that a wave of heavy demand could come at any time.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Only seven months in office, President Janio Quadros resigned today with a declaration that he had been crushed by opponents at home and abroad.
GREENVILLE, S.C., Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The Houston Oilers, led by George Blanda, defeated the New York Titans, 30 -- 20, tonight in an exhibition between American Football League teams.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 25 -- Talks broke down tonight between Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and the Sikh leaders who have been striving for three days to find a way to end the hunger strike of Master Tara Singh.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Aug. 25 -- Sir Ralph Grey, the Governor of this British colony, and Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, the leader of the People's Progressive party, conferred today on the formation of government under a new constitution giving British Guiana internal self-government.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Industrial shares rallied in the stock market here today after early falls, but still showed net losses at the close.
A patrolman accused of sharing the loot with two Brooklyn hold-up men who had used his pistol was suspended from the police force last night and charged with assault and robbery.

PINKERTON'S National Detective Agency, the oldest private detective agency in the world, has been chosen to provide the security for the New York World's Fair in 1964-65. Some 1,300 uniformed guards and detectives will patrol the fair grounds to protect visitors against pickpockets and the fair itself against thieves, vandals, drunks and employes with their hands in the till.
BRASILIA, Aug. 26 -- Brazil's vigorous, anti-Communist War Minister, Gen. Odilio Denys, said tonight that the armed forces would not permit Vice President Joao Goulart to take over as President.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 26 -- A heavy squall hit the boats at the start of today's Yacht Racing Association regatta on western Long Island Sound. Another and stronger squall struck just as the last boats in the fleet of 113 were finishing.
The Joint Distribution Committee, an American agency that aids needy Jews abroad, last year helped 232,500 persons in twenty-five countries on five continents, the agency's annual report shows.
ATLANTA, Aug. 26 -- Construction of a $200,000,000 rapid transit system with thirty-two stations and sixty miles of track has been proposed by the Atlanta Regional Metropolitan Planning Commission.
ATLANTA, Aug. 26 -- Atlantans face desegregation of their public schools Wednesday with cautious confidence that the change will come peacefully.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson called today for Federal laws to jail local officials who connived with or refused to prosecute interstate crime syndicates.
THE three men in the Oriental room were variously occupied. The youthful-looking, slim executive type suddenly said, "Come on, boys. Let's get this while we're still young -- if it's not too late."

What amounts to an agreement between Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner seems to have removed the New York City school crisis as a major issue in this year's city campaign, or at least to have dulled its cutting edge.

Thanks to the automobile, bicycles and scooters have all but disappeared in the big cities, bike races have been kicked off the main roads, and the affluence of bike factories has dropped so sharply that racing teams are now being sponsored by television and refrigerator companies.

In your columns on Aug. 13 six members of the Mathematics Department of Stanford University criticized the President's speech for*** "still largely following a policy based ultimately on military power."
HONOLULU, Aug. 26 -- Statistical analysis of 35,000 cases of stomach cancer has shown a striking proclivity of that disease for people with blood type A, it was reported here today.

MY-THO, Vietnam, Aug. 25 -- In the war against Communist infiltration, subversion and terrorism in South Vietnam, an army division has come up with an effective method of winning the vitally important cooperation and loyalty of local peasants.
The nation's giant automobile industry has reached a critical crossroad.
HAMILTON, Mass., Aug. 26 -- The leaders in the competition for the Col. John W. Wofford Memorial Perpetual Challenge Trophy increased their margins today in the second day of the equestrian event.
The New York Telephone Company has announced that beginning Oct. 1 the area code for calls to northern New Jersey will be 201 instead of 11.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 26 -- For the next five days hunters will be permitted to go into the country's last free-ranging buffalo herd at Big Delta and soot fifty of them.

A DISTINGUISHED painter -- doubtless with a glance at his patrons -- once noted that a portrait is a picture which has something wrong with the nose. Almost any anthologist might paraphrase this observation. An anthology, he might conclude as he faced his readers and reviewers, is a collection of excellent writing with many of the wrong things included and many of the right things left out.

Although New York may in some respects be a Summer Festival, that role owes precious little to the contributions of art galleries, most of which are closed fast against the heat and emptiness of Madison Avenue.

THE moon rose over the second act of Wagner's "Meistersinger" here at the Prinzregenten Theater last week. It bathed the stage with white light as the night watchman came through the empty streets of Nurenberg and it tickled one listener into all kinds of nostalgic associations.

WITH the fifteenth season of Cinema 16 due to begin on Oct. 22, the country's largest film society is offering members what it believes to be one of the most provocative programs in several years. Sixteen screenings will include more than eleven award-winning features and thirty short subjects from ten countries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Administration is putting on one of its most impressive displays of bipartisan strength to get its bill to set up a permanent high-level disarmament agency through Congress before adjournment.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Baltimore Colts routed the Washington Redskins, 41 -- 7, tonight in an exhibition football game.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- John Isbister of Larchmont sailed Tranquille to decisive victories in both races as the first Atlantic Coast championship of the International 5 -- 0 -- 5 Class opened off Larchmont Yacht Club today.
BELGRADE, Aug. 26 -- The shaping up of the Berlin crisis has had the effect of rallying the Slav peoples in Eastern Europe against West Germany.
What the Kennedy Administration should do about controls over imports of heavy fuel oil is a question on which there are many opinions, depending largely upon the interest of each party.

At the tail end of a summer of vacation cruises the pleasure boat skipper, as autumn approaches and days get shorter, reduces his mileage and plots his courses nearer home. He finds Friday-to-Monday weekends more captivating than ever.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 26 (AP) -- David Alfaro Siqueiros, one of Mexico's leading artists and one of her top Communists, is starting his second year in jail and criticism over the Government's handling of his case.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Three lawyers were arrested here today and held in $55,000 bail on charges of trying to bribe an Internal Revenue official with $10,000.

FRANKLIN, N.C. -- A gem collector, Kerrait Martin, has found an enormous ruby and an equally enormous sapphire in the Cowee Valley here. In the rough, the sapphire measures three by five -inches and weighs around 2,000 -carats, or about fourteen ounces.

With the tone of statements from the Kremlin so ominous and threatening, it was heartening the other day to read one story with a Moscow dateline that provides a glimmer of the concept of human brotherhood.

TO an observer, the MacDowell Colony would have seemed this summer, perhaps even more than in other summer, a New England paradise. The weather was especially good, ranging from soft, hot days when the smell of warm pine needles filled the air, to crisp, clear ones when the skies were a cloudless blue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Western powers told the Soviet Union today that it had no jurisdiction over Allied flights into Berlin and reiterated a "solemn warning" against interference with those flights.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- Maj. Gherman S. Titov had the unusual experience during his recent orbital flight of watching droplets of spilled fruit juice float before his eyes. He also amused himself by taking movies of his logbook hovering overhead in the cabin of his spaceship Vostok II.

DURING the month ahead, wide-eyed 5-and 6 - year - olds throughout the country will experience their first encounters with formal education. Countless articles have been written on preparing children for this new adventure.

RECENTLY published British and American books deal with photographic practices and applications, ranging from general manuals to particular uses and the search for ideas.

LATE summer is the best time of year for planting new lawns and repairing old ones. After Sept. 15 success is still possible, but difficulties increase with each passing day. To insure the establishment of a velvety turf the home owner must have a well-prepared seedbed with enough organic matter to hold moisture, limestone if the soil is too acid, plenty of fertilizer, and a moderate seeding of the right kinds of grass.

A bid of $2,001 a month to operate a parking lot on city-owned property in Long Island City, Queens, has brought to light the fact that the Department of Public Works had been renting the same property without bidding for six years for $225 a month.
HONOLULU, Aug. 23 -- The long arm of Antarctica reaching toward South America has been found, in aerial photographs, to be 200 miles longer than previously supposed.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 26 -- Illinois will restore the historic Sangamon County Courthouse here as a Lincoln shrine.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Sources at the United Nations expressed doubt today that United Nations forces in the Congo had promised Premier Cyrille Adoula any assistance in ending Katanga's state of secession.
Arthur Herzog reports interestingly on noisemakers of New York ("New York Is a Summer Decibel," Aug. 13), but overlooks the menace of the barking dog.
Mr. Herzog fails to mention one of the worse "monsters" of all, the television set.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- The Democratic National Chairman called today for an investigation of what he said was an attempt by private power leaders to get control of the Colorado River storage project.

KENTUCKY bluegrass, red fescue and colonial bentgrass perform best in the cool humid regions of North America. Although these species are commonly seeded in the Northeast, they would still tend to dominate after a period of years, even without seeding, because they are widely distributed and well adapted to the climate.

PARIS -- The man who knows all about champagne at the caves in Reims studied, with considerable devotion, his sparkling, frosted glass, vintage 1954, a good year, and recommended earnestly that any champagne at home older than that year be drunk as soon as conveniently and happily possible.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 26 -- A gale and choppy seas blown up by a strong southwest wind hindered the invitation regatta of the Domino Yacht Club today.

"NOT until I hit my fifty-seventh and fifty-eighth home runs in the same afternoon," said Hank Greenberg, "did I really think I had a genuine chance of breaking Babe Ruth's record. Why shouldn't I have thought that way? I had five games left and it was not unreasonable to assume I might get three more.

Against the background of comparative price stability in the past year or so, a relatively sharp increase in the Consumer Price Index occurred from June to July, .4 of 1 per cent. For the entire year from July, 1960, to July, 1961, the corresponding rise had been only 1.2 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Cathy Crosby of Arcadia, Calif., fought off match point at 4 -- 5 in the third set to defeat the top-seeded foreign entry, Mary Habicht of Sao Paulo, Brazil, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 6, 6 -- 8, 7 -- 5, today in the fourth round of the United States girls' grass court tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

GENEVA -- The Genevois are looking beyond their lake and beyond the majestic backdrop of mount Blanc to scan the international horizon; but, unlike other Europeans, they seem to be worrying mainly whether present or looming crises will bring more conferences, summit or otherwise, to their peace-dedicated and parley-saturated city.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 26 -- Israel's first music festival, which opened in Jerusalem tonight, has brought artists to the country in greater concentration than ever before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- For the last two weeks there has been a great splutterfuss on Capitol Hill over President Kennedy's request for Treasury borrowing authority to finance $8,800,000,000 in foreign development loans over the next five years.

In recent months there has been persistent talk about American college students' alleged sharp turn to the political right. News of this trend came on the heels of earlier criticism of lagging student interest in national, international and social issues and of an atmosphere of self-centered "privatism."

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 26 -- Ch. Dandy Duke of Ravenhill, an English cocker spaniel owned by Mrs. J. Donald Duncan of New York and handled by Jane Kamp, was named best in show today in the Nowtown Kennel Club's eleventh annual dog show and obedience trial on the grounds of the Wooster school.

THE United States Government is moving slowly into the travel business under a Visit U.S.A. program that will be headed by Voit Gilmore, recently appointed director of the United States Travel Service, a unit of the Department of Commerce.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 -- James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, flew here tonight to try to put down rebellion in the Middle Midwestern sector of his union.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- For the first time since the Korean War the United States this week called Army, Navy, and Air Force reserves to augment the regular armed forces.
College football coaches apparently have given up their battle for free substitution.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- The Green Bay Packers scored two fourth-quarter touchdowns tonight to beat the Chicago Bears, 24 -- 14, before 42,580 fans, the largest crowd to watch a professional football game in Wisconsin.

TORONTO, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Diefenbaker, along with sports stars and fans, today paid tribute to the sport's heroes at the official opening of the Hockey Hall of Fame.

Mildred Lawrence introduces us to a tightly-knit group of high school seniors in a small Southern town, then describes the be wilderment of the one girl whose boy friend bows out.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 26 -- This was one of those weeks when most Indians were especially thankful that they did not have their Prime Minister's job.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 26 (AP) -- State and local health officials mobilized today to distribute 350,000 doses of newly approved Sabin oral vaccine to combat a polio outbreak in three central New York counties.

SAUGUS, Mass., Aug. 26 -- Voters of this eastern Massachusetts town ousted three of their five Selectmen in a special election this week. It was the first election to recall public officials in the state in fifteen years.

Investments in new industrial plants in the Chicago area totaled $33,296,000 during July, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. There were fifty-three projects announced during the month. A year ago in July the figure was $50,239,000 involving twenty-seven projects.

WHERE the slow pace of glaciers tumbles icebergs into the Arctic sea, the United States has put to work the fastest processes man has devised to meet the threat of intercontinental missile attack. This is the BMEWS -- Ballistic Missile Early Warning System -- installation at Thule Air Force Base, Greenland, established under treaty with Denmark.

UNION, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Jim Greber of Rock Spring, a 17-year-old Millburn High School graduate, defeated Joe Patterson of Hackensack, 6 and 5, today to win the New Jersey State Golf Association's junior championship at the Suburban Golf Club.

Labor leaders from New York and Long Island took part in a "unity" demonstration yesterday outside Belmont Park to signal the end of the five-week-old strike of grooms, exercise boys and other backstretch workers. Indicating, perhaps, a trend toward a more reasoned and less emotional view of varying football fortunes, the leading colleges have exercised admirable restraint in making coaching changes since last season. There were fewer changes among the major powers than there had been for years.

Negotiations in the Metropolitan Opera contract dispute will move to Washington tomorrow.
Beetles do double damage to gardens. They feed on flowers and foliage in the summer. Then the adults lay eggs in the ground and the hatching and hungry grubs feed on the grass roots.

THE new season gets under way Tuesday evening when the New York City Ballet opens a three-week engagement at the City Center, and it is going to be an even more congested season than had been expected. Besides the Leningrad Kirov Ballet, which will come into the Metropolitan Opera House for three weeks beginning Sept. 11, and will overlap the City Ballet season, two other entrants are now appearing over the horizon.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 26 -- Neither the Communists nor the West have fared well in South Asian opinion as a result of their latest moves on Berlin. Initially, closing of the East Berlin border swung considerable Asian sympathy toward the West.
TRENTON, Aug. 26 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner is expected to veto a bill Monday that would ban any new jetport in North Jersey.
Vernon Downs, thirty-five miles away from Syracuse, the site of the first Hambletonian in 1926, is ready to make its bid to stage the trotting classic in 1963.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- So many diplomatic notes have crisscrossed between Washington and Moscow on the Berlin crisis in the last three months that even the diplomats confess confusion.

The Park Association of New York City has chosen the Dec. 14 performance of "The Complaisant Lover" for its annual theatre benefit. The Graham Greene comedy starring Michael Redgrave is scheduled to open at the Barrymore Theatre Nov. 1.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Aug. 18 -- A small pioneer college near here is playing an important part in Tanganyika's program of building a nation.
YONKERS, Aug. 26 -- Royal Scotchman, the Drumbeat Stable's 6-year-old pacing horse, upset the calculations of most of the 34,835 winner-seekers at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Al Smith, who hadn't hit a home run since July 9, hit two today in leading the White Sox to a 10-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians. The homers were his twenty-first and twenty-second of the season.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Hank Greenberg resigned today as the general manager of the Chicago White Sox. The club secretary, Ed Short, was named as his successor.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Aug. 26 -- President Kennedy will hold a White House reception Monday for the first Peace Corps volunteers to be sent overseas.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- France regarded the speed, unanimity and firmness of the Allied reply today to the Soviet challenge to Western air access to Berlin as evidence of the relative unimportance of Allied differences on tactics in the Berlin crisis.
REHOVOTH, Israel, Aug. 20 -- Israeli scientists have learned to distinguish between old and young red blood cells through electron-microscopical observation of membranes.

LONDON, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- Terry Dyson's three goals enabled Tottenham Hotspur to beat Arsenal, 4 -- 3, in a first-division English League soccer game at Tottenham. The thrilling match drew a capacity crowd of 60,000.

MOSCOW, Aug. 26 -- The propaganda impact of the Berlin crisis in Moscow cannot be assessed in the same terms as in the Western world or neutral countries. The well-indoctrinated Soviet population is accustomed to accepting the interpretation of the Government and the party as regards events abroad.

Columbia's football team will open its 1961 pre-season training sessions Friday morning at Camp Columbia, Lakeside. Conn. Coach Aldo (Buff) Donelli will have eighteen letter men on hand when camp opens. Fifty candidates are expected to report.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26 -- Mrs. Margaret du Pont's quest for her fourteenth national women's doubles tennis championship ended in the semi-final round today at the Longwood Cricket Club.
THIS year marks the centenary of the birth of Helen Porter Mitchell, a fact that will be meaningless to most people until it is added that she was better known as Nellie Melba.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- School enrollment across the nation will be up 3 per cent this fall, from 47,000,000 to 49,000,000. This is the seventeenth consecutive year in which enrollments have increased.
DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- The first close look inside the 1962 automotive package that will be unwrapped in public next month is being offered now to a selected audience of "outsiders."

THE homeowner who has a staircase with worn treads can solve his problem by covering the steps with resilient floor tile. Any type of tile can be used (asphalt, vinyl or rubber) so that designs and colors can match or blend with adjoining floors.

Cleveland business activity continued somewhat on the dull side with week-to-week changes mixed as to direction and limited in extent. District Department stores sales rose 3 per cent in the week ended Aug. 19 from the year-ago level. With only end-of-model closeout sales in the picture, automotive trade remains sluggish.

Football, already virtually in full swing on the professional front, will break out all over this week. Practice for the upcoming season begins Friday at most colleges and, by next week, the grunts, groans and leather-popping thuds characteristic of the autumnal madness will resound through the land.

AN amiable Scot who recently became Professor of International Relations at Edinburgh University, Ritchie Calder is pretty much the reigning dean of British popular science writers. Under the National Collegiate Athletic Association control program, the American Broadcasting Company (Channel 7 in New York) again will televise leading college games on thirteen dates this season. Restoration of the American automobile to a more practical footing continues, as evidenced by the growing trend to smaller and less frill-bedecked cars. MERSIN, Turkey -- This classic rendezvous for continent-hopping warriors of ancient times is bidding again for a place in the warm Mediterranean sun. Authorities here are assembling the ingredients for making it a popular crossroads for modern travelers.

Congress last week was driving toward adjournment early next month and political observers were beginning to tally President Kennedy's legislative record. LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Sylvie Hulsemann, a 17-year-old Luxembourg girl, won the women's over-all title today at the world water ski championships. The defending champion's father protested, but his objection was turned down by the judges.

Elwood Quesada, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Quesada of Washington, and East Hampton, gave a supper dance tonight in honor of Mrs. Quesada's debutante daughter, {[iss Kate Davis Putnam, at their home on Georgia Road. General Quesada. president of the Washington Senators baseball club was first administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency under former President Dwight D. Eisenhower.

MOST house-hunters fall into three categories: Those who are looking for a house to build, those who want a house already built and those who would like to remodel anything from a barn to a windmill into a house. One leading representative of the last category is photographer George Ratkai. A former squash court is the place he calls home.

In a letter published on Aug. 13, Archibald B. Roosevelt, trustee of the Veritas Foundation, stated that "Our study reached the conclusion not that Keynesians are the dupes of any underhanded Communist conspiracy but that they are engaged in softening up American youth and American public opinion to accept with resignation, if not with enthusiasm, a centralized tyranny over our people."

THE Southern Negro tradition * * * is more casual than Negro recitation in the West Indies, where the formal style of African storytelling persists. * * * The animal tales so prevalent in the West Indies cross over to the mainland, but they blend with tales based in slavery, supernatural experiences borrowed from the Whites, American anecdotes and tall tales, and European folktales.

FOR the last few months there have been doleful forecasts about the outlook for television programing for the season that begins this fall. There have been indications that filmed situation comedies and adventure shows may dominate the TV screen more than ever during the 1961-62 term.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The renewed United Nations pressure on France to evacuate her naval base near Bizerte is unlikely to cause any great change in the French attitude, according to informed diplomatic quarters here.
ROME, Aug. 26 -- In its first comment on the present phase of the Berlin crisis, L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper warned the Soviet Union today that it was trying to do the impossible.
A trend among Government and business users of air transportation to urge personnel to fly in cheaper class services appears to have developed in the last year or so.
