About 5,000 persons jammed a Harlem armory yesterday to hear Elija Muhammad, Negro Muslim leader. Those attending were carefully searched after a death threat against Mr. Muhammad.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Senora Maria Martinez de Trujillo, widow of the slain Dominisan dictator, Generalissimo Rafael Leonides Trujillo Molina, a son, Capt. Rhadames Trujillo, an Air Force officer, and five grandchildren left here today for New York on their way to Europe.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Norman Matthews, vice president of the United Auto Workers, said today he intended to ask the union's international executive board for authority to strike at Chrysler Corporation at midnight Thursday if no new contract has been agreed upon.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- The weather was kind to the sailors of the 132 boats that started in today's regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound. It provided a steady southwest breeze of about ten knots.

Four four-story buildings at 85-101 Avenue A and 443-45 East Sixth Street, on the northwest corner, have been sold by Mrs. C.D. Jackson, wife of the publisher of Life Magazine, and Mrs. Mary Livermore. William A. White Sons and Horace S. Ely Co. were the brokers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Gail Russell, film actress, was found dead, apparently of natural causes, in her Los Angeles apartment late last night.
Mayor Wagner and his supporters for his renomination campaigned yesterday through the decaying slums and fresh housing projects of the lower East Side.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Both New York Senator, both Republicans, urged today that a United Nations committee be sent to Berlin.
The three city-wide Republican candidates made public a fourteen-point program yesterday, including a declaration that "gainful work should be found for every able-bodied welfare recipient."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Henry Bassford Jr. of Staten Island defeated Donald M. Frame of New York, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, today and gained the third round of the Eastern senior grass court tennis championship at the Huntington-Crescent Club. The rest of the field is a round behind.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- "Anybody who joins the Peace Corps to avoid the draft is going to be a disappointed volunteer," R. Sargent Shriver Jr., director of the corps, said today.
NEWARK, Aug. 27 -- A Bridgeport, Conn., machinist shot to death his estranged wife and his mother-in-law early this morning when a reconciliation attempt failed.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- Roy Sievers and Floyd Robinson combined to drive in nine runs today while pacing the Chicago White Sex to a 10-6, 9-3 sweep over the Cleveland Indians.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today that negotiations should certainly take place between the West and the Soviet Union on Berlin, but that these must be held in the "right atmosphere" and at the "right time."
MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today nothing would prevent the Soviet Union from signing a peace treaty with East Germany before the end of the year.
HYANNIS PORT, Aug. 27 -- President Kennedy spent a quiet holiday on Cape Cod today.

The real estate investment funds have caught on strong enough with investors to the point where their national trade association is becoming a strong working force. Robert M. Burr, a man well versed in the Washington, D.C., world, has taken on the job of executive director.

I must, in all good conscience, take exception to your recent editorial which so confidently predicted that the Legislature, by passing a bill reorganizing the Board of Education, "has ended a long and dismal chapter in the story of New York City schools."

THE smooth-skinned nectarines that are one of the most plentiful fruits now are relatively new to most New Yorkers. Only within the last five years has the fruit been grown in sufficient quantity in the Sacramento Valley of California to provide supplies for Eastern markets.

City school principals will not have to submit reports during the coming school year on "Implementation of Fourth Stanza of America," "Flower Arrangement Contest," "Best Route to School" and "World Poetry Day."

GENEVA, Aug. 27 -- The Swiss stock market prices declined last week under the pressure of the uncertain international political outlook and in sympathy with the general tendency on the European exchanges.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Milt Pappas lashed two home runs and fired a two-hitter today as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Minnesota Twins, 3 -- 0.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 27. -- The Soviet Union, Communist China and East European Communist regimes have begun to display interest in the coming Belgrade conference of heads of uncommitted nations.

An American edition of Ronald W. Clark's account of Britain's work on the atomic bomb will be issued by Horizon Press Oct. 2 under the title "The Birth of the Bomb: The Untold Story." The author tells how Professors Peierls and Frisch discovered in 1940 that the bomb appeared to be a practical possibility and how the famous Maud Committee was set up under Professor (now Sir George) Thomson.

WASHINGTON, Aug 27 -- (AP) -- The United States should negotiate an agreement with major industrial countries to help ward off balance of payments crises, a Congressional economic subcommittee recommended over the week-end.
TUNIS, Aug. 27 -- The Algerian rebels have named a Left-wing extremist to replace Ferhat Abbas, a relative moderate, as Premier of their Provisional Government.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Jim Brewer, with the help of Bob Anderson, scored his first major-league victory today as the Chicago Cubs beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 -- 5, in the second game of a double-header.
CAIRO, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- The Government of the United Arab Republic announced today plans to shift its operations to Damascus for four months every year.

The news of Aug. 18 that 450 miles will be added to the alternate-side parking ban sends shudders through my spine. Alternate-side parking is already a nightmare to thousands of us who can't afford $40-$60 a month for a garage, but can afford (almost) to keep a car in the city.

The silver anniversary convention of the American Educational Theatre Association continued yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. The meeting, bringing together theatre students, teachers and professionals, will continue through Wednesday.

A production of the Tennessee Williams play, "Orpheus Descending," scored a "big success" with a Moscow audience yesterday, according to an English-language dispatch from Tass, the Soviet press agency.
HONOLULU, Aug. 27 -- An insidious disease known as cadang-cadang is spreading slowly through the coconut palms of the Pacific, threatening the habitability of thousands of islands.

WILLOW GROVE, Pa., Aug. 27 -- A jet plane from the Willow Grove Naval Air Station crashed through the roof of a department store today, killing the pilot and injuring thirty-five or more Sunday shoppers, none critically.
Six new feature films will open here during the week. The program follows:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Thirty-five Democrats in Congress have told President Kennedy that they see dangers of monopoly in preliminary decisions on the nation's satellite communications system.

Negro players will give free outdoor performances in Harlem. They will appear in a double bill, consisting of George Llyonel Williams' satire, "The Eye Patch," and Jonathan Tree's fantasy, "The Fisherman."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 21 -- Australia's business recession is expected to give place to a recovery and a renewal of economic growth, but not within the next few months. This is the finding of the Federal Department of Trade, based on a survey that covered forty-four industries and included 850 interviews with leading Australian business executives.
GLENDIVE, Mont., Aug. 27 (UPI) -- San Carlos, Calif., defeated a scrappy Englewood (N.J.) team, 9 -- 2, on the four-hit pitching of Steve Caria today to win the 1961 Babe Ruth world series.

FORT WASHINGTON, Pa., Aug. 27 -- Merrybrook's Beautiful Belle, a wire foxterrier owned and bred by Mrs. Franklin Koehler of Long Valley, N.J., went best in show today at the thirteenth annual Perkiomen Valley Kennel Club event. There were 458 entries.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- Rocky Colavito hit four home runs in two games, three in the finale, and paced the Detroit Tigers to 7-4 and 10-1 victories over the Washington Senators today.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 -- The Cincinnati Reds beat the Los Angeles Dodgers twice today, 6 -- 5 and 8 -- 3, and thus removed temporariy (and possibly for good) much of the tensoin from the National League pennant race.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -The Senate Internal Security subcommittee accused Cuba today of campaigning to "subvert the American Negro against his own Government." But it said the campaign had been unsuccessful.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 27 -- Quaker Colony captured the working-hunter championship of the twenty-second Fairfield (Conn.) County Hunt Club junior horse show that ended today after three days of competition.
STONY POINT, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- A five-mile section of Route 9W, a major truck route on the west bank of the Hudson River here, will remain closed for "an indefinite time," the state police said today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 27 -- Brazil's Minister of War was quoted here tonight as having said that the time had come to choose "between communism and Brazil."

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Direct Government subsidies to the oil and gas industry were suggested yesterday by the nation's tax chief as an alternative to the present 27 1/2 per cent depletion allowance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -The United States, accused by the Soviet Union and Cuba of having engineered the resignation of President Janio Quadros in Brazil, is watching the developing situation there with much concern.
The Bronx Zoo is planning a multimillion-dollar renovation that would allow all its animals to be exhibited in natural settings without fences or bars.

Oppenheimer Fund, Inc., announced last week that its dividend policy had been changed to make payments from investment income and realized gains once a year in December. Silvio M. Smilovici, vice president of the fund and partner in the sponsor concern of Oppenheimer Co., said that this would enable "fullest possible portfolio use of the fund's cash flow."
ROME, Aug. 27 -- Premier Khrushchev has confirmed in writing to Premier Amintore Fanfani that he is willing to negotiate with the Western Allies on Berlin and other European problems.

The Indian Head Mills, Inc., textile manufacturer, has made an offer to purchase all the stock of Joseph Bancroft Sons Company, also engaged in textile operations, at $20 a share, according to a statement made yesterday by W.R. MacIntyre, president of the Bancroft concern.

HAMILTON, Mass., Aug. 27 -- Three days of tense competition among the country's leading equestrians ended today with Michael O. Page of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., winning the Col. John W. Wofford Memorial Perpetual Challenge Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk will fly to New York tomorrow morning and spend the day conferring with Adlai E. Stevenson and Dag Hammarskjold, the State Department an nounced today.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The dog days, or silly season, as some Britons call it, hit the stock market hard last week.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Larry Jackson shut out the San Francisco Giants on three hits for the second straight time to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-0 victory today.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 27 -- The Dalai Lama asserted in a letter made public today that Tibet was passing through a food shortage "unprecedented in its history."

Amity Fabrics, Inc., a textile concern, has leased most of a floor at 111 West Fortieth Street through Ira Koerner and Charles L. Goldenberg of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agent for the building. The lessee will move from 12 West Thirty-second Street about Oct. 1.
The Public Service Commission yesterday assailed the city's plan for preventing power failures as "an impossible goal" to attain.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Ann Clark's Ballet Master won the Hunter championship of the Brookville junior horse show today. The bay gelding took two blues and scored 14 points. He also won the junior jumper event.
A 21-year-old psychology student at Upsala College began his second attempt late yesterday to be the first person to swim around Staten Island.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Ray Mawby, vice chairman of the Moral Law Defense Association asked. Home Secretary R.A. Butler today to get the dramatization of "Lady Chatterley's Lover" removed from the Arts Theatre as indecent.

State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday walked the streets of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a stronghold of Orthodox Judaism, and made frequent use of the Yiddish taught to him by his grandfather.

The Cosden Petroleum Corporation reported over the weekend a net income of $1,151,743, or 38 cents a share, for the three months ended on July 31. This was an increase of 13 per cent over the net income of $1,016,100, or 34 cents a share, a year earlier.

The Aug. 18 letter of Eric Kahler and others in recent issues of The New York Times are poorly disguised pleas to the free world to abandon West Berlin. They ere reminiscent of the cry: "Why die for Danzig?" which went up among isolationists and appeasers when Hitler threatened the peace of the world.
MONROE, N.C., Aug. 27 -A policeman was shot in anti-segregation picketing violence today and a white couple was held hostage for several hours by Negroes.

I read with interest Dr. Howard Rusk's two excellent articles on "Loss of Hearing." Both he and The Times are to be congratulated on bringing the long-neglected field of ear research to your readers' attention. We feel many may be interested to learn how they can tangibly help further the work now being done in the broad field of deafness -- the nation's most chronic affliction.

After an early show of firmness, prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange eased last week. At the close Friday, active futures contracts on the exchange showed net losses for the week of two to twenty-five points.

All the hazards of open-air performances seemed to be conspiring Saturday night at the Forest Hills (Queens) Music Festival. But Harry Belafonte took the difficulties graciously, even surmounting them to end the evening on an uncommonly communicative level.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 27 -- The market was overshadowed throughout last week by the Berlin situation. In view of the political tension, prices were unable to withstand selling pressure. An allround decline was recorded.

THE threat of rain almost cost the Municipal Concerts Orchestra its audience during its concert Saturday night at the Central Park Mall. Three-quarters of the way through the program, lightning, thunder and a very fine drizzle sent a large number of persons scurrying from their seats, just before the appearance of the soloist for the evening.

The Blackfriars Guild will open its twenty-first season on Oct. 20 with "Anthony on Overtime" at 316 West Fifty-seventh Street. As is customary with the experimental group, guided by the Rev. T.F. Carey, the presentation, the fifty-second in the series, is a new script.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Senate investigation group reported today a continued rise in juvenile delinquency, "largely among the children of the so-called white collar classes."

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 27 -- The Yankees today regaled a gathering of 34,065, the largest crowd ever to see a ball game in this metropolis, with an extraordinary exhibition of their depth of personnel as they brought down the Athletics, 8 -- 7.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Angels mustered thirteen hits today and sent the Boston Red Sox to their eighteenth loss in twenty road games, 8 -- 3.

While the fight between Mayor Wagner and the party organization is the No. 1 issue in the city's Democratic primary, a paradox in New York's housing problem has become No. 2 in several party leadership contests on Manhattan's East Side.

Trading in the foreign exchange market continued dull during the past week. British pound sterling showed a slight gain while the Canadian dollar showed a loss.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 27 -- Best in show at the nineteenth annual fixture of the Great Barrington Kennel Club went to the smallest dog in the finale. This was the Pomeranian. Ch. ONE of the most exclusive groups of designers in America today is composed of those who create made-to-order clothes. Theirs is a dwindling art because skilled workers are hard to find and the cost of producing clothes to order is exceedingly high.
SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 27 (UPI) -- Mickey Wright today continued a rally she had started yesterday and won the $7,500 women's Spokane open golf tournament.

The selection panel charged with the search for nominees to New York City's new Board of Education meets for the first time today. It has the mandate to make educational history. The opening session will concern itself not with nominations but with determining ground rules for drawing up a list of eighteen men and women from whom the Mayor must choose the nine members of the new board.

Mo., and Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., 11 -- 9, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, in the American Zone cup final at Cleveland.

Rain, sleet, fog, high altitudes and dust storms are now off-the-shelf items, according to the Associated Testing laboratories, Inc. A new $8,500,000 Koppers Research Center will be opened today by the Koppers Company, Inc., at Somervell Park, Monroeville, Pa. It makes the high point of a twelve-year program of diversification and research.

No doubt much can be accomplished through a study of the Police Department by City Administrator Tenney. Commissioner Murphy says his years of experience in the department have convinced him that management procedures are in need of review.

The resignation of President Janio Quadros of Brazil is swiftly bringing on the dangerous complications that were to be feared. It is hard to disagree with the criticisms published in the Brazilian press. Janio Quadros did desert his post. He had the constitutional means to stay in power and so far as is known no one was trying to force him out.
Soldiers, sailors and airmen being recalled from civilian life Oct. 1 are beginning to cope with the paper work that will mark their transition to active duty.

Having achieved stardom in Hollywood, Carroll Baker is planning to return to Broadway, where she tarried briefly in "Escapade" (1953) and "All Summer Long" (1954). In Paris, Miss Baker acknowledged the other day she was "seriously considering" the starring role in "Come on Strong."
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -Trade stimulants were scarce in the grain futures market this week and, in general, prices showed only fractional changes from a week ago.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 -- James R. Hoffa pledged today to commit as many organizers as necessary to quell a rebellion here against the Teamsters Union.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -- Jack L. Warner, president of Warner Brothers, today disparaged the importance of independent movie producers and of movie companies that do not own studios.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 27 -- A tiny schoolhouse on the island of Bimini in the British West Indies will "go modern" Sept. 8. Courses in science, Spanish, typing and sewing will be beamed to it from Miami's educational television station, WTHS-TV.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 -- The United Automobile Workers Union is now looking to General Motors and the Ford Motor Company for improved contract offers following a tentative agreement yesterday with the American Motors Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Eighty-seventh Congress is preparing for a final drive toward adjournment of its first session. Mutual security and school aid legislation are the main obstacles to a quick close of the session.
HAVANA, Aug. 27 (AP) -The Cuban Government has agreed to return immediately all funds deposited by foreign diplomats and embassies in the Aug. 13-14 currency exchange, informed sources said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Employers were reminded today that on Sept. 3 the Federa{ m'mimum wage goes to $1.15 an hour for workers previously covered. Many thousands, more :come under the law for the first time at a starting rate : of $1, the present minimum.

Television techniques are being adapted to print-style advertising in a campaign planned to run in the fall in national magazines on behalf of Bigelow rugs and carpets. Running along streets of steaming cement and asphalt while thousands of sweltering New Yorkers looked at him and his rivals in wonder, James O'Connell, an evening student at City College, captured the second annual Milk Run yesterday.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- Jay Hebert sank a 20-foot birdie putt on the final regulation hole today to tie Gary Player in the American golf classic, then defeated him on the second extra hole of a sudden-death play-off for first-place money of $9,000.
GENEVA, Aug. 27 -- Semyon K. Tsarapkin, chief Soviet delegate to the talks here on a nuclear test ban, returned late today from hurried consultations in Moscow.

Walter P. Reuther's imaginative leadership of the United Automobile Workers appears to have achieved a significant break-through for his profit-sharing ideas. The tentative agreement on this issue between the union and the American Motors Corporation brings profit sharing into greater prominence as a possible mode of worker compensation than it has been for many years.

Sources close to Congress say that the "very friendly atmosphere" that prevailed at the House Ways and Means Committee hearing last Thursday greatly strengthened the possibility that legislation favoring stockholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., will get through Congress before adjournment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -The New York Central Railroad announced today it would appeal to the Federal courts an order by the Interstate Commerce Commission blocking a proposed change in rail freight service.

The possibility that state Controller Arthur Levitt will defeat Mayor Wagner in the Sept. 7 Democratic primary is provoking a great deal of speculation about the effect of such a result on this year's general election in November.

White, Weld Co., Inc., and associates are offering to the public today 160,000 common shares of the Blue List Publishing Company, Inc., at a price of $13 a share. The stock sale is the first to the public by the publisher of daily compilations of state, municipal and authority bonds scheduled for offering.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 -- The tempo of steel ordering has begun to quicken. Some customers, who fear it may be more difficult later to obtain steel easily, have stepped up their order volume. More are expected to do so soon.
ONE of the most imaginative raconteurs in the history of broadcasting is Jean Shepherd, who is heard Monday through Friday nights and on Saturday afternoons on WOR radio.

This morning, if all goes well, a 12-year-old Berlin boy named Erwin Schabe will get on his red bicycle and ride from his home in an area known as the Eiskeller, or Ice Cellar, to his school in West Berlin. The distance is about three miles. It is not a hard trip for a healthy boy in good weather, though Erwin might prefer a school bus if there were one.
A SPRAY of Miss Dior perfume wafted over the upturned Russian faces and the crowd pulsated with appreciation.

A battle for supremacy in coffee is brewing. Martinson Coffee is about to introduce a redesigned can and a hard-sell shipping carton, backed by a large-scale advertising and selling campaign through Grey Advertising, Inc.

HAVANA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Industry Minister Ernesto Guevara said today shortages of raw materials and spare parts had forced many factories in Cuba to halt production. He blamed "aggression of imperialism" for the shortages.
BERLIN, Aug. 27 -- The United States and Britain have agreed on a note to the Soviet Union that contains a guarded approach for East-West negotiations on Berlin.

An executive of the newly formed United Church of Christ said yesterday that "churches must now redouble their efforts to activate their brotherhoods." "If not," the Rev. Dr. James E. Wagner said, "we will lose the true essence of the Christian Church."
BERLIN, Aug. 27 -- "Things are pretty gay here," a Communist party functionary in East Berlin said today. With a note of sarcasm, he added, "Our boys have been having a gay time along the border."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- A Nobel Prize chemist formerly of the Atomic Energy Commission said today that, although the possibility of worldwide radioactive fall-out caused the most fears, the local type was the deadliest.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Exhortation of the steel industry to keep its prices where they are has only just begun.
Mayor Wagner accused Arthur Levitt yesterday of engaging in "gutter politics" and Mr. Levitt attacked the Mayor for "fumbling and ineptness."

LANGHORNE, Pa., Aug. 27 -- Jim Hurtubise of North Tonawanda, N.Y., won both fifty-mile segments of the 100-mile United States Auto Club national sprint car championship on Langhorne's one-mile dirt track today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A search was on today for a compromise on the financing of the long-term lending program in the Administration's foreign aid bill.
Seeking the cloak-and-suit vote, Louis J. Lefkowitz moved into the Garment Center at noon yesterday and tried to shake hands with everybody but the window mannequins.
BOSTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- The Floyd Patterson-Tom McNeeley world heavyweight title fight, previously scheduled for Oct. 23, has been rescheduled for Nov. 13.

Shoppers will find that an increasing number of clothes are being laminated. The process utilizes a thin layer of a foam synthetic, called polyureathane, which is bonded to the back of a fabric. The plastic is sealed permanently, either with an adhesive or by melting the plastic sufficiently for binding.
Rockefeller Center, Inc., has announced the signing of leases for office space for four new tenants.
SEED catalogues inform gardeners that their descriptions are of average-sized fruits and Vegetables when they are fully grown.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- When East Germany sealed off the border between East and West Berlin Aug. 13, Henry Nannen got an idea that has already paid off in the propaganda struggle initiated by the Communist action.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP) -- The wife of a man accused of blowing up microwave stations in Nevada and Utah was found dead in a hotel room today. The police said that she had apparently committed suicide.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- The House voted today to authorize the building of a national fisheries center and aquarium here. A supporter estimated the cost at $15,000,000 to $20,000,000.
WASHINGTON SQUARE concerts have tended to specialize in eighteenth century music. But last night's final event of the season switched from baroque and rococo to contemporary.

The Pittsburgh Steel Company plans to sell $10,000,000 of 6 per cent first mortgage bonds to an institutional investor as part of a previously announced capital spending program that will call for $20,000,000 in new permanent capital and an added $5,000,000 in bank credits.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Following are the texts of President Kennedy's letter to both sides and Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg's statement on the settlement of the Metropolitan Opera's dispute with the American Federation of Musicians:

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Aug. 28 -- G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said tonight that African nationalist leaders he had met were sincere and were doing their best to help their people.

J.P. Seiberling announced yesterday that he would retire as president or the Seiberling Rubber Company on Thursday. H.P. Schrank, now executive vice president, was named to succeed Mr. Seiberling as president and chief executive officer. Mr. Seiberling will continue as chairman of the company, which was founded by his father forty years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Senator Russell B. Long has ordered Congressional hearings on recommendations that an advisory group is to make on the development of a worldwide space satellite communications system by private industry.

MADISON, Wis., Tuesday, Aug. 29 -- The annual convention of the National Student Association adopted this morning a resolution calling for the abolition of the House Un-American Activities Committee. The vote was 269 to 156.
Taller skylines are beginning to appears in nearly every major city in the country because of the mounting pressure for office-building sites.
A few nights ago a mildly perplexed handful of voters on the West Side heard two young lawyers in heated debate. "Vote regular," said one. "Vote reform," said the other.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Hardened by a rugged summer training program that ranged from troop duty in Europe to Ranger training at near-by Camp Buckner, 115 cadets reported today for football practice at the United States Military Academy.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The time soon may arrive when border controls cease to exist in Europe. Already stiff customs inspections are a thing of the past. At some frontiers, particularly Swiss ones, customs men sometimes don't stop cars at all; they sit on the steps of the customs shed in the sun reading the newspapers and idly wave them through.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A constitutional amendment to set a maximum residence requirement of ninety days for voting in Presidential elections was proposed in the Senate today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 28 -- The presentation of the Theatre Guild American Repertory Company, which includes Helen Hayes, Nancy Coleman and Leif Erickson, has proved to be one of the most outstanding successes in recent times here, according to local critics.
NAUGATUCK, Conn., Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Eastern Company of Connecticut announced today it had purchased the Thompson Materials Corporation of Belleville, N.J. The purchase price was not disclosed.
The first special language and orientation program for Soviet exchange students in the United States has been canceled.
Weather Bureau officials admitted with aplomb and without much embarrassment yesterday that it was really cooler than they said it was on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.
The outlook for national currencies this year is more somber than ever, according to the seventh annual edition of Pick's Currency Yearbook, out today.

I am well aware of the problems faced by the residents of Morningside Drive and of the great cultural divide between the upper and the lower reaches of Morningside Park. Yet I feel the decision to erect gates, which I understand will be closed each evening, at the upper entrances to the park, is an unwise one.
HONOLULU, Aug. 27 -- The worst kind of harbor for protection against tidal waves may be one with a narrow mouth.
The Nation's production of raw steel topped 2,000,000 tons last week for the first time since early June, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The Grand Prix of the United States, the last event in 1961 to count toward the world road-racing drivers' championship, will be run at Watkins Glen N.Y., on Sunday Oct. 8.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower pledged tonight his full support if his Vice President, Richard M. Nixon, decides to run for governor of California.

The gas industry of 1970 will be a giant with sales revenues of $12,000,000,000 a year, serving 44,300,000 customers and having a volume of 165,200,000,O00 therms a year. Its gross plant investment will be $48,200,000,000 and it will have 924,200 miles of main, including pipelines.

The Citizens Union, a nonpartisan organization concerned with the quality of public officials, has disclosed it is refraining from expressing any preference between Mayor Wagner or State Controller Arthur Levitt in the primary.
A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board has issued a finding that Deck Scow Captains Local 335 is an independent union.

HONOLULU, Aug. 28 (AP) -- An airliner crew spotted what appeared to be signs of a sea disaster 800 miles northeast of Honolulu today but the Coast Guard said the gear floating on the Pacific might be the remains of a Navy rescue drill in the area recently.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 28 -- Most of this city and several near-by communities were without water this morning after a seventy-two-inch water main burst. Millions of gallons of water poured into the meadowlands, and factories and housewives found their water taps dry.
" A CHILD'S GAME," the drama on Channel 5 last night, was taped in Germany earlier this year before new barriers were placed between the Eastern and Western sectors of Berlin.

TUNIS, Aug. 28 -- The National Council of the Algerian Revolution underlined today "the importance of the material, political and diplomatic support of the Socialist countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America."
DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- The United Automobile Workers and the three major car companies carried on a war of nerves today in contract talks.
CASTLEMARTIN, Wales, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The first German troops in Britain have captured an objective -- the hearts of hundreds of British girls.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Ron Santo and Don Zimmer each drove in two runs today as the Chicago Cubs edged the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5 to 4, in the rubber game of a five-game series.
William Shakespeare became a Democratic primary issue yesterday.
Mayor Wagner ruled out yesterday any post-primary reconciliation with Carmine G. De Sapio or the Democratic leaders of Brooklyn and the Bronx.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Fred Hutchinson will manage the Cincinnati Reds in 1962 and 1963. Bill DeWitt, the club's general manager, said today that Hutchinson had signed a two-year contract after Saturday's defeat by Los Angeles.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Hal Brown pitched a five-hitter and Jim Gentile his fortieth home run tonight as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Angles, 8-1.

KEY WEST, Fla., Tuesday, Aug. 29 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba today urged Brazil "to profit from the experience of Cuba" and set up a guerrilla war against what he termed "reactionary militarists" who forced the resignation of President Janio Quadros.
The stamp imparted to the high-grade bond market by the late-August vacation season -- inactivity, minor price fluctuations and abundance of short-term investment money -- persisted yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 28 -- Take it from Mickey Mantle: There are more fine players in the major leagues today than ever before and it is unfair to attribute the success of present-day stars solely to better equipment.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 28 (UPI) -- About fifty Negro children applied to enter the first grade at all-white elementary schools here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today a plan by thirteen airlines to fly passengers 12 through 21 years old at half fare.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- New demands for the immediate independence of British Guiana can be considered only after a formal request has been submitted by the colony's newly elected Government, a spokesman for the Colonial Office said today.
SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 28 -- Stronger leadership by state governments was advocated by Governor Rockefeller of New York today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The N.V. Nederlandsche Aardolie Maats-chappij (N.A.M.), an affiliate of the Royal Dutch Shell Group and Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), today successfully moved a mobile drilling platform into the North Sea, about 2.3 miles from the coast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Mr. Nixon's call on General Eisenhower was part of a four-day series of conferences with friends, confidants and political leaders in which Mr. Nixon is chiefly discussing his overwhelming problem -- whether to run for Governor of California in 1962.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Henry Lower, aide of Teamster Jimmy Hoffa, head of the teamster union, died of cancer yesterday at the Palmer Park Osteopathic Hospital. He was 58 years old.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The grain futures market lost ground almost all along the line today on a moderate volume of liquidation against meager support.
BLOOMINGDALE, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Two New York couples -- neither of them millionaires -- own their own islands, from which they commute daily to Manhattan, an hour away.
CAIRO, Aug. 28 -- The heads of Government of the so-called Casablanca group of African states ended their "summit" conference tonight after a single meeting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Americans for Democratic Action urged today the removal of the chairman of a Miami draft board.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Lewis B. Hershey, selective service director, figures that the service will continue to call up only 23-year-olds until next summer despite the stepped-up draft.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- An international instrument designed to reduce the number of persons in the world without passports was completed here today.
PHILADELPPHIA, Aug. 28 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad sought an injunction today to block a strike threatened for midnight Thursday by the Transport Workers Union.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 28 (UPI) -- The first shipment of Sabin vaccine arrived today to help combat a three-county outbreak of poliomyelitis.

YONKERS, Aug. 28 -- The unveiling of a large bronze plaque honoring the memory of William H. Cane and the disclosure of a big entry list for the $112,450 Cane Futurity Pace Sept. 8 were the big events at Yonkers Raceway today.

NO one has ever been quite sure of where Joao Belchoir Goulart, the 43-year-old Vice President of Brazil, stands politically. The legal heir to the Presidency vacated by Dr. Janio Quadros last week has long been a figure of controversy and changing political complexion.
PARIS LANDING STATE PARK, Tenn., Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall called attention today to studies of the proposal to develop a 140,000-acre national playground near here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 -- Now that David L. Wolper has completed a one-hour film on the silent era of movies he wonders that he ever tried it. For he encountered more trouble getting clearances to make this movie than in doing his security-guarded shows, "The Race for Space" and "Project: Man in Space."

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox scored three runs against Norm Bass in the first inning tonight and gained a 4-3 victory over the Athletics. Bill Monbouquette was the starting and winning pitcher for Boston, though he was relieved in the ninth.

For the second time in a row, Art Carney, popular TV performer, is to portray a father on Broadway. That was his assignment when he made his stage debut here in "The Rope Dancers" (1957). And it will be again as the star of "Age of Consent," the new Phoebe and Henry Ephron comedy.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Aug. 28 -- A husky 21-year-old lifeguard finished swimming around Staten Island late today, after spending twenty-five hours in the water. He was the first person to swim around the island.

" DUORO" is Portuguese for gold, and there is a type of gold in the hills of the Duoro region of Portugal. It is liquid, its color may be tawny gold or rich ruby red, and it is very dear to the well-fed Englishman's heart.

President Kennedy noted in a telegram of greeting read yesterday to the American Educational Theatre Association that its very existence was "living evidence that the theatre is a widely supported art form in this country."
HAVANA, Aug. 28 -- Premier Fidel Castro denied tonight that the food shortages in Cuba had made his country more eager to negotiate with the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Warren Spahn scored the 304th victory of his career and his sixteenth this season when he pitched the Milwaukee Braves to a 7-1 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.
Secretary of State Rusk asserted yesterday that negotiations with the Soviet Union on the Berlin situation would take place because all parties wanted such talks.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru appealed to the big powers today "not to stick too much to legal niceties" on the Berlin problem. He urged them to strive urgently to reach a peaceful settlement of the dispute.

ONE thing that never grows obsolete is the announcement that something or other is obsolete. A deep-dish thinker can always get a trend-rampant story out of that. A style of painting, a way of waging peace or war, a doctrine, a system of government and a finny motor car all lend themselves to rousing essays of disenchantment.

MRS. SALLY JOHNSON of Westport, Conn., says she had long been looking for just such an opportunity as was offered to the West hand in this deal, and it finally came up in a national championship -- the women's pair tournament played earlier this month at Washington.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- West Berlin ballet fans have lost their hearts to Jerome Robbins and his "Ballets: U.S.A." Since the American troupe opened its six-day stand here on Friday cheers have grown louder and applause wilder each night.

Mayor Wagner, Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley and Dr. Ray E. Trussell, the Hospitals Commissioner, swung hammers on 135th Street yesterday to start the demolition for the new main building of Harlem Hospital.

ORAN, Algeria, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Six Algerians were killed and thirty-two were injured when a rampaging mob of European teen-agers swept through Oran tonight to avenge the killing of two youths by Algerian terrorists.

IT was just about a year ago that Lew Burdette of the Milwaukee Braves pitched a no-hit, no-run game. Less than a month later, Burdette's room-mate and closest friend, Warren Spahn, also spun a no-hitter, the first of his long career.

Susan Broady, 21-year-old daughter of John G. (Steve) Broady, a former lawyer and private detective, was critically injured yesterday when she jumped or fell from the window of her family's third-floor apartment at 110 Riverside Drive. She was taken to Knickerbocker Hospital.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, N.Y. THIS former whaling port is little more than an hour away from New York, but the boom of suburbia has not yet touched its borders. It is still a town with a single railroad track to handle trains coming and going and a shopping center that consists of Main Street, where an intriguing variety of shops are comfortably ensconced in the clapboard houses, some more than 150 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Washington World, a new weekly newspaper, will appear next month. The date is not yet firm, News of non-government character will be emphasized.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 28 -- President Sukarno decreed today that the Indonesian Government would now take 60 per cent share of profits made by foreign oil companies operating here. The decree was announced tonight over the state-owned radio a couple of hours before Mr. Sukarno emplaned for the Belgrade conference of nonaligned nations.
The stock market offered a seeming paradox yesterday. Prices were steady on the New York Stock Exchange for most of the day, yet the key averages showed small declines at the close of trading.
City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa staged an old-fashioned political tour of South Brooklyn last night.
The New York Football Giants, still seeking a pass-catcher to make Sundays unbearable for safetymen, may have come up with the right man yesterday.

First National Stores, Inc., has entered into an agreement to purchase the New York division of Safeway Stores, Inc. Although the food chains declined to disclose the price, the transaction represents one of the largest store consolidations in recent years.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation has sold privately to institutional investors, $60,000,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1991. The bonds are a 5 3/8 per cent series. One of the principal purchasers was New York Life Insurance Company.
NAHA, Okinawa, Aug. 27 -- For the last week there have been two worlds on the island of Okinawa, living and interwoven but 1,300 years apart in time and taste.
A power failure on the IND knocked out subway service on two Manhattan lines for an hour and a half early today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- The Soviet Union published today photographs of the earth taken by Maj. Gherman S. Titov on his twenty-five-hour orbital flight earlier this month.
RENO, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Bill Muncey of Seattle, who said he had planned a "cold, calculating race," bounced to his third Gold Cup hydroplane championship today without winning a single heat.
Guinea injected the question of continued good relations with the United States yesterday into the case of the recent Harlem street fight between a policeman and a Guinean diplomat.
LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 27 -- One of the most striking features of the anti-Portuguese insurrection in northern Angola is that its origins and character are still largely a mystery.

Vice President Johnson, speaking in Berlin for Americans and the United States Government, is as inaccurate as he is extreme in poor judgment when he likens our feelings regarding Berlin to our ancestors' feelings regarding America. The comparison is repugnant and careless.

Foreign orders for machine tools have reversed their rising trend of recent months. Orders from abroad have been a major factor in sustaining the domestic industry, and the decline in foreign demand was an important factor in a sharp over-all decline.

Transportation has been a problem in New York ever since it took on the dimensions of a busy commercial center, long before it was a city in the technical sense. Subsequent triumphs of engineering skill over distances and over enormous crowds of people have made the city famous for its subways, bridges, tunnels and other devices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Unless the principal union demand in the suspended shipping strike is previously removed, or Congress specifically asserts before Sept. 20 that existing labor legislation was not intended to govern the internal relations of owners and crews of the foreign "flags of convenience," the far-flung aid commitments of the United States will become more difficult than ever to redeem.

The chances of joining a bowling league this year are fast running out. The winter season begins a week from today in this area and the indications are that the bowlers already signed up are the lucky ones.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Pleon Yacht Club entry from Marblehead, Mass., took the lead today as the thirty-seventh Sears Cup sailing final began for the North American junior championship.

State Controller Arthur Levitt seized on the occasion of the testing of a new snow-removal machine yesterday to direct against Mayor Wagner a bitter criticism of last winter's snow removal "fiasco."
FARMVILLE, Va., Aug. 28 -- Prince Edward County has decided to continue its effort to keep its private, segregated school system alive in the face of a court order.

The bustling old lady of Union Square retailing, S. Klein on the Square, is ready to take her first step outside the confines of the New York metropolitan area. Stores will be opened in Philadelphia, Boston and Chicago, according to Philip S. Harris, president of S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., which operates the Union Square store and three branches in Newark, Yonkers and Hempstead, L.I.
Three little white whales that squeak like mice arrived at the Coney Island Aquarium yesterday after a flight from Alaska in a converted bomber.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 28 (AP) -- An emaciated tourist has survived ten weeks trying to find his way out of the sub-Arctic Alaska wilderness.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 28 -- Among the happy events of the present Edinburgh Festival has been the reappearance, after a very long interval, of Robert Atkins, the English Shakespearean director, with the Old Vic Company.
LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The British expect a Western move in the direction of negotiations on Berlin and Gremany soon, an official source said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Western Allies were reported tonight to be rapidly nearing the point of proposing broad negotiations to the Soviet Union on Berlin, Germany and Central Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Fears were raised here today that the Brazilian political crisis might interfere seriously with President Kennedy's inter-American Alliance for Progress program of economic and social development.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board report issued today attributed the crash of an American Airlines Electra at La Guardia Airport in New York last September on pilot error, but said factors beyond the captain's control might have contributed to it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Metropolitan Opera labor dispute was settled here today in the office of Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg. The opera association and the American Federation of Musicians agreed to submit the issue to "final and binding" arbitration, with Mr. Goldberg himself as arbitrator.
PARIS, Aug. 28 -- Vice President Joao Goulart of Brazil said today that he expected the "fast-moving events" in Brazil to provide a solution for the crisis in his homeland.
The election of Raymond H. Herzog and Harry Heltzer as vice presidents of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing (3M) Company was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Aug. 28 -- Premier Hayato Ikeda rejected today the Soviet contention that the United States-Japan security treaty menaced the Soviet Union and "other peace-loving states" and the suggestion that it therefore be abolished.
New Yorkers who encountered grasshoppers or a bullfrog on Park Avenue yesterday might be forgiven if they thought it was the heat. That had something to do with it.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25 -- A hard fact of Argentine life is that President Frondizi finds it necessary to issue elaborate assurances of Argentina's "Western and Christian" character.
Paul G. Whitmore has been elected vice president of Middle South Utilities, Inc. He served as an engineer with Ebasco Services, Inc., from 1929 until 1942, when he joined Middle South.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- The sarcasm can be heard at the airport and in the hotel lobbies where the tourists, draped with cameras, stand around piles of luggage impatiently waiting to begin the homeward journey.
MONROE, N.C., Aug. 28 -- A Negro leader was indicted today on charges of kidnapping a white man and his wife and holding them hostage during a race riot here yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 28 -- Brazil's military leaders declared their determination today to prevent the Leftist Vice President, Joao Goulart, from succeeding Dr. Janio Quadros as President.

The Graham-Paige Corporation reported yesterday that stockholders' equity and the share value rose for the six months ended on June 30. The special situation investment company also sought in its semiannual stockholders' letter to clarify certain details of the proposed new Madison Square Garden Center.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A sports service operator told Senate investigators today that his clients paid him up to $50 a day to relieve acute "tension and anxiety" about the outcome of horse races.

A GROUP of more than twenty informative booklets on mental health subjects is on display at the headquarters of the Brooklyn Association for Mental Health, 30 Third Avenue, Brooklyn. Copies are available free but cannot be ordered by mail

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- Communist East Germany, experiencing one of the leanest harvests since the war, has empowered local government organs to draft all persons in their jurisdiction to work in the fields.
Net income of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad in July rose to $459,592 from $405,508 in the 1960 month, the road announced yesterday.
The Police Department will stop deducting pay from a policeman for his first three days on sick report.
UNION CITY, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Chief of Police James J. Zaccaro ordered a step-up in night patrols today to combat a series of terroist shootings directed against Cuban residents here.

WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Aug. 28 -- A Nobel Prize-winning geneticist urged tonight that "banks" of human sperm be esstablished to protect the reproductive cells of members of the armed forces against radiation damage.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Negro and white delegates of the Virginia labor federation opened a state convention at the Golden Triangle Motor Hotel here today.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Eastman Kodak Company disclosed today that it had won broad legal protection against infringement on its distinctive style of packaging.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 28 -- In a closing frenzy of hitting, Chuck McKinley and Dennis Ralston overcame the clever tennis of Rafael Osuna and Antonio Palafox of Mexico today and won the national doubles championship. The scores of the final-round match at the Longwood Cricket Club were 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 2 -- 6, 13 -- 11.

This summer's hottest marketing war has been waged over cold drinks. Steel and glass manufacturers have been battling for the business of packaging the 35,000,000,000 soft drinks consumed in this country each year.
Seven concerts featuring Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic will be televised next season by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, August 28 -- The United Nations command in the Congo removed white officers from the army of secessionist Katanga Province today. The operation was apparently aimed at helping to put the province back under the rule of the Leopoldville Government.
The activation of 76,500 reservists is expected to increase requests by others to get out of reserve units, especially units that may be called up.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28 -- Foreign Minister Adolfo Mugica resigned tonight in the wake of an uproar over his public statements about a recent meeting between Maj. Ernesto Guevara, Cuba's Minister of Industry, and Richard N. Goodwin, President Kennedy's assistant for Latin American Affairs.
TRENTON, Aug. 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner proposed today that New Jersey purchase and operate the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The nation's automobile producers rolled into 1962 model production last week, leaving only Checker and Ford's Atlanta plant still producing 1961 models.

Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy gave Jimie E. White, 29-year-old actor-model, a ten-year suspended sentence yesterday for stealing and transporting to his home in Texas a $150,000 Degas pastel and two other art works.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- President Kennedy said today that celebration of Labor Day this year "again makes the vital distinction between opposing ways of life in the modern world."
NEW LONDON, N.H., Aug. 28 -- The discovery that viruses need not be present in later stages of the cancers they cause was reported here today.

NEWPORT HARBOR, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Timothea Schneider of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club, Oyster Bay, L.I., carved out a substantial lead today in the first two races of the Adams Trophy series for the women's national sailing championship.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Democrats who support aid to schools agreed today to send President Kennedy's compromise education bills to the House floor.

After slowing somewhat because of unfavorable the reordering of rebounded last week to the level of comparable 1960 week, according to reports from resident buying offices. Reordering was reported brisk with buyers generally optimistic as to the acceptance of the goods.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 28 -- Prime Minister Nehru appealed again today to Master Tara Singh of the Sikhs to give up his hunger strike, which began Aug. 15.

GENEVA, Aug. 28 -- The Soviet Union brushed aside today a new United States attempt to reopen negotiations at the nuclear test ban talks. This dashed the last hope that a separate accord still might be possible.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A case in Connecticut was cited today by Representative Frank Kowalski as "further shocking evidence" that taxpayers were paying some strikebreaking' costs.
The skeleton staff at the Metropolitan Opera House let out a cheer yesterday afternoon when the news came from Washington that there would be an opera season after all.
A panel set up to nominate members for the new city Board of Education held its first meeting yesterday. It announced that it hoped to have its list of candidates ready Sept. 12.
A lawyer added a new term to the legal lexicon in Housing Court yesterday during the explaining part of "guilty with an explanation" to forty-three housing violations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- President Kennedy praised today the first groups of Peace Corps volunteers to be assigned overseas.
Mayor Wagner announced a plan yesterday for removing the selection of judges from political control.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- (AP) The Detroit Tigers hit three home runs, one a sixth- inning grand slam by Jake Wood, to beat the Washington Senators, 7 -- 3, today. Al Kaline and Rocky Colavito hit solo homers for the Tigers in the first inning.

Philips Incandescent Lamp Works, Ltd., increased its sales 2.7 per cent in the six months ended June 30 to a record of $586,635,000 from $571,373,000 in the 1960 period. Earnings, however, declined 13.5 per cent, according to the semi-annual report of the big Netherlands company.

THE temperature of a home freezer should be checked frequently to be sure it remains at zero degrees. The quality of frozen foods stored in the freezer will deteriorate markedly from one exposure to a temperature that is much too high or to repeated exposures, even days or weeks apart, to temperatures that are only a few degrees too high.

LAST week-end two husky make sharks and a fine white marlin were hoisted onto the scales of the Deep Sea Anglers Club at Motauk, L.I., over the admiring eyes of anglers engaged in the final tournament of the season.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Federal Judge Waiter E. Hoffman ruled today that President Kennedy tfad exceeded his authority in instructing the Coast Guard to prevent a United States marshal from serving attachment papers on the Cuban freighter Bahia de Nipe.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 28 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano of West Germany said today that the Western powers would soon propose negotiations to the Soviet Union on Berlin.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Plans to orbit a monkey in the Discoverer satellite program have been abandoned, Air Force officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- The Senate passed and sent to the White today a bill that would classify airplane hijacking as piracy. The bill would make the crime a Federal offense punishable by death.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Treasury bill rates fell sharply on today's sale of the regular weekly issues. The ninety-one-day bills sold at discounts averaging 2.321 per cent, compared with 2.503 per cent on last Monday's sale. The companion issue of 182-day bills sold at discounts averaging 2.617 per cent, compared with 2.793 per cent last week.

The flags hung limply in the infield, there wasn't the faintest breeze and on all sides the comment could be heard, "Boy, it's hot." It's doubtful, however, that any one of the 25,084 thoroughbred enthusiasts at Belmont Park yesterday would have preferred to be anywhere else.

WATER MILL, L.I., Aug. 28 -- A leading night-club success ormula in Manhattan -- the combination of polite jazz, hearty food and the vivid personality of the owner -- has been applied with equal felicity to this chic South Shore resort area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- High defense officials and Adlai E. Stevenson agreed today that the United States must sincerely pursue the quest for disarmament while building up its defenses for the Berlin crisis.
President Kennedy may have been saved from assassination last December only because Mrs. Kennedy unexpectedly appeared with their two children to bid him goodbye on his way to mass.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Senator Strom Thurmond indicated today that he had tried to enlist the aid of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in eliminating what the Senator considers the muzzling of military officers.

The lights on the West Side Highway were described yesterday as in "a deplorable condition, really disgraceful for this city." The "obsolete and deteriorated" illumination on the Hutchinson River Parkway in the Bronx was called little better.

Your Aug. 22 editorial "It's Lending, Not Spending" states "At stake is the security, the prestige and the good faith of the United States on which hinges the free world's confidence in us." Even more important is the confidence of the American electorate in the good faith of its officials.
PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Tactical differences among the Allies in dealing with the Berlin crisis appeared tonight to have beer narrowed down to the date for a meeting of the Western foreign ministers.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 29 -- The New York Giants today pared their roster to the forty-three players permitted on this date by National Football League rules. The Giants released four rookies -- Francis Marriott, a quarterback; Allan Webb, a halfback; Glenfield Knight, an end, and Dale Rems, a tackle.
BUFFALO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The State Association of Letter Carriers adopted a resolution today urging legislation that would halt mail delivery in weather emergencies.

The board of directors of the Family Finance Corporation proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock and raised the dividend on the present shares. The company also announced an increase in earnings for the fiscal year ended on June 30.
The Federal Aviation Agency has awarded a transport certificate to the Lockheed JetStar, the manufacturer of the four-jet utility transport announced yesterday.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 29 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that the number of Ranger rocket launchings would be increased from five to nine.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, viewing the Democratic primary fight from the Republican sidelines, yesterday termed the two Democratic contenders for the mayoral nomination "Laurel and Hardy groping their way through a political tragedy."
VENICE, Aug. 29 -- While the big European musical festivals continue to feature opera and symphony, music of a more intimate nature is currently taking place in Venetian churches, courts and palaces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Some 92,500 disabled persons were placed in employment thorugh the state-Federal vocational rehabilitation program in the twelve months ended June 30. The figure was a record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved the creation of a Delaware River Basin Compact, but a new dispute over public vs. private power threatened to block final passage of the measure this year.
LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- Many airlines of the world, though flying higher and faster than ever before, are losing ground financially.

A HELICOPTER sightseeing flight that offers aerial views of lower Manhattan, the Statue of Liberty and ocean liners entering and leaving New York Harbor is offered daily from 11:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. by New York Airways.
Mayor Wagner supported Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy yesterday on Mr. Murphy's denial of police brutality in the Harlem incident involving a United Nations diplomat from Guinea.
GENEVA, Aug. 29 -- The fourteen-nation conference here on Laos referred to its drafting committee today a controversial issue it was unable to settle itself.

Less than twenty-four hours after he had won the national doubles championship with Chuck McKinley, Dennis Ralston was suspended yesterday and declared ineligible for amateur competition by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

Stocks moved little in either direction yesterday and volume was about the same as on Monday. The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks was up slightly, Standard Poor's index of 500 stocks was down a little and more stocks fell than rose.
FOR returning vacationers, the post-holiday period can be cruel. It is a time when freedom is glimpsed briefly only to vanish without a trace.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 29 -- The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, food merchandising giant that has long held itself aloof from newer methods of distribution, is preparing to enter discounting.

WARREN, Mich., Aug. 29 -- Two cars having a distinctive sports look were featured as Pontiac offered its 1962 preview today at the General Motors Technical Center here. They were a small convertible in the luxury compact Tempest line and a racy low-slung bucket-seat coupe in the full-size Pontiac.
PARIS, Aug. 29 -- -Six persons died today when a French Air Force jet cut a traction cable of the aerial cable lift over the Mont Blanc massif in the French Alps. Three cars fell 500 feet.
Following are excerpts from the text of Mayor Wagner's platform, issued yesterday:

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Soviet Union ordered tonight a halt in demobilization of military personnel. At the same time Moscow threatened that if war came over Berlin it was "fully resolved to put an end once and for all to the forces engendering aggression."

WILLOW GROVE, Pa., Aug. 29 (UPI) -- A Navy Reserve flier apparently decided not to take the "easy way out" just before he was killed when his jet fighter crashed into a large discount store in Willow Grove, the Navy said today.

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 29 -- A fishing party boat with fifty-two men, women and children aboard was rammed by a trawler in a fog today and sank four miles southwest of Block Island. Eight persons suffered slight injuries, but all aboard were rescued.

INWOOD, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Mrs. Pat Cici, Lido, and Mrs. Samuel Trepner, Glen Head, led a field of 100 today with a 36, 37 -- 73 gross score in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's better-ball-of-partners tournament at the Inwood Country Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -- Max Youngstein, vice president of United Artists, disagreed sharply today with a week-end statement by Jack L. Warner, who disparaged the importance of independent producers and of movie companies that do not own studios.
The National Fuel Gas Company announced yesterday the purchase of the Empire Gas and Fuel Company, Ltd., of Wellsville, N.Y., for about $3,000,000 in stock.
Assemblyman Mark Lane was struck on the head by a beer can as he rode through East Harlem last night on his way to a political rally.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CHAMONIX, France, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Angus Taylor, a vacationing mathematics professor from the University of California at Los Angeles, watched the jet cut the wire. He was at an observation point on one of the peaks.
TUCSON, Ariz., Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Rebel members of Teamsters Local 310 took steps today to break away from James R. Hoffa's International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Two officers with a score of years experience each in military intelligence work were named today to fill out the top posts in the new Joint Defense Intelligence Agency.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29 -- In a highly unusual action for India, an editor was formally reprimanded in Parliament today for a "gross breach of priviledge and contempt."

THE New York City Ballet, fresh from a fairly extended summer tour, opened a three-week engagement last night in its home theatre, the City Center, and in spite of both the calendar and the thermometer, was welcomed by a full house and an even better than usual advance sale.

A secondary offering of 214,500 common shares of Republic Aviation Corporation at $49.875 a share was completed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith, Inc., and associates yesterday. None of the proceeds are to go to the company.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Jim O'Toole, with help from Jim Maloney, defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3 -- 0, tonight and kept the Cincinnati Reds' National League lead at three and a half games.
Brighter skies lie ahead for the slumping cotton textile market, according to a report by the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.
State Controller Arthur Levitt proposed yesterday that the city and state break through the "mortgage curtain" that he said restricts the right of home ownership to many Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

Taxpayers in New York City may logically begin to wonder how much the election campaign is going to cost them. The more active candidates for Mayor have been making demands for and promises of enlarged, improved city services that are bound to be expensive in terms of a budget already in precarious balance and threatening to require new revenue sources in 1962-63.

Supreme Court Justice Morris E. Spector disqualified Representative Alfred E. Santangelo yesterday as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Manhattan. He held that Mr. Santangelo lived in the Bronx, not Manhattan.

The Futterman Corporation of New York has bought twenty-three properties in the South from Wallace Properties, Inc. The parcels, which were acquired through a Futterman subsidiary in a package deal, are valued at more than $27,000,000.
West Coast negotiators in the nation-wide maritime dispute have failed thus far to reach an agreement, according to reports last night from San Francisco.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 29 -- The Milwaukee Braves moved past San Francisco into third place tonight -- by beating the Giants, 7 -- 6, on Eddie Mathews thirteenth-inning home run.

The maritime industry expressed approval yesterday of the appointment of William G. Vale as chief of the Shipping Division of the Department of State. Mr. Vale, a State Department employe since 1950, has had considerable experience in private shipping as a freight specialist.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Jim Gabrielsen, a 19-year-old summer visitor from Athens, Ga., led the metropolitan section's qualifiers for the United States Golf Association's amateur championship today.
NEW LONDON, N.H., Aug. 29 -- Animal cancers have been produced with non-tumor viruses that are commonly carried by humans, it was disclosed here today.

The atmosphere was quieter than might have been expected at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday, following the news that the 1961-62 season would go on as scheduled, with Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg arbitrating the contract dispute.
LONDON, Aug. 29 -- A dispute between Oxford dons is always something the British enjoy and there is added relish when the clash is between two of Britain's most prominent historians.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The following joint statement was issued late today by David M. Kennedy, chairman of Continental Illinois, and Arthur T. Leonard, president of City National, following filing of a complaint by the Department of Justice to prevent merger of the two banks:

WHEN Thomas Mann's "Doctor Faustus" was published here in 1948, it was received with what might be described as muted enthusiasm. The medieval legend had become in Mann's hands the chronicle of a musician who sells his soul to the devil in return for certain creative gifts. It was an allegory of modern Germany, for in Mann's eyes she too had sold herself to evil.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Chauncey DePew Steele Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., the defending champion, and William Lurie of Hawthorne, Calif., seeded second, reached the third round of the Eastern senior grass-court tennis championship at the Huntington-Crescent Club today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Democrats steered the Administration's compromise program of aid to education through the House Education and Labor Committee today amid sharp partisan strife.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Representative James B. Utt told President Kennedy today that both the President and the Pentagon were "helping the Kremlin" to destroy anti-Communist organizations.

In this critical time the contemporary meaning and political significance of self-determination is the right of the population of every country to choose its form of government by free and unfettered elections, without any direct or indirect outside interference.

PITTSTON FARM, Me., Aug. 29 -- Northern Maine juts like a great thumb into Canada, with the Province of Quebec to the west and New Brunswick to the east. These millions of acres of forest are predominantly productive timberlands owned by paper-producing interests, but they are of great interest to sportsmen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Government filed suit today to block the merger of two Chicago banks, on the ground that it would "substantially and unreasonably" reduce commercial banking competition in the Chicago area.
TRENTON, Aug. 29 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said tonight he was "somewhat pessimistic" about a three-state meeting he will attend tomorrow on commuter problems.
ATLANTA, Aug. 29 -- Officials here took final steps today to insure that the beginning of public school desegregation in Georgia tomorrow would be peaceful.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- War Minister Odilio Denys flew here tonight from Brasilia to rally military opposition to Vice President Joao Goulart.
SEATTLE, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Harold Johnson scored a fifteen-round split decision over Eddie Cotton tonight and retained his National Boxing Association light-heavyweight crown.
The City Council grudgingly approved $2,934,000 more for the proposed baseball stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, yesterday.

NAHA, Okinawa, Aug. 29 -- On the Island of Okinawa, where jets boom through the sound barrier and nuclear weapons are stored underground, a master sergeant earnestly argued the military case for the bow and arrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Luther H. Hodges, Secretary of Commerce, said today his department was being doubly careful these days in handling applications for exports to Iron Curtain countries.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Briefs field in Federal court showed today that Moisant International Airport officials contend no law is being broken in the exclusion of Negroes from an airport dining facility.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Senate has agreed to a test vote tomorrow on extending the life of the Civil Rights Commission for two years.

Because of a sharp rise in unemployment insurance benefits in the first six months of this year, New York State employers are facing an $85,000,000 rise in unemployment insurance taxes, starting Jan. 1.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made it clear tonight that the Government was determined not to accede to the demand of Master Tara Singh, a Sikh leader, for a Punjabi-speaking state.
Mayor Wagner dropped in on a meeting of his Task Force on the Organization of Medical Services yesterday to confer a citation on its chairman, David M. Heyman.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 cents a bale off to 25 cents up yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A group of Peace Corps workers took off for Ghana tonight, bearing the responsibility of starting an American experiment.

DURING the Depression, Sam Osman did not have a choice. It was pushcart peddling on the Lower East Side or nothing, and pushcarts won because they were the only way he could make an average of $4 a day.

CAIRO, Aug. 29 -- Representatives of five African countries selected today a commander in chief for a joint African supreme command. They also named a secretary general for liaison and approved reports calling for formation of a joint military force and a common market.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- Chancellor Adenauer has written to President Kennedy to express his grave fear that any further reverses to the Western Allies' position in Berlin may result in a neutralist mood in West Germany.
The City Purchase Department reported yesterday that it had received identical low bids from three drug concerns for a vitally needed supply of antibiotics.
A substantial capital gain enabled the Hilton Hotels Corporation to lift the net income in the first half of this year to $11,698,222 from $6,561,175 in the 1960 period.

HAVANA, Aug. 2 -- Thirty-five hundred managers of state farms, cooperatives and factories prepared today to tell the Cuban people that they would have to work harder and, at least temporarily, eat less.
Berlo's return to competition after an absence of almost a year was a disappointment to the favorite players among the 18,006 customers at Belmont Park yesterday.
A small airline and a tiny island are reaping benefits from a modest advertising campaign with an unusual approach.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Representative H.R. Gross, Republican of Iowa, says that Pogo should stick to lecturing Albert the alligator and stay out of Government service.
Here and abroad people have been flocking to summer music festivals. The popularity of this delightful blending of nature with art is encouraging in an age of billboards and bop.
LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Price movements in the stock market here continued irregular and small today. But, for the first time in many days, gains out-numbered declines in the main industrial sections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The House passed today by 394 to 0 a bill increasing the amount of readjustment pay for long-time reserve members of the military services released involuntarily from active duty. The measures now goes to the Senate.
SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 29 -- The Secretary of Defense called upon the American Municipal Association today to help undertake an immediate Civil Defense survey.

The Metropolitan Opera's 1961-62 season is assured, thanks to President Kennedy, who took a vital interest in the labor dispute; to Secretary Goldberg, who brought the musicians and the opera management together, and to both sides for agreeing to the drastic solution of arbitration by an outsider.

ELISABETHVILLE, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga charged today that United Nations soldiers had "arrested and manhandled" him five times yesterday while disarming his European army officers.
A landlord was fined $2,000 in Housing Court yesterday for 128 health and building violations in three tenements on East Ninety-eighth Street.
A LOT more than just baloney is encompassed by the term sausage. Even the most modestly stocked grocery store displays enough different kinds of sausage to baffle all but the most knowing shopper.

The Watkins Glen (N.Y.) promoters, having secured the Grand Prix of the United States for Oct. 8, face one of the busiest preparation periods of their careers. There are improvements that must be made on the 2.3-mile course and in the paddock and spectator sections.

A total of 1,184 persons were injured in 776 car accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was a decrease of seventeen from the 1,201 hurt in the like 1960 period.
