PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Vice President Joao Goulart of Brazil declared here today that he would return to Brazil "to fulfill the constitutional duties imposed on" him by the people of Brazil.
BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- Troops of the United States and British garrisons here moved tanks, armored cars and infantry units along busy West Berlin streets in training exercises today.
Vito P. Battista, the United Taxpayers party candidate for Mayor, appealed last night for volunteers to help fight "socialism in city hall."
Potato and Brazilian coffee futures were actively traded on New York commodity exchanges yesterday in otherwise quiet sessions.
A simple and accurate Chemical test to help distinguish between a long-standing chronic disease and a sudden infectious process was described here yesterday.
A 4 1/2-year-old girl lost her right arm yesterday when she fell from between two subway cars to the tracks. A quick-acting transit policeman saved her from immediate death.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Western foreign ministers will probably meet here in about two weeks in an effort aimed at breaking a double impasse over Berlin -- one with the Russians and one among themselves.
COOL weather will soon be at hand, and six tools and a simple technique will help in pressing wool clothes that have been stored for the summer.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax raised the Los Angeles Dodgers' pennant hopes today by pitching a two-hitter for a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

A new set-up is contemplated for the 1962 summer season of the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy at Stratford, Conn. That much was acknowledged yesterday by Lawrence Langner, chairman of the board.
Thunderstorms, driven by winds up to eighty miles an hour, lashed central Westchester, southwestern Connecticut and Nassau County yesterday.

TUNIS, Aug. 29 -- The day after the announcement that Benyoussef Ben Khedda had supplanted Ferhat Abbas as Premier of the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government, a well-informed Algerian here said with a broad smile: "The wind is blowing from the East."

NEW DELHI, India, Aug 29 -- The state-owned Italian oil company agreed tonight to extend to India technical assistance and credits equivalent to $100,000,000 for the development of the Government petroleum industry.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 29 (UPI) -- A delegation of the Indiana Farmers Union threw the American Soybean Association into a parliamentary uproar today and got a court order halting the association's annual election of officers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Senator Strom Thurmond, Democrat of South Carolina, said today that an investigation into his charges that the Defense Department had gagged military officers would startle the public.
BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- The East German regime has stepped up its campaign of pressure on dissident elements, including officials of the ruling Socialist Unity (Communist) party.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 -- The Soviet Union called upon the United Nations General Assembly today to establish a deadline for the abolition of colonialism.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The United States started its venture in foreign currency holdings last March with a purchase of almost $25,000,000 of Swiss francs. It has bought more, of various currencies, and sold some, but precise details have not been made public.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The "gambler's priest" prepared today for the quiet of a Midwestern town after a farewell party last night.

The Glickman Corporation, which plans a sixteen-story apartment house at 1056-64 Lexington Avenue, northwest corner of Seventy-fifth Street, has contracted to buy the adjoining parcel at 1066 Lexington Avenue to serve as a light protector for the apartments.

Sales of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation for its first fiscal quarter, ended on July 31, increased to $117,821,515 from the adjusted volume of $114,639,804 for the year-earlier period, John R. Kimberly, chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday at Neenah, Wis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Administration officials viewed today Premier Fidel Castro's advice to Brazilians to wage guerrilla war against the army as outright intervention in the affairs of Brazil.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 29 -- The liberal bloc at the National Student Association convention was pressing tonight for quick passage of a resolution assailing a Miami, Fla., draft board for denying a deferment to a Peace Corps trainee.
The wife of a prominent psychiatrist, carrying her 2-year-old daughter in her arms, was fatally shot last night by a woman who had been a patient of her husband's.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation is initiating a campaign to reduce the number of bank robberies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The development of a technique that might help speed the production of live-virus poliomyelitis vaccine was reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Senate passage today sent to President Kennedy legislation to strengthen the reserves of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

Mrs. Robert Howe Baldwin and Col. Edward P.F., Eagan, co-chairmen of the annual Dinner of Champions, have announced the appointment of a dinner committee for the event. Thomas F. Wands has been appointed assistant to the vice president in charge of factories for Sears, Roebuck Co. He had been factory controller.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- More Americans held jobs this month than in any August in history, but not enough to reduce an unemployment rate that has hovered near 7 per cent for nine consecutive months.

San Diego, Calif., borrowed $20,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public school construction.

Glenmore Distillery Company of Louisville, Ky., filed yesterday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed public offering of $7,500,000 of convertible subordinated debentures due 1981.

Many of the abuses from which these workers suffer are a result of exploitation by those who recruit, transport and get employment for them on their seasonal migrations -- abuses that the standards required by Federal registration would curb.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad went deeper into the red last month, trustees of the road disclosed yesterday.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 29 -- A European punched G. Mennen Williams on the jaw at Lusaka Airport last night.

NOT only did Warren Spahn achieve the 300th victory of his gaudy pitching career, but he whipped right past it to the 304 mark without hesitation. When Robert Moses Grove reached 300, however, he stopped. He could not win another. That was twenty years ago and no one was to join him in the Three Hundred Club until Spahnie made it.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 29 -- Gen. Cemal Gursel, chief of the ruling Turkish military junta, has been selected as the Presidential candidate of the recently founded New Turkey party.
We should like to take a moment from your busy schedule to compliment you upon the recent editorial appearing in your fine newspaper which relates to the control of pesticides.

Paperboard production in the nation totaled a record of 341,687 tons in the week ended Aug. 26, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. The previous high was 336,991 tons in the week ended Aug. 8, 1959.

VENICE, Aug. 29 -- The Soviet Union's last-minute feature entry, "Peace to Whoever Enters," last night became the surprise hit of the Venice Film Festival, which is already being called the best in years.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 29 -- The possibility of increasing Communist penetration in North Africa is perplexing the representatives of uncommitted nations who will meet here Friday.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- The French Government sought today to enlist the general public in defense of its economic and financial program, under attack by farmers and other special interests with Parliamentary support.
A campaign to raise $225,000 to start a vigorous program for the Puerto Rican Board of Guardians to combat delinquency and to aid the city's Puerto Ricans was announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox capitalized on two Detroit errors tonight for a 4 -- 3 victory over the Tigers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Victoria Palmer, a 16-year-old Phoenix (Ariz.) player, won the United States girls' lawn tennis singles championship today, defeating top-seeded Billie Jean Moffitt, 17, Long Beach, Calif., 5 -- 7, 6 -- 1, 16 -- 4.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Selling pressure continued almost without let-up today and the grain futures market finished generally down for the second consecutive day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Atomic Energy Commissioner Robert E. Wilson said today that a nuclear-powered television satellite transmitting directly to television sets around the world appeared possible in this decade.
Behind-the-scenes efforts to muster community support have been quietly started by several members of the outgoing Board of Education who are eager to be reappointed.
THE throw-in is classed among the difficult or postgraduate plays of bridge, and probably with justice, for the average player seldom executes a throw-in and has a right to feel proud when he does.

A baseball expert who never has watched a game or read a box score was confronted yesterday with one of the year's most pressing questions: Will Roger Maris or Mickey Mantle break Babe Ruth's record of sixty home runs for a season?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians scored six runs in the seventh inning, five unearned, and handed the Washington Senators a 6-4 defeat, their eleventh straight, tonight.

The New York Central Railroad petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to reconsider and to remove its order denying the carrier the right to place an embargo on its less-than-carload freight services.

The House of Heide, Inc., a restaurant concern, has leased ground-floor space with a frontage of forty-five feet in the Forty-third Street side of the new Pfizer Building, which is at the northwest corner of Second Avenue and Forty-second Street running through the block to Forty-third Street.

In July, 1863, Brig. Gen. John Hunt Morgan, commanding 2,460 Confederate cavalrymen, crossed the Cumberland River and pushed North. The group's activities in burning bridges, wrecking railroads and disorganizing the Union forces are told by Allan Keller in "Morgan's Raid."

MONROE, N.C., Aug. 29 -- The police here arrested a New Yorker tonight and charged him with kidnapping for his part in the seizure of a white couple as hostages during a scene of racial violence last Sunday.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29 -- King Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva of Nepal met Indian and foreign newsmen here today in apparent attempt to clarify misunderstandings about his regime.

The equivalent of $39,000,O00 will be made available to Colombia for a highway improvement and maintenance program by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Work Bank) and its affiliate, the International Development Association, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Kennedy adopted today a position of interested neutrality on the Brazilian crisis and criticized by inference the efforts of Premier Fidel Castro to influence developments in Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Kennedy required only one word today to declare his neutrality in New York City's hot Democratic primary.

Bar association rating of judicial candidates for professional competence is doing much to assure high standards of performance on the bench. WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Farm product prices rose nearly 2 per cent between mid-July and mid-August, the Department of Agriculture reported today. Higher prices for beef cattle, milk, hogs, cotton and wheat accounted for most of the increase.
Six persons were hurt slightly and a police bullet narrowly missed a youth seated in a car during the chase of a hold-up man in Times Square about 5 P.M. yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 30 -- The Premier of Indonesia's rebel government, Dr. Sjafruddin Prawiranegara, and four rebel Cabinet ministers capitulated Monday, bringing to an end the three-year-old revolt against the Jakarta Government, an army spokesman announced today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Administration made its first public effort today to head off the possibility of a steel price increase this fall.
ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- Governor Rockefeller appointed a special investigating commission today to make a broad study of public welfare in the state.

The Wolf Corporation, a realty investment concern, has contracted to buy three properties on Long Island for more than $1,000,000 in cash. The parcels, all of which contain Friendly Frost stores, appliance discount centers, were sold by Sol Goldman. Julius Reiner was the broker.
PARIS, Aug. 30 -- The troubled world political situation is continuing to depress European stock markets.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--The House of Representatives killed the Administration's compromise school construction bill today, 242 to 169.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that his office had obtained a court order against a lawn spray equipment company for false advertising.
QUONSET POINT, R.I., Aug. 30 -- Navy's football squad, 102 men strong, is encamped at the Naval Air Station here to prepare, physically and academically, for the forthcoming campaign.
TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 31 -- The Japanese Government expressed regret today over the decision of the Soviet Government to resume nuclear tests.
Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman, called last night for State Controller Arthur Levitt's nomination for Mayor in the primary next Thursday.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- A United States Army car with a captain and three sergeants was held in East Berlin for seventy-five minutes today. The incident brought Ameri can tanks rumbling to the border line, their guns pointing down the street from West Berlin into Communist territory.
Vice President Joao Goulart of Brazil flew here from Paris yesterday and said he was planning to return home "as soon as possible" to assume the Presidency vacated by Dr. Janio Quadros.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Kennedy is barely keeping ahead of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower in the frequency of his news conferences.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 30 -- Two Hindu ascetics were expected tonight to end their hunger strikes tomorrow. No end was in sight, however, for the fast of Master Tara Singh, 76-year-old Sikh leader.
TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 30 (AP.) -- Ernest Hemingway's widow shipped several boxes of manuscripts to New York today, but said no decision had been made on whether any would be published.

The Kayser-Roth Corporation had record profits in fiscal 1961, Chester H. Roth, president of the apparel manufacturer, reported yesterday in the annual statement for the twelve months to June 30. Sales and earnings set new highs for the third successive year, he noted.

The Atlantic Improvement Corporation, developer and builder of the proposed residential community at the Breezy Point section of the Rockaways, Queens, intends to offer to the public 150,000 common shares. A registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday said that the shares would be offered through Bear, Stearns Co. and associates at a price of $13.50 a share when the shares were cleared for offering.

A recently published book on dog training for the upland bird hunter is causing plenty of comment. According to its author, Richard A. The Carrier Corporation reported yesterday a net profit of $6,075,000 for the nine months ended on July 31, equal to $2.66 a share. This compared with $3,052,000, or $1.18 a share, cleared a year earlier when two strikes adversely affected results.
The Department of Defense held its first nation-wide closed-circuit telephone auction of surplus property yesterday.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved steadily forward all day yesterday and ended with substantial gains for rails, motors, chemicals and pharmaceuticals.

Production of electric power dipped to 15,491,000,000 kilowatt-hours last week from 15,665,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This figure compares with 15,018,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the 1960 period.

The Metropolitan Opera Association may seek government subsidies to save it from "the threat of eventual bankruptcy," Anthony A. Bliss, president of the association, said yesterday.
Seven highway bottlenecks will add to normal congestion in leaving and entering the New York area over Labor Day.

In a compromise that goes a long way toward putting foreign aid on a more businesslike basis and therewith strengthening our defenses against the Communist challenge, the Senate-House conference committee has agreed on what is in effect a five-year free-world development program analogous to the Marshall Plan for Europe.
The Government has embarked on a campaign to convince maritime unions that the "flags of convenience" issue must be removed from the labor bargaining table.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Thirty-two Senators of both parties joined at a luncheon today to salute Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff for his fifty-five years in the communications field.
WARSAW, Aug. 30 -- Poland is stepping up its state of military preparedness, presumably in reaction to the tense confrontation of East and West in Berlin.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Stockholders of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation approved today a merger of the companies.
The City Housing Authority reported yesterday that more than 200,000 persons participated in its community center programs during 1960.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
NEWPORT, Ky., Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Gov. Bert T. Combs ordered the State Police into Newport today to help a grand jury investigate gambling, vice and alleged pay-offs.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday that if any of his three rivals for Mayor was elected this November New Yorkers might be subjected to taxes on payrolls and on overnight street parking.

Two of three drug concerns that recently submitted identical low bids to supply the city's Purchase Department with an antibiotic declared yesterday that the identity of bids was coincidental, not collusive. The concerns were Charles Pfizer Co., Inc., and American Cyanamid.
MILFORD, Mich., Aug. 30 -- A new line of smaller cars to meet basic transportation needs was shown today by the Chevrolet Division of General Motors.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 30 -- Harlan Dean, a trotting colt whose career was jeopardized by assorted muscular aches and pains earlier in the season, today made short shrift of the thirty-sixth Hambletonian -- and in world-record time, too.

The recent management changes at the Chrysler Corporation were not a stop-gap arrangement, George H. Love reported to the company's stockholders yesterday. Mr. Love headed a directors' committee that drafted the changes and is chairman of a new executive committee.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 30 -- Eugene Francisco will be discharged on Friday from the Fairfield State Jail here with the hope of continuing an art career that started, in a small way, behind the bars.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Seven of the eight seeded players in the men's national singles championship, which begins Friday, were among the signers today of a telegram petitioning the United States Lawn Tennis Association to permit Dennis Ralston to compete in the tournament at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 30 (AP) -- John Sellers scored his fourth victory of the day when he rode Townsend B. Martin's Sunrise County to a length-and-a-quarter victory in the $25,050 Seashore Stakes today.
Following is a transcript of President Kennedy's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:
State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that Mayor Wagner had a lack of fiscal judgment that was leading toward a city income tax.
Nineteen professional engineering societies and their 650 employes will start moving about a mile across midtown Manhattan today. They will finish the move tomorrow night.

An independent committee headed by former Secretary of State Christian A. Herter will estimate the Government's manpower needs in foreign affairs for the next decade. It will also suggest ways of recruiting and training the right persons for the job.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Aug. 30 -- This city will integrate public schools for the first time next week when fourteen Negro children enter formerly white schools.
FOUR Queens children have made friends where many adults would hesitate to go in a guided tour de force of New York City.
RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 30 -- The dominant party in Morocco's Government charged today that Moroccan Jews were abandoning their Moroccan character and national responsibilities to serve Zionism.
A broadening demand for high-grade corporate bonds enlivened the market for prime debt securities yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Kennedy announced today that Gen. Lucius D. Clay would return to West Berlin next month as his personal representative to enhance the nation's "resources of judgment and action" in that city.
" Come on Strong," the new romantic comedy by Garson Kanin, will bring Van Johnson back to Broadway after an absence of twenty-one years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The United States declared itself freed tonight from its promise not to conduct nuclear tests, but it withheld any definite decision on the resumption of testing.
DETROIT, Aug. 30 -- Walter P. Reuther turned to the General Motors Corporation bargaining table today in an effort to wring major concessions from the nation's largest automobile manufacturer.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles crushed the Los Angeles Angels tonight, 11 -- 4, and helped set an American League season record for home runs in one park -- 204.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The twenty-five-nation African group at the United Nations expressed deep concern today over "recurrent and serious incidents" in the United States in which, it charged, African diplomats have been the victims.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation is skipping the payment of cash dividends for the first time, as a result of unprofitable production activities, it was disclosed last night. Instead, the company has decided upon a 2 per cent semi-annual stock dividend, payable on Oct. 3 to holders of record of Sept. 11.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- A plea by Kenneth Kaunda, leader of the United National Independence party of Northern Rhodesia, for a special inquiry into the recent disturbances in that area has been rejected by Prime Minister Macmillan.

One of the largest offices of the New York Public Library loses its chief to retirement today. She is Lucille T. Mathews. As head registrar, she controls the records of nearly 1,000,000 library members.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 30 -- The fourteenth annual convention of the United States National Student Association, ended on a moderate note today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 -- The United States District Court today stopped 11,000 Pennsylvania Railroad maintenance workers from going on strike at midnight tomorrow.

The acquisition of the Indiana State Bottling Works, Inc., which operates under the name of Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company of East Chicago, Ind., by Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers, Inc., was announced yesterday.
CAMAGUEY, Cuba, Aug. 31 -- Twenty-acre squares of newly ployed land, all but lost in the endless green sweep of sugar fields and pasture, symbolize Cuba's efforts to solve her critical food problem.

Metropolitan Syndications, Inc., Edward Gettinger, president, has contracted to buy four buildings with a total of 915 apartments in this city -- and in Trenton, N.J. The purchase price is $11,258,500, to be made up of $3,075,000 in cash and $8,183,500 in mortgages.
WHETHER it be in this country, in England or in Australia, the housewife who asks her grocer for "cheese" will almost certainly receive Cheddar.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- A double steal with Lee Maye sliding home safely gave Milwaukee a 2-1 victory over Los Angeles tonight, putting the Dodgers three games out of first place and the Braves alone in third place in the National League pennant race.
Speed limits are being raised five to ten miles an hour to "more reasonable and realistic" levels on the Prospect Expressway in Brooklyn and the Van wyck and Long Island Expressways in Queens.

Wall Street had a quiet day yesterday, despite announcements on the testing of nuclear weapons, continuing international crises and a pocketful of mixed industrial news. Volume was lower in expectation of the coming three-day week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The National Association for Advancement of Colored People requested the Attorney General's office today to provide protection to Negroes seeking to register and vote in Amite County, Miss.

The cement industry's first price increase since early 1960 was announced yesterday by the Alpha Portland Cement Company and the Ideal Cement Company. A few other manufacturers said they were seriously considering price increases.
PARIS, Aug. 31 -- The Soviet Union's decision to resume nuclear testing is viewed here as the Kremlin's latest bet in the dangerous East-West poker game over Berlin.

Four major New York City banks have sold to institutional investors their 60 per cent interest in the Discount Corporation of New York. The banks explained that this interest represented a "larger concentration of ownership than was originally contemplated."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Stan Musial tripled high off the right-field wall in the ninth inning to bat in the winning run as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 2 -- 1, tonight.

Port Authority patrolmen and employes of National Airlines searched passengers' hand luggage last night at New York International Airport after receiving a tip that an attempt would be made to seize a jet liner.

Keystone Low-Priced Common Stock Fund S-4 reported yesterday that it completed its fiscal year on July 31 with new highs in almost all phases of its operations. The annual report was sent to a record of 82,194 shareholders, or 34 per cent more than a year ago. More than 21,000 new accounts were opened in the year.
Mayor Wagner shifted his primary-election attack yesterday from New York City's Democratic county leaders to Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman.

In an action that shocks the world and edges it closer to the brink of atomic holocaust, Premier Khrushchev announces that the Soviets are resuming nuclear testing to produce monstrous super-bombs capable of being dropped at any point on the globe from space.
An earthquake in South America gave rise yesterday to reports that a nuclear explosion might have been set off in the Soviet-China border area in Central Asia.
Enlistments in the armed services in the Greater New York area have shown a marked increase for August.
FORECASTING the weather for the next day, the man said that we should expect "shower activity." "Rain shower activity," in fact, as distinguished from showers of meteors.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 31 -- Mickey Mantle today continued his effort to climb back into the home run derby by hitting his forty-eighth homer of the year. Roger Maris, leading with fifty-one, again drew a blank.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The chief editor of the Soviet Union's new Yiddish language literary magazine said today that the publication's editorial policy would be anti-religious.

Two five-story brownstone houses at 147-49 West Seventy-second Street have been purchased for cash by Dr. Jose Saez. The property, with a plot 31 by 100 feet, is assessed at $113,000. It was sold through Joseph Hidalgo Sons, Inc. broker.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Nearly 100,000 persons turned out to take oral vaccine today, bringing the over-all total to 393,075 persons who have responded to a three-day drive to halt polio outbreak in three central New York counties.
Judging by the little business that was done, the bond houses of the financial district were already at work yesterday "discounting" the long Labor Day holiday week-end.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Eleven unions representing the bulk of the nation's railroad workers demanded today a 25-cent-an-hour raise by Nov. 1.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 -- The sharpening conflict between the Western and Communist blocs could lead to a more stable world without resort to war, a sociologist said today.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in tile stocks from which the averages are computed, the comb/ned trading in both classes of issues, as well as the total daily transactions for week and month:
The Citizens Union, a non-partisan organization, expressed a preference yesterday for seven candidates in primary contests for nominations for the City Council.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 31 -- The Hambletonian, which annually adds as much class, color and tradition to harness racing as the Kentucky Derby contributes to the thoroughbred sport, will do business at the same old stand -- the Du Quoin State Fair Grounds -- through 1963.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Strong doubts arose today over prospects for revival of President Kennedy's school-aid program next year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Department store sales in the nation last week rose 6 per cent above the year-ago level.

Senate passage of the Administration's Manpower Development and Training Bill is a big step forward in dealing with the "hard-core" unemployment problem -- finding work for those who have lost their jobs because the jobs themselves have been eliminated by new methods and machines.
HONG KONG, Aug. 31 -- Communist China issued a statement tonight expressing resolute support for the Soviet Union's decision to resume nuclear tests.
Some of the largest stockholders in Joseph Bancroft Sons Company, textile finishing concern, have agreed to sell their shares to Indian Head Mills, Inc.
THE annual Knickerbocker Championships will begin today at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- An elaborate list of all source material on American history that is now available in tile British Isles was published here today.

Labor Day is at hand and this is the traditional time of the year for examining the outlook for the economy during the important cool-weather months -- the period when business conditions should be at their strongest.

SEPTEMBER may be here, complete with its "r," but the oyster is ignoring the implication. Not for a walrus, a carpenter nor any other oyster eater will he leave the cool of the oyster bed for another few weeks.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 31 -- United States athletes, led by New York University stars, won five gold medals and broke three meet records today in the second day of track and field competition at the Maccabiah Games.
Community leaders with the most influence and leaders to whom mentally ill people often turn may be the least knowledgable about the problem, a study of prominent New Yorkers has found.

We wish to make a formal protest against the completely distorted and erroneous article from The New York Times correspondent in Tunis, reporting on the final communique issued by the National Council of the Algerian Revolution (C.N.R.A.), in The Times of Aug. 29.
" Mr. President" is the title of the new musical that is being written to Irving Berlin's songs by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- An anonymous letter demanded today a 140,000 ($392,000) "ransom" for the return of the stolen Goya portrait of the Duke of Wellington.
Ralph C. Gross will take office today as executive vice president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics pounded four Los Angeles pitchers for nineteen hits, including four home runs, and whipped the Angels, 17 -- 3, in the first game of it double-header tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The motives that prompted the Soviet decision to resume nuclear testing preoccupied and in some measure puzzled Washington today.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 31 (AP) -- United States District Judge Hobart Grooms has turned down a motion by attorneys for The New York Times Company to dismiss seven libel suits.

The Brazilian military officers who defied their own Constitution and the will of the voters in refusing to let Joao Goulart take the Presidency have now brought their nation to the verge of civil war. Only a belated acceptance of legality on their part can now save Brazil from disaster. With Senhor Goulart now approaching his country, there is no time to lose.

The American public is apparently being rushed by propaganda into accepting as essential to our interest a foreign aid plan that will tragically fail to accomplish its stated purpose: to raise appreciably the standard of living of the masses of Latin America.

ROVING reporters in Florida last spring wasted little time in the Lakeland camp of the Detroit Tigers. The natural presumption was that they weren't going anywhere. So why bother? Logic demanded that far more attention be paid to such supposedly valid challengers to Yankee supremacy as the Baltimore Orioles and the Chicago White Sox, plus a distant look at the Cleveland Indians in their Arizona hideout.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Public Health Service granted $5,022,803 today to eight institutions for cancer research programs.

In answering a letter by Eric Kahler and others, Sidney Hook, in your issue of Aug. 28, argues for the necessity for hanging on to West Berlin on the somewhat dubious ground that "whoever controls Berlin controls Germany, and whoever controls Germany will soon control Western Europe."
The merger of Macfadden Publication, Inc., Bartell Broadcasting Corporation and Process Lithographers, Inc., into a single publishing, broadcasting and printing enterprise was proposed yesterday.
DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers came out of a brief slump today as Billy Bruton and Norm Cash crashed two-run homers in an 8-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Senate and the House of Representatives passed the foreign aid bill today and sent it to the White House.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Pentagon atomic specialists said today that a twenty-megaton bomb exploded on the ground would devastate an area of about six miles around the point of explosion, killing everyone. They said about half the population would die and damage would be heavy in an area reaching out for about six to twelve miles.
The men's and women's national amateur tennis championships begin today at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

The Associated Press announced yesterday it would automate its tabulation of stock market tables, providing greater speed and accuracy in the assembly of quotations and their transmission to newspapers.

IT is not always necessary to hire a brass band in order to let the world know of a new business enterprise. D.R. International, Inc., has scheduled its grand opening for early fall, but since installing itself at 866 Lexington Avenue (corner of Sixty-fifth Street) it has won a faithful clientele interested in distinctive, contemporary furniture, accessories and fashions.
Brazilian coffee and potato futures again dominated trading yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges in an otherwise quiet day.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Nineteen-year-old Valeri Brumel of the Soviet Union broke his pending world record in the high jump today with a leap of 7 feet 4 1/2 inches in the world student games.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- President Kennedy decided today against taking any action now toward cutting duties on imported watch parts.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 31 -- The Studebaker-Packard Corporation nas lengthened most of its Lark compact cars to medium-size status in an effort to compete with its more affluent rivals.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 -- Connecticut tax authorities have instructed 33,000 Connecticut employers to prepare to withhold New York income taxes from New Yorkers who work for them or else supply information about such persons.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Friday, Sept. 1 -- Brazilian troops and ships were on the move today to put down forces supporting Vice President Joao Goulart in the dispute over the Brazilian Presidency.

For several years now, television station representatives have been watching the growth of participation sponsorship of network programs with mounting alarm. This fall, the representatives' anxiety is reaching near-epidemic proportions.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is studying the question of whether to discontinue telecasts of major league baseball games on Saturday and Sunday afternoons.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Western Allies barred two airlines today from making special passenger flights through the air corridors to Berlin en route to the Leipzig trade fair in East Germany.
The Government's fear that maritime union pressure will drive urgently needed ship tonnage from United States control is well founded, according to a study of shipping records.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Aug. 31 -- The town responded today to a charge by a Negro clergyman that proposed changes in the municipal development plan were aimed at systematically driving Negroes from the community.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The United States raised the possibility today that inter-American sanctions against the Dominican Republic might be partially lifted if "definite beneficial changes" are found there by an investigating committee.
Net income of the Union Pacific Railroad in July rose to $4,689,764 from $4,158,747 in the 1960 month, the road announced yesterday.
Robert W. Hubner has been appointed director of marketing services for the International Business Machines Corporation. He had been executive assistant to the chairman.
Wall Streeters, much like newspaper financial writers, have an unusual position in the grandstand for watching the parade of business, finance, trade, commerce and industry.

TUNIS, Aug. 31 -- An official Algerian nationalist spokesman emphasized here today the importance of support for the nationalist cause from the Soviet bloc and Yugoslavia, as well as from the countries, Communist or not, of Africa, Asia and Latin America.

On Aug. 18 you published a letter by William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York in which he charged that it would be "extremely dangerous to our entire transportation system and economy" to provide highway, bridge and tunnel revenues to aid commuter railroads in the New York metropolitan area.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Industrial share groups remained irregular in the stock market here today, with more small losses than gains.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- After starting in a steady to firm range for the first time this week, the grain futures market ran into another accumulation of selling today and closed with losses in most contracts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- An alert United States monitor at a remote Middle Eastern listening post fished a significant paragraph out of reams of insignificant Soviet news reports yesterday. That paragraph gave Washington its first warning that Moscow had decided to resume tests of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- DeLesseps S. Morrison was accused today of having accepted contributions from a racketeer and a brothel operator in a campaign for Mayor of New Orleans.
Two leading American foes of nuclear testing, Dr. Linus Pauling and Norman Cousins, condemned the Soviet decision to resume tests, calling it a threat to peace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee will question Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara before deciding whether to investigate charges that speech-making military men have been muzzled by Pentagon policies.
Mrs. Arthur Levitt made her debut as a political speaker yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- President Kennedy saluted today the fiftieth anniversary of the workmen's compensation law.
Bonds redeemed before maturity in August dropped to their lowest level since November, 1960.
Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange showed a small gain in August. Trading was the largest for any August since 1932 and the largest monthly trading since last May.
State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that campaign workers for Mayor Wagner had injected anti-Semitism into the Democratic primary fight.
BERLIN, Aug. 31 (AP) -- West Berliners have opened their homes and hearts to the United States soldiers rushed to this encircled city to defend it against Communist take-over.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The Air Force said today that no decision had been made when to attempt recovery of the capsule of Discoverer XXIX.

If the Transit Authority's $226,000,000 subway-car-buying program is not financed outside the city's debt limit, progress will be retarded on other important projects in 1962 and the next five years, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- An examiner for the National Labor Relations Board recommended an order today that would eliminate "hot cargo" clauses from Teamster union contracts with tracking firms.

THE chief feature of last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center was "Electronics," George Balanchine's experiment of last season with choreography to a musical score created entirely by electronic means.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy late today notified Representative Melvin R. Laird that an investigation would be made of allegations against Paul Corbin, special assistant to the Democratic National Chairman.

Earnings of Sears, Roebuck Co., in the six months ended on July 31 were the second highest for any comparable period in the company's history, the company reported yesterday. Sales established a new record for the period, it said.

Little by little the secrets of 1962 lines of small pleasure boats are being unfolded. On every side there are new concepts, new horizons of utility and luxury, revolutionary new devices to facilitate shallow-water cruising.
Twentieth Century-Fox has "indefinitely postponed" its contemplated multimillion dollar production of "The Greatest Story Ever Told," Spyros P. Skouras, president of the company, said last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- The acting career of George Chandler, president of the Screen Actors Guild, illustrates the similarities and differences between the early days of Hollywood moviemaking and the Hollywood-manufactured television series today.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System were unchanged at $37,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $15,000,000 to $612,000,000.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ATLANTA, Aug. 31 -- Education officials took steps today toward relaxing precautions in four public high schools as the second day of desegregated classes passed without incident.
Sections of the Queens police headquarters were evacuated yesterday afternoon after a woman brought in what appeared to be a homemade bomb.

MOUNT KINEO, Me., Aug. 31 -- Flying over, walking, boating and driving through an estimated 7,000,000 acres of Maine's north-country forest land is an experience of the first magnitude. The desolate, uninhabited area stretches to the Canadian border and the only transportation is through the air by small float planes or over the private, gravel roads of paper companies.
The National Labor Relations Board has found the Consolidated Edison Company guilty of unfair labor practice.

S. Hazard Gillespie, who will head the special investigation into public welfare in the state, conferred yesterday by telephone with several of the other members of the commission that Governor Rockefeller appointed Wednesday.

NEWPORT, Ky., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Campbell County Grand Jury brought felony indictments against fifteen men today. It accused them of operating premises for betting on horse races, in an inquiry into vice in northern Kentucky.
BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- President Heinrich Luebke of West Germany emphasized in a television address to all Germans today that the West was closely linked to the fate of the city.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The House passed today a bill to permit stand-up drinking at Washington bars.

Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley told twenty visiting traffic experts yesterday that the conversion of various avenues here to one-way operation had resulted in marked benefits to motorists and pedestrians.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 31 -- The Government expressed its regret and concern" today over the Soviet Union's announcement that it would resume nuclear testing.
Joseph T. Sharkey responded yesterday to Mayor Wagner's demand for his removal as majority leader of the City Council by calling the Mayor "a bare-faced liar" devoid of personal decency.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 31 -- Belgian public opinion, incensed over the United Nations' m removal of. European officers from the Katanga Army Monday, is convinced that the action violated an understanding betweeu Foreign Minister PaulHenri Spaak and Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie and Mrs. Henry B. Kirkland of Apawamis scored 38, 34 -- 72 ill alternate-stroke competition at Westchester Hills Golf Club today to win the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association tournament by five shots.
The value of new bonds offered publicly in August was the smallest since November, 1958, and below the levels of the two preceding Augusts. The value of new equity offerings also fell last month.
An off-duty patrolman was attacked early yesterday after he had ordered a group of men in a tavern in the Bronx to stop making so much noise.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Asian and African delegations have decided to complain to Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjold against incidents in recent months "involving racial discrimination" against African and Asian diplomats.

Mrs. June McKnight's Chufquen survived a harsh landing on the eleventh jump and went on to win the $11,275 Harbor Hill Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. He covered the twelve-jump course of about two and an eighth miles in the record-breaking time of 3:55 2/5.

Bache Co., stock brokers, have leased 5,000 square feet in the new office building at 770 Lexington Avenue, northwest corner of Sixtieth Street, from the Jarcho-Landau Corporation, the builder and owner. James D. Landauer Associates was realty consultant to the lessees.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 31 -- The Nigerian Government was concerned today over the Soviet Union's decision to resume nuclear testing.

TUNIS, Aug. 31 -- Algerian rebel and Tunisian political observers said here today that they believed the Soviet decision to resume nuclear testing would produce an antagonistic reaction in Belgrade, where their regimes' leaders were preparing for the neutralists' conference.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended yesterday that the certificate of Aero-lineas Argentinas to serve New York be renewed for three years -- without the safeguards against rate-cutting proposed by Pan American World Airways.

LAFAYETTTE, Ind., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Dr. Charles E. Elton of Oxford University, known to biologists as the father of population research, received the Eminent Ecologist Award of the Ecological Society of America last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Speaker Sam Rayburn, who has pride of himself through the years on never being ill, bowed to an attack of lumbago today. He flew back to his home in Texas for a rest.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York City declined $19,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives adopted a resolution today opposing admission of Communist China to the United Nations and diplomatic recognition of the Peiping regime.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Britain believes that the Soviet Union's decision to return to nuclear testing marks a complete change of direction in the contest for support of the uncommitted countries.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs turned on their erstwhile tormentors, the San Francisco Giants, today with a 6-1 victory, collecting all their ten hits in the first three innings.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Judge Julius H. Miner in Federal District Court today refused to grant the Government's request for a temporary restraining order to block the merger of two large Chicago banks, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and the City National Bank and Trust Company.

Madison Square Garden's corporate image took on a paternalistic mien yesterday with the announcement of a plan to revivify professional boxing. The sport has been on the ropes for more than a decade.
