WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Senate approved today a $100,000,000 ten-year program to expand the Government's drive to convert sea and brackish water into fresh and pure water.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Matthew Gordon, who has been in charge of United Nations press services, resigned today after fifteen years in his post.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday reinstated Representative Alfred E. Santagelo as a candidate for Borough President of Manhattan in the Democratic primary next Thursday.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 31 -- Many Indians reacted gloomily today to the decision of the Soviet Union to resume nuclear weapons tests.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller will make a personal contribution of $58,000 toward an increase of $138,000 in the cost of restoring the fire-damaged Executive Mansion.
DUNN, N.C., Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Twenty Indian children were admitted to previously all-white Dunn High School today without incident.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The White House declared today that the Soviet Union's announcement that it would resume tests of nuclear weapons was "primarily a form of atomic blackmail, designed to substitute terror for reason."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A Senate subcommittee said tonight that it was satisfied that an encounter in Montevideo Uruguay, between Maj. Ernesto Guevara of Cuba and a White House aide two weeks ago had been a casual and unimportant meeting at a cocktail party.
YONKERS, Aug. 31 -- O'Brien Hanover, Hugh Grant's 6-year-old bay horse, set a world pacing record of 2:31 1-5 for a mile and a quarter tonight in winning the $25,000 Anzac Pace.
BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- For the servicemen of the First Battle Group, Eighteenth Infantry, who were sent to reinforce the United States garrison in West Berlin eleven days ago, today was a day of joy.
Robert Moses, Director of the 1964 World's Fair, has asked New York City to spend vast sums of money to construct new roadways leading to the fair.
TRENTON, Aug. 31 -- A statewide referendum on the question of legalizing games of skill and chance at county and state agricultural fairs will be held Nov. 7.

While at least a token integration in the schools of Atlanta is being peaceably accepted, a Federal court in New Orleans, like a recent Federal court in Richmond, Va., reminds those interested that the 1954 school integration decision of the United States Supreme Court cannot be evaded by subterfuge.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- While the railroad industry reported decreased freight loadings today, the trucking industry continued to report sizable gains in tonnages.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Twenty-nine intellectual and political figures from Europe, Asia, Africa and the Americas have expressed their dismay over the violation of human rights by the closing of the border between East and West Berlin.

IT was Ecclesiastes who found himself some 2,300 years ago "praising the dead which are already dead more than the living which are yet alive." It could well be on this text that Edward Lewis Wallant wrote his somber novel, "The Pawnbroker."* For Sol Nazerman, the pawnbroker of Mr. Wallant's tale, is a man who has come back from the dead, but who is yet less alive than those he left behind.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 31 -- Israeli Foreign Ministry officials conceded privately today that they were astounded by the announcement that the Soviet Union intended to resume nuclear testing. They were especially surprised at the timing of the announcement, on the eve of the meeting of uncommitted nations at Belgrade, Yugoslavia.
An effervescent Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz campaigned through the Bronx yesterday with handshakes, homey wit and a bit of baseball.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Municipal Court Judge Andrew G. Bucaro today dismissed breach of peace charges against a Dutch writer arrested in an integration incident here Monday.
LIVINGSTON, N.J., Aug. 31 -- Wes Ellis of Mountain Ridge and Bill Moran of Plainfield shot six-under-par 65's today to share individual pro golf honors at the Cedar Hill Country Club.
Rochester, N.Y., borrowed $6,930,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements, including urban redevelopment projects and expansion of the water system.

Final papers were signed yesterday for construction of the York Hill apartments, a city-aided middle-income cooperative development to be built on York Avenue between Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 31 -- Vice President Joao Goulart reached the last stop on his roundabout return trip to Brazil here today. He must now decide when and how to reenter his politically divided country.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Jose Medel of Mexico City, the National Boxing Association's top ranking bantamweight contender, knocked out Mitsunori Seki tonight in thirty-six seconds of the fifth round of a scheduled ten-round nontitle match.
The Metropolitan Opera Company has had to drop its previously announced production of Richard Strauss' "Salome" from its 1961-62 season.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Swift Co., biggest meat packer, reached a tentative wage settlement today with one of three unions. It granted up to 19 cents an hour in raises over a three-year period to 5,000 of its 23,000 plant workers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The Army announced today that it would expand Fort Gordon in Georgia.

Satisfactory Federal aid to the public schools, although solemnly promised in both the Republican and Democratic party platforms and labeled with highest priority by the Kennedy Administration, has been killed beyond hope for revival in this session of Congress. This is the tragic end to a chapter of legislative irresponsibility and inept executive leadership.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 -- School sports programs will be evaluated by the state Education Department to determine their contribution to the physical fitness of pupils.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The couple whose rag-bedecked clotheslines have been the banners of controversy here for many months has applied for permission to keep the rags flying -- as a matter of safety.
The United States monetary gold stock dropped $150,000,000, to $17,452,000,000, in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The customary holiday exchange of populations began last night as city dwellers began to leave and tourists began to arrive.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- The United Nations demanded today the immediate suspension of Katanga's Interior Minister on "grave suspicion" of having plotted the murder of United Nations personnel.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31 -- The Soviet Union's announcement that it would resume nuclear testing aroused anger, disappointment and worry today among the twentyfour delegations here for the opening of the neutralists' conference tomorrow.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- M/Sgt. William Millikan of West Point, N.Y., the Army plebe tennis coach, upset Frank A. Thompson Jr. of St. Louis, seeded fourth, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, in the quarter-final of the Eastern senior grass court tennis championship today at the Huntington Crescent Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Woodie Held hit his seventeenth home run of the year, a two-run blast into the left-field bleachers in the second inning, to help give the Cleveland Indians and Jim (Mudcat) Grant a 3-2 victory over the Washington Senators.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 -- A billion-dollar network of atomic development facilities in the West, employing about 27,000 workers, is ready for the possible resumption of nuclear testing by the United States.
DETROIT, Aug. 31 -- Negotiator's for the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation discussed the company's economic offer in detail today but found themselves still far apart.

A nonrecurring gain of $2,560,000 from the sale of a division resulted in a net profit of $1,497,000 for the McCrory Corporation in the six months ended on June 30. The variety strore chain had an operating loss of $1,063,000 on sales of $131,465,000 during the period.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- President Kennedy nominated William Ruder today as Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Administration and Public Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- President Kennedy urged Congress today to give the Federal Trade Commission power to issue temporary orders stopping alleged unfair practices while cases aimed at permanent orders were pending before the agency.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31 -- A warning by Premier Khrushchev against global war was conveyed today to the uncommitted nations opening their conference here tomorrow.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 25 cents a bale off to 10 cents up yesterday in slow trading.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Conservation of natural resources as a means of solving the world's acute shortage of protein was the theme of several technical discussions at today's 123d annual meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The Maritime Administration announced plans today for the design of a ship that would travel above the water on a cushion of air at possible speed of more than 100 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations announced today an agreement by its rival New Jersey organizations to merge at a special convention in Newark on Sept. 25.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 -- A new state law prohibiting discrimination in the sale or rental of some private housing was praised tonight by Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Sixty United States marshals have been ordered to New Orleans on stand-by duty for the opening of public schools next week, the Justice Department said today.
Hundreds of Cubans in the United States have been returning to live in Cuba, as opposed to the thousands of refugees seeking to depart from the rule of Premier Fidel Castro.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- There's no established passer and several positions pose problems. Nevertheless, Army's football outlook seems the brightest since Dale Hall took over the coaching reins from Earl Blaik in 1959.
The tiniest world that man knows, the realm of the elementary particles of physics, has had a population explosion within the last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Moscow's announced intent to resume testing nuclear weapons was described today as the "worst Soviet blunder" since the Russians moved into Budapest to crush the 1956 Hungarian revolt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- James J. Sheeran, Mayor of West Orange, N.J., has presented the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization with petitions bearing 14,961 signatures favoring the construction of a tunnel through First Mountain for a bomb shelter.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 31 -- The Russian decision to resume nuclear tests has been received with dismay in Sweden.
The Neponsit Home for the Aged, a Welfare Department center that will provide care for persons unable to provide for themselves, was dedicated yesterday.
The City Planning Commission was urged yesterday to approve the Board of Education's request for a capital budget of $129,700,000 for 1962.

AGAINST some sparkling backgrounds of the blue Tyrrhenian Sea, a fishing port on the Gulf of Salerno and the tree-shaded avenues of Rome, French director Rene Clement has done the incongruous thing of unfolding a murder thriller that is as fascinating as it is dazzlingly beautiful.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey sharply indicted the Soviet Union last night for its decision to resume nuclear testing. He termed the move a "cruel and vicious blow to the cause of peace."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Kennedy's adviser on regulatory matters. James M. Landis, supports the idea of subsidizing railroad passenger service, but his is a rather lonely view on this subject in official circles here.

Production of lumber totaled 226,026,000 board feet in the week ended Aug. 26. This figure compared with 229,029,000 board feet in the previous week, according to reports received from regional associations. A year ago 233,370,000 board feet were produced.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 31 -- The son-in-law of Hudson County Democratic Leader John V. Kenny and the brother of Mayor Thomas Gangemi of Jersey City were named to county jobs today by the Board of Freeholders.
BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- Every other night this week a young American soldier walked along the Kochstrasse in the West Berlin borough of Kreuzberg, cradling a Browning automatic rifle in his arms.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Government estimated today that Japan would experience a $1,000,000,000 trade deficit in fiscal 1961 as Cabinet ministers discussed measures to reduce the rising excess of imports over exports.
Two warring flight unions and an airline are scheduled to meet today with a Presidential Commission named to settle the dispute over crews on jets.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 -- Mme. Nina Petrovna Khrushchev walked tonight into a meeting dedicated to Soviet-United States understanding while her husband, the premier, was busy with other things.
Ten members of the tournament committee for the national tennis championships sent a telegram last night urging that Dennis Ralston be allowed to compete.

MONROE, N.C., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Four more kidnapping indictments were returned by the Union County grand jury today as a result of the two-and-a-half-hour abduction last Sunday of a white couple during racial disturbances here.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Ron Barak of Los Angeles, the lone American gymnast at the Maccabiah games, won four gold medals today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The United States presented the evidence today supporting the Western powers' right to fly civilian planes through Communist East Germany to West Berlin.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 1 -- The Government announced today that it would not acknowledge the Soviet note on nuclear testing because of the Russians "interference" in West Germany's election campaign.

THE hairy mandarins of our culture talk about the importance of having roots in the past and being in touch with the soil and all that. They mean well, even if they sound a trifle pompous. Possibly they'd do better if they took time out to read "The Battle of the Wild Turkey and Other Tales," by Alvin Johnson. They'd enjoy it. So will we all.

An acting State Supreme Court justice questioned yesterday whether the Board of Education might not have "thrown the baby out with the water of its bath" when it barred twenty-four contractors accused of giving gratuities to school employes.

THE apples that are appearing now on fruit counters are for the most part more suitable for cooking than eating out of hand. This suggests any number of apple-flavored dishes -- pies, cakes, cookies and puddings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices declined, 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 118.8 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 1 -- The United Nations mission here severed relations today with secessionist Katanga Province.

One of the least active weeks in recent memory is ahead in the market for new capital. There are no large issues of municipal bonds scheduled for sale in the four-day work week and no sizable issues of fixed-interest securities.

Rehearsals for Bill Travers, the 6-foot 4-inch British actor who will portray a strapping Greek short-order cook in "A Cook for the General," resemble the activities of a schoolhouse rather than the earnest preparations of a stage project.

ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller called a meeting of the Civil Defense Committee of the Governors' Conference today. He said the Governors needed to discuss fall-out shelters and other defense problems "in view of international developments."
ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- Nineteen bingo-playing organizations in the New York City area began court action today to force a test of three new regulations of the State Lottery Control Commission.
President Kennedy made an appeal yesterday for care and consideration on the nation's highways as the last long weekend holiday of the summer got under way.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A temporary order that forbids striking Miami pressmen to picket the Detroit Free Press will remain in effect until a Federal court rules on a request for a permanent injunction.

What looks like a radically new phase in the long struggle in Algeria appears to have begun with the replacement of Ferhat Abbas as Premier of the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government by the much younger and much more revolutionary Benyoussef Ben Khedda. Mr. Abbas had the reputation of being a moderate and of following a policy based upon confidence that agreement could be achieved with President de Gaulle.

Michael H. Prendergast, responding to an attack by Mayor Wager, charged yesterday that the Mayor had "sold out his moral obligations" to the Democratic party for an alliance with "apostles of hypocrisy."

DETROIT Sept. 1 -- Negotiators for the General Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers reported today that they had reached a better understanding of key problems. But there was no indication that the company was willing to improve its original economic offer to the union.
SELECTING an appropriate lamp shade can be a bewildering venture. For not only should the shade blend with the decorating scheme of the room, but it also should be tailored to suit the lamp base.
Five California family groups, of seven, six, five, three and two members, were killed yesterday in the crash of a Trans World Airlines plane near Chicago.

Family attic-rummaging, one of the rarer American delights nowadays, is having a revival on virtually a national scale because what is probably the most fascinating family attic in the land, that of the White House, is being so assiduously rummaged in by experts, led in person by the First Lady.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Justice Department sued today to strike down a Louisiana law requiring segregation of bus terminal facilities.
State Senator Thomas J. Mackell charged yesterday that supporters of Deputy Mayor Paul R. Screvane were "improperly and indecently" exploiting religious and philanthropic causes for political gain.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 -- The next generation of leaders in Western Europe will give top priority to the political formation of a United States of Europe, a sociologist predicted today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Following is the text of a Soviet document prepared for the Council of Foreign Ministers meeting in 1947 and made public today by the State Department in support of the United States contention that access to Berlin by Allied civilian and military aircraft had until recently been accepted by the Soviet Government:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Americans added a record of $7,013,000,000 to their financial savings in the April-June quarter, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The board's compilation includes savings in savings and loan associations, commercial banks, mutual savings banks, credit unions, savings bonds, postal saving accounts and life insurance policy reserves.

BUFFALO, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Gino Cappelletti scored all of Boston's points tonight in leading the Patriots to a 15-12 victory over the Buffalo Bills in an exhibition between American Football League teams before 9,022 at War Memorial Stadium.

While baseball's vaunted M Squad spent a sultry, frustrating evening at the Stadium last night, three relatively obscure Yankees combined forces after two outs in the ninth inning and downed the Detroit Tigers, 1 -- 0.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from speeches today at the opening of the conference of twenty-four nonaligned nations here:
OTTAWA, Sept. 1 -- The United States Embassy has made a further protest to the Canadian Government regarding the recommendations of the Royal Commission on Publications, it was learned today.
TOKYO, Sept. 1 -- The Japanese Government approved today a proposal by Foreign Minister Zentaro Kosaka for filing a strong protest with the Soviet Union against its decision to resume nuclear tests.
MONROE, N.C., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Separate trials for more than forty persons arrested in last week-end's series of racial outbursts here began today in recorder's court.

THE Knickerbocker Championships, an annual tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association, continue today with the open-pair event. It will be played in two sessions, at 2 and 8 P.M., at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

BERLIN, Sept. 1--More than twenty years ago a disciplinary court of the Evangelical Church in Nazi Germany described the Rev. Dr. Kurt Scharf as "pater pastorum"--father of flocks. The court then moved to ban Dr. Scharf from the pulpit because of his determination not to submit to the regime's pressure.
LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 1 -Columbia opened its pre-season training camp this morning with an offensive workout for the forty-four football candidates.
CIENFUEGOS, Cuba, Sept. 1 -- A first glance, it would almost seem that the Cuban revolution had never passed along the rutted back roads of Las Villas Province.
DETROIT, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- An early start has pushed the auto industry off to a strong gain in new model production over last year's rate, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
LEIPZIG, Germany, Sept. 1 -- Nineteen days after the Communist regime sealed the Berlin exit to the West, East Germany has become a land of contradictions.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Asian and African diplomats said tonight that they were ready to shelve their charges of racial bias and police brutality in New York affecting a delegate of Guinea.

The man tending the rose bed beside his development home in Hicksville, L.I., was probably as intent as the farmer who worked that same land ten years ago. The homeowner might have unintentionally pruned a rose bud, if he knew his investment in the 60-by-100 foot plot would have paid five acres twenty years ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Senate passed a five-year federal airport program today. Key features of the $375,000,000 bill are aimed at improving aviation safety.
The suspension of Dennis Ralston and his ban from the national championships were upheld yesterday by the overwhelming vote of the executive committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Nine men accused of bombing the first "freedom rider" bus to enter Alabama have been indicted by a Federal grand jury.

Although many parents with youngsters underfoot for the summer may agree with Abraham A. Ribicoff that some easing of child-labor laws may be desirable to give children "useful gainful employment,'' the image of children's exploitation in mines and mills is still fresh enough to suggest that a general relaxing of juvenile work laws is -- and should be -- some distance away.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- The Senate passed legislation today embodying three major programs of veterans benefits.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The resumption of Soviet nuclear tests will not cause any change in the loose timetable the Western powers expect to use in their moves toward negotiations on Berlin, British sources said today.
YONKERS, Sept. 1 -Adios Don, a 3-year-old pacer owned by Jane and Harold Large of Jericho, L.I., scored his ninth victory of the season tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
Two rival candidates contended yesterday that Mayor Wagner was spending too much time running for re-election while crime in the city marched on.
Chuck McKinley and Darlene Hard led the winning procession yesterday on a routine opening day in the eighty-first national amateur tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens.
The attention being given to this year's mayoralty contest threatens to obscure a local primary that will have important city-wide and statewide consequences.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 1 -- Vice President Joao Goulart was thought to have agreed to a compromise plan that will permit him to be sworn in Monday as President succeeding Dr. Janio Quadros, the chief of the Brazilian Senate announced today in Brasilia.

Queens District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday he had tried several times without success to obtain a city report reputedly linking State Controller Arthur Levitt with a with a housing windfall.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 1 -- Americans won all four of today's swimming events at the Maccabiah games and broke games records each time.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos of Mexico aligned himself with the United States today in his annual State of the Nation address. But he was careful to repeat Mexico's hands-off attitude on Cuba.

Record sales for the three and six months ended July 31 were reported yesterday by the May Department Stores Company, operator of fifty department stores and six regional shopping centers in eleven metropolitan areas.
The text of the letter sent to George E. Barnes, the president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, by Maurey D. Kallie, the referee of the recent Davis Cup series with Mexico:
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- A Mexican company has been formed to run regular steamship passenger service between Los Angeles and Acapulco.
A parched, sweltering Mayor Wagner tramped along hot streets in Brooklyn yesterday urging residents to vote for him in the primary next Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Senate voted today to ban farm labor by children under the age of 14 except on farms of their parents or those of neighbors within twenty-five miles.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians ruined the managerial debut of Luman Harris tonight by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 5 -- 4, despite three Baltimore homers.
An around-the-clock police bodyguard was assigned yesterday to protect a Brooklyn woman who said she feared she was marked for death by the underworld.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- The Hooker Chemical Company will sell the phenolic molding business it bought from the Monsanto Chemical Corporation, St. Louis, in 1958, under a ruling adopted by the Federal Trade Commission earlier this week.
Yesterday's airliner crash near Chicago, in which seventy-eight lives were lost, was the fourth worst aviation disaster in the continental United States.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- James R. Hoffa was in tentative agreement today with trucking associations of the Western states over a three-year contract.

The recovery of corporate profits from their recession levels apparently is beginning to be translated into improved dividends. Dividend changes in August were more favorable than in the corresponding month of last year for the first time this year, according to Standard Poor's Corporation.

State Controller Arthur Levitt urged Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday to investigate "the practice of political bigotry and bring to stern account those who are responsible for these outrageous tactics."
RIO DE JANERIO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Brazil's top military chiefs held fast to their refusal to accept Vice President Goulart as President under any conditions or even let him enter the country.

SEATTLE, Sept. 1 (AP) -- British Walker Cup strategy was exploded by two American old-timers today. As a result, the United States swept all four foursome matches and now must win only three of tomorrow's eight singles to retain the international amateur gold trophy for two more years.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- A Trans World Airlines Constellation plunged into a cornfield twenty miles west of here early today, killing all seventy-eight persons aboard.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Angels scored five runs on six straight hits and a sacrifice fly in the fourth inning today and defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 6 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- An oil company scientist has invented a nuclear reactor with an octopuslike design. It is regarded as capable of increasing severalfold the "flux," or intensity of radiation, of reactors of the homogeneous type.
Norwalk, Conn., announced yesterday plans for the sale of $3,080,000 of capital improvement bonds on Sept. 21. The issue will come due serially from 1962 to 1981.

Roman Catholic schools here will open on Sept. 11, a week from Monday, with an enrollment of more than 364,000 pupils. This is an increase of more than 4,100 over the last school year and is about one-third of the public school total.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1 -Eighty-nine sailing craft set out at sunset today on a 231-nautical-mile passage which is the Stamford Yacht Club's annual Vineyard race. It was a record fleet, reduced from an original entry of ninety-nine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- James E. Webb, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, asked Congress today for authority to buy the land to expand the Cape Canaveral missile facilities.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Western Europe winds up its 1961 vacation season this week-end with the political news bad but with the economy prospering as never before. For the great majority of concerns in all countries, business remains excellent.
BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- Communist authorities have barred the Rev. Dr. Kurt Scharf, chairman of the Council of the Evangelical Church in Germany, from returning to East Berlin.

MIAMI, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Cuban Government has granted safe conduct passes out of the country to 800 persons who have been living in asylum in various Havana embassies, Manuel Aristigueta, Venezuela's consul general in Miami, reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- President Kennedy saluted the promotion of James J. Rowley to Chief of the Secret Service today.

Warner Brothers, in an effort to stimulate advance interest in their expensive new film, "Splendor in the Grass," scheduled yesterday a paid public "preview" of the film at two local theatres, to take place a month before the opening.

Shareholders of the Del E. Webb Corporation of Phoenix, Ariz., and Los Angeles, have approved the $15,000,000 acquisition of the Nevada resort and hotel properties of the Sahara-Nevada Corporation through an exchange of 1,500,000 shares of Webb common stock, it was announced yesterday.

HONOLULU, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Three parachuting skindivers tonight recovered from the Pacific a 300-pound capsule that had carried human, animal and soil life samples through the deadly radiation of space for two days.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Sept. 1--President Kennedy loaded eighteen youngsters aboard his big white golf cart tonight for a twilight visit to the neighborhood candy store. He wound up the trip with a weeping youngster in his lap.

NORWICH, England, Sept. 1 -- A cautious description of some methods of detecting nuclear explosions in space and underground was given by a leading Government scientist at today's meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.
Grandma Moses approaches her 101st birthday still active mentally and full of plans, although she has been in a nursing home for the last few weeks.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers scored a run in the ninth inning on Johnny Roseboro's single and defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 4 -- 3, tonight. The Dodgers moved to within two and a half games of the league-leading Cincinnati Reds, who were idle.
Zionist leaders called yesterday for a unified and strengthened Zionist movement in keeping with Zionism's basic principle "of the oneness of the Jewish people."

NEW SUFFOLK, L.I., Sept. 1 -- A model of a Civil War balloon boat, a precursor of modern aircraft carriers, went on display in Washington today at the Naval Historical Foundation's Truxton-Decatur Museum.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- President Kennedy pledged today that he would assign the "highest priority" in next year's Congressional session to a program of medical care for the aged under Social Security.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)--The Small Business Administration has announced a program to reduce paper work and thus speed the handling of loans where commercial banks agree to put up at least 25 per cent of the cash.

Sales of the major department stores of the metropolitan area continued a four-month rise last month, registering an average 5 per cent increase over the August, 1960, level. This was indicated by a survey of six of the eight stores yesterday by The New York Times.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Ridan, ranked by many as the best 2-year-old of the year, will risk his unbeaten record against eight rivals in tomorrow's $100,000 added Washington Park Futurity at Arlington Park.

WARSAW, Sept. 1 -- On the twenty-second anniversary of the Nazi invasion of Poland, the Government has launched a major effort to convince Poles of the "hard necessity" of the Soviet Union's policy on Berlin. In the country's present mood, this is no easy undertaking.

The property at the northeast corner of East Brunside and Walton Avenues, the Bronx, which contains Loew's Burnside Theatre and five stores, has been sold by the theatre chain. Title has been taken by the buyer in the name of the Burnside Realty Company, representing Joseph S. Rosenblum, a realty investor and builder, and Fechter, Schneider and Spector.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The City Welfare Department today began photographing relief recipients as they called to collect their monthly checks.
September and football reached the United States simultaneously yesterday although summer's heat continued to sear most of the nation.
LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 31 -- There is hardly anyone in Luanda who has not in some way been touched by the African rebellion in northern Angola.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., filed in Federal District Court today a proposed final judgment for disposing of its 63,000,000 shares of General Motors Corporation stock. The plan, as expected, would give du Pont latitude to choose the methods of divestments to minimize possible losses to stockholders.

In your news reports concerning the extraordinary session of the Legislature on Aug. 21 you report that I voted in the negative on the bill to discharge the present Board of Education and to set up a panel system for selection of a new board, etc.
PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Sept. 1 -- Vice President Joao Goulart flew into Brazil by a secret route in a blacked-out jet airliner tonight to lay claim to the Presidency.
Evening up -- the balancing of purchases and sales -- by commodity futures traders dominated pre-holiday week-end sessions yesterday on the New York exchanges.

" Techniques of Tailoring" will be the subject of a series of free sewing classes at Stern's beginning Tuesday, Sept. 5 through Friday, Sept. 8. The classes, to be held in the sixth floor Special Events Center, will be given by Mrs. Marjorie Arch of Advance Patterns.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Senators received six-hit pitching from a rookie, Joe McClain, tonight and snapped their fourteen-game losing streak with a 5-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox in the second game of a double-header. The White Sox won the first game, 3 -- 2.
The players arrived at Yankee Stadium last night in bright, new automobiles. Dozens of small boys rushed toward them and pleaded, like supplicants, for autographs or for some word, some recognition.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- President Kennedy today asked Congress to give the Selective Service System $3,830,000 more to handle the increased draft calls in the current military build-up.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation today sought a rehearing of a Public Service Commission order that would cut a proposed $11,000,000 increase in electric rates to less than $4,000,000.
Some of the most famous 3-year-old colts in the nation are entered in today's Jerome Handicap, the one-mile test that will have its ninety-second running at Belmont Park.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 1 (AP) -- United Nations informants here said today that Antoine Gizenga, leader of the dissident Leftist regime in Stanleyville, had handed out arms to a mob there.

August is over and summer, in every practical sense, is ended. This week-end marks the turn, and you may as well ignore the almanac, which is technical at best, and endure the weather, which is always whimsical. Next Tuesday we all get back to work. Playtime is over.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 1 -- Authorities acted today to prevent Sikhs from demonstrating in New Delhi in support of the demand of Master Tara Singh for a Punjabi-speaking state.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- A former Army enlisted man has been named First Captain and Brigade Commander of the Corps of Cadets at the United States Military Academy. He is James R. Ellis, 24 years old, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raiford Ellis of Birmingham, Ala.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The grain futures market tended to weaken today in light dealings apparently directed largely toward evening commitments for the long holiday week-end.

Frankly, I am tired of reading the type of letters critical of President Kennedy's handling of the Berlin crisis which seem to have appeared rash-like in the recent letters column of The Times. The most recent one by Harold W. Thatcher (Aug. 22) is a case in point.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1--Premier Khrushchev was quoted today to the effect that he had decided to resume the testing of nuclear weapons to shock the Western powers into negotiations on Germany and disarmament.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Most United States airlines eventually may drop the controversial requirement that passengers reconfirm their return reservations on roundtrips.

The Belgrade meeting of "nonaligned" -- or "positive neutralist" -- Governments opened yesterday in what was obviously an atmosphere of crisis. The crisis arose from the challenge which had been contemptuously thrown before the Belgrade meeting by the Soviet Government earlier this week when it announced its intention -- since carried out -- of resuming nuclear testing, including testing of the most powerful hydrogen bombs the world has ever known.
National bodies representing the Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish faiths yesterday called on employers and employes alike to give priority in their differences to justice and charity.

Fifty-four newly promoted officers of the Department of Sanitation were sworn in by Mayor Wagner yesterday at ceremonies on the steps of City Hall. Sanitation Commissioner Frank J. Lucia and Deputy Mayor Paul R. Scre vane, former Sanitation Commissioner, also participated.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board disapproved today a plan of Pan American World Airways, Inc., for leisurely sale of the stock it holds in National Airlines, Inc.
LONDON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- The first reaction here to the adjournment of the oil talks between the Iraq Petroleum Company and the Iraqi Government was one of cautious optimism.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (UPI) -Ernie Bowman tripled after a disputed call on a pitch in the fourteenth inning today and drove in Joe Amalfitano with the run that enabled the San Francisco Giants to beat the Chicago Cubs, 4 to 3.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Senate passed today a bill designed to streamline the Securities and Exchange Commission by permitting it to delegate functions to individual members and subordinates.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The British police held up an airliner bound for Rome today for thirty-five minutes while they made a fruitless search for the Goya portrait that was stolen last week from the National Gallery.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins downed the Boston Red Sox, 5 -- 1, tonight as Pedro Ramos gained his tenth victory on a six-hitter.
Cotton futures closed 15 cents a bale up to 10 cents off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The old crop months rose.

Three Queens Republican officials charged yesterday that Frank Kenna, former county leader, had "hand picked" two candidates for the Supreme Court to be nominated at the judicial convention for the Tenth Judicial District on Sept. 14.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- An arbitrator ruled today against the Transport Workers Union in a dispute with the Pennsylvania Railroad.
The bond market made a show yesterday of doing business in advance of the Labor Day week-end, but it was not impressive.
The election of Mrs. Everett Needham Case as a director of the Radio Corporation of America was announced yesterday by David Sarnoff, chairman.
SYRACUSE, N.Y. Sept. 1 (AP) -- Sixteen high school bands conceled appearances at the New York State Fair today some because of a poliomyelitis outbreak centered in Syracuse.
LONDON Sept. 1 -- Turnover remained small in the stock market here today and price movements among industrials were aimless.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Eastern Senators lost by a 41-to-40 vote today a fight to repeal a 6 per cent advantage the law now gives Western shipyards on subsidized ship construction contracts.
In a letter to the American people made available here yesterday, Premier Khrushchev repeated his belief that there would be no war over Berlin.

Having completed the first round of its annual battle over foreign aid, Congress has approved and sent to the White House a $4.3 billion program for the current fiscal year and a potential program of some $22 billion over a five-year period. This double program is remarkable on several counts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Treasury bill rates edged upward again on today's sale of next week's regular weekly issues. They had dropped sharply last Monday.

Two patrolmen were attacked last night as they tried to break up a dispute in a Harlem tenement. Four other patrolmen were injured slightly responding to their call for assistance when their radio cars collided at Lexington Avenue at 121st Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The White House announced today that the Soviet Union resumed the testing of nuclear weapons early this morning by exploding a device over Soviet Central Asia.
The special session of the United Nations is now over, and once again the Arabs find themselves disappointed by the United States stand.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Larry Jackson defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 -- 4, tonight, giving the St. Louis Cardinals their thirteenth straight home victory. Jackson yielded eight hits. Curt Flood, Alex Grammas and Jim Schaffer drove in two runs apiece for the Cards.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman announced today that he planned to inspect a number of under-developed countries in Asia during October.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 1 -- Leading Indian newspapers strongly criticized today the Soviet Union's decision to resume testing of nuclear weapons.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1 -- The inauguration today of what is called here the "non-bloc conference" was a triumph for President Tito of Yugoslavia.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 1 The tenth world congress of Liberal parties called on the nations of the Atlantic defense alliance today to reinforce their conventional military units and to stand firm in negotiating with the Soviet Union against any threat to the liberty of West Berlin or of access to the city.

OTTAWA, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Prairie drought has withered Canada's total 1961 wheat crop to an expected 252,495,000 bushels, or 48 per cent below the year-ago level. It was the smallest crop since the disaster year of 1937, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics said today.
The worst response the United States could make to the Russian nuclear testing announcement would be to follow the Soviet example, a psychologist said here yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 1 -- Yale University announced today it had agreed to lend $4,500,000 to Roger L. Stevens, the New York developer, to help him carry out his commitment in the city's major business redevelopment project.

ALTHOUGH the temperature continues to soar, summer styles will soon be put away and fall clothes and school paraphernalia brought out of moth balls. Stores, too, are bracing themselves for the change in season.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Legislature approved today and sent to Gov. John Patterson a bill designed to make it easier to sue out-of-state newspapers for libel in Alabama courts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Government decided today it would no longer approve "juicy smoked hams" that are juicy with water.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1. -- The conference of the nonaligned countries opened today and heard President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic denounce the Soviet decision to resume nuclear testing. He urged an immediate summit conference to save the peace.

DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 1 (AP)--Arnold Palmer, Johnny Pott and Earl Stewart shot three-under-par 67's today and tied for the first-round lead in the $30,000 Dallas open golf tournament. Palmer is the year's leading tournament winner, Pott the defender and Stewart the home pro.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 1 (UPI) -- A Baton Rouge teacher was dismissed today, apparently because her husband, a Baptist minister, had publicly advocated that "justice, decency and humility" should prevail between whites and Negroes.
Three national women's organizations yesterday urged President Kennedy to seek an inspected ban on the testing of nuclear weapons through the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, called today for Ray M. Gidney to vacate the office of Controller of the Currency.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Defeated in his last two races, the Harbor View Farm's Wolfram will try to strengthen his bid for top grass-racing honors tomorrow in the Kelly-Olympic Handicap at the Atlantic City course.

ON Thursday morning the city's largest captive audience, 1,000,000 strong, will take its seats in local classrooms. For many, it will be a day of high excitement and great expectations. But for some the occasion will mark a rare personal appearance.

C.S. Lewis, in a new book titled "An Experiment in Criticism," presents a new criterion for judging books and a defense of literature as enjoyment. He doubts the usefulness of strictly evaluative criticism and suggests that if a book is enjoyed it is, by that very fact, a good book.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Senate today refused to give Nassau County officials a veto on the use of Mitchel Field, near Hempstead, L.I., as a general aviation airport.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- French agricultural organizations protested vigorously today against President de Gaulle's declaration yesterday that a forthcoming special session of Parliament would have no right to legislate on farm problems.

Wall Street had a lazy day yesterday. Trading volume fell, but in spite of Berlin tensions and the uncertainties that tend to beset the market just before a three-day week-end, prices did better than hold their own. Only two of the fifteen most active stocks failed to rise.

WHEN a home owner notices paint peeling around the outside of his house, his first instinct is to blame the paint itself. In most cases this is actually not so. TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 4 -- American athletes, led by Gary Gubner and Dick Savitt, won sixteen gold medals today as the Maccabiah Games ended. Jewish athletes from twenty-six nations took part in the quadrennial competition.

In a letter, "Effect of New Jersey's Tax Rate," in your Aug. 11 edition Adele C. Mohr states as follows: "Our need for funds for educational institutions and social, health and welfare agencies is so pressing and so unprovided for in our state budget that, as a native of Mrs. White's fair state, I hang my head in shame."
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Bill White's second four-run homer of the season paced the St. Louis Cardinals to a 9-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP) -- About 1,500 college students and young vacationers, on a three-day drinking spree, turned this resort village today into a battlefield. Beer cans and high-pressure hoses were used in the rioting.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- The draw for the fifth annual world professional hard court tennis championships was made today in a cocktail lounge off the Champs-Elysees under the supervision of Tony Trabert, the European representative of the Jack Kramer tennis troupe.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 -- Bill Tripp of Port Washington, L.I., a yacht designer, today assailed Bill Luders Jr. of Stamford, Conn., To a yacht designer, for the latter's un-orthodox use of headsails in lieu of a mainsail. The criticism occurred at the prize presentation luncheon that followed the Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard Trophy race.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Gold and convertible currency reserves held by Britain rose sharply last month, but most of the rise reflected a large drawing from the International Monetary Fund.
USUMBURA. Ruanda-Urundi, Sept. 3 -- Independence is coming and it is such a wonderful thing that everyone here looks forward to it, white man and African alike.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa denied recurring rumors yesterday that he would abandon his independent race for Mayor if State Controller Arthur Levitt, the Democratic organization candidate, won the nomination in Thursday's primary.

The Brazilian crisis precipitated by the sudden resignation of President Janio Quadros has ended without civil war and by constitutional procedures. Vice President Joao Goulart is to become President shortly in the capital of Brasilia, as he was legally entitled to do.
BOSTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) -- Jim Grant gained his fourteenth victory of the season today as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Boston Red Sox, 7 -- 2.

Arthur A. Herman and Walter A. Cubita have formed the Minuit Properties Corporation, a real estate investment and syndication concern, with offices at 580 Fifth Avenue. Mr. Herman is a lawyer. Mr. Cubita was formerly on the staff of Albert B. Ashforth, Inc. realty company. Mr. Herman is president of the new company, and Mr. Cubita is vice president.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 4 -- The impatience and militancy of young Negroes demanding immediate desegregation of buses and restaurant is a healthful development, the president of the National Urban League declared here tonight.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., raised the dividend rate on its common stock with the declaration yesterday of a quarterly payment of 22 1/2 cents a share. The dividend is payable on Oct. 2 to holders of record of Sept. 15.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Establishment of the Peace Corps on a formal basis was approved today by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
DAY after day hunters, would-be hunters and experts of varrying hue talk and write learnedly of the flight characteristics of woodcock, grouse, quail and pheasant.

SHOES are beginning to shape to the foot that wears them, according to Joseph Gandolfo, designer for Rinaldi shoes.
BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Chuck Essegian and John Romano led Cleveland s fourteen-hit attack on three Boston pitchers tonight as the Indians beat the Red Sox, 9 -- 5.

GEORGE ROBERT TEBBETTS has cast doubt on his reputation as one of baseball's smartest and shrewdest operatives. He has left his impregnable post as executive vice president of the Milwaukee Braves and moved into the exposed position of manager, where snipers will have clear shots at him and where the mortality rate is high.

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Sept. 5 -- Vice President Joao Goulart who flew from here to Brasilia today, left behind a civil population that is now considerably bewildered by the implications of the new parliamentary system instituted by Congress.

The shopping center containing thirteen stores at 1630 to 1656 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, L.I., has been sold by the Hyde Park Properties Company. It was bought by the Victor Properties Company for cash over mortgages amounting to $215,000.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Prime Minister Macmillan met with his Cabinet today. Shortly afterward it was announced that he expected to resume his vacation in Scotland tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The State Department said today that it deplored the arrest, detention and sentencing by the Soviet Union of Mr. Makinen on espionage charges.

The Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., and its subsidiaries registered a 15.5 per cent increase in sales for the first half of this year, but earnings failed to match those of the 1960 period, the semi-annual statement disclosed yesterday.

TAKORADI; Ghana, Sept. 5 -- Opposition to President Kwame Nkrumah's austerity budget and the imposition of national compulsory saving erupted today into strikes and demonstrations by workers here and in Kumasi, a regional headquarters for Ghana Railways.

Ogden Phipps' Funloving gave the 16,061 spectators at Belmont Park a good show yesterday. The 3-year-old daughter of Tom Fool was the strong favorite in the feature purse, which attracted five starters, and she won by a length and a half over Taylor Asbury's Epitome.

The country needs three nurses for every two it now has. The range of their services in modern health care has expanded so rapidly that we keep falling farther and farther behind in the availability of nurses, even though we are training more of them than physicians or any other group of health professionals.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The first private crop report of the month contained a big surprise for the soybean trade today and prices of that commodity turned weak. Some contracts fell to their lowest levels of the season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5 -- George Stevens, two-time Oscar winner and one of the top producer-directors of the American movie industry, attacked Wall Street today for interference with the creative aspects of moviemaking.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 6 (AP) -- President Kennedy's decision to resume underground and laboratory and nuclear testing caused the Japanese to be dismayed and downhearted today. But the announcement came as no surprise.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Sept. 5 (Reuters) -- Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan was sworn in today as Premier of British Guiana. He also assumed the role of Minister of Planning and Development.
United States exporters were scored yesterday for delaying their own cargoes in foreign ports because of "sloppy and illegible markings" on their exported freight.
WASHINGTON, Sept 5 (UPI) -- The Senate passed today and sent to the House a compromise $194,440,000 Atomic Energy Commission money bill providing funds for a reactor plant at Hanford, Wash.

IN the final event of the Knickerbocker Championships over the week-end, the team-of-four contest was won by the Long Island group of Jeff Westheimer of Lido Beach, Armand Barfus of Glen Cove, William Eisenberg of Long Beach and Martin Ginsberg of Atlantic Beach.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 5 (UPI) -- Gales from tropical storm Carla tonight buffeted Swan Island, where foes of Cuban Premier Fidel Castro maintain a radio propaganda outpost.

WEMBLEY, England, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- Dave Charnley, the British, Empire and European lightweight champion, scored a ten-round decision over Len Matthews of Philadelphia at the Empire Pool tonight.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Bob Purkey pitched a six-hitter for league-leading Cincinnati tonight as the Reds beat the Cardinals, 5 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- President Kennedy ordered today the resumption of nuclear weapons tests by the United States. He specified that the tests should take place "in the laboratory and underground, with no fall-out."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 5 -- Without getting full credit, Rutgers had one of the finest football teams in the East last season. The Scarlet and Black won eight of nine games, losing only to Villanova, 14 -- 12, in a shocking form reversal.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 5 -- The Louis E. Wolfson Fellowships in the fields of social sciences and the humanities have been established here, Dr. Donald R. Hamilton, dean of the Graduate School of Princeton University, announced today.

Al Hirschfeld has been recording the American theatre in a series of caricatures since the Nineteen Twenties, many of them being a prominent feature in this newspaper's Sunday theatre section. He has brought together what he considers the best of these to form "The American Theatre as Seen by Hirschfeld," which Braziller will publish on Oct. 18.

A theatre party has been arranged by supporters of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society. It will be the evening of Nov. 29 at the Shubert Theatre for the performance of "The Gay Life."
A total of 921 persons were injured in 625 automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The Navy announced today the award of contracts totaling $274,000,000 for planes land $10,000,000 for aviation fuel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Santa Fe Opera Company has canceled its plans to perform its repertory in Warsaw this fall. According to State Department Officials, the visit has been called off because some of the company's singers cannot spare the time for a visit to the Polish capital.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The steel price debate in the Senate is scheduled to resume Thursday.

THE Original One-Day Rural Flea Market at Salisbury, Conn., offers three acres of open-air antiques to the collecting public. It will be held this year from noon to 6 P.M., rain or shine, on Saturday. Admission is 50 cents, and children and dogs are welcome free.
MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- A Soviet military tribunal sentenced Marvin William Makinen, an American tourist, to eight years' detention today on espionage charges.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- President de Gaulle urged today that the West firmly and steadily resist, by force if necessary, the menace of the Soviet "totalitarian empire." He said that any use of Soviet force in Berlin should be met by force to maintain Allied positions and communications.

The appointment of Thomas C. Fogarty, president of the Continental Can Company, as chief executive officer was announced yesterday following a special meeting of the board of directors.

The appointment of Robert O. Goodykoontz as vice president in charge of the Esso Standard, Eastern Region of the Humble Oil and Refining Company, effective Jan. 1, was announced yesterday. William W. Steel production scored a fifth consecutive weekly advance in the seven days ended last Saturday, according to data compiled by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
