A sturdy vacant seat in the upper deck of Yankee Stadium prevented Mickey Mantle's fifty-first homer of the season from leaving the Bronx last night. It was the first salvo of a Yankee attack that crushed the Washington Senators, 6 -- 1.
BERLIN, Sept. 5 -- United States soldiers hurled teargas grenades across Berlin's East-West city border at East German policemen twice today after the policemen had sprayed them with a water hose.

The Belgrade "summit meeting" of twenty-five "nonaligned" countries has come to an end in a state of shock over the continuous Soviet nuclear explosions and in a condition of nervousness over the threat of war raised by the Moscow-made crisis.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The United States Government sold today the major part of a huge aircraft engine plant for $3,401,500.

"In Case of War," an hour-long program about the implications of an attack upon this country, is being prepared by the Columbia Broadcasting System. It will be televised on "C.B.S. Reports" in late October or early November.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 7 -- The Japanese Government sorrowfully protested today against the United States decision to resume tests of nuclear weapons.

Overshadowed in public attention by the Berlin dilemma, the current political crisis in Brazil is bound to have fateful repercussions. In yet another respected country constitutional democracy has been trodden under by the military boot. Brazil's record in constitutional legality is second to none in Latin America from the enlightened monarchy to the republic.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- Two Government scientists have developed a "highly important" technique for extracting cancer-producing virus from the blood of laboratory rats in nearly pure form.

BRASILIA, Sept. 6 -- Vice President Joao Goulart conferred today with War Minister Odilio Denys, one of the men who had sought to prevent him from assuming the Presidency. The meeting took place at the apartment of Acting President Pascoal Ranieri Mazzilli.

Mayor Wagner branded as "a lot of nonsense" yesterday the charge by Carmine G. De Sapio that the Mayor was legally "ineligible for any public office." Mr. De Sapio, the Tammany leader, had made the charge Tuesday on the ground that the Mayor had received favors.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Caroline Kennedy and a dozen of her friends will attend school at the White House this fall.
Capt. James J. Tully and his 200 patrolmen and detectives opened their new East Fifty-first Street station house for business at 4 P.M. yesterday and two women promptly stole the show.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 6 -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman warned today that the United States would have "grave reservations" if the European Common Market restricted imports of American farm products.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Stockholders of the Commonwealth Edison Company approved a two-for-one split of the utility's common stock at a special meeting today. The split will be effective at the close of business on Sept. 22.
"THE courage of the first man who ate an oyster was matched by the skill of the first man who really learned how to open one, for opening oysters is an art."
DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 6 -- Racial integration of public schools began here today in an atmosphere of serenity.
The twentieth International Congress of the History of Art will begin a six-day session tonight with a dinner at Low Memorial Library, Columbia University.

Business in the high-grade bond market picked up yesterday. Prices were firm to higher. The money market continued to have an abundance of excess bank reserves available for day-to-day lending at rates as low as one half of 1 percent.
CLINTON, N.Y., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Retired Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant 3d resigned today as chairman and as a member of the National Civil War Centennial Commission.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 6 -- President Francois Duvalier made sweeping changes in the army command today, less than a week after reports that an anti-Government plot had been crushed.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 6 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox behind Juan Pizzaro and Don Larsen, downed the Minnesota Twins tonight, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 2.

A series of twelve chamber concerts will be presented under the auspices of New York University on its Washington Square campus during the coming season. The concerts will take place on Friday evenings and Sunday afternoons, beginning Oct. 27.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Grain futures prices held firm most of the day here today on the Board of Trade, but eased during the final hour and finished in a narrowly mixed range.

Beginning Monday, New York residents who deposit money in the new branches of Puerto Rico's Banco de Ponce here will be able to write checks on the bank's other branches in Puerto Rico towns when they visit the island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended August 30:

HAVANA, Sept. 6 -- Premier Fidel Castro said today that Cuban doctors, engineers and technicians who had fled to the United States would be deprived of their citizenship and forbidden to return to Cuba.
Mayor Wagner said last night that his opposition in today's primary election had made a "scurrilous" attack on himself, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.
In reporting my keynote address to the National Catholic Conference for Interracial Justice an obvious error slipped into the story.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers rallied with five runs in the eighth inning tonight and beat the San Francisco Giants, 9 -- 5. The victory moved the Dodgers within one game of league-leading Cincinnati.

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes listed below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of companies the shares of which are listed on the exchange.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Following are the National Guard and Reserve units ordered by the Army today to begin an intensified training program. Four Guard divisions and 146 other units will be raised to near full strength and required to add one week-end drill a month.
The Democratic primary for the Borough Presidential nomination in Brooklyn is a gentlemanly contest, in contrast to the mudslinging battle for the nomination for Mayor.

Sales of United States Savings bonds in August were the best for the month in five years, and cash-ins were the lowest for any August in seven years, the Treasury reported yesterday. There was a rise of 11 per cent in sales and a drop of 6 per cent in redemptions in the month.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 6 -- The Caribbean Organization came into being here today at a conference that will continue until Sept. 15.

The United Artists Corporation achieve record gross and net income for the first six months of this year and results for all of 1961 are expected to exceed those of last year, according to Robert S. Benjamin, chairman.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals took advantage of four errors by Cincinnati's infield tonight and beat the first-place Reds, 11 -- 5.
A $30,000,000 building program for Florida's public institutions of higher education was announced here yesterday by Gov. Farris Bryant.

LOWELL, Mass., Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Raytheon Company and CBS Electronics have agreed on essential terms for the purchase by Raytheon of the real estate, physical facilities and certain inventories of CBS here, it was announced today.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Stockholders of R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company approved today a proposal to split the stock two for one.

THAT phenomenon of deficit spending, the American Football League, will make another bold effort starting this week-end to siphon off for itself some of the enormous appeal, patronage and popularity of the National Football League. A new season will begin for this neophyte member of the play-for-pay set, a week earlier than the formal getaway date of the solidly established Nationals, the goliaths of the trade.

Although a major purpose of the Board of Education's open meetings is to give the public a chance to be heard on school matters, the board occasionally has added items to the calendars of the meetings without informing the public, a hearing in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn was told yesterday.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, called for a major revision of the Education Law yesterday.
Though only three months old, the infant field of stereo radio already has become a major marketing battlefield.

The recent announcement on the pages devoted to the theatrical news that a British actor named Charles Gray had changed his name to Oliver Gray in anticipation of an appearance in a forthcoming Broadway production should come as a great relief to the entertainment-going public.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would ask the City Planning Commission to kill the highly controversial plan for renewing a fourteen-block section of Greenwich Village.
Many railroaders, particularly in the East, have been waiting impatiently for railroad prospects to improve with the general economy.

Recently the White House announced that some 720,000 metric tons of coke would be bought in the United States for our forces in Germany and would cost -- together with some coal -- about $17,250,000 rather than the $15,000,000 the coal would have cost in Europe.
PARIS, Sept. 6 -- Maj. Gen. Jacques Massu, leader of one army revolt in Algeria and a symbol for a second, was given a command position today after nineteen months on the inactive list.

WHAT must have been one of the most distinguished audiences ever to attend a concert in this city was present last night in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art to hear music by Milton Babbitt, Elliott Carter and Leon Kirchner.
The Maxson Electronics Company, New York, signed a contract yesterday to acquire the Hopkins Engineering Company of San Fernando, Calif., for an undisclosed amount of Maxson stock.
SPEAKING of a prodigiously productive poet, Van Wyck Brooks says that the man had "a kind of waffle-iron" in his head that "turned into the shape of a sonnet every thought that entered it."

The Brittany is a dog of paradoxes. He is a spaniel, but he looks like a small setter. He is the only member of the spaniel family that doesn't flush his game -- he points it. An excellent upland hunter, he also is a natural retriever.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The public schools of the city are opening this morning for more than 1,000,000 pupils and a teaching staff of 40,000. Closing time will be 2 P.M. because of the primary elections.
An automobile dash across Staten Island last night helped to save the life of a 21-year-old Staten Island Zoo employe who had been bitten by a poisonous snake.
Michel Collet, the Guinean diplomat involved in a fight with a patrolman in Harlem, has quietly left the United States.

A method of making high-speed computer techniques available for automating production machinery was detailed yesterday by the Remington Rand Univac division of Sperry Rand Corporation and the Rohr Aircraft Corporation of Chula Vista, Calif.

The "cold war" and its implications for Americans are discussed by Edgar Ansel Mowrer in his new book "An End to Make-Believe." Mr. Mowrer gives a history of the spread of international communism and the attempts by the Administrations of Roosevelt, Truman and Eisenhower to block it. He also analyzes the Soviet-Western tensions encountered by the Kennedy Administration.
Watson-Guptill Publications, Inc., publisher of the magazine American Artist, has leased a floor in 111 Fourth Avenue, at the corner of Twelth Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- The air in the United States and other industrial nations contains a chemical known to cause cancer in animals, it was reported today. There is, however, no evidence that it causes cancer in man.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced tonight that the Soviet Union had detonated a fourth nuclear device in the atmosphere.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 6 -- Mobs stoned United Nations troops and United Nations property today as tension in this city increased.

A secondary offering of 150,000 common shares of Corning Glass Works was marketed yesterday at $165 a share. Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co. managed the offering of the shares, which belonged to members of the Houghton family.
EBS closed yesterday at 34 1/8, up 1/8 for the day, on a volume of 2,600 shares.

The most important question to be decided by New York City's voters today, between the hours of 3 and 10 P.M., is whether Mayor Wagner or State Controller Levitt will receive the Democratic nomination. The citizens' comparative neglect of the primary election is indicated by the fact that whereas 2,300,000 Democrats are entitled to vote, the expectation is that only between 500,000 and 800,000 will bother to go to the polls today.

Bids for an estimated total of $60,926,300 worth of highway construction, grade crossing elimination and canal work will be opened in Albany on Oct. 5, State Superintendent of Public Works J. Burch McMorran announced yesterday.
Joseph E. Horak has been named general manager of the new sales and distribution department of the General Electric Company's Hotpoint division. He was general manager of the distribution department.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today a "something for everyone" public works bill. It would provide more than $1,000,000,000 for water projects by the Army Engineers and the Bureau of Reclamation.

CAPE CANAVERAL,, Fla., Sept. 6 (UPI) -- An Air Force Titan missile capable of hurling a five-megaton nuclear warhead nearly halfway around the world hit a target 6,100 miles away in a military test flight tonight.

WITH the pioneering days of Israel now a thing of the past, the women of that country are becoming increasingly aware of the need for charm, poise and an attractive appearance in their daily lives, according to Mrs. Leah Fletcher, founder and head of Israel's only charm and modeling school.

YONKERS, Sept. 6 -- O'Brien Hanover, often a long-priced wagering hazard in his racing career, is the 6-5 favorite for the mile and one-half Single G Pace, the $25,000 feature at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz contended yesterday that Democratic "one-party misrule" of the city was breeding the same abuses that one-party systems had bred in Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 -- The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached a tentative economic agreement today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker, who was relieved of his command in Europe earlier this year, violated a criminal statute in attempting to influence the outcome of an election through political indoctrination of his troops, Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Safe Mission won the $51,927 Horseman Stake at The Indiana State Fair mile track today. Rain forced a postponement of a race-off in the $55,635 Fox Stake, the big feature on the Grand Circuit program.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- It is likely that a relatively large nuclear power plant under consideration for the island of Luzon in the Philippines would prove, by the end of the Nineteen Sixties, to be economically competitive with a a conventional power plant of equal size.
Mayor Wagner yesterday announced a program for rehousing families on relief now living in hotels in the city.

A TRUCK driver leaned out of his window one day this week to bid three meter maids a good, good morning. Two business men jokingly offered them $4 cash to tear up the $5 ticket on an illegally parked car. And a doorman darted from beneath his green-and-white-striped awning to slip another dime into a near-by parking meter.

TRENTON, Sept. 6 -- The Department of Defense asked New Jersey and the Department of the Interior today to join in preparing short-range and long-range plans for the use of Sandy Hook as a state park and recreation center.

Dorsey Products, Inc., maker of rubber products, has leased the one-story building at 10-55 Fiftieth Avenue, Long Island City, for occupancy by its distributor, Naugatile of New York, Inc. The building was leased from the Rochambeau Holding Corporation through Fred Hughes of the Jack Sprung Company, broker.
A strike of 450 professional and clerical employes against the Development Corporation of Israel, the organization that sells Israeli bonds in this country, started yesterday in fifty cities.
LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today that the United States plan to resume nuclear tests was "perfectly understandable" in view of the Soviet test blast.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 6 -- The battleship North Carolina, affectionately known as "the showboat" by her crews during World War II when she took part in every major offensive in the South Pacific, was turned over from the Navy to the State of North Carolina today.

OUT of Canada, source of refreshing breezes, has come once again a droll and charming revival of Gilbert and Sullivan. Last year it was "Pinafore"; last night "The Pirates of Penzance" arrived at the Phoenix Theatre.

As a kindness to pitchers in the pay of the Washington Senators, somebody really ought to hang warning flares on those supposedly benign entities in the nether regions of the Yankee batting order, below the redoubtable Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The House Ways and Means Committee considered tax relief for stockholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in closed session today but came to no final decision. Another meeting was scheduled for tomorrow and there were indications that it might produce a bill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- President Kennedy today selected James R. Browning, now clerk of the United States Supreme Court, to fill a vacancy on the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, with headquarters in San Francisco. The nomination was sent to the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A high-level inter-American investigating commission is expected to fly to the Dominican Republic Tuesday to prepare a report on that country's progress toward democracy.
Confronted with Premier Khrushchev's "atomic blackmail" on Berlin, President Kennedy is being approached from two opposite directions on how to deal with the situation and avert a new world war.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Viet Cong rebels from Vietnam have been discovered in Cambodian territory and have been forced back across the border after heavy fighting, the Cambodian Army said today.
A proposed local law establishing a minimum wage of $1.50 an hour in contracts let by the city for goods and services was sent to the City Council yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Legislation designed to increase United States exports by providing guarantees against the risks of doing business in foreign countries was approved today by the House Banking Commitee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The House majority leader, John W. McCormack, predicted today that the foreign aid money bill would be increased to "at least $4,000,000,000" by the time it was ready for President Kennedy's signature.
The observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, marking the Jewish New Year 5722, will begin Sunday at sundown.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 6 -- The Yugoslavs were pondering today the causes and extent of a political defeat they suffered in the conference of nonaligned powers.
A picket line of about thirty men was placed in front of Pier 9, Hudson River, at noon yesterday by the International Longshoremen's Association.
THE need for special care might be expected for fragile Chantilly lace and damask, but there is even an art to handling modern wash-and-wear fabrics.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 6 -- Negroes in America will face a battle against "hidden" prejudice and discrimination after they win their fight for equal rights, Whitney M. Young Jr. of New York predicted here tonight.
The names of fourteen Brooklyn and Queens physicians and a Manhattan dentist whose licenses have been revoked or suspended by the State Board of Regents were made known yesterday.
A policewoman asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to direct the Civil Service Commission to permit her to take an examination for sergeant.

EASTON, Pa., Sept. 6 -- With the lightest and smallest squad it has had in the four-year coaching tenure of Jim McConlogue, Lafayette doesn't expect to knock down and trample on many of its nine football foes this season.
ATHENS, Sept. 6 -- A new United States Embassy building was dedicated in a formal ceremony here today.

Robert E. Herman, State Rent Administrator, was warned yesterday that he would he cited for contempt if he did not comply with a court-ordered formula for setting the rent in a Park Avenue apartment house.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- Directors of the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company proposed today a two-for-one stock split and declared a 3 per cent stock dividend in addition to the regular quarterly payment of 25 cents on the present common.
A section of Arverne in the Rockaways, Queens, was designated yesterday by Mayor Wagner, as the city's third Area Services Project.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Lee Loevinger, the head of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, said today a $50,000 fine for a corporation with a $250,000,000 income was no heavier penalty than a $3 parking ticket for a man with a $150,000 income.

Louis A. Oviedo, Consul General of the Dominican Republic, said yesterday that contracts had been signed by his Government with two groups of United States investors for the development of more industries in his country.

Fred W. Hooper's Teacation, taking over after the pace-setter tired near the end, won the $28,800 Maskette Handicap at Belmont Park by a length yesterday. The pace-setter, Mrs. Whitney Stone's Shimmy Dancer, managed to hold on to the place, by a length and a half over Frank J. Viggiani's Craftiness, in the one-mile test for fillies and mares.

The acquision of the Burry Biscuit Corporation by the Quaker Oats Company was approved by their directors yesterday. The transaction would involve about $25,000,000. Negotiations had been in progress since July.
BELMONT, N.H., Sept. 6 -- Artemas Packard, who recently retired as Professor of Art at Dartmouth College, and his wife were killed today in an automobile accident.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6 -- The second year of token desegregation in this city's public schools will begin tomorrow under stringent police precautions.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 6 -- Chancellor Adenauer said tonight that he was convinced there would not be a war despite recent "disquieting events."

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Warren Spahn hurled a three-hitter tonight for his eighteenth victory of the season and No. 306 of his career as the Milwaukee Braves beat the Philadelphia Phillies. 1 -- 0.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Negroes tried unsuccessfully today to enroll their children in nine all-white public schools.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The House of Representatives wrote an apathetic postscript to the school-aid battle today by approving the continuation without change of two expiring education programs.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., Sept. 6 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood and La Junta White of Englewood led the qualifiers in the Garden State Women's Golf Association's better-ball-of-partners championship today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- Five Pittsburgh Pirate errors, including three by Dick Groat, eased the Chicago Cubs to a 6-2 victory today.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 6 -- President Itzhak Ben-Zvi asked David Ben-Gurion tonight to attempt as speedily as possible to form a new Government for Israel.

Stephen W. Rousseas claims in his letter (Aug. 29) that he is "well aware of the problems faced by the residents of Morningside Drive," but his letter shows only ignorance of the conditions that have made the erection of the gates to the upper entrances of Morningside Park a grim necessity.
PARIS, Sept. 6 -- French press and political circles asserted today that President de Gaulle's statements yesterday on domestic and North African affairs were disappointing and imprecise.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Senate passed the wilderness bill tonight after having stood off an attempt by lumber and other business interests to amend it. The vote was 78 to 8.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 6 -- Five debutantes were presented tonight at parties on the North Shore in the traditional little season that follows their June graduations from finishing schools and precedes their entrance to college this month.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 6 -- A general alarm waterfront fire today destroyed the eighty-building complex of the Goodman Warehouse and Furniture Company at First Street and Lexington Avenue. Damage was estimated at $3,000,000.
NORWICH, England, Sept. 6 -- A leading British nutrition expert rejected today the theory that increased consumption of animal fats had led to a rise in the number of heart-disease cases.
Democrats will nominate their candidate for Mayor today and settle a bitter, bruising battle for party control. The effects of the fight may be felt far beyond New York City.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- The United States and the Soviet Union began a new series of disarmament talks today.

Bernard J. O'Connell, Commissioner of Licenses, revoked two permits held by Carl M. Person to operate a mobile carrousel and as an itinerant musician, following a hearing yesterday at 80 Lafayette Street.

Two parking meter collectors were arrested on a downtown street corner at the end of their day's rounds last evening. According to City Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan, they were dividing the contents of a sack of dimes -- 5,000 of them.
"A Passage to India" is due on Broadway early next year.
DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 6. -- From an abandoned firehouse on the Boston Post Road here, thousands of books and magazines are being sent abroad to further international understanding.

A loan and two development credits amounting to the equivalent of $13,400,000 were extended yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) and the International Development Association.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 6 -- President Kennedy's decision to resume nuclear testing without further delay has been welcomed by United States military leaders in Europe.
ON BOARD S.S. AQUARAMA, on Lake Erie, Sept. 6 -- The Chrysler Corporation unveiled today its first new styling theme since 1957.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- Following is the official text of the final declaration of the conference of nonaligned nations that ended here early today:
HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 6 -Doug Ford, an occasional competitor in metropolitan tournaments, captured the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship by one stroke today.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 6 (UPI) -- Charles S. Kamen will be given a chance to appeal personally to the Miami draft board that refused him a deferment to serve in the Peace Corps.
Stabilization of raw wool prices at the Australian auctions helped raise wool futures prices yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 6 -- The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's annual fall race week began today with light-to-moderate airs, 187 starters and enough protests for half a dozen regattas.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Stock market prices closed with minor irregular changes here today. Business turnover was lower than yesterday's, although some buying toward the end of the session wiped out many early losses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The State Department reported today that Jacob D. Beam. United States Ambassador to Poland, and several other diplomats had been called home for about four months to serve on Foreign Service promotion boards.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Pentagon today ordered intensified "combat readiness" training for 148,000 members of the military reserves, including four Army National Guard divisions.
Carlos Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States, accused the Soviet Union yesterday of "bringing the world to the brink of nuclear incineration."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Western powers have drafted another strong warning to Moscow against interference with their air traffic to West Berlin. The new note will probably be delivered in the Soviet capital Friday.
BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- Mayor Willy Brandt warned today that the West could expect new Communist moves against Berlin in the next two weeks.

The progress made by contract negotiators for General Motors and the United Automobile Workers offers a welcome indication that the country will be spared a punishing onset of labor-management warfare while it is pulling itself out of the year-long business slump. The combined requirements of economic recovery and military preparedness make a major auto strike this year unthinkable.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- President Kennedy today chose Charles W. Cole, vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation, as Ambassador to Chile.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 6 -- Dr. Janio Quadros resigned the Presidency fully convinced that he would be called back to power a few hours later with dictatorial powers, the newspaper Tribuna da Imprensa reported today.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Mrs. Nat Koch and Mrs. Sidney Mishkin of Fairview combined their cards for a gross best ball of 44, 41 -- 85 at the Pelham C.C. today to win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association event for Class B members by four strokes.

The Walter J. Schneider Corporation, a national realty company with headquarters in New York, has taken title to two properties and has contracted to buy two additional ones in two cities. The properties have a total value of about $5,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The House today passed a bill to make it a crime for a member of any subversive group to apply for a National Science Foundation scholarship.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- President Kennedy today called the peaceful integration of many schools in the South a "dramatic demonstration of progress in improving the position of American Negroes."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept 6 -- Anson Beard Jr. of Islip, L.I., sailing Tsunami, won both races in the Atlantic Coast championship of the International Star Class off the Larchmont Yacht Club today and took a 9-point lead in the series.

State Controller Arthur Levitt wound up his bid for the Democratic nomination for Mayor last night with a spirited defense of the support he is receiving from the party organization. "There is no need for me to apologize for the support of the Democratic organization" he said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Federal Reserve board approved today the proposed merger of two New York banks -- the Manufacturers Trust Company and the Hanover Bank -- to form the fourth largest bank in the world.

DALLAS, Sept. 6 -- Dr. Warren Travis White, Superintendent of the Dallas Independent School District, is the highest-paid public official in Texas. His salary is $8,000 higher than the Governor's $25,000, and his emolument is generally heartily endorsed rather than questioned.
Two men were arrested here last night by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and $100,000 worth of stolen jewelry was recovered.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 6 -- Unable to decide whether C. Jules Brulatour or his wife had died first, a State Supreme Court justice ruled here today that the wills of both, although different, should control the distribution of jointly owned properties.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 6 -- A year can make a tremendous difference in the prospects of a college football team.
BOSTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- Don Schwall pitched his fourteenth victory of the season for the Boston Red Sox today, defeating the Cleveland Indians, 9 -- 4.

TUNIS, Sept. 6 -- President Habib Bourguiba returned to Tunis tonight from the Belgrade conference in a new mood of conciliation toward President de Gaulle of France. It suggested the possibility of a negotiated solution for Bizerte.
Laurence Harvey was signed yesterday for the title role in "The Manchurian Candidate," the Richard Condon novel, which will be filmed early next year with Frank Sinatra heading the cast.
A fleet of Liberian-flag tankers controlled by a United States trust established by Aristotle S. Onasis, the Greek shipping magnate, will soon be sold.
THIS deal, played at the Whist Club the day before yesterday, unquestionably has a moral; but it is hard to say whether the lesson to be learned from it is technical or inspirational.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Tropical storm Carla developed into a hurricane today and headed toward the Yucatan Peninsula.
WARSAW, Sept. 6 -- Negotiations under way in Washington for a new round of United States economic aid to Poland have become stalled, according to information available here.
Cotton futures closed 10 cents a bale off to 75 cents up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- The Board of Education here transferred 267 pupils today from the predominantly Negro Lincoln Elementary School to eleven other schools.

East Haven, Conn., sold yesterday $2,935,000 of sewer and school bonds due from 1962 to 1981 to Harris Trust and Savings Bank and associates. The price paid was 100.55 for obligations bearing 3.6 per cent interest.

TOKYO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Representatives of the Japanese cotton and textile industry urged Premier Hayato Ikeda today to assume a "strong" stand in present negotiations seeking an increase in Japan's cotton and textile exports to the United States.
LONDON, Sept. 6 -- The Trades Union Congress, representing 8,000,000 British workers, formally rejected today the Government's plea for a pause in wage increases.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6 -- The third race of the International Dragon Class Series was postponed today because of the lack of wind. The thirteen competing crews face an extra-heavy schedule tomorrow as a result.

The Puritan Fund of Boston reported yesterday that net assets amounted to $108,858,020, equal to $8.49 a share on 12,816,693 shares outstanding, on July 31, the end of its fiscal year. The net assets represented a peak for the fund and were 44 per cent higher than a year earlier.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 6 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia handed to the United States and Soviet ambassadors today appeals asking for a meeting of President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev to avert a nuclear war.
Persons who appear best qualified for foreign aid jobs abroad are those most likely to break down under the strain of foreign experience, a Government psychologist said yesterday.
Indications that the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers might be near a peaceful solution of their differences sent the stock market up briskly yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- An official of the Internal Revenue Service has been indicted with three lawyers by a Federal grand jury in Boston on charges of attempting to fix an income tax case, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy announced today.

ZURICH, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- The Zurich Cantonal Health Authority revealed today that "substantial stores" of pep pills and other stimulants were found during a locker room raid at the Swiss national bicycling championships on July 22.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Twenty bills aimed at increasing the membership of the House of Representatives were killed today by the House Judiciary Committee.
MANVILLE, N.J., Sept. 6 (AP) -- A brother and sister, 4 and 5 years old, were found bludgeoned to death today in the basement of their home.
The "Port of the Future," where deep-sea freighters will tie up at offshore facilities and tankers will load at submarine sea terminals, was depicted here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today a bill backed by President Kennedy to create a disarmament agency.
A new Merriam-Webster unabridged dictionary -- entirely renewed in content and radically altered in style -- will be published Sept. 28. It will be the first completely new edition since 1934.
Another of the United States top contenders was beaten in the national amateur tennis championships yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India appealed today to Premier Khrushchev to take immediate action with President Kennedy to avert the danger of war.
Building permit values in 200 cities declined in July for the second consecutive month, Dun Bradstreet reported yesterday.

Hitchner's response to your recent editorial on "Controlling the Pesticides'' you state that "the industry has not acted responsibly in dealing with the hazards of chemical insecticides.'' In other words, you accuse the industry of irresponsibility with respect to such hazards.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Pittsburgh blended five hits and a walk with four Chicago errors to score five runs in the third inning today and went on to defeat the Cubs, 7 -- 5.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 7 -- Four debutantes who will make their bows tomorrow at the Darien-New Canaan Autumn Cotillion at the Wee Burn Country Club were honored tonight at a supper dance given by their parents at the Tokeneke Club.

For almost three years now Khrushchev has been on the offensive, varying his arguments, accusations, proposals and threats in minor details but pushing on and more and more dominating the scene, because two American Administrations have permitted him to choose the ground on which to argue.

HOUSTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Paul Richards signed a novel three-year contract as general manager of the Houston Colts today and said his No. 1 problem is the immediate evaluation of all National League players.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 7 -- A number of skippers who placed high on the opening day of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week yesterday fared well again today.

Tentativeness dominated the high-grade bond market yesterday in a session held in touchy equilibrium by the expectation of an announcement from Washington of the Treasury's advance refunding and cash borrowing plans.

Despite the crisis over Berlin, American companies planned in August to invest $3,290,000,000 in plants and equipment overseas next year, only slightly below the $3,430,000,000 to be spent this year. The sum ranks well ahead of the $2,800,000,000 spent in 1960, according to a survey of spending plans made by McGraw-Hill Publishing Company.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept 7 -- Miss Suzette Haven Waters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haven Trevor Waters of Lawrence, and Miss Dean da Silva Tyndall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Spellman Tyndall of Hewlett Neck, were honored jointly tonight by their parents at a dinner dance at the Rockaway Hunting Club here.

RYE N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Dr. Webster Stover, who has hung dirty rags on clotheslines in his front yard to protest taxes here, said tonight he and his wife had sold their home after "twenty-two years of persecution."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Kennedy has warned leaders of the steel industry that a price increase might require the Government to apply brakes to the economy that would retard recovery, keep unemployment high and hamper growth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Sept. 2, were 4 per cent above the year-ago level.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 -- Floyd B. Odlum, one of the nation's best-known financial figures, has ended a sixteen-month period of "retirement" to become chairman and senior officer of the Federal Resources Corporation.

DENVER, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Dave Hill of Denver led the field today in the first round of the $30,000 Denver open with an eight-under-par 32, 31 -- 63 over the 6,843-yard Meadow Hills course. Thirty-seven of the 102 golfers cracked par, with Bob Rosburg of Portland, Ore., closest to Hill with a 34, 31 -- 65.

MOSCOW, Sept. 7 -- Premier Khrushchev is prepared to meet again with President Kennedy in another effort "to resolve pressing international problems." He hopes that such a new encounter can be "fruitful" and that both sides "will display understanding."
An art scholar urged last night that each country accelerate the completion of photographic archives of its works of art because of the danger of destruction.

The J.I. Case Company increased its sales and sharply reduced its deficit in the quarter and nine months ended July 31, according to the report yesterday of William J. Grede, president of the farm equipment producer.
Officers of the Manufacturers Trust Company and the Hanover Bank moved swiftly yesterday to complete the merger of the two institutions.
FISHING has been described accurately enough as a contemplative sport and Lee Wulff, who knows a thing or two about it, says it is best practiced by "true believers."

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Lester A. Dixon, president of the Dixon Paper Company, said today that the Mead Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, would acquire his paper distributing company, together with some buildings, for $3,720,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Coffee Break won the $55,635.33 Fox Stake for 2-year-old pacers at the Indiana State Fair today, finishing more than half a length ahead of Meadow Grayson in a rain-postponed race-off.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Robert M. Blakeman, Valley Stream's Village Attorney and the Republican organization candidate for the State Assembly in the Sixth District, defeated two insurgents in Nassau County's only contest for public office in today's primaries.

Clarence D. Martin Jr., Under Secretary for Transportation in the Department of Commerce, told shipping leaders last night that an expanding Federal research and development program was designed to make American carriers "more competitive in the international transportation market."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 7 (UPI) -- The Rev. Arthur Garfield Wright of Detroit, a 64-year-old Baptist minister, died today seventeen, hours after he suffered a severe head injury in a riot at a church convention here.

MANY desserts such as refrigerator ice creams, mousses and souffles have both whipped cream and beaten egg whites folded into the basic mixture. To achieve maximum lightness and delicacy in the finished products, the following procedure for folding in the two ingredients is suggested.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Orioles exploded for five runs in the second inning tonight and defeated the Washington Senators, 6 -- 3. Milt Pappas, gaining his third straight victory and his sixth in his last eight starts, now has a won-lost record of 12 -- 7.

The general chairman for the April in Paris Ball, Mrs. Winston F.C. Guest, has announced the formation of a junior committee for the tenth anniversary event, which is to be held Oct. 20 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) A tax concession to cushion the divestiture of $3,000,000,000 of General Motors Corporation stock owned by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., passed its first congressional test today.

Title to the huge Ford Motor Company assembly plant in Edgewater, N.J., was acquired yesterday by Irving Maidman, New York realty investor, and K.B. Weisman, a banker. Ford had announced a plan for the sale of the property a few months ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A leading Government official warned today that any interference with the West's essential rights in Berlin would be "the straw that breaks the camel's back."

BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- Workers in a number of East German factories raised their own production quotas today in what appeared to be the start of a country-wide movement to produce more works for the same wages.
Confusion, voting-machine breakdowns and a flood of protests about electioneering marked New York's primary election yesterday.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Mrs. A. Brock Park of Deepdale and Mrs. J.B. Balding of The Creek scored 77's today and won duplicate prizes for low gross in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Class A one-day tournament at Fresh Meadow.

Gyro of the Jagma Stables provided a mild upset by winning the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. The colt was ridden to success by Eric Guerin in the six-furlong purse of $10,000. He beat William Ewing's Four Lane by three lengths.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- An official Army report made public today described Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker as "a sincere, deeply religious, patriotic soldier" but also as "an eccentric."

President Kennedy has addressed directly to the steel companies an appeal not to raise steel prices when wages in the industry go up next month. Voluntary action to prevent more inflation is of particular urgency in an industry that will play so crucial a role in the moves we are making to achieve greater military preparedness.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 25 cents a bale off on the July contract to 15 to 65 cents up on the other yesterday.

THERE was a woman named Hallgerda Hoskuldsdaughter. When she was a child at her father's stead in Laxdale near Hvamm Firth she wanted to be a queen. Her mother tried to teach her the duties of a good wife, how to discipline servants properly and to entertain guests hospitably, how to oversee the work in the wool house and the dairy.

STOWE, Vt., Sept. 7 -- In Vermont's peaceful green hills today, a group of Soviet and American scientists worked, despite the rising world tension, to draft a broad program of mutual collaboration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The seasonal upturn of freight loadings continued last week as compared with last year's depressed traffic, the American Trucking Associations reported today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Stockholders voted overwhelmingly today to merge the Standard Oil Company (Kentucky) and the Standard Oil Company of California, effective Oct 1.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 7 -- A Westchester team took the lead today in the second annual three-ring intersectional professional matches at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 7 -- Concrete aid to nationalists in Algeria and Angola has been promised by the governments that were represented in the conference of nonaligned nations. Conference sources said the help would be "diplomatic and practical," but refused to go into details.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- India's fishermen had their second-best year in 1960, with the catch and landings at 1,160,000 metric tons of 2,204 pounds each. The volume exceeded the pre ceding year's total by almost 340,000 tons, although it failed to equal the 1957 peak of 1,233,000 tons.
Mayor Wagner, running on an "anti-boss" platform, scored a smashing upset victory in yesterday's Democratic primary.
Borough Presidents Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan and Albert V. Maniscalco of Staten Island won the Democratic nominations for full four-year terms yesterday by decisive margins.
Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany Hall, was defeated in his own bailiwick yesterday.

The remarkable victory of Mayor Wagner in the Democratic primary yesterday represents a smashing defeat for New York City's hoary Democratic machine. It is a personal as well as political disaster for the three principal Democratic bosses of the city, Messrs, De Sapio of Manhattan, Buckley of the Bronx and Sharkey of Brooklyn.
ELISABETHVILLE, Sept. 7 (Reuters) -- United Nations troops were ordered today to shoot back if fired on as secessionist Katanga Province announced it was building up its forces in this capital city.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Britain announced today the further reinforcement of the British Army of the Rhine in West Germany.

GUATEMALA, Sept. 7 -- There were indications today that the Government of President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes might allow the establishment here of a Cuban government in exile.

WHILE driving in Ontario recently (to see a superb performance of "Love's Labour's Lost") I felt it my duty to denounce the boorishness of New York manners. Circumstances have made that impossible, as will presently appear.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara refused today to give a Senator the name of the person in the Pentagon immediately responsible for deleting anti-Communist statements from speeches by an Army general.
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- "The Fantasticks" received a mixed reception from the newspaper reviewers after its opening at the Apollo Theatre here tonight.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers made public tonight details of their new economic agreement. The union said it would give workers a net raise of 12.04 cents an hour.
OTTAWA, Sept. 7 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker said today Canada intended to increase her forces in the Atlantic alliance and her reserves at home because of the Berlin crisis.

Push-button outboard boating was inevitable in this day and age of automation. Evinrude has done it. This Milwaukee outboard manufacturer calls it Selectric Shift. It is a shift control offering completely simplified operation through electronic advances.
CHATHAM, N.J., Sept. 7 -- A major step toward creation of a national wildlife refuge in the Great Swamp of Morris County was approved by the Chatham Township Committee tonight.

Two news items just about canceled each other out yesterday in their impact on the stock market. NEW HAVEN, Sept. 7 -- Yale University exhibited its noted Charles E. Ives collection of music manuscripts and presented a concert of the late composer's works while being host today to the eighth Congress of the International Musicological Society.

The United States monetary gold stock remained unchanged at $17,452,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Charges that the Department of Defense had devised a procurement method to circumvent American shipping laws were leveled yesterday by Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 7 -- The second year of public school desegregation began peacefully here today when eight Negro pupils joined four who entered previously all-white classes last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The United States, Panama, Colombia and Ecuador were named today as members of a special inter-American investigating commission that to leave for the Dominican Republic next Tuesday.

In its open market operations for the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve System made the biggest addition to its outright holdings of United States Govern ment securities in at least ten years. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which reported the $642,404,000 increase, said that it brought the system's holdings to a record level of $27,902,000,000.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 7 -- The departure of Belgian military men from secessionist Katanga Province has become a familiar sight here.
Islip, L.I., borrowed $1,940,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept 7 -- "A Day on Round Hill," featuring a tour of notable homes and historic landmarks in the Round Hill section of Greenwich, will be held from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on September 21.

Sharp disagreement with Moscow's contentions that Soviet Jews are not interested in Jewish cultural and educational institutions was voiced yesterday by a group of B'nai B'rith officials. They returned Tuesday from a visit to the Soviet Union.
PARIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Dr. Joseph Berkson of the Mayo Clinic told a meeting of medical statisticians today they may be on the wrong track in linking lung cancer to cigarette smoking.
PARIS, Sept. 7 -- President de Gaulle's latest bid to settle the Algerian problem brought today the threat of a motion of censure by Socialists and other opponents of his policy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today a special investigation of sales practices of fifty-eight publishers and distributors of books, magazines, comics and paperbacks.
A Port Authority expert was named yesterday by the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to direct the new Tri-State Transportation Committee.
Insurgent candidates for Democratic nominations to the City Council won nine of eleven contests in yesterday's primary.
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Stock market prices advanced modestly in the important industrial sections here today.

TOKYO, Sept. 7 -- Dr. Earle L. Reynolds, an American pacifist teaching in Japan, said today that he would sail into the Soviet port of Vladivostok in protest against Moscow's decision to resume tests of nuclear weapons.
WARSAW, Sept. 7 -- War-fearful Poland reluctantly lost today the soothing presence of two of President Kennedy's sisters.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $20,000,000 to $57,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements dropped $72,000,000 to $530,000,000.
YONKERS, Sept. 7 -- Stephan Smith, enjoying a "perfect journey," took the Single G Pace in world-record time at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 7 -- The National Urban League will give more attention to international activities during the coming decade.
Officers of the World Council of Churches, in a statement made public yesterday, deplored the Soviet Union's resumption of tests of nuclear weapons.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Communist East German police showed increasing determination today to break up demonstrations by jeering West Berliners who gathered close to the barricades along the closed East-West Berlin border.

Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, a former United States titleholder; Ewfim Geller, Soviet Union, and Dr. Petar Trifunovic, the champion of Yugoslavia, were tied for the lead at 2 1/2 -- 1/2 after three rounds of the chess tournament at Bled, according to a report from Yugoslavia yesterday.

Directors of Heublein, Inc., recommended yesterday a three-for-one stock split, and approved other changes involving recapitalization. The Hartford, Conn., manufacturer and importer of foods, wines, and liquors, also reported record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended on June 30.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The United States Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals freed today a hijacked freighter for return to Cuba. The court stayed its order for five days to permit an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to permit French troops in the forces of the Atlantic Alliance to be trained in the use of nuclear weapons.

"The Gallic Approach" and "The Teutonic Approach" to music will come under the scrutiny of Leonard Bernstein when he conducts the New York Philharmonic in two six-week periods during the forthcoming season.

AN elderly woman who is a day-to-day resident in a Salvation Army home was discovered recently pawning her few remaining possessions to pay her room rent of $2.50 a night. The effort was unnecessary because the Army would have made allowances.

IN honor of the twentieth International Congress of Art History, an art world summit conference, now being held in New York, the Museum of Modern Art will open today two special exhibitions. They will remain on view throughout the autumn.
Burlington Industries,. Inc., has expanded its European textile operations through an agreement with Cyril Lord, Ltd., a British manufacturer of carpets, woven goods and surgical products.
The city's public schools opened their doors yesterday to more than a million pupils, the largest number in twenty years.

ROGER HOWE GILMAN is a transportation economist whose abiding passion is the efficient movement of people and goods. Sometimes his problem is a multi-million dollar bridge. Sometimes it is adding four feet to the depth of a ship channel in the harbor, or putting a parking lot near a tunnel, or setting up an express shuttle bus service.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 7 -- Voting was light today in Westchester's primary election. There were no contests for countywide nominations, although an exceptional number of local contests were settled.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- in the discussions of Berlin in the embassies here these days there is considerable talk about the possibility of internationalizing that city under the United Nations.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 -- The Republican national chairman demanded tonight that the Administration let his party participate in domestic and foreign affairs.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 7 -- The head of the John Birch Society filed suit in United States District Court here today charging Fawcett Publications of Greenwich, Conn., with having infringed on his copyright on "The Blue Book of the John Birch Society."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Following are excerpts from a speech today by Paul H. Nitze, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, to the Association of the United States Army, on military policy in the Berlin crisis:
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Hurricane Carla roared toward the United States Gulf coast today, and at the same time a new tropical storm, Debbie, was born in the Atlantic.
News of the possible settlement of the Chilean copper strike increased trading and reduced prices of copper futures yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 7 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion declined today to form a new Israeli Government. He balked at demands by potential coalition partners for more supervision over the administration, particularly the defense establishment.

IT was reported here last week that the Washington (D.C.) Bridge League, which for years had openly barred Negroes from tournaments of the American Contract Bridge League, held a referendum among its members on integration. The members voted, 624 to 279, to permit Negroes to play.
BUFFALO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Incumbent Frank A. Sedita was upset by a total of 514 votes in the Democratic mayoral primary tonight. He lost to City Councilman Victor E. Manz, 25,336 to 24,822.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 7 -- Foreign Minister Manzoor Qadir said today that the Afghan Government had refused to allow the British Embassy in Kabul to look after Pakistan's interests in Afghanistan following the severance of diplomatic relations between the two countries yesterday.
The General Electric Company was accused yesterday of having refused to extend a union contract for even one day to prevent last fall's three-week strike against the company.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 7 -- Forty parents of pupils of the Glenfield School protested the reopening of the predominantly Negro school today by picketing it.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Lynn Wanamaker of Southampton, L.I., rode her 8-year-old bay gelding Trade Winds to victory in the Smithtown Hunt Challenge Trophy event for working hunters as the twenty-eighth North Shore horse show opened at the Old Field Club today.
NEWCASTLE, N.H., Sept. 7 -- The executive committee of the Governors' Conference approved today a proposal for Governors of sixteen states to meet on railroad problems.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 7 -- Chancellor Adenauer said today that the West German forces would "probably" retain 36,000 conscripts who are eligible for discharge Sept. 28.
BEDFORD, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Leon Grosjean gave a dinner dance at their home here tonight to present their daughter, Miss Diane Davies Grosjean.

TRENTON, Sept. 7 -- The state Commissioner of Education today upheld the saying of grace before eating and the singing of Christmas carols and Hanukkah songs in the Freehold public schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, appealed today to American cities and communities to provide jobs for the thousands of skilled Cuban refugees who are now concentrated in southern Florida.

Leaders of major American Jewish religious and secular groups appealed yesterday in Rosh ha-Shanah messages for the strengthening of every phase of Jewish life as well as intensified financial support for Israel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Fourteen freshman Republican members of the House unveiled today what they called "Operation Survival."

Your Sept. 3 editorial "The Quest for Water" rightly points out that the difficulty in saline water conversion is to do it cheaply enough. It is surprising that the "cost" figures you cite are so completely misleading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Senate investigators started looking today into alleged efforts by gamblers to corrupt college football.

A NEW fall collection of one-piece wool maternity dresses offers the advantage of ingenious devices that make the clothes wearable before and after the baby arrives.
