HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- Hollywood has been given the go-ahead by Los Angeles County to help wipe out the rash of smutty films current in Southern California.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Anson Beard Jr., champion of the Great South Bay fleet, increased his lead for the Atlantic Coast championship of the International Star Class today by winning the fourth race of the series being sailed off Larchmont Y.C. with his white-hulled sloop, Tsunami.
Government officials of African countries toured the Bronx Zoo yesterday and saw some African animals.

DALLAS, Sept. 7 -- A man stood at a drugstore counter here today methodically buying a dollar's worth of 10-and 15-cent items one by one, having the clerk ring up each transaction separately. That way he evaded Texas's first sales tax -- 3 per cent on transactions exceeding 25 cents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Kennedy Administration, in effect, broke the 4 1/4 per cent interest rate ceiling on Government bonds today. Actually, the Administration did away with the rate ceiling by a legal ruling last April, so -- for the purposes of a transaction such as today's -- there is no ceiling.

A new development has affected Dore Schary's list of great expectations. He will get busy with the direction and co-sponsorship of the newly acquired "Something About a Soldier," a play derived from Mark Harris' book (Macmillan) and written by Ernest Kinoy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The State Department has denied Premier Khrushchev's contention that there are similarities between the proposed Soviet peace treaty with East Germany and the Japanese peace treaty that was signed without Soviet participation in 1951.

THERE is only one major change in food prices this week, and it is an expected one. The advent of Rosh ha-Shanah brings with it a 20-cent jump in the cost of yellow pike and whitefish. Chicken carp steak is more conservative, with a 10-cent increase. There has been no price action in saltwater varieties.
LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Sept. 7 -- More than a month of violence has indicated the extent of the African opposition to Britain's proposals for a new Northern Rhodesian Constitution.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 7 -- A strong interior line and a well-balanced backfield encourage hopes that Lehigh's football team will get back on the alkaline side after three losing seasons in a row -- a phenomenon in the sixteen-year reign of Bill Leckonby, the winningest coach in the university's history.

BOSTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A single hit with a broken bat by Chuck Schilling, a Red Sox rookie, sent the Detroit Tigers to their seventh straight defeat today, 8 -- 4, after Frank Malzone hit a three-run homer.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7 -- Gail Wild of the Greenwich Country Club and Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of Winged Foot led a field of seventy-seven in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association tournament today with 80's on the par-74 Tamarack course.
James S. Lanigan lives only a few doors from Carmine G. De Sapio on Washington Square West. There the similarities end.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg told Congress today that unemployment insurance benefits were not adequate.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Eleven elementary schools that are largely white opened today with enlarged classes that included Negroes transferred from Lincoln School at the request of parents.

The Jerrold Electronics Corporation is expanding its operations further through the acquisition of the Technical Appliance Corporation (Taco) for $2,700,000 in bash, it was announced yesterday by Sidney Harman, president of Jerrold.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- The Jewel Tea Company announced today that it had joined three Belgian corporations in organizing a new concern to develop a self-service chain of department stores.

President de Gaulle of France has given another manifestation of his capacity for practical realism in offering political sovereignty over the French Sahara to an independent Algeria willing to cooperate with France. His offer marked a distinct shift from France's previous stand that France would not concede control over the Sahara to an independent Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The space agency announced today that a Government-owned ordnance plant near New Orleans had been picked as the site of a $50,000,000 project to fabricate stages for moon rockets.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Democrats in the Senate accused Governor Rockefeller today of overlooking the national interest in an effort to win the support of New York State dairy interests.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Selling pressure continued in soybeans almost without let-up today and prices on the Board of Trade again were weak, with some contracts at or near their lows of the season.
Four New York advertising agencies are starting market research studies in nine countries this week for the United States Travel Service.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- It looks as if it may cost a nickel to mail a letter, starting next year.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Four books, one of them a Pulitzer Prize winner, have been removed from local school libraries on recommendation of the Chatham County grand jury.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 7 -- Despite certain obvious shortcomings, the New York Repertory Company was received warmly by audiences and critics in Mexico City, its last stop on a two-month tour of Latin America.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Following is the text of a letter written by President Kennedy yesterday to the heads of twelve steel companies:

The commercial building containing 32,000 square feet of space at 49 Edison Place, Newark, has been purchased by Court House Park Building, Inc., representing Al Rubin and Harry Busch. It was sold by Blonder Tongue Laboratories. Michael R. Gingold, head of the commercial property department of Leslie Blau, was the broker.

Production of electric power in the nation reached a record of 16,214,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Sept. 2, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This figure compared with 15,491,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 15,353,000,000 in the 1960 week.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association today amended its rule requiring champions to defend every six months by permitting Floyd Patterson to defend the world heavyweight title once a year.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that potential school "dropouts" in seven cities would be given special training this fall in an effort to increase their chances of getting a job.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- President Kennedy signed legislation yesterday that gives national recognition and financial support to a Pearl Harbor memorial. It will honor all Americans who lost their lives in the Pacific in World War II.

The nation's inventories of gasoline declined by 976,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the week-end, total supplies were 190,280,600 barrels, compared with 191,256,000 a week earlier and 188,665,000 a year ago.

ON the corner of Broadway and Eightieth Street is a handsome little store that owes virtually everything but its outer walls to Israel. At the Galil Confectionery and Gift Shop, 2239 Broadway, all the wares are imported and even the manager came from Israel as recently as two years ago.

"The Autobiography of Eleanor Roosevelt" has been scheduled for Sept. 25 publication by Harper. The 454-page volume contains material selected from Mrs. Roosevelt's three earlier books of memoirs with new material added that brings her story up to date.
An order for twenty French Caravelle jetliners at a cost of nearly $100,000,000 was announced by Trans World Airlines yesterday.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., Sept. 7 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood and LaJunta White of Englewood will meet Mrs. Philip Cudone of Forest Hill and Mrs. Joseph Rudnick of Jumping Brook in the final round of the Garden State Women's Golf Association better-ball-of-partners championship.

LONDON, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- Britain's giant General Electric Company, Ltd. (G.E.C.) is likely to manufacture some goods in Common Market countries if Britain joins that group. It also would establish a system of licensing and cross-licensing Arnold Lindley, chairman, told stockholders today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- The Ryewood team of Skip DiBiccari and Herb Hendlin posted a 35, 31 -- 66 best ball today and won the Westchester Professional Golfers Association's pro-amateur event at the Ridgeway Country Club by one stroke.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 7 (AP) -- A Titan missile was launched here tonight, the second in two days. The flight tested the inertial guidance system of a more powerful model of the Air Force's intercontinental range weapon.
Joseph R. Weiss, suspended Deputy Superintendent of Schools, pleaded not guilty to charges of improper conduct at a Board of Education hearing yesterday.

JIMMIE DYKES has been part of the baseball scene for a long time. He now is a study in slow motion as the manager of the Cleveland Indians, but he once was a nimble third baseman on the Philadelphia Athletics, a bearcat at handling his position and a dependable batsman. In fact, he made 2,256 hits during his career, a statistic he will supply at the slightest hint.

MEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 7 -- In seven seasons as football coach at Tufts University, Harry Arlanson has never had a losing campaign. He has every reason to believe the 1961 season will follow the pattern.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 7 -- The Government was pressing tonight to settle the long strike that has closed several big copper mines in Chile owned by United States concerns.

THE homemaker viewing her city abode after a summer away may feel the entire house needs a new face. Presumably well-rested and armed with imagination and a small reserve of funds, she may want to tackle the job room by room.

As a stranger to your country (I arrived here a week ago) and as a traveler and explorer of this city it is with great pleasure that I say many thanks to all New Yorkers I have come into contact with for their unfailing courtesy, friendliness, advice, real interest in my impressions of this land.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 7 -- Belgrade residents can relax at last. This status-seeking capital is lapsing into a belated summer lassitude after months filled with hectic preparations and the heady week of the "konferencija," the meeting of leaders of the nonaligned nations that gave Belgrade a most cosmopolitan air.
WORCESTER, Mass. Sept. 8 -- There is a feeling in New England college football circles that Dr. Eddie Anderson is fashioning a Holy Cross eleven that may become one of the East's best.
TRENTON, Sept. 8 -- A state agency said today that more than a tenth of the residential areas in northeast Jersey needed renewal, either clearance, conservation or reclamation.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 -- Polly Bergen, the actress, who says she agreed to appear in a film under a contract that called for its use in television, filed suit for $1,000,000 damages in Superior Court today. The complaint said that the film is about to be exhibited in theatres.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency ordered eight airlines today to inspect a key control linkage on certain Constellation planes within the next twenty-five hours.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Benjamin Dranow, linked by the Senate rackets committee to what it called "the peculiar financial manipulations" of James R. Hoffa, was indicted today on three counts of income tax evasion by a Federal grand jury in Minneapolis.

Carmine G. De Sapio, badly whipped in the primary Thursday, will lose his post as New York County Democratic leader before the end of the month. But it appeared highly unlikely last night that his successor would be chosen until after the Nov. 7 election.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 8 -- Talks by political leaders to form a new coalition of parties to govern Israel appeared today to be close to a deadlock.

BRASILIA, Sept. 7 -- If compromise, persuasion and the small bargaining of party politics are the heart of the parliamentary system of government, Dr. Tancredo Neves may well be the right man for the Premiership of Brazil.

Bad as things were everywhere Thursday for Carmine G. De Sapio, they were worst for him in his home election district in Greenwich Village. There he finished sixth in a field of six running for three places on the Democratic county committee.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles extended their longest winning streak of the season to seven games tonight by sweeping a doubleheader from the Washington Senators, 2 -- 1 and 4 -- 2.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 8 -Bruce Huston of Rochester won the international Dragon Class sailing series off Newport today as he finished ninth in the final race.
Mayor Wagner received thousands of telegrams and telephone calls yesterday from friends and well-wishers congratulating him on his decisive victory in the Democratic mayoral primary on Thursday.

There was a lot of Democratic -- and even a bit of Republican -- praise yesterday for Mayor Wagner's landslide victory over the Democratic organization in Thursday's primary election. Former President Harry S. Truman, who is visiting here, said that the city Democrats "made a good choice" and that "New York is lucky to have" Mayor Wagner.
John P. Cartwright has been named vice president, machinery group, of Dresser Industries, Inc. He was a vice president and general manager of the Joy Manufacturing Company.

ATHENS, Sept. 8 -- Lieut. Gen. George Grivas, who after his return from Cyprus two years ago founded a party in hope of becoming Premier of Greece, lost most of his party Deputies tonight. General Grivas said he would decide later what he would do.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold asked United States authorities here today to undertake a "common study" with the United Nations of the problem of protecting visiting diplomats.

The Department of Justice sued yesterday to block the merger of the Manufacturers Trust Company and the Hanover Bank minutes after the banks filed merger papers with the New York State Banking Department here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- "Shocking," "disgraceful," and "highly dangerous" were descriptions applied by Senators today to the use of United States Army forces in the filming of a Jack Paar television show in West Berlin yesterday.
SHEILA CATHERINE JONES, known to most of her friends as Casey, is being married today in a $40 dress that she copied from a $925 design by Norman Norell.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A retired Air Force general has patented an aerial camera to take automatic photographs of a nuclear bomb explosion from the plane that drops the bomb.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Sept. 8 (AP) -- President Kennedy returned to Cape Cod late today to celebrate his eighth wedding anniversary with his wife and family.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 8 -- A group of Negro parents who object to the reopening of Glen-field School indicated today that they were prepared for a protracted fight.

Americans went down to defeat on the stadium, grandstand and outside courts at Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday. As in 1958, the United States is left without a representative in the semi-finals of the men's national tennis championship.

The Western Union Telegraph Company sent shareholders warrants yesterday under a previously proposed financing plan. The warrants evidenced rights to subscribe to 1,069,451 shares of the company's common stock at $40 a share.
Sparked by a $100,000,000 financing by California and one of $46,756,000 by Massachusetts, the market for new capital will be active next week, although few other major issues are in the offing.

Associates of State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that bitter dissension had raged for weeks at Democratic headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel over the strategy and tactics to be employed in the primary.
BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- A statement by an East German legal expert was regarded here today as a new hint that the Communists might interfere with civilian air traffic in the three air corridors to Berlin.
DETROIT, Sept. 8 -- The General Motors Corporation continued to be harassed today by wildcat strikes. If kept up they would threaten to cripple automobile production.

Investors have bought 8814 Bay Parkway, corner of Cropsey Avenue, Brooklyn, a six-story apartment building on plot 150 by 96 feet. The property contains seventy-one apartments and is assessed at $260,000. It was sold by the Donna 57 Avenue O Realty Company, which bought it a month go.

A BOOK that was written by "somebody exactly like you" and published by E.P. Dutton and Co. ($4.95), reached local book stores yesterday. According to the author, Lila Perl, "What Cooks in Suburbia" was not written by 'the white-coated chemist cooks of some stainless steel test kitchen" but a regular homemaker -- albeit with the advantage of having studied home economics.
The Fire Department bestowed its departmental certificate of merit for bravery on a civilian yesterday for the first time in departmental history.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- Premier Khrushchev outlined today his conditions for negotiating with the West on Berlin. He stipulated that such talks must be held soon and that they must result in a German peace treaty.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- On its first anniversary as a sovereign state last June 26, the Malagasy Republic, the world's fourth largest island, had cause for further congratulation -- a $7,000,000 reduction in its trade deficit was reported for 1960.
Renata Tebaldi said yesterday she would not sing at the Metropolitan Opera next season because the company's cancellation of a starring vehicle for her had not been made in good faith.

After spending one evening listening to works by three contemporary American composers and another to works by that singular American phenomenon, Charles Ives, the august members of the International Musicological Society turned their attention last night to music that is more than 450 years old.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The Atlantic Coast championship of the International Star Class remained undecided today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Long touchdown passes by Ed Brown and Bill Wade sparked the Chicago Bears to a 24-21 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in an exhibition game between the National Football League teams tonight.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 -- John M. Bailey, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, charged tonight that Republican attacks on Administration foreign policy gave aid and comfort to the enemy.

DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Donut King and Rattle Dancer headed a field of fifteen 2-year-old horses entered today in tomorrow's $106,390 Del Mar Futurity. The race is the richest in the history of this seaside course.
WILTON, Conn., Sept. 8 -- The Goodwill Industries of Western Connecticut found itself in a dispute today with the Zoning Commission here over one of its collection boxes.
I note that the speed limits on some New York City expressways have been increased, with the new limits based on studies of the extent to which motorists have ignored the previous limits.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (API) -- The Democratic National Chairman, John M. Bailey, cleared Paul Corbin, his special assistant, today of charges of having worked for Communist causes.

A hail of assorted objects, thrown from the United States Realty Building at 115 Broadway, forced the police to close two streets between Broadway and Trinity Place yesterday. It was the second day in a row that debris had been thrown from the building.
Trading in copper futures were again active yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York, following Thursday's heavy trading.

Despite appeals by both President Kennedy and former President Eisenhower for adequate foreign aid in this "climactic hour in the fight for freedom," Congress is still wrestling with the question as to how far it will actually finance the program it has authorized. The House has restored some of the funds cut by frenetic opponents, and the Senate may restore some more.
Edward L. Nash said yesterday he was gathering evidence for State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to support his charges of fraud in Thursday's primary.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg presented a union scholarship award to two Negro students today in recognition of their work in civil rights.
STORRS, Conn., Sept. 8 -- Connecticut, a booming university and a rising football power under Coach Bob Ingalls, eagerly awaits the coming gridiron campaign.
The Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad Company announced yesterday that the company would mail to stockholders on Sept. 11 an offer to purchase the company's shares at $100 a share.

MONZA, Italy, Sept. 8 -Richie Ginther's Ferrari averaged more than 133 miles an hour around the 6.2-mile Auto-drome track today to lead the qualifiers for Sunday's Grand Prix of Italy, the final European race counting toward the driver's world championship.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Quietly, a new course of study is being presented in public high schools across the country. The subject is world communism, what it is and how it works.

Bad feeling and lack of cooperation between South Vietnam and Cambodia have long hindered countermeasures against Communist guerrillas operating in jungle areas bisected by the border between the two countries. When attacked by security forces in South Vietnam, Communist bands have sought sanctuary by slipping into neutral Cambodia, where they have even had extensive base camps.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- A 22-year-old East Berlin truck driver crashed through the heavily guarded Brandenburg Gate today in the most spectacular Berlin escape since the Communists sealed the border nearly a month ago. Hans Boehm, accelerating his state-owned delivery truck to sixty miles an hour, smashed through the wooden barrier and swept past Communist guards clustered at the gate.
BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Red Sox beat the fading Detroit Tigers, 9 -- 2, tonight.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Dick Ellsworth pitched his third three-hitter of the season today to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 4-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- A chemical test designed to reduce confusion about the relation between cholesterol in the blood and the presence of heart disease was described here today to the American Chemical Society's 140th national meeting.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Administration officials are augmenting the President's public appeals for steel-price restraint by private approaches to industry leaders.

The Securities and Exchange Commission was notified yesterday of financing plans by two credit concerns. A registration statement was filed by the Japan Development Bank concerning a $20,000,000 external loan, and another was filed by the Commercial Credit Company covering a proposed exchange of stock with City Loan and Savings Company, Lima, Ohio.
SOUTHOLD, L.I., Sept. 8 -- An organization of residents and summer residents will dedicate an observatory Sunday afternoon in this North Shore community.

Critics of the Federal Government's recently reorganized maritime agencies were assured yesterday that one of their major complaints against the agencies -- "the veil of anonymity" in regulatory decisions -- would be lifted.

One of Gary Bell's pitches hovered a split second too long in Mickey Mantle's strike zone last night at the Stadium. Before the Cleveland right-hander had time to say, "Shucks, there goes No. 52," it was gone. A crowd of 41,762 watched its flight.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 8 -- Mayor Willy Brandt said tonight that a Socialist-led Government in West Germany would work out with its allies the basic principles of a peace treaty for all Germany.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today auto production this week would drop to 82,655 passenger cars because of the Labor Day holiday and wildcat walkouts at some General Motors Corporation plants.

Christopher T. Chenery's Cicada, the winner of the Spin-away and the Schuylerville at Saratoga in her last two starts, is the 6-5 favorite among thirteen 2-year-old fillies named for the $101,390 Matron Stakes at Belmont Park today.
ALTHOUGH it started as a fairly austere railroad station, Grand Central Terminal has become one of Manhattan's brightest, busiest and best-known shopping centers.

Round and round and round they went, in a looping orbit stretched between the Ninth Avenue and the Eighth Avenue ends of the once new Madison Square Garden in the Nineteen Twenties, and they were rounders, may one say, to conjure with.

The conduct of twenty more Board of Education employes suspected of having accepted gratuities from contractors or of having committed other improprieties is being examined by a special committee of school officials.
With great interest I read all the speeches made at the conference of nonaligned nations in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, reported in The Times of Sept. 4.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A variety of influences contributed to a generally strong grain futures market today, with wheat and rye gaining a cent or more on almost all contracts. Other grains and soybeans finished with advances in major fractions in spots.

Steel profits, their function and their comparison with profits of other industries, may figure prominently in steel producers' eventual replies to President Kennedy's attempt to head off any price increases.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants, with long home runs by Willie Mays, Orlando Cepeda and Jim Davenport, beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7 -- 3, tonight. The defeat dropped the Dodgers two games behind the league-leading Cincinnati Reds.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 8 -- knobby knees and all, the Cain Hoy Stable's Battle Joined will be favored to take the World's Playground Stakes at the Atlantic City Race Course tomorrow.
THERE were twice as many dancers in the audience at the City Center last night as there were on the stage.
The election of Roy L. Ash as president of Litton Industries, Inc., was announced yesterday by Charles B. Thornton, chairman and chief executive officer of the electronics company.

PARSIPPANY, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Ch. Roadcoach Roadster, owned by Mrs. S.K. Allman of Doylestown, Pa., and handled by Charles Meyer, was named the best of breed at the Dalmatian Club of America's annual specialty show today at The Harbor.
Dr Warren Weaver was elected president of the Public was announced yesterday.
HAVANA, Sept. 8 -- Five rebel prisoners taken after the unsuccessful landings at the Bay of Pigs last April were sentenced to death tonight. Nine others were given thirty-year jail terms.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The United States Weather Bureau reported that the radioactive debris from the first Soviet explosion, which took place Sept. 1, was moving today in a 500-mile-wide band across the Great Lakes area and the northeastern part of the country.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept 8 -- New Jersey won the second annual metropolitan intersectional professional golf team matches today. The victors' two-day total was 42 1/2 points, to 36 for Westchester and 29 1/2 for Long Island.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- A move by Pakistan to put the issue of nuclear weapons testing before the General Assembly as a matter of priority was stalled temporarily today -- apparently by opposition from participants in the recent Belgrade conference of nonaligned nations.

To pour or not to pour? That is a question occasionally posed for many a host or hostess if they are presented with a bottle of wine by a dinner guest. Should the wine be poured on the evening it is received? The answer is in most cases no.

The story of Joan of Arc, a source of inspiration to authors ranging from Mark Twain to Bernard Shaw and actresses as varied as Ingrid Bergman and Jean Seberg, is being filmed again by one of France's finest directors, Robert Bresson.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- There is no paradise except that which can be manufactured on this earth. Such, at any rate, is the firm belief of Mr. Khrushchev. He sent Majors Gagarin and Titov to investigate the problem and they reported in the negative.
The National Association of the Pet Industry, which opened its annual exhibition yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel, would have given Old Mother Hubbard quite a start.

AMERICANS in France these days are sometimes as busy as the French fur-trading leaders were in the New World at the time of Louis XIV. That delayed counter-tide of business enterprise has aspects of the sincerest form of flattery. Also, of course, it leads to a certain amount of friction -- as Edwin Gilbert shows us in his lively, probing novel, "The New Ambassadors.''*
The danger of inflation continues to be a matter of debate among economists.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 6 to 15 points yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
A married couple has been barred from tile securities business in New York State for promoting an unsound $750 000 "speculation in slums," Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.
WARSAW, Sept. 8 -- The Government disclosed today that it had set out to take control of the religious instruction of Polish children.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 8 -- Gathering together 4,000 paintings and sculptures and a couple of thousand other objects and getting them properly installed for exhibition is job enough without a political crisis thrown in to tie things up.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- There were growing indications tonight that the United States was preparing to send as many as 38,000 troops to bolster its forces in Europe.

Any military officer might be pleased to be described, as Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker was in an official Army report, as "a sincere, deeply religious, patriotic soldier dedicated to the nation and the Army." However, General Walker was relieved of his command of the Twenty-fourth Infantry Division in West Germany last April, reprimanded and transferred to a less important post.
Plans by Trans World Airlines to train pilots in the use of a new self-contained navigation device embroiled the carrier in a sharp dispute with its navigators yesterday.

New York State Education Commissioner James E. Alien Jr. has given the Board of Regents a "memorandum" for future action which deserves immediate attention. His "Goals and Plans for Education in New York State" should be regarded as something far more important than discussion topics; they can, and must, become a program to avert the kind of chaos exposed by the recent New York City school investigations.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Plenty of passing is expected tomorrow night when the Boston Patriots and the New York Titans open the American Football League's sophomore season at Boston University field. Kickoff is 8 o'clock Eastern daylight time.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 8 -- Sixty-two volunteers of the United States Peace Corps arrived here today.

Directors of the Stanley Works yesterday elected Garth W. Edwards as vice president for finance and Donald W. Davis as a vice president. Howard L. Richardson, president, also announced the appointment of William E. De Caulp as director of employe and public relations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A football player for the University of Oregon told a Senate subcommittee today that he thwarted a bribery scheme last fall. He said two gamblers had offered him $5,000 to fix the Oregon-Michigan game so that Michigan would win by at least eight points. Michigan won the game, 21 -- 0.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Eddie Kasko's single in the tenth inning tonight enabled the Cincinnati Reds to post a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
WASHINGTON, Sept 8 (AP) -- The Army reported today the successful use of electricity as an anesthetic for a human patient.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- John W. Merriam, a land developer, has settled with the Cedarbrook Country Club for its 150-acre tract at Cheltenham Avenue and Limekiln Pike. The purchase price was $2,150,000.
MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- The Soviet Union is considering the use of artificial gravity in space ships if weightlessness proves to be a problem.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Two Brooklyn, N.Y., physicians reported statistical evidence today of an association between heavy cigarette smoking and coronary heart disease. Their report appeared in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 8 -- The Duffy Stables' McLain Street took a one-point lead in the battle for the jumper championship during the second day of the twenty-eighth North Shore Horse Show at the Old Field Club today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Western powers gave Moscow another solemn warning today against interference with their flights across East Germany into West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Senate passed tonight a modified version of President Kennedy's bill to create a permanent disarmament agency. The roll-call vote was 73 to 14.
Your editorial of Sept. 4 "Megalopolitan Myopia" is a disservice to the future of our people.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 5 -- 3, tonight on Minnie Minoso's two-run homer in the tenth inning.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- White flowers and garlands of green leaves adorned the ballroom of the Shenorock Shore Club here this evening for the twenty-third annual Westchester Cotillion.

Peter J. Thelen, 20 years old, pleaded guilty in Adolescent Court yesterday to a disorderly conduct charge stemming from an attack on a detective Thursday night. At least a dozen persons went to the aid of the embattled policeman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Senator Strom Thurmond Democrat of South Carolina made a new effort today to learn which Pentagon censors deleted specific portions from speeches by military officers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon cautioned today against "exaggerated speculation" based on the size of this year's budget deficit. He said the deficit should not be inflationary.
NEW CASTLE, N.H., Sept. 8 -- The executive committee of the Governors' Conference decided unanimously today to end the exchange of gifts at annual meetings.

Certain sections of the high-grade bond market were affected sharply yesterday by the implications of the Treasury's plan for an advance refunding of $7,600,000,000 of war debt not due until 1970 and 1971.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 8 -- Enrollment of whites increased substantially today at three of this city's six desegregated schools.

Production of lumber totaled 224,761,000 board feet in the week ended Sept. 2. This figure compared with 226,026,000 board feet the week before, according to reports' received from regional associations. A year ago 216,998,000 board feet were produced.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 8 -- The three-day visit here of Joey Adams and his troupe as part of President Kennedy's Special International Program for Cultural Relations has been a great success. Such was the demand for the tickets that an extra performance was arranged.
NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood and LaJunta White of Englewood today won the second annual Garden State Women's Golf Association better-ball-of-partner's tournament.

FORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 8 -- The wind failed for the third day's competition of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's annual Race Week sailing today. The result was that only Howard McMichael's Kangaroo in the International Class and John Potter's Va Vite in one of two Catamaran classes gained victories.

MOUNT HALEAKALA, Hawaii, Sept. 4 -- Electric lights have begun to appear among the stars. Carried by Discoverer satellites, they are turned on briefly by radio command to be photographed by a telescopic camera atop this volcano.
PARIS, Sept. 8 -- France received with official interest today the declarations looking toward a settlement of the Bizerte issue by President Bourguiba.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Dan Waern, Sweden's star miler, turned professional today. He had been banned by the International Amateur Athletic Federation and was in trouble with the Government for allegedly taking under-the-table payments.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Directors of National Newark Essex Banking Company today announced plans for a five-for-two stock split and an increase in the capital stock by selling an additional 100,000 shares of new stock.

An exhibition of old prints opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in honor of the twentieth International Congress of the History of Art now in session at Columbia and New York Universities.
TUNIS, Sept. 8 -- President Habib Bourguiba proposed today an agreement permitting France to retain her naval and air base near Bizerte "during the present world crisis."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Senate Labor Committee approved today President Kennedy's college-scholarships bill.

Disguised as a Negro by special medication, John Howard Griffin toured the South in the fall of 1959. He hitchhiked, walked, and rode buses through Mississippi, Alabama, Louisiana and Georgia. He learned firsthand the difficulties of obtaining the simple courtesies white men take for granted.

The Gettysburg School Authority, Pa., has sold $1,465,000 of lease revenue bonds due serially from 1963 to 1991 to Drexel Co. and associates at an interest cost of 3.5225 per cent. The obligations were re-offered to investors at prices to yield from 2 to 3.75 per cent.
DENVER, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Dave Hill stroked a seven-under-par 64 today for the halfway lead at 127 -- one over the Professional Golfers Association record -- in the $30,000 Denver golf open.
STOWE, Vt. Sept. 8 -- Soviet and United States scientists neared agreement today on far-reaching proposals for international status for the moon and the planets.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Hurricane Carla, a "large and dangerous" storm affecting the entire Gulf of Mexico, moved toward land tonight, pushing high tides to the Louisiana and Texas coasts.
BRASILIA, Sept. 8 -- The Brazilian Congress gave an overwhelming vote of approval tonight to Premier Tancredo Neves and his new coalition Cabinet.
GREENE, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Monroe H. Sweet, 46 years old, a Binghamton physicist and inventor, died today in the crash of his private plane.

SYLVESTER LOWERY of Philadelphia wrote recently to correct a report of a tournament hand that appeared in this space.

Buildings Commissioner Peter J. Reidy ordered all twenty families living at 283 West 147th Street yesterday to vacate the tenement within ten days. He acted after an inspector found a two-foot accumulation of sewage in the basement.
HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 8 (AP) -- The 12,500-ton British freighter Wheat King docked here today and got a familiar welcome -- a line of pickets.

Stock prices reacted yesterday from their new 1961 high marks. Brokers ascribed the weakness to international uncertainties, to lightening up for the Rosh ha-Shanah holiday starting tomorrow, and to President Kennedy's warning that steel prices must not be raised.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges administered a temporary setback today to plans of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to build two huge ore carriers with Government construction subsidies.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz declared yesterday that the State Investigation Commission had a duty to the public to disclose any information it might have relating to Mayor Wagner's official conduct.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Turnover remained small in the stock market here today, and the movements of industrial shares were again irregular. Most transactions were said to be for comparatively small parcels of shares, and the level of trading was at times barely sufficient to test prices.

Dick Company, has leased a new building and two acres of land on Edison Place, off Springfield Avenue, in Springfield, N.J. American tourists returning today and henceforth from foreign spending sprees will find that the price has gone up.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Generally favorable weather in August raised the official forecast of this year's cotton crop by 344,000 bales to put prospective production at 14,262,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight.

Dodd called today for a Congressional investigation of the United States Information Agency and for the dismissal of one of its specialists in Russian affairs. ATLANTA, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The third wife of Richard J. Reynolds won a new trial today of a divorce action brought against her by the heir to a tobacco fortune.

A bill to ease the tax burden of the 225,000 shareholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., gained in Congress last week.

PARIS. THE past two or three years have brought a veritable bloom of pavement art to Paris. It all began, so it is said, when a certain citizen, who had had one too many sank into the gutter and began to draw on the sidewalk with a piece of chalk.

LENINGRAD, Sept. 9 -- The opera season opened here tonight at the Kirov Theatre, a fine old traditional house in cream, gold and light blues, with good acoustics and bad sight lines, with dancing angels on the ceiling and an attentive, delighted proletariat in the seats.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- Three unearned runs in the eighth inning sent the San Francisco Giants to a 9-6 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today in a wild game that was damaging to both teams.

Soaring temperatures and the return of the city's children to school caused retail sales in the area last week to fall below the level of a year ago. The turnover in department stores dipped 5 to 6 per cent from the comparable 1960 week, according to leading department store officials.

BILLY BLUESAGE was like a bird of the high places -- shy and hard to approach. The wild boy traveled like a mountain breeze on Bocla, a horse "part mustang, part Arabian, part lightning." When bandits or Indians threatened trail parties, Billy glided down to warn the travelers.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 9 -- W.M. Schwarz won the ninth annual Commodore's predicted-log contest today that closed the 1961 season in the New York area. More boats registered than in any other contest this year.

Department store sales in the Federal Reserve district for the week ended Sept. 2 showed an increase of 2 per cent from the 1960 level. The four-week period ended the same date showed an increase of 1 per cent, and for the cumulative year an increase of 1 per cent.

Business activity in Cleveland gained momentum toward the end of August. Electric power output rose sharply in the week ended Sept. 2, to a new weekly high for the year. Attainment of a new year-to-date peak at this time of the year -- an unusual event -- serves as significant evidence of business recovery, the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland reported.

Department store sales volume continued to swell during the last week as back-to-school buying reached full swing. The tempo of business generally was rising with Labor Day and the end of summer. Employment was increasing.
ROEBLING, N.J., Sept. 9 -- Richard J. Hughes, Democratic candidate for Governor, started his fall campaign today at a strategy meeting with top Democratic leaders and labor officials in Princeton.

Not since the Korean war, it appears, has the world situation been so dramatically altered in so short a time as it has in the week and a half since Moscow announced that it was resuming tests of nuclear weapons.

The seasonable demand for fall goods last week was stimulated by heavy promotions on the part of retailers and also by ideal shopping weather. Dollar volume pushed comfortably ahead of a year ago, with gains of 5 to 10 per cent more evident in the larger cities than in recent months.

The plans of three large American steamship companies to make a wholesale entry this fall and winter into the Caribbean cruise trade is being "carefully studied" by the subsidy board of the Maritime Administration, an agency spokesman said yesterday.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Sonny Jurgensen passed for two touchdowns to Tommy McDonald tonight as the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 27 -- 0, for an unbeaten exhibition record against National Football League teams.

TODAY there are greenhouses to suit the taste and pocketbook of every home owner. A plastic-covered wooden frame constructed around a cellar window costs less than $5. A glass-covered redwood or aluminum structure large enough to house a few dwarf fruit trees or to cover a swimming pool can amount to thousands of dollars.

NEW HOPE, Pa. -- An aquatic version of the surrey with the fringe on top has mushroomed, within seven years, into a prime attraction in this rapidly growing Bucks County resort. It consists of a fleet of three mule-drawn, canopy-covered passenger barges that ply the gently flowing waters of the moss-and foliage-banked Delaware Canal.

THE pictures in the "1962 Photography Annual" (New York: Ziff-Davis. 224 pp. $1.25) inadvertently provide illustrations -- pro, con or inconclusive -- of the editor's introductory essay on the recognition of photography as an independent art.

DAYTIME television has come in for considerable criticism over the years and by and large it has not been altogether fair. Far from failing to achieve the purpose of serving the public interest, the morning and afternoon attractions constitute an example of acceptable therapy to sustain efficient operation of the American home.

IN Tokyo -- It may be true in other cities too -- a conversation about what is going on these days in writing has at way of skirting literature proper and passing on to peripheral matters: literary gossip, literary politics, just plain politics and, with a swerve back toward literature that does not quite make it, the problem of language reform.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- Even before Premier Khrushchev visited the French national exhibition here last Monday, it was regarded by Soviet citizens and foreign residents alike as the best fair yet put on in the Soviet capital by any of the Western powers.

LASSEN National Park, Calif. -- Those most ubiquitous fellows, The Experts, report confidently that Mount Lassen, the most recently active volcano in the United States proper, "is not expected to erupt again for many years."

A lightweight nuclear thermoelectric power source to provide electricity for instruments landed on the moon has been designed by Westinghouse engineers in Lima, Ohio. A demonstration model has been built delivering about sixty watts.
For the forty-fourth consecutive year, the National Jewish Welfare Board will conduct Operation New Year for American Jewish military personnel.

OF all major sports, automobile racing suffers most at the hands of American journalists. After waiting fifteen minutes for wind, forty-two boats started yesterday in the City Island Yacht Club's twenty-sixth annual distance race to Stratford Shoal.
Stanley M. Isaacs yesterday denied charges of fraud in his victory in Thursday's primary.

BISHIWAKA, Okinawa Sept. 3 -- This is one of the smallest and simplest military camps on Okinawa but by special order of the President it is getting a careful build-up and particular attention from the United States Army.
IN a big bridge tournament, as many as five hundred players may compete in one contest for a national championship, and all of them are experts.
Dennis Ralston's suspension from amateur tennis competition will continue for the remainder of the year, and he has been lost to the United States Davis Cup team.
" By 1965, more than one-third of the families in Western Europe will be eating frozen foods regularly."

A trace of pessimism pervaded the stock market last week despite sharp gains for many blue chips. There was notable strength in defense stocks.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 9 -- The United States Golf Association's Amateur championship will be held over the Pebble Beach course for the first time since 1947, starting Monday.
The Federal Government is trying for the second time to sell to American ship operators a 14,800-ton freighter. The vessel is the 522-foot Coast Progress, which has been idle since last December.
LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Sept. 9 -- A general election under the proposed Constitution for Northern Rhodesia is likely to be held in the second half of 1962.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said today that the Kennedy Administration's record of legislation was one that "compares favorably to the first 100 days of the Roosevelt Administration."
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Sept. 9 -- Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., scored two victories today to reach the semi-finals of the Perth Amboy invitation tennis tournament.
BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 9 -- About twenty adopted children from Seoul, Korea, and Hong Kong romped at a picnic with their new American families at Bethpage State Park today.
CHICAGO, Sept 9 (UPI) -- Jim Owens gave only five hits today while pitching the Philadelphia Phillies to a 6-2 victory over the Cubs.

GENEVA, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union recessed their negotiations for a nuclear test ban in failure today and passed the whole unresolved problem on to the United Nations.

As an economic unit (all thoughts of art aside) the Broadway theatre is not so much a place where some people make fortunes with luck and skill, and others lose fortunes -- though it is that, too. As an economic unit Broadway is one of the main attractions and assets of the City of New York.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 9 -- McLain Street, a gray gelding owned by the Duffy Stables of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and ridden throughout the show by Johnny Bell, won the open jumper championship with 25 points today on the third and final day of the North Shore Horse Show on the ground of the Old Field Club.

THE renewed interest in blues singers, which continues to be apparent in the releases of a growing number of record companies, is bringing back to attention exponents of almost every aspect of the blues with one notable exception -- the so-called "classic" blues style that flourished in the Nineteen Twenties.
ONE of the snappier folktales to come up the pike this summer concerns a man, his daughter and a dog he almost owned.
SEPTEMBER is a busy month for a Water Mill, L.I. naval architect. But it is not Giovanni Cardelli's profession which takes an upswing at this time of year; it is his avocation.

Investments in industrial projects announced during August totaled $16,990,000, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. In the same month last year the amount was $15,574,000. There were thirty projects in August this year, compared with thirty-eight a year ago.

THE layman at the hi-fi show who is amazed at the flow of technical talk should understand that this particular approach to marketing helps to keep high fidelity on the track. DONCASTER, England, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Aurelius won the $98,882 St. Leger stakes today and led a sweep of the first four places for women owners in the world's oldest classic for 3-year-old horses. The winner is owned by Mrs. Vera Lilley of England.

The New York City Democratic organization is the party's most powerful instrument in the State. It delivers roughly half the party vote in statewide elections. ALBANY, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller announced two programs this week aimed at cutting unemployment through education.

The architect for the Protestant chapel at New York International Airport accused the Port Authority yesterday of trying to dictate the design of the chapel without accepting authorship.

HYANNIS, Mass. -- Most Americans turn their backs on vacation resorts as soon as the sun sets on the first Monday in September. Historically, that day is set aside for observance as Labor Day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The United States will send about 40,000 Army troops to Europe "in the immediate future" to strengthen combat and combat-support forces there, the Pentagon announced today.

ONE of the most intriguing individuals in the history of polar exploration is the central figure of this book. Was Dr. Frederick Cook a "monster of duplicity," an "infamous wretch," "the greatest impostor of all time"? Or did he reach the North Pole a year before its official discoverer, Admiral Robert Peary? Andrew Freeman's book is a detailed and impassioned plea in support of Cook's claim.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Members of the New York Unit of the Herb Society of America will celebrate "Christmas in September" when they take this theme for their annual fair and tea on Sept. 21.

RESIDENTS of Litchfield, Conn., have launched a program to preserve the town's Colonial heritage of elm-lined streets, Their plan includes protection of many magnificent old American elms from Dutch elm disease and planting to replace those trees that have succumbed.

THAT peculiar -- and peculiarly -- English animal, the public school, is again under fire for being so obviously private. RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 31 -- The Soviet Union is expected to make a strong bid for first place in the field of research and educational cinematography at the fifteenth Annual Congress of the International Scientific Film Association, which opens here on Sept. 16.

The 73-to-14 vote by which the Senate passed the bill to set up a permanent United States disarmament agency is good news. It provides the basis for hope that similar action by the House of Representatives at this Congressional session will soon permit the agency to come into being.

The unseasonably warm weather across the nation last week reduced retail sales, according reports from resident buying officers. The houses noted that the religious holidays coming up will slow deliveries and have caused stores to make earlier than usual commitments for early October promotions.

THE latest name on the long roster of modern dragons -- the polite, friendly type -- is that of Darius, Judy Varga's "sweet, gentle dragon," whose chief amusement is to spit colored fire. Oil operations abroad by private companies are becoming increasingly unattractive. To cover growing costs of governmental operations, including ambitious long-term development programs, some of the host countries are demanding a bigger share of the profits.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 9 -- The Pennsylvania Department of Welfare reported this week that 200 children of migrant farm workers had spent their summer at play and study in seven day-care centers supervised by the department.

A LONG with the first year of the Civil War Centennial, 1961 marks the hundredth anniversary of the admission to the Union of her thirty-fourth state -- Kansas. LARCHMONT, N.Y. Sept. 9 -- The third annual Candlelight Ball, to be given by the Westchester Alumnae Chapter of Delta Gamma on Oct. 21, again will be held at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

NORTHEASTERN gardeners sometimes wait for decades before new hardy rhododendron hybrids are introduced. Though breeding has been slow and difficult, a host of new hybrids from several breeders makes their debut this fall, in time for planting.

AMONG the ever-growing number of festival cities, Athens can claim to be the most ancient. DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Refugees from Hurricane Carla swarmed inland today from the coast of the Gulf of Mexico.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 10 -- It wasn't exactly Ivy League football that went on display atop the sacred sod of the Yale Bowl on this scorching afternoon. The professionals invaded this shrine for a charity game, not far from the spot where Walter Camp, Frank Hinkey, Pudge Heffelfinger and the other Eli immortals built their altars to the gridiron gods.
The Bethlehem Steel Company asserted yesterday that steel price stability depended largely on wage demands by the United Steelworkers of America.
MAUNA LOA OBSERVATORY, Hawaii, Sept. 4 -- Weather researchers, perched uneasily on this sleeping, but far from dead volcano, have found that the air is steadily becoming richer in carbon dioxide.

WITH the children back at school, a line of empty lunch boxes stretches into the distance. Using a variety of breads and rolls, adding a fresh new garnish to a favorite sandwich and a surprise ending for the packed lunch can spark a child's appetite.

ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Sept. 10 -- Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N.J., and Augie Pabst of Milwaukee drove a twelve-cylinder Maserati to victory today in the annual Road America 500-mile race. They finished three laps ahead of George Reed of Midlothian, Ill., and Ed Hugus of Pittsburgh, in a Ferrari Testa Rossa.

In an ironic twist to the Broadway season, "All the Way Home," which has been struggling for existence since opening Nov. 30, established itself yesterday as the longest-running of the current plays and then announced its closing at the Belasco next Saturday night.

WARSAW, Sept. 10 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, Communist chief of Poland, announced today what appeared to be a partial mobilization of the Polish armed forces.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -Docking charges for ships in California's major harbors are scheduled to be increased by about one-third under a resolution adopted by representatives of nine harbor and terminal operators in Long Beach last week.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 10 -- The United States has gained friends in Brazil and Cuba has lost some as a result of the different attitudes assumed by Washington and Havana toward the crisis brought about by the resignation of President Janio Quadros.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- Premier Khrushchev said today that he saw an "encouraging glimmer of hope" for negotiations in the Berlin crisis. The Soviet leader voiced this hope in a speech dedicating a big hydroelectric station at Stalingrad.
ROME, Sept. 10 -- A dozen bombs explode during the night in Rome, Trent, Verona, Rovereto, Monza and Rimini.

Paying more to mail a letter is an unwelcome prospect in this period of renewed worry about inflation, but the necessity for raising postal rates is too clear to permit delay. The postal deficit is approaching $1,000,000,000 a year, and no concept of public service justifies asking the taxpayers to continue carrying a burden of such magnitude out of general revenues.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Soviet Union recently rejected a United States offer to prohibit all underground nuclear tests if the Russians would agree to an enlarged control system.
DUBLIN, Sept. 10 -- Dublin's Theatre Festival, which has attracted to Ireland theatregoers from many parts of Europe, will be opened by Lord Mayor Robert Briscoe tomorrow.
Another streak of silver has appeared among the clouds of uncertainty that hover over plans for the forthcoming Metropolitan Opera season.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- About 2,000 demonstrators in Trafalgar Square cheered speakers today who were opposing war over Berlin.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Several hundred residents of this village and surrounding communities were guests this afternoon at an open house aboard three oceanic research vessels of Columbia University's Hudson Laboratories.
While manufacturing costs in major industrialized areas overseas are frequently lower than in the United States, other costs often equal or exceed the sayings, a new study disclosed yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics hammered seventeen hits and routed the Minnesota Twins, 13 -- 1, in the first game of a double-header today, but Pedro Ramos cooled off the A's in the second game as he pitched the Twins to a 7-0 victory with a five-hitter.
A Federal court has affirmed the right of the nation's freight forwarders to offer volume rates for piggy-back rail shipments.

Nearly half of the city's 1,000,000 public school children seem to require some kind of extra help from their schools, the final report of the Mayor's Juvenile Delinquency Evaluation Project estimates.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Five days a week Miss Dzidra Minders of Red Bank works in a Freehold dress shop. On most week-ends, the 28-year-old blonde can be found here at the eight-acre recreation center of the New Jersey Latvian Society.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- George Thomas hit a two-run homer in the seventh inning today to lift the Los Angeles Angels to a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

The eighth Congress of the International Musicological Society ended its sixth day yesterday, its last day in New York. MORE and more New York women are wearing wigs, and the interesting thing about this phenomenon is that once they have tried these beautiful but artificial thatchings they seem to go back for more.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Bob Hayward of London, Ont., who won the Harmsworth Trophy international unlimited power boat race three times, was killed today when his boat flipped in his second heat in the Silver Cup Regatta on the Detroit River.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Four European banks have agreed to participate in an Inter-American Development Bank loan to Mexico. This reflects the growing interest of European financial institutions toward Latin-American economic development.

This is the time of year when Detroit enjoys its season in the sun as new auto models are unveiled and optimistic sales forecasts are advanced. In introducing their 1962 makes, auto producers this year appear convinced of two facts: First, that they are going to sell more cars during 1962 than during 1961; and second, that they will have to spend more money on advertising in order to ensure this sales increase.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Only a few years ago, the choral music of Anton Webern was considered to be virtually impossible to sing accurately. Yesterday evening the local high school choir here sang the two Webern cantatas accurately and with musical understanding.
DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- The General Motors Corporation faces the prospect of many individual plant walkouts tomorrow unless local agreements are reached before the strike deadline at 10 A.M.

A book contending that the American people "have been fantastically misinformed and -- to an extent -- deliberately confused on every aspect of American recognition of China" is planned for Oct. 2 publication by Macmillan.

Investors Planning Corporation of America's August sales of $12,923,000 were "the highest by far" ever reported for that month, Walter Benedick, president, reported over the week-end. The total ran 19.6 per cent higher than a year ago and raised the total for the first eight months to $115,777,000, or 11.8 per cent above that of a year ago. . . .

The pace of trading in over-the-counter issues quickened last week with much of the demand centered in the bank and utility groups.

A bumper crop of raw Indian jute for 1961 is expected to restore stability to the industry, which has been hit hard in the last year by an acute shortage of the fiber and reduced consumption of burlap, one of its major end products.

Is Premier Khrushchev's atomic terror campaign boomeranging in his own backyard? The West has shown no signs of panic in the face of the Soviet leader's rattling of hydrogen bombs and long-range rockets. But in Poland this past week there has been massive panic-buying of essentials and luxuries. The shortages thus created have become so threatening that Wladyslav Gomulka felt forced yesterday to reassure his people that there is no immediate danger of war.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- One of the most amiable of the company negotiators in the automobile contract bargaining here is a stocky, graying man with a friendly smile and an unruffled manner. He is Earl Ralph Bramblett, director of labor relations for the General Motors Corpora tion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A business man's group cautioned today against any United States actions that would restrict international trade.

THE married career woman and the working mother are no longer exceptional. Almost one out of every three married women in America is trying to be a wage-earner and a homemaker at the same time. Twice as many women are making the attempt as did twenty years ago.

DONALD Brooks, well known designer for the wholesale concern of Townley Inc., will create a special custom-order collection exclusively for Henri Bendel.
