ALGIERS, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Several persons were injured today in four hours of clashes between Jews and Moslems in Oran, in western Algeria, on the occasion of the Jewish New Year.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 -Seven persons were burned, one critically, early this morning when a flash fire swept a small section of a resort motel filled with visitors here for the Jewish Holy Days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The House tentatively approved today a $947,878,750 military construction appropriation bill. But it put off a final vote until Wednesday because of a dispute with the Senate over one project.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Soldiers and policemen in the Dominican Republic were publicly warned today to stop interfering in the political campaign for next year's elections.
KAPLAN, La., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Tornadoes produced by Hurricane Carla harried southern Louisiana today while this town began picking up the pieces and counting the damage from one that hit yesterday.
OTTAWA, Sept. 11 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker said today that he believed the time had come when the United Nations might consider the internationalization of Berlin.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- A Soviet note to the United States, Britain and France declared today that all foreign citizens who wish to enter East Germany or East Berlin must make arrangements with the East German Government.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- The Saudi Arabian Government announced tonight a Cabinet shuffle that appears to herald a rapprochement between King Saud and his brother, Crown Prince Faisal.

What will be the shape of the boom expected to come next year? The nation is now "facing another period of inventory accumulation," John B. Wilson, vice president and economist for the Chase Manhattan Bank, said yesterday at a conference of client companies sponsored by Ebasco Services, Inc. Ebasco provides technical help for utilities.
Seventeen families in a Harlem tenement will be asked to vacate their apartments tomorrow while repairs are made on a broken drain that allowed two feet of sewage to accumulate in the basement.

THE Leningrad Kirov Ballet made its American debut at the Metropolitan Opera House last night and brought us some superb dancing. The ballet chosen for the opening of its season was the full-length "Swan Lake" as restudied by the company's artistic director, Konstantin Sergeyev.
Bobby Fischer of New York is in a four-way tie for first place after six rounds of the chess masters tournament at Bled, Yugoslavia.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company began operation as a merged institution yesterday, despite the possibility that a Federal court might halt further steps today.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- Pilots for the three Western airlines flying to West Berlin over Communist East Germany have received no instructions from their companies in anticipation of the possibility of interference by Communist planes.
Through the efforts of a persuasive young man with red hair, twelve newspaper men from twelve countries will start out today to cover their biggest story -- the United States.

About thirty Protestant Episcopal clergymen are scheduled to leave New Orleans today on a "Prayer Pilgrimage" designed to point up racially segregated educational institutions operated by the Episcopal Church.

YONKERS, Sept. 11 -- Even a plaid-suited county fair manager desirous of providing a sure-fire box-office attraction couldn't have asked for more today as the drawings were made for Thursday's $50,000 Harness Tracks of America Trot at Yonkers Raceway.

Premier Castro is learning the first lesson of all dictators -- freedom is hard to kill. Sunday night's anti-Government demonstration by 4,000 Cubans in downtown Havana indicates that, whatever popularity his revolutionary program may still have, there is a conspicuous lack of mass support for his determination to draw ever closer to the Soviet Union and ape its tyrannical methods.

The forthcoming session of the United Nations will give to the United States, as the foremost supporter of the U.N. in principle and in practice, the opportunity to expound once again in the world's great forum the determination of this country to continue working for international peace, social justice and individual freedom.
Stocks made their deepest retreat since April 24 yesterday, but volume did not increase, as on the earlier occasion. It fell.

All thinking citizens concerned about the future domestic well-being and the international position of the United States applaud your recent penetrating, lucid and convincing editorials on Federal legislation related to foreign aid and aid to education.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- Following are the texts of statements on the auto workers' strike issued by the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers Union:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Kennedy will receive the Presidents of Indonesia and Mali tomorrow with a show of pomp and cordiality, but with firmness against any suggestions of unilateral concessions in negotiations with the Soviet Union.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 11 -- The shrill election campaign has obscured for most West Germans the probability that they will be asked soon by the Western Allies to face up to some tough decisions on Germany's future.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Frustrated backers of Federal aid to education opened Senate action today aimed at giving Congress another chance to pass a broad education bill next year.

PEBBLE BEACH Calif., Sept. 11 -- Deane Beman the 23-year-old defender from Bethesda, Md., scored a 1-up victory in the opening round of the United States Amateur golf championship today but he found unexpected trouble in doing so.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The Justice Department has started investigations in some thirty-five counties to determine whether Negroes are denied the right to vote.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Judge Clarence B. Nixon continued on a day-today basis today a petition by the General Motors Corporation for a preliminary injunction to limit the number of pickets at its strike-bound Fisher Body plant in near-by West Mifflin, Pa.
The Universal Leaf Tobacco Company, Inc., and its consolidated subsidiaries reported yesterday a record net income of $4,565,180 for the fiscal year ended on June 30.

ATLANTA, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The Georgia Pardon and Parole Board promised today to investigate the murder conviction of a 15-year-old Negro whose death sentence touched off a wave of protests at the urging of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.
NEWARK, Sept. 11 -- A $300,000 medical and dental clinic was opened here today for 2,000 members of the International Longshoremen's Association employed in the Port Newark area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Congressional conferees agreed today to a $756,422,550 compromise money bill with a Senate rider extending the Civil Rights Commission for two years. But the rider will require a separate House vote.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- Automobile workers went on strike today at ninety-two General Motors Corporation plants across the nation. The dispute focused primarily on working conditions at local factories.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 11 -- The "mystery" of the resignation of President Janio Quadros has been clarified by the testimony of key actors in the drama, which brought Brazil to the verge of civil war.
SEACLIFF, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Two boats from Newport Beach, Calif., excelled today as trials to decide the American defender in the international catamaran challenge match began in Hempstead Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that railroad freight rates on fresh fruit and vegetables shipped to New York be lowered to equal those on shipments to New Jersey.
I write, as an English resident in the United States, to comment on the letter from John W.N. Ridell, published in your issue of Sept. 8 titled "A Briton's View of War."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The possibility of a disastrous fire in the Capitol Building has been worrying members of Congress for some time. They found out today that elimination of the fire hazards would cost about $815,000.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Nassau County took the first step today to obtain 235 acres of Mitchel Field for the use of the Nassau County Community College.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 -- A rare kind of world congress opened here today, attended by more than 700 water transport experts from nearly fifty foreign nations.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Sept. 11 -- Former President Eisenhower said today that no plans for an invasion of Cuba had been made before he left office. He said he agreed as early as March, 1960, to help train some of the Cuban refugees then in this country. But he said that it would have been impossible to go beyond this because of the lack of any cohesive leadership among the Cuban patriots.
OSLO, Norway, Tuesday, Sept. 12 -- Norway's ruling Labor party suffered an unexpected set back in yesterday's Parliamentary elections.
The nation's investor-owned electric utilities disclosed yesterday a ten-year, $8,000,000,000 plan designed to block public power advocacy of a nation wide interconnected power network.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 11 -- The international jury of the sixth Sao Paulo Bienal announced yesterday that the grand prize in plastic arts goes to a French painter, Vieira da Silva.
Seemingly unending summer (it will end a week from Saturday) continued yesterday to plague New Yorkers with oppressive heat and high humidity.
THIS deliberately quaint little town, hardly more than an artistically colorful speck on the Pennsylvania side of the Delaware River, is caught on the horns of an age-old dilemma.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The aim of the Soviet Union's new series of atomic tests is to develop a whole arsenal of improved weapons, according to the views of United States officials.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The Tiros III weather satellite is keeping an eye on three hurricanes, two typhoons and two smaller storms that may turn into hurricanes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Senate passed today, 75 to 9, a two-year extension of the Mexican farm labor program, but first adopted an amendment designed to give the imported workers higher wages.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Seventy-eight Freedom Riders pleaded not guilty today to charges of breach of peace. Their trials on appeal were set to start March 12 in Hinds County court.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 11 -- Hurricane Carla hit the Texas coast today at Matagorda Bay and smashed inland, leaving behind destruction totaling millions of dollars.

KUWAIT, Sept. 11 -- While the Saudi Arabian vanguard of an Arab League protective force moved into Kuwait yesterday Kuwait's ruler asserted that the agreement for British protection of Kuwait "remains unaffected."

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 11 -- Eight teen-age Negro pupils from Prince Edward County, Va., will begin classes in this area this week. Public schools in their central Virginia community have been closed for two years through the integration battle.
As hundreds of thousands of persons fled Hurricane Carla, 453 insurance adjusters moved into the Texas-Louisiana coastal area.

Pleas for spiritual sacrifice and renewed dedication to a future world of justice, peace and freedom were voiced yesterday by rabbis here as they marked the first day of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year 5722.

WITH the current boom in art collecting, a big bare wall simply does not stand a chance. To do justice at home both to the art and to the wall is to know the difference between hanging a painting and hanging it to death.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 -- John J. McCloy challenged business and industrial leaders today to "accept the world" and do something about it. Its ills, he said, are becoming "too much for just the statesmen to deal with."
ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- The construction of a youth rehabilitation center will begin next month near Pilgrim State Hospital in Brentwood, L.I., Governor Rockefeller announced today.

Except for a fortunate few who own productive oil wells or who have inherited, or married into, substantial sums of money, parents of college-age offspring lately have been going through a worrisome period.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (UPI) -About 6,600 auto workers went on strike against three General Motors Corporation plants here today an hour after the company suspended all seventeen union negotiators. Just three hours before the stoppage the plants had reopened following a strike that began last Wednesday.
D-Day -- D for duty -- came to Pier 86 at West Forty-sixth Street yesterday morning as 1,557 passengers swarmed off the liner United States to face the new duty-free customs limit of $100.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Senator John J. Williams declared today that officials who knew refused to tell him how much feathers and down were in the nation's strategic stockpile.

RAMSTEIN, Germany, Sept. 8 -- Intensified training in conventional warfare tactics and reinforcement of the United States air strength with seventy-two tactical fighters represent to date the principal Air Force preparations in Europe to cope with the Berlin crisis.
A large and enthusiastic turnout last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the premiere here of the Leningrad Kirov Ballet was a fair indication that art knows no politics.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The tropical Atlantic, spawning ground for hurricanes, is "hotter than a firecracker," a veteran weather forecaster said today.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 11 -- In the hotels where the motor-racing crowd stays, yesterday's horror at Monza is on everybody's mind. The death toll among spectators has risen to fourteen and in the lobbies men talk of that, consciously avoiding the name of Count Wolfgang von Trips who died when his Ferrari sliced through a section of the crowd.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 11 -- A man concealing a gun in a bouquet of flowers locked a maid in a closet yesterday and robbed a millionaire's home of four paintings that the family valued at $670,000.
THIBODAUX, La., Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Sheriff Eddie Ste. Marie reported today that Hurricane Carla had created a strange traffic problem.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox staged an eight-run inning against the Senators for the third time this season tonight en route to a 14-4 victory.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Hillbilly music mixed strangely with the cries of babies today in dank City Auditorium -- one of Houston's largest refugee shelters.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- A bank at Ochlochnee, Ga., has been closed for liquidation following discovery of a shortage of $180,000, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, announced today.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Carl Sawatski's two-run single with the bases filled in the sixth inning broke a 1-1 tie tonight as the Cardinals beat the Milwaukee Braves, 4 -- 1.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Sept. 11 (AP) -- President Kennedy took up the cotton picker lap problem today.
The Red Cross will collect blood at the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., 4 Irving Place, and at the New York Telephone Company, 104 Broad Street, today.

As a result of having been considerably roughed up in their 49-20 exhibition defeat at the hands of the Baltimore Colts last Sunday, the New York Giants will present somewhat of a patched line-up Sunday when they open the regular National Football League season against the St. Louis Cardinals at Yankee Stadium.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Flood waters along the Gulf Coast today were driving rattlesnakes and water moccasins to higher ground -- the ground occupied by refugees from Hurricane Carla.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Governor Rockefeller called today for a broad Federal program to cope with the "railroad crisis." He asked for repeal of the 10 per cent Federal tax on passenger tickets to give ailing carriers a $200,000,000-a-year "shot in the arm."

" A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH,"* A by Virgilia Peterson, will be one of the most-talked-about books of the year. It is an uncommonly candid and compelling autobiography, told with the selective art of a novelist.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Bob Watson of Fairview, a former Panama open golf champion, established a record today on the Westchester Country Club's West course. He fired a 33, 31 -- 64, eight under par. The course measures 6,490 yards.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 11 -- A team of five skippers and crews representing the United States defeated a team from Norway, 54 to 51 1/4, today in the first race of a three-of-fiverace series for the Skoal Trophy.

Wise Ship, Milton Ritzenberg's good grass campaigner, won the $29,900 New York Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday in a thrilling finish. With Heliodoro Gustines guiding him, the 4-year-old son of Sky Ship beat Art Market by a nose in the mile-and-three-eighths race that was run over the Widener Turf Course.
There were two important points concerning the New York Yankees' departure yesterday on their final trip of the season.
BELLEVILLE, N.J., Sept. 11 -- This town is sending its favorite musician off to Pallanza, Italy, this week to seek the title of world's champion accordionist.
ATLANTA, Sept. 11 -- A Georgia official said today that he thought most state employment security directors would attend a national convention here despite a controversy over hotel segregation.
Individual utilities and several groups of power companies also made known yesterday their own plans for expanding transmission lines and interconnections under the industry's program.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Dodgers defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 6 -- 5, tonight on an eleventh-inning home run by Gordon Windhorn, a pinch-hitter.

PETERBOROUGH, N.H., Sept. 11 -- Steve Sinko, whose Boston University football teams regularly play one of the strongest schedules in the East, thinks his 1961 squad is headed for a successful campaign.
The Commerce and Industry Association of New York announced yesterday that it was opposed to the adoption of the proposed new City Charter.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Industrial shares prices drifted steadily lower in the stock market here today and by the close losses ranged to a shilling (14 cents) or so.
ELIZABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 11 -- President Moise Tshombe said today that he had received a United Nations ultimatum to meet with the leaders of the Congolese central Government in Leopoldville.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 11 -- The parents of pupils boycotting the predominantly Negro Glenfield School agreed tonight to a request to send their children back to school tomorrow.

Samuel Bronston is convinced that the salvation of the film industry lies in expensive, three-hour, reserved-seat costume spectacles, and he has acquired the production capital to demonstrate his point.

A $50,000,000 issue of thirty-three-year debentures of Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone Company will be offered to competitive bidding about Nov. 15, according to an announcement yesterday by the company's executive committee.

Jobs for Youth, a free placement agency in the Yorkville area, was the beneficiary of the preview opening of the Sheraton-East's Embassy Club last evening. This was the first benefit to be sponsored by The Friday Evenings, which last season gave a series of cocktail dances.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Joe Altobelli's three-run pinch homer in the eighth inning gave the Minnesota Twins and their strikeout artist, Camilo Pascual, a 5-2 victory over the Los Angeles Angels tonight.
BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- B.Z., a West Berlin newspaper said today that Jack Paar, United States television personality, had "put on a disgraceful show in front of the barbed wire at the sector border".
The so-called egghead magazines, whose space salesmen once were pretty generally snubbed along Madison Avenue, are suddenly enjoying surprisingly bountiful times.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 11 -- Dag Hammarskjold, the United Nations Secretary General, has accepted an invitation from the Congolese Government to come to Leopoldville "in the near future," a spokesman for Premier Cyrille Adoula announced tonight.

PETERBOROUGH, N.H., Sept. 11 -- Steve Sinko, whose Boston University football teams regularly play one of the strongest schedules in the East, thinks his 1961 squad is headed for a successful campaign.

The Professional Bowlers Association, continuing to expand its program, has added a weekly tournament circuit that will start in January. Each of the end-of-the-week competitions will be nationally televised during the final rounds on Saturdays.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 11 -- Mario Guerra Leal, president of the Constitution Revolutionary party charged today that a disputed plot to begin a series of riots throughout Mexico had been financially backed and directed by the Cuban Government and the Cuban Embassy in Mexico.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- A French general charged with having been the ringleader of a nationwide plot here to overthrow President de Gaulle in conjunction with the April army mutiny in Algiers refused today to recognize the special court trying him or to defend his actions.

THE Yankees have been doing some unashamed rooting of recent weeks. They have manifested undisguised delight every time one of the twin terrors, Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle, has advanced another notch in their assault on Babe Ruth's historic homer record. That is both proper and commendable.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Paul Porter and Robert Cohen of Pine Hollow scored 30, 34 -- 64 to win the Long Island Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The Malayan Government protested today to the United States that neither Malaya nor the International Tin Council was consulted piror to the announcement that the United States General Services Administration had approached Congress for authority to dispose of 5,000 tons of surplus tin.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals took under consideration today a request by the Kohler Company to reverse a ruling by the National Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The Senate passed a bill today that would modify separation and annulment laws in the nation's capital to put them more into line with those of Maryland and Virginia. The bill now goes to the House.

ACCIDENTS kill more children than the seven leading childhood diseases combined. Furthermore, according to the Easter Seal Society, between 40,000 and 50,000 children are permanently crippled in accidents each year. Despite the fact that a child is presumed to be safest in his own home, most childhood accidents happen there.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 11 (UPI) -- State Agriculture Commissioner John White said today he feared the entire Texas rice crop, worth $70,000,000, would be erased by Hurricane Carla and "hundreds of millions of dollars" of other crop damage would be done by the huge storm.

I read with interest the letter in your issue of Sept. 4 from my dear friend Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter, urging the restoration of Proportional Representation instead of the system of minority representation proposed to the voters by the Charter Commission, of which I am a member.

New York State has sold $50,000,000 of tax anticipation notes bearing 1.6 per cent interest, State Controller Arthur Levitt announced yesterday. The money will be used to help finance a payment of $190,000,000 for aid to public education. The notes will come due March 15, 1962.

Cotton futures advanced 60 cents to $1.50 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. General buying was touched off by fears that Hurricane Carla might cause damage to the Western growing belt and possibly to some sections of the Central belt.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Chancellor of the Exchequer, has put up $18 to pay off a debt that goes back across the years to the American Revolution.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Treasury bill rates declined on today's sale of the regular weekly issues.

Your "some day social scientist" is going to have to be slightly taller than the Empire State Building to show up the naivete of your statistical "Megalopolitan Myopia" editorial of Sept. 4. Just how do you propose to spread the 142 persons per acre who now inhabit the island of Manhattan out into the Megalopolitan belt where you claim there is plenty of room?

ASSEMBLE a few dozen outdoors writers together in a safe place, put guns in their hands and two things are bound to happen. The first will be that some will turn out to be fairly respectable shots. The second thing is that the rest will discourse knowledgeably on how they can hit game with ease but just can't seem to get the hang of breaking clay birds.
Plans were announced today for the forthcoming season by the American Opera Society. This will be the ninth annual season for the company, presenting rarely heard operas in concert versions.

As a frequent reader of The Times I cannot help noticing the large number of letters and advertisements in your paper that protest our defense of Berlin and the German people. The latest of these was Samuel Buck's epistle (which roundly assailed the Germans for atrocities in the last war).
The chairman of the selection panel that is to nominate new members for the Board of Education said yesterday he hoped the group would complete its work today as originally scheduled.

The Dominguez Oil Fields Company announced yesterday that it would solicit stockholder approval at a special meeting on Sept. 29 to sell its assets exclusive of cash to the Union Oil Company of California for about $7,000 in cash.
The nation's output of raw steel rose slightly last week, despite the Labor Day holiday, for the sixth consecutive gain.
The city's Roman Catholic schools opened yesterday as children from the public schools took a two-day vacation because of the Jewish holidays.

On strike are locals of the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers of America. The union represents 310,000 production Workers in 130 local unions at 123 plants of the General Motors Corporation.
More than 16,000 employes of the General Motors Corporation in the metropolitan area walked out yesterday in the strike of local unions affiliated with the United Automobile Workers.
STOWE, Vt., Sept. 11 -- High-ranking Soviet and United States scientists began talks today on specific steps that their countries might take to lead to weapons control and disarmament.
Mayor Wagner disclosed yesterday that he intended to drop from the city payroll many of the officeholders who opposed him in last Thursday's Democratic primary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Retail sales in August rose slightly from the disappointing July level, the Department of Commerce announced today in a "flash" -- or advance -- report. However, volume was below the year-earlier level for the eighth consecutive month.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
DENVER, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The first major missile base strike since a national pact was agreed to earlier this year hit the Denver area Titan complexes today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Seventeen long-time suppliers of wearing apparel and specialty items to Sears, Roebuck Co. announced today plans to merge into a single company. The manufacturing concerns have combined sales of about $80,000,000 a year and produce non-competing lines.

The Theatre Outlook, a professional, but nonprofit, repertory company from Liverpool, England, will begin a fifteen-week tour of sixteen American cities on Sept. 21. It will give performances in theatres and auditoriums that are not on the normal touring route.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 11 -- Brazil's new Finance Minister, Walter Moreira Salles, promised the nation financial "sobriety" today, but he conceded that the recent political crisis had aggravated a long-standing problem of inflation.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he had "never received sought or obtained any favors from anyone doing business with the city."
There was more bad news yesterday for the United States Davis Cup tennis team. The squad will play in India on grass.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Atlantic Refining Company said today that it had acquired control of J.P. Frank Chemical and Plastic Corporation, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent during the week ended Tuesday, Sept. 5, to 118.7 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 12 -- Stuart Finley-Bissett, 58 years old, was fined 50 ($140) or two months' imprisonment in Magistrate Court here today for common assault on G. Mermen Williams, United States Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs at Lusaka Airport in northern Rhodesia Aug. 28.
The police issued an alarm last night for the arrest of a Greenwich, Conn., man on the complaint of a former chief assistant United States Attorney.

Mrs. John R. Stevenson, chairman of the Debutante Ball of the New York Junior League, gave a rehearsal tea Monday at the Plaza for the young women who will be presented to society at the Nov. 22 event, also at the Plaza.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Wally Post slammed his nine-teenth homer of the season and Darrell Johnson drove in three runs with a pair of doubles to pace the league-leading Cincinnati Reds to a 7-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.

TRENTON, Sept. 12 -- Richard J. Hughes, Democratic candidate for Governor, offered today to open his personal financial records to public inspection. He challenged his Republican opponent, James P. Mitchell, to do the same.
The directors of the Washington Gas Light Company yesterday raised its quarterly dividend to 66 cents a common share and also proposed a two-for-one stock split.

The Republic Steel Corporation has announced plans for the construction of what it said would be the steel industry's largest bright-annealing installation. The unit is expected to be ready for start-up in January, 1962, in Massillon, Ohio.
Three ore ships operated by a United States concern under the Liberian flag have apparently joined the growing list of vessels leaving effective American control.

The restrained editorial in The Times (Sept. 7) on the United States resumption of nuclear testing touched upon, but did not sufficiently emphasize, a point that has dismayed if not infuriated a great" many Americans.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 11 -- Afghanistan's foreign polisy is undergoing a reappraisal that could seriously affect the United States position in South Asia.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- William Posner, Democratic leader of Monroe County, left tonight for a Washington meeting with representatives of the Kennedy Administration, increasing speculation that he would be the next Democratic state chairman.
Harold S. Prince has signed George Abbott to direct "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," the new musical comedy by Burt Shevelove, Larry Gelbert and Stephen Sondheim.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Senate approved today the continuation for two years of two expiring education programs.

The County Line Shopping center, a five-acre development at Main Street and Carmen Road, Farmingdale, L.I., has been sold by the Plymouth Properties Corporation. It was bought by the Victor Properties Company in a deal negotiated by Joseph R. Ruffino of the Ruffino Realty Company of Kew Gardens, broker.

THE feast of San Gennaro, honoring the patron saint of Naples, will begin Friday evening on Mulberry Street, centering near Spring Street. The area will be closed to traffic, and the streets will be lined with game booths, bandstands and food vendors' stalls.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- West Berlin officials are drafting plans to strengthen the city's economic, political and cultural position in the face of continued Communist threats to the independence and freedom of 2,200,000 West Berliners.
Operations of the J.C. Penney Company for the six months ended on July 31 resulted in improved sales and earnings, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

Thank you for your lead editorial of Sept. 7 in which you point out that the atomic weapon cannot be used, either in open tests or in open warfare, against one chosen nation alone; that "it is the enemy of all humanity, indeed of all life."
MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Thomas G. Allen of Buffalo triumphed in the opening race of the first International Lightning Class Association world sailing championship on Long Island Sound today.
The Ohio Oil Company announced yesterday from its Findlay, Ohio, headquarters the creation of an international organization in a move to accelerate its world activities.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 12 -- From Norway to Turkey, elements of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's armed forces moved into the field today for a forty-eight-hour exercise.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Rain, after making several threatening gestures during the day, finally cracked down on the series opener between the Yankees and the White Sox tonight in the sixth inning.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, said today that the Senate would begin debate Saturday on a proposal to curb filibusters.

The Senate's vote to extend aid to the Federally impacted school districts by two-years completes the sell-out to those who are determined to block real Federal aid to public schools. By turning a deaf ear to pleas for a stop-gap, one-year extension, the Senate has immeasurably strengthened the hand of those who would like to see the school-aid debate muzzled until after the next Congressional election.
CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., Sept. 12 (AP) -- More than 200 men from the Second Marine Division here left by air today to aid victims of Hurricane Carla in Texas and Louisiana.
Massachusetts borrowed $46,756,000 in the public market yesterday to finance public improvements.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- President William V.S. Tubman asked today for wide-ranging emergency powers to deal with "subversive" activities that he said were instigated by "certain foreign agencies."
STOWE, Vt., Sept. 12 -- Unofficial Soviet-American arms discussions took a hopeful turn today when Russian spokesmen advanced what were described as new and significant proposals.
WILLIAM MASSELOS, through no fault of his own, gave what sounded like an underwater piano recital last night at the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park.
A FAMOUS theatrical producer of another era once said that all productions should open on the second night instead of the first, and he might well have been referring to the Leningrad Kirov Ballet.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Discoverer XXX was fired into a polar orbit by the Air Force today. An attempt will be made to recover its gold-plated capsule.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Thirty states indicated support today for a State Department plan to insure incident-free travel in the United States for foreign diplomats, particularly Africans.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 12 -- Congolese Government circles and United Nations officials voiced disappointment tonight over the latest refusal by President Tshombe of Katanga to visit the Congolese capital.

The women's All-England field hockey team, on a seven-week tour of the United States, gained a 4-0 victory over the New York Field Hockey Association eleven at the Hunter College field in the Bronx yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Navigators for Trans World Airlines said today they would go on strike tomorrow if the Federal Aviation Agency resumed its evaluation of controversial new cockpit navigation equipment.
Representative Paul A. Fino, Bronx Country Republican leader, announced yesterday that he would ask the Republican County Committee to provide for the direct election of district leaders.

At the annual meeting in Minneapolis, Minn., stockholders of the Pillsbury Company were told that the company continued to expand into international markets along with maintaining steady growth in this country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The House Appropriations Committee denied today President Kennedy's request for $4,000,000 for preserving some of the ancient monuments to be submerged by construction of the High Dam at Aswan, Egypt.
IN addition to a plaything, "toy" can mean amorous dalliance, a paltry concern or something diminutive. The Toy Cafe, 149 West Forty-fourth Street, presumably was named for its pocket size.
DENVER, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The first major strike at a missile site since President Kennedy established his Missile Site Labor Relations Commission ended today.
GALVESTON, Tex., Sept. 12 -- The dying winds of Hurricane Carla generated tornadoes today that killed at least ten persons in Texas and Louisiana, bringing the storm's death toll to fifteen.

The new post of Deputy Director of Port Development has been created by the Port of New York Authority, and Hayden B. Johnson, chief of the agency's planning section for six years, has been named to fill it.

Hurricane Carla, with wind velocities reaching 173 miles an hour, ranks as one of the eight worst reported on the Texas coast since 1875. Men, women and children fled before the storm in a mass evacuation, one of the greatest such exoduses in American history.

Making an abrupt about-face, stocks retraced the ground lost on Monday and took one step more yesterday. As on the day before, most of the movement came before 2 P.M. Thereafter, prices wobbled and drifted a little lower.
Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley yesterday ordered a study of a dispute in which 122 Harlem children are being kept out of school by their parents.

The First Boston Corporation and associates placed on the market yesterday $18,000,000 of 4 7/8 per cent debentures of the Mountain Fuel Supply Company. The issue, due in 1986, was priced at 101.09 to yield 4.80 per cent to maturity.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 12 -- West Coast catamarans continued today to dominate the trials that will select an American defender for the international catamaran challenge match against Great Britain.

USUALLY a successful squeeze play depends on having all but one of the remaining tricks. A declarer who has nine winning cards may be able to squeeze out a tenth trick, but not until he has lost three tricks.
Mayor Wagner came under attack from Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and city Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa yesterday for his plan to purge officeholders who opposed him in the Democratic primary.

DUBLIN, Sept. 12 -- The world premiere of Dublin's two-week theatre festival, Hugh Ross Williamson's "Teresa of Avila," received a generous reception last night from members of an audience aware that the play had met with last-minute production difficulties.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept 12 (AP) -- Air France listed one passenger as Prince Sakhri of Kuwait.

An executive of the United Church of Christ proposed yesterday that the major Protestant denominations bypass their sectarian differences and merge their mission boards as a first step toward uniting of the denominations themselves.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Labor Department said today that factory employment showed normal midsummer improvement last month despite shutdowns in the automobile industry for the annual changeover to new models.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 12 -- Three neutralist chiefs of state met here today at the United States Air Base to review the Belgrade conference of nonaligned states which ended last Wednesday.
The election of William R. Biggs and Thomas F. Milbank as trustees of the Bank of New York was announced yesterday by Albert C. Simmonds Jr., chairman.

MONTREAL, Sept. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The defending champion, Harry (Bud) Melges of Lake Geneva, Wis., today won the fifth of eight races on near-by Lake St. Louis to recapture the lead in the North American yachting finals from Bob Mosbacher of Houston.

GENEVA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Australia warned the world's major sugar exporting countries this morning they must control production and check rising sugar stocks, or face an international market disaster.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- A French Parliament, fuming over alleged executive slights to its power and prestige, administered a severe -- but purely symbolic -- rebuke to the Government of Premier Michael Debre today.
DOVER, N.J., Sept. 12 -- A woman was killed and sixteen persons were injured today in an explosion at the Picatinny Arsenal.

Professional indoor seven-man football will be added to the metropolitan sports calendar in January when a new league begins play in the 3,000-seat Jersey City Armory. Franchises will be located in Jersey City, Newark and Teaneck in New Jersey and Manhattan and Brooklyn in New York.
Rarely is there a scientific paper that is of great interest simultaneously to historians, anthropologists and archaeologists on the one hand, and chemists and physicists on the other.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 12 (AP) -- It is now easier than it once was to bring libel suits in Alabama courts against out-of-state newspapers.
The controversial telecast in which United States troops joined Jack Paar before the cameras along barricades dividing East and West Berlin was shown to American viewers last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Senate Preparedness subcommittee has found a "clear and critical" need for pushing the manned bomber program, its chairman, John Stennis, said today.

On strike are locals of the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers of America. The union represents 310,000 production workers in 130 local unions at 123 plants of the General Motors Corporation.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 12 -- Moise Tshombe, President of Katanga Province, said today he would not go to Leopoldville to meet Dag Hammarskjold.

IN mid-July a flash flood in Baltimore washed out a Yankee-Oriole game before it had reached the legal distance and left it three outs short of going into the records as official. Swept down the drain with it were homer No. 36 by Roger Maris and homer No. 34 by Mickey Mantle. Each had to be smitten all over again at later dates.
A plea for American aid to establish mandatory secondary school systems in Israel, Greece and Italy was made yesterday by Charles J. Bensley, a member of the Board of Education.
The temperature rose to 94 degrees yesterday, a new high for a Sept. 12. The previous high for the date, 93, was recorded in 1895. A little relief was forecast for today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Pete Burnside, the winner of only one previous game all year, set the Boston Red Sox down on three hits tonight as the Washington Senators scored a 5-1 victory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- President Sukarno of Indonesia and President Modibo Keita of Mali arrived today to give to President Kennedy "the thoughts and concerns" of the Belgrade conference of non-aligned nations.
The Papercraft Corporation, Pittsburgh, producer of gift wrappings and tapes, had record sales and earnings last year.

TWO swallows, it is said, do not make a summer. Two first novels written at an advanced age by Italian noblemen don't supply sufficient evidence for sweeping generalizations about late-blooming literary talent among the aristocracy in Italy. Still -- the coincidence is striking. Last year "The Leopard" by Giuseppe di Lampedusa, a Sicilian prince who wrote his book in his sixties and did not live to see its publication, was an international triumph.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Poncho Segura, Andres Gimeno and Barry MacKay tonight moved into the quarter-finals of the fifth world professional hard court tennis tournament. They joined Ashley Cooper, Tony Trabert and Pancho Gonzales, who advanced yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Ireland gave notice to the conference that it would seek to change its status in the sugar market from an importing to an exporting country because of the development of its sugar beet industry to "near self-sufficiency."

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12 -- The Federal Aviation Agency has asked the Genera Services Administration not to release Mitchel Field as surplus Government property unless plans for its use include a civil airport.
By some freak of nature the most violent of big storms sometimes produce other storms that are even more destructive. In other words, hurricanes breed tornadoes.

Francis Biddle, who had a book of memoirs published last month, will have a second book published Sept. 25 by Macmillan. It will be "Justice Holmes, Natural Law and the Supreme Court," which is based on three lectures given by the former Attorney General at the University of Texas.

Samuel J. Briskin, head of production at Columbia Pictures since Harry Cohn's death three years ago, announced in Hollywood yesterday that he would turn over complete operation of the studio to Sol A. Schwartz on Oct. 2.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The House Appropriations Committee moved today to end "back-door spending" by Federal agencies through Treasury borrowing and contract authorizations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Congress moved rapidly today toward approval of President Kennedy's agreement to help France with training information on the use of nuclear weapons.

Worshipers of the Orthodox and Conservative branches of Judaism yesterday observed the second day of Rash ha-Shanah, marking the beginning of the Jewish year 5722. Reform worshipers observe one day of this holiday.
BONN, Sept. 12 -- A roar of acclaim greeted the handsome man alighting from a cream-colored Mercedes convertible.

The Air Force has opened the door to increased profits for defense manufacturers as an incentive for extraordinary performance in meeting military contracts, it was disclosed yesterday. At the same time, defense contractors must be ready to absorb larger than normal penalties for poor performance.

THE merits of the latest Continental and the Rolls Royce were being earnestly discussed. Markoe Robertson, Mrs. Lowell Weiker, Mrs. Wolcott Blair, Mrs. John Barry Ryan and Mrs. John F. MacGuigan.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points up to 13 points down yesterday. (One point equals 5 cents a bale.)

Station WNTA-TV has selected eleven dramas from "The Play of the Week" for repeat showing over Channel 13 beginning Sept. 23. Each two-hour play will be presented twice -- Saturday at 10 P.M. and Sunday at 3:30 P.M.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Malayan concern over the possible "short-cut" release of 10,000 tons of tin from the United States stockpile was echoed in the metal market here today.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 12 -- An Air France Caravelle jetliner crashed and burned in a ravine near here today, killing all seventy-seven persons aboard. It was the third major air disaster this month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board overruled Teamster Union objections today and certified an independent union as bargaining agent for employes of two Chicago taxi concerns.

MONCTON, N.B., Sept. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Alvin Hamilton, Agriculture Minister, said today he hoped long-term agreements with the Soviet Union, Communist China, Poland and Czechoslovakia would enable Canada to maintain a high level of wheat exports to those countries.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- The suicide rate has risen sharply in East Berlin since the Communist regime closed the border with West Berlin Aug. 13, according to information received today from physicians who work in East Berlin hospitals.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Joe Walker, X-15 test pilot flying "by guess and by gosh" because of mechanical trouble, still managed to set a speed record of 3,645 miles an hour today.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Typhoon Pamela slashed across northern Taiwan today, killing 100 persons and causing great property damage before crossing into the Chinese mainland.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Controller of the Currency and the Attorney General agreed on roughly half of the bank mergers proposed last year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 -- Private enterprise was called upon today to participate more boldly and responsibly in building economies of under-developed countries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Patent No. 3,000,000 was issued today with almost as much ceremony as attends the crowning of Miss America.

Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon in United States District Court here proposed yesterday that the Department of Justice's antitrust suit against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company be brought to a quick trial. He suggested that the parties agree on the facts.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 -- Liberia is planning to overhaul her shipping laws to meet the problem posed by American union seamen who are determined to win labor contracts on much of the Liberian merchant marine.
The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers adopted several resolutions yesterday aimed at cushioning the effect of automation on employment.

Phil Hill's winning of the world driver championship in the Grand Prix of Italy at Monza on Sunday and the death of Count Wolfgang von Trips and a number of spectators during the course of the race have raised speculation in this country as to the attitude Commendatore Enzo Ferrari now will take toward the Grand Prix of the United States at Watkins Glen, N.Y., on Oct. 8.

Keystone Custodian Funds, Inc., has no plans at this time to seek representation on the board of the Chicago Great Western Railway even though it now owns nearly 9 per cent of the railroad's common stock, a spokesman said yesterday.

TUNIS, Sept. 11 -- Western diplomatic observers believe that President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia has taken a "great risk" in offering to settle the Bizerte problem by accepting continued French occupation of the military base there for the duration of the Berlin crisis.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The American Bankers Association endorsed a bill today that would increase the amount of money available to national banks for real estate loans.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Roger Maris is a forthright young man who speaks his piece, lets the chips fall where they may and, possibly, would rather be right than the home run king of the majors.

The Leningrad Kirov Ballet, now appearing at the Metropolitan Opera House, will give ten performances at Madison Square Garden, Oct. 3 to 11, at a prices ranging from $2 to $8. Performances will be given evenings (except Monday) and Saturday and Sunday afternoons.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The grain futures market was beaten down by a bearish Government crop report until the final minutes of trading today when it rallied and finished with most contracts showing gains.
As rare as golfers' holes-in-one, identical bids by underwriters on a bond issue always cause a bit of comment and interest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, said after a White House call today that President Kennedy has made no final decision to nominate George D. Woods, New York financier, as his foreign aid director.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The United States indicated today that it would hold the Soviet Union responsible for any actions by East German authorities in violation of post-World War II agreements on Berlin.

Williams Co., Inc., has announced several leases in Manhattan. The leasings include Ritter Ritter, importers, with 16,000 square feet of space at 151 West Twenty-sixth Street; the Paper Box Corporation of America, with 5,000 square feet at 56 West Twenty-second Street, and the Franco Manufacturing Company, with 6,000 square feet at 28 West Twenty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Arlington Park Futurity and the Washington Park Futurity, each for 2-year-olds with a gross of $200,000, will be combined in 1962 as the Arlington-Washington Futurity with a gross of $400,000 -- the richest in world horse racing.
WASHINGTON, Sept 12 -- Congress sent to the White House today a bill to aid communities in fighting juvenile delinquency.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 12 -- The Dominican Government tonight placed its capital on a virtual war footing. Tanks were lined through the streets following a day of wild disorders marked by fatal shootings.

DENVER, Sept. 12 -- Richard M. Nixon tonight warned the growing field of Republican gubernatorial entries in California to focus their primary campaign ammunition on the Democrats rather than each other.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The value of four paintings taken in a robbery of the David E. Bright mansion was reduced today to $246,165 from the original estimate of $670,000, the police said.
Six hundred women gathered at the Metropolitan Club yesterday to honor Dr. Hachiro Yuasa, entomologist and recently retired president of the International Christian University of Tokyo.

A cab driver, a bank messenger, a bricklayer, a postman and a manufacturer's representative received the Police Department's green and white Civilian Commendation bar yesterday for helping policemen "at considerable personal risk."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A special committee of the Civil War Centennial Commission failed today to agree on a replacement for the commission's ousted executive director, Karl S. Betts.

THE Belgrade conference of unaligned countries was the subject of an hour-long review last night over Channel 4, a review of valuable and incisive interest. THE clothes sold beneath a College Shop banner do not always make their way to a campus. Despite the hiring of college students to act as saleswomen, the addition of collegiate decor in sportswear departments and vigorous advertising promotions, all of which have become standard procedure in many New York stores, the merchandise is frequently more popular among young matrons than with collegians.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A former Dodger, Don Demeter, drove in seven runs with three homers and a single tonight as the Philadelphia Phils belted Los Angeles, 19 -- 10. The loss dropped the second-place Dodgers four and a half games back of the National League leaders, the Cincinnati Reds, who defeated the Chicago Cubs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- With Dick Stuart driving in all the runs on a pair of homers, Joe Gibbon, Pittsburgh Pirates' southpaw, shut out the San Francisco Giants, 3 -- 0, tonight with three hits.

William Schuman's selection as president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is a rare case in this country of a creative artist's being chosen to fill a key administrative post. In Europe, the direction of cultural institutions is often placed in the hands of important figures in the artistic world on the theory that a topflight creative mind can learn how to handle administration as quickly as an administrator can penetrate artistic problems.

VIENNA, Sept. 12 -- The Austrian Cabinet instructed Interior Minister Josef Afritsch and several of his ministerial colleagues today to sharpen the controls along the Austrian-Italian border, over which Austrian and German terrorists have been smuggling explosives into Italy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Soviet Union conducted the seventh atomic test in its current series by detonating a multi-megaton device in the atmosphere early today at its Arctic proving ground.
