A modernization program has begun in the twelve-story office building at 320 Fifth Avenue, at Thirty-second Street. Most of the remodeling work will be done in the lobby and on the facade of the structure, which is owned by Jack Brause. Automatic elevators and a new heating plant will be installed.

The First National Bank of Waukesha, Wis., put into operation yesterday an Autobanker, a device that allows teller and customer -- though hundreds of feet apart -- to see each other, talk with each other and to exchange money, bank books or other documents.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Despite a short-lived rally, industrial shares generally closed with small net losses on the stock market here today. The turnover remained very low.

THAT the demands of marriage and motherhood are not necessarily incompatible with a fruitful professional. career is a proposition Margaret Millicent Carey McIntosh has often advanced in speaking and writing.
GALVESTON, Tex., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Hurricane Carla carried its potent wrath to the Midwest today, leaving at least thirty-one dead in its path that stretched from the Gulf of Mexico into Illinois.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 13 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold arrived here today a few hours after United Nations military forces gave the Congolese Central Government control over the secessionist province of Katanga.

ROME, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Agostino Cardinal Bea, German-born member of the Vatican Curia, said today every effort should be made to achieve a union of aims among world churches, regardless of denomination.
In connection with the A.P. dispatch published in The Times on Sept. 7 and your editorial of Sept. 9 "Cambodia Against Communists," I feel obliged to make the following comments:
Since "Happy Birthday" closed here in 1948 after a run of 563 performances with Helen Hayes in the starring role, there has been talk of putting Anita Loos' comedy into musical form.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 13 -- An American team of five skippers and crews defeated a team from Norway, 59 1/4 to 47, in the second race of a three-of-five series for the Skoal Trophy today and took a 2-0 lead in the competition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 6:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Cuban affairs specialists here recalled today that an assassination attempt against Se+/-or Rodriguez several months ago also failed.

The Air Reduction Sales Company, a division of Air Reduction Company, Inc., "Airco" announced an agreement with E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., to furnish oxygen from a large-volume plant to be built and operated by Airco, on a site adjacent to du Pont's new methanol facility being constructed near Huron, Ohio.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 13 -- The United Nations' intervention in Katanga today was apparently based on a Security Council resolution authorizing the organization to use force "in the last resort" to prevent civil war in the Congo.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 13 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller said today he would have removed Mayor Wagner from office if the State Investigation Commission had reported information to warrant it.
The reported ending of Katanga's fourteen months of independence as the Congo's secessionist province may mean a new economic lease on life for the Congo's Central Government.
A strike threat by flight navigators against Trans World Airlines was revoked last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- The House approved today legislation designed to speed the deportation of undesirable aliens, including racketeers and subversives.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Village officials reported today they would pay $175,000 for 3.4 acres of land for a new park or village hall site and levy 90 per cent of the cost against 475 near-by property owners.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- A new police burglary scandal came to light today less than a month after eight Chicago policemen were convicted of having conspired with a thief to commit burglaries and conceal stolen property.
The word went out to the Democratic clubhouses in the Bronx and Brooklyn yesterday to replace Levitt posters with Wagner posters.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The United States is urgently reviewing its policies toward the Dominican Republic in the light of the violent developments of the last two days.

MRS. MORI HANAE, a diminutive Japanese dress designer, was in New York for a few days recently to take a look at American fashions as they are conceived on Seventh Avenue and worn on Fifth Avenue. After she had studied the situation, she was a little puzzled.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., attained record sales in the six months ended July 31, and made a substantial increase in earnings for the second quarter of this year, according to the report issued yesterday by Bruce A. Gimbel, president.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The United States will ask the Western Allies this week-end to join it in a gradual effort to negotiate an accommodation with the Soviet Union on Berlin and the rest of Germany.

Thurgood Marshall, chief counsel to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, is slated for appointment to one of three new judgeships on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Government reports indicate that farm real estate debt will climb to a record by the end of the year.
WASHINGTON Sept. 13 (UPI) -- The Treasury took a cautious "neutral" position today on legislation to provide tax relief for stockholders in the du Pont-General Motors antitrust case.
An owner of a rooming house in the Chelsea area of Manhattan was fined $350 and given a sixty-day suspended sentence in the workhouse on a first offense in Housing Court yesterday.

In a letter published Sept. 1 Harvey Glickenstein questioned whether a small sum of money could not be expended on a subway extension to the 1964 World's Fair site. He noted that Robert Moses has asked for a huge sum to be appropriated for roadway construction leading to the fair.

The National Broadcasting Company has sold the Hudson Theatre to an undisclosed buyer who plans to demolish the building and erect a garage. The theatre is at 141 West Forty-fourth Street, between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.

The American Management Association has leased three floors in the twenty-three-story office building under construction at 135 West Fiftieth Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.
How long will our confused nation continue to give priority to some sort of global Hooper rating over the megaton rating preferred by the Kremlin?

The Buildings Department started yesterday to evict about seventy-five persons, most of them children, from a Harlem tenement that was so dirty and rundown it was described by one city employe as a "horror house."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Navy will call up 1,957 more reservists to fill the ranks of eighteen air squadrons that previously were summoned to active duty.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Congress completed today action on legislation extending the life of the Civil Rights Commission for two years.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 13 -- United Nations forces seized control of this city today in fierce fighting with troops of Katanga Province.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Dominicans by the thousands defied the Government today, shutting their shops and joining a dramatic funeral procession despite a major show of strength by the armed forces.
A series of television debates between Mayor Wagner and his Republican opponent. Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, became a strong possibility yesterday.
BRIDGE will be one of the attractions at a party to be given at sea on the liner Nieuw Amsterdam on Sept. 21 by the New York Committee of the American Cancer Society.

As media costs continue to rise, advertisers are making more and more of an effort to pinpoint their potential markets and to aim their messages at a selective audience. This principle has been carried to its logical extreme by one Washington, D.C., advertiser, which sponsors a radio program with perhaps the most selective audience of all.

KINGS POINT, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy, climbing the football ladder under the energetic coaching of Harry Wright, expects its 1961 team to be at least 50 per cent improved over that of 1960.

Now that the House and Senate have passed differing versions of the bill to acquire waterfowl marshes while there are still marshes to be saved, and a conference committee has agreed on a compromise, Congress should surely complete action before adjournment.
PARIS, Sept. 13 -- The split between France's Government and her Parliament widened today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The House of Representatives today refused to approve even a single electric generator at the Hanford, Wash., plant that produces plutonium for nuclear weapons.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 13 -- The State Department publicly urged Maryland's Legislature today to pass a bill ending segregation in all restaurants, hotels and other public accommodations in the state.
Consumption of gasoline over the long Labor Day week-end failed to make a dent in the nation's inventories of the fuel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Washington Senators, with Joe McClain putting down a ninth-inning threat in relief of Ed Hobaugh, beat the Boston Red Sox, 4 -- 2, tonight for their second straight victory.
The Army announced yesterday it would extend options to some former enlisted men beyond the ninety-day period to permit them to re-enlist at their former ranks.

The Pittsburgh National Bank announced yesterday that it would buy 63,750 capital shares of its own stock from a New York City investment banker in order to effect a proposed merger with the First National Bank of New Kensington, Pa.

Your editorial of Sept. 2 "Overnight Parking Fees" is, from the standpoint of the New York city car owner, preposterous. You recommend a $5-a-month fee for overnight parking on the streets because this "simple method" would help "solve the city's fiscal needs" and "bring in more than $40,000,000 year revenue."
Printers employed by ten New York newsapapers began balloting last night on whether to accept a proposed two-year contract or strike.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 13 -- A team described by its coach as "tired of losing" will carry the hopes of Villanova through the coming football season. The Wildcats are determined to improve on their 1960 showing of two victories and eight losses.

The Turtle Bay Music School will benefit from a theatre party to "The Gay Life" on Nov. 28. The musical is scheduled to open at the Shubert Theatre on Nov. 18. A pre-theatre dinner party will be held at Leone's.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 (AP) The Cleveland Indians routed the Baltimore Orioles tonight, 5 -- 0, and snapped a six-game losing streak behind the four-hit pitching of Gary Bell.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he would not disclose the identifies of the twenty-six candidates proposed for membership on the Board of Education.
The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation announced yesterday it planned to acquire the Kirk Telephone System in Alabama and Georgia.

THE characters in J.D. Salinger's stories are always tap dancing expertly on one another's nerves. They are bright Tarkingtonian people in Kafka's dark world, full of high spirits and low boiling points.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 13 -- Governor Rockefeller's son-in-law and eleven other white and three Negro clergymen were arrested here today while seeking service in a segregated bus terminal restaurant.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 13 -- "Everybody is hot, but some people feel hotter than others."

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that its sales and earnings for the third quarter set records for the period and helped make results for the first nine months of its present fiscal year the second highest in the concern's history.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 13 -- Woody Hayes, the head football coach at Ohio State, indicated strongly tonight that college football games had been fixed by gamblers.
The Ford Motor Company plans to acquire the Philco Corporation in an exchange of stock that would involve about $100,000,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Probably more than anyone else, Hank Greenberg knows what Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle, especially the former, are going through. He is cognizant of the pressure, the anxiety, the loss of privacy and the myriad problems with which the Yankees' M-Squad is confronted.
MONTREAL, Sept. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Harry C. (Bud) Melges of Lake Geneva, Wis., today won the Mallory Cup for the North American. yachting championship for the third time in its ten-year history.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- Two-run homers by Dick Stuart and Bill Mazeroski highlighted a six-run barrage in the eighth inning tonight that brought the Pittsburgh Pirates an 8-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

The real losers in the controversy over the appointment of George D. Woods or Henry R. Labouisse to head the new foreign aid organization are the people of the United States. Either man would have been an excellent choice to direct the Agency for International Development, as it is to be called. But now A.I.D., a major instrument of American foreign policy, has had to start off under the cloud of an utterly unnecessary row.

Production of electric power in the nation totaled 15,838,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the holiday week ended last Saturday, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This figure compared with a record of 16,214,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 14,615,000,000 kilowatt-hours a year ago.

Long Island schoolboy football, regarded by some as the best in the state, promises to be more competitive and exciting this season. New schools, new coaches and the revision of the teams in the Nassau County leagues are expected to add spice to the program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Sol C. Siegel, a man who can decide what moviegoers will see three years from now, said yesterday that he would not make pictures with racial themes or sex perversion angles.
Camels were destined to race again, the other day, as they did ninety-five years ago, in Virginia City, Nev., a place of immortal memory now given over to tourist enticement.
Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, head of Barnard College since 1947, will retire next spring.

On Sept. 7 the Democratic voters of New York administered a crushing defeat to Tammany. This is a notable achievement, but does not necessarily mean that the Tammany system of political bossism and power for the sake of power has been eliminated once and for all.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- American League officials today adopted a 162-game schedule for 1962 and set aside dates for two All-Star games, the first on July 10 in Washington.

RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 13 -- The American naval attache to Monrovia, Liberia, and his assistant were among seventy-eight persons killed in the crash last night of a French jetliner three miles east of here. Three Americans in all died in the disaster.

HAVANA, Sept. 13 -- The Government said today that an attempt had been made on the life of Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, editor of the Communist newspaper Hoy and an increasingly influential figure in Cuba.
Two youths in a stolen car injured six persons and sideswiped five automobiles during a five-mile chase in the Bronx last night.
The recent firmness of the high-grade bond market became more emphatic yesterday, but the volume of transactions in other than new issues stayed light.

COUNTLESS women (and a handful of men) have landed in retailing feet first. The late Dorothy Shaver, as president of Lord Taylor, was only one of many successful merchants who started as comparison shoppers.

North Advertising, Inc., is placing an unusual series of advertisements on behalf of several of its clients in a French magazine, Jours de France. The clients pay only for the artwork and layout, while the agency loots the bill for the space.

Dick Gregory, who won quick fame last spring as the first Negro comic to succeed in sophisticated, metropolitan cabarets, is back at the newly reopened Blue Angel. If there was any suspicion that he might prove to be a one-season vogue, rather than a durable, first-rate talent, it is now completely dispelled.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- The Secret Armed Organization of Right-wing extremists now opposing President de Gaulle's Algerian policies denied responsibility today for last Friday night's attempt on the President's life.

NEWPORT, Ky., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Campbell County grand jury indicted almost the entire Newport city government today. It charged that thirteen officials had conspired to obstruct justice by permitting widespread vice.
The Daniel Guggenheim Medal for 1961 will be awarded to Jerome Lederer, international authority on flight safety, for "his constant and untiring efforts to reduce the hazards of aviation.''
UPTON, L.I., Sept. 13 -- The world's largest and most powerful particle accelerator, the $32,000,000 alternating gradient synchrotron, was dedicated here today at Brookhaven National Laboratory.
CLIFTON, N.J., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Clifton and Passaic police used fire hoses today to stop what they called the worst labor fight here in twenty-five years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- A member of President Kennedy's fact-finding board in the nation-wide maritime strike sent word today that he would be on hand tomorrow to help negotiate an agreement here between West Coast shipowners and deck officers.

VIENNA, Sept. 13 -- Janos Kadar, First Secretary of the Hungarian Communist party took over, the post of Premier today in a shake-up of the regime. The governmental reorganization, which gave Mr. Kadar virtual single-handed control in Hungary, was reported by M.T.I., the Hungarian Press agency.

A new master plan for state aid to local school districts was submitted to state officials yesterday by the New York State Educational Conference Board. If adopted, the plan is expected to give New York City close to $100,000,000 in additional school aid annually.
White and Negro parents at the Manhattanville housing project in Harlem banded together yesterday in defiance of the Board of Education's refusal to allow their children to change schools.

Artur Rubinstein, who will perform works by Beethoven, Brahms, Debussy, Villa-Lobos and Chopin at his Oct. 30 recital in Carnegie Hall, will turn the proceeds of that evening over to the Musicians Emergency Fund.

With submission of a list of twenty-six names to Mayor Wagner, the selection panel for the city's new school board has completed the first phase of a dramatic and long-range school reform program. As all the candidates on the list have already indicated their willingness to serve, the panel has thus given Mr. Wagner a broad choice from among almost three times as many persons as there are positions to be filled.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) United States negotiators have agreed to a 7 to 8 per cent increase next year of Japanese exports of cotton textiles to this country.
DENVER, Sept. 13 -- From a hotel window overlooking Denver's downtown area, no signs have been perceptible, except at rare intervals, that anything unusual is going on.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers charged yesterday in a convention resolution that the Kennedy Administration and Congress had taken no action to protect the best interests of the working people.

TO judge by the restaurants that have opened in New York recently, there has never been a greater interest in Chinese cuisine than at present. A further indication is the enrollment in cooking classes that specialize in Chinese dishes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The United States Steel Corporation told President Kennedy today that its concern for inflation was no less than his, but that steel prices and profits were not the cause.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad said today that preliminary figures indicated net income rose sharply in August to the largest total for any month this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it would offer surplus corn for sale at market prices.

Bishop Eduardo Boza Masvidal, former rector of Villanueva University, which has been closed by the Cuban Government, was reported yesterday to be under arrest in connection with a large anti-Government demonstration in downtown Havana Sunday.
Stocks gave a mixed performance yesterday, as the averages dominated by the shares of the larger companies went down and those containing a wider selection went up. More stocks rose than fell.

Between plays of a dummy scrimmage at the Polo Grounds yesterday, Al Dorow of the New York Football Titans struck the incongruous pose of a batsman. The quarterback swung at an imaginary pitch and told a team-mate:
Cotton futures fell 5 to 45 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- For the second time within a month, a nation-wide syndicate headed by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association was out bid today for a $100,000,000, offering of California bonds.
As a member of the House Committee on Education and Labor I wish to commend you on your critical editorial of Sept. 6 on school aid.

Damage from Hurricane Carla to the Freeport, Tex., plant of the Dow Chemical Company is expected to cost at least $2,000, 000, Dr. Leland I. Doan, president of Dow, told the annual meeting in Midland, Mich., yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers trounced the Kansas City Athletics today, 8 -- 0. Rocky Colavito and Norm Cash hit homers and Jim Bunning allowed five hits in pitching his sixteenth victory.

THE headline in The New York Times for the Labor Day ball game was curiously enigmatic. "Could Not Score a Run," it said. The New York team had played a scoreless tie with the Philadelphia team and the story was as curiously enigmatic as the headline. That was on Sept. 5, 1888; newspapers were a little different in those days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Soviet Union set off two more nuclear explosions today. They were the eighth and ninth of a rapid testing program that, the United States charged, must have required long and secret preparation.
STOWE, Vt., Sept. l3 -- Soviet and American scientists meeting in unofficial discussion agreed today on some issues connected with cessation of production of nuclear stockpiles and their destruction.
NEW DELHI. India. WHEN Usha Kapoor decided to become a salesgirl a few years ago, her father was strongly opposed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's statement today at the conclusion of his meetings with President Sukarno of Indonesia and President Modibo Keita Mali:

The prompt termination of a work stoppage at a Titan missile site near Denver focuses attention on the general effectiveness of the no-strike machinery set up by President Kennedy and Secretary of Labor Goldberg last May. In the first three months of the pledge by unions and employers to resolve their disputes peaceably through the mediation and arbitration facilities created by the Government, only 768 man-days of work were lost through strikes.
Mrs. Donald Agnew, chairman, and Mrs. Carleton H. Palmer, vice chairman, have announced that arrangements are being made for a theatre party for the benefit of the National Council on Alcoholism.

DETROIT, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- Jubilant Michigan Republicans hailed today their sweeping triumph in the state's constitutional convention election as a sure sign that the party was making a comeback after more than a decade of Democratic successes.

JACK PAAR'S numbing determination to make a spectacle of himself was realized Tuesday evening in his first taped television program from West Berlin. The display of puerility on the border by the entertainer and his co-star, Peggy Cass, amply substantiated Washington's apprehension and Moscow's appreciation.

A forty-eight-hour world-wide strike aboard Argentine-flag vessels called by the Argentine Maritime Workers Union to focus attention on demands for higher wages and a forty-eight-hour work week is scheduled to start this morning.

A new series of books on mathematics was issued here yesterday as part of a concerted effort to bridge the gap between mathematics as it is practiced by professional mathematicians and as it is taught in high schools.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Administration endorsed today the key provisions of a bill designed to lower drug prices and safeguard the consumer.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 13 -- A Commonwealth debate on Britain's move to join the European Economic Community Common Market, ended tonight with a blunt warning that Britain had jeopardized her leadership of the Commonwealth.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 13 -- Alarmed at a sharp drop in prices of coconut products and loss of traditional markets for these commodities, the Ceylonese Ministry of Trade Commerce is planning to make representations to the United States Government about alleged dumping of excess soybean oil in European markets.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The grain futures market had periods of fairly general strength today on the Board of Trade but it was mostly weak at the finish.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 13 -- The first real winds showed Roy Hickok's Wildcat to her best advantage as trials continued today to select the American defender in the catamaran challenge match against Great Britain.

MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 13 -- Adding two second places to his triumph yesterday, Thomas G. Allen of Buffalo maintained his lead as the International Lightning Class Association's first world sailing championship continued today.
The City Planning Commission paved the way yesterday for a wide redevelopment in Manhattan. It unanimously declared two sections on the East Side and one on the West Side suitable for urban renewal.
Sessions of the New York commodity exchanges were quiet yesterday, with the exception of the New York Mercantile, where 923 carlots of potatoes were sold.

BY following a few simple rules the home cook can always brew a good cup of coffee. Start with a thoroughly clean coffee-maker and rinse it with hot water before using. Use only fresh coffee and buy the size of can or package that will be used within a week after opening.
A weather rocket streaking into the stratosphere, loosing clouds of sodium and lithium vapor, enchanted and alarmed thousands of persons in the New York area shortly before 8 o'clock last night.

HOPEWELL, N.J., Sept. 13 -- A house tour that will include a visit to the Hopewell Museum will be held Saturday for the benefit of the museum. Tickets will be available at the museum on East Broad Street.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13 -- The Soviet Union asserted today that its armed forces were equipped with intercontinental ballistic rockets "invulnerable to modern means of counter-action" and of practically unlimited range.

TANANARIVE, Malagasy Republic, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- The twelve nations of the French Community in Africa demanded today a share for all African nations in the exploitation of the oil and mineral resources of the Sahara.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 13 -- Army troops of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland were moved today to guard the Northern Rhodesian border with Katanga.
Joe Manchester, theatrical producer, charged in State Supreme Court yesterday that he had been cheated of his right to produce a new George S. Kaufman-Leueen MacGrath play, "I Give It Six Months."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Senate investigators accused naval officials today of showing a lack of concern about payoffs involving civilian employes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee restored all but a fraction of the House cuts in foreign aid funds today and cleared the way for a vote on the $4,196,600,000 bill on Friday.

ATHENS, Sept. 13 -- The engagement of Prince Juan Carlos, son of the pretender to the Spanish throne, and Princess Sophia, eldest daughter of King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece, was announced today.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller said tonight that tax increases would not be needed to finance sharp rises in state spending for schools next year.
The Transit Authority will meet with the City Planning Commission within a week to press its request for $161,242,449 to buy 1,580 new subway cars.

An American edition of a Japanese officer's story of the fall of Singapore will be published on Oct. 2 by St. Martin's Press. Called "Singapore," the book was written by Col. Masanobu Tsuji, who carried out the reconnaissance leading to the Japanese campaign in Malaya and directed operations that led to Singapore's defeat.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- The Roger Maris-Mickey Mantle home run derby and the Yankees' pennant drive ground to a soggy halt tonight. For the second successive night the weather interfered in the three-game series with the White Sox.
SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 13 (AP) -- A long-range study of Government policy on purchases of uranium was proposed today at the American Mining Congress' convention.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 13 -- The Mapai party decided today to ask President Yitzhak Ben-Zvi to turn the job of forming a new coalition government for Israel over to Finance Minister Levi Finance.

Last Sunday at the Westchester Kennel Club show, an entry of twenty-five Basenjis competed for the best-of-breed prize. Among the contestants was a red-and-white dog, Phemister's Babu, shown by Alexander Phemister of Kingston, Mass.
The Atomic Energy Commission reported yesterday it was investigating a report that a concrete and steel barrel with an A.E.C. symbol has been snagged in a fisherman's net off the New Jersey coast.
BERLIN, Thursday, Sept. 14 -- The East German police have arrested four foreigners, including two Americans, on charges of having attempted to smuggle persons out of East Germany.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Jim Duffalo, making his first major league start, beat the Philadelphia Phils tonight, 8 -- 2. He also drove in four of the San Francisco Giants' runs, three of them on a homer.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller said tonight that corruption would remain a major issue in the New York City mayoral race despite Mayor Wagner's primary victory on an anti-bossism issue.
HILO, Hawaii, Sept. 5 -- One of the mottos of the National Park Service is: "Keep our forests green." In fact its guiding policy is to preserve the status quo throughout its farflung domains.

The New York and American Stock exchanges reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies:

David B. Charnay, who on Aug. 23 resigned as a director and chairman of the executive committee of Hazel Bishop, Inc., cosmetics manufacturer, on the same date liquidated his entire stock holdings in the company. This was disclosed yesterday in the so-called insiders' list issued by the American Stock Exchange.
CONNIE FRANCIS, a successful popular singer whose style is loud, clear and not particularly distinctive, had her own one-hour show over Channel 7 last night.
VIENNA, Sept. 13 -- The Austrian Tyrol terrorist organization that is operating in Italy today planted Molotov cocktail bombs in Vienna against Italian citizens.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 13 -- Eight Soviet delegates to the Twentieth International Navigation Congress straggled into the meeting this morning three days late because of what they said was visa trouble.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- The Free Democratic party said today it would demand the ouster of Chancellor Adenauer if his Christian Democratic party should lose its Parliamentary majority in the West German elections Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- President Kennedy signed three bills aimed at organized crime and racketeering today.
THE usual pains of adolescence, hymned in song, story and drama, are a pleasant bagatelle compared with the troubles that confront Jeff, the lad in "Cockeyed Kite."

Events tonight: David Vanderkooi, 'cellist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Dick Wellstood and The Fats Waller Alumni, Jazz in the Garden, Museum of Modern Art, 8:30; Operatic Concert, presented by Opera Workshop, Public School 75, West End Avenue and Ninty-fifth Street, 8.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Sept. 13 -- Nathan Straus, chairman of radio station WMCA in New York and former Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, was found dead in a motel room here this afternoon.
A television station in Hartford has arranged to make an off-the-air pickup of two WCBS-TV educational programs hero and relay them to viewers in Hartford.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Officials said today that the Kennedy Administration had decided to shelve the latest request of the Communist Government of Poland for United States economic aid.
HARTFORD, Sept. 13 -- Republican leaders of eleven Eastern states gathered here today to exchange ideas on how to win friends and influence voters in 1962.
High weight, a vexing problem to some ladies, was the undoing of Primonetta in the $28,850 Gazelle Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.
Professional and clerical employes of the Development Corporation for Israel have ratified the terms of a two-year contract, their union announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- Industrial and business leaders of the free world were cautioned today that "lapses from grace" by one business damaged the whole business structure, stained its nation's flag, embarrased a country's friends and gave comfort to its enemies.
The top management of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, prime contractor for the Polaris missile, was reorganized yesterday.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Favorites fared badly on the Pebble Beach course today during the United States Amateur golf championship. By the time the third and fourth rounds had reduced the field to sixteen, only two players who had ever won national titles remained.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- President Kennedy made it clear to two neutralist leaders today that he was not prepared to begin summit talks with Premier Khrushchev until "they could serve a useful purpose."
The top management of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, prime contractor for the Polaris missile, was reorganized yesterday.
Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges carried his familiar pep talk on exports to Boston yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Joey Jay blanked his former Milwaukee Brave team-mates on four hits tonight and led Cincinnati's Reds to a 1-0 victory.
The Audio Show, an annual high point for sound buffs and musical engineers, has adopted a dignified, pianissimo tone this year.

The Department of Justice withdrew its motion for a temporary restraining order in its antitrust suit against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company yesterday with the understanding that its case would be tried before the end of the year.

The New York State central school district composed of Ramapo, Clarkstown, Orangetown and Haverstraw sold yesterday $3,230,000 of bonds due serially from 1963 to 1991 to the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and associates.

Control of tonight's First District Democratic judicial convention hung in the balance last night after a day of furious political activity by the Wagner-reform and the De Sapio-Buckley regular Democratic factions.
The wives of the three Republican candidates for citywide office opened a demure election campaign of their own yesterday with a press conference at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Sir David came to Washington in 1942 as chief of a British propaganda and intelligence mission. His job was to help co ordinate British and United States propaganda and intelligence activities in Europe and the Far East.

THE National Society of Interior Designers will open four interior-design clinics to the public, one each week during National Interior Design Month, which will be held from Sept. 18 to Oct. 18. The clinics will be held at the National Design Center, 415 East Fifty-third Street.
Maritime management and labor urged the Secretary of Commerce yesterday to approve promptly a steel company's application to build two huge ore carriers with Government aid.
The possibility of a measles vaccine to be ready some time next year was suggested yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, long a leader of the conservative bloc in Congress, estimated today that the Administration's programs would increase the Federal budget to at least $106,000,000,000 by 1965.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Following is the text of a letter to President Kennedy from Rober M. Blough, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, the country's largest steel producer:
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 13 -- Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak will visit Premier Khrushchev in Moscow Tuesday.

ATLANTA, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Nearly complete returns in Atlanta's mayoralty race indicated tonight there would be a runoff between a prominent business man making his first political race and an ardent segregationist.

Theatre parties to "Hi, Paisano" on Sept. 28 and 29 will benefit the Paderewski Foundation, Inc. The musical is scheduled to open at the York Playhouse, First Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, on Sept. 27.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 13 -- The United States fired an unmanned Mercury capsule into orbit today and brought it back safely after one circuit of the earth.

JERICHO, L.I., Sept. 13 -- Mrs. Allan A. Ryan, the Creek Club, took the first low net prize with 37, 35 -- 72 in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournament at Meadow Brook County Club today.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The British Government said tonight it was willing to hear objections to its proposed changes in the Constitution of Northern Rhodesia.
A widow charged in State Supreme Court yesterday that her husband's death had been caused by "excessive vibrations and noises by giant air conditioners" in their East Side apartment building.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- The merged labor federation urged President Kennedy today to issue an executive order recognizing the right of Federal employes to join labor unions and permitting the deduction of union dues from their pay checks.

The State Investigation Commission left open yesterday the possibility that it might disclose the results of an inquiry into Mayor Wagner's affairs, though it again refused to confirm or deny that it had made such a study.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- T. Edmund Beck of the Scarsdale Golf Club took a twos-troke lead for the twenty-seventh annual Westchester Seniors' golf Association championship today by scoring a 40, 37 -- 77 over the East course at the Winged Foot Golf Club.
PARENTS today are better informed, more critical and more articulate than ever before, in the opinion of a woman who pleads the case of local parents at City Hall and in Albany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- From the destructive path of Hurricane Carla, meteorologists were beginning today to glean scientific findings that should lead to better understanding and perhaps control of tropical storms.
After four months in power, the military junta ruling South Korea has begun to show commendable signs of competence and responsibility.
Standard Poor's, Inc., after more than six months' statistical work with the help of a computer, has compiled a master list of 200 Rapid Growth Stocks out of more than 4,000 candidates.
LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The British Government banned tonight the mass demonstration against nuclear weapons planned for next Sunday by the Committee of 100.
Irwin Vincent Powell, a 41-year-old securities dealer who was accused of kidnapping and beating a former United States Attorney, was arrested yesterday at his home at 4 Putnam Hill, Greenwich, Conn.

The first part of a three-day auction of city-owned property was held yesterday by the Department of Real Estate at the Statler Hilton Hotel. Of 201 parcels offered, mostly vacant land in Queens, 136 were sold. The rest were either withdrawn or no bids were received.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- After a dull start, share prices improved in the stock market here today. In most cases the early losses were not quite erased and small falls predominated at the close.

The record of a journey of discovery through the islands of the South Seas is told by David Attenborough in "People of Paradise," which Harper will issue on Sept. 27. The author, a producer of documentary films for the British Broadcasting Corporation, toured through Fiji, Tongo and the New Hebrides.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company announced today it had signed agreements that would permit United States subscribers to Western Union's Telex service to communicate directly with foreign patrons of International Telex Systems.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 14 -- Joe Carr brought a realistic challenge from Dublin to the United States Amateur golf championship today. Running in a birdie putt at the eighteenth hole after Gene Francis, his 23-year-old opponent from Westbury, L.I., had knocked the ball over the sea wall, Carr won their quarter-final match by 1 up.

CLIFTON, N.J., Sept. 14 -- An uneasy peace prevailed today at the Duralite Company plant on Barbour Avenue, where twenty persons, including four Clifton policemen, were injured yesterday in a clash of rival unions. Involved are the International Union of Electrical Workers and the Teamsters Union.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York rose $58,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase compared with a rise of $160,000,000 in the 1960 week.

GALILEE, R.I., Sept. 14 -- In its most familiar form, tuna is encountered between slices of bread. By the weight of a few tunafish sandwiches the United States Atlantic tournament record was broken yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches took a one-stroke lead today in the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's eleventh annual thirty-six-hole senior championship.
The first concert in the New York Bach Festival series will take place in Town Hall tonight at 8:30 Sayard Stone will conduct the New Chamber Orchestra.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Hurricane Esther continued along her west-northwest course toward the United States today, but weather men said it was much too early to predict whether it would continue on to the mainland.
The nation-wide air defense drill next month that will ground all but military planes for twelve hours has presented the airlines with a problem of what to do with all that time on their hands.

David Vanderkooi, principal 'cellist of the Oklahoma City Symphony Orchestra, made his New York debut last night with a program in Carnegie Recital Hall. As one of the earliest of the indoor concerts to be given this season, it helped to start off the city's musical activities most engagingly.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- A three-day general strike called by opponents of the Government to protest the deaths of two Opposition workers collapsed twenty-four hours short of its goal today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- A big white ship, the floating hospital and medical school Hope, returned to her home port today from Indonesia and South Vietnam. She sailed out through the Golden Gate last Sept. 22 on a privately financed mission to carry medical knowledge and treatment to Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill to continue authorization for dual rate contracts by steamship conferences. It earlier rejected anti-trust amendments strongly urged by the Justice Department.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charged yesterday that forces in the city administration were apparently trying to hamper his investigation of charges that eleven plumbing companies had attempted to defraud the Board of Education.
Amid the splendor of the East Side, an experiment in entertainment is under way. The swank Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel is exploring new roads for the musical theatre.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- President Kennedy has set up a Cabinet-level group to draft a program for waging psychological and political warfare.

The Ford Motor Company disclosed yesterday where it would obtain the more than 1,000,000 shares of common stock needed for exchange purposes to complete its proposed acquisition of Philco Corporation. It plans to buy the shares from the Ford Foundation.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 14 -- Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, received prolonged applause at the Inter-Parliamentary Conference today when he answered a Soviet attack on the West.

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 14 (AP) -- W. Averell Harriman arrived here today for talks with Laotian leaders on forming a coalition government for Laos and reaching a peaceful settlement of her thirteen-month-old crisis.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Ken Boyer's twenty-second homer to open the eleventh inning tonight lifted the St. Louis Cardinals past the Chicago Cubs, 6 -- 5, for a sweep of a double-header. The Redbirds won the opener, 8 -- 7.
A SMALLER supply from near-by fields means a larger price tag on a number of vegetables this week-end.

No American -- not even and not especially when he happens to be a former Turkish citizen -- should venture to take sides about internal Turkish problems, such as is the trial of the former Bayar-Menderes administration now reaching its climax in Yasi-Ada.

A provocative new attack upon the values of the advertising business has been made by the British historian, Dr. Arnold J. Toynbee. According to Dr. Toynbee, "the destiny of our Western civilization turns on the issue of our struggle with all that Madison Avenue stands for more than it turns on the issue of our struggle with communism."

A MAINBOCHER collection that falls to convince women of taste that the "Main way" is the right way is as rare as a sunflower in the snow. Yesterday's fall and winter custom showing intensified this conviction and left many women in the audience craving one of his designs.

The long-delayed showdown for the control of the Dominican Republic may be finally approaching. The time bomb placed there on May 30 when Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina was assassinated after thirty-one years as Latin America's harshest dictator could well be nearing the point of explosion.
An auto mechanic and firemen were credited with assists yesterday in the arrest of two teen-aged boys accused of attacking and robbing a 77-year-old woman in the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A Government notice that it would sell surplus corn somewhat more freely chased some speculators out of the future market today in a broad flurry of liquidation on the Board of Trade. Prices fell more than a cent a bushel on all corn contracts.

The New York Stock Exchange, which likes to spread the good word about stock ownership, also likes the idea of employe stock purchase plans. Yesterday, it published a twenty-four page survey on the subject, entitled "Stock Plans for Employees."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Only 4,328 fans -- the smallest crowd since the Giants moved west from New York in 1958 -- watched today as the Philadelphia Phillies beat San Francisco, 4 -- 3, in ten innings.
Most futures prices on the New York commodities exchanges were lower yesterday in generally featureless trading.

AS you took your seat for the opening of "I Want You" at the Maidman Playhouse last night, the usher gave you, with the program, a copy of the sheet music of the title song. It was a gift, about the only one of the evening.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 14 -- An American missionary smuggling an Arab youth from Jordan to Israel stepped on a mine in No Man's Land in early morning darkness today. Both were seriously injured by the explosion.

Eleven television stations in the South are considering whether to carry an American Broadcasting Company documentary about the world of the Negro American and how it feels to live in it. The network said the stations had requested a preview before deciding to put the program on the air.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins split with the Los Angeles Angels in their final 1961 meeting today, the Twins taking the second game, 3 -- 1, on Jim Kaat's three-hitter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Industrial production continued to rise last month. The gain was less than those in the preceding four months but more than normal for August.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- In the Yankees' dressing room after he had gone hitless in seven official trips to the plate in today's double-header with the Chicago White Sox, Mickey Mantle was ready to toss in the towel in his quest of a home run record.
The Bates Manufacturing Company announced plans yesterday to establish a broad licensing program for manufacturers of apparel, home furnishings and other textile products.

SEWANEE, Tenn., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Seven Protestant Episcopal clergymen, including one Negro, will not be welcomed as a group in a restaurant on the campus of the church-operated University of the South.
GALVESTON, Text., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Searchers found the bodies of more victims of Hurricane Carla today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Kennedy Administration won House approval today of its bill to give permanent status to the Peace Corps.

John J. Gilhooley, the Republican candidate for Controller, expressed confidence yesterday that the city could be run without a tax increase under a Republican regime. This could be done, he said, primarily by wiping out what he called $75,000,000 or more in annual waste.
MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 15 -- The Soviet Union announced early today that it successfully launched a rocket into the Central Pacific on Wednesday in the first of a series of shots.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Rallying on the final two holes Al Brosch of Sands Point and Jack Mallon of Wheatley Hills upset Pat Cici of Lido and Shelley Mayfield of Meadow Brook, 1 up, in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association pro-pro championship at the Sands Point club today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 14 (AP) -- C. Arthur Bruce, chairman of the E.L. Bruce Company, Memphis, Tenn., asked the Court of Chancery today to issue an injunction against the proposed merger of Bruce into the Empire National Corporation of New York.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department accused some meat packers, food chains and dealers today of restricting competition in the purchase of lamb.
WARREN, Mich., Sept. 14 -- Cadillac celebrated its sixtieth anniversary today with all the traditional appointment of a bride.

Harry A. Love's Peal, the third betting choice among half a dozen, set a course record of 3 minutes 52 seconds for the two and one-eighth mile Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Labor Day holiday slashed railway loadings last week from volumes of the preceding seven days.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- President Kennedy told the president of the United Steelworkers of America today that "we count on all concerned" to keep steel prices stable.
The startling results of the Democratic primary are a clear-cut victory for the people of our great city, and your own newspaper can claim a sizable share of the credit for this unusual result.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange slipped hour after hour yesterday. Volume was lighter than on Wednesday.
NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Sept. 14 -- The Ford Motor Company's space planners unveiled a ball-shaped lunar capsule today.

Production of lumber fell to 194,810,000 board feet in the holiday week ended Sept. 8 from 224,761,000 board feet the week before, according to reports received from regional associations. A year ago 193,532,000 board feet were produced.

Directors of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., yesterday recommended a four-for-one split of the common stock and a reduction in the par value of the stock from $5 to $1.25 a share. The board also declared the regular quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share on the present stock. It is payable on Nov. 3 to holders of record of Oct. 13.
President Kennedy has commended Dr. Gordon S. Seagrave for his humanitarian services in Burma, the American Medical Center for Burma, Inc., here, said yesterday.
Mayor Wagner received an important setback last night when the First District Democratic judicial convention rejected his recommendations for two State Supreme Court nominations.
A SMALL shop at 780 Madison Avenue, which opened yesterday, is a veritable treasure trove of designs in Far East fabrics. It is called Shangri-La.
THE Leningrad Kirov Ballet introduced last night its "Gala Program No. 1" in its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, and just about danced the roof off the place, heat or no heat.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14 -- Three Democratic candidates for the State Supreme Court were nominated today at a Ninth Judicial District Convention. The district includes Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess, Rockland and Orange Counties.
Five individuals and a defunct brokerage concern were indicted yesterday on stock fraud charges in which the public was allegedly defrauded of $4,660,000.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Duke Snider blasted a three-run pinch homer in the ninth inning tonight, enabling the Los Angeles Dodgers to post a 7-6 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Bobby Fischer of the United States, Mikhail Tal of Latvia and Miguel Najdorf of Argentina drew games in the seventh round of the international masters tournament at Bled, according to a report from Yugoslavia yesterday.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System were down $30,000,000 at $27,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $83,000,000 to $628,000,000.

Officials of the United Presbyterian Church issued a statement yesterday expressing interest in a proposal that the major Protestant denominations merge their mission boards as a first step toward unity.
The Metropolitan Opera Association had another fight on its hands yesterday -- adamant tenants who refused to move from the old Broadway house.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- The Yankees' triumphant march through the West came down with a crash today.
A two-year covering composing room employes of ten New York newspapers won acceptance in a union referendum yesterday on the basis of unofficial and incomplete returns.

President Kennedy has instructed Secretary of Commerce Hodges to prepare a broad program to cope with the mounting difficulties that beset all forms of transportation. Mr. Hodges' mandate is to draft a national transportation policy designed to make a "maximum contribution to economic growth, national security, cultural advancement and international trade and commerce.''

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and Germany are now conferring here on the German problem, but very little is expected from this phase of their discussions.

Nedick's Stores, Inc., has signed a seventeen-year lease with Seaman's Bank for Savings for 3,000 square feet of space at 16 Beaver Street. Nedick's will convert the area into a store seating more than 100 customers and offering take-out service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Soviet Union detonated a multimegaton nuclear device over the Arctic today, its tenth nuclear explosion since it resumed atomic weapons tests on Sept. 1. A megaton blast is equal in explosive force to 1,000,000 tons of TNT.
Off-Broadway producers are standing firm against Actors Equity's threat to pull its members out of shows now in preparation unless deposits in escrow are made covering rehearsal pay.
New York Hospital operated at a deficit of nearly $1,718,000 last year, according to its annual report, issued yesterday. This compared with a loss of about $1,410,000 in 1959.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 -- A jewelry store chain with headquarters in Texas is seeking control of the Bailey, Banks Biddle Company, a jewelry concern that has been a landmark on Chestnut Street here throughout its 129-year history.

DOVER, N.J., Sept. 14 -- A quantity of high explosive about the size of a golf ball was blamed today for Tuesday's explosion at Picatinny Arsenal that killed a 52-year-old woman and injured fifteen persons.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Strikes at plants of the General Motors Corporation will cut into new car production this week, holding industry output to an estimated 62,169 units, Automotive News said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A Senate-House disagreement on a $3,812,000 item for transfer of a Quartermaster Corps research institute from Chicago to Natick, Mass., stalled final Congressional action today on a $947,878,750 appropriation bill for military construction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Under Administration pressure, the House Rules Committee tonight cleared a $521,000,000-a-year postal-rate increase for floor action in a way that all but assured enactment before the adjournment of Congress.

The third annual Cargo Handling Exposition will be held next September in Philadelphia, Harry D. Hunter, chairman of the New York chapter of the Kings Point Alumni Association, announced yesterday. The association's members are graduates of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, N.Y.
Contracts for $2,368,526 were awarded for construction at Port of New York Authority marine, aviation and highway facilities at the monthly meeting of commissioners yesterday.

J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., a leading textile producer, raised its sales in the third quarter over the 1960 level but earnings were down. For the three-quarter period, sales declined 6.7 per cent, while earnings were half those of the previous year's period.
The body of a 19-year-old youth was found yesterday between the tracks of the IND Jamaica Line in Rego Park, Queens.
DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg appealed today in behalf of President Kennedy for a speedy settlement of the four-day strike of more than 250,000 General Motors workers.
The city's annual expenditures in its fight against juvenile delinquency will exceed the $74,000,000 budgeted for 1961, Mayor Wagner predicted yesterday.
The philanthropic projects of the New York City Federation Of Women's Clubs, Inc., will benefit from a fashion show and luncheon to be held at the Tavern-on-the-Green on Monday.

As an American tourist who has just left the Soviet Union after a forty-day tour of that country, I feel compelled to dispute your editorial prescription for the tourist's disease which you label "Sputnikitis." (Aug. 30.)
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The United States has prepared a plan by which the General Assembly would postpone for another year the question of admitting Communist China to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Legislation seeking the establishment of an international space year was proposed today by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Navy asked Congress today to authorize the loan of sixteen warships to friendly powers to assure command of the seas if war should come.
DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Wayne Causey slammed a home run and saved a fine pitching performance by Bob Shaw with his glove today as the Kansas City Athletics beat the Detroit Tigers, 5 -- 2.
An 8-year-old girl who was taken to a Bronx clinic yesterday for treatment of a cold died there soon after she had received an injection of penicillin.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 14 -- A freakish accident on the landing float, in which Carter Pyle's Pacific sustained slight damage to her centerboard trunk, put a damper on today's trials to select the American defender in the international catamaran challenge match with Britain next week.

Some of the rollicking joy that Fats Waller once brought to jazz -- a quality that jazz has sorely missed in recent years -- was rekindled last night in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art by pianist Dick Wellstood and a foursome identified as "The Fats Waller Alumni."
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The British Board of Trade announced today a widening of the nation's trade gap in August.
HONG KONG, Sept. 14 -- There were two loud explosions in Chinese Communist territory just across the bordrer from this British colony on Tuesday night.

Two hundred and thirty-one works of outstanding Chinese art, selected from hundreds of thousands of objects assembled over a thousand years by the Chinese emperors, are presented in a loan exhibition opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- When United Nations leaders were casting about for an experienced diplomat to untangle the snarl of Congo politics months ago, their prompt choice was Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien.

More than 150 children in the Manhattanville housing project at Broadway and 126th Street returned to class yesterday after their parents had kept them out of school during the past week. But the return was conditional.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Teamsters and the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Unions, both independent, have signed a mutual assistance pact under which they will cooperate in major areas of union activity.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14 -- A prominent real estate broker here acknowledged today that she had prepared a memorandum to her sales staff warning against selling property to Jews.
HAVANA, Sept. 14 -- The Cuban Government canceled today more than 15,000 tickets for air passage held by Cubans trying to get to the United States.
THE "backward finesse," strictly speaking, is two finesses. It occurs in such a situation as this:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The White House announced today the nominations of John F. Dooling of Brooklyn and Thomas F. Croake of White Plains to be Federal District judges.

YONKERS, Sept. 14 -- Elaine Rodney won the $50,000 Harness Tracks of America Final for 4-year-old trotters tonight. The race was marked by a spectacular stretch accident involving two contenders, Ed Schafer's Lumber Dan and the Bonnie Keek Farm's Nike Hanover.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- Despite Administration opposition, a bill that would sharply raise tariffs on lead and zinc won unanimous approval of the House Ways and Means Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Republicans announced plans today to send panels of Congressmen into twenty states after Congress adjourns, looking to a campaign they hope will give them a majority in the House of Representatives in the 1962 elections.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- Mr. Nixon listened for two and a half hours here today to appeals from twenty-four California Republican leaders. They all urged him to run for governor. He declined to say either yes or no.

STERN'S is readying is Manhattan store for its annual offering of imported merchandise, an event that starts on Monday under the title, "International Holiday." More than 1,600 items are involved in the current offering, and some twenty countries are represented.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 14 -- The all-England women's team gained its third victory in five games by defeating the Long Island Field Hockey Association eleven, 5 -- 1, yesterday. A crowd of 700 saw the game at the Adelphi College Field.

The 5,700-mile Louisville and Nashville Railroad announced last night that it would be filing "promptly" with the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to exercise control over the 862-mile Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad.

Irregular price movements in United States Government securities diminished the high-grade bond market's recent assurance yesterday, but the general tone remained firm in trading of moderate activity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- The White House said today that Mrs. John F. Kennedy would keep her children at their Cape Cod summer home until mid-October. She will commute to Washington to attend to her social duties.
Essex County, N.J., borrowed $4,140,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.

DENVER, Sept. 14 -- Some fall-out, supposedly from the Soviet atomic tests, raised radiation readings in this "Capital of the Rocky Mountain Empire" Tuesday. But it did not dampen a boom atmosphere surpassing that of the bonanza mining days.

ALLIE SHERMAN is small of stature, soft of voice and gentle in manner. He does not fit the popular conception of a professional football coach. But the youthful field boss of the New York Giants displayed a completely unsuspected side of his nature last Tuesday in his first meeting with his battered heroes after the Baltimore Colts had stampeded all over them in the Yale Bowl on Sunday.

President Sukarno of Indonesia, casting himself in the role of peacemaker, announced yesterday that he was dispatching his Foreign Minister to Moscow to discuss "the common interest of peace" with Premier Khrushchev.

According to information in The New York Times of Sept. 9, Senator Thomas J. Dodd has called for a Congressional investigation of the United States Information Agency, his principal target being Dr. Ralph K. White, chief of the Soviet Bloc Division of the United States Information Agency's Office of Research and Analysis.
Some 87,000 stockholders of the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., will share in the distribution of one new share for every five they hold.
The Kinney System Rent-A-Car is negotiating to acquire an interest in Avis, Inc., the second largest car rental agency in the country.
BERLIN, Sept. 14 -- Otto Grotewohl, Premier of East Germany, charged tonight that the flight of two West German jet fighters over East German territory had been carried out "for espionage purposes."

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Eleonora Sears' chestnut mare Reno, from Prides Crossing, Mass., ridden by Kathy Kusner, retired the Frank Melville Jr. Trophy today, the opening day of the fifty-sixth Piping Rock horse show at the Piping Rock Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept 14 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 14 -- The United States defeated Norway, 53 1/4 to 52, today in the third race of the sailing series for the Skoal Trophy and clinched the best-of-five series, 3 -- 0.
HONOLULU, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- A capsule ejected from the Discoverer XXX satellite was recovered in flight today by an Air Force C-130 over the Pacific near Hawaii.

Recently there was a short editorial in The Times about "The Children of Virginia." The situation as regards schools for colored children in Prince Edward County is indeed deplorable and the Richmond editors and educators are trying to do something about it.
One of Hollywood's periodic problems -- the question of prior rights to stories in the public domain -- was raised again yesterday by Jerry Wald.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The perennial Senate battle over the filibuster has quietly reopened at the Capitol with an abundance of ironies but little prospect for change.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday that independent petitions nominating him as the Citizens party candidate for Mayor would be filed with the Board of Elections on Tuesday. In the meantime, he is not concerned with the maneuvering in the Democratic party, he added.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 14 -- Troops of Katanga Province staged a fierce counter-attack today against the United Nations troops here, and by the end of the day the combatants were virtually in a war.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Sept. 9, were 1 per cent below the level of a year earlier.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 14 -- Chancellor Adenauer was reported today to have decided that if re-elected he would not serve the full four-year term.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 14 -- Vice President Juan Lechin Oquendo presented his resignation today to President Victor Paz Estenssoro following accusations printed in Argentina linking Senor Lechin's name to alleged illicit drug operations.
RIVERVALE, N.J., Sept. 14 -- John M. Bailey asserted tonight that James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, was the puppet of "party bosses" at the national level.
Charges against four Greenwich Village booksellers for violating the Sabbath law were dismissed yesterday on a technicality.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 14 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. ordered Bullock and Macon County registrars today not to discriminate against prospective Negro voters.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 14 -- "This probably is the best football squad I've had in my twelve years here. The first team definitely is my best."
MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko will meet in New York with Secretary of State Dean Rusk for an exchange of views on Berlin and Germany, the Foreign Ministry announced tonight.
MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Thomas Allen of Buffalo scored his second victory in the Lightning Class world championships on Long Island Sound when he captured the fifth race of the series today.
HAVANA, Sept. 13 -- The regime of Premier Fidel Castro has been badly jarred by last Sunday's large-scale outburst of anti-Government feelings.
American Distilling Company and Piedmont Natural Gas Company, Inc., notified the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday of prospective offerings of new securities to stockholders.
The Hertz Corporation announced yesterday the election of Howard L. Clark and Frederick M. Glass as directors.
Cotton futures moved 50 cents a bale up to 10 cents lower off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

IN July the bobolinks stopped singing and started South. After collecting in contemplative rows on the telephone wires, the tree and barn swallows drifted way in August. The blue jays, who behaved very respectfully during their nesting season, have become bullies again and are screaming boisterously in the dooryard.
The annual Imperial Ball, a fete that each year has a titled guest of honor, will salute Princess Niloufer of Hyderabad on Dec. 7.
Crowds of demonstrators against nuclear bomb tests sang and marched through Times Square last night, Carrying miniature mushroom clouds.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century retained a two-stroke lead today after two rounds of play in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association's 54-hole Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy tournament at the Elmwood Golf Club.

Last spring Dr. William Fitzjohn, Charge d'Affaires of Sierra Leone, was denied service at a restaurant in Hagerstown, Md., because of his race. The incident brought apologies from the President and the State Department and also amends in the form of a dinner for Dr. Fitzjohn given by the city's Mayor and 200 other leading citizens.

A $20,000,000 packaging research center in two units was opened officially yesterday by the Continental Can Company in Chicago and Plainfield, Ill. It consolidated the company's research and technical activities in the manufacture of metal, glass, paper and plastic packaging products.

Customarily it takes no longer to nominate a State Supreme Court Justice at a judicial convention than it takes the Legislature at Albany to pass a bill fixing the doe-hunting season in Cattaraugus County. That's roughly about fifteen seconds.

Steel-making furnaces in the United States produced 8,657,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings during August, the second highest monthly total so far in 1961. according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Blitz Memorial during the second day of the fifty-sixth Piping Rock horse show today.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 -- The Yankees advanced two more strides toward clinching the pennant tonight. Whitey Ford achieved his twenty-fourth mound triumph of the season and the Bombers set a major league club record of 223 homers in a season.

COOKING is not the Japanese husband's cup of tea, even as a hobby. Prior to the last World War he seldom, if ever, presided over the kitchen or hibachi, as it were. With recent American influence, however, some husbands make sukiyaki now and then, but it is the wife who assembles the ingredients.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- The Department of Justice moved today on a new legal front to undo the merger of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and the City National Bank and Trust Company, both of Chicago.

The National Broadcasting Company is developing a series of half-hour telecasts based on the American Revolution.
NEWARK, Sept. 15 -- Leading members of the Kennedy Administration will take an active part in New Jersey's governorship campaign, it was predicted here today.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith called for an investigation yesterday of policies land practices of the Greenwich Real Estate Board that allegedly had led to discrimination against Jews.

Stan Kenton, whose brassily bellicose bands have been challenging American eardrums for more than fifteen years, brought the latest edition of his orchestra to Basin Street East on Thursday night. There are four more brass instruments than usual in this new group, but Mr. Kenton has chosen them to serve as a mellowing, softening influence as well as to intensify the band's normally piercing brassiness.
Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, will be the setting tomorrow at 5:30 P.M. for a special service of dedication to world friendship and peace.

YASSI ISLAND, Turkey, Saturday, Sept. 16 -- Former Premier Adnan Menderes and two of his former ministers were sentenced to death here yesterday by a special court. They were convicted of having violated the Turkish Constitution.

Political bosses don't die; they don't even fade away. That is the lesson the supposedly defeated and deflated organization Democrats in Manhattan and the Bronx taught Mayor Wagner at the party's First District judicial convention. The henchmen of Tammany leader De Sapio and Bronx boss Buckley pushed through their designates for two impending vacancies on the State Supreme Court, despite frantic pre-convention maneuvering by the Mayor and his allies in the Democratic reform group.
MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 15 -Thomas Allen of Buffalo captured the Lightning Class world championship today. Thirty-four contestants took part in the four-day, six-race series.

REVERE, Mass., Sept. 15 -- A former colonel in the Nationalist Chinese Air Force, who was a central figure in a case involving allegations of embezzlement of millions of dollars, official corruption and international conspiracy, was killed today in an automobile crash.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- President Kennedy today named Najeeb E. Halaby, administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency, to head a new interagency steering committee studying this country's international air transport policies.
Antibodies against viruses taken from human cancers have been found in the pooled blood of more than 4,000 non-cancerous persons, scientists reported yesterday.

ALTHOUGH 1961 marks no special anniversary with respect to the life of Johann Sebastian Bach, this season will see at least three series of concerts in New York devoted to his music. Nor is there anything unusual about this.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A drive against "backdoor spending" by the House Appropriations Committee was halted in the House today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- The scholarship fund of the College of New Rochelle will be aided by the proceeds of the third annual Autumn Dance sponsored by the Westchester Chapter of the Alumnae Association.

Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, will install its new spiritual leader at 9 A.M. today. He is the Rev. Dr. William Berkowitz, associate rabbi since 1951. GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 15 -- Fairfield Prep, the mythical 1960 Connecticut scholastic football champion with a 10 -- 0 record; Stamford, Danbury, Notre Dame of Bridgeport and Bridgeport Central are rated highly in the southern end of the state this season.

An active week is ahead in the market for new capital, with $151,883,000 of municipal fixed-interest securities issues of major size scheduled for competitive sealed bidding. Few corporate issues of major interest are expected, and none are on the calendar for competitive bidding.

Department store sales in the Philadelphia metropolitan area dropped 7 per cent in the week ended Sept. 9, compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the Federal Reserve. Center city sales declined 10 per cent and suburban sales fell 3 per cent.

THE sprightly species tulips are among the choicest of spring's flowers. They range in height from three to twenty inches and blooms appear from the end of March to mid-May. Since these little bulbs are early to bloom, they are among the first to be planted. Species tulips should be in the ground by early fall.

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- Early this week the big Massey-Ferguson tractor plant in the north of France near Lille announced that it would have to lay off 400 workers. NEWPORT, R.I. -- The 12-meter yacht series between Columbia and Easterner for the Decoursey Fales Trophy ended in a tie today as Easterner won the last two races on Rhode Island Sound.

HAVANA, Sept. 17 -- Bishop Eduardo Boza Masvidal and 135 other Roman Catholic priests were expelled from Cuba today aboard a Spanish liner.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Bobby Marshman, a 24-year-old driver from Pottstown, Pa., set a world record today in winning the 100-mile midget car race on Trenton's one-mile speedway.
Account shifts involving more than $2,000,000 in billings were announced over the week-end. Gaining the new business were William Esty Company, Inc., and Cunningham Walsh, Inc.

Samuel Baron will conduct the third and final concert in the New York Bach Festival tonight at 8:30 in Town Hall. The Beaux-Arts String Quartet, the Clarion Woodwind Quintet and Eugenia Earle, harpsichordist, will be the performers.
The cruise industry is now in the final stages of planning for what it expects to be the biggest season in the history of winter ocean pleasure travel.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 17 -- President Kwame Nkrumah lifted today all emergency measures the Government had imposed in response to a railway and port strike. At the same time he gave the strikers until Tuesday morning to return to work.
VIENNA, Sept. 17 -- The United States and the leading nations of Europe reached almost complete agreement tonight on a new plan to reinforce the defenses of the sometimes shaky world monetary system.
