NEWARK, Sept. 17 -- Plans for a $7,000,000 coliseum and civic center in the South Broad Street area here have been proposed by a group of business men.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 17 -- Trading on the Amsterdam Bourse was quiet and dull last week.

The bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company announced yesterday that it would raise certain interstate and intrastate fares by 5 cents a ride. The new fares are expected to become effective next month.
HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Betsy Luce, long-time reporter for The New York Post, and a woman friend were drowned in heavy surf at Ponquoque Beach here this afternoon.

The invasion of private rights in the name of law enforcement is the subject of a new book by Alan Barth, called "The Price of Liberty." Mr. Barth, an editorial writer for The Washington Post, is the author of "The Loyalty of Free Men" and "Government by Investigation."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Cuban exile leaders said tonight that death sentences had been asked for three more foes of the regime in Cuba in the continuing series of counter-revolutionary trials.
HONG KONG, Sept. 17 -- President Tito and Yugoslavia's policies are subjected to violent criticism in the latest issue of the Chinese Communist publication Hung Chi.

LOOKING at both the North and South hands in today's deal, one would not choose to be in a slam, but normal considerations were altered by the exigencies of the situation. Hope was expressed in a pulpit here yesterday for Protestant Episcopal acceptance of "God's will of unity for His Church."

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- The San Diego Chargers crushed the Oakland Raiders, 44 -- 0, today before 20,216 fans in Balboa Stadium. The Chargers scored on the third scrimmage play when Dick Harris intercepted a Tom Flores pass and dashed 41 yards.

The similarities between the Jewish High Holy Days and the Christian observance of Holy Week were discussed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington at the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- The Minnesota Twins won a double-header from the Indians, 5 -- 0 and 5 -- 3, today.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies, who had won only two of twenty-one previous games with Cincinnati, slowed the Reds' drive toward a National League pennant today with a 4-0 victory that was protested.

ZURICH, Sept. 17 -- Prices continued to move irregularly on the Swiss stock exchanges last week. The undertone was more cheerful than in the precedeing week, reflecting the intermittent firmness on American and West German stock exchanges.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- Steel demand increased last week and the outlook is for further expansion of new orders, shipments and steel output. While there may be some lag in orders from General Motors Corporation, this is expected to be temporary.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 18 -- The most ambitious British demonstration against nuclear arms ended early today in Trafalgar Square after 1,140 persons had been arrested. DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Allen Green, a rookie from the University of Mississippi, kicked a 27-yard field goal as time ran out today and the boot enabled the Dallas Cowboys to beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 27 -- 24, in the National Football League.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- Negotiators for the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reported some progress over the week-end. But they saw little prospect of a settlement of the week-old strike until Wednesday or later.

SEATTLE, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Dave Marr sank a 3-foot birdie putt at the first play-off hole today and won the Greater Seattle $25,000 open golf tournament. He had been tied with Bob Rosburg and Jacky Cupit at 265 after the regulation seventy-two holes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Congress is driving to adjourn this week. If it does, members will leave Washington without acting upon half a dozen major Administration proposals. Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Senate Democratic leader, said today that he was still hoping for adjournment on Friday or Saturday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- All thirty-seven persons aboard an Electra II airliner were killed this morning when it crashed in flames just after taking off from O'Hare International Airport. Its pilot had just radioed back a message unintelligible except for the words "no control."

A contractor and a designer confronted with the problem of expanding and remodeling a midtown Manhattan recording studio without disrupting operation of the business, devised several methods to solve the logistical difficulties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Pentagon today ordered to active duty two Army National Guard divisions and 249 smaller Army Reserve and National Guard units throughout the country. The mobilization date will be Oct. 15.
THE "Giselle" that was presented by the Leningrad Kirov Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night is a sheer triumph from beginning to end.

The uncertainty regarding the tax treatment of proceeds from the sale of oil assets and declining prices of its common stock have caused Producing Properties, Inc., to drop plans to sell up to 600,000 common shares.
A total of 1,110 persons were injured in 748 car accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Howard Kaskel of Rockrimmon and Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis shared honors today in the Westchester Tournament of Club Champions at the Winged Foot Golf Club.
BIZERTE, Tunisia, Sept. 19 -- The withdrawal of French troops from the city of Bizerte has been delayed for at least twenty-four hours.

TOKYO, Sept. 19 -- The eulogies come now from all over the world, but eight years ago Dag Hammarskjold said himself much of what there is to be said -- of what kind of man he was and what kind of servant he wanted to be to the United Nations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- One further obstacle to maritime peace on the West Coast was removed today. It was not, however, the last.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A site near Houston was chosen today as the command center for the nation's multi-billion-dollar program to send manned expeditions to the moon and then on to the planets.

KOTA BELUD, North Borneo, Sept. 18 -- One objection of the people of North Borneo to the proposed merger of this British crown colony with the Federation of Malaya is that it would jeopardize the protection afforded by the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.

The Brown Company, producer of pulp, papers and plywood, will move its executive and general sales offices from Boston to New York over the week-end of Sept. 30. The company will move to 733 Third Avenue, at Forty-sixth Street.

Once again a generally shaky market found excuses in the news for a sharp sell-off yesterday. The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks broke to the lowest close since July 26. The loss in The Times industrial average was the widest for any one day since April 21.
Directors of the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday the sale by the city of the Baisley Gardens housing project in Jamaica, Queens, to a private concern that plans to provide middle-income cooperative apartments.

READING Louis Aragon's "Holy Week,"* an enormous historical novel about the flight of Louis XVIII from Paris after Napoleon's return from Elba, is a confusing and exhausting experience. At first one is mildly irritated by the lack of a central narrative, by the superabundance of characters, by the unending and dizzy shifts from one point of view and one stream of consciousness to another.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges indicated today that he might draw a new Business Advisory Council from the ranks of business men already advising his department.

Davidson Bros., Inc., operator of Federal Department Stores, has entered an agreement to acquire four suburban department stores operated by Sams, Inc. The transaction between the two Detroit-based department store chains involves about $3,000,000 cash.

A state legislative committee will recommend to the Legislature late this year that the city's Marine and Aviation Department and the Port of New York Authority join in a proigram to hasten the improvement of the city's piers.
The Kings County Republican executive committee yesterday endorsed Herbert I. Bayevsky, a Democrat, for Municipal Court justice in the Third District of Brooklyn.

Hanging on the racks by the dozens, being pulled at and pulled on by size 8's, 10's, 12's, and 14's, the newest designs of Balenciaga, Givenchy, Dior, Ricci and other Paris couturiers are being put to a popularity test by New York women this week.
Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, the most solemn day of the Jewish year, began at sundown last evening with the melody of the Kol Nidre in synagogues and temples throughout the world.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 19 -- Roy H. Thomson, Canadian newspaper publisher, became full owner today of the Belfast Telegraph.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The acting Speaker of the House, John W. McCormack, said today that there would be no consideration of legislation to increase postal rates at this session of Congress.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 19 -- Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, Prime Minister of Ceylon, expressed deep sorrow today at the death of Dag Hammarskjold.
PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 19 -- A civil defense mobilization involving about 5,000 persons from seventy towns in Bergen County took place tonight here at the Garden State Plaza.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gierman of suburban Grandview have been notified they are in violation of a 1922 zoning law by allowing a Kenya mother and her infant to live with them.

The Magnavox Company reported yesterday that earnings after taxes were a record of $3,362,000 for the first eight months of this year. This was equal to 47 cents a share on the stock outstanding since the three-for-one split in July.
President Kennedy gave an unmistakable indication yesterday that he regards Mayor Wagner as the Democratic party spokesman in New York City on matters affecting Federal patronage.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Bob Anderson pitched his first complete game of the season and slammed a two-run homer tonight as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7 -- 3.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- In the early months of 1961, Soviet sales of gold appear to have been at an even higher annual rate than in 1960, the Economic Commission for Europe reported today in its quarterly bulletin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Ed Bailey singled with the bases full in the ninth inning today to enable the San Francisco Giants to score an 11-10 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. Warren Spahn failed in his bid for his twentieth victory of the year.

Eric Semon Associates, a new concert management' corporation, has been formed here by Gerard and Marianne Semon, former vice presidents of the National Concert and Artists Corporation. The organization is named in honor of Gerard Semon's father, one of Europe's leading concert managers, who died in this country in 1943.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- When the General Assembly of the United Nations finally dries its tears, it might take a look at the epitaph Dag Hammarskjold wrote for himself six years ago in India.

The work of Manhattanville Community Centers, an interracial settlement at 514 West 126th Street, will receive the proceeds of a theatre party at the Nov. 29 performance of "A Man for All Seasons" at the ANTA Theatre.
I think it is important that someone answer the letter of William H. Clark, published Sept. 13, in which he paraphrases from an article by Lewis Strauss in The Reader's Digest.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 75 cents a bale off on a closing bid on new March, to 5c up to 25 cents off yesterday.
GENEVA, Sept. 18 -- The death of Dag Hammarskjold was deeply regretted in Switzerland, which is not a member of the United Nations.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- A few months after he took over a United Nations administrative post in the Congo, Mahmoud Khiari remarked to a worried fellow Tunisian: "Just leave me here for four years with these people; we will settle everything peacefully."
Firmness continued to dominate the market for debt securities of investment grade yesterday.

Joseph R. Weiss testified yesterday that he had omitted from applications submitted to the Board of Education any mention of his work as a consultant for an engineering concern that did business with the Board of Higher Education.

I would like to comment briefly on your editorial of Sept. 13 "School Aid: Sell-Out." As you know, I am in complete agreement with your very forceful stand for an adequate program of general Federal aid to education.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- Thousands of Berliners lined the streets today to welcome Gen. Lucius D. Clay, retired, who arrived to take up his duties as President Kennedy's special representative in West Berlin.

John D. Gray, president of Hart, Schaffner Marx, has been elected president of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A., an organization of 700 garment manufacturers in the men's and boys' field.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- A committee headed by James R. Hoffa rejected today a rebel teamster's charge that Mr. Hoffa had allowed teamsters to negotiate "sweetheart" contract deals with trucking concerns.
PARIS, Sept. 19 -- Former Gen. Raoul Salan, a fugitive under sentence of death for mutiny, engaged in a printed debate today with the editor of the newspaper Le Monde, Hubert Beuve-Mery.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
New York City's 733 air raid sirens will be tested tomorrow at 11 A.M.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The Senate refused today to permit 18-year-old residents of the nation's capital to vote for President and Vice President.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The State Department was deeply concerned today that a daring assault by rebels in Vietname presaged a multi-front attack by the Communists against the Government.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 19 -- Political rivalries are threatening to delay Kenya's constitutional advancement.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Senate gave final approval and sent to the White House today a bill appropriating $947,000,000 for military construction.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- The long-awaited Ford Foundation project for the commissioning and performance of new American operas bore its first fruit last night, as the San Francisco Opera Company presented the world premiere of Norman Dello Joio's opera, "Blood Moon."

The American International Bowling Corporation has initiated a new wrinkle in stockholder relations. The company, which says it is the world's largest operator of bowling lanes, has invited its 3,000 stockholders "to sample the product" by visiting any of its forty-three bowling centers in the United States and Canada.
When the Government shakes a finger at business, the stock market sometimes quakes. This was all too evident yesterday in the case of the Honolulu Oil Company, large West Coast crude oil producer.

Sales of the nation's leading retail store chains rose 3 2 per cent in August and 3.7 per cent for the first eight months of 1961 from the levels of the 1960 periods, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.
KENILWORTH, N.J., Sept. 19 -- The first fine was imposed today on a parent for allowing a juvenile to loiter on a street corner here in violation of a new borough ordinance.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Spry Rodney set one world record and tied another today in the Walnut Hall Farm Filly Stake for 2-year-old trotters at the Delaware Grand Circuit meeting.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) --Tributes to Dag Hammarskjold were voiced today in many parts of the world.
The city's plans for the controversial Cadman Plaza Title I site in Brooklyn Heights were attacked once again yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg announced the establishment of a review board to consider the "flag-of-convenience" controversy in the maritime industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- The Scott Paper Company dedicated its new soundproof executive offices, research and engineering center today on a forty-seven-acre tract adjacent to the Philadelphia International Airport.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 19 -- The death of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has helped to increase anti-British feeling in India.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 19 -- The people of Jamaica voted today to withdraw from the West Indies Federation, putting the fate of the Federation in doubt.

Trading in commodity futures on the New York exchanges was generally dull yesterday, affected in part by the Jewish holiday that began at sundown and will end today at sundown. Since today is expected to be quiet, with many traders absent, new commitments were kept at a minimum.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk will meet Thursday with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union to discuss the Berlin crisis.
PARIS, Sept. 19 -- France's Deputies were told today they could vote the Government out of office if they wished, but not before Oct. 3 when Parliament's regular session begins.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which announced last February that it proposed to curtail the number of special television shows this season, added four more yesterday. The total for the season has not been determined, but it probably will not be so limited as was expected earlier.

Northeast Airlines, Inc., one of the most financially troubled members of its industry, received a complex merger proposal yesterday from the presidents of three competitors -- Eastern Air Lines, Inc., National Airlines, Inc., and Mohawk Airlines, Inc.
"CAIN'S HUNDRED," a modern-time "Untouchables," blasted its way onto Channel 4 last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A dispirited effort to put new curbs on the filibuster was abandoned in the Senate today for lack of substantial support.
Nine candidates for Mayor -- a record number in this city -- were on the Board of Elections' books last night at the deadline for filing independent nominating petitions for the Nov. 7 election.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman called Dag Hammarskjold one of the great men of peace today. Mr. Truman said the United Nations Secretary General was on the brink of a great achievement when he was killed in an airplane crash.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The turnover contracted still further in the stock market here today and industrial share prices declined. There was a modest rally in the middle of the day but prices soon resumed their downward drift.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 19 -- President Joaquin Balaguer said tonight that he would invite opposition parties this week to form a coalition Government in an effort to carry out his democratization program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Large increases in radioactive fall-out in six Southern states were reported today by the Public Health Service.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Kennedy has decided not to appoint George D Woods, chairman of the board of the First Boston Corporation, as foreign aid administrator.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Jim Archer blanked Cleveland, 6 -- 0, in the opener of a double-header tonight, but Tito Francona and a rookie, Ty Cline, paced the Indians to a 6-2 victory over Kansas City in the second game.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The Royal Government announced today that it would reopen negotiations with the Leftist rebels in the village of Namone in another effort to form a coalition regime and end the Laotian civil war.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Thirteen Protestant Episcopal clergymen serving jail terms for desegregation efforts gained their freedom today. Two others remained in jail.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has countered a $20,000,000 breach-of-contract suit brought by the Tennessee Valley Authority with a claim for $31,971,793.
DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- The General Motors Corporation and the striking United Automobile Workers were reported today to be close to a settlement.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 19 -- The United Nations is conducting cease-fire talks with Katanga's President, Moise Tshombe, on exactly the same terms as Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold would have done, a spokesman declared here tonight.

HARTFORD, Sept. 19 -- Daniel E. Jessee just keeps rolling along as head football coach at Trinity College. He has only eleven days to go before fielding his twenty-seventh Trinity team in thirty years at the college.
THE lore of bridge includes at least one case in which an expectant mother at the bridge table gasped: "The next time I'm dummy I must go to the hospital and have my baby."
There was no diplomatic immunity yesterday for William Constantine, alias "Ambassador Kawatta of Ghana," when a magistrate sentenced him to six months in the workhouse.
Carmine G. De Sapio described himself yesterday as a "lively corpse." He may be out of power because of his defeat in the recent Democratic primary, he said, but he is not out of politics.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Ted Williams, 43-year-old former baseball player for the Boston Red Sox, was married today. His bride was Lee Howard, 36, a model.

The three-car train to be used in the Transit Authority's experiment with a fully automatic subway operation has been undergoing tests in the 2,600-foot tunnel of the Times Square-to-Grand Central shuttle.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 -- The California Motor Vehicle and Pollution Control Board has approved one automobile fume-control device and hopes to certify at least two more this year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept 19 -- A jet fighter plane that has been attacking United Nations forces in Katana is reported to be piloted by a Belgian.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- A United Nations signal officer denied tonight that the Kamina base had been captured by Katanga forces. He said the base now had increased short-wave radio contact with the United Nations here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Congress virtually completed action tonight on the Administration's proposal to set up a new agency responsible for planning and research on disarmament.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 19 -- Calm settled on Israel at sundown today as the nation began observance of Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement and the holiest day in the Jewish calendar.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 19 -- Consumers served by distributors of Tennessee Valley Authority power paid, during the fiscal year 1961, $128,000,000 less than they would have paid had they bought the same amount of electricity at rates prevailing generally throughout the nation.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 19 -- Katanga troops suffered heavy losses last night in an attack on a United Nations roadblock here. Fighting also continued around the Post Office, but it was lighter than in previous days.
Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., and associates are offering today 375,000 common shares of NuTone, Inc., at $22 each.
HOUSTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Houston Colts tonight named Harry Craft, a former manager of the Kansas City Athletics, as field manager of the 1962 National League entry.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 -- The Soviet Union suggested today that the United Nations General Assembly consider transferring the United Nations headquarters from New York to West Berlin. Moscow indicated it would support such a move if the Western powers accepted a Soviet demand to terminate the Allied occupation of West Berlin by converting it into a free city.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 19 -- The thirteen Episcopal clergymen arrived here today and said they intend to continue working to "banish all traces of racial segregation and discrimination from the church and from all parts of the land."

Paperboard production climbed to a record 347,649 tons in the week ended Sept. 16 from 261,790 tons in the preceding holiday week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. The latest figure compares with 320,971 tons in the same period last year.

Red-dogging linebackers can be tamed by any striking platoon that knows how to think like those carnivorous gridiron marauders. Coach Sammy Baugh said so yesterday in preparing the New York Football Titans for Sunday's home game with the Denver Broncos.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The State Department announced today that it would rewrite part of a historical pamphlet on Berlin to make it clear that former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was not responsible for the way Germany was divided after World War II.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- The Soviet Union called on the United Nations today to recognize Communist China as the rightful holder of the Chinese membership in the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The following Army Reserve component units are among those to be called for active duty starting Oct. 15:
BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 -- Game No. 154 comes up for the Yankees tomorrow night, but Roger Maris is not going to alter his swing because of an asterisk.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 -- Roger Marls, for whom time is rapidly running out in his bid to break Babe Ruth's record of sixty, hit no homers tonight. The Yankees didn't bag the 1961 pennant, either.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower will join Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz' mayoral campaign here Friday.
Thomas Kanza, who came here last year as the Congolese minister-delegate to the United Nations, was denied entry to the United States last night.
An experiment is quietly under way to determine the feasibility of transmitting regularly scheduled performances of Broadway shows to theatres across the country over closed-circuit television.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers presented Don Mossi with a four-run lead in the first inning today and the left-hander bedeviled the Los Angeles Angels with a four-hitter to score a 6-2 victory.

NOW is the time to think of sending packages to children away at school and to servicemen stationed in faraway places. A reminder of home in the shape of mother's favorite cookies can nourish both the body and the soul.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The Republican National Chairman said today President Kennedy and his Administration must take full blame for the Berlin situation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The House passed a bill tonight that would ease the tax and impact on the stock market of the impending disposal of $3,000,000,000 of General Motors Corporation stock by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

A problem often develops concerning the property rights to the bathroom mirror. A necessity for husbands who would shave without cutting their throats, it is equally important for wives desirous of applying make-up in a good light.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Air Force said today it had removed two officers from their jobs and reprimanded them for violating orders by showing the film "Operation Abolition" to a Reserve unit during training hours.

Beau Prince, the Calumet Farm handicap horse who was beaten a neck and a head in Belmont's recent Jerome Handicap, is the favorite at 6 -- 5 in the field of ten named for today's $28,800 Stymie Handicap.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 19 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy and Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower are among contributors to a cookbook being sold here for the benefit of the Well Baby Clinic.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 19 -- Foreign Minister Selim Sarper will head Turkey's delegation to the United Nations General Assembly session in New York, it was announced today. This indicated that a Cabinet crisis had been averted.
The Play Schools Association will benefit from the evening performances of "Write Me a Murder" on Nov. 1 and 6 at the Belasco Theatre. The play will open Oct. 26.
HAVANA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Nelson Figueras Blanco, a leader of forces opposed to Premier Fidel Castro, died before a firing squad today. He was the twelfth person executed in Cuba since Sept. 9.
The development of a new wood-pulping process that was said to require much less water and chemicals than normally used in conventional pulp production was announced yesterday by Columbia University.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- The Department of Justice moved in Federal Court here today to block the sale of $380,000,000 in assets of the Honolulu Oil Corporation.

A creative arts workshop for children will offer Saturday classes in ballet, drama, music, painting, ceramics and other crafts beginning Sept. 30, at the West Side Y.M.C.A. Fees for the fifteen-week courses range from $15 to $30. The "Y" is located at Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street. For further information, call PLaza 5-2700.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- The farm bloc that dominated American agricultural policy for almost half a century is "no longer a united or cohesive force," Aled P. Davies, vice president of the American Meat Institute, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Kennedy welcomed President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche of Peru today and said their two countries stood "shoulder to shoulder" in the fight for "a world at peace, a world of law."
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The Texas Railroad Commission today followed the advice of a majority of oil purchases and ordered an eight-day oil production schedule for October.
PARIS, Sept. 19 -- Let us now remember the text of Ralph Waldo Emerson: "Things are in the saddle and ride mankind."

Nine singers who have not appeared with the New York City Opera for a year or longer will be heard with the company during the season, which opens on Oct. 5. They are Adele Addison and Joan Sena, sopranos; Eunice Alberts, Debria Brown, Martha Lipton, Carol Smith and Claramae Turner, mezzo-sopranos and contraltos; Harry Theyard, tenor, and Donald Graham, bass.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Dr. Bela Fabian and more than fifty anti-Communist European exiles picketed in the rain outside the United Nations headquarters today, blaming Premier Khrushchev for the death of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Juan Pizarro limited the Boston Red Sox to three hits tonight as the Chicago White Sox triumphed 5 -- 1. It was Pizarro's seventh victory in his last eight starts.
The owner of record of a Harlem tenement described as a "horror house" pleaded guilty to two charges and not guilty to two others in Housing Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan introduced today legislation that would widen the antitrust laws to bar strikes paralyzing interstate transportation.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- The sixteenth General Assembly of the United Nations opened today and a campaign to have the Assembly appoint an Acting Secretary General ran into difficulties.
An official of a letter carriers' union testified yesterday that some Post Offices in this state were so unsanitary and unsafe that they would not pass local health and fire department inspections.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 19 -- A garbage collector was arrested today in connection with the disappearance of jewelry valued at $36,000 at wholesale. The jewelry was at first believed to have been dumped with other refuse into the city incinerator.

Justice has often needed a seeing-eye dog to find her way through the maze of unsettled accident cases that have clogged the calendars of state courts. Relief from this judicial traffic jam now appears at hand, thanks to an expediting program successfully tested in the Manhattan and Bronx department of the State Supreme Court.

THE intense, concentrated passion of a towering Greek classic was unleashed at the City Center last night. With Piraikon Theatron (the Greek Tragedy Theatre) offering its splendidly orchestrated version of "Electra" by Sophocles, New Yorkers had a golden opportunity to see and hear an ancient masterpiece brought to vibrant life.
ALBANY, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Boating deaths dropped more than 60 per cent in New York State waters this summer.

VIENNA, Sept. 19 -- The world's richer nations were given advance warning today that they soon would be asked to put up more money for the youngest of the international financial institutions -- the International Development Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges reported today that the nation's economy expanded by 2 per cent during the last three months to a record high.

Has anyone else in New York, an artist perhaps, been comparing the new mosaic street signs with the old ones in the subways? I have just been noticing the new black-and-white "New York University" sign at the IRT Christopher Street station. How flat and ordinary!
NDOLA, Northern Rhodesia, Sept. 19 -- The peace talks that Dag Hammarskjold was seeking between Katanga and the United Nations began today.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 19 -- Queen Juliana opened the annual session of Parliament today with a speech sketching the Netherlands' "unprecedented economic growth" in the midst of the "disquieting" international situation.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Coast Guard cutter Eastwind sailed today for the Antarctic. She is the vanguard of a group of Navy and Coast Guard icebreakers that will operate at the bottom of the world again this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins, behind the six-hit pitching of Jim Kaat, defeated the Washington Senators, 3 -- 1, tonight.
TELEVISION had one of its finest evenings last night in the presentation of two superb filmed documentaries on widely separated yet related struggles by Negroes to attain full freedom.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 19 -- The 1,000 acres near here being made available by Rice Institute as the site for the space research laboratory were once a part of a ranch operated by the late J.M. West, a Houston oilman, lumberman and rancher.
The major domestic airlines lost $1,473,000 in July, according to the Air Transport Association of America. The year's losses through July totaled $15,059,000.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 19 -- The Free Democratic party of Dr. Erich Mende decided unanimously today against joining a coalition West German Government under Chancellor Adenauer, the 85-year-old leader of the Christian Democratic Union.

Our timid and sometimes ineffectual Art Commission of New York, before which the design of a gymnasium for Columbia University in Morningside Park is pending, again ducked its job at its meeting at City Hall on Sept. 11.

Mayor Wagner administered the oath of office yesterday to eight of the nine new members of the Board of Education, shortly after two of the outgoing members lost a court bid to stop him from doing so.
ROME, Sept. 19 -- "Deep sorrow" was expressed today by Pope John XXIII to the United Nations and the Swedish Government for the "painful loss" of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Fred Olsen, a talented Norwegian skipper, finished first in both races held today and increased his lead in the defense of his International Class world sailing championship on Long Island Sound.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) --Preliminary findings incidate that three of every five college students who have borrowed money under the National Defense Education Act are planning to teach.

The president of a major advertising agency said yesterday he was "shocked" at the degree to which promising young men were shunning the advertising profession because they believed it to be "dishonorable."

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 19 -- Victorious in seven of nine games, Bucknell's 1960 football team was a close runner-up to Rutgers in the title race of the Middle Atlantic Conference's formidable university division.
"Devi," a new film by Satyajit Ray, the Indian director of the prize-winning "Apu" trilogy, will be presented at this year's San Francisco Film Festival, to be held Nov. 1 to 14.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 19 -- Sweden will give Dag Hammarskjold a state funeral. This decision -- an unusual tribute to a Swede not of royal birth -- was made today by the Swedish Government.
FORT LEE, N.J., Sept. 19 -- It's taking a heap of blasting to make a rock a road on the edge of this Palisades town.

An agreement that offers the Philippines the encouraging prospect of a start toward self-sufficiency in oil production by the end of the year was announced yesterday by United States and Filipino companies.

ALF GOULLET and Albert Grenda started their journey at a line painted across the banked wooden track in old Madison Square Garden. Six days and 2,759 miles later they finished the trip at the same spot. They had been nowhere because this was the race to nowhere. This was the six-day bike race, 1914 vintage.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Bill Buchan of Puget Sound, Wash., moved a step nearer to the world Star Class championship today by winning his second straight race.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The grain futures market ranged from firm to weak on the Board of Trade today but finished with most price changes in minimum fractions.
LANGUAGE records are making it possible for housewives to learn Hindustani, Thai, Serbo-Croatian or the more familiar European languages while doing the breakfast dishes and straightening the house.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Curt Simmons pitched a five-hitter and Start Musial hit a two-run homer as the Cardinals defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 3 -- 0, tonight.
PURCHASE, N.Y, Sept. 19 -- Lois Hallager of Bonnie Briar won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Windle Trophy over the Old Oaks Country Club course today.
The city and most of the metropolitan area went on an emergency alert last night to prepare for a heavy battering by gale winds and tidal floods from Hurricane Esther late today.
CAPE HATTERAS, N.C., Wednesday, Sept. 20 -- Twenty-five-foot waves battered the Outer Banks of North Carolina early today as Hurricane Esther moved toward the Eastern Seaboard.
The Burroughs Corporation announced yesterday its entry into the low-cost punch-card electronic computer field with the introduction of four new computer systems.
STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 19 -- The clouds of war seem dim and very far away in West Germany.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Alliance for Progress, just a month old, is facing its first strains, testing its effectiveness as a workable program of inter-American economic and social development.
DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- Supporters of a move to change the name of the Protestant Episcopal Church are convinced that their chances have never been better.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds scored seven runs in the fourth inning tonight and posted a 10-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Axel and Erik Schmidt, 22-year-old twin brothers from Rio de Janeiro, maintained their lead today in the world championship regatta on the Snipe Class on Long Island Sound.

CROTON, Mass., Sept. 19 -- Groton School, with its impressive, ivy-covered, red brick buildings, is pitched in country that Indians delighted in raiding more than two centuries ago. Today, there was another raid -- by forty-five "new" boys.
Oklahoma borrowed $35,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction of colleges and other public institutions.

The Family Finance Company has filed a registration statement covering a proposed public offering of $25,000,000 of senior debentures due Oct. 15, 1981. Goldman Sachs Co. was named manager of the underwriters.
KEARNY, N.J., Sept. 19 -- Thousands of waterfowl and marsh birds are dying in the Hackensack River tidal flats and marshlands from an outbreak of botulism, a type of food poisoning.

SOME 700 sub-teen-age children from local public, private and parochial schools took part yesterday morning in a highly critical experiment to determine the suitability to American youngsters of a group of British-made children's films.

With the New York Rangers supplying the opposition for the Bruins in Boston, the National Hockey League's forty-fifth season will start Wednesday night, Oct. 11. Each of the six teams in the league will play seventy games.

The Mayor has picked a new school board of superior quality. Whatever other names the selection panel submitted (and the panel deserves the city's gratitude for a difficult task well done), the final appointments inspire full confidence.

THE following stores are presenting their adaptations or copies of European fall fashions. Copies follow the original design in silhouette and details; adaptations use the original model only for inspiration.
Stockholders of the Hercules Motors Corporation, at a meeting yesterday in Cleveland, agreed to the terms under which the company will be acquired by the Hupp Corporation.
ATHENS, Sept. 19 -- Premier Constantin Karamanlis announced tonight his intention of holding general elections in Greece next month.

Watkins Glen N.Y., the little resort town in the Finger Lakes region where the United States Grand Prix will be run on Oct. 8, will warm up its facilities this Friday and Saturday with its annual classic sports car races.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Federal Housing Administration acted today to crush reports that it was thinking of raising its ceiling on interest rates. It announced that the rates would remain unchanged for now.

At a recent National Day celebration in Communist North Vietnam, Defense Minister Giap issued an order of the day to his forces hailing the "patriotic struggle" in South Vietnam, which he said was "growing with every passing day" and would "certainly succeed."

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- Trygve Lie, predecessor of Dag Hammarskjold as Secretary General of the United Nations, declared that the late United Nations leader had followed correct policies in the Congo.
NDOLA, Northern Rhodesia, Sept. 19 -- United Nations officials arrived here today to begin the grim task of confirming identification of the dead.

Construction has started on a $600,000 addition to the building of the American Institute of Physics. The work will almost double the size of the institute's national headquarters at 335 East Forty-fifth Street.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 19 -- The City Council is expected to authorize legal action next Monday to void a lease held by the East Orange Golf Association.
Domestic air cargo tariffs based mainly on commodity density have been published by the Flying Tiger Line.

MADRID, Sept. 19 -- All is ready. The two soccer teams, Vasas of Hungary and Real of Madrid, have gone through final light workouts. Lines file slowly past ticket windows. In the streets and cafes knots of men talk excitedly of tomorrow night's game.
The United States Court of Appeals in a 4-to-1 decision yesterday reinstated a first-degree murder conviction vacated earlier by a Federal district court in New Haven.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Kennedy Administration tried today to relieve the United Nations -- and itself -- of the consternation brought on by the death of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

Charles (Chuck) McKinley of St. Ann, Mo., headed a four-man squad named yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association to represent this country against India in the first Interzone Davis Cup series, which will be held at New Delhi on Sept. 30, Oct. 1 and 2.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 19 -- President Francois Duvalier of Haiti has assumed full powers over the nation's economy. Authority for the action was granted to Dr. Duvalier by the National Assembly as it went into recess late last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Kennedy, in a departure from custom, today ordered flags of the United States on all Government buildings and installations here and abroad flown at half-staff because of the death of Dag Hammarskjold.

VIENNA, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Mr. Black's appeal for more "soft" loans met a rebuff from Britain's Chancellor of Exchequer, Selwyn Lloyd, who said the question of enlarging the resources of the I.D.A. did not appear to call for immediate decision.

The current Vienna meeting of the International Monetary Fund has brought agreement on a major step to strengthen the defenses of the free world's monetary system. The purpose is to permit approximate stability of the exchange rates among currencies and to prevent major changes born of essentially transitory forces.

Dr. Severinus D. Emanuels, Premier of Surinam, appealed to the United States and other Western powers today to remember their friends as well as the neutrals when planning their overseas development programs.

FISHING would be a fairly dull endeavor if the fish always cooperated by being on hand, mouths agape, to satisfy the angler. The fisherman doubtless would soon begin to conclude such a situation was his due.
TORONTO, Sept. 20 (CP) -- Five medical researchers, including one Canadian, will share 1961 Gairdner Foundation awards totaling $25,000, the foundation president J.A. Gairdner, announced today.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP) -- A youth who made a parachute jump on a Sunday was cleared today of a charge of violating the state business laws.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- James M. Symes, chairman and chief executive officer of the Pennsylvania Railroad said today his railroad was still willing to study a merger with the New York Central Railroad.
A strike against the Univac Division of Sperry Rand Corporation began in twelve areas throughout the nation yesterday by employes who service computers, tabulating machines and other equipment.
TOKYO, Sept. 20 -- The majority of the fans polled here today believe Ruth's record should remain unbroken unless a player gets more than sixty homers in 154 games.
Major news developments whipsawed the stock market yesterday but it closed with a good gain.

A fighting statement came yesterday from the Tidewater Oil Company in answer to the Government's antitrust suit against the sale of Honolulu Oil Company's assets to Tidewater and the Pan American Petroleum Corporation, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).
THIRTEEN amateur baby sitters who hope to turn professional spent last Saturday at this village's Second Baby Sitting Conference, which was held in the auditorium of radio station WBAB.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Crews of eighteen nations sailed the fifth race in the International Snipe Class series off the American Yacht Club today, fulfilling the minimum class requirements and making the regatta an official world championship.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 -- In many respects the Yankee team that just clinched a twenty-sixth American League pennant has been the most remarkable of the Bomber squads that over the past forty years brought an almost constant flow of championships to New York.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Mongi Slim of Tunisia, newly elected President of the General Assembly, dealt candidly with half a dozen delicate political problems in his inaugural speech today.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Lord Hailes, Governor General of the West Indies Federation, will meet here tomorrow with Iain Macleod, the British Colonial Secretary, to discuss what steps may be taken to hold the federation together if Jamaica secedes.

Most commodity futures prices moved narrowly in moderate trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. The Jewish Day of Atonement observance and the early departure of some traders because of the threat of a hurricane kept the day's volume light.

Gale-force winds felled power lines and trees on Long Island early today as the fringe of Hurricane Esther hit the metropolitan area. The center of the storm was moving east of the city, threatening the Northeast from eastern Long Island to Eastport, Me.
James J. Farley said yesterday he had been dismissed from his $12,500-a-year office as Assistant Commissioner of Public Works by Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan.

DETROIT, Sept. 20 -- The House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church agreed unanimously and without debate today to "explore the possibilities" of a four-way merger with the United Presbyterian Church, the Methodist Church and the United Church of Christ.
AUGSBURG, Germany, Sept. 20 -- From high command to private first class, the Army in Europe has been deeply disturbed by the case of Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker.

NDOLA, Northern Rhodesia, Sept. 20 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province and United Nations officials announced today that a provisional cease-fire agreement had been reached. It was scheduled to take effect at 12:01 A. M. tomorrow.

As was expected, Russia's resumption of nuclear tests in the atmosphere has led to an increase in radioactive fall-out all over the world. In this country, ground-level radioactivity increased sharply in twelve Eastern and Northern states and the District of Columbia. The Public Health Service also reported much larger increases in radioactivity in six Southern states.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Federal Government has received identical bids in the last five years in each of the twelve major categories of goods it buys, according to a Justice Department report.
The automobile industry apparently will hold the price line for the third straight year.
MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- Premier Khrushchev today voiced support of a recent appeal by Pope John XXIII for East-West negotiations to halt threats to peace.
ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 20 -- An editorial in The Ghanaian Times accused Britain today of responsibility for the death of Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations.

ROME, Sept. 20 -- Pope John XXIII protested today against the expulsion of a Bishop and many priests from Cuba. However, the Pope said he was still confident that goodwill and calm would prevail over "hasty deliberations."
The bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company said yesterday it would listen to any alternatives to its proposed fare increase.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 20 -- The Williams football team is treading on thin ice, hoping that injuries won't hamper the team any more than they have so far this year. The 1961 squad is the smallest that Coach Len Watters has had in his fourteen years with the Ephmen.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan tonight considered recalling Parliament ahead of schedule to discuss the world situation.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 -- The Yankees tonight clinched their twenty-sixth American League pennant by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 4 -- 2, but for Roger Maris it was an evening of frustration.
THE following recipes are for dishes that are frequently taught at some of the cooking schools listed separately on this page.
The Associated Press, a tenant since 1938 in the building that bears its name at 50 Rockefeller Plaza, has renewed its lease for a twenty-year period.
Former Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy promised yesterday to announce today or tomorrow whether he would run for Mayor.

USUMBURA, Urundi, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- Final official results made public today on the general election held here Monday showed a sweeping victory for the Union and Progress National party over the Common Front coalition, which is led by the Christian Democrat party.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Frank Malara Jr., an amateur, led the field of 170 with a par-equaling 71 in the metropolitan open golf championship today.
THE motto of a downtown pet shop "When your children have left home, buy a monkey," is only one of many indications that exotic pets are rising in popularity.

THE Leningrad Kirov Ballet repeated last night its fine production of "Giselle" at the Metropolitan Opera House, but this time with a new ballerina in the title role. This was young Natalia Makarova, who danced the role for the first time only during the past summer in London.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- President Kennedy set up today a system for taking secrecy wraps off classified Government material.

ROME, Aug. 31 -- Archaeologists at the Greek colonial town of Morgantina, near Aidone, Sicily, have unearthed a theatre in a remarkable state of preservation. It has survived in its original form, without being altered in any way by ancient Roman stagehands.

Every man should have a pond. Not necessarily, a Walden; just a little pond with a few willows skirting the shore, and a deep spot out in the middle somewhere as a lurking place for things that go SLOSH! in the night.
Mayor Wagner's successful primary campaign for the Democratic nomination for another term cost more than $500,000, Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., his campaign manager, estimated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Some forty or fifty young Americans in a new Roman Catholic "peace corps" will be working in Latin America by year's end, a church spokesman said today.

The usual office furniture advertisements may be cluttered with desks, chairs and the like, but a new campaign started by Itkin Bros., Inc., centers on such creatures as goldfish and mice. The first ad, created by Smith-Greenland Company, Inc., shows a goldfish in a water cooler.

The Peoples' Symphony Concerts will begin their sixty-first season on Oct. 21 at Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place. As in recent years, three series of six programs will be offered, each with a subscription rate of $3.
Mayor Wagner at City Hall yesterday greeted the riders who will compete in the six-day bicycle race starting tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.
Eddie Rickenbacker attacked yesterday what he called censorship that prevented military commanders from instructing their men in how to deal with communism.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Britain's first national strike of teachers kept 1,000,000 pupils at home today during a one-day protest against Government cutbacks in proposed salary increases.
The new Board of Education, which officially took office at midnight last night, will be briefed Saturday on the problems it must deal with.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 20 -- The largest number of delegates to attend an annual conference of the Liberal party since before World War II gathered here today on the eve of this year's meeting.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Britain's conduct during the bitter fighting in Katanga Province is causing resentment, ill feeling and regrets among even her closest friends here as a result of the death of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

A contract for concrete construction, said to be the largest ever let for a Housing project, has been awarded to the Driscoll-Moccia Construction Corporation for Rochdale Village, a cooperative development to rise on the site of the Jamaica Race Track in Queens.
The nation's oil producing and refining activity declined last week, reflecting the effect of Hurricane Carla on industry operations along the Texas section of the Gulf Coast.

WARREN, Ohio, Sept. 20 -- The Republic Steel Corporation unveiled a new, highly automatic $55,000,000 hot strip mill here today, as the steel industry neared a period of intensified profit squeeze beginning on Oct. 1.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- Federal mediators worked against a deadline only twenty-four hours away today in an effort to reach an agreement between West Coast shipowners and deck officers.

" I'VE often wondered how people tear their hair," the suavely commonsensical heroine of Edward Streeter's enjoyable novel, "Chairman of the Bored,"* remarks in the rigadoon's moment of true frenzy. "This is obviously the place to find out as far as I'm concerned."

If you believe, as I do, that our free enterprise system is the basis of our strength and leadership of the free world, then I cannot believe that you can view with equanimity President Kennedy's ukase to the steel industry.
Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris warned yesterday that the nation would be courting an attack if it allowed the Soviet Union to be first with an anti-missile missile.
