A theatre party at the Nov. 16 preview of "The Gay Life" has been planned to raise funds for the Sheltering Arms Children's Service. The new Kermit Bloom-garden musical will be at the Shubert Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Administration has decided that, apart from members of Congress, it will appoint only professional diplomats as delegates to the United Nations General Assemblies.

BEFORE the season began last April, Ralph Houk was in what appeared to be baseball's most exposed and vulnerable position. He had succeeded Casey Stengel as manager of the Yankees and there's nothing tougher than succeeding a legend, particularly one as glamorous as the Ol' Perfessor.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies:

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -Trading in September grain futures contracts ended today with the expiring soybean delivery under heavy selling pressure and rye in strong demand. The sell-off took soybeans down 4 cents a bushel, while rye climbed 6 1/4 cents.
Should the mantle of George Herman Ruth drape the shoulders of Roger Eugene Maris?
TRENTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- New Jersey's Attorney General, David D. Furman, filed suit today against nine manufacturers of electrical equipment. He charged them with price-fixing.
The American Civil Liberties Union protested yesterday against a proposal to suspend the Federal "equal-time" law for the duration of the city mayoral campaign.
The Jacob A. Riis Settlement has chosen the Nov. 14 performance of "Write Me a Murder" for its annual theatre benefit. The play is scheduled to open at the Belasco Theatre on Oct. 26.
The average exhibitor at a dog show dreams of some day owning a champion. Barbara Worcester of Little Falls, N.J., has twenty-two champions.
TORONTO, Sept. 20 -- A sample of opinion among baseball fans here showed most of them in favor of giving Maris the home-run record even if he takes eight more games than Babe Ruth to do it.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Governor Rockefeller indicated today that he had no affection for the political label of liberal.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 20 (UPI) -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad (Mopac) announced that it had applied to the Inter state Commerce Commission for authority to acquire control of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad.

Several paper industry officials expressed reservations yesterday about a new process for making wood pulp. They said further production tests would be necessary before the effectiveness of the process could be compared with present methods.

YONKERS, Sept. 20 -- There was no surprise in the announcement by the race secretary, Ted Gibbons, today that he had assigned O'Brien Hanover to the No. 7 (outside) position for Saturday night's $25,000 Red Sails Free-for-All Handicap Pace.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Most big Government agencies permit some kind of telephone monitoring, a House subcommittee said today.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 20 -- The Soviet Union has expressed interest in helping India build a publicly owned steel mill that the Kennedy Administration also has indicated willingness to aid.

WASHINGTON, Sept 20 -Secretary of State Dean Rusk brought a somber report on world affairs to Capitol Hill today. The legislators who heard him behind closed doors described it as "realistic," "skeptical" and "complex."

Anthony A. Bliss, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association, will speak on the "Star Night" program, sponsored by Five Towns for Lincoln Center, on Saturday at 8:15 P.M. in the Lawrence High School, Cedarhurst, L.I.
The bond market's recent latent strength, perceptible for weeks in quiet trading sessions, broke out emphatically yesterday as business expanded from the stimulus of rising bids.
LITTLE FALLS, N.J., Sept. 20 -- A New York City advertising executive today was charged with the murder of his wife in an apartment they occupied here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Following, in unofficial translation from the French, is the text of the inaugural address today by Mongi Slim of Tunisia, the new President of the General Assembly:

The Federal Communications Commission will begin another series of public hearings here Tuesday in connection with its study of network television operations. It will hear testimony by executives of companies that sponsor national programs.

JOEY BISHOP, whose deadpan monologues have justly won him a substantial following, is the latest comedian to risk the perils of a half-hour film situation series. The premiere of his show occurred last night on Channel 4, and once again it was the old Hollywood story: Joey was put in the mold.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- The official Dominican party announced today it will open its campaign for the 1962 election Saturday with mass rallies throughout the country.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 20 -- Colonial Secretary Iain Macleod of Britain has been asked to receive a delegation from the Jamaica Government to discuss the result of the referendum and to fix the earliest possible date for independence.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Ron Fairly singled to score Wally Moon in the thirteenth inning tonight and enabled the Los Angeles Dodgers to score a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Clubs.

In his letter of Sept. 18 on the subject of unemployment insurance, Harold C. Hanover begs The Times to print "all the truth," but this plea comes at the end of a letter containing many inaccuracies, misstatements and distortions.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- President de Gaulle announced today that he would abandon at the end of this month the sweeping emergency powers he has held since April.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended on Sept. 13:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter introduced today a bill calling for the dismissal of any Federal employe who avoids questions from a Government agency about Communist activities.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 20 -- Leaders of the Inter-parliamentary Union voted today to appeal to the Turkish Government for clemency for political leaders sentenced to prison terms for crimes against the nation's Constitution.

ATHENS, Sept. 20 -- King Paul of Greece, acting on his Government's advice, dissolved Parliament today and set Oct. 29 as the date for general elections. He also appointed a nonpolitical caretaker Cabinet to conduct the elections.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The recent meeting between Prince Souvanna Phouma and President Kennedy's roving ambassador, W. Averell Harriman, did not result in the necessary assurances that Souvanna Phouma is genuinely neutral, a Laotian Government spokesman said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- The Soviet Union and the United States have reached agreement on a broad set of disarmament principles that could lead to a resumption of arms negotiations. The talks have been suspended for fifteen months.
NDOLA, Northern Rhodesia, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Two men on opposite sides in the Katanga fighting met today and gravely shook hands outside a Protestant church where Dag Hammarskjold's body lay in state.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Princeton's venerable humor magazine, The Tiger, which has chronicled laughs for eighty years -- from the era of the chaperone through the days of the raccoon coat to the day of sick jokes -- will stir no more smiles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche of Peru told the Organization of American States today that it must decide to defend the hemisphere through a rejection of communism, "which seeks to take new positions in our midst by force."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- The Senate Finance Committee approved tonight a controversial bill to provide tax relief for stockholders in the du Pont-General Motors antitrust case.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Wally Post lashed a towering home run over the left-field screen with one on in the eighth inning tonight and the Cincinnati Reds took another step toward a National League pennant with a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Lillian Barnard Gilkes, short-story writer and author of "Cora Crane," a biography of Mrs. Stephen Crane, has received a literary fellowship from the Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust. The book which she will finish with the aid of the grant is a biography of Park Benjamin, nineteenth-century American poet, editor, critic and lecturer.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Bobby Del Greco hit a two-run homer in the ninth inning tonight and led the Kansas City Athletics to a 4-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians. Del Greco broke a 2-2 tie with his fifth home run of the season and his second in two nights.

New York City borrowed $42,940,000 in the bond market yesterday. The money raised will go mostly to finance school construction and street improvements and to cover part of the outlays made last winter for snow removal.

Production of electric power in the nation totaled 15,869,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Sept. 16, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This figure compared with 15,838,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 14,298,000,000 kilowatt-hours for the same period last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A study and appraisal of alleged Pentagon censorship of critics of communism in the defense establishment was voted today by the Senate Armed Services Committee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- President Kennedy sent to the Senate today the nomination of Fowler Hamilton to be the administrator of the new Agency for International Development.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- President Kennedy nominated a new Controller of the Currency today and two hours later withdrew his name. The Treasury announced that it had made "a clerical error."
In March, 1960, two children living in two connected tenements at 53 and 55 West 105th Street were bitten by rats.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Marion Davies has been given the last rites of the Roman Catholic Church and was reported to be near death today after a long illness.
TOKYO, Sept. 20 -- The Japanese Government reported the "first signs of danger" in radioactive fall-out above Japan today as a result of the Soviet nuclear tests.
HAVANA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro accused "Fascist" priests today of plotting with the United States to overthrow his Government.
DETROIT, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Chico Fernandez' bases-filled double highlighted a four-run rally in the seventh inning today and lifted the Detroit Tigers to a 6-3 triumph over the Los Angeles Angels.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's body will be flown home to Sweden Saturday, it was announced today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points up to 20 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
BERLIN, Sept. 20 -- Prof. Ernst Bloch, one of the world's leading experts on Marxist philosophy, has sought asylum in the West to evade Communist pressure in East Germany, it was disclosed today.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Don Ferrarese pitched the Philadelphia Phillies to a 6-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals and dropped the losers into a fourth-place tie with the Milwaukee Braves.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 20 -- John Motley Morehead added $7,000,000 in stock today to the Morehead Scholarship Foundation at the University of North Carolina, his alma mater. The 90-year-old retired industrialist gave the foundation 50,000 shares of Union Carbide and Carbon Company stock.
HAVANA, Sept. 20 -- Cuban baseball fans are unanimous in their opinion that Maris should break the record in 154 games or not at all.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The reporf of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy has resigned from the Metropolitan Club because of its discrimination against Negroes.
ROGER VIVIER, who as designer for Christian Dior was the man responsible for squaring the toes and lowering the heels on shoes, opened a new bag of tricks at a press showing this week.

The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation has borrowed $40,000,000 from the Prudential Insurance Company of America to provide funds for capital expansion and retire outstanding debt. The loan carries a twenty-year maturity, the industrial concern announced yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Mongi Slim of Tunisia was elected President of the General Assembly today. As the Assembly held its first business session the day's developments threw little light on whether Mr. Slim would be given the additional duties of Acting Secretary General.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Ray Herbert scattered seven hits tonight to beat the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 1, for the first time sinced he joined the Chicago White Sox. The Red Sox' second baseman, Chuck Schilling, completed the 154th game of the season with only seven errors, tying a major league record set by Jackie Robinson with the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1951.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union drew with a countryman, Ewfim Geller, today and broke a three-way tie for second place in the international grand masters chess tournament.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 -- The University of Pittsburgh has at least one asset of which other aspirants to top Eastern football ranking are envious. That's an official entry on the winning side of the season's ledger.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Lew Burdette scored his seventeenth victory of the season today as the Milwaukee Braves snapped an eight-game losing streak by defeating the San Francisco Giants, 7 -- 4, in the Giants' final home game.

MADRID, Sept. 20 -- Club Real of Madrid, the champion of Spain, eliminated Vasas, the Hungarian titleholder, from the European Cup soccer tournament tonight. The score was 3 to 1. The crowd was poor by the standards of this soccer capital of the world, only 115,000.
LONDON, Sept. 20- Some buyers were attracted by the marking down of prices in the stock market here today, although the resultant modest rally was insufficient to recover the ground lost earlier.

TO the large list of fine domestic and foreign chamber ensembles that have been formed in recent years to honor the increasing demand for the small sound, add the name of the Chicago Strings. This group of fourteen string players from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra made its Town Hall debut last night, in a concert full of musical rewards.
POCONO MANOR, Pa., Sept. 20 -- Speedy action for the development of the water and land resources of the Delaware River basin was urged here today.

Shaving may be a tedious business for the average man but it is a downright cutthroat business for the average company in the field. The once fairly stolid business of making electric shavers, razors, razor blades and similar instruments has taken on an argumentative and ill-tempered aura of late.
DETROIT, Thursday, Sept. 21 -- The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers agreed yesterday on terms of a new three-year contract covering 310,000 production workers.
Arthur Krock in his column of Sept. 5 endorses the concessions to the Soviet Government proposed by Claiborne Pell in an Aug. 22 speech on the Senate floor.
BERLIN, Sept. 20 -- The East German Communist Government received vast powers today to mobilize its citizenry in the event of a "national defense emergency."
The five-story building housing the Thibaut Gallery, at 799 Madison Avenue, has been purchased by Marilyn C. Fischbach, co-owner of the gallery.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- For a man known as a moderate, Mongi Slim of Tunisia has managed to ruffle quite a few diplomatic tempers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A House committee warned homeowners today to beware of "fly-by-night operators" who peddle inadequate family shelters against radioactive fall-out.

VIENNA, Sept. 20 -- The main countries of Continental Europe announced today their willingness, with conditions, to go along with a new plan aimed at averting future monetary crises. The finance ministers of the Free World are meeting here.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The new president of General Electric company said here today that a water purifying system his company was developing was "unique" and showed "great promise."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The President and Mrs. Kennedy will return to Hyannis Port, Mass., this week-end, the White House announced today.
The Southern Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for August and for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31.
FORT JACKSON, S.C., Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Staff Sgt. Jack R. Lawrence from Richards-Gebauer Air Base, Mo., shot sub-par golf last month to qualify for the all-Army golf tournament now in progress.

" GOOD cooking is the foundation of true happiness." These words of Escoffier have been adopted as the slogan of the Mar-Grets Cooking School, a newcomer to the roster of local schools endeavoring to spread happiness through improved home cooking.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Treasury sold $2,500,550,000 of nine-month tax bills today at discounts averaging 2.705 per cent. The previous similar financing -- $3,500,000,000 of eight-month tax bills in July -- sold at discounts averaging 2.483 per cent.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and Mrs. Eisenhower arrived here yesterday afternoon by automobile from their Gettysburg, Pa., farm.

Sales of Basic Products Corporation for the fiscal year ended on July 31 came to $48,896,606, the second largest in the company's history, but 9 per cent below the record of $53,853,888 for the preceding fiscal year.

A glowing picture of bigger markets and higher living standards for this country over the next decade was painted at the ninth annual marketing conference of the National Industrial Conference Board at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- D. Brainerd Holmes, a 40-year-old executive with the Radio Corporation of America, was named today to direct the nation's manned expeditions into space and to the moon.

VIENNA, Sept. (UPI) -- Vladimir Stogov of the Soviet Union tonight won the world bantamweight title in the 1961 world weight-lifting championships with a record-equalling three-lift total of 761 pounds. The Olympic champion, Charles Vinci of Cleveland, finished fourth.
THE story of the Indonesian voyage of the American hospital ship Hope was told on Channel 2 last night.
The head of the nation's tenth largest steel company has replied to President Kennedy's plea for price stability by urging Government measures to help "little steel."
A truck reported to be carrying nearly $100,000 in art works was hijacked yesterday and its driver taken for a three-hour ride in Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20 -- Coronado, an old seaside resort town about a two-hour drive from Hollywood, will stage a film festival next month despite ample evidence that the American movie industry is opposed to it.

Ford C. Frick, the Commissioner of Baseball, yesterday announced the list of eligible world series players from the New York Yankees, the Cincinnati Reds and the Los Angeles Dodgers. Frick also revealed the series ticket scale of prices in the three cities.
The Jamaican vote to withdraw from the West Indies Federation is a great disappointment. A great deal of patient, delicate work over a period of fifteen years has now been jeopardized.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 20 -- Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo angrily accused "capitalist powers" last night of responsibility for Secretary. General Dag Hammarskjold's death.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Following is the text of a joint statement issued today by the United States and the Soviet Union on principles they have agreed on for disarmament negotiations:

With a unanimity which under better circumstances would be a good augury, the General Assembly of the crisis-ridden United Nations has elected Mongi Slim of Tunisia as its President for the current session. To the extent that Tunisia continues to profess its commitment to Western values, even to the point of setting aside its quarrel with France over Bizerte and the Sahara during the present world crisis, this election can be welcomed.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 20 -Westchester County's highway safety engineer said today that Federal and state regulations for traffic-sign uniformity were being ignored in most suburbs.
OTTAWA, Sept. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway is handling more cargo this year than last year.
Jews here and elsewhere over the world attended services in Synagogues yesterday in solemn observance of Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 20 -- Details of the plight of a company of Irish troops that surrendered at Jadotville to forces of Katanga Province reached here today.
Pancho Gonzalez, the professional tennis champion of the world for nearly a decade, is retiring from pro tournaments, but may be willing to play in open tournaments.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 -- Beads of sweat rolled down his cheeks. Fatigue was written on his face. But his eyes told the story.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- For more than fifteen years the United Nations has stood for many things in many minds.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 20 -- The Soviet Union's delegate rose in the General Assembly tonight to offer "sincere condolences'' over the death of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

Critics of the Pentagon's handling of the General Walker episode -notably Senator Strom Thurmond -have said or implied that the General has been victimized for being too openly or vociferously anti-Communist.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 20 -- Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium returned today from Moscow after a visit which is understool here to have been a personal mission to find out the state of mind of Premier Khrushchev.

GOOD saleswomen are born, not made. In the ferociously competitive world of retailing the woman who can sell fashion is pampered by management, envied by her peers. Grateful customers send her fan letters.
Directors of the Northrop Corporation authorized yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock, subject to approval by shareholders at their annual meeting on Dec. 12.
Black Thumper, a dark bay 4-year-old gelding, romped off with a three-and-one-half length victory over eight rivals yesterday in Belmont's $28,550 Stymie Handicap at one mile and a quarter.

WASHINTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill today that would give the Attorney General the power to compel the production of documentary evidence needed in civil antitrust investigations.
The Pet Milk Company announced plans yesterday, to expand into the shelled nuts business through the proposed acquisition of the R.E. Funsten Company of St. Louis, Mo.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Despite bitter criticism, from Commonwealth countries and governments of non-aligned states, the British Cabinet is convinced of the wisdom of its course in seeking an end to the fighting in Katanga.

DETROIT, Sept. 20 -- The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation reached a basic economic agreement on Sept. 6, but a dispute over relief time and numerous differences at local plants precipitated a nation-wide strike.

It took beer and sandwiches, printing and postage stamps, cash payments to district captains, a hand-painted red, white and blue sign for the clubhouse, and then more beer to run the Democratic organization primary campaign in the West Bronx, the Board of Elections was informed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -The Justice Department sought today a Federal court order to prevent prosecution by state authorities of a Negro arrested because of a campaign to register Negro voters in Walthall County, Miss.
I have just returned from a week's stay in your fair city after an absence of eight years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- President Kennedy today signed a three-year extension of the Federal Airport Act and ordered fresh efforts to make flying as safe as possible.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 20 -- An anti-Western undercurrent has been gaining strength in Leopoldville in the last few days.
THE annual regional tournament of the New York-New Jersey Bridge Conference begins today with two-session contests for men's pairs and women's pairs.

William Grant Still, the American composer, has won the National Federation of Music Clubs Composition Contest for an orchestral work dedicated to the United Nations. Mr. Still's composition is entitled "The Peaceful Land."

Robert Moses asserted last night that the New York World's Fair 1964-1965 would suffer "almost irreparable damage" if the present session of Congress failed to authorize a United States pavilion for it.
George Alpert, preident of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, sold all but 710 shares of his stock in the railroad last month.

When Richard Barr and Clinton Wilder joined forces two years ago to devote themselves to the presentation of new plays by new authors, they had no inkling of the number of scripts that would come their way. Their backlog of accepted scripts, they disclosed the other day, now amounts to 475 new works.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange fell again in the month ended last Friday, as it had in every month since mid-February, the exchange disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The House approved by voice vote and sent to President Kennedy today a $230,000,000 community health facilities bill.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Some of the favorites have been withdrawn because of injuries, but the biggest field in its sixteen-year history will compete in the $70,069 Little Brown Jug tomorrow.
MILO FOWLER HAMILTON is capable of "splendid indifference" on the golf course, his closest friends say, and of "brilliant concentration" elsewhere.

SHREVEPORT, La., Sept. 20 (AP) -- A storm of protest arose here today over "Walk in My Shoes," a documentary on the Negro, which was carried here last night by television station KTBS, an affiliate of the American Broadcasting Company.

Thomas R. Kanza, a former representative of the Congo at the United Nations who was detained by immigration authorities on his arrival here Tuesday, said last night that he would start back this morning to Leopoldville.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Hurricane Esther is the first hurricane to be discovered by a satellite.
WASHINGTON, Sept 20 (AP) -- President Kennedy's two children stayed at the Kennedy retreat on the shore of Cape Cod tonight rather than take shelter from Hurricane Esther at Otis Air Force Base.

HINSDALE, Ill., Sept. 20 -- In a splendid exhibition of team play, the Milwaukee Polo Club won the National Open championship today by riding to a 13-to-9 triumph over the Beaver Ridge Farm quartet of Detroit at the Oak Brook Polo Club.

Superficially, at least, Senator Strom Thurmond won a victory when the Senate Armed Services Committee voted to conduct the investigation he has demanded into alleged intimidation of generals and admirals who want to speak their minds about communism.

The sudden announcement by President de Gaulle that he will abandon his emergency powers at the end of this month is a retreat -- not much of a one, hardly more than a step backward, but nevertheless a gesture of conciliation and relaxation.
An investment syndicate headed by Frank H. Klein has acquired a long-term lease, valued in excess of $5,000,000, on the Park Royal Hotel, a sixteen-story West Side structure.

Hope that the country will escape another inflationary surge is strengthened by announcement that the 1962 prices of General Motors cars will not go up, despite the higher labor bill involved in the company's new union contract.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Robert Moses, chairman of the State Council of Parks, assailed a proposed wilderness bill tonight. He said the measure would lock up the Adirondacks and Catskills "still tighter for imitation Indians and amateur mountaineers."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- President Kennedy moved today to heal a dispute with top business leaders. He chatted for an hour at the White House with some sixty members of the Business Council.
Unless the Rusk-Gromyko talks produce results far exceeding the expectations of most observers, it appears almost certain that Berlin tensions will continue to mount at an accelerating pace.
The New York City Charter Commission decided yesterday to set up an "independent citizen's committee" to campaign for the adoption on Nov. 7 of the new Charter it has put before the voters.
ROME, Sept. 21 -- The newspaper L'Osservatore Romano replied on behalf of the Vatican today to remarks by Premier Khrushchev about the peace appeal made by Pope John XXIII Sept. 10.

NEITHER wind nor rain kept the faithful away from Bergdorf Goodman yesterday morning. Weighted down with umbrellas, slickers and rain-wilted coiffures, the women filled the rows of folding chairs of the fourth floor salon to view the fall, ready-to-wear collections of Bernard Newman and Gigliola Curiel.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Henry T. Adios won the $70,069.14 Little Brown Jug and Adios Butler set a world pacing record for a half-mile track with a 1:55 3/5 mile today at the Delaware, County Fairgrounds.

AUSTIN, Tex. Sept. 21 (AP) -- State Representative Dan Struve of Texas asked President Kennedy and top Pentagon officials today to investigate the Fourth Army's role in a "regional strategy seminar" on communism that begins tomorrow in San Antonio.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Orville L. Freeman, Secretary of Agriculture, announced today that he was considering fixing the 1962 domestic sugar consumption quotas at 9,500,000 tons, 560,000 tons below this year's quotas.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 21 -- Belgians in all walks of life were expressing relief today at news of the truce between Katanga Province and the United Nations forces there. The expressions of sentiment revealed how strong the bond still is between Belgium and the Congo.

ALGIERS, Sept. 21 -- Raoul Salan, the rebellious former French commander in Algeria, who is in hiding from a death sentence, denounced President de Gaulle tonight on a television frequency in Algiers.
ALBANY, Sept. 21 -- Harry G. Herman of Mount Vernon, N.Y., Westchester County Attorney for the last fifteen years, was named Surrogate of Westchester by Governor Rockefeller today.
VIENNA, Sept. 21 -- The retiring president of the International Finance Corporation said today that it was partly the fault of the under-developed nations that they remained poor.
Roberta Peters, Connie Francis, Louis Armstrong, Sid Caesar and the comedy team of Rowan and Martin are among the performers Ed Sullivan has lined up for his trip to West Berlin.

A new salary schedule for staff members at the City University of New York was announced yesterday by Dr. Gustave G. Rosenberg, chairman of the Board of Higher Education. The increases are effective from Sept. 1.

If several large and basic uncertainties can be ignored, the economy of 1975 will be "enormously larger and infinitely more complex" than that of today, the annual marketing conference of the National Industrial Conference Board (N.I.C.B.) was told yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Benjamin F. Stacey, a vice president of the First National Bank of Boston.

AUGSBURG, Germany, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A United States Army doctor declined today to back a newspaperman's contention that medical examinations had shown that Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker was suffering from a brain tumor last winter.

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21 -- Beau Mischief and Citadel won the amateur green working hunter championship and reserve, respectively, of the Eastern States horse show, which opened its four-day run today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Holders of almost $3,700,000,000 of World War II bonds have accepted the Treasury's offer to exchange them in advance of maturity for longer-term bonds bearing higher rates of interest.

The Greyhound Corporation is planning to acquire control of the Boothe Leasing Corporation through an exchange of stock, it was announced yesterday by Frederick W. Ackerman, president and chairman of Greyhound, and D.P. Boothe Jr., president of Boothe Leasing.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges was reported to be in serious condition today after having suffered a heart attack. The attack was described by his physician as moderately severe.

HAVING established with last season's "Hedda Gabler" that there is a large audience for Ibsen, the 4th Street Theatre moved on last night to "Ghosts." The second production in David Ross' latest cycle should fare as well as the first.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Senate has scheduled a last-minute showdown tomorrow on a tax bill to ease the impact of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.'s forced divestiture of its General Motors Corporation stock.
MOCOW, Sept. 21 -- The Soviet Union protested today the United States project to wrap the earth in a ribbon of needles for foolproof radio communications.

American Airlines signed new agreement yesterday for the purchase of Convair 990 jet transports from the General Dynamics Corporation despite the airplane's failure to meet speed specifications in the original contract.

Your news columns on Sept. 9 carried an article about tourists returning from abroad having their exemptions reduced from $500 to $100 -- a $400 reduction in the value of foreign-purchased articles they may bring in duty free.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Maj. Gen Edwin A. Walker requested today that he be heard at any investigation of the alleged "muzzling" of anti-Communist military officers by the Defense Department.
FALMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 2l (AP) -- President Kennedy's two children and six of their first cousins were sheltered by the Air Force today against the menace of Hurricane Esther.
PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, in another bitter attack on President de Gaulle, has charged that "things are on the road to rot" in Algeria.

DURING the late, unlamented hot weather, fried chicken was consumed ad nauseam indoors and out. Small-fry birds have been in the bargain category for many a month; lighting the oven has proved a punishment equal to any form of Chinese torture, and the great outdoors has invited many a picnic -- hence fried chicken.
BUFFALO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Joseph McD. Mitchell, city manager of Newburgh, today proposed putting the question of social welfare to the people in state-wide referendum next year.
PARIS, Sept. 21 -- A French general and a colonel were sentenced to ten years in prison tonight after having been convicted of conspiring to overthrow the regime last April.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Postmaster General J. Edward Day said today that the charges that resulted in the dismissal of a Savannah, Ga., letter carrier had had nothing to do with his activities as a leader in the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it had arrested two Dutch tourists on espionage charges.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York set a record goal of $22,500,000 last night for its forty-fourth annual maintenance appeal.

The members of the Municipal Bond Women's Club of New York yesterday elected Mrs. Jane N. Brownell as president for the coming year. Mrs. Brownell, associated with Chas. E. Weigold Co., succeeds Dorothy Root, of F.S. Smithers Co., who will remain a member of the board of governors.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Yves St. Laurent, who created a sensation in the fashion world four years ago by designing a collection for the house of Dior at the age of 21, will open his own fashion house next January, he disclosed tonight.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York rose $98,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase compared with a rise of $116,000,000 in the 1960 week.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System were up $17,000,000 at $44,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements were down $9,000,000 at $579,000,000.

The Soviet Union informed the United States yesterday that it was standing firm on its demand for a peace treaty with East Germany and a settlement of the Berlin problem on the basis of such a treaty.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Freight loadings volumes last week were sharply above those of the preceding Labor Day period, the railroad and trucking industries reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Sept. 16 were unchanged from the level of a year earlier.

The surprise appointment yesterday of James J. Saxon, a 47-year-old counsel for a Chicago bank, as the new United States Controller of the Currency has left a lot of people guessing. Among the most active guessers are the nation's bankers, especially those representing national banks.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 21 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, the Economics Minister, predicted today that the West German economy would continue to expand in the coming months despite the political difficulties facing the world.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 21 -- Elisabethville was uneasy as a cease-fire began today.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he had ordered management "efficiency" units established in every executive agency of the city government.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Dr. Webster Stover, a former college president, and his wife Marion pleaded not guilty in City Court here today on a charge of violating a new city ordinance against clotheslines in front yards.

Directors of the Gillette Company authorized a three-for-one stock split yesterday and declared an extra dividend of 80 cents on the common now outstanding, along with the regular quarterly dividend of 62 1/2 cents. Both dividends are payable Dec. 5 to stockholders of record of Nov. 1. An extra of 50 cents was distributed last December.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Floyd Patterson today signed to defend his world heavyweight boxing championship against Tom McNeeley of Arlington, Mass., but a deadlock over a "non-resident-referee clause" left the sit uncertain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Kennedy will address the United Nations General Assembly Monday, the White House announced today. Mr. Kennedy will arrive in New York Sunday night, after a week-end at his summer house in Hyannis Port, Mass.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 21 -- Israeli Arabs have been staging anti-Government demonstrations in Nazareth for two days.
Sixty-three members of the Transit Authority police force were honored yesterday with Awards of Valor. Mayor Wagner made the presentations at a City Hall ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A smiling, outspoken Peruvian returned to Washington this week, repeating a pilgrimage of almost twenty years ago. He came to assure the United States that Peru would stand by its side in a 'cold' or 'hot' war.

Herman Badillo, who was defeated for the Democratic leadership of the Sixteenth Assembly District South in the Sept. 7 primary election, asked the state Supreme Court yesterday to order a new election.
A plea to political partisans not to put campaign stickers on traffic signs was made yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley.

In a speech in Chicago last week, Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Bell Howell Company, criticized advertisers for sponsoring too much "trash and trivia" on television. He urged companies to spend more on public service programs that would contribute to the "edification" rather than the "stultification of the minds of our people."
GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 21 -- The Glen Cove Board of Education will put its worst foot forward next week in an effort to demonstrate the inadequacy of its teaching facilities.
As Hurricane Esther swept out to sea yesterday, she left winds and rain on her fringe strong enough to put off the majority of sports events on Long Island and in Westchester County.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21 -- The saga of three generations of Adamses, as revealed in their own papers, was opened to the public today with the publication of the first series of "The Adams Papers." This series is titled "The Diary and Autobiography of John Adam."
A shift of stratospheric winds to the north early this month is thought to have been responsible for the rash of four hurricanes that followed in quick succession.
Members of the junior committee for the Salute to America Ball have been announced by Mrs. Robert Coulson Jr., chairman of this group, and Mrs. William C. Blanchard, vice chairman.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Britain announced today it would permit increased imports of cotton textiles in 1962 and from three of its Asian suppliers -- Hong Kong, India and Pakistan.

" Viridiana," the Luis Bunuel film that shared the grand prize at the Cannes Film Festival in May and subsequently was banned in its native Spain, is scheduled for distribution here, before the end of the year.

The death of the Secretary General of the United Nations is indeed a great tragedy for the entire world. The quiet courage, the faith in the future and devotion to duty despite momentous obstacles displayed by Mr. Hammarskjold have become well known to us through the press and other news media.
Most commodity futures prices declined in dull trading yesterday on the New York exchanges.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- When the leaders of the United States grow weary these days of worrying about Berlin, they sometimes take a change of pace by worrying about Outer Mongolia.

An American edition of Romain Gary's autobiography, which has been a best seller in France since its publication a year ago, will be issued by Harper on Oct. 11 in an English translation by John Markham Beach.
A driver's "incredible" story that a truckload of art works had been hijacked led yesterday to his arrest and the arrest of three other men.

POCONO MANOR Pa., Sept. 21 -- John P. Robin, chairman of the Delaware River Basin Advisory Committee, predicted here tonight that a commission to develop the water resources of the Delaware would be functioning within three months.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 21 -- A bit apprehensively, in view of its advance rating as the top contender for the Eastern title and a candidate for national honors, Penn State's rugged football squad today put the finishing touches on its preparations for Saturday's opener against Navy.
Two merger proposals affecting four banks, and plans for the opening of a new bank were announced yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds announced plans today to start processing mail orders for world series tickets at Crosley Field.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien is being recalled from his post as the United Nations representative in Katanga Province of the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche of Peru said today that he would be ready to recognize a Cuban government in exile provided that all the groups opposing Premier Fidel Castro succeeded in uniting.
Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald testified yesterday that he had called his $26,000-a-year deputy, Joseph R. Weiss, a "dope" for trying to resolve a tie in two bids by tossing a coin.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 -- Roger Maris doesn't consider his work done, even though the Yankees have their pennant and he no longer has a chance of breaking Babe Ruth's 154-game record of sixty homers.
ERNIE KOVACS, the whimsical impressionist of television, presented the first of his comedy specials for the season on Channel 7 last night.

A PERIOD of time of no fewer than 2,500 years -- from prehistory to the fifteenth century Aztecs -- is covered in the Museum of Primitive Art's new exhibition, "The Art of Ancient Mexico." This includes stone and terracotta sculpture, ritual vessels and gold objects, seventy pieces in all, none of which has been shown before.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The new Kennedy program for mass transit and urban "open space" may be crippled or delayed for lack of Congressional appropriations in the current rush to adjourn, Administration spokesmen said today.

THE regional tournament of the New York-New Jersey Bridge Conference, being played in the Convention Hall at Asbury Park, N.J., continues today with a two-session contest for mixed pairs at 2:30 and 8:30 P.M.

HAVING finished the third and final volume of his autobiography, "From the Shadow of the Mountain" (Dutton), Van Wyck Brooks, 75, is well into his next book. It will contain brief biographies of Americans of minor fame, like Ernest F. Fenollosa, George Catlin and Randolph Bourne.

Production of lumber climbed to 228,684,000 board feet in the week ended on Sept. 16 from 194,810,000 board feet in the preceding week, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago 234,178,000 board feet were produced.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Grain futures trading almost stalled today as the market exhausted its recent speculative influences and dealers found little additional incentive to do business.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Monroe County Welfare director charged today that some welfare officials in Florida and Georgia were paying the bills for welfare recipients to come North to get on New York relief rolls.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- President Kennedy today selected Justice George Rosling of New York to be a United States District Judge in eastern New York state. The position was created by Congress this year. It pays $22,500 a year.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 5 to 95 cents a bale yesterday, with the far months leading the falls.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 21 -Of primary concern to Williams, Wesleyan or Amherst football teams is the Little Three championship. Amherst is favored to take this important title for the third straight season.
Harold Gross, 43-year-old former teamster official, was acquitted yesterday by a Federal court jury of a charge of having extorted $20,000 from a printing company to insure labor peace.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A bill providing for Federal participation in the New York World's Fair appeared to be dead today.

Dr. Jack Weinstock and Willie Gilbert, having adapted Shepherd Mead's book (Simon Schuster) for the incoming musical "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," are processing another novel for song and dance devotees.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 21 -- Nearly half the Jewish population of Morocco is now free to travel abroad for the first time since this country became independent five years ago.

VIENNA, Sept. 21 -- Western Europe -- or much of it -- is determined to exact its pound of flesh. This was the interpretation being drawn here increasingly today as the dust began to settle on the agreement in principle reached among the main industrial nations for reinforcing the defenses of the world monetary system.
A former Superintendent of Schools in Cleveland was appointed yesterday as a special assistant to the State Education Department to help bring about improvements in the New York City school system.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 -- Their pennant clinched, the Yankees called on the junior varsity tonight as they opposed the Orioles in the finale of the four-game series.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 21 -- President Joaquin Balaguer called representatives of two opposition parties to the Presidential Palace today to invite them to form a coalition Government in support of the democratization program here.

Reform Democrats have agreed on John T. Harrington, district leader in the Tenth Assembly District South, as their candidate to succeed Carmine G. De Sapio as leader of the New York County Democratic organization (Tammany).

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Eastern Long Island leaned l into Hurricane Esther's more powerful punches this morning and came out largely unscathed, except for widespread losses of electricity and telephone service.

IT is safe to predict that more than a few unfortunates will seek to purchase a hunting license on the small-game opening day in a little more than two weeks and discover they can't. This will be because they are new hunters, and the New York State law says they have to take the course in hunter safety instruction before licenses are issued to them.

Jerome Robbins' "Ballets: U.S.A." will have a three-week run at the ANTA Theatre beginning Oct. 8. Performances will be presented by the Rebekah Harkness Foundation, which has sponsored the three-month European tour the company is completing with appearances in Stockholm, Sweden.

With the rainy by-product of Hurricane Esther saturating the steeplechase course, Allison Stern's 4-year-old gelding Naval Treaty scored a four-and-a-half-length victory at Belmont yesterday in the thirty-ninth running of the $10,950 Charles L. Appleton Memorial Steeplechase Handicap.

The AviSun Corporation announced plans yesterday to manfacture a new polypropylene packaging film that it called the greatest innovation in the field since the introduction of cellophane almost forty years ago.
The high-grade bond market had another day of rising prices yesterday, with the buying accent shifting to the Treasury's long-term bonds of post-war issue.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Prime Minister Macmillan announced tonight that Parliament would be recalled a week early to consider the international crisis.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 -- More than 750 bishops, priests and laymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church toured the automotive complex today. They were later told that they had seen a segment of life almost ignored by contemporary religion.

I have observed a tendency in American public opinion and in the American press to explain the resignation of President Quadros as an action taken by him as the result of military pressure. In his farewell statement to the nation Mr. Quadros declared that he wished to express his "gratitude for the exemplary conduct shown by the armed force, in all circumstances."

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday a second move to augment the earnings of the city's pension funds by selling some of the funds' holdings of low-interest rate bonds of short maturity and replacing them with high-grade corporate bonds bearing higher interest coupons.

Your editorial of Sept. 19 "Trouble at the Khyber Pass" should be considered a most unfair interference in the affairs of two mutually friendly countries, with a view to deliberately taking the side of the wrong.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury in Littleton, N.H., indicted foreign corporations and twenty-five individuals today on of having sold $7,000,000 worth of stock in a nonexistent nickel mine.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower visited the site of the 1964 World's Fair yesterday and predicted that by the time the fair opened things were "bound to be better."
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Some speculative demand in a market short of stock raised many industrial shares prices here today. Turnover remained small however.
Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the leader in the international grand masters chess tournament at Bled, adjourned his twelfth-round game, according to a report from Yugoslavia yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Four paintings valued at $670,000 were recovered in West Los Angeles tonight after a Palm Springs real estate dealer admitted the robbery, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith said today that the Kennedy Administration apparently lacked the will to use nuclear weapons. She said this had weakened the country's capacity to deal with the Soviet Union.
Commissioner Ford Frick yesterday clarified his position on Babe Ruth's home run record and his stand if Roger Maris surpasses the Babe's mark of sixty before the season ends.

The Yankees today will start accepting ticket orders, by mail only, for world series games at Yankee Stadium. Any such orders, the American League champions stipulated, must be postmarked no earlier than 7 o'clock last night to be acceptable.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 21 -- A taped recording of how local junior high school students feel about such subjects as segregation, the United Nations, colonialism, and even dating will be mailed tomorrow to the junior high schools in New Zealand and South Africa.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Over the Soviet bloc's protests, the General Assembly's Steering Committee accepted a United States-British proposal today for urgent debate on a treaty to ban nuclear tests under effective international control.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Senator Stuart Symington said today that there were "convincing reasons to suspect" that the Soviet Union had secretly conducted extensive nuclear tests before openly resuming weapons testing.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 21 -- Chancellor Adenauer served notice on the Free Democratic party today that it was not the only possible partner for a new West German coalition Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- A United States Tax Court judge has ruled that a man who pays kickbacks to keep a job does not have to pay income tax on them.
THE City of New York was the subject of television's interest and concern last night on three programs.
The promoters of a mysterious "flying saucer space ship capable of excursions to the moon" were ordered yesterday by the State Supreme Court to stop selling stock in New York.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 21 -- The Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions will hold a conference on "World Order and Freedom" 'in Athens Oct. 23 to 27, the organization announced today.

The names of twenty-one young women who will be presented at the Mistletoe Debutante Ball, an annual benefit for the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, have been announced by the co-chairmen, Mrs. Horace J. McAfee and Mrs. Robert E. Coulson.

Pleasure boating's season of 1962 will be launched officially this morning in Chicago, where an exciting Marine Trades Exhibit and Conference will have a four-day stay. The site will be McCormick Place, the multimillion dollar new exposition hall, at Twenty-third Street and Lake Shore Drive.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The chairman of the board of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that the "concept that Bell System management is out to dominate and control space communications simply has no basis in fact."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- B.K. Nehru, India's new Ambassador, presented his credentials at the White House today. President Kennedy took the opportunity to ask him about a statement by Defense Minister V.K. Krishna Menon of India about American nuclear tests.
The City Council moved yesterday toward repeal of the 5 per cent tax on legitimate-theatre admissions.
Three soloists will appear with the New York Philharmonic in Carnegie Hall in the opening week of the orchestra's 120th season.
The American Medical Association's call for mass administration of oral vaccine against poliomyelitis has been attacked as "premature" and possibly dangerous.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- The Federal Radiation Council today proposed drastic controls if necessary to protect the general public from radioactive materials that get inside the body and attack its sensitive organs from within.

Jet planes, space travel and clogged automobile highways will have to withdraw into relative insignificance tonight with the start of the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden. The anachronistic "ride to nowhere" will be back in the famous arena for the first time since 1939.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- The eleven-year-old claim of the Communist Government in Peiping to China's seat in the United Nations moved forward tonight with the endorsement by the General Assembly's Steering Committee of a formal debate on the issue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- Negotiations were broken off this evening between West Coast ship owners and deck officers. A resumption by the week-end of an interrupted strike that began in June was threatened a few hours later.
ONE of the most lavish and extensive fashion caravans on the American scene left New York last night in a Greyhound bus bound for a two-and-a-half month journey across the United States.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 21 -- The United States moved today to strengthen the United Nations military position in the Congo.

LONDON Sept. 21 -- Britain's adjusted balance of payments account for the second quarter of 1961 showed a deficit of 15,000,000 ($42,000,000), resulting in a marked improvement over the first quarter, when the deficit reached 68,000,000 ($190,400,000). The deficit in the second quarter of 1960 was 50,000,000 ($140,000,000).
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 21 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright's supporters appear confident that he will retain his Senate seat despite mounting attack from Right-wing factions.
Anybody who thinks football players don't know enough to come in out of the rain should have seen the New York Titans scampering for cover yesterday.
A DANISH-AMERICAN collaboration of talents that has revolutionized table furnishings from Maine to Hawaii, from Lapland to Lima in five years is making plans for its future.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Soviet Union canceled today the Saturday openings of a Soviet medical exhibit in Oklahoma City and an American transportation exhibit in Moscow.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay said today that the Soviet Union was behind rather than ahead of the United States in "super bombs."
DETROIT Sept. 21 -- The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation will make another attempt to settle all unresolved local plant disputes over the week-end.
A mass trial of seventy persons accused of counter-revolutionary activity is scheduled to begin in Havana today. The trial had been set for yesterday but was postponed until 9 o'clock this morning.

After reveling for two months in the applause of those who like to evade social responsibility by assuring themselves that most people on relief are shiftless no-accounts, the city of Newburgh, N.Y., has apparently beaten a quiet retreat from the most obnoxious features of its restrictive new welfare code.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- House and Senate conferees broke off negotiations on an appropriation for President Kennedy's foreign aid program today. No time was set for resuming the talks and no compromise was in sight.
An official of the State League of Women Voters urged support yesterday for the court reorganization amendment to the State Constitution in the November election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators said good-by to Griffith Stadium today in losing their final 1961 home game to the Minnesota Twins, 6 -- 3, before 1,498, the smallest crowd of the season.

ROGER MARIS sure gave it a gallant try. Even the worshipers at the shrine of Babe Ruth had to admire the way this iron-nerved young man withstood the almost unbearable pressures of the closing stages of his grim assault on one of baseball's loftiest records, the Bambino's sixty homers, within the span of a 154-game season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Now that Izvestia, that official and family organ of Nikita Khrushchev, has indicated its support for moving the United Nations from New York to Berlin, several interesting questions arise.

FOUR major works were offered by Dean Sanders in his first New York piano recital in Town Hall last night. Mozart's Fantasy in C minor, Beethoven's Sonata in F minor, Op. 2, No. 1, and Sonata in A flat, Op. 110, and Franck's Prelude, Chorale and Fugue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Kennedy today asked Congress for a $55,000,000 appropriation primarily to help Texas and Louisiana recover from Hurricane Carla last week.
Apparently the happy engagement of the investor-owned and Government utilities has ended well before the wedding ceremony could be performed.
Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., the nation's seventh largest food chain, had record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended on July 1, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

As the mayoralty election comes closer, this year's race takes on the proportions of a backyard brawl. There have been some pretty scurrilous criticisms, coming from both sides. Whom does one believe? Who is the real villain?
Bernard Newman, the chairman, and other officers of the New York County Republican Committee were re-elected unanimously for two-year terms at a reorganization meeting last night.
Macy's Herald Square announced yesterday it would be open until 9 P.M. on Fridays, starting Oct. 6.
Bank clearings in the nation's twenty-six leading cities aggregated $31,082,638,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc. reported yesterday. This was its highest level since June.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The highest level of radioactivity in the atmosphere recorded in this country since the Soviet Union resumed nuclear weapons testing was listed at Little Rock, Ark., yesterday.
District offices of the Department of Motor Vehicles in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens will remain open until noon on the next two Saturdays to accommodate motorists whose licenses expire Sept. 30.

A group of militant pacifists who have been marching from San Francisco to Moscow, via New York and Europe, have received clearance to agitate for nuclear disarmament in Red Square, Moscow, according to the Rev. A.J. Muste, who negotiated the agreement.

RODEZ, France, Sept. 21 -- President de Gaulle began a tour of south-central France today and received an enthusiastic welcome from the people. At the same time he was greeted with rebukes from municipal officials.
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- For the third straight race, Bill Buchan of Seattle finished ahead of the fleet in the world Star Class sailing championship yesterday.
Mayor Wagner and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz cleared the way yesterday for a debate on the issues of the city election campaign.
Trading sentiment reversed in midcourse in yesterday's stock market and the strong gains made before 2 P.M. were missing at the close.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept (UPI) -- The Public Health Service announced plans today to train 60,000,000 Americans in basic medical procedures that would be of value in a national disaster.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge Harold Cox denied today a request from the United States Justice Department that he halt Mississippi's prosecution of a Young Negro who had an altercation with a county voter-registration official.

Shearson, Hammill Co. and associates offered yesterday 1,000,000 shares of First Mortgage Investors at $15 a share. The company was organized as a real estate investment trust under recent amendments to the Internal Revenue Code.
Fifteen manufacturers of room air conditioners have formulated plans to test the cooling capacities of their 1962 models and to certify the accuracy of the ratings.

The controversial issue of American-owned ships registered under foreign flags will be high on the agenda of today's meeting of the seafarers' section of the International Transport Workers Federation.
Hurricane Esther, calmed by cool northern waters, moved slowly away from the Atlantic Coast early today, reduced to a "tropical storm." It left much less damage than had been expected.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay flew by helicopter today to Steinstuecken. The general, President Kennedy's personal representative in Berlin, thus demonstrated that it was possible for Westerners to reach the hamlet, which is part of the United States sector of Berlin but separated from the city.

HOLIDAYS and hurricanes have combined to make fish quite a scarce commodity these days. High demand has encouraged the limited supplies to command quite fancy prices. Even porgies, that usually faithful bargain, have reached the relatively high figure of 39 cents pound.

VIENNA, Sept. 21 (AP) -Isaac Berger, the former Olympic champion from York, Pa., won the featherweight title in the world weight-lifting championships today, defeating Yevgeni Minaev, the Soviet Union's 1960 Olympic gold medalist.

The Chrysler Corporation completed realignment of its top management yesterday by electing George H. Love, Pittsburgh industrialist, as chairman of the board. The post had been vacant since Lester L. (Tex) Colbert resigned last summer.
The world's second tallest skyscraper, the Chrysler Building, is being scrubbed down these days by ten men with dishpan hands.

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Clyde E. Weed, chairman of the Anaconda Company, said today that the copper industry "can no longer tolerate prolonged work stoppages or unreasonable demands of labor, both of which play into the hands of competitors both at home and abroad."

The pain of giving was eased considerably for 500 philanthropists last night. They sailed aboard a luxury liner for a moonlight cruise, dined and wined, danced, shot craps and played roulette, blackjack and chuck-a-luck -- all for charity.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 22 -- The British Liberal party called today on the Soviet Union and the United States to stop nuclear testing and urged Britain and France "to renounce all future tests."
MOORESTOWN, N.J., Sept. 22 -- The English women's touring field hockey team scored its sixth victory in eight games in this country by defeating West Jersey, 5 -- 0, before 2,000 spectators today.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 22 -- The Central Government served notice today that it disapproved of the cease-fire between the United Nations and the Katanga Government.
In an atmosphere charged with politics, the Board of Estimate yesterday laid over until after election the controversial proposal to widen most of Fulton Street between Broadway and South Street.
It is to be regretted that some letter writers to your paper and to the President appear to suffer from the psychological fall-out which stems from the latest Soviet resumption of tests.

BERLIN, Sept. 22 -- Two United States soldiers were detained for six hours by the East German police yesterday, it was disclosed today. They had been driving from West Berlin to Helmstedt, in West Germany.

A prediction that total retail trade in the nation would increase 4 per cent or more next year from this year's level, was made yesterday by Myron S. Silbert, vice president of Federated Department Stores, Inc. He also forecast sharp gains for both soft and hard goods industries.

VIENNA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon said today Washington hoped that by next year its allies' military purchases in the United States would pay for United States military expenditures abroad.

It is clear that we will have to wait at least a generation to clear the slums if we must rely solely on the use of public funds. What is worse, by the time we get done we may find that many of our public housing projects have themselves become slums (not to mention many of the private apartment buildings mushrooming everywhere with neither quality nor style).
HARTSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Songs and dances are being used by Greenburgh Democrats to attain a goal that ordinary campaigning had left out of reach -- the election of Democratic town officials.
"We had gone to bed in summer and we awoke in autumn, for summer passes into autumn in some unimaginable point of time, like the turning of a leaf."
ROME, Sept. 22 -- Italian shipbuilders were gratified today to learn of the agreement signed in Moscow yesterday whereby Italian yards will build six 48,000-ton tankers for the Soviet Union.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 22 -- Nassau County's program for redeveloping Mitchel Field was said today to be jeopardized by Navy plans to acquire housing at the former Air Force base.
BERLIN, Sept. 22 -- An authoritive United States source called on West Germany today to accept, in its own interests, the "reality" of the existence of two German states.

The International Longshoremens Association and the Waterfront Commission joined yesterday in requesting -- for different reasons -- a prompt Supreme Court ruling on the constitutionality of new restrictions against ex-convicts in the pier union.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller declared tonight that there had been "a major change" in New York State's business climate since 1958, the year of his election.

Three new collections of home furnishings will be presented Wednesday at America House, 44 West Fifty-third Street. The display will include furniture by Phillip Lloyd Powell and Paul Evans, lamps By Peter Voulkos, Franz Wildenhain and others, rugs by George Wells, Thomas Stearns, Lewis Guidetti and Robert Charles Heitman. America House is open weekdays from 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- The question of the admission of Communist China to the United Nations was sent to the General Assembly tonight with little fuss and no fury.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 -- A threatened resumption of the maritime strike on the West Coast was delayed today at least until Monday.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- The Hughes Tool Company has announced another in a series of diversifications that are planned to take the company away from total dependence on the oil industry.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 22. -- Save-Co. Veterans and Services Department Stores, Inc., of San Diego has rejected a discount operation proposed by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.
WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- The fourteenth annual sports-car racing classic meeting in this Finger Lakes resort village opened today.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 22 -- Penn State, labeled the Eastern teams most likely to succeed, and Navy, the section's top independent of 1960, will test each other's mettle here tomorrow in one of the high spots of the college football season's first week-end of extensive activity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Kennedy assured legislative leaders of both parties today that Congress would be quickly recalled to Washington if an international emergency warranted that step. The leaders are hoping to adjourn Congress for the year tomorrow night.

VIENNA, Sept 22 -- The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Per Jacobsson, said today he was "confident" a new borrowing arrangement would be worked out in the next few months to augment the resources of the fund.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 22 (AP) -- This city has become the control center for a campaign aimed at stripping the Amateur Athletic Union of its jurisdiction over almost all non-collegiate track and field competition in the United States.
MONTREAL, Sept. 22 -- One of the largest office developments in the world, financed by Canadian and European interests, was announced here today.
Radioactive fall-out in the city is not a danger to health at this time, Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner said yesterday in announcing the start of round-the-clock monitoring of fall-out.
The 13,345-ton passenger-cargo ship Media sailed out of the Port of New York yesterday on her final voyage under the Cunard house flag.
ATLANTA, Sept. 22 -- Ivan Allen Jr., 50-year-old business leader and the moderate candidate in a run-off election that centered on segregation, was nominated today as mayor of this city.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk urged the Genera Assembly today to name "an outstanding world leader" immediately to take over the functions of the United Nations Secretary General on a temporary basis.

Recently some economists have been predicting a rise in long-term interest rates by the year-end, especially with regard to mortgages. Yesterday, an economist reasoned that short-term interest rates were likely to rise by year-end or early next year.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 22 -- The West German Government is reported to be puzzled and deeply concerned by recurrent articles in United States newspapers to the effect that major concessions are being sought from Bonn in preparation for an East-West conference.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Jerry Walker, with an assist from Jim Archer, held Cleveland to four hits tonight and the Kansas City Athletics scored a 4-3 victory over the Indians. Willie Kirkland hit a two-run homer for the Indians in the seventh.

HONG KONG, Sept. 22 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China said tonight that the forthcoming General Assembly debate on the question of Peiping's admission to the United Nations would be a "test" for the countries of the world.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that "hot cargo" clauses in labor contracts were illegal.

General Dynamics/Astronautics, a division of the General Dynamics Corporation, is forming special parts for spacecraft by an explosive method at a new underwater installation at San Diego, Calif., it was announced yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 21 -- The skyline of Bucharest is dominated by a huge, ugly building that was built in the Soviet style of architecture. Upon seeing it on the outskirts a visitor prepares for the worst. But he could not be more wrong.

"Human eyes are limited in their scope. Yet with one small brush I can draw the vast universe." Such an assertion by Wang Wei, a Chinese painter of the fifth century A.D., sounds like an outrageous boast. Less so, however, when we come face to face with the panoramic landscape paintings of the T'ang and Sung dynasties, the glory of the incomparable exhibition of Chinese art treasures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Each of the dozen fillies and mares entered in today's $96,000 Beldame Handicap at Belmont has won a stakes race -- a factor that will make the selection of a betting favorite a difficult business.

THE men's pair contest in the regional tournament at Asbury Park, N.J., was won Thursday night by Jeff Westheimer and Martin Ginsberg of Long Beach, L.I. Irving Ingwer and William Lifton of Brooklyn were second.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Westchester won the Myra D. Patterson trophy for the third year in a row today in the thirty-third intersectional team match of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Apawamis Club.
Stock market prices receded yesterday for the eighth time in the last eleven days. It was a slow and rather deliberate New York Stock Exchange session, with relatively few losses of importance.
The market in high-grade bonds stayed strong yesterday.
WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 22 -- Little Flight won the amateur working hunter championship of the Eastern States horse show today. Flying Curlew took reserve honors.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates scored four unearned runs in the ninth inning tonight and defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 6 -- 3.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 22 -- Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said today that the reclamation of the Hackensack Meadows in New Jersey might soon take "a giant step forward" through a study by the Army Corps of Engineers.
PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Members of the United Automobile Workers will meet Sunday to act on committee recommendations for a strike vote at the Caterpillar Tractor Company.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- The Snipe sailing champion of Brazil, Axel Schmidt, captured the world title today with his twin brother, Erik.

J.J. Newberry Company is negotiating the private placement of $15,500,000 of debentures, according to J.E. Nelson, president. The financing would include issuance of warrants for the purchase of 155,000 shares of common stock.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The grain futures market moved in a mostly firm to strong range today on the Board of Trade despite profit taking that weakened oats and rye.
A Navy-sponsored study of what happens when a volcanic eruption almost annihilates the plants and animals of an island has produced results applicable to problems that would follow a nuclear attack.
ACRE, Israel, Sept. 22 -- Twelve persons were injured in rioting between Arabs and Jews in the old city of Acre today.

PRINCE NORODOM SIHANOUK, the mercurial chief of state of Cambodia, was once known to the world chiefly for his saxophone playing and expert horsemanship. The Prince, who delivered a disarmament plea at the United Nations yesterday, has been characterized as "alert, sensitive, stubborn."
Former Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy declined yesterday to run for Mayor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Too many airlines are competing for international traffic, the chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 22 -- The effect on the Dominican Republic's economy of the sanctions imposed by the Organization of American States has become a matter of bitter controversy between the Government and the Opposition.

ALGIERS, Sept. 22 -- The Europeans of Algiers and other Algerian cities demonstrated their opposition to a settlement with the Moslem rebels tonight by creating a tremendous din with pots and pans, whistles and automoble horns.

Kenneth Mills, a Canadian pianist who makes his home in Toronto, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. He opened his program unconventionally with Ravel's "Alborada del gracioso" and Prelude and Debussy's "L'isle joyeuse."

The Royal McBee Corporation had a net loss of $1 079 519 on sales of $106,846,198 in the fiscal year ended July 31. In the preceding fiscal year the company had a profit of $771,057 or 28 cents a common share, on sales of $111,073,396.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 22 -- Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of State Dean Rusk distributed today before his talk at a Foreign Press Association luncheon and of questions put to Mr. Rusk and his answers at the luncheon:
DETROIT, Sept. 22 -- The Protestant Episcopal Church is still the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Aboard a rattling subway express train racing under Bronx real estate early yesterday, four members of the New York Football Giants sat hunched over morning newspapers. Their sporty attire and their sleepy-eyed demeanor paralleled that of other wage-earners en route to less glamorous pursuits.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Jim Gentile hit his fifth grand-slam homer of the season tonight as the Orioles defeated the White Sox, 8 -- 6. Gentile's drive enabled him to tie the major league record set by Ernie Banks of the Cubs in 1955.
Paul Newman has been signed for the role of Robert F. Kennedy in a fictionalized film version of the Attorney General's book, "The Enemy Within."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Nine electrical manufacturers convicted this year of price-fixing and bid-rigging were sued by the Government today for alleged overcharges in the sale of insulators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Average prices in wholesale primary markets declined 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday, to 118.6 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor statistics announced today.
