WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A rear-view mirror that was patented this week dims itself against the glare of headlights from a following car. The rest of the time it gives a normal, clear reflection.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- The United Nations is building its own air force in the Congo. The decision, disclosed tonight, followed the military setbacks the United Nations force suffered in eight days of bitter fighting in an unsuccessful effort to end the secession of Katanga Province from the regime in Leopoldville.

The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday it was reducing the price of its primary aluminum ingot 2 cents a pound, to 24 cents. The company asserted the action was "forced by foreign competition, both Canadian and European."

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Jerry Barber set an 18 hole course record of 64 today and moved into a three-way tie for the lead at the halfway point of the Portland open golf tournament. Barber, Dave Hill and Jerry Steelsmith all have 36-hole totals of 134 on the 6,675-yard, Columbia-Edgewate Golf Club course.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of the Piping Club turned back Mrs. Allan A. Ryan of Creek, 4 and 3, today in the semi-finals of the Women's Long Island Golf Association match-play championship at the Creek Club.

Mrs. Louis Davidson Sage and Mrs. Thomas W. Frank, co-chairmen, have announced plans for a theatre party to aid the James Weldon Johnson Community Center. The event will take place at the Oct. 30 performance of "An Evening with Yves Montand" at the Golden Theatre.
The nation's banks may be suffering greater dollar losses from staff embezzlements than ever before, but on the average bank personnel are becoming more honest with each passing year.

Joseph R. Weiss, suspended deputy superintendent of schools, admitted yesterday that he had erased "fifteen, maybe ten" names from check stubs that had been requested by the State Investigation Commission.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- City officials rejected today a plan to build sixteen-story apartment houses for 400 families in the Grace Church Street estate area, adjacent to Port Chester.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- Ground was broken this week for the Occidental Center, a $25,000,000 headquarters complex for the Occidental Life Insurance Company of California.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- Taking advantage of an open date in the schedule, Manager Ralph Houk today turned his attention to the Yankee pitching staff. The job is to rotate it properly so that it will come to the opening of the world series on Oct. 4 at peak efficiency.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr. and his father were accused in a law suit today of misusing thousands of dollars in insurance company funds for airplane trips, political expenses, wardrobes and other personal items.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 -- The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reported slow progress today in resolving unsettled plant disputes.
Twelve adjourned games from the seventh, tenth, eleventh and twelfth rounds were played off yesterday in the international chess masters tournament at Bled, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

ALBANY, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller and the legislative majority today named twelve members of a commission to cooperate with Cornell University in observing the 100th anniversary next year of the Morrill Land-Grant Act.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union and the United States clashed tonight on the question of how to discuss disarmament in the United Nation.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 22 -- Fred Olsen, 32-year-old Norwegian retained his world International class sailing title today without being required to compete in the last race of the series on Long Island Sound.
The Federal Aviation Agency's timetable for perfecting a highly advanced computer and companion devices for control of air traffic has slipped many months.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Frank Lary, a right-hander, gained his twenty-second victory of the season as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Los Angeles Angels tonight, 6 -- 4. The Tigers, trailing, 4 -- 0, after two innings, got the deciding run on a sixth-inning homer by Al Kaline.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- Premier Khrushchev has asserted that he is ready for negotiations at "any time, any place and at any level" to avert the danger of war over Berlin and Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept 22 (UPI) -- President Kennedy signed bills today that made the Peace Corps permanent, expanded the program for changing salt water to fresh and granted Federal help to the states in fighting juvenile delinquency.

MENDE, France, Sept. 22 -- President de Gaulle, touring the south-central part of France with the vigor of an ardent political campaigner, stressed the need for French unity in speech after speech today.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- Former Premier Paul Reynaud has quoted Premier Khrushchev as having said that the Communists did not want West Berlin and considered it unimportant in the over-all competition between East and West.
OTTAWA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- "Make a joyful noise unto the Lord," says the psalm -- and the Rev. Bernard de Brienne does just that.

New York State's adoption of the Federal Medical Assistance to the Aged program is too restrictive to do much good in the city, welfare and health experts told a legislative committee hearing here yesterday.

The appearance of counterfeit $10 bills in New York was announced yesterday by the Secret Service. The spurious money has shown up thus far at Belmont Race Track, a night club, and several uptown bars and liquor stores.
Columbia University recently took over the mortgage on dirty, rundown building at Broadway and West 112th Street in another step to save its neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Administration hopes of a minimum $4,000,000,000 foreign aid appropriation were bogged down today in a war of nerves between House and Senate negotiators. The fight caused cancellation of a third meeting on a compromise of the bills passed by the two houses.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell ran into trouble today over his statistics on welfare caseloads and illegitimate births.
Sales of the Collins Radio Company set a record for the year ended on July 31, but earnings were less than half those of the preceding fiscal year, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

Atlantic City Electric Company yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 200,000 shares of company stock. The underwriting group is headed by Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and Smith, Barney Co.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee and then the full committee approved in rapid succession tonight the nomination of Federal District Judge Luther Meritt Swygert of Chesterton, Ind., to be a judge of the Seventh Circuit of Appeals.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept 22 -- Ernest Ransome 3d, of Riverton, N.J., was the medalist with a two-over-par 36, 36 -- 72 in the thirty-seventh George Arthur Crump Memorial Cup golf tournament today at Pine Valley Golf Club.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 22 -- Nationalist China will not hesitate to use its veto power in the Security Council as an ultimate measure to prevent Outer Mongolia's admission into the United Nations, an authoritative Nationalist source declared today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 22 -- The Inter-Parliamentary Union adopted resolutions today appealing to the United States and the Soviet Union to negotiate on world problems and urging all countries to refrain from nuclear tests.

The Honolulu Oil Corporation has postponed until Monday a special stockholders' meeting to consider sale of its assets. The meeting had been set for yesterday in San Francisco but was adjourned earlier this week when the Department of Justice filed suit seeking to stop the sale.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Justice is conducting an investigation to determine whether antitrust violations have occurred in the purchase and sale of pulpwood.

IF Alla Sizova of the Leningrad Kirov Ballet would like to have the City of New York, all she has to do this morning is ask for it. It was all but handed across the footlights to her last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for her performance of "The Sleeping Beauty."

MIDDLETOWN, Conn. Sept. 22 -- The men who will carry the ball for Wesleyan are new to varsity backfield competition. But there are men in the line who know how to crack rival football defenses. Wesleyan hopes that the big fellows up front will open the way and that the young men in the rear will follow.
An 81-year-od Chelsea landlord with a long record of building violations was fined $510 and sentenced to ten days in the workhouse in Housing Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The bill providing for Federal participation in the New York 1964-65 World's Fair died today in the files of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
PEKIN, Ill., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen told a hometown audience tonight that he would run for a third term next year.
A live Broadway production will be telecast over a closed circuit to a theatre outside New York for one month during the winter.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Sept. 22 (AP) -- A marine board of investigation has concluded that the break-up of the 16,716-ton tanker Pine Ridge last winter -- which cost seven lives -- was caused mainly by improper ballasting.

HOW did the contemporary world get itself into the perilous state the papers report today? A stimulating discussion of all that troubles us is presented in Edgar Ansel Mowrer's new book, "An End to Make-Believe."* It is a controversial jeremiad from start to finish. Mr. Mowrer, who has been reporting long wars and short outbreaks of peace for decades, once again sounds his somewhat exasperated call for liberty.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Vincent Fitzgerald of Garden City won the fall championship of the New York State Seniors Golf Association at the Westchester Country Club today with a 36-hole total of 76, 72 -- 148.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia appealed today to the United Nations to accept a general and total disarmament plan with inspection by neutral countries as "the only solution" to the arms problem.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- This Hudson River Valley city of 30,000 is working on a plan to use fifteen acres of limestone caves under its downtown section for giant fall-out shelters.
The Security Council has fixed next Tuesday as the time for dealing with the applications of new states for membership in the United Nations.

A theatre party at the Nov. 2 performance of "Write Me a Murder" by Frederick Knott will augment the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York. The play, starring Kim Hunter and James Donald will open at the Belasco Theatre Oct. 26.
NEWARK, Sept. 22 -- A 14-year-old Newark school girl will leave tomorrow for Moscow, where she will continue her studies.

Billy Rose accused the city government yesterday of a "hit and miss" method of assessing Broadway real estate values. The very existence of the New York legitimate theatre, he charged, is in jeopardy unless ameliorative measures are taken.

For the first time in almost two years, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday suspended one of its allied members for violation of rules. The Board of Governors of the exchange found Marvin Kleinzahler, a voting stockholder of Rodetsky, Kleinzahler, Walker Co. of Jersey City N.J., guilty of violating Federal margin regulations in his personal account.
Two children playing hop-scotch were injured yesterday when a car went out of control and ran onto a sidewalk in front of 358 Webster Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

INTRIGUING passers-by on East Sixty-seventh Street between Madison and Park Avenues is a charming floral- decked cart, with all the gaiety of a French outdoor market. The bunches of flowers are picked daily in the country and sell at $1 each.

In his letter published Sept. 15 Thomas G. Eybye attempts to defend Dr. Ralph White's remarks (made in a speech under the auspices of the United States Information Agency) against Senator Dodd's criticism by alluding to the putative chauvinists and jingoists among us, who, in Mr. Eybye's opinion, are obstructing useful negotiations with the U.S.S.R.

The chief of the German Federal Republic's Division of Mass Media said here yesterday that his nation's youth must be indoctrinated with the traditions of the German past that embraced democracy, liberalism and self-government.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Georgia Tech struck for three touchdowns and a field goal in the first half tonight and rolled over Southern California, 27 -- 7, before 36,950.

The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Abraham Ribicoff, made a speech worthy of consideration on Sept. 14 when he commented upon accusations made of charitable organizations that they have failed to give the public a clear accounting of their activities.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 50 cents a bale off to 5 cents up (on far December) yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- The commander of the Military Air Transport Service asserted today that the Air Force is "equipped, ready and trained" to carry out another Berlin airlift.

President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche of Peru received a friendly welcome yesterday as he arrived here for a five-day visit that will include an address before the United Nations General Assembly on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Kennedy administration has decided to reassure itself about the political and economic situation in Ghana before it determines whether to commit the United States to supply $133,000,000 in aid for the Volta River project in the West African Republic.
Bright weather returned to the city yesterday in the wake of Hurricane Esther. It was the last day of summer, and the temperature reached a high of 88 degrees at 3:20 P.M.
PARIS, Sept. 22 -- Last month Khrushchev confided to a foreign diplomat: "If the West Germans lost faith in the West they will turn to us. They have no place else to go."
WARSAW, Sept. 22 -- The Roman Catholic Church has summoned its priesthood to resist a Government attempt to take control of religious teaching in Poland.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that interplanetary space is a military medium -- one in which the Air Force must have a dominating role.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission prescribed rules today forbidding racial discrimination in interstate bus transportation. The rules cover terminal facilities as well as buses.
UNITED NATIONS N.Y., Sept. 22 -- The Guinean diplomat involved in a Harlem Street fight with a New York policeman last month returned to the United States tonight as quietly as he had left.
PARENTS who for years have been dismayed over the caliber of television in the hectic pre-supper period from 5 to 6 o'clock, will be inclined to give a cheer this morning for two Washington fathers.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 22 -- President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga warned last night that he would abolish the cease-fire throughout the province if the United Nations troops did not soon evacuate the Post Office building here.

ATLANTA, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- The Communicable Disease Center said today that a sharp increase in the number of poliomyelitis cases was recorded in the United States in the last week. Ninety-eight cases, including sixty-two paralytic were reported in the week.
YONKERS, Sept. 22 -- The top horse win be the one farthest from the rail at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night in the $25,000 Red Sails Pace, a handicap event.
Commodity futures prices generally declined again yesterday in moderately active trading on the New York exchanges.

AUGSBURG, Germany, Sept. 22 (AP) -- An Army captain testified today that he doubted a reporter's contention of having obtained a medical report that said Maj. Edwin A. Walker was suffering from a brain tumor.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said yesterday, 'I didn't really gamble" during a charity cruise Thursday night.
A large Long Island shopping center has been sold and another is under contract for sale.

THE Henry Glaubers have never considered their home a castle. It is a log cabin with Swiss chalet overtones perched on a hill in Garrison, N.Y. One day, however, the Glaubers took a look at an abandoned castle and decided, "That's our art gallery."

The old-line Tammany district leaders were unable to agree yesterday on a candidate for county chairman to be presented at a reorganization meeting of the New York County Democratic Committee next Wednesday night.
SEPTEMBER brings, along with bad things like the wind and rain of hurricanes, a host of good things like the Bartlett pear. The fruit has a curious history involving a real estate transaction.

The 366 Small Business Investment Companies in the United States should find it easier to borrow from commercial banks from now on, according to Phil David Fine, deputy administrator of the Small Business Administration.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- An American Medical Association publication came up today with a new phobia: nucleomitophobia, or fear of atomic energy.

BITBURG, Germany, Sept. 22 -- Concrete and steel underground structures stressed to withstand the blast of nuclear weapons are nearing completion around the United States air base here on the Eifel plateau of West Germany.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 22 -- Mrs. Gordon Park of Glen Ridge and Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells won the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's Scotch foursome one-day tournament today at the Montclair Golf Club by a draw.

At the New York World's Fair visitors from every nation on this globe, and particularly the newly emerged nations to whom America has until now been a far away land, will have a superb opportunity to get to know us at first hand, and to become intimately acquainted with what we stand for.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Chet Sanok an upper Montclair Country Club amateur, took the lead in the metropolitan open golf championship as the tourney was resumed today. Sanok's three-under-par 68 over the East course of the Winged Foot Golf Club gave the big fellow a 36-hole score of 143 and a three-stroke margin.

TORONTO, Sept. 22 -- A sinking ship in an old British movie being shown on a New York television station Wednesday afternoon crackled out an SOS -- and inadvertently sent ships and planes into a hunt for a "ghost" vessel in the Canadian sub-Arctic.
What started out last night to be a six-day bike race at Madison Square Garden turned into something resembling a three-ring circus.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Sept. 22 -- The White House released today letters from seven leading steel companies indicating little or no sympathy for President Kennedy's plea that the line be held on prices.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Eagle-Picher Company's net sales for the three months ended Aug. 1 were $26,930,618, compared with $27,546,744 for the 1960 quarter.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Robert C. Liebenow, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, charged today that Government price fixers had taken tens of millions of dollars out of the pockets of corn producers through Federal sales of "tens of millions of bushels" of feed grains.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower put on an "I Like Louie" button yesterday, beamed at Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and said, "He's my man."

The late Clark Gable is the subject of two books that will be published this season. One is "Clark Gable, a Personal Portrait," by his widow, Kathleen Gable, which Prentice-Hall will issue on Monday. The other is "Dear Mr. G -- ," by Jean Garceau with Inez Cocke, to be published by Little, Brown on Oct. 19.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Disappointment with the interim earnings statements of two of Britain's big industrial corporations, Vickers and Associated Electrical Industries, carried industrial shares down in an irregular stock market here today.
The market for new capital will be in full swing next week with about $250,000,000 of fixed-interest securities, mostly municipals, slated for marketing.

The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission urged here yesterday that the nation's three television networks join in guaranteeing at least one hour of high-quality children's programing in the late afternoon each weekday.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 22 -- Only one Cincinnati base-runner reached third tonight as the Reds were blanked, 6 -- 0, by Billy O'Dell of the San Francisco Giants at Crosley Field.

VIENNA, Sept. 22 -- Chancellor Alfons Gorbach told a society of industrialists last night that neutral Austria had to devise some form of association with the European Economic Community if she was to survive economically.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Don Drysdale and Ron Perranoski pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 6-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

ELIZABETH KATA has written a brief, sensational novel, presumably set in her native Australia, that tells in quick-paced prose, and with mounting intensity, the story of an 18-year-old blind girl's discovery of the life outside the one small room in which, since her loss of sight at the age of 5, she has remained virtually a prisoner.

THERE are some very good things in this first novel of the Allied advance through northern Italy in World War II and of an American artillery battalion's part in it. Mitchell Goodman evokes with life and vigor the movement of the war through mountains and mud, the quality of an army's personality and spirit, the Italian landscape.

THE big, exciting thing that is going on in the Arab world, all the way from the Atlantic to the Persian Gulf, is that the Arab people who, during centuries of sterility and stagnation could claim distinction only in their glorious medieval past, are now moving into a brighter future. This future, if not glorious, looks as though it might at least add prosperity and social justice to independence.

Ask who someone is and the reply invariably comes back, "Why, he is a plumber," or a "surgeon," or an "economist," or a geographer," or a "dean," or a "policeman" -- not a man at all but only a splinter.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Paolo Rosi knocked out Jackie Donnelly in the second round of a scheduled ten-round lightweight bout tonight. A right cross followed by a jarring left hood finished the Buffalo fighter.

IN the past decade, running away from home has declined by 30 per cent. In either case, it is apparent that the young man who once ran off to seek his fortune, knowing that he had a fair chance of finding it, is a vanishing breed.

THE Leningrad Kirov Ballet will begin its final week at the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow evening, before moving to Madison Square Garden for further performances. The schedule will contain three presentations of "Sleeping Beauty," three of "Gala Program No. 2" and one of "Gala Program No. 1."

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Run For Nurse, owned by J. Graham Brown of Louisville, rallied in the muddy going and scored a three-length victory today in the $28,700 Charles W. Bidwill Memorial Handicap at Hawthorne.

PRIVAS, France, Sept. 23 -- President de Gaulle's tour through three of France's poorest departments is emerging as a personal triumph for him not Withstanding the threats of demonstrations and boycotts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Congress gave up today on efforts to adjourn the 1961 session tonight and decided to try again next week.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The prospect of a statewide strike of teamsters was averted today when trucking employers agreed to accept a Teamsters Union counterproposal on a new contract. Approximately 18,000 teamsters are involved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The Defense Department's single-manager procurement system -- and that includes oil buying -- is on the way out.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Following a brief but somber oration by Coach Dale Stanley Hall, who ordinarily is no dressing-room Cicero, Army's football team went out and "prowessed" Richmond, 24-6, today.
NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Boston College battered the University of Cincinnati, 23 -- 0, on the power thrusts of Harry Crump and the timely passes of George Van Cott today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today a streamlining of its organizational set-up in an effort to speed a man to the moon.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower spent the warm, sunny afternoon yesterday golfing at the Links Golf Club in North Hills, L.I.

Better-price and popular-price fall apparel reorders were a feature of resident buying office business last week. MONROE, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- A letter written by William H. Seward on Feb. 20, 1849, recalls today's widely debated issue of aid to parochial schools. Seward wrote about the financing of parochial schools in New York City, an issue more than 100 years ago.

ALTHOUGH Cathy is not such an original as the hero of Joan Lexau's first book, "Olaf Reads," she has her own share of childhood logic. When, as she is getting ready to visit her Cousin Barbara, her mother says, "You must be good when you are company," Cathy answers "You mean I don't have to be good here?"
There is such a thing as being too successful. Mrs. Alan H. Kempner learned that when she nearly had Arabs enlisted in behalf of her cause -- the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

OLD DEERFIELD, Mass. -- One of the foremost collections of Early American silver will be added this fall to the historical and architectural riches of this 300-year-old restored village. The collection will be part of the Parker-Russell Silver Shop, a restored eighteenth-century silversmith's shop that is scheduled to be opened to the public next month.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The other day, President Kennedy sent a note to several of his associates in the Government asking why the policy of the United States on Germany was not better understood.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Eva B. Adams, a longtime Congressional aide and a former educator, was confirmed by the Senate today as Director of the Mint. Approval was by voice vote.

IN Howard Taubman's recent critique of present-day theatre, he touched on a sore spot which it seems to me concerns not only the dramatic but all the arts.

Bank debits in this Federal Reserve district were up 3 per cent for August and 6 per cent for the year to date, the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank reported. Totals for August were $6,209,588,000, compared with $6,044,094,000 a year ago, and for the eight-month period, $45,813,259,000, against $43,166,453,000 last year.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A Navy patrol plane carrying a crew of ten ditched in the Atlantic north of Bermuda last night after fire knocked out its starboard engines. It broke up on impact and only three of the crew are known to have survived.
President Manuel Prado of Peru and Senora Prado were luncheon and dinner guests of leading New Yorkers yesterday.
The president of the newly constituted Board of Education feels that school buildings are important, but not nearly so important as the teachers inside them.

After watching the "Jack Paar Show" tonight, I suddenly came to realize the tremendous potential that a war might have. * * * It could be enjoyed by all people in all parts of the world. WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A single Southern Democrat defied House and Senate leaders today and blocked efforts to reach a compromise agreement on the Administration's $4,000,000,000 foreign aid appropriation.

LEWISBURG, Pa. -- The Susquehanna River country of eastern Pennsylvania is fine territory for city motorists to explore on a long week-end. Lying just west of the Poconos, it is easily reached from the metropolitan area in half a day.
HILO, Hawaii, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- A new volcanic eruption sent molten lava coursing towards four small Hawaii Island villages today. They were hastily abandoned by their 2,500 residents.

Cool breezes presented a perfect setting last week for a big increase in retail apparel sales, but on the Eastern coast the threat of a hurricane tended to put a damper on merchandising plans. From Cape Hatteras north through Rhode Island, high-velocity winds and rain kept shopping to a minimum in the middle of the week.

FEW other garden chores pay greater dividends than fall clean-up and division of perennial flower borders. The weather is propitious and the soil is warm and workable -- the ideal combination for prompt root growth.
THE United Nations Postal Administration is considering a memorial stamp in honor of Dag Hammarskjold, the United Nations' Secretary General who died in an air crash in Rhodesia last Monday.

IT has always seemed to me that Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt's candid, poignant account of her youth in "This Is My Story" should be required reading for every shy, uncertain girl. Now Mrs. Roosevelt, with co-author Helen Ferris, has written a book especially for young girls, prompted by teen-agers' questions and discussions, and drawing upon her own experiences to help them meet problems which are essentially the same generation after generation.

HAVANA, Sept. 20 -- With his harsh moves against the Cuban clergy, Premier Fidel Castro chose during the week between two politically dangerous alternatives. To ignore the recent demonstrations in front of churches in Havana and the interior might have caused his large but fearful opposition to organize new and bigger ones.

Despite stormy weather, retail sales in the New York area last week rose from the level of the 1960 week. Strong sales volumes on Monday and Tuesday helped sales advance over a year ago by 2 to 3 per cent, according to estimates by leading department store officers.

Mayor Wagner has advised reform Democratic district leaders that he believes Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. should be elected New York County chairman. The county committee will meet Wednesday night to reorganize.

MANY broadleaved and needled evergreens will respond favorably to fall planting if the job is done promptly. Among the needled (narrow-leaved) types are most of the yews, junipers, arborvitae, false cypress and pines such as white, Swiss stone, Scotch and mugo.

Hopeful signs of business recovery in the metropolitan area were seen by the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Average wholesale prices of major spices in international trade have risen an average of 740 per cent above the pre-war levels. WARSAW Sept. 21 -- Do-it-yourself home construction, the means by which hundreds of thousands of Poles have put roofs over their heads in the last decade, has been struck a staggering blow.

The sun, and the countless trillions of stars of the same type, are hydrogen bombs under control. In the interior of the sun, at a temperature of 20 to 30 million degrees Centigrade, a mass of 600,000,000 tons of the lightest variety of hydrogen is fused into 596,000,000 tons of helium every second, which means that 4,000,000 tons of the sun's mass are converted every second into radiant energy, light, heat, ultraviolet rays, and X-rays.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A twin-engine Turkish airliner crashed in torrential rain near here tonight. Airline officials said all twenty-five passengers and the crew of four were believed to have been killed.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Dave Hill, the first-day leader, regained the lead in the $25,000 Portland golf open today with a three-under-par 69 for a 54-hole total of 203.
ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Alabama combined the rushing of Mike Fracchia with an iron defense today and thrashed Georgia, 32 to 6, in a Southeastern Conference football opener.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Monticello Raceway ended its fourth season tonight with new track marks in handle, attendance and performance.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- Two Ghanaians were appointed chiefs of Ghana's naval and air forces tonight. The appointments followed an announcement last night of a reorganization of the armed services in which Britons were removed from the top commands.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 15 -- An order of German Protestant nuns has been working quietly in Israel for the last four years to be of service to Jews. All of the sisters were in the Hitler Youth during World War II.

Experience with the city's new "vandal resistant" parking meters has been encouraging, Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley said yesterday.

Department store sales in the Federal district for the week ended Sept. 16 showed an increase of 13 per cent from the 1960 level. The four-week period ended the same date showed an increase of 4 per cent and for the cumulative year an increase of 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The frozen diplomatic climate surrounding the Berlin issue appears to be warming. Both Moscow and Washington are beginning to acknowledge their eagerness for "honorable" negotiations over Berlin and Germany. Both are in the process of taking the next step of proving to the other a desire to be "reasonable."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Peace Corps, by act of Congress and a stroke of the President's pen, is now officially a permanent agency of the Federal Government. How well it will do overseas is still to be seen.

Individual barometers of Cleveland business activity varied considerably and these were some setbacks in the latest weekly summaries. The slump in the building industry continued, with the estimated cost of all projects authorized in the week ended Sept. 16 amounting to $838,000.

Retail trade in the Kansas City area moved slightly ahead of a year ago under the impetus of promotions featuring winter wearing apparel. ITALIAN publishers are a happy exception among their European colleagues: far from complaining, they confess that business is booming and sales are mounting. This is a recent phenomenon, for Italians today are not only reading but are also buying more books than ever before.
LONDON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A woman was killed and four ships were damaged in collisions today in the fog-shrouded English Channel.

BLAIR, Neb., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Blair golf course has taken fourteen acres out of corn and milo production and turned it into fairways. Now it's waiting for a Government check under the feed-grain program.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23 -- The Orthodox churches of the world, including the huge Russian Orthodox Church and its small Middle Eastern sister churches, are gathering this week-end on the island of Rhodes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- A House investigating subcommittee charged today that a United States road building project in Cambodia had been "so badly bungled" that Justice Department action might be warranted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, introduced today legislation to outlaw strikes at missile bases and other strategic defense installations.

People of the Left, Right and Center wanted to know, in accents of anguished reproach, how free-born Britons could be arrested for expressing their views in the traditional home of free speech and free assembly.

Remaining single tickets for all New York Philharmonic subscription concerts in the forthcoming season will go on sale this morning at the Carnegie Hall box office, 154 West Fifty-seventh Street. Mail orders for single tickets will also be filled by the box office beginning today.

THE Washington social season is about to be off and whirling like a dervish, and with its bustle comes the frantic cry for long white kid gloves and full-length evening gowns -- a cry familiar to Julius Garfinckel Co. and one that the store is always ready to answer.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Warren Spahn of the Milwaukee Braves became the fourth pitcher in major league history today to win twenty or more games in twelve seasons. He beat the Chicago Cubs, 8 -- 0, on two hits in the first game of a double-header.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Sir Leslie Munro, President of the 1957 General Assembly, urged today that all past Assembly Presidents hold "an immediate conference" to advise the United Nations on the choice of a new Secretary General.
Arnold Toynbee, writing in the Oct. 2 issue of Christianity and Crisis, declares that the plurality of religions is "a boon for mankind."

ROME, Sept. 24 -- The Christian Democratic Premier, Amintore Fanfani, and his Government gained new life today when the Democratic Socialist party decided to continue supporting him at least until December.

The newly formed National Assembly for Democratic Rights recessed yesterday on a note of rejoicing at the sight of "representatives of the Christian Church and the Communist party on one platform ready to work for the freedom of all in the United States."
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Billy Casper Jr. of Apple Valley, Calif., shot a five-under-par-67 today and won the $25,000 Portland open golf tournament for the third consecutive year.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals beat the Los Angeles Dodgers today, 8 -- 7.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 24 -Eddie Sachs of Allentown, Pa., won his third straight 100-mile championship auto race today in the world-record time of 59 minutes 23.89 seconds.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- One reason, perhaps, that the French so venerate logic is that they so rarely practice it. This paradox is blatantly evident in the plots of the Secret Army Organization, or O.A.S., that seeks to overthrow de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Some 120,000 reservists who have been summoned to active duty next month will be ready for combat in half the time that was needed to prepare such units for the Korean war, the Army said today.

The Greyhound Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to acquire control of the Boothe Leasing Corporation, San Francisco, through an exchange of stock. Boothe leases heavy equipment to industry.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Paul Hornung served notice today that he was ready to defend his National Football League scoring championship. He scored a touchdown, three extra points and three field goals to lead the Green Bay Packers to a 30-10 rout of the San Francisco Forty-Niners.

The bill that would reduce the tax impact of the court-ordered distribution by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., of its General Motors Corporation stock renewed its tenuous lease on life last Saturday when the Senate found it impossible to adjourn as hoped.

Attrition followed by negotiations set in at the six-day bike race at Madison Square Garden yesterday. As a result, the regular practice of making up new teams from halves of old ones went into effect early last night.

HAVANA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Cuban Government announced today thearrest of a dozen counter-revolutionaries accused of plotting to kill Premier Fidel Castro with bazookas and hand grenades supplied by the Central Intelligence Agency of the United States.

A sweeping reorganization of its top echelon was announced over the week-end by the embattled Ladies' Home Journal. The Journal is engaged in a bitter competitive struggle with fast-rising McCall's magazine.
Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market backed and filled during the early part of last week, but then softened to close lower.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Johnny Robinson sprinted 13 yards for a touch-down with 1 minute 55 seconds remaining today as the Dallas Texans scored a 42-35 victory over the Oakland Raiders in an American Football League game before 6,900.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A fairly steady but thin demand held the grain futures market on a generally firm trend last week, and most contracts finished with moderate gains.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles clinched third place in the American League today with a 5-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox after dropping the first game of a double-header, 8 -- 7.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Jim Martin's 49-yard field goal, his third of the game, brought the Detroit Lions a 16-15 victory today in a fierce battle of defenses with the Baltimore Colts of the National Football League before a crowd of 54,259.
Trading in the foreign exchange market was quiet during the past week. British pound sterling and the Canadian dollar showed only minor changes in price.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 24 -Internationals generally lost ground last week, reflecting the political uncertainties and the committent reserve of investors. The general stock index fell to 393 from 397.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission accused Carter Products, Inc., today of using false shaving lather in television advertising to promote the sale of Rise lather and to disparage competing products.
ALGIERS, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- A veteran French Army officer died today of wounds received in a bomb attack. Two Moslem rebel leaders were killed by he police.

A MAN well known in British fashion plans to bring an international flavor to Delman shoes. Edward Rayne, new president of the shoe concern, will capitalize on the best talents available throughout the world by establishing design studios for Delman in Paris, Milan, London and New York.

IN Saturday afternoon's, presentation of "The Sleeping Beauty" at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Leningrad Kirov Ballet showed us the sixth ballerina of its current season. This was Ninel Kurgapkina who was not scheduled for the role here, but who stepped into it at a day's notice when Irina Kolpakova hurt a foot.
A Presbyterian minister appealed yesterday for faith in man's ability to rise above his troubles with divine help.
Scenes from Shakespeare will be given Oct. 4 in the White House. The occasion will be the state dinner at which Ibrahim Abboud, President of the Sudan, will be guest of honor.
Significant details have been ironed out to accelerate the formation of "Blood and Thunder," a musical designed for Mary Martin.

Stephen C. Cheng gave a vocal recital in Judson Hall yesterday afternoon, with Emanuel Balaban at the piano. The concert was sponsored by the China Society of America. Mr. Cheng has made previous appearances in this area in Broadway shows and on television, but this was his formal local concert debut.

A leading topic of conversation these days among those interested in New York politics is "the new Wagner." There is wide agreement that the Mayor has been acting like a new man for the last several months, but there is a great divergence of opinion as to whether the apparent change is permanent or temporary.
GENEVA, Sept. 24 -- The Swiss stock markets moved sluggishly within narrow limits last week and domestic issues closed mixed with only small net changes for the most part.
The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers will hold its sixty-ninth annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Nov. 16 to Nov. 18.

VIENNA, Sept. 24 -- Despite a certain amount of official optimism, there was a strong undercurrent of worry at the five-day world monetary meeting here last week about the financial stability of the Western World.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Democratic National Chairman John M. Bailey accused his Republican counterpart today of irresponsibility.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 24 -- The appointment of Dr. John Whitney Hall as the first Alfred Whitney Griswold Professor of History at Yale University was announced today.

VIENNA, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Soviet musclemen swept four titles in the world weight-lifting championships, which ended today, and gained the team title. The United States won only one title but finished second in the five-day meet.

CAIRO, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic demanded today an investigation by the United Nations into the plane crash that killed Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

DALLAS, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Power running by two rookies, Don Perkins and Amos Marsh, augmented by the spectacular defensive saves of Dick Moegle and Bob Bercich, figured in the Dallas Cowboys' 21-7 National Football League victory over the Minnesota Vikings today.
The New York Central cleared $2,035,976, or 31 cents a share, in August, it was announced over the week-end. This compared with a net loss of $2,636,463 in the corresponding month of last year.
The first major shopping center in Huntington, L.I., containing thirty stores, a bank, a motion picture theatre and parking for 2,000 cars, is nearing completion.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 24 -- The regional tournament of the New York-New Jersey Bridge Conference, played here over this weekend, set at least one regional attendance record and posed one knotty problem for the directors and lawmakers of tournament bridge.
Paul Huddleston gave a song recital last night at Town Hall that consisted of nothing but Liszt.

KOLWEZI, the Congo, Sept. 25 -- The second most celebrated man in Katanga today -- second to President Moise Tshombe -- is a white flier whose bombing and strafing shifted the balance in the recent fighting in the seceding province.

Senator Estes Kefauver charged yesterday that electrical manufacturing companies were trying to discourage municipalities from suing for treble damages for price-rigging for which they were convicted in February.
Trading in commodity futures on the New York exchanges yesterday followed Friday's pattern of moderately increased volumes and general price declines.

WHAT to do about the belles of St. Trinian's, that hairy swarm of English boarding-school girls Frank Launder and Sidney Gilliat had the temerity to set loose upon the screen, appears to have become more of a problem for their harassed scenarists than it is for the make-believe British school authorities who are supposed to be staggered by them.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- The new director of the new Deutsche Oper Berlin unveiled his first production tonight. Gustav Rudolf Sellner, who succeeds Carl Ebert, staged the world premiere of "Alkmene," composed in the twelve-tone idiom by Giselher Klebe.
President Kennedy's speech was broadcast live all over the world by United Nations radio and the Voice of America.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The State Department praised today the late Sumner Welles as a founder of the United Nations and an architect of the Good Neighbor policy toward Latin America.

A biography of the late Secretary General of the United Nations, Dag Hammarskjold, which Doubleday had planned for publication next year, will now be issued Nov. 16. Called "Dag Hammarskjold: Custodian of the Brushfire Peace," the book is the work of Joseph Lash, editorial writer and columnist of The New York Post.

Although street games -- from marbles to skipping rope to punch ball -- have almost disappeared for children on the bumper-to-bumper blocks of New York, it is some small consolation to know that grown-ups are using the same places for their own games. One is called Standing. Another, Double Parking. Then there is Beating the Meter.
The Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange has suspended Rule 355, which requires approval by the Exchange of private wire connections between members and non-members.

The Avco Corporation had a 20 per cent increase in earnings in the nine months ended on Aug. 31 despite a 3 per cent decline in sales, it was disclosed yesterday at a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

Harry Wismer and Sammy Baugh, who have spoken only through intermediaries this season, are scheduled to meet face to face tomorrow afternoon to try to resolve their dispute.
Representative Paul A. Fino was re-elected Republican leader of the Bronx last night and won the support of the county committee for new rules to provide for direct election of district leaders.

MARY McCARTHY writes with an air of cool, friendly violence. Whether she is contemplating the gaudy follies of the passing show or the battered state of the eternal verities, her opinions are delivered brilliantly in a forceful style. Few contemporary authors match her wit and clarity.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -The President's style in his address before the General Assembly won praise today from Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister.
BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- The United States Air Force is confident it can supply West Berlin by an airlift if the Communists blockade the land access routes.

A look into the future of business and industry was offered to top executives yesterday at the New York Coliseum. Visitors at the opening of the Industrial Building Exposition and Congress saw new construction methods, new telephones, models of employe recreational parks to adjoin plants, and pastel-colored factories.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -The feed grains were under fairly heavy selling pressure most of the time today on the Board of Trade, and losses ran to more than a cent a bushel. The futures market for other grains and soybeans was steady to firm.
Patronesses for the Christian Dior-New York luncheon and fashion show next Monday afternoon at the Astor have been announced. The event is a benefit for the Police Athletic League (P.A.L.).

MADRID, Sept. 25 -- Yesterday afternoon in the Plaza de Toros, before a sellout crowd of 23,000, a novice bullfighter named Antonio (Orteguita) Ortega broke down and wept when he was unable to kill his bull promptly.
A THREAD of tender sentiment runs through "The Opening of a Window." Its honesty knits a loosely written play into a semblance of dramatic concentration.

THE team-of-four contest in the New York-New Jersey Bridge Conference regional tournament last week-end was won by Samuel M. Stayman, Victor Mitchell and Philip Feldesman of New York and David Strasberg of Levittown, N.J.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 25 -- Southern Governors joined today in a display of national unity reflecting the region's concern over world affairs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- When the front-running Reds planed in from Cincinnati early tonight, they were in the luxurious position of not caring whether the Dodgers were playing at Pittsburgh or even how the runners-up were making out.

AN auditorium with pearl gray walls, antique gold velveteen folding chairs and a seating capacity of 200 persons may not sound as if it belongs in a beauty salon. At Helena Rubinstein's, this "Little Theater," as it is called, will house one of the most important functions of her salon.

The Missouri-Illinois Metropolitan District reportedly received a single bid yesterday on its proposed issue of $5,900,000 of grain elevator bonds. Cruttenden Podesta Co. submitted the bid, but the price was not announced and no announcement of an award of the issue is expected until Thursday.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 25 -- Nassau County refused today to withdraw its opposition to the Navy's plans to occupy 127 housing units at Mitchel Field.

Now that the nation's schools are open again the administrative and policy-making outlook for our local public schools may still appear a bit clouded. It must not be forgotten, however, that even before the sun breaks through full force classroom teachings have been going on as usual for our approximately one million children.
The New York Airways helicopter airline yesterday received the first of five turbine-powered helicopters it is acquiring.
City and state welfare officials have taken action to hasten the return to Puerto Rico of families who come to New York and go on relief but make no attempt to find work.

A merger of the Metal and Thermit Corporation and the Udylite Corporation has been proposed by the boards of directors of both companies. The plan is subject to the approval of the stockholders of both concerns at meetings on dates to be announced.
NEWARK, Sept. 25 -- The New Jersey branches of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor joined the ranks of the merged labor federation today.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Two army officers, recently sentenced to prison for their roles in the Paris plotting connected with last April's military mutiny in Algeria, escaped here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Kennedy's speech in the United Nations was enthusiastically applauded on Capitol Hill today, but beneath the public words of praise ran an undertone of Republican reservations.
Mikhail Tal of Latvia took the lead with a score of 10 -- 4 in the fourteenth round of the international chess masters tournament at Bled, according to a report from Yugoslavia yesterday.

IT was during the first all-star game at San Francisco in mid-July that the initial inkling arose concerning the possibility of a National League pennant for the Cincinnati Reds. At that time, the Reds had a five-game lead over the Los Angeles Dodgers. Visiting American Leaguers had begun to wonder if this wasn't something of an optical illusion.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- This little world of diplomats and their staffs demonstrated today that sixteen years of seeing the world's most famous faces had not jaded its enthusiasm for new ones.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Three masked and armed bandits held up a fashionable jewelry store in Monte Carlo this morning and escaped with an estimated total of $500,000 in jewels.

GENEVA, Sept. 25 -- The seafarers section of the International Federation of Transport Workers voiced support here today for the stand taken by the National Maritime Union of America in its dispute with United States owners of foreign-registered ships.
ONEONTA, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- Governor Rockefeller indicated today that he would support increased education aid for city school districts next year.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 25 -- Sabre, owned and sailed by Ernest B. Fay of Houston, won the first race in a five-race series for the United States 5.5-meter championship today.
DALLAS, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Al Dorow of the New York Titans continues as the top passer in the American Football League, where only two of the top ten throwers have 50 per cent averages.

When the Japanese wish to display musical accomplishments many turn to an instrument whose history goes back twelve centuries. The instrument is the koto, and the place it now occupies in Japanese culture is at least as important as that of the piano in Western life.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Elbert Miller Brooks, his wife and 6-year-old son boarded a Piedmont Airlines plane here yesterday for a short flight to Roanoke, Va.
After seven consecutive months of operating in the red, the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company moved into the black last month.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- The Hampshire C.C. team of Gus Salerno, pro, and Leo Bernson posted a three-stroke victory today in the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association pro-amateur tournament at Fenway G.C.

Dr. Corliss Lamont, author, philosopher and friend of the Soviet Union, acknowledged yesterday that he had been "disillusioned" by the Soviet Government's "inexcusable" resumption of nuclear weapons testing.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Tally-Ho Stable's August Sun, who won the Philadelphia Turf Handicap here as an outside choice, was equally at home over the same course today as the choice of most of the 11.283 fans.
NEWARK, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Ralph Blount, a 17-year-old football player for West Side High School, died last night twenty-four hours after his collapse following a game Saturday.

GOOD business and sweet charity will keep steady company this week. At 6 o'clock this evening, a cocktail party will be given by the French Consul General and Bloomingdale's at the store for the benefit of Entr'aide Francaise, a recently established organization that gives assistance to local residents of French background.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Ministers from the six nations of the European Common Market started a three-day meeting here today to decide the terms for British membership.
HONG KONG, Sept. 25 -- An early reopening of warfare in Laos was forecast today by a leading organ of mainland China's Communist party.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Congress sent to the White House today a bill to make legal dual freight-rate schedules for ocean steamship companies.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 25 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a Government attempt to regulate the prices and the number of pages of Indian daily newspapers was unconstitutional and void.

The Allied Stores Corporation, operator of department, junior department and specialty stores, offered to stockholders yesterday the right to subscribe for $27,006,200 of 4 1/2 per cent twenty-year convertible subordinated debentures.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 -- The officers of the American Hospital Association are preparing a statement on medical care for the aged and will present it to the governing body of the association this week here at its annual conference.
Mayor Wagner appeared last night to have succeeded in forcing an armistice between the old-line and the reform Democratic factions in Manhattan.
Guests will gain admission to a luncheon and fashion show at the Sheraton-East on Oct. 17 by bringing a package of rummage.

The departmental trial of Joseph R. Weiss on nineteen charges of misconduct came to an end yesterday with the suspended Deputy Superintendent of Schools maintaining that he was innocent of wrong doing.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -- A political hubbub arose today over plans to televise Richard M. Nixon's news conference when he is scheduled to announce his decision whether to run for Governor of California in 1962.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- Mongi Slim of Tunisia has decided to resign as President of the General Assembly if he is named temporarily to fill the duties of the late Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 (AP) -- John Orsino, a rookie, smacked two home runs tonight as the San Francisco Giants mustered eighteen hits and beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 10 -- 2.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- The United States offered the General Assembly today a detailed and comprehensive program for "general and complete disarmament in a peaceful world."

Blood will be given to the Red Cross today at the Lever Brothers Company, 390 Park Avenue. Donations also will be made at the J.C. Penney Company, 330 West Thirty-fourth Street; Bonwit Teller, 721 Fifth Avenue, and the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., 40-20 Lawrence Street, Flushing, Queens.
DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- When the United Automobile workers started hard bargaining today for a new labor contract with the Ford Motor Company, they were promptly offered new economic proposals.

Prices of high-grade bonds generally rose slightly yesterday in a quiet market. Dealers in fixed-interest securities were awaiting offerings today of several major municipal issues and the first top-rated corporate bond offering in more than five weeks.

ROME, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz of Kings County Court discussed juvenile crime today with Pope John XXIII. The New York judge is in Europe seeking the views of judges and police officials on the subject.

It's easy to determine the whereabouts of riders in the six-day bike race at Madison Square Garden. One member of each team is on the track while the other is eating, sleeping or walking around inside or near the Garden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- United States fall-out experts said today the Soviet Union may have put as much radioactive pollution into the atmosphere in the first three weeks of its 1961 tests as it did in five weeks of extremely heavy testing in the fall of 1958. were in the megaton range, troposphere, the zone closest.

The Missouri Pacific (Mopac) Railroad Company will retire by the end of this year all its outstanding collateral trust 4 1/4 per cent notes due on March 1, 1976, D.B. Jenks, president, announced yesterday.

A three-story building at 231 West Fifty-eighth Street, near the Coliseum, has been purchased by the American Athletic Union as its national headquarters. The group has had rented quarters in the Woolworth Building for twenty years.
Dr. Carroll V. Newsom resigned yesterday as president of New York University.

The Ford Foundation's announcement that it is setting aside $100,000,000 for the support of liberal arts colleges is much more than the start of a generous handout. The significance of these grants is in the manner in which the money is to be given.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- The hard luck that has plagued Carl Willey of the Milwaukee Braves all season nearly reached him again tonight, but he escaped with a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. The smallest crowd ever to see a major league game here, 4,689, watched.
YONKERS, Sept. 25 -- Silver Song, owned by the Mercury Stable of the Bronx, rallied from fifth place tonight and won the $25,000 Jean Laird Trot by a nose before 21,203 at Yonkers Raceway.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 25 -- Edwin G. Michaelian, County Executive of Westchester, was re-elected chairman of the Westchester Republican County Committee at a convention in the County Center tonight.

Eleven retail buildings in as many cities across the country have been purchased by Bruno Low and Anthony Bersani, upstate real estate investors.

School segregation remains a widespread evil in this country although seven years have now passed since the Supreme Court's historic decision declaring such segregation unconstitutional. The number of new school districts annually integrating their children has dropped sharply in the last two years as compared with the number complying annually in earlier years subsequent to the Supreme Court decision.

American Airlines announced yesterday a move to eliminate the differences in air freight charges on thousands of items -- from nuts and bolts to pharmaceuticals -- by substituting a single rate for almost all commodities.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Bob Shaw of the Athletics defeated the Detroit Tigers, 6 -- 3, in the second game of a doubleheader tonight on a three-hitter.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 4 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Prices of General Motors' new medium-sized Chevy II will range from $1,973 to $2,464, f.o.b. Detroit. The $1,973 price, which is for the lowest series of four-cylinder two-door sedan, is about $11 more than for the company's small Convair and $310 below the bottom of the full-sized Chevrolet line.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Former Premier Pierre Mendes-France warned today that France was threatened by civil war. He proposed a brief transitional regime to ward off the threat.
Paul Knopf, a pianist and composer, offered a program of his works for jazz sextet and jazz trio last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Meredith Willson is working on his next Broadway musical, "The Understudy," for which he will serve as librettist, lyricist and composer.
