The sponsor of a show about the American Negro that has aroused resentment and threats of boycott in the South has announced intentions to continue the presentation of television documentaries without exercising censorship.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Industrial shares turned dull in the stock market here today after a bright start and net movements were mostly downward.

The merger of New Jersey units of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations brings to a successful end the long campaign of the parent federation to establish unity in all its state affiliates. Even though the task took nearly six years, its accomplishment is a welcome step toward eliminating the conflicts in representation and policy that have done so much to weaken labor's voice in legislative and community affairs.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The board of directors of Ralston Purina Company proposed today a 2-for-1 split of the common stock, subject to stockholders' approval on Dec. 15.
The Camelot has joined the growing list of cabarets swinging to revues without highly ranked and highly paid stars.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Harold L. Price was appointed director of regulation for the Atomic Energy Commission today.
The Housing and Redevelopment Board is trying to work out a program with the city's banks to have them provide low-interest loans for down payments on middle-income cooperative apartments.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Sept. 25 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower commended President Kennedy's United Nations speech today. He said he believed "it summed up eloquently the peaceful aims of the American people."
Six of the eight major league baseball teams that completed their home schedules last week suffered attendance declines during the season.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 25 -- At intervals of a second or two, the switch was closed and a brilliant blue-white light spurted from the engine's nozzle.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 25 -- French and Belgian public-utility officials signed contracts here today for a nuclear-fueled, 240,000-kilowatt electricity plant to be built under the joint program of the European Atomic Energy Community and the United States.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 -- The Ford Motor Company offered the United Automobile Workers a set of economic proposals today. They closely paralleled terms of the union's recent settlement with the General Motors Corporation.
A story of ancient Peru, fashioned of collectors' art objects and running several thousand years to the Spanish Conquest, was unfolded yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Treasury bill rates moved slightly, in opposite directions, on today's sale of the regular weekly issues. The ninety-one-day bill rate eased for the third consecutive week, while the 182-day rate rose.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Al Lopez signed today to manage the Chicago White Sox for another year. Lopez, who is completing one of the worst seasons of his managerial career, reportedly will receive close to $50,000.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, floored by a left hook to the midsection near the end of the eighth round, hung on tonight for a split decision over the Canadian middleweight champion. Wilf Greaves.

The September total of draftees in the Greater New York area is expected to reach 2,000, about 50 per cent greater than that in August, the Army Recruiting and Induction Headquarters, 39 Whitehall Street, reported yesterday.

Mrs. Helen Sobell picketed the United Nations yesterday with a sign urging that her husband, Morton, be freed from prison. He was sentenced in 1951 to a thirty-year term after having been convicted with the late Julius and Ethel Rosenberg of conspiracy to commit espionage.
Steel production last week increased to the highest point in nearly seventeen months.

UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 25 -- Enthusiasm for President Kennedy's address was reflected today by warm applause and by words of praise from Western countries and from a number of Asian and African neutrals.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 25 -- Recent events have placed a harsh strain on West Germany's confidence in the word of the United States.

TOKYO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado of Cuba vowed in Peiping today that Premier Fidel Castro's regime would recover the United States military base at Guantanamo "through a resolute and tenacious prolonged struggle."

Cicada of the Meadow Stable just made it in the $30,200 Astarita Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The 23,478 fans had made this daughter of Bryan G. the odds-on favorite in the race for 2-year-old fillies, and she scored by a head over E. Barry Ryan's Firm Policy.
Three bar groups have registered opposition to the nomination of Irving Ben Cooper, retired Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions, to be a Federal distinct judge.

AUGSBURG, Germany, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A German court turned down today a request by Siegfried Naujocks that two United States Congressmen and the United States Secretary of the Army be called in his defense.

IMPORT originals geared to American sizes and moderate prices hold the same lure for the very young as they do for grown-ups. A woman who should know is Rose Finkel, merchandise manager for Gimbels Children's World.

Curtis H. Bingham, president of Bingham, Walter Hurry, Inc., Los Angeles, has been nominated for president of the Investment Bankers Association of America to succeed George A. Newton, partner in the St. Louis investment banking house of G.H. Walker Co.
LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Ghana has accepted more aid for her vast Volta River project, this time from the Soviet Union.
Beginning Sunday customers of the New York Telephone Company in southern Westchester County and Nassau County will have to dial area code 212 before dialing numbers in New York City.

THERE is a man somewhere in California with a problem. He has a surplus of gophers. Evidently they must be driving him close to the brink of utter distraction, for he appealed to his father, William E. Pennington of Bellerose, L.I., who turned to this department for help.
A design specialist declares that commuter railroads can ease their financial strain and improve their passenger stations by providing commercial and office space in suburban railroad depots.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- The stars and other figures who live near Hollywood's Sunset Strip have become the most fall-out proof citizens of Southern California with the opening of a fully equipped mass shelter.
BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- A Swiss brokerage firm is offering West German and foreign buyers a new investment fund consisting solely of West Berlin stocks, it was disclosed today.

Two films will have their local premieres today. "The Hustler," a drama produced and directed by Robert Rossen for Twentieth Century-Fox presentation, is the newcomer at the Paramount Theatre, Broadway and Forty-third Street, and at the Seventy-second Street Playhouse on East Seventy-second Street.

SINCE George Bernard Shaw's "Misalliance" is nothing but talk, talk, talk, an open stage production does it no harm at all. In fact, the revival last night at the Sheridan Square Playhouse does it rather proud.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Net new orders from abroad for machine tools, which have been increasing in recent months, fell in August for the second consecutive month. By way of contrast, domestic orders, which have been dropping almost steadily, rose with sufficient strength to put the total ahead of the month before.

Dilbert's Quality Supermarkets had a net loss of $596,000 in the six months ended on July 1, not a net profit of that amount, as reported in this newspaper last Saturday. The report was based on incorrect information in Standard Corporation Records, a statistical publication of Standard Poor's Corporation.
The troubled affairs of Southeast Asia were discussed for an hour yesterday afternoon by President Kennedy and a leading neutralist from the area, Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 25 (AP) -- A Federal official told the nation's port executives today that they must step up the preparedness planning for their harbors.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz declared last night that the operation of city government would continue "in the Tammany tradition" until the Nov. 7 election despite Mayor Wagner's break with the Democratic party bosses.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- This "strange world, poised between hope and despair," as Prime Minister Macmillan described it, was shown an example of political constancy today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that 1,113,577 running bales of cotton from this year's crop had been ginned through Sept. 15. This compared with 1,918,143 bales a year earlier.

AT the salon of Georges Kaplan, where mink is pronounced "meenk" and you can buy anything from a classic "meenk" coat to a floor-sweeping hooded robe of nutria, surprises never cease. Georges Kaplan and his designer son, Jacques, are both French and love to be different.
Mayor Wagner asked the Board of Elections yesterday to set an extra day for registration, which falls this year on Oct. 12, 13 and 14.

TELEVISED education in in the early morning hours resumed yesterday on a broader scale than ever. A new series, "College of the Air," began over the Columbia Broadcasting System, while "Continental Classroom" continued its pioneering ways over the facilities of the National Broadcasting Company.
RUTLAND, Vt., Sept. 25 (AP) -- A long, bitter wage dispute has culminated in the Rutland Railway's second strike within a year.
The city's new Board of Education, which elected a president and a vice president at its first meeting on Saturday, may have to hold another election to make it official.
The New York Yankees, who open a two-game series against the Baltimore Orioles at the Stadium tonight, received some unhappy news yesterday.
The first major revision of New York City's Building Code since 1937 was ordered yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The process is expected to take three years and cost $800,000.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Gary Geiger's two-run pinch triple enabled Boston to defeat Chicago, 7 -- 5, for a double-header split today.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The heart of Cincinnati's downtown area was jammed tonight by a seething, howling mass of people celebrating the Reds' first National League pennant since 1940.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Consumer Price Index declined slightly in August, principally because of the normal summertime reduction in food prices. It has declined in six of the last ten Augusts, including this one.

FOR the discerning, Maximilian showed its fall collection yesterday, in which fur was manipulated as deftly as if it were cloth. All of the important silhouettes were there ands few new ones, too. The subtly fitted coat, flattened in front; the gently flared hem; fur lining fur, banding fur or combined with sheared versions of the original, all were part of this fine collection.
An influx of buyers, order books at the ready, is bringing smiles to the faces of apparel manufacturers here.
Public School 119 in Harlem, which figured in last spring's highly publicized rat incident, found itself the center of attention again yesterday.
Of the millions of New Yorkers who live in apartment houses and work in office buildings, only a few thousand have any sort of protection against radioactive fall-out in the event of nuclear attack.
An officer of the Housing and Home Finance Agency said yesterday that the Kennedy Administration was trying to speed the nation's urban renewal program.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- The Netherlands offered today to give up all control over Netherlands New Guinea and put the disputed territory under United Nations jurisdiction.
Major party candidates for Mayor came under attack yesterday from independent opponents, who accused them of not sticking to the job and not talking up on city issues.
The Non-Partisan party announced yesterday that it had swung its support to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz for Mayor.

For perhaps an hour yesterday the market on the New York Stock Exchange put on a brilliant technical rally and wiped out more than a third of Monday's losses. Thereafter the momentum was lost. Stocks began to fall at accelerating rates.
FROM Cape Cod comes news that the work of reclaiming fish ponds there goes on under a program started several years ago.
The Cincinnati Reds won their first National League pennant in twenty-one years yesterday and earned the right to play the New York Yankees in the 1961 world series.

Massachusetts Investors Growth Stock Fund ended its third fiscal quarter on Aug. 31 with highs in net assets, share value, and number of shareholders. During the twelve months, net assets soared 44.5 per cent, nad the share value rose 24.6 per cent.

GENEVA, Sept. 26 -- Communist China said today that President Kennedy's speech to the United Nations yesterday had shown "total disregard" for the United States' responsibility for the situation in Laos.

The first winner of the newly established Gregor Piatigorsky Biennial Award of the Violoncello Society made his New York debut in Carnegie Hall last night. His name is Douglas Davis, he is 20 years old and he comes from Los Angeles.
ALOT of Mr. Kenneth's clients are maintaining that he makes them look "sort of Japanese these days."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Under Secretary of State Chester Bowles appealed to Maryland editors and publishers today to back a campaign to abolish segregation in restaurants and other public places throughout the state.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that one of his major goals was to make New York the first big city of the world without slums.
What is developing into the best off-Broadway show in town is being avoided more than attended. And it's only a block off Broadway.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- The Soviet Union accented today the positive and moderate aspects of President Kennedy's speech yesterday before the United Nations General Assembly.

The Yankees yesterday "declined with thanks" the city's offer of a ticker-tape parade in honor of their twenty-sixth American League pennant. They suggested that, should they win the world series, the reception be held for them next spring after their training season.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 15 cents a bale up to 25 cents off yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26 -- Economic planners from twenty-one countries met here today to discuss ways to speed economic growth in non-Communist Asia.

THE Greek Tragedy Theatre which gave us Sophocles' "Electra" last week, brought more classics to the City Center last night. The company presented the last two parts of Aeschylus' "Oresteia" trilogy, "Choephori" and "Eumenides."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -The Government's pronounced aim of encouraging collective bargaining between management and labor is being thwarted by the National Labor Relations Board, a House subcommittee said today.
One step ahead of history -- not two.
The appointment of John J. Foley as executive director of the Police Athletic League was announced yesterday. He will take over his new duties next Sunday.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- Authorities in Iran were reported today to have arrested Mullah Mustafa al Barzani, accused of leading a Kurdish revolt in Northern Iraq. It was said the prisoner would be handed over to the Iraqis.

Directors of the American-Marietta Company declared a special dividend yesterday of 17 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Oct. 9 to holders of record of Sept. 29. The dividend is based on the expected merger of the company and the Martin Company next month.
ALGIERS, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- A British consular official was killed by a terrorist here today following violent anti-Government demonstrations last night.
Mayor Wagner pledged last night to intensify his campaign for a higher state minimum wage and to use the city's purchasing power to improve working conditions here.

Joseph Monserrat, director of the New York office of the Puerto Rican migration division, will confer next week with City Welfare Commissioner James P. Dumpson about the problem of Puerto Rican migrants who are on relief but who are not eligible for such aid under state law.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Though retarded in its development by a multiplicity of sprains, bruises, fractures and virus infections the Army football team is expected to be in fairly good shape for its game here Saturday with Boston University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The United States Conference of Mayors announced today the names of twenty-three mayors who would make a goodwill visit to West Berlin to underscore American commitments to that city.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26 (AP) -- President Kennedy signed today an amendment aimed at correcting inequities of a 1954 law called the Alger Hiss Act.
NEWPORT, Sept. 26 -- President Kennedy began his vacation here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- President Kennedy signed today a controversial immigration bill making it more difficult for aliens ordered deported to appeal to the courts. There was an immediate request for a change in administrative procedures of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to soften its impact.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Somewhere back in the hills or underbrush there may be a man, woman or child who publicly, before the season opened, picked the Cincinnati Reds to win the National League pennant.

In his U.N. speech the President apparently sought to extend the time limit in which to negotiate a settlement of the present crisis and also to broaden the scope of such a negotiation. Berlin was placed within the context of wider and ultimately far more important things -- the fate of Germany itself, disarmament and the governance of outer space.
President Kennedy and President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina spent four hours together yesterday in what was described as a "frank and blunt" discussion of political and economic problems.

NAZARETH, Israel, Sept. 25 -- Abdul Aziz Zubi, 35-year-old Deputy Mayor of Nazareth, expressed fear today that the rancor and bitter demonstrations of the last week had set the Arabs and Jews of Israel back thirteen years in their relations with each other.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell arrived at his office today under police guard.

TRENTON, Sept. 26 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner charged today that James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, was doing the public a "disfavor" in refusing to debate campaign issues with Richard J. Hughes, his Democratic opponent.
AUGSBURG, Germany, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- A Bavarian district court convicted a German reporter today on three counts of criminally slandering Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker.

THERE'S one thing that can always be said for Dick Powell; he's a pro. And it showed last night in the style and polish that he brought to the whodunit that served as the premiere vehicle of his new anthology series over Channel 4.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Grain futures prices ranged broadly today in active dealings on the Board of Trade. Corn slid to its lowest levels of the season and most wheat contracts were within fractions of season highs when they turned sharply downward to finish with a loss.

A series of eight Sunday concerts, concentrating on music of the eighteenth and twentieth centuries, will be presented at the New School for Social Research in the coming season under the musical direction of Alexander Schneider.

Representatives of Roosevelt Raceway conferred yesterday with William Zeckendorf Sr., president of Webb Knapp, Inc., in negotiations that could lead to sale of controlling interest in the track to the real estate firm.
VIENNA, Sept. 26 -- The fifth general conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency began today with little prospect of bridging the differences between the Western and Soviet governments.
Twenty-two Brooklyn savings banks are planning to establish a common automation service center, it was announced yesterday during the annual meeting of the Group V Savings Banks Trustees.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics reached Ran Nischwitz for six runs in the first three innings tonight and then coasted to an 8 -- 5 victory over the Detroit Tigers. Nischwitz, who was making his major league debut as a starter, was plagued by wildness.
Alfredo Salmaggi, the opera impresario, was found guilty and given a suspended sentence yesterday for having failed to obtain a theatrical license for the use of Triborough Stadium this last summer.

A total of 1,031 persons were injured in 745 auto accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was an increase of seventy-five over the 956 hurt in the same period in 1960.

The 890,000-square-foot Walt Whitman Shopping Center at Huntington, L.I., is now 75 per cent rented, according to the Winston-Muss Corporation, which owns and manages the center through subsidiaries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Officials of the Department of Commerce continue to show concern about a lag in spending by consumers, who have done little to promote the economic recovery.
A REVUE that derives from the art of improvisation can be subject to the ills that revues prepared by calculating experts are heir to: the difficulty of keeping an entire evening lively.
The city's Department of Marine and Aviation yesterday announced the first step in the redevelopment of the waterfront at West Forty-second Street into a modern center for sight-seeing craft.
Robert G. Lindsay, the Richmond County manager of Mayor Wagner's successful bid for the Democratic nomination, was elected last night as the county's Democratic chairman.

USUMBURA, Ruanda-Urundi, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- With more than half the votes counted, the general election and plebiscite in Ruanda showed an overwhelming majority against the return of King Kigeri V today.
Wall Street is showing signs of becoming increasingly concerned about "corporate images" and other such esoteric concepts more readily associated with Madison Avenue.
Roger Maris last night became the first major league baseball player to hit sixty home runs in a championship season since Babe Ruth achieved that record total in 1927.
Samuel D. Leidesdorf, philanthropist and accountant, was honored last night when he was named recipient of the Frank H. Lahey Award for "outstanding service to medical education."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The Yugoslav Foreign Minister reproved the Soviet Union today for renewing nuclear tests.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- Richard M. Nixon is scheduled to unveil tomorrow night the best-kept political secret in a long time: Whether he will run for Governor of California next year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk conferred today with the foreign ministers of four countries. He intends to talk with as many as possible of the sixty-two foreign ministers now scheduled to attend the General Assembly session.

The Bethlehem Steel Company, Monti Marine Corporation and Maine Ship Repair Company were the apparent low bidders when the Navy opened bids here yesterday on the reactivation of three tankers now in lay-up.

Paperboard production climbed to a record 350,512 tons in the week ended on last Saturday from the previous high of 347,649 tons reached in the preceding week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year ago 321,633 tons were produced.

The Georgia State School Building Authority sold $31,452,000 of revenue bonds yesterday to an investment banking group led by Blyth Co. and Robinson-Humphrey Company, Inc., Atlanta, Ga., at a net interest cost of 3.57431 per cent.

PALERMO, Sicily, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Known losses in a rash of major art thefts since early summer neared $6,000,000 today with a Sicilian nobleman disclosed as the sixth victim. His prizes went the mysterious way of treasures in the United States, Britain and France.

Ernest Angell, chairman of the board of directors of the American Civil Liberties Union, announced yesterday the election of Francis Biddle of Washington as chairman of the union's national committee, an advisory body.
Agrarian reform and "accelerated industrialization" are the chief tasks facing Algeria when it becomes independent, a nationalist spokesman said yesterday.

Charles Erwin Wilson was not the nation's greatest Secretary of Defense. The political demands of the job were unsuited to his blunt, business-tycoon manner. He was in frequent conflict with Congress, and he was awkward in handling interservice rivalries and maladroit in explaining his views and actions to the public.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates eliminated the Los Angeles Dodgers from the National League pennant race tonight with an 8-0 victory behind Joe Gibbon's one-hit pitching.

The Eighty-seventh Congress, meeting in a year that cried for new dimensions in statesmanship, has responded with something less than greatness. It was strong in coupling a resolute military program with improved means for peaceful international cooperation. It was weak in its failure to recognize that better schools, full employment and the repair of the internal flaws in our democracy are equally required for national security.
Mayor Wagner defended his traffic policy yesterday by asserting that his administration had done more to speed traffic flow than any other administration in the city's history.

The price of branded gasoline supplied to Midwest markets by mid-continent refiners has been cut about one-half cent a gallon as a result of broker sales of unbranded gasoline and continuing retail price wars.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- The Soviet Union sought tonight to bypass the office of Secretary General through the appointment of four Under Secretaries. One of the Under Secretaries would be elected chairman by the others and function as the executive head of the United Nations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- President Kennedy's speech and performance at the United Nations were well received, but he did not remove the confusion here over Berlin and Germany.

A plan designed to avoid a veto in the selection of a successor to the late Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, was proposed yesterday by Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, the Philippine Ambassador.
Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosch, president of Barnard College, will deliver the convocation address when Barnard begins its seventy-third year tomorrow.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 26 -- The European Economic Community invited Britain today to negotiate on the terms of its proposed adherence to the six-nation trade bloc.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26 -- President Kennedy named four members of the newly created five-man Federal Maritime Commission today.

RECENT publication here of a hand in which declarer did not have to rectify the count to execute a squeeze brought forth some letters that said, "When you do rectify the count, how do you do it -- and why?"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that this year's cotton crop -- like four out of the previous five -- will be smaller than the demands from domestic and foreign markets.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 26 -- Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien said today that President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province wanted to send a delegation to talk with members of the Congo's Central Government in Leopoldville. President Tshombe was unavailable for comment tonight.
President Kennedy signed legislation yesterday creating a disarmament agency. He immediately appointed William C. Foster, a Republican and former foreign aid official, as its first director.

THE Philharmonic is back in town. The opening program of the orchestra's 120th season took place last night at Carnegie Hail; it was a Pension Fund concert under the direction of Leonard Bernstein, with Eileen Farrell as the soprano soloist.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- President Kennedy was credited today by Senator Hubert Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, with having recouped in his address to the United Nations some United States prestige losses on Cuba and Laos.

The Missionary Sisters of St. Augustine have bought the four-story building on lot 22.6 by 100 feet at 435 West Forty-seventh Street from Anna M. Ehrenberg and Dorothea P. Meder. The Roman Catholic missions order has owned and occupied the adjoining building at No. 437 for fifty years.

Indian Head Mills, Inc., announced yesterday that it was splitting its common stock two for one. At the same time, James R. Robison, president of the diversified producer of textiles, reported increased sales and earnings for the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 2 compared with those in the 1960 periods.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 -- Lung cancer has become the most common type of malignancy among men in upstate New York, the State Health Department reported today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 26 -- The bodies of Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, and fifteen others who died with him when his plane crashed in Northern Rhodesia last week were flown here from Salisbury, Southern Rhodesia, today for a brief and moving airport ceremony.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 26 -- Joey Adams twenty-three-man variety show is leaving Thailand for Saigon, Vietnam, after having entertained thousands here and in the provinces and almost split the troupe in the effort.

THIS is harvest-thanksgiving time in Israel, for the observance of the week-long Festival of Succoth is under way. The feast symbolizes the gathering of the harvest and the travels of the ancient Israelites from Egypt to the Promised Land. It has been said that the pilgrims' thanksgiving was modeled after the Jewish festival.
NORWOOD, La., Sept. 26 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense under President Dwight D. Eisenhower, died today at his plantation home near here.
MOREHEAD CITY, N.C., Sept. 26 (AP) -- An oil tanker caught fire and exploded here tonight, killing at least one person and injuring at least twenty-one others.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The first session of the Eighty-seventh Congress prepared tonight to adjourn for the year.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The Women's Tri-County Golf Association's team won the first triangular Scotch-play championship at Dellwood today.
LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Members of the historic Pepys family said today they pronounced the name "Pepp-iss," not "Peeps."
DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- Leaders in the automobile industry here mourned the death today of Mr. Wilson. Among them were:
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Sept. 27 -- Congress approved a compromise foreign aid appropriation of $3,914,600,000 yesterday and cleared the way for the adjournment of its longest session in ten years.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- The Cincinnati Reds clinched the 1961 National League pennant today. It took them virtually all day to do it, but what's a day more or less to a club that's been waiting twenty-one years for a league championship?

ARTURO MARELLI works an A eleven-hour day and a sixty-six-hour week. His major interest is a shoe factory in Gallarate, Italy, about twenty miles outside Milan. But Signor Marelli also operates ski lifts at Bormio, an Alpine resort, as well as two hotels and seven shoe stores in other Italian towns.

Major custom smelters yesterday trimmed the price they pay for scrap copper by 1/4 cent a pound, the fifth 1/4-cent cut in two and one-haft weeks.
Representative Charles A. Buckley, Bronx Democratic leader, has called a meeting of the county executive committee for Monday to select a candidate for City Court Justice.
DUNEDIN, Fla., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Sam Snead has been dropped from the Ryder Cup team and replaced by Doug Ford, the Professional Golfers Association of America said tonight.

L'ESPRIT DE FRANCE is the name that Bloomingdale's has given to its storewide presentation of French merchandise. Starting today, the Lexington Avenue store has transformed itself into a veritable Grand Magasin.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 26 -- The Thai Oil Refinery, a Bangkok concern backed by the Shell Oil Company, signed a $35,000,000 contract today for construction of a 40,000-barrel-a-day oil refinery here.
ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Twenty persons were arrested early today in simultaneous narcotics raids at fourteen private homes in western Suffolk County.
Prices of long-term United States Government bonds advanced yesterday by as much as 18/32, in a thin market helped by the success of the Pacific Gas and Electric issue of $60,000,000 of bonds.

Seymour Weiner has been named assistant to the controller of the Airborne Instruments Laboratory division of Cutler-Hammer, Inc.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, told the United Nations today that the question of a German peace treaty, although not "formally" on the agenda, had overshadowed all other issues before the General Assembly.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, said here today that he could not make any guarantees at this time concerning his company's plans for the Philco Corporation.

The prompt endorsement given by former President Eisenhower and other ranking Republicans to President Kennedy's speech before the United Nations was a wholesome reaffirmation of the principle that politics should not obstruct the conduct of foreign affairs in this period of dangerous trial.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Members of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association, who will begin their thirty-sixth annual championship tomorrow, played for the Scotch foursomes title today as a tune-up on the south course at the Westchester Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers has cut its ties with the International Labor Organization, contending the United Nations agency is dominated by leftists.
BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- Six foreigners, including two American students, were sentenced to prison today by a Communist East German court on charges of having tried to smuggle women out of East Berlin.

A second publisher has announced a book on the late Dag Hammarskjold. To be called "Dag Hammarskjold and Crisis Diplomacy," it has been written by Richard I. Miller, former observer of United Nations affairs for the National Education Association.
Trading in the common stock of Harvey Aluminum, Inc., of Torrance, Calif., began yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- President Kennedy became an uncle again today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- A bitter East-West fight developed today in the Security Council over membership applications by Mauritania and Outer Mongolia.
Prices of coffee and copper futures continued their downward trends yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in other commodities was generally dull.

Mrs. Philip Cortney, chairman of the Hope Ball, a benefit for the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University Medical Center, has announced the names of members of the committees for the fete.
The increasing pressure for admission to college may be partly offset next year by a rapid rise in the number of places available in freshman classes.
Despite the determination of the President and the Congress to ignore blackmail with rockets, the West has not yet gained the diplomatic initiative. Hence we cannot negotiate effectively.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Gary Bell, a right-hander, scored his twelfth victory against fifteen defeats today as the Cleveland Indians pounded three Minnesota pitchers for fourteen hits and a 7-2 triumph over the Twins.

Once an assistant press agent on Arthur Cantor's staff, Robert Weiner will join forces with his former employer to introduce "Happy Happy Happy." Devoid of punctuation, the Gertrude Steinish title identifies the song and dance variation of Alan Harrington's novel, "The Revelations of Dr. Modesto" (Knopf).
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that the 15-cent fare would be maintained until at least Jan. 1, 1963, barring unforeseen circumstances.

" Macario," a Mexican-made symbolic film drama, opens today at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, near Twelfth Street. Ignacio Lopez Tarso and Pina Pellicer have leading roles in the Azteca Films release. Roberto Gavaldon directed the film, which is in Spanish with English substitles.
Rose O'Neill, a California filly who had won the Hollywood Oaks in her last stakes victory, romped to a two-length triumph at Belmont yesterday in the mile-and-a-sixteenth Joe H. Palmer Purse.

BERNARD REDER, who is a sculptor, a kind of architect, and an esthetic theorist of something he calls the volumetric principle, is the subject of a one-man show on all three counts opening today at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A drug used to treat tuberculosis has also been found effective in preventing it, the Public Health Service announced today.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Wildcat, the American defender of the International Catamaran Challenge Trophy, began coming apart during the opening leg of her match with England's Hellcat today and once more ended on a towline.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26 -- The Sikhs broke off talks with the Government today on ways to end the six-week-old hunger strike of their political leader, Master Tara Singh.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves themselves of at least a fourth-place tie in the National League today by trouncing the St. Louis Cardinals, 9 -- 2, at County Stadium.

Sales of Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., a leading manufacturer of tractors and combines, showed increases for the quarter and nine months ended on July 31, but earnings declined from the year-earlier levels, the company reported yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- A statement by Mayor Wagner of New York City backing the New York Central Railroad ht a major railroad merger battle was thrown out today by an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner.

LAUGHTER came easily to Porky Oliver. He was the jolly fat man who enjoyed life to the brim. His cheerful disposition made him one of the most popular members not only of the golfing fraternity but of the entire world of sports. That merry laugh has been stilled, though. Cancer claimed him at the age of 46.

As a symbol of the importance he attaches to the American plan for general, complete and controlled disarmament submitted to the United Nations, President Kennedy has promptly signed the law establishing the new Disarmament Agency and charged it in the face of the present world crisis with the task of converting the plan into practical reality.

NEWPORT, R.L., Sept. 26 -- Following is the text of a communique issued at President Kennedy's vacation headquarters here following the President's talks in New York with President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina:
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Britain will not join the European Common Market unless "vital Commonwealth interests" are protected, Duncan Sandys declared today.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, met with executives of the Ford Motor Company today to work out a three-year labor contract.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 26 -- The committee for the Monmouth County Hunt Meet, to be held on Oct. 21 on the Woodland Farm estate of Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell in adjacent Middletown Township, was announced today. Mr. Haskell is president, and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell Jr., treasurer.

A host of New York's socially prominent and a sprinkling of United Nations dignitaries attended the concert last night that opened the 120th season of the New York Philharmonic. It marked the beginning of the orchestra's last season at Carnegie Hall.

BELGRADE, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn and Mikhail Tal of Latvia won adjourned fifteenth-round games tonight and remained tied for first place in the international grand masters chess tournament.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The stock market was gloomy today and prices fell in quiet trading, as much from lack of support as from selling pressure, which was light. Industrial shares were depressed by fears that tomorow's interim statement by the Imperial Chemical Industries would show lower sales and profits.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 26 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano said tonight that West Germany could not underwrite the division of Germany by recognizing the East German Communist regime.
CAIRO, Sept. 26 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser accepted tonight the resignation of Lieut. Col. Abdel Hamid Serraj of Syria as Vice President for Internal Affairs of the United Arab Republic.

Rome, Sept. 26 -- Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz met with a high Italian police official and Rome's chief rabbi today in a round of discussions on new solutions for the problem of juvenile delinquency in the United States in general and in New York in particular.
Robert R. Pauley has been named president of the American Broadcasting Company network.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26 -- Indians warmly welcomed today President Kennedy's new program to speed general and complete disarmament and his appeal to strengthen the United Nations.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 26 -- President Kennedy is expected to name John A. McCone tomorrow as director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

Wrote Horace M. Albright in a letter dated Sept. 5 to The Times: "We shall never have any more and we shall certainly have far less if developments continue to gobble up natural shorelines which a generation ago we all took for granted as being pleasantly available to us whenever we wanted to enjoy them."
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 26 -- The South's failure to exercise selectivity in its bid for new industry was admitted today at the Southern Governors Conference.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26 -- President Kennedy said today that he would increase by 40 per cent the United States' contribution of uranium 235 "for peaceful uses at home and abroad."

DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- Sales of new cars continued at a low daily rate in mid-September, but Ward's Automotive Reports predicted that a buying surge would occur as 1962 models became generally available.
Dalton's Import, a novelty shop at 1604 Broadway near West Forty-ninth Street, may have held its last close-out sale -- until, that is, it really closes.

British Inter-Marque Trophy Day, run by the Long Island Sports Car Association in cooperation with the British Automobile Manufacturers Association last Sunday at Roosevelt Raceway, attracted more than 350 entries and 3,500 spectators.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Somewhere in South Vietnam there is a considerable supply of Metrecal supplied by American taxpayers.
The elections of two officers of Columbia University -- Dr. Grayson Kirk and Dr. Courtney C. Brown -- to the boards of two corporations were announced yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Sabre, owned and sailed by Ernest B. Fay of Houston, Tex., scored a decisive victory in today's second race of the national championship series in the 5.5-Meter Class on Long Island Sound.

The Broadway theatre, despite its obvious faults, is one of the city's principal adornments and we recognize that it must be healthy financially as well as artistically. We are not persuaded, however, that repealing the 5 per cent theatre ticket tax, as the City Council plans to do tomorrow, is a necessary contribution to the theatre's survival, much less to New York's budgetary well-being.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Gene Green hit a home run in the ninth inning tonight and the Washington Senators scored a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Angels. Ted Kluszewski tied the score for the Angels in the eighth with his fifteenth homer.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Western powers gently brushed aside today the vehement Soviet protests against the flight over East Germany by two West German fighter planes two weeks ago.
A disagreement over the sponsor's right to interfere with television programs developed yesterday as executives of four companies testified before Government investigators here.
Following is the text of a statement read by President Kennedy yesterday after he had signed the bill creating a disarmament agency:
NEWARK, Sept. 26 -- Mr. Hughes today advocated "strong" conflict-of-interest legislation to assure "objective and effective" government services.
" My Fair Lady," the most successful musical in Broadway history, is about to be sold to the movies for a record price.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 26 -The injection of "partisan politics" into the nation's welfare problems was decried today by the leadership of the National Conference of Catholic Charities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that his department had canceled six soil bank contracts in Brandon, Colo. He said that they had been part of a scheme to evade a maximum limit on payments for keeping land in a conservation reserve.
THE nation's new director of arms control and disarmament, William Chapman Foster, has a reputation among colleagues as an excellent administrator.
The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway announced yesterday that its net income in August rose to $3,151,368 from $2,289,769 in the comparable year-ago period.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Harry G. Traver, for fifty-eight years a designer and manufacturer of amusement rides, died today at New Rochelle Hospital. His age was 83.

A CHILD'S desire to pick up and examine pieces in a museum exhibit is encouraged in a "please touch" exhibit at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. The exhibit recreates the interior of a Dutch home in New Amsterdam, furnished with seventeenth and eighteenth century objects that children may handle.

A syndicate of realty investors headed by Walter A. Cubita and Arthur A. Herman has purchased the two-story building containing seven stores and eleven offices at 51 to 55 West Burnside Avenue, corner of Grand Avenue, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Senate, without a word of debate, passed and sent to President Kennedy today a bill authorizing the Treasury to assign every taxpayer a number in order to reduce delinquencies.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26 -- The Secretary of the Army pledged here today that any recall of professionally trained medical persons to active duty would be done with efficiency, with the individual in mind.

The Financial General Corporation, one of the largest investment companies in the South, announced yesterday that it had bought a majority interest in the Shenandoah Valley National Bank, Winchester, Va.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Lynn N. Bitner of Rochester, general manager of The Gannett Company, was elected president of the New York State Publishers Association today. The company publishes a chain of newspapers.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 -The Protestant Episcopal Church overwhelmingly recorded today its endorsement of the National Council of Churches.
THE Kohon String Quartet played at Carnegie Recital Hall last night and earned an A-plus for imaginative prograining; the performances get good marks, too, but none near so high.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz pictured himself yesterday as the man to wear the mantle of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.
HAVANA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Cuba has reorganized her army into three main corps as a defense against new invasions, Premier Fidel Castro said last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Eighteen Soviet technicians have been arrested in Guinea for stealing diamonds from Guinean mines, a high administration official said today.
The Selective Service increased its call in New York City this month.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Thirty-nine unions representing about 3,000,000 factory workers rejected today the Government's plea for a "pause" in wage increases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- In the final days of its Administration, President Dwight D. Eisenhower once told his chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission: John, you shouldn't spend so much money fixing up this house.

STEVE ALLEN is a man who has written several very creditable books, plays good fraternity-house piano, feels genuine alarm over the nuclear arms race and can be a bright and perceptive humorist. With such credentials at his disposal one wishes he could overcome his compulsion to be a slapstick clown, most especially after last night.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Bill Mazeroski of the Pirates belted a two-run homer in the last half of the ninth inning tonight as Pittsburgh defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5 -- 3.

Sixteen singers -- six sopranos, five tenors, three baritones and two basses -- will make their Metropolitan Opera debuts during the forthcoming season. Among them will be a singer the Met had previously put in its "unavailable" category because of the labor disputes during the summer.
A popular young Soviet poet has come under severe attack in Moscow for having published a poem denouncing anti-Semitism and hinting that it still existed in the Soviet Union.
The Queens County Criminal Court Building in Kew Gardens, a $21,000,000 headache for ten years, was finally dedicated yesterday.
A contract has been signed for construction of a three-man aluminum submarine capable of descending almost three miles.
Former President Harry S. Truman yesterday was awarded the newly established Thomas Jefferson Award of the National Society of Interior Designers.

Mayor Wagner and his running mates beamed approval at a Brooklyn luncheon yesterday as forty-three builders and real estate men, many of them doing business with the city, pledged more than $25,000 in campaign contributions.

The stage is beckoning Myrna Loy, a popular motion picture star from way back, whose fans have been augmented through her pictures on television's "The Late Show." She has agreed to star in "There Must Be a Pony!" and is awaiting the outcome of negotiations with producer Alan Pakula.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- An association of motion picture film delivery concerns and two Chicago Teamsters Union officials were indicated today by a Federal grand jury. They were charged with seventy-four counts of conspiracy to violate the Taft-Hartley Law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The Defense Department is taking definite steps to cut down on the dissemination of intelligence information and defense data on new weapons, a Government official said today.

Eleven games that had been adjourned from the thirteenth, fourteenth and fifteenth rounds of the international grand masters chess tournament were played off, according to a report from Yugoslavia yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- A thirteen-acre excavation on Boston Common, where British troops drilled during the tense days before the American Revolution, is being considered for use as a bomb shelter in these tense days of the Berlin crisis.

NAMONE, Laos, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The three contending Laotian princes will meet within the next two weeks to choose a coalition Premier for this divided Kingdom. Their representatives agreed on the meeting here today.
Montgomery Ward Co. plans to enter the discount store field by merging with Interstate Department Stores, Inc.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A crowd of 13,417 made the entry of Decade and Social Relations their strong choice in the $17,900 Home Bred Handicap today, and this duo lived up to their backers' confidence. They ran one, two in the six-furlong race for Jersey-bred juveniles. The winner's share was $11,017.50.

WASHINGTON, Sept 27 -- The Moscow radio has launched a major propaganda campaign based on the "statement of principles" for disarmament negotiations that was agreed to by the Soviet Union and the United States last week.
Ten-year-old Diosa Monponte was saved from a possible four-story fall yesterday afternoon by a policeman who made a daring rescue while dangling from a rope.
The statements of campaign contributions and expenditures filed by candidates in the recent Democratic and Republican primary elections have been subpoenaed in a state investigation.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 27 -- Vice President Johnson has been asked by President Kennedy to confer in Paris with United States officials and Gen. Lauris Norstad, Supreme Commander of the forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The imminent sale of controlling interest in Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways was reported and denied yesterday.
The second annual Bourbon Ball will take place Nov. 2 in the Plaza. Mrs. William H. Woodward is honorary chairman of the event.
The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest carrier, showed a substantial profit last month, whereas it had a sizable loss in August, 1960.

Events tonight: New York Philharmonic preview concert, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Krainis Baroque Trio, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Jazz in the Garden, featuring the Buster Bailey Sextet, Museum of Modern Art, 8:30.
THE Leningrad Kirov Ballet resented its "Gala Program No. 2 at the Mertopolitan Opera House last night, and left us all looking both backwards and forwards with a freshly piqued interest.

The 125th anniversary of the founding of the Riverdale Children's Association will be observed at a preview performance on Oct. 12 of the new Abe Burrows-Frank Loesser musical, "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," at the 46th Street Theatre.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Sharks traveling in groups of sixty caused an alarm along a twenty-mile stretch of beach today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- The opening concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra's 1961-62 season, scheduled for Friday afternoon, was canceled today because of a strike of the musicians.
New York City was reported yesterday to be hesitant about installing anti-pollution devices on its own cars and trucks despite apparent proof that they were effective.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These notes do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.

With a traditional rival, Notre Dame, back on the schedule, New York University's basketball team is booked play nineteen games this season. The Violet quintet will also participate in the annual Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden, Dec. 26, 28 and 30.
BUFFALO, Sept. 27 -- Unemployment in New York State declined by 90,000 seasons between mid-July and mid-August.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 27 -- Following is a transcript of remarks by President Kennedy announcing the appointment of John A. McCone to succeed Allen W. Dulles as director of the Central Intelligence Agency and of the responses of Mr. Dulles and Mr. McCone:
PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The resumption of talks with the Algerian rebel government was predicted yesterday by President de Gaulle in a meeting with a delegation of the French Socialist party.
ARMONK, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- After 30,000 miles of worldwide wandering that nobody could fully explain, a book was returned to the shelves of the North Castle free library here today.

" TELEVISION sets, mink stoles, buttons -- our customers will attempt to buy anything by phone," says Lillian Beyer, manager of the Adjustment Service Department at Macy's. And, since so many people prefer to order by telephone, this store is braced for virtually any kind or number of telephone inquiries.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Prices of all grain futures turned weak today on the Board of Trade, with wheat and rye losing major fractions to more than 2 cents a bushel under heavy pressure.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 27 -- President Kennedy announced today his nomination of John A. McCone to succeed Allen W. Dulles as director of the Central Intelligence Agency.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 35 cents a bale off yesterday, except 1962 March which was 75 cents up on a bid.
The high point of Victor Borge's show on Channel 2 last night came when the master of the crazy keyboard joined with the piano virtuoso Leonid Hambro in an impish and skillful concert.

The United States Committee for Refugees is assisting the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in developing plans for the observance in this country of the centennial of the birth of Fridtjof Nansen, the great explorer, scientist, statesman and humanitarian who was born in Norway on Oct. 10, 1861.
Before buying wallpaper, the measurements of the walls to be papered as well as the paper itself must be considered, according to John Angle of Pageant Wallpapers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- No foreign voyage of discovery is required to establish the fact that United States foreign policy since the Marshall Plan has seemed to our allies to be weakened in effectiveness by a national tendency to shun certain harsh world realities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- For more than three thousand years after Joshua sent his spies into Jericho, the techniques of intelligence gathering remained essentially unchanged. Then the scientific revolution, and particularly the progress of electronics, opened revolutionary new possibilities in the arts of espionage.
A network advertiser challenged some traditional theories about television programs and ratings here yesterday.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Canterbury's football squad traveled over Litchfield's scenic hills to near-by Washington this afternoon for a scrimmage with Gunnery. The contact practice was Canterbury's first with an outside school in five years.
A primary campaign tour in the summer by Mayor Wagner resulted yesterday in a $300 fine against an East Harlem landlord in Housing Court.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Congress has appropriated $4,000,000 to help save the historic treasures of the Nile River valley.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Gov. Robert E. Smylie of Idaho charged that Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall was subverting orderly processes for the determination of land use in the Western states.

Programing activity for tomorrow's seasonal debut of the "Bell Telephone Hour" hummed like a busy signal as the show moved toward airtime without the scheduled personal appearance of its two most highly publicized stars.
Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and associates are offering to the public today 200,000 Class A common shares of Swingline, Inc., at $41.50 a share.
Fundamental and technical elements combined yesterday to give the New York Stock Exchange one of the best gains of the year.
California announced yesterday that it would offer $100,000,000 of construction bonds at competitive bidding on Oct. 18.

The work of the Child Development Center will be aided by a theatre party at the Tuesday performance of "Pirates of Penzance" at the Phoenix Theatre. There will be a supper party afterward at Luchow's.

The Aluminum Company of America extended the downward revision of its published prices to a wide range of mill products yestreday. These included items representing an estimated 65 to 70 per cent of the total sheet and plate tonnage.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- (UPI) -- The first session of the Eighty-seventh Congress voted $95,800,000,000 for President Kennedy to spend -- more than any other President has received in peacetime.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Frank Lary pitched his twenty-third victory tonight as the Detroit Tigers hit three home runs and routed the Kansas City Athletics, 10 -- 2.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 27 -- Syracuse University, which has risen to national prominence on the gridiron the past five seasons, seems destined to maintain its lofty position during the 1961 campaign.

THE defenders congratulated each other when they defeated the contract and saved a game in this deal, and deservedly. Their play had to be very accurate. But they received an unnoticed assist from the declarer.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 -- Gen. Celestino Gasca, 70 years old, and twenty-eight others were indicted last night for crimes against the Government, including homicide, attempted rebellion and making and carrying weapons.

RHODES, Greece, Sept. 27 -- The first Pan-Orthodox conference in twelve centuries, already troubled by East-West political differences, was further divided today by an invitation to the delegates to visit a United States aircraft carrier.
JACK BENNY, wit and fiddler, was the guest of honor last night in an unusual one-hour program over Channel 2.
Bookings of fabricated structural steel totaled 384,981 tons in August, the third highest monthly figure so far this year, according to the American Institute of Steel Construction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Eighty-seventh Congress is going to have few new faces in it when it convenes for its second session Jan. 10. But the election in 1962 appears certain to bring in many more.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Emanuel Shinwell, former Labor Cabinet Minister, set the tone today for a chorus of Commonwealth doubt and criticism of Britain's proposed entry into the European Common Market.
BUFFALO, Sept. 27 (UPI) A continuing strike, affecting about 3,200 Buffalo longshoremen blocked the flow of cargo in and out of this port today.
There was disagreement last night about the status of the merger offer that Northeast Airlines, Inc., received last week from Eastern, National and Mohawk Airlines.

KENSINGTON, L.I., Sept 27 -- Residents of this small North Shore Village voted 298 to 19 this evening against buying a four-acre plot as a means of preventing the erection of an apartment building on it.

The electric power industry hailed yesterday a development that was said to parallel in importance the first breaking of the sound barrier in the field of aviation.

THEIR attire distinguished by sports-shirt informality, the Yankees straggled into the clubhouse at the Stadium yesterday for their final game of the year with the Baltimore Orioles. But when Roger Maxis, a late arrival, strolled through the door, he looked every inch the prosperous young business man that he is.
YONKERS, Sept. 27 -- A big move during the third quarter and a strong finish enabled Galileo Pick to score by a nose in the feature pace before 19,397 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The State Department has hopes that a contract dispute that has caused the Russians to postpone their medical display in Oklahoma City and an American transportation exhibition in Moscow will be ended shortly.

NEW DEHLI, India, Sept. 27 -- India was reported today to be pressing for a United States and Soviet agreement that the United Nations General Assembly should elect an interim Secretary General who would have the same powers as the late Dag Hammarskjold.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Wes Ellis Jr. regained the Metropolitan Golf Association open championship today. "I could have used a golf cart on those last holes," said the 29-year-old pro from the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The International Coffee Agreement was renewed today with six-month quotas established for the world's coffee exporting nations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff will begin a nation-wide campaign next week to sell the American people on Federal aid to "quality education."
New York's seventy-fifth international six-day bike race will end at midnight.

Arthur S. Bernard and Robert $. Bernard have joined the property-anysis department of the Tenney Corporation. Arthur S. Renmrd formerly was sales manager of the New York office of the C. Snyder Company and Robert 3. Bernard was a' sales broker with the Cross Brown Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Strategic Air Command expects soon to place its first intercontinental ballistic missiles in bases that will afford some protection against thermonuclear blast.
While mention of trading in commodity futures still can draw stares and cliches at cocktail parties, public participation in that investment field is slowly but steadily increasing.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 -- Manager Fred Hutchinson's blueprints for upsetting the Yankees in the world series call for the Cincinnati Reds to start only three pitchers -- Jim O'Toole (won 18, lost 9), Joey Jay (21-9) and Bob Purkey (16-12), in that order.
Consumer confidence in the economy improved decisively during the summer, according to the Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan.

CAIRO, Sept. 27 -- The third Arab Petroleum Congress will bring more than 400 members of the oil industry from fifty-seven countries to the United Arab Republic next month. Abdul Khalem Hassuna, secretary general of the Arab League, called a news conference to announce that the Congress would meet from Oct. 16 to 21 at the University of Alexandria.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Mrs. Edwin H. Vare Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., the defending champion, took the halfway lead in the thirty-sixth United States Senior Women's Golf Association tournament today by shooting 39, 39 -- 78 over the South course at Westchester Country Club.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 27 -- President Tshombe appealed today to Premier Adoula to meet with him as soon as possible on neutral territory. He indicated that the meeting should be held without United Nations influence.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The stock market steadied here today after yesterday broad decline. Industrial shares hardened toward the close after earlier softness, while the gilt-edge issues were more actively traded than on any day in the last three months.

Bernard Alt was in a reflective mood yesterday as he strolled down the Avenue of the Americas. "Most advertising men are always rushing from one place to another," he observed. "But I'm one advertising man who is never in a hurry."

Chances appeared excellent yesterday that the New York football Titans would be able scrap their "lonely quarterback" offense within a day or the General Manager Steve to expects to obtain an un-study for Al Dorow before yesterday's return match with the Boston Patriots at the Polo funds.

Fifteen true stories by captives of Indians who lived to tell them have been brought together by Frederick Drimmer in "Scalps and Tomahawks." The time span is from 1750 to 1870, from the capture of James Smith, who lived with the Mohawks for five years, to Fanny Kelly's escape from the Sierra and her saving of Fort Sully from a surprise attack.
The new Board of Education is expected to grant new administrative powers to the Superintendent of Schools tonight in order to free itself of much of the red tape that hampered the previous board.
BERLIN, Sept. 27 -- Communist East Germany served notice on the West today that future access to West Berlin would hinge on direct negotiations between the Allies and the East German regime.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 27 -- A jury awarded $115,000 today to the widow of a man who was electrocuted while flying a kite.

Robert Lehman's Ambiopoise, an erratic performer in a dozen previous starts this year, returned to his best form at Belmont yesterday when he won the seventeenth running of the $28,150 Discovery Handicap by two lengths.
An expert in nuclear hazards predicted here yesterday that small, underground nuclear power plants might eventually compete with coal and oil as a source of municipal power and light.

Del Shofner of the New York Giants is the leading pass receiver in the National Football League. Official statistics released yesterday showed that, in two games, the fleet wingman had caught thirteen passes for 174 yards and one touchdown.

The fifteen-story and penthouse building for thirty-three families at 55 Park Avenue, near Thirty-eighth Street, has been sold by the 55 Park Avenue Corporation to an investing client of Herbert Charles Co., broker. The luxury apartment house is a Murray Hill landmark.

The extension of the International Coffee Agreement had a nominal effect yesterday on trading in futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices were irregular on the "B" contract, and off for the "M" and "R" contracts.

Six young drivers, who will make their metropolitan area debut at the fall harness racing season starting tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., were introduced at a luncheon yesterday in the Gaslight Club, 124 East Fifty-sixth Street.

Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc., operated in the black in the fiscal year ended on June 30 while a loss was incurred in the preceding year, Emerson E. Mead, president, noted in the annual report yesterday. Sales reached a new record.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Sept. 26 -- Dr. Eric E. Williams, Prime Minister of Trinidad, opened a campaign last night to keep his People's National Movement in power.

The sale of five Boeing 707 jet passenger transports intended for service between Cairo and North and South America may come about as a result of the impending visit of a four-man delegation of the United Arab Airlines.

Today's new film is "Question 7," an American-made drama filmed in Germany, at the Guild Theatre, Avenue of the Americas and Fifty-first Street. Christian de Bresson, Michael Gwyn and Margarete Jahnen head the cast of the Louis de Rochemont Associates release, which was directed by Stuart Rosenberg and produced by Lothar Wolff.

VIENNA, Sept. 27 -- In a message to the fifth general conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency President Kennedy said the agency could "help to maintain a bridge of understanding between nations."
The New York Academy of Medicine last night initiated its new section on occupational Medicine last night began its the health of workers.

Three weeks ago the citizens of New York came out in unexpected numbers to exercise their voting privileges and line up candidates for the November elections. Mention is made of this today, Sept. 28, for a reason that may surprise many voters and not a few of the candidates.
Paul P. Goldner has been appointed national account manager, Eastern division, of Du-Bois Chemicals, Inc., manufacturers of industrial cleaning and maintenance compounds.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 27 -- It will be strange to see Princeton's football team line up against Rutgers before some 30,000 spectators at Palmer Stadium Saturday without either Hugh Scott or Jack Sullivan in the tailback spot of the traditional Tiger single wing.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Al Schroll of the Twins pitched no-hit ball for eight innings against the Cleveland Indians today, but gave two hits in the ninth and finished with a 10-4 victory.

The Belgian Line announced yesterday plans to build four motor vessels, each of 11,810 deadweight tons, to serve trade potential expected to develop within two years. The ships are scheduled to be delivered to the line between June, 1963, and April, 1964.

Production of electric power in the nation totaled 15,025,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Saturday, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This figure compared with 15,869,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 14,556,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the same period last year.
International marine and air insurance underwriters are disturbed by serious losses on imported merchandise discharged at New York International Airport in Idlewild.
The Automatic Canteen Company of America, through its New York subsidiary, the Hubshman Factors Corporation, has acquired Jones Co., New York commercial factoring concern.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 27 -- President Surkano said today that the best way to end the dispute over Netherlands New Guinea was for "the Netherlands to transfer immediately its authority to Indonesia.''

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27 -- It is not for nothing that Yale has won more intercollegiate football games, scored more points and placed more men on the all-America teams than any other college in the land since Princeton and Rutgers touched off the autumnal madness in 1869.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Stewart B. Hopps, internationally known insurance executive and financier, surrendered today to face conspiracy charges in New York. He has been accused of evading $4,000,000 in income taxes, interest and penalties.
Vito M. Battista, the United Taxpayers party candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that supporters of former Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy had been "sold out" to the Republicans.

AMERICA'S population explosion is no accident. The baby boom -- more than 4,000,000 births in each of the last six years -- was created by couples who wanted babies, although some of the births were unplanned.

TOKYO, Sept. 27 -- The Emperor of Japan, once the fountainhead of authority in this country, spent just six minutes and thirty seconds today performing the deliberately plain ceremony that is his only remaining public political duty.
Following is the text of a statement by Richard M. Nixon, as recorded by The New York Times, announcing his intention to run for Governor of California:

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 26 -- Opposition groups in the Dominican Republic tried today to reach an agreement on conditions for accepting the invitation of President Joaquin Balaguer to form a coalition government.
The city's Labor Department reported yesterday that it had helped to avert "scores" of strikes here during 1960.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Jim Pagliaroni drove in two runs with a homer and double today as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Chicago White Sox, 6 -- 4, in their final 1961 home appearance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 20:
Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, held their second exploratory talk yesterday on the possibility of starting negotiations on the Berlin crisis.
BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- Toughness, "spit-and-polish" and pride are characteristics of the 6,500 United States soldiers who garrison the divided city of Berlin.

EXCEPT for the soot, the subway and the occasional power failures New York is not so much a big city as it is a series of small communities. The typical residents of Manhattan live in their particular neighborhoods as they would in a small town or a suburb.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 27 -- Long Island farmers, who have been plagued with below-cost prices for their potato crop, started their second big cash crop, cauliflower, to the markets today on a bleak note.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The Soviet Union submitted to the United Nations tonight a memorandum listing eight measures that it said would lessen international tension and promote disarmament.

The four-hour conference this week between the President of the United States and the President of Argentina was described as one of the longest Mr. Kennedy has held with any visiting chief of state. In view of Argentina's status, this is not surprising.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Britain's application to join the European Common Market was welcomed here today.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Scientists representing fifty-one nations approved today a worldwide study of the "year of the quiet sun" beginning in 1964.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Civil Aeronautics Board investigators reported today that a bolt vital to the operation of the hydraulic control system was missing on a Trans World Airlines Constellation that crashed Sept. 1, killing all seventy-eight persons aboard.
About 4,000 city elementary school teachers will begin a television course next week on how to teach reading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- There is only one thing certain about the tax complications of the forced divestment by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., of its stock in General Motors Corporation. The Senate is scheduled to talk about it again on Monday, Jan. 15, 1962.
This is National Dog Week. The theme adopted for the thirty-fourth annual observance is: "Deserve to be Your Dog's Best Friend."
In the long and distinguished list of British Ambassadors to the United States, Sir Harold Caccia, who leaves Washington today, has an honorable place.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 27 -- The Government of India announced plans today to reduce by the equivalent of $31,500,000 a year the revenues received by Western oil companies for refined petroleum products.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 27 -- A.E. Hotchner is simultaneously putting together a movie and a stage play that involve the life and works of Ernest Hemingway.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers set a National League modern strikeout record tonight when he fanned seven Philadelphia Phillies and lifted his season total to 269.
Emile Griffith, the champion, and Benny (Kid) Paret, his challenger for the welterweight title Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, are engaged in a private "battle of the bulge."

The nation's oil production and refining rates increased last week as major centers along the Gulf Coast resumed operations that had been affected by Hurricane Carla. Inventories of refined products, meanwhile, showed moderate gains from the preceding week.

Directors of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation yesterday raised the quarterly dividend on the common-stock to 75 cents a share. The dividend is payable on Oct. 31 to holders of record of Oct. 16. In previous quarters, shareholders received 65 cents a share.
NEWARK, Sept. 27 -- Four hundred junior high school students rioted for an hour outside a police station today in an attempt to free a teen-age prisoner.
The bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company filed an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday for a 5-cent increase on most passenger fares.
LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Middle East broadcasts said today rebels had launched an uprising in Syria and President Nasser announced his army would march on Damascus and smash them.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Yugoslavia assailed tonight the draft program of the Soviet Communist party, saying it recalled the anti-Yugoslav spirit of the Stalinist era.

Burton N. Pugach, a disbarred lawyer, who is to be sentenced Tuesday for his part in a lye attack that partly blinded his former fiancee, was described as insane in a psychiatric report issued yesterday at Kings County Hospital.
WARSAW, Sept. 27. -- The Polish Communist party is trying to raise the ideological readiness of the Polish armed forces.
The market for United States Government securities eased a bit yesterday.

Calvert Electronics, Inc., manufacturer of electronic equipment, has leased a floor at 220 East Twenty-third Street from Harry G. Silverstein Sons, owner of the building. The lease was arranged by the Clemence Kahm Company, broker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A study prepared for Scandinavian Airlines System said today that "retaliation must be expected" if the United States starts restricting the schedules of foreign airlines.
DETROIT, Sept. 27 -- The Protestant Episcopal Church listed for the first time today explicit qualifications for church membership.
A fight manager, Herman (Hymie) Wallman, has admitted giving gratuities to a New York boxing judge, the State Athletic Commission disclosed after a hearing yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 -- The American Hospital Association today declined to endorse medical insurance for the aged under Social Security.
President Kennedy was urged yesterday to sign a measure passed by Congress to legalize the use of a dual-rate system by steamship conferences.
MALIBU, Calif., Sept. 27 -- An ion engine punier than a mouse, yet designed to power rocket journeys far into the universe, was demonstrated today at the Hughes Aircraft Laboratories here.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 27 -- Walter E. Cosgriff, prominent Western banker, was killed in an automobile accident yesterday near Wells, Nev.
