WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The House of Representatives forced adjournment of the Congressional session of 1961 at dawn today over the protests of a frustrated Senate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The first Kennedy Congress has ended a long and exhausting session in which it heard but responded coolly to the call of the New Frontier.

GUILDERLAND, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The Guilderland Central School District is awaiting Walter F. Wessendorf's signature on a $1,300 contract under which he will drive his two daughters to school in his Cadillac this school year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Two 19-year-old rookies, Danny Murphy in the outfield and Ken Hubbs at second base, hit three of the four home runs for the Chicago Cubs today in a 5-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
DETROIT, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Efforts of the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers to reach immediate agreement on a new three-year contract hit a snag today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Army announced a $171,821,000 contract today for additional development of the Nike Zeus anti-missile missile system.
The world of Hansel and Gretel, the Three Little Pigs and the White Rabbit will come alive today in Central Park.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- An Executive order banning discrimination in federally aided housing is being prepared at the White House.

When a responsible civic organization opposes the proposed revision of the City Charter on grounds that are factually incorrect it is the duty of the Charter Revision Commission to issue a correction.

UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary told the General Assembly today that a settlement of the Berlin crisis must permit the people of West Berlin "to live the life which they have chosen for themselves," with absolute guarantees for that freedom.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 -- Richard M. Nixon announced tonight that he would be a candidate for Governor of California next year. The former Vice President simul taneously renounced any intention of being the Republican candidate for President of the United States in 1964.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 27 -- The Soviet Union's attempts to put the United Nations under several executives representing a divided world appeared today to be meeting unexpectedly strong opposition.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27 -- An Argentine ring of gunrunners falsified a governmental decree and tried to buy weapons in Italy for delivery to the Algerian rebels the Federal police said here today.
An operation that corrects impaired blood supply to the kidneys has been successfully used over the last four years in treating some types of high blood pressure, it was reported here yesterday.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Sept. 27 -- Republican state Chairmen of the thirteen Western states cheered and applauded tonight on hearing Richard M. Nixon's announcement that he would seek the California governorship.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Sept. 27 -- There were growing indications today that the Congolese Central Government and President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province might attempt to solve their differences through consultation.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The small West African nation of Sierra Leone was admitted unanimously tonight to the United Nations as the organization's 100th member.

IN June, 1961, Herbert L. Matthews told an audience at Columbia that Cuba was then and for some time had been "a totalitarian police state." How he arrived at this and many other spirited conclusions is set forth in his remarkably contentious book about the Castro Revolution, "The Cuban Story."

The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation has given the go-ahead sign for construction of an iron-making blast furnace at its Cleveland Works. It awarded Koppers Company, Inc., a construction contract estimated at $20,000,000 by industry sources.
ALGIERS, Sept. 27 -- Algeria has become one of the most unpleasant places in the world to live.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The United States will soon open four experimental nuclear reactors to inspection by the International Atomic Energy Agency.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 27 -- Ambassador Walter C. Dowling has given the West German Government formal assurances that United States policy on the Berlin and German questions has not changed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- West Coast members of the Masters, Mates and Pilots Association voted today to strike thirteen shipping concerns after their negotiators rejected a final offer for a new contract.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 27 (AP) -- J. Will Young, attorney for Jackson City Lines, told a three-judge Federal Court today that his company would be forced to suspend operations soon if a decision was delayed in a suit seeking desegregation of transportation facilities.

A proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would help public and private institutions of higher education to finance new facilities received the support yesterday of the Association of Colleges and Universities of the State of New York.

RINGWOOD, N.J. Sept. 27 -- This community's civil defense director, Walter Bullard, wants to put the historic Ringwood Iron Mines in a new role: that of a vast bomb shelter. The cost is estimated at $1,000,000.

The Interstate Commerce Commission agreed yesterday to permit the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey to buy part of the Lehigh and New England Railroad, with the rest of the Lehigh to be abandoned. The agency also agreed to guarantee repayment of a $15,000,000 loan to the Jersey Central to enable it to make the purchase.
The "other" Yankees -- those who aren't named Roger Maris or Mickey Mantle -- had their chance yesterday to show what they could do on their own. As it turned out, they didn't do much.
Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Mayor Wagner's campaign manager, was elected chairman of the New York County Democratic Committee at an organization meeting last night.

THE years have a way of creeping up on blond, blue-eyed Mrs. Nancy Hawes, fashion promotion manager for Dan River Mills, Inc. While the average woman is thinking about clothes for the fall of 1961, Mrs. Hawes is thinking about clothes for the spring and fall of 1962.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Auxiliary Bishop Walter W. Curtis of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark since 1957 was appointed Bishop of Bridgeport, Conn., today.

Roger Sessions, the American composer, supervised a rehearsal of his String Quintet (1958) late yesterday afternoon. The performers were led by Felix Galimir. The rehearsal lasted about ninety minutes, during which time the first movement was played through twice, and a umber of sections were gone over intensively after suggestions by the composer.

NEWARK, Sept. 27 -- Three Negro school teachers have been promoted to posts never before held by members of their race in Newark. Two have been assigned secondary school administrative jobs and the third a central office supervisory position.

The Humble Oil and Refining Company announced yesterday marketing plans for a high-pressure oil burner attachment that it asserted would cut heating off bills, give cleaner heat and decrease the noise level in burner operation.
Illinois awarded yesterday its first bond issue in more than twelve years to an investment group led by Glore, Forgan Co. on a bid of 100.0404 for 4, 2 3/4 and 3 per cent coupons.
Within the month, two of New York City's outstanding academic leaders have announced their intention to retire from the field of higher education. They will both be missed.

I have read with interest Telford Taylor's comment regarding the General Walker episode, published as a letter in The New York Times of Sept. 21. Mr. Taylor's theory is that officers must maintain political neutrality in their relations with their troops in order to facilitate recruiting and to avoid creating morale problems.
MIAMI, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Emett C. Choate ordered a man identified as an official of the Cuban regime of former President Fulgencio Batista released from custody today.
NEWARK, Sept. 27 -- The Bergen Drug Company, Inc., of Hackensack, today asked for treble damages totaling $600,000 in an antitrust suit filed against Parke, Davis Co. of Detroit.

LO, the poor cabbage. That venerable vegetable, so rich in vitamin C, has long been held in love esteem. The name is used to denote pilferage and cribbing, and a brainless fellow is sometimes known as a cabbage-head. Lewis Carroll referred to its earthy nature by writing of cabbages and kings.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 27 -- The United States Air Force in Europe announced today that eight tactical fighter squadrons had been temporarily assigned to Europe for overseas operational training.

The New York State Banking Board will hold a special meeting tomorrow morning to consider the biggest bank holding company proposal in the nation's financial history. The question before the board will be whether to approve the application of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York and six upstate banks to form a bank holding company to be known as the Morgan New York State Corporation.

BERLIN, Sept. 27 -- The Army exonerated today two colonels who had been admonished for their part in a television show filmed here several weeks ago by Jack Paar, star of a late evening National Broadcasting Company program.

New York City sold yesterday for the account of its retirement system and pension funds $11,171,000 of the city's serial bonds to Salomon Brothers and Hutzler. The group submitted the best bid -- $11,204,534 -- for nine lots of bonds offered by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa in a notice on Sept. 21.
The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the twelve and eight months ended on Aug. 31.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina told the world's affluent societies today that their most urgent duty at this "extraordinary and grave" time was to aid the under-developed nations of Latin America, Asia and Africa.

After appropriating a record total of $95 billion, Congress has adjourned its longest session in ten years in a quarrel between Senate and House that reached its climax over the foreign aid bill. Under a last-minute "compromise" dictated by a fanatical opponent of all foreign aid, Representative Passman of Louisiana, the final appropriation for the "Decade of Development" proclaimed by President Kennedy was $3,914,600,000.

HONG KONG, Thursday, Sept. 28 -- The Peiping radio broadcast yesterday a warning to the people of China's vast northwest province of Sinkiang against the health menace of heavy Soviet nuclear fall-out, according to a report by the Chinese Nationalist regime at Taipei.

IT is difficult to tell who is kidding whom in "Fourth Avenue North," the new revue that opened last night at the Madison Avenue Playhouse at Thirtieth Street. Ostensibly, the intimate show is supposed to be joshing the customs, establishments, mores and institutions of Park Avenue.

Coordinating committees of county and city officials from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and New York City were named yesterday to work with the Tri-State Transportation Committee, established on Aug. 30 by the Governors of the three states.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association announced yesterday that it would file objections before the Federal Communications Commission on behalf of the daily newspaper business to proposed rate rises for leased wire services.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Reliable sources said today that discussion of the Berlin situation between East and West in New York had failed to disclose any basic change in the Soviet position.

The death of Dag Hammarskjold may be one of those tragedies by which institutions come of age. It was in his character to have wished it that way. Not long before his death he wrote to a friend, stressing the need for a "deep sense for the spiritual basis -- and responsibility -- of the United Nations."
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 27 -- Moderates at the Southern Governors Conference blocked a move today to name Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas as chairman.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Execpt for a brief flurry of buyLug in wheat, grain futures trading was bearish again today, with prices mostly weak.
PITTSBURGH. Sept. 28 (AP) -- Two brothers, Matty and Felipe Alou, figured in all of the San Francisco scoring tonight as the Giants downed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7 -- 4.

Measurements of stock market progress disagreed yesterday. In a session of the New York Stock Exchange that seemed to be making adjustments for the over-corrections of earlier days, more stocks rose than fell, Standard Poor's 500-stock average was up and both the Dow-Jones industrial average and The New York Times combined average went down.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 28 -- Nearly 150 leaders of Indian political and intellectual life gathered here today to evolve what they consider to be one of their country's most urgent needs -- a program for national unity.
A new quarterly of opinion in the field of journalism was announced here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Total United States exports of pulp, paper and paperboard in the first half of 1961 reached a record high of 1,170,000 tons, according to the Department of Commerce.
Two of the nation's leading producers of copper announced yesterday the promotions of several key officials.

I have lived in Africa for the last thirteen years, representing an American company, and from personal knowledge of the Congo and the Katanga I know that our action in the Congo is dangerous, unrealistic and highly immoral.

A LONG-TIME champion of contemporary American abstract painting who was closely associated with Mondrian during his last years in New York Charmion von Wiegand is holding a ten-year retrospective of her work at the Howard Wise Gallery, 50 West Fifty-seventh Street.
Cotton futures fell 20 to 50 cents a bale on the near-by contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The most distant months were steady to 95 cents off on a bid.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Sal Di Buono and Lois Hallager of Bonnie Briar won the Westchester pro-woman Scotch-foursomes golf championship at Ryewood today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Nearly 3,000 delegates and Secretariat staff members honored the memory of Dag Hammarskjold today in a service in the General Assembly Hall. The ceremony moved many to tears.
DETROIT, Sept. 28 -- The Protestant Episcopal Church endorsed artificial birth control here today.
ALGIERS, Sept. 28 -- A demonstration of soli larity by Europeans ended here today after sporadic riots by about 300 youths.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the airlines today to discuss standards for serving food and liquor in transit, including possible elimination of food on certain jet flights.

AN armed guard stood at attention yesterday afternoon in a Seventh Avenue showroom, keeping his eye on $2,000,000 worth of modern art and $110.75 worth of modern sweaters. The latter were allegedly inspired by the former.

RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 28 -- Moroccans were deeply troubled by reports of the revolt in the Syrian province of the United Arab Republic, which has been considered here as the cornerstone of a future united Arab state.

Reluctant to call it quits on the boating season, the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club of Port Washington is using this weekend for a double-barreled cruising rendezvous, headed by C.W. Phalen. The assembly will be at Price's Bend, south of Eaton's Neck.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. 28 (UPI) -- The body of a retired Colorado Springs priest was found in the trunk of his car near Walden today. He had been missing since Sept. 20.

Arthur Snyder Jr. has been appointed controller of the Behr-Manning division of the Norton Company. He will be the chief financial officer of the company's coated abrasives and pressure sensitive tape manufacturing division in Troy, N.Y.

FOOTBALL scrimmage and statistics go hand-in-hand. Thus, for many parents with eager, young scrubs at home, the football season creates trepidation because of the known hazards of this sport. This fall there have been eleven schoolboy fatalities in the nation, a high figure so early in the season.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Louisville Nashville Railroad filed an application today to gain direct control of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad through control of its stock.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. presented $500 scholarships last night to ten persons who had taken part in freedom rides in Alabama and Mississippi.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- The state reported today that 782 persons on relief had been assigned to work-relief projects in twenty-three upstate counties. This was a decrease of almost 400 from last year.
Orson Welles was accused in State Supreme Court yesterday of disrupting the filming of "Mr. Arkadin" in Europe in 1954 and 1955 by repeated drunkenness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- An official of the Central Intelligence Agency has testified that infiltration of police forces and efforts to turn the public against them were favorite Communist tactics.

ROME, Sept. 28 -- The existence of a Jewish community on the outskirts of ancient Rome has been revealed by the chance discovery of a Jewish temple at Ostia, formerly the port of Rome at the mouth of the Tiber.
Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York rose $5,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Rutgers will dress fifty-eight football players for its opening game against Princeton at Palmer Stadium on Saturday -- and all of them are physically able to play.

KIPUSHI, the Congo, Sept. 28 -- Fierce tribal fighting between Baluba tribesmen and other Katangans continued today. At least twenty-two persons were dead and an estimated total of 100 or more Africans were wounded in the clashes, which erupted yesterday.
The "CAT" on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday had only one life and it was short, as shown by the ticker tape notice saying "NO CAT." In fact, there is no CAT at all.

Owners of the Pittsburgh Steel Company's common stock will receive rights early in November to subscribe to additional shares to help finance a $44,000,000 capital improvement program, Allison R. Maxwell, Jr., president, said after a special meeting of shareholders in Pittsburgh.
Labor troubles may bring the current season of the New York Philharmonic to a halt just as it has begun.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina gave support today to the forthcoming debate on the admission of Communist China to the United Nations, but took no definite stand toward the Peiping Government.

Jay-Thorpe, Inc., a West, 57th Street shop specializing in women's apparel, has filed a petition seeking an arrangement with its creditors under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act. The store will continue in business while efforts are made to work out an arrangement.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz found a new beverage yesterday in the gustatory campaign for the Mayoralty.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- President Kennedy has now completed his team of foreign and defense policy experts and it's about as competent, undramatic and nonpartisan an outfit as ever served in Washington.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Every afternoon when Colgate's fifty-man football squad finishes its daily practice, the players complete their arduous chores by running halfway up Agony Hill.
The hurler of lye that maimed the former fiancee of Burton N. Pugach, a disbarred lawyer, was sentenced to up to sixty years in state prison by Bronx County Judge Joseph A. Martinis yesterday.
A 28-year-old Queens letter carrier charged in Supreme Court yesterday that he had been denied appointment to the Police Department because of "the so-called sins of my relatives."
If the Soviet Union actually carries out its reported intention to veto the admission of Mauritania to the United Nations, such action would constitute another flagrant Soviet misuse of the veto.
City and state welfare officials here are demonstrating that malingerers can be kept off the relief rolls without get-tough methods of the type employed in Newburgh.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The French Socialist party called today for a grouping of all democratic forces in France to prepare an alternative to the regime of President de Gaulle.

In the market for high-grade bonds yesterday, attention was focused on the $100,000,000 issue of Illinois bonds that reached the market Wednesday priced to yield 1.40 per cent to 3.20 per cent in 1986.
MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- Fifteen Soviet newsmen assigned to the United Nations received United States visas today. They had charged an excessive delay in issuance of the visas in an open letter to Pravda.
A director of the Yale University Center of Alcohol Studies took issue yesterday with a New York clubwoman's contention that drinking promoted promiscuity among teen-age girls.
CAIRO, Sept. 28 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser said tonight that the United Arab Republic was in "grave danger" as a result of an army revolt in Damascus early in the day.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 28 -- Ernest B. Fay's Sabre from Houston retained the lead in defense of the United States 5.5-meter yacht championship despite finishing third and second in today's races. Both races were won by George O'Day's Minotaur from Boston.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Billy Maxwell and Jon Gustin, a stylish swinger who suffered a broken arm five months ago, carded 67's today to share the first-round lead in the $25,000 Bakersfield open golf tournament.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- The group of women delegates at the Sixteenth Session of the General Assembly outranks and outnumbers any earlier group of women delegates here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- Masters, mates and pilots collected their belongings and their pay here today. Then they walked off their ships into a coast-wide strike against the Pacific Maritime Association.
Four major European airlines have gone to court to challenge a C.A.B. order that foreign carriers must file traffic, schedule and equipment data for approval.

Metropolitan harness racing will shift tonight from Yonkers Raceway to Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I. There a fifty-four-night meeting will continue until Nov. 30, the final night of the New York State season.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Usually staid Cincinnatians have refused to allow any attempts to spoil the celebration over the city's first National League pennant in twenty-one years.

The bankrupt New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad cut its losses last month $463,122 below the level of 1960. The trustees of the road disclosed yesterday that the carrier's net loss in August dropped to $1,235,918 from $1,699,040 in the 1960 month.
Prices of copper futures declined yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange, after posting small gains on Wednesday.

A public offering of 350,000 common shares of Cerro Corporation, formerly Cerro de Pasco Corporation, was made yesterday by Morgan, Stanley Co. and Smith, Barney Co., Inc. The stock was priced at $32.625 a share.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall today dedicated a research center for the study of methods to replace the hundreds of millions of fish that disappear annually in anglers' creels.

The directors of Freeport Sulphur Company have elected Robert C. Hills as president, it was announced yesterday by Langbourne M. Williams, chairman. Mr. Hills succeeds Charles A. Wight, who has been named vice chairman of the board.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Industrial shares continued to drift lower in the stock market here today.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The X-15 rocket plane reached a speed of 3,454 miles an hour today in a test of its ability to withstand temperatures of 1,100 degrees Fahrenheit.

The opening of the exhibition of the paintings of Dora Khayatt at the Wildenstein Galleries on Oct. 10 will benefit the New York State Association for Mental Health, Inc. So will the sale of the paintings during the exhibition, which will run through Oct. 21.
The Argo Oil Corporation of Denver, Colo., may soon be acquired by one of the big-league oil companies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Sept. 23 were 4 per cent above the level of a year earlier.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined by $17,000,000, to $27,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

SHIRLEY BOOTH is the latest member of the Sardi aristocracy to go West in pursuit of those satisfying film residuals, and last night she made her bow on Channel 4 in "Hazel," a half-hour series based on The Saturday Evening Post cartoon.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 28 -- The chairman of the West Orange Citizens for Survival resigned today after learning that his son-in-law was serving as an official in the Federal Office of Emergency Planning.
Three men who operated a $100,000-a-year Harlem speakeasy known for its "Kink Kong Specials" were sentenced yesterday to prison terms of six to eighteen months.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 28 -- The body of Dag Hammarskjold was flown to his native Sweden today for a state funeral tomorrow

YONKERS, Sept. 28 -- Rodare, a 5-year-old trotting gelding, and Merrie Adios, a 4-year-old pacer, won the feature events as Yonkers Raceway ended its share of the Greater New York harness racing season tonight. The scene now shifts to Roosevelt Raceway at Westbury, L.I.

Contracts awarded for new construction throughout the country last month amounted to $3,542,567,000, an increase of 8 per cent over the volume of $3,295,217,000 in August, 1960, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation, construction news analysis.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 28 -- A 19-year-old Navy football player died this morning at the Naval Academy Hospital as a result of injuries received in practice.

Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, was cleared yesterday by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office of any criminal wrongdoing in having had a boat built for himself at a city school under a relative's name.

The weather at Belmont Park turned cloudy for the fourth running of the $16,300 Elkridge hurdles race yesterday, but no cloud settled on the athletic shoulders of George H. (Pete) Bostwick, the owner, breeder and trainer of the even- money favorite, Barnabys Bluff.
TRENTON, Sept. 28 -- For the first time in seventy-seven years, New, Jersey has seized a vessel for illegal clamming.

The Swiss team of Oscar Plattner and Armin von Buren won the seventy-fifth international six-day bicycle race that ended at Madison Square Garden at midnight. This hardy pair earned the victory in a wild finish that saw three of the seven surviving teams tied in distance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Kennedy Administration, with the enthusiastic advice and consent of the Senate, concluded in the final weeks of the Congressional session of 1961 the greatest expansion of the Federal judiciary in history.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 28 -- The Great Neck School Board, which three years ago spent $9,205,000 for its South Junior and Senior High Schools, may have to spend $1,720,000 more to ease excessive temperatures in the classrooms.

Milton Berle, who recently has been flirting with the idea of returning to the Broadway stage, will probably make it this season. He has signed contracts to star in the musical, "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," which is due here May 3.
NEWARK, Sept. 28 -- Four more teen-agers were arrested today in the riot of 400 junior high school students outside a police station here yesterday.
BUFFALO, Sept. 28 -- A new attempt to find out what is wrong with the state workman's compensation system will get under way within a few weeks at Governor Rockefeller's request.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Puerto Rican Government reported this week a $44,400,000 Government-sponsored medical care plan financed by withholding taxes.

Max and Erwin P. Staller and Associates, realty developers, have announced plans for a shopping center on a ten-acre site they have purchased on Montauk Highway at Lake Avenue in Center Moriches, L.I.
The board of directors of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation proposed yesterday a 2-for-1 stock split. They also announced their intention of raising the dividend rate on the new shares.

Although cancellation of next week's concerts by the New York Philharmonic has become a possibility because of a contract dispute between the orchestra management and the musicians, a program has been' scheduled for the four subscription events in Carnegie Hall.
The State Housing Commissioner, James W. Gaynor, has charged the city with failing to meet its minimum housing responsibility toward middle-income families.
BUFFALO, Sept. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he did not believe Richard M. Nixon had eliminated himself from consideration as the Republican Presidential nominee in 1964.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that control of the Democratic party here was passing into the hands of a coalition of the new and "the best of the old."
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Contributions of $1,000,000 to 100 colleges and universities were announced today by the Eastman Kodak Company as part of its aid-to-education program.
We would like to suggest that a major issue, if not the major issue in the mayoralty campaign should be the improvement of the New York subway system.
OTTAWA, Sept. 28 (Canadian Press) -- A full Federal investigation of how unions operate in the Canadian shipping industry was demanded today before the Canada Labor Relations Board.

Your editorial of Sept. 19 on the "Church and the Revolution" seems to overcomplicate the issue. No Communist state can tolerate a philosophy which insists on freedom of the spirit, freedom to think, freedom of any kind.
Alan H. Temple, who joined the National City Bank thirty years ago as an assistant statistician, retires today as vice chairman of the board of directors of the First National City Bank, New York.

IN the middle of the program called "The Festive Pipes" in Carnegie Hall last night, Bernard Krainis, playing a bass recorder that has the dulcet sound of a cooing dove, and Barbara Mueser, plucking delicately on the strings of a viola da gamba, performed an anonymous sixteenth-century almande and recreated from another era a spell of quiet enchantment.
A prime contractor of the City College School of Technology building was declared in default last night at a meeting of the Board of Higher Education.
As a daily commuter by auto from New Jersey to Manhattan I should like to support wholeheartedly the recommendations made by the Automobile Club of New York, yet with some qualifications.
A crisp autumn evening brought out a sweater-bearing audience for the last outdoor jazz concert of the season in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art last night.

Production of lumber climbed to 236,850,000 board feet in the week ended Saturday from 228,684,000 board feet the preceding week, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago 240,321,000 board feet were produced.
IT is marvelously exhilarating to hear the Negro speak for himself, especially when he does so in the fullness of his native gusto and the enveloping heartiness of his overflowing laughter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The State Department said today that the revolt in Syria appeared to be a purely internal affair, not fomented by any outside power.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 -- Hours after announcing his candidacy for Governor of California next year, Richard M. Nixon found himself embroiled today in some lively political skirmishing.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 28 -- The newly established New York State Council on the Arts begins its theatrical career tomorrow with a presentation of the Phoenix Theatre production of Shakespeare's "Hamlet," and George Bernard Shaw's "Androcles and the Lion" at the new Mineola Theatre here.

John A. McCone, President Kennedy's selection as new head of the Central Intelligence Agency, has shown in his past governmental posts that he has the qualities needed for effective performance in Washington high administrative ability, driving energy and the capacity to get along well with Congress. He will need all these qualities, and more, in his new position.
MOUNDSVILLE, W. Va., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The strong arm of the law didn't have a chance tonight in the West Virginia State Penitentiary.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today accused James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, of "shoddy tactics."
The son of a Paraguyan official at the United Nations called a New York policeman a "gringo swine" last Saturday after a curbside dispute in which a waitress was arrested, the police said yesterday.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 28 -- While Roger Maris (and some Babe Ruth loyalists) have been losing hair and hulking padded figures have started losing teeth, a professional basketball team named the New York Knickerbockers has been quietly trying to devise a way of losing fewer games than it did last season.

THE spanking new stadium that is Washington's latest showpiece will open for business on Sunday. It will replace the ancient and ramshackle Griffith Stadium as the future home of both the baseball Senators and the football Redskins, a shining monument to modernity with a 50,000-spectator capacity and not an obstructing girder.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- The United States and Britain called on the United Nations General Assembly today to press for a treaty to ban nuclear weapons tests "in all environments" under an effective system of controls.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- The Syrian rebels said today they had wiped out a group of paratroops who landed near the port of Latakia on Syria's Mediterranean coast.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Evidence is growing that Switzerland will play a role in the evolving arrangements for better defense of the world monetary system.
ROME, Sept. 28 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said here tonight: "I do not think it is impossible for the Oder-Neisse to become a firmly fixed frontier."
THE prospects for weekend fishing are either excellent or depressing, depending on whether one is thinking of salt water or fresh.

A QUICK glance at the deal shown today should convince anyone that four hearts was a most distasteful contract for South. Bridge players like nothing less than to land at a high contract with a weak trump suit, especially when the adverse trumps are bunched in one hand.
A bright new face in folk music is appearing at Gerde's Folk City. Although only 20 years old, Bob Dylan is one of the most distinctive stylists to play in a Manhattan cabaret in months.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28. -- A public that has come to know what it wants and is entitled to in medical care will demand even more of hospitals in the future, a state insurance official told the American Hospital Association here today.

Favorable critical reactions to last spring's trio of films from Poland, "Ashes and Diamonds," "Kanal" and "Eve Wants to Sleep," have prompted a new distribution company to schedule three more Polish features for American release.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Cruising on the yacht Honey Fitz in Narragansett Bay today, President Kennedy had the destroyer Willis A. Lee halted to give his family a look at the vessel and 225 saluting crewmen.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 28 -- Six Ghanaian ministers and junior ministers have been asked to resign, it was announced today in a Presidential statement. The step was taken as a result of investigations by a commission set up four months ago to look into the financial position of ministers and members of Parliament.

Pre-Columbian voyages to America form the subject of a second book to be published this season. It is "They All Discovered America," by Charles Michael Boland, a pioneer writer-director-producer in television.

What this country needs is more "competition, duplication and confusion" in the procurement of weapons systems, Vice Admiral John T. Hayward, Deputy Chief of Naval Operations, asserted here yesterday.

BEFORE the rebellion in Damascus yesterday, Lieut. Col. Abdel Harold Serraj was a key military figure there and was often described as "Nasser's right hand" in Syria. It was unclear last night just what role he was playing in the uprising, but recent happenings indicated his disaffection from the Government in Cairo.
DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Automobile production in the United States this week will exceed 100,000 units for the first time in more than two months, Automotive News reported today.

NOT much time is left. Since the sun sets at 6:30 (fast time), the season of long evenings is over, and the autumn chill keeps everyone indoors. At night the thermometer drops to the "low forties" or the "mid-thirties," as the television weatherman phrases it; and the oil burner, trusting the thermostat implicitly, consults with itself and sends a wisp of heat through the house.

IT is only a mild exaggeration to say that if a restaurant in New York offers one dish of abiding excellence, the fact is worth recording. One such establishment that has this to recommend it is Alfredo of New York; at 240 West Fifty-sixth Street.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), in its first move to diversify outside the petroleum field, announced yesterday it would purchase the Imperial Casualty and Indemnity Company of Omaha, Neb.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Paul Reynaud, former French Premier, said today that Premier Khrushchev had given him a different version of Allied rights in Berlin than that cited in James Reston's column in The New York Times yesterday.
ATLANTA, Sept. 28 -- Negroes were admitted without incident today to restaurants, lunch counters and other facilities in many of this city's drug, variety and department stores.

The problems that the British Government faces in trying to join the European Economic Community -- the Common Market -- are being made clear to the world. They are not new. When the Government sent Ministers to all the Commonwealth capitals to announce that Britain was going to apply for entrance into the E.E.C., the Ministers heard some very strong criticism.
Blue was appropriately the accent at the fourteenth annual Blue Grass Ball at the Plaza last night. Proceeds of the fete will go to the New York Travelers Aid Society.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today he was glad that former Vice President Richard M. Nixon would seek election as Governor of California.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Lord Home met today with Mr. Gromyko in another exploratory talk to determine whether the West would pro pose negotiations with the Soviet Union on the Berlin question.
WARSAW, Sept. 28 (AP) -- United States strongmen beat Poland's weight lifters, 4 -- 3, tonight in the first match between the countries.
DETROIT, Sept. 28 -- George C. Scott, film and stage star, announced today the establishment of the Theatre-of-Michigan Corporation to produce plays here.
The first New York County prosecution to result from the recent investigation into tow-truck rackets began yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions.
Repeal of the city's 5 per cent tax on theatre admissions was voted yesterday by the City Council. The vote was 21 in favor and one abstention.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Army today announced the award of three contracts worth almost $12,000,000 to New York City concerns for the production of cotton sateen cloth.
The General Motors Corporation vetoed a television script in which a happy drunkard drove an automobile, a Federal hearing was told here yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- Eugene M. Zuckert, Secretary of the Air Force, reaffirmed today the United States' determination to maintain uncontrolled air access to West Berlin, both for military personnel and for civilians.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Mrs. Theodore W. Hawes of Summit, N.J., became the champion of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association today.
A long-accepted hazard to cancer surgery may not really exist, according to two scientific reports out today.

Abraham A. Ribicoff, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, yesterday challenged hospital administrators to give public as well as private support to care for the aging through Social Security.
Gilbert Ancowitz, New York realty investor, has purchased a three-acre supermarket property occupied by the A. P. in Ledgewood, Roxbury Township, N.J., near Dover.
A 20-year-old secretary was found shot dead yesterday in a midtown office with her employer's revolver.

The movement of retailers into the discount field picked up added steam yesterday when the F.W. Woolworth Company disclosed details of its proposed nation-wide chain of Woolco discount department stores.
It is perhaps excusable if we fail to understand the motives of other countries, but there is no excuse for misunderstanding our own.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- A Brooklyn horse player who believes in long shots has asked the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court to help him collect $1,295 he won at Jamaica race track two years ago.
RHODES, Greece, Sept. 28 -- The Pan-Orthodox conference explored today the possibilities of closer association, or even unity, with other churches of the East and of the West.
TOKYO, Sept. 28 -- The Japanese Government emphasized today its determination to act politically "in close concert" with the West.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Dr. Erich Mende, leader of the Free Democratic party, dropped his demand tonight that Chancellor Adenauer resign. He indicated he might be willing to support him for another year.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers clinched second place in the National League tonight with a 10-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- The American Medical Association announced today a program to help Cuban physicians in this country who are refugees from the Castro Government. It indicated there are 1,200 of them.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28 (AP) -- In a series of emergency orders today to counter the uprising, President Nasser discharged six Syrian military officers. They defied the orders.

At the age of 76, when most men have long since retired, John J. Totten is walking into a brand-new job. With the begining of 1962 he will become the first house manager at the new Philharmonic Hall at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, which will open next fall.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 28 -- Economic integration of the Americas in a potentially tariff-free association was suggested today by Clarence D. Martin Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Sept. 28 -- Senator Barry Goldwater told a Western Republican conference tonight that the greatest Republican landslide in history would result if the elections of 1962 were held tomorrow.
GENEVA, Sept. 28 -- The International Control Commission in Laos has warned of the "gravity" of the situation there.
Mayor Wagner's two principal opponents for election protested yesterday the way $25,000 in campaign gifts had been solicited from persons who do business with the city.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Senator Strom Thurmond, who has accused the Pentagon of "muzzling" its officers, will go on active Army Reserve duty Oct. 7 for two weeks at the Pentagon.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 28 -- An unauthorized walkout of 700 longshoremen brought work on local piers to a standstill today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- As the United Nations continues its search for a Secretary General to replace Dag Hammarskjold, the work of its Secretariat is being conducted -- as one source put it -- "around the desk of Andrew W. Cordier."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Sonny Liston, a contender for the heavyweight boxing title, was acquitted today of a charge of turning off his automobile lights to avoid arrest by the police. Liston, because of the charge, had been suspended from boxing by the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission.

A battle to block the confirmation of Irving Ben Cooper as a Federal judge in the Southern District of New York was strongly indicated last night when it was learned the American Bar Association had rated him "not qualified."
The new 3,500-horsepower Diesel-electric tug M. Moran will leave from Port Arthur, Tex., tomorrow for Korea on her first commercial assignment.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Crawford H. Greenewalt and Ben D. Dorfman have never met, but their fates became entwined during behind-the-scenes maneuvering as the Senate wound up its business.
Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, announced yesterday that the Milbank Memorial Fund had given $100,000 toward the construction of a student center on the Barnard campus.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 28 -- The United Nations set a new deadline tonight for the expulsion of about 100 white mercenaries still serving in the Katanga army.
GROTON, Mass., Sept. 28 -- Three students were expelled from the Groton School last spring for entertaining friends with tape-recordings made in a house master's residence without his knowledge.
VIENNA, Sept. 28 -- Proceedings at the general conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency today echoed the East-West struggle at the United Nations General Assembly in New York.
The City Council elected Herbert B. Evans yesterday to an interim term in the Council expiring Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission reprimanded the American Broadcasting Company today for not informing viewers that an episode in its TV series on Al Capone was fictional.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A capacity audience in the Theater Des Westens here gave Igor Stravinsky a fifteen-minute standing ovation today when he appeared to conduct the Santa Fe (N.M.) Opera Company in a performance of his musical drama "Persephone."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Freight loadings last week were reported higher than the preceding week's level by both the rail road and trucking industries.

General Aniline and Film Corporation, which soon may be returned by the United States Government to public ownership, has a new chairman and chief executive officer. The election of John I Snyder Jr. to the two posts was announced yesterday, following retirement of Thomas A. Morgan as chairman.
The cab driver discharged his passenger, a woman of middle age, at Eighty-eighth Street and Second Avenue shortly after 8:30 P.M. Wednesday.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Plans for modifying the new Constitution of the West Indies Federation were completed here today at the conclusion of a series of conferences.

SAN DONA DI PLAVE, Italy, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Seven Italian nuns of the cloistered Order of St. Claire have been ousted as a result of a month-long dispute that erupted into fighting within convent walls.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 28 -- Programs of popular tunes broadcast from Communist East Germany indicate that propaganda has engulfed the entertainment field.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Some of the personal and political consequences of Richard M. Nixon's decision to run for Governor of California are in plain view. Others are obscure and will not fully materialize until the end of the Republican National Convention of 1964.

A scathing indictment of the "gravediggers of advertising who are helping to bury their own business" was served as an aperitif to members of the Magazine Promotion Group prior to their luncheon meeting yesterday.

" Once upon a time, there lived in the mightiest city in the world a happily married couple." With this fairy-tale opening, Park Commissioner Newbold Morris began his dedication yesterday of Central Park's new Children's Zoo.

An Egyptian official, speaking after the 1958 merger of his country with Syria, said with a rueful smile: "Those Syrians are certainly difficult to govern." His remark sums up much of the brief history of the United Arab Republic.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Denmark suggested today that the United Nations relocate one of its agencies in Berlin.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Woodie Held drove in five runs and Wynn Hawking pitched steady relief ball today at the Cleveland Indians trounced the Minnesota Twins, 12-5.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Representatives of the United States and the Soviet Union met today and discussed their opposing plans for a temporary solution of the constitutional problem created by the death of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 28 -- The situation in Communist-threatened South Vietnam was described today as "dangerous" by the top United States military commander in the Pacific Asian area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- James B. Carey, labor leader, accused the National Association of Manufacturers today of having reverted to the "most primitive kind of isolationism" in dropping out of the International Labor Organization.
An Austrian editor who maintained contact during the war between anti-Nazi German physicists and Allied scientists was honored yesterday for long devotion to science.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Edward Heath, Lord Privy Seal, promised today that Britain would not be "a junior partner" in the European Common Market and the Commonwealth would not become "a backwater" as a result of her entry.
DETROIT, Sept. 28 -- The United Automobile Workers warned the Ford Motor Company today it would face a strike unless a new national agreement was reached by 10 A.M. next Tuesday.

IN this century of unending and often violent change many people over 50 can remember ways of life that already seem as remote as those of the Shakers or the Incas. It isn't necessary to have been a Grand Duke's child in imperial St. Petersburg. Wars, revolutions, fantastic and dread-fur inventions, social and political trans formations have made every pre-World-War-I childhood and many pre-World-War-II childhoods seem far away and long ago indeed.
New York State plans to offer $48,700,000 of bonds on Oct. 16 to raise money for acquisition of lands to be used for recreation areas and low-income housing.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Leon Wagner drove in eight runs with a grand-slam homer, two doubles and a sacrifice fly tonight as the Los Angeles Angels defeated the Washington Senators, 13 -- 4. The game drew only 1,681, the second smallest crowd of the season here.

Tickets may still be obtained for the theatre party to the matinee next Wednesday of "Mary, Mary" at the Helen Hayes Theatre that will be part of the current fund-raising program of the Child Care Women's League, Inc. They are also available for the Oct. 30 performance of "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying" at the 46th Street Theatre, which will also be part of the program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- An attempt will be made next year to send an instrumented space craft to the vicinity of Venus, but with a less powerful rocket than originally planned, the space agency said today.

Gimbels announced yesterday that it would keep its main store, on Thirty-third Street, open until 9 P.M. on Fridays, starting next week. Its action followed the lead of Macy's, which announced a similar move last week.

Builders will be encouraged to emphasize housing for low-income families in their construction programs in the next few years, Heal J. Hardy, Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, said here yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Tom Bolan, the president of Championship Sports, Inc., said tonight that the heavyweight championship bout between Floyd Patterson and the challenger, Tom McNeeley, would be held in a city other than Boston, probably on Nov. 20.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- The nation's capital is arranging a new bowl game to go with its new stadium.

The campaign committees for Mayor Wagner, State Controller Arthur Levitt and State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz filed accountings yesterday with the Board of Elections. The accounts detailed the funds the candidates received and spent for the Sept. 7 primaries for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, are expected to meet at least a half dozen more times in the coming weeks for long and detailed discussions on Berlin and Germany.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Sales and new orders of United States manufacturers continued to climb in August, extending a rise that began last February, the Department of Commerce reported today.
New York's radio stations, often much more specialized in audience than their television counterparts, are moving in many directions for the new season.
City Council President Abe Stark demanded an inquiry yesterday into why gasoline prices are 2 to 4 cents a gallon higher in New York City than in Nassau County.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 28 -- Afghanistan appeared today to have decided to depend almost entirely on the Soviet Union as her trade link with the outside world.

Earnings of the General Tire and Rubber Company for the nine months ended on Aug. 31 rose by 11 per cent to $18,061,334, or $3.20 a share, from the $16,272,431, or $2.90 a share, cleared for the fiscal 1960 period.
MANILA, Sept. 28 -- Jorge Freire Gonzales, embassy attache here for the Cuban Government, sought political asylum in the Philippines today as he was about to board a plane for a flight back to Cuba.

Columbia will open its football season against Brown at Providence tomorrow with its team at full strength. That's news. A year ago, Tom Vasell, a quarterback, and Bob McCool, a center, were already on the sidelines before this game because of pre-season injuries.

Mickey Mantle was hospitalized late yesterday with an abscess in the upper right hip and will miss the Yankees' final three games of the regular season. However, he is expected to play in the world series next week.
The sixth annual Polonaise Ball will take place Nov. 18 at the Sheraton-East.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Treasury offered today $2,000,000,000 of nineteen-month notes priced to yield 3.33 per cent as the second part of its undertaking to borrow $5,000,000,000.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 28 -- A program aimed at social reform and industrial development with financial stability was presented to Congress in Brasila today by Premier Tancredo Neves, leader of Brazils new Parliamentary Government.
Roger Maris is still seeking the elusive sixty-first home run that would give him the distinction of having hit more homers in one season than any player in major league history.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Space Agency has patented the escape tower that surmounts each Project Mercury capsule. If something goes wrong with the rocket booster, on the pad or in flight, the invention jerks the capsule up and out of harm's way.

The Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, under fire recently for its conduct of track and field and other sports in which it is this country's recognized international representative, called yesterday for an end to "petty bickering."

How do you burp a baby rabbit? The question was asked recently at a dinner party by an earnest suburban wife who had faced the problem that day. In her weeding she had plucked a clump of crabgrass and out tumbled two pink, tiny, newly born baby rabbits.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Deborah Bacon, dean of women at the University of Michigan for eleven years, resigned today.

Emile Griffith, the 23-year-old world welterweight champion, is a 3-1 favorite to retain his title when he meets the former champion, Benny (Kid) Paret, in a fifteen-round match in Madison Square Garden tonight.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 29 -- Rosel H. Hyde, who has been a member of the Federal Communications Commission since 1946, said today he was opposed to having the commission "exert a more direct influence on the programing of radio and broadcast television stations."
The Administration's health-care-for-the-aged bill was termed a "hoax" here yesterday by Senator Robert S. Kerr, who was a sponsor of the Kerr-Mills Act, now in effect.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Vice President Johnson arrived tonight from Sweden, where he attended the funeral of Dag Hammarskjold.
The A.O. Smith Corporation announced yesterday that its board of directors had voted to reduce the quarterly dividend because of "disappointing" operations in the fiscal year ended on July 31.
TUNIS, Sept. 29 -- An agreement was signed today for the evacuation of French troops from the Tunisian city of Bizerte and its surrounding area.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Wildcat overcame the handicap of a bad start today and won a race from Britain's Hellcat, making things a bit more rosy in the American.
ALBANY, Sept. 29 -- The State University announced a timetable today for converting its teacher-training colleges of education into general purpose institutions over the next five years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced plans today for a program designed to develop a whirling gas method of producing nuclear fuel and explosives.

THE volume of news presentations in good evening time, already one of the bright spots in television's record of accomplishment, was further increased last night with the introduction of Frank McGee's new regular half hour "Here and Now" over Channel 4.
NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- Charles Dillon Stengel, banker, leaned back in his swivel chair today and beamed his joy at again becoming Casey Stengel, baseball's nonpareil manager.

NEWARK, Sept. 29 -- The spokesman for two groups promoting interracial relations in Newark today revised their opinion that unrest between Negroes and Puerto Ricans had caused a riot Wednesday of 400 teen-agers. Thirteen persons were arrested after the clash with policemen and firemen outside a police station.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, Sept. 30 -- Syria won independence by force of arms from the United Arab Republic yesterday and a new conservative regime promised today that there would be elections and constitutional rule.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The Financial Times industrial shares index fell below the 300 mark today for the first time this year. In the foreign exchange market, however, the pound sterling reached a high for the year against the United States dollar.
TOKYO, Sept. 29 -- Premier Khrushchev again has warned Japan that the presence of United States military bases is a threat to this country's safety.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The new economic arm of the North Atlantic community, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, will start its formal existence tomorrow.

The General Pulaski Memorial Committee will hold a Fifth Avenue parade tomorrow in honor of Count Casimir Pulaski of Poland, who served as a brigadier general in the Continental Army in the American Revolution. More than 100,000 persons are expected to march.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman, President Kennedy's firs appointment to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, was sworn in yesterday.
The twenty-fifth anniversary of World-Wide Communion Sunday, symbolizing the unity of all Christians, will be marked tomorrow in Protestant churches around the world.

CAIRO, Sept. 29 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser told Egyptians tonight that he had called off armed resistance to the Syrian coup against the United Arab Republic. He appealed to the Syrian people to preserve "the rights they have earned" through union with Egypt.

While the necessity of giving private financial aid to colleges is widely accepted, the need for philanthropic support of independent elementary and secondary schools is too often overlooked. There are about 3,000 such schools throughout the country, enrolling more than 1,300,000 students. A recent survey of 400 of these institutions showed that they had given $6,000,000 in scholarship assistance to needy pupils in one year.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Bobby Fischer of the United States and Miguel Najdorf of Argentina played to a draw tonight in the Bled chess tournament.
Stock prices fell this month on the New York Stock Exchange as unsettled domestic and world-wide economic and political factors depressed prices.

The Kratter Corporation,, New York real estate investment company, plans to offer its shareholders $100,000,000 of 16 per cent subordinated debentures due in 1976, with warrants attached for the purchase of 2,000,000 Class A common shares.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 cents a bale up on old October to unchanged to 40 cents off on the other contracts yesterday.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Jake Wood's two-run single to left in the tenth inning today enabled the Detroit Tigers to post a 6-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Warren Spahn pitched the Milwaukee Braves to a rain-shortened 4-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight for his twenty-first victory of the season. The triumph kept alive the Braves' hopes for a third-place tie in the National League.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 29 -- The Congolese Central Government announced today that it had refused accreditation to a diplomatic mission from East Germany.
The metropolitan area schoolboy football season will go into full swing today.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker flew back to the United States today for a twenty-day leave.
The Freethinkers of America moved in State Supreme Court yesterday to prevent the construction of three religious chapels at the New York International Airport.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Champion Shady Hill's Bit O'Copper, a black and tan owned by Mr. and Mrs. H. Terrell Van Ingen of Greenwich, Conn., was best of breed at the Cocker Spaniel Club of Long Island's twenty-ninth specialty show yesterday.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 29 -- College students armed with rolls of nickels have been filling parking meters showing the word "violation" in the Town of Hempstead to help a political candidate.
A traffic light facing the "wrong way" on Forty-fifth Street at Lexington Avenue has a legitimate, but limited, purpose.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Hank Foiles hit a home run with one out in the tenth inning tonight to give the Baltimore Orioles a 3-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

Despite a loss of approximately $30,000 in its first venture, the nine-man Sports International Inc. syndicate is in the six-day bicycle race promotion business to stay, according to David J. Paully, the president of the firm.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Negotiators for the International Harvester Company and the United Auto Workers tried to agree on terms for a new contract today -- the eve of the expiration of the old contract.
MIAMI, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Guided by two crippled quarterbacks, the Miami Hurricanes displayed startling ground and air power tonight to crush Penn State's eighth-ranked college football team, 25 -- 8.
Roger Maris did not hit his sixty-first home run last night at Yankee Stadium. Bill Monbouquette, a right-hander with a "sneaky fist" pitch, saw to that.

Dag Hammarskjold died September 18, on the eve of the Sixteenth Session of the U.N. General Assembly. This tragedy offered the Russians an opportunity to push for a three-headed, four-headed, or even five-headed substitute for the single Secretary General. For the Western world it presented a depressing problem.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Prices for farm products rose nearly one-half of 1 per cent between mid-August and mid-September, the Department of Agriculture reported yesterday. Higher prices for dairy products, citrus fruits, grains, hogs and tobacco were primarily responsible for the increase.

ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 29 (AP) -- George Lincoln Rockwell, leader of the American Nazi Party, was held in contempt of court today for delay in making support payments for three children by a previous marriage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities will conduct hearings next week on the formation of an organization that has been called part of a drive against the law requiring Communist groups to register with the Government.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy ordered the demotion yesterday of Deputy Chief Inspector John T. Bradt Jr. to the rank of Inspector.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The House-Senate Atomic Energy Committee said today it had sent President Kennedy a secret report on handling of nuclear weapons abroad, including recommendations for avoiding "accidental wars."
Casey Stengel is returning to town.
The starting signal is about to be given for detailed design of an Air Force-Navy fighter able to cross any ocean without refuelling and to operate from short fields or aircraft carriers.
A sponsor's objections to television scripts involving pregnancy and out-of-wedlock fatherhood were described at a Government inquiry here yesterday.
Lawrence Welk, facing keen Saturday night competition from network movies and Westerns on other channels, is planning some variations on his usual American Broadcasting Company TV program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, urged Congress today to free the General Aniline Film Corporation of what he called the dead hand of Federal management and control.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The coup in Syria was as great a surprise to the British as it was to President Nasser.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported there were some indications of lower interests rates on conventional mortgages early this month.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Sabre, Ernest B. Fay's defender from Houston, Tex., retained the national championship in the 5.5-meter class today by finishing second in the fifth and final race of the sailing series.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Britain can best serve the Commonwealth by playing a "full part" in the development of Europe's economic and political unity, Prime Minister Macmillan declared tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- Sigma Delta Chi, the national professional journalism society, honored Benjamin Franklin today by placing a bronze plaque at the site where he published The Pennsylvania Gazette and Poor Richard's Almanac.
An action to invalidate the nominating petitions of the Citizens party designating Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa as a mayoral candidate was started yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
EASTCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- For the last four years a post office has been at 155 Fisher Avenue here and Eastchester has been an official postal address.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Elvis J. Stahr Jr. said today the stronger United States forces built up during the Berlin crisis must be maintained for years to come to thwart continuing Communist threats.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The last two of fifteen Episcopal clergymen arrested on charges of breach of the peace posted bond and left the city jail today.

A former tow-truck driver admitted in Special Sessions Court yesterday that he had bribed policemen, insurance adjusters and hack inspectors, had falsified accident reports and had smashed cars that had been in accidents to increase the repair bills.

A "Champion of Liberty" United States postage stamp honoring Dag Hammarskjold is in order. Its issuance would provide the United States Government and the American people with an appropriate opportunity to pay homage to this bold pioneer for international action to promote world peace.

The market for new fixed-interest securities will be relatively inactive next week, with only $81,481,300 of bonds scheduled for sale. This compares with the impressive volume of $249,502,000 registered this week.
New legislation designed to prevent underworld control of waterfront union activity was upheld yesterday by Justice Saul S. Streit of the State Supreme Court.
NEW DELHI, India, Saturday, Sept. 30 (AP) -- One of America's weakest Davis Cup tennis teams in years faces India in interzone matches starting today.

WHEN a vegetable travels only a short distance to market, it usually means high quality and plentiful supplies. This is true of the sweet potato. The vegetable is available in varying quantities throughout the year, but it is at its best in the fall.

New York City has lived too long with a building code unsuited to its needs. A thoroughgoing revision has now been ordered -- the first major overhaul of the code since 1937. Rewriting of the code will take three years and cost some $800,000. When the work is finished it should be a worthy companion to the city's new zoning resolution that goes into effect on Dec. 15.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- The United States and the Soviet Union remained in sharp conflict today on the future leadership of the United Nations Secretariat.

In his two dispatches of Sept. 21 and 22 to The Times, Lawrence Fellows reported the slaying by Israeli border guards of five Arab youths who attempted an escape across the demarcation line between Israel and the Gaza Strip. These five would-be escapees unfortunately did not make it.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Sept. 29 -- Reports circulated today at the Western Republican Conference here that "Rockefeller money" was being sent into California to help finance next year's gubernatorial primary campaign of former Gov. Goodwin J. Knight against former Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
The New York Titans yesterday reacquired Bob Scrabis, a former Penn State quarterback.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The sponsors of Krebiozen, a controversial drug that has been used to treat cancer, turned over the chemical formula and clinical data on its use to the National Cancer Institute today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- President Kennedy will probably send a personal message to Premier Khrushchev next week to obtain a more precise indication of Moscow's approach to formal East-West negotiations on Berlin and Germany.
BOSTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Long-term unemployment in the United States is steadily growing and calls for remedial programs, the Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today.
TOKYO, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Premier Khrushchev rejected today an appeal from Premier Hayato Ikeda to end soviet nuclear-weapons tests.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 29 -- The Free Democratic party of Dr. Erich Mende accepted today an invitation from Chancellor Adenauer to join him for talks on a coalition Government.

FESTIVE olive and blue striped balloons herald the debut of "Nancy's Fancy," a decorative accessories shop, which opened this week at 1075 First Avenue (near Fifty-ninth Street). Those familiar with the neighborhood will remember this was formerly the site of East House, once a gift shop, now a wholesale establishment in another location.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Billy Haughton's entry of Caduceus, an 11-year-old New Zealand horse, and Apmat, an 8-year-old Australian, finished one, two tonight in the $25,000 Spirit of St. Louis Pace that highlighted the opening of Roosevelt Raceway's fall meeting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A push to complete President Kennedy's legislative program -- with medical care, postal-rate increases and tax revision high on the list -- will start as soon as Congress comes back in January, Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts said today.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The calendar puts it differently, but for Londoners this is really the beginning of the year. The long, long summer, which began with the running of the Derby early in June, is over.

VIENNA, Sept. 29 -- Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, and Prof. Vasily S. Yemelyanov, head of the Soviet Atomic Energy Authority, have had a number of private meetings in Vienna to discuss the continuation and possible expansion of United States-Soviet collaboration in the peaceful uses of atomic energy.
City Purchase Commissioner Roger J. Browne said yesterday that three chemical companies had submitted identical bids for supplying the city with calcium chloride flakes.

ALGIERS, Sept. 29 -- Maurice Joxe, French Minister for Algeria, arrived here today amid rumors that he was acting under instructions from President de Gaulle to pave the way for setting up a 50,000-man "local police force."
Two gunmen seized a $19,000 payroll in Brooklyn yesterday and shot a guard who reached for his pistol. An hour later, a lone gunman fled from a midtown pier with a $48,150 payroll and a hostage.

KEY WEST, Fla., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro's firing squads executed two men today and revolutionary tribunals sentenced forty-six other persons to long prison terms, the Havana radio reported.

The six story apartment building with self-service elevator at 43-17 Forty-eighth Street, Sunnyside, Queens, has been sold by the Realty Equities Corporation. On a plot 200 by 90 feet, it contains ninety-six apartments.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 29 (AP) -- A Polaris missile, testing a revolutionary thrust-control system for the first time, was launched successfully on a flight of several hundred miles today.
Twenty-seven witnesses told a legislative committee here yesterday that they favored changes in the state's liquor laws, but only one supported raising the minimum drinking age from 18 to 21.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Syria's divorce from the United Arab Republic has dealt a severe blow to Pan-Arabism, in the view of Near East experts here.
NEW DELHI, Indio, Saturday, Sept. 30 -- A crude bomb exploded near a bus stop in Delhi last night, just one and a half minutes after a car carrying Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru had passed.

Events today: Thomas Darson, pianist, Town Hall, 2:30 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano, Philippe Entremont, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Mira Gilbert, folk singer, Town Hall 8:30 P.M.; Carolyn Hester, folk singer, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30 P.M.
BERLIN, Sept. 29 -- The Soviet Union has protested increased patrolling of the Autobahn between Berlin and West Germany by the United States military police.
The Chicago Board of Education announced yesterday that it will offer to competitive bidding $8,500,000 of bonds due 1963 to 1981 on Oct. 24.
The New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N.J., is expected to be restored to the good graces of the Navy Department.

Enkells-Rakoff Co., realty investors, have taken title to the six-story building containing forty-four apartments and five stores at 2 Marble Hill Avenue, corner of Broadway. They bought the property recently from Philip Holtzer.

Among the many problems confronting the now leaderless United Nations is one that is surpassed in importance only by the Berlin crisis and the crisis over the Secretary Generalship. This problem is the Congo, where an uneasy truce threatens to explode into new violence that could again rock Africa, the United Nations and the world.
OTTAWA, Sept. 29 -- Canada's Parliament adjourned early this morning with the question of an early election still undecided.
DETROIT, Sept. 29 (UPI) At five minutes to three yesterday afternoon Miss Shirley Hutchinson, a second-grade teacher, ordered 7-year-old Gary Murphy to sit in the cloakroom for misbehaving.
DETROIT, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Jerry Gross and Jim Shorter paced the University of Detroit eleven to a 34-8 victory over Xavier of Ohio tonight before 15,750 at Titan Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The House highways investigating subcommittee said today that Florida must assume a full measure of blame for the highway scandal there.
DETROIT, Sept. 29 -- Following is the text of a pastoral letter issued here today by the Episcopal House of Bishops:

Bail of $1,000 was continued yesterday for Anne McKiernan, the waitress who was involved last Saturday in a dispute with the son of a Paraguayan United Nations official. A hearing was set for next Wednesday.
The New York Criminal and Civil Courts Bar Association announced its endorsement yesterday of Irving Ben Cooper for the Federal bench here.
Moving men put dollies under the desk of Carmine G. De Sapio at 331 Madison Avenue yesterday as the new leaders of the New York County Democratic Committee began to take over Tammany Hall.

The uprising in Syria against Egypt has now taken form in a Syrian Government in Damascus. The situation is still far from clear; but the United Arab Republic, founded in 1958, is at least temporarily no longer united. This is a major development that could affect the current history of the Arab world in a profound way.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept, 29 (UPI) -- A sophomore halfback, Andy Tucker, ran 101 yards with an intercepted pass tonight for the touchdown that enabled Virginia Military Institute to beat Richmond, 8 -- 6.

Garcilaso, considered today one of the greatest of South-American writers, was born in Peru in 1539, the son of an Inca princess and a Spanish conquistador. At the age of 21 he left his native country for Spain, where he took part in the wars against the Italians and Moors.
The Government is suing an airline pilot for $1,000 because he refused to let a Federal Aviation Agency inspector sit in the cockpit of a jet airliner on a segment of a trans-Atlantic flight.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Two former French Premiers and rival leaders of the French political Left met today for the first time in more than three years.
WHAT promises to be an amusing, well made television version of "The Father of the Bride" made its debut last night on Channel 2.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in theI stocks from which the averages are computed, the combinedI trading in both classes of issues, as well as the total daily] transactions for week and month:
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Cornell University's football situation might be termed the new frontier of the Ivy League.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Army today awarded fifteen contracts totaling $84 546,775 for ammunition production and maintenance of ammunition plants.
ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa sought today to suppress wiretap evidence he said United States attorneys were using to try to re-indict him for misuse of $500,000 in union funds.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Lieut. Comdr. Harold F. Skelly recommended today a decoration for Electrician's Mate 1/C John J. McGee, 40 years old, of Chula Vista, Calif., whom he credited with saving the submarine Charr and her seventy men.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 29 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to have offered to buy fresh and dried fruits that Afghanistan was unable to sell because of a suspension of trade across her border with Pakistan.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- A voter campaign designed to enable Negroes to "change the political structure of the South and the nation" was pledged today by a leading integrationist organization.

Air France has broadened its United States corporate structure "to meet new marketing and sales demands" resulting from the company's jet expansion program. Henri J. Lesieur, general manager for the French carrier's North, Central American and Caribbean divisions, announced the change yesterday.
The American Ballet Theatre will benefit from "A Gala Evening of Ballet," which will feature its premiere performance of the new ballet "Etudes" at the 54th Street Theatre on Thursday.
