DETROIT, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company announced today plans for immediate construction of $15,000,000 in new facilities to increase natural gas deliveries to twenty-nine utilities in five Midwestern states.
The Navy Bureau of Ships announced yesterday the award of contracts for the reactivation of two tankers to New York harbor shipyards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered the United States airlines today to specify in their rate schedules the type of aircraft and seating arrangement used for each service.
Prices for regular coffee were lowered 2 cents a pound at both the wholesale and retail levels yesterday. The cuts become effective on Monday.

RHODES, Greece, Sept. 29. -- The Pan Orthodox Conference of Rhodes -- the first assembly of twelve major Eastern Orthodox Churches since 1787 -- unanimously approved today a list of theological, ecclesiastical and social topics to be debated at a future Pan-Orthodox gathering, the Ecumenical Pro-Synod.
BUFFALO, Sept. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller today revived his proposal that groups of school districts be allowed to levy their own sales taxes to raise more money for public education.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Almost half of the grain futures contracts on the Board of Trade finished unchanged or within minimum fractions of preceding closes after an aimless session today, limited mostly to evening up commitments for the week-end.

Trading was dull on the New York Commodity exchanges yesterday. Lead, zinc, rubber and sugar futures prices rose slightly; copper, hides, coffee, wool and cottonseed oil declined and cocoa and potatoes were narrowly irregular.

FOR women who love animals, a new career has opened. Two girls in their twenties, Miss Carolyn George and Miss Tatiana Gillette, are provisional menagerie keepers at the Central Park Zoo. This is an innovation for the Department of Parks Service in New York. Until now, women have worked as attendants for visitors, but have not been in charge in the cages.
Gary Sigurdson, first flutist of the Kansas City Philharmonic, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.
Flotations of new bonds in September were at the highest level since June but remained below the levels for September in the two preceding years.

MAHMOUN AL-KUZBARI, the new Syrian Premier, is a conservative, a mild-mannered man toward whom dynamic politicians turn in explosive situations. The Arabic meaning of his first name -- "the trusted one" -- is apt.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 29 -- Jordan promptly recognized the Syrian rebels today in the latest move in this country's quarrel with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.
Dr. Hollis L. Caswell resigned yesterday as president of Teachers College, Columbia University.

The lights that Macy's and Gimbels burn at their downtown stores on Friday nights starting next week will have been turned on by shopping centers across the nation. The decision of the retailing giants of Herald Square and Greeley Square to stay open a third night every week follows a trend that got its start when the post-war growth of the suburbs revolutionized American shopping habits.
SIX weeks of the Gallic approach were inaugurated yesterday at the season's opening concert of the New York Philharmonic.
The construction concern that held the prime contract for the new City College School of Technology building accused the Board of Higher Education yesterday of a breach of contract.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller said tonight fall-out shelters in homes and other buildings would have to be made compulsory "at some point." He recommended income tax deductions to encourage property owners to build them.
ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Cases of poliomyelitis decreased this week by about one-third from the previous week, the Communicable Disease Center said today.
Sam Snead's appeal to the Professional Golfers Association for reinstatement so that he might be a member of the Ryder Cup team has been turned down.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court called today for quick United States recognition of Outer Mongolia and its immediate entry into the United Nations.

In a dull and dreary session of the New York Stock Exchange, stocks inched forward yesterday. More stocks rose than fell and the leading averages rose somewhat but enthusiasm was confined to a handful of specialties.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 -- The bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church called on their 3,500,000 constituents today to shun parochialism and to work with patience and sacrifice for the end of a divided Christendom.
For thirty-five years and four months Mrs. Margie Goodman has been one of the impersonal faces seen by subway riders as they hastily scoop up tokens and cash and dash for their trains.
Five productions will be offered by the New York City Opera in the first week of its thirty-fifth season at the City Center.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Jim O'Toole of the Cincinnati Reds gave one run and four hits tonight in a five-inning tune-up for the world series as the Reds routed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 -- 1.

The Carrie Realty Corporation has sold the six-story building containing fifty-nine apartments at 130 Lenox Road in the Flatbush area of Brooklyn. The property, with a plot 95 by 166 feet, is assessed at $245,000.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP) -- 1 Laders of industry, labor andI the nation's armed forces paidI final tribute today to Charles i E. Wihon, former Secretary of J Defense and former president] of the General Motors Corporation.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 29 -- President Kennedy is considering a plan to sponsor seminars in key cities to build public support for medical care for the aged and other Administration proposals.

UPPSALA, Sweden, Sept. 29 -- Dag Hammarskjold, acclaimed as "the devoted servant of all mankind," was buried here today in the presence of representatives of those he had served. The state funeral accorded the United Nations Secretary General by the Swedish Government, with King Gustaf VI Adolf and Queen Louise in attendance, became almost a world funeral.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29 -- The rapidly increasing cost of a Harvard education may eventually limit enrollment in the College to a small "economic elite," according to Wilbur J. Bender, former Dean of Admissions and Financial Aids.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- A 48-year-old banker, Sir Frederick Hoare, was found "fit and able" today to be Lord Mayor of the City of London. He succeeds Sir Bernard Waley-Cohen.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The National Labor Relations Board, in a reversal of policy, ruled today that the agency shop is legal in Indiana, a "right-to-work" state.
WILLIAM ROOT has been appointed games authority for the Association of American Playing Card Manufacturers, the association announced last week.

Blanche Yurka, one of the theatre's most distinguished actresses, will head a cast of theatrical unknowns tonight when the Equity Library Theatre begins its eighteenth season with Emlyn Williams' "The Corn Is Green."
Sales and earnings of the Green Shoe Manufacturing Company for the nine months ended on Aug. 31 rose from the year-earlier levels, the concern reported yesterday.
The winning bid for the Argo Oil Corporation has been made by the Atlantic Refining Company in a spirited contest with the Sinclair Oil Corporation.

Some time between Oct. 3 and 8 the world will witness an unprecedented event: the conduct of a political demonstration in Moscow's Red Square independently by a group of Americans and West Europeans. The demonstrators will denounce the Soviet resumption of nuclear testing and will call upon the Government, as they have called upon others, both East and West, to cease all war preparations and take unilateral steps toward disarming.
CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Pennsylvania scored 24 points in ten singles matches today to lead the annual golf competition for the Lesley Cup at the Pine Valley Golf Club.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Two rounds were completed in the twenty-eighth annual New Jersey pro-amateur four-ball golf championship today but the defending champions and the medalists failed to get by the first round.

ROME, Sept. 29 -- After four days of foreign policy debate the Chamber of Deputies expressed tonight its approval of the support shown by the Government of Premier Amintore Fanfani for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Twelve thousand persons will march up Fifth Avenue today in honor of Germany's historic ties with this country in the annual Steuben Day parade.
The Syrian revolt appears to be a serious setback for President Gamal Abdel Nasser's ambitions to lead Arab nationalism. It also seems to create a new breathing space for Israel.

S.J. PERELMAN is the enfant terrible emeritus of modern American humor. He has been entertaining the country with wild and wacky pieces throughout his alarmingly perpetual youth. And, as his new book -- "The Rising Gorge"* -- shows, he still stands with unreluctant feet where the styles of Groucho Marx and Benchley meet.
WHEN he became President of the United States, John F. Kennedy automatically took title to humble little craft that was once described as "the world's most luxurious floating locker room."
Mayor Wagner agreed yesterday to a Board of Ethics inquiry into the way that gifts to his political campaign had been solicited from persons who have business with city agencies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said today Soviet industrial output was growing rapidly but ten years from now would still be 25 to 40 per cent behind that of the United States.

Bonds called for redemption before maturity aggregated $39,843,000 in September. This represented an increase from the $23,669,000 of redemptions for August but was below the $52,559,000 level of September, 1960.
Ivy League teams and the mighty of the Big Ten, headed by Ohio State and Iowa, join the parade today as the intercollegiate football procession reaches full stride across the land.
The Long Island Rail Road moved back into the red last month after showing profits for three consecutive months.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday ordered an investigation into the higher prices paid for gasoline by motorists in New York City.
A salesman's lot can be a very happy one. It all depends on the reception he receives.
